column5: We don‰Ûªt actually see any of the environmental damage or social disruption, and there are no succinct summations of the timeline or the issues as in a traditional documentary, a decision that costs the film some urgency. The speakers meander, and the film seems unfocused. But perhaps that‰Ûªs the point. A recurring theme of the speakers is that they are resigned to having their concerns disregarded; it is, they say, just another example in a long history of cavalier treatment of American Indians and their heritage. Certainly, at this point, the oil work is not going to be stopped. Mr. Brook and Ms. Wells are in a sense not documenting a controversy at all; they are capturing an endemic, heartbreaking defeatism.

‰ÛÏA Different American Dream‰Ûù takes an unfamiliar approach to documenting the controversy surrounding oil exploration on tribal lands in North Dakota. It‰Ûªs not particularly successful, having the odd effect of making the issues seem less urgent than they are, but at least it lets opponents of the drilling be heard at longer than sound-bite length.

Oil company operations on the lands of the American Indian confederation known as the Mandan, Hidatsa and Arikara Nation have caused all sorts of upheaval and have left residents divided over whether the oil revenue is a good or a bad thing. The filmmakers, Simon Brook (writer and director) and Jane Wells (writer and producer), basically allow a handful of opponents to talk at length about their concerns. (The pro-oil faction gets only a brief hearing.) The worries cover a broad range: environmental degradation, disruption of ancestral lands and traditions, demographic changes, uneven distribution of the oil revenue and more.

Stories like that make a particular moment in this movie even more pertinent: Mr. Davis, speaking to Faith Morris of the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis, poses a knotty question about how far his cause of eliminating race hate has yet to go. Her reply: ‰ÛÏHow long is this documentary going to be?‰Ûù
He goes to the Lincoln Memorial and points out the spot where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his ‰ÛÏI Have a Dream‰Ûù speech.

The African-American musician Daryl Davis, a journeyman who has played backup for Chuck Berry, has an unusual hobby. He cultivates cordial relationships with prominent racists ‰ÛÓ Ku Klux Klan leaders, front men for neo-Nazi groups and so on ‰ÛÓ and through a form of friendly persuasion, tries to steer them from their bigotry.

‰ÛÏAccidental Courtesy: Daryl Davis, Race & America,‰Ûù directed by Matt Ornstein, begins by showing Mr. Davis tooling around the D.C. area, where he lives. He speaks with friends and neighbors, some African-American, some not. One of his stops is Ben‰Ûªs Chili Bowl, where he interviews the owner, Virginia Ali, a friend, about progress and setbacks in race relations.

The movie follows Mr. Davis to Los Angeles, where he delivers a lecture. He tells his audience, ‰ÛÏAlways keep the lines of communication with your antagonist open,‰Ûù because ‰ÛÏif you‰Ûªre talking, you‰Ûªre not fighting.‰Ûù Then we see him patiently talking with white men and women who hold the most repellent views imaginable. When Mr. Davis tries to share his philosophy with Black Lives Matter activists, however, the discussion gets very heated ‰ÛÓ on both sides.

This movie arrives two weeks after Carl Paladino, a white political operative and ally of President-elect Donald J. Trump, equated the first lady, Michelle Obama, to a gorilla, then said in a follow-up interview that his remarks were ‰ÛÏnot racist.‰Ûù

Steven C. Miller is not such a director. And while Mr. Cage anchors only a few scenes in Mr. Miller‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏArsenal,‰Ûù his name is the biggest hook on which the movie hangs. Playing Eddie, a Mississippi crime boss, he hides beneath impenetrable shades, a dead-beaver wig and a joke shop nose-and-mustache combo ‰ÛÓ a disguise that reprises the one he wore as another Eddie in the 1993 thriller ‰ÛÏDeadfall.‰Ûù This time it frees him to indulge a character distinguished mainly by flying-spittle rages, which the cinematographer, Brandon Cox, captures with undeserving and wobbly reverence.

Nicolas Cage has been surviving on professional gruel for so long now that it seems churlish to ponder performances that, much like the movies around them, have bordered on cartoonish. An intelligent, occasionally eccentric actor, Mr. Cage has offbeat skills that have been best showcased by directors ‰ÛÓ like Martin Scorsese, Norman Jewison and Andrew Niccol ‰ÛÓ who know when to rein him in and when to let him fly.

The story is not terrible. Two brothers (Adrian Grenier and Johnathon Schaech) who survived a dirt-poor childhood in Biloxi, Miss., grow up to embrace very different lives. While the younger sweats honestly in his own construction company, the elder is a small-time hood who owes Eddie a debt he can‰Ûªt repay. At least, not without putting Family above family.

Despite solid acting (including John Cusack as a plainclothes detective), ‰ÛÏArsenal‰Ûù is hobbled mainly by its director‰Ûªs histrionic tendencies. Every bludgeoning needs an invisible gospel choir; every pummeling seems rendered in leering slow-motion. Come for the grungy Biloxi setting; stay for the stun grenade.

Throughout, the actors have a beautifully balanced rapport that prevents one from dominating the other. Mr. Feldman‰Ûªs pleading eyes and indecisive body language lend Henry an endearing immaturity, and Ms. Thirlby‰Ûªs gentle confidence makes Dianne‰Ûªs hurt all the more heartbreaking. As the couple try out romantic alternatives ‰ÛÓ he with an orgy-loving musician (Analeigh Tipton) and she with a married performance artist (Adam Goldberg) ‰ÛÓ the director holds the focus on the movie‰Ûªs essential question: What do you do when the life you want is incompatible with the love you have?
Stingingly attuned to the tension between long-term love and last-minute misgivings, ‰ÛÏBetween Us‰Ûù makes a familiar situation feel remarkably fresh.

For Dianne and Henry (Olivia Thirlby and Ben Feldman), a young Los Angeles couple celebrating six years together, the search for a new apartment opens an unexpected rift in their relationship. She wants to purchase a modern, spacious home in an upscale neighborhood; he wants to continue a bohemian downtown lifestyle ‰ÛÓ a vision he thought they shared. A stalled filmmaker in his 30s, Henry must confront not only his financial inadequacies but also something much more nebulous: his self-image.

A man shying from commitment is nothing new, but here the writer and director, Rafael Palacio Illingworth, injects small subtleties that enrich and complicate the emotional landscape. The couple‰Ûªs devotion is never in question, but Henry, who fetishizes the infatuation phase of a relationship, is constantly mourning something he may never have again. And Dianne chooses to ignore how her comfortable background might contribute to Henry‰Ûªs insecurities.

An unfinished version of ‰ÛÏGerman Concentration Camps Factual Survey‰Ûù was screened in September 1945, but then the film was abandoned, an apparent casualty of changing political priorities and a shift from renunciation to reconstruction. Simply put, the Allies needed Germans to rebuild their country. (According to one scholarly account, Mr. Bernstein was informed that ‰ÛÏpolicy at the moment in Germany is entirely in the direction of encouraging, stimulating and interesting the Germans out of their apathy.‰Ûù) An incomplete version of the film, titled ‰ÛÏMemory of the Camps,‰Ûù was released in 1984; some of the material was used in another documentary, ‰ÛÏA Painful Reminder‰Ûù (1985).

This troubling sense of familiarity soon dissipates, though, because this is not like most films. In contrast to many movies about atrocities, including some documentaries, there is nothing reassuring about ‰ÛÏGerman Concentration Camps Factual Survey.‰Ûù There are no hollow claims about the ‰ÛÏtriumph‰Ûù of the human spirit, no third-act heroics or narrative balms. The few smiles here are desperate. Mostly, there are starving survivors milling about the camps and staring into the camera with hollow eyes. Some lie on the floor, too frail to move; others drift about on stick legs. In most camps, the survivors appear outnumbered by the dead, with corpses scattered like refuse or in piles and in pits.

In 1945, the British producer Sidney Bernstein contacted his good friend Alfred Hitchcock for help on a horrific project. Mr. Bernstein, the chief of the film section of the Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force, had been present at the Nazi extermination camp Bergen-Belsen in April that year, soon after its liberation. The film he was preparing would serve as irrefutable evidence of Nazi atrocities and be shown to Germans and to the world. Mr. Bernstein wanted it to ‰ÛÏbe in the form of a prosecuting counsel stating his case.‰Ûù Hitchcock‰Ûªs contribution seems to have been advisory; he suggested, for instance, that the film use long takes to affirm the material‰Ûªs authenticity.

At once a document and a denunciation, the film builds its case rapidly and unblinkingly. It looks back at 1933 and the rise of National Socialism ‰ÛÓ using images of Hitler among the masses from the propaganda film ‰ÛÏTriumph of the Will‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ then skips forward to a number of recently liberated extermination camps. Some of this imagery will likely be familiar and not just to those who have watched other Holocaust documentaries. One of the eerie truths of this film is that, however difficult it is to watch, it can seem shocking, but not surprising, simply because such imagery has been so thoroughly incorporated into pop culture, either through direct citation or by inference.

More than half a century after Mr. Bernstein began work on this documentary, it has been at last completed and restored, and is now receiving a commercial release under the exacting, straightforward title ‰ÛÏGerman Concentration Camps Factual Survey.‰Ûù The title‰Ûªs blandness is appropriate given the bluntness of the prosecutorial narration (read by an actor, Jasper Britton) and the unsparingly graphic evidentiary visuals. Most of the film consists of material shot inside and near several extermination camps, including Dachau and Auschwitz; much of the imagery is heart-crushing and extremely tough to watch, consisting of newly freed skeletal men, women and children and thousands of corpses.

‰ÛÏGerman Concentration Camps Factual Survey‰Ûù was finally finished and restored in 2014 by the Imperial War Museums, in Britain, where the original elements had been kept. Its history is long and tangled. It began as an Allied endeavor and, according to the historian Toby Haggith, the director of the restoration, was meant to include concluding statements from President Harry S. Truman, Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin. (Dr. Haggith has written a useful, concise history of the documentary that is available on the British Film Institute‰Ûªs website.) The Americans, however, opted to produce their own film, ‰ÛÏDeath Mills‰Ûù (1946), directed by Billy Wilder. Mr. Bernstein continued working on the original project; Hitchcock, Mr. Haggith writes, may have contributed to the script.

This restoration of ‰ÛÏGerman Concentration Camps Factual Survey‰Ûù is an extraordinary act of cinematic reclamation and historiography. The documentary proper runs about 75 minutes and is book-ended by two new sequences, including a brief introduction that offers critical viewing context. Just as crucial, though, is a longer postscript that includes interviews with some of the principals involved in the Imperial War Museums‰Ûª restoration. They contribute more on the film‰Ûªs complex history, but they also talk about how hard this material is to watch, offering a much-needed humanizing coda. One man suggests that you may at times need to close your eyes; mostly, though, you need to watch.
‰ÛÏMaster‰Ûù is a routine South Korean crime thriller whose bloat magnifies its generic qualities. The movie seems to float the same double crosses two or three times.

Scenery changes ‰ÛÓ much of the second half takes place in Manila ‰ÛÓ and elaborate cons (Kim impersonates a money launderer who must rank among the world‰Ûªs least discreet) add to the aura of a mediocre James Bond picture. But slick production values can‰Ûªt disguise the lack of imagination.

Although Jin‰Ûªs gurulike speech might connote Steve Jobs, and the vast arena portends a set piece like the assassination that opens Brian De Palma‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSnake Eyes,‰Ûù the director, Cho Ui-seok, zeros in on an audience member: Park Jang-gun (Kim Woo-bin), One Network‰Ûªs computer systems manager. After the speech, he is grilled by two officers, Kim Jae-myung (Kang Dong-won) and Shin Gemma (Uhm Ji-won), as part of a fraud investigation.
The action kicks off with a speech by Jin Hyun-pil (Lee Byung-hun), chairman of the One Network corporation. In reality, One Network bilks investors and maintains a far-reaching web of bribes.

Whether they can trust Park as a mole ‰ÛÓ and whether Jin will continue to trust him ‰ÛÓ is a question that hovers over the first half, as Park and his uneasy allies try to acquire an incriminating ledger, which Jin hides behind a tastefully illuminated liquor rack in a secret basement bunker. (Like all supervillain lairs, this one comes with a giant fish tank.)

Mr. Pront doesn‰Ûªt have much new to say on these themes, but he does have a strong sense of place and a brisk, gritty directing style. Even though, in retrospect, ‰ÛÏThe Ardennes‰Ûù feels a little obvious and secondhand, it unfolds with enough speed and wit to hold your attention. Keep your eye out for ostriches.

Kenny (Kevin Janssens), with a slick of dark hair down the middle of his head and a Kirk Douglas dimple in the center of his chin, is the wilder sibling, eager to fight and possessing a certain thuggish charm. Dave (Jeroen Perceval), bald and slight, is comparatively quiet and sensitive. Sylvie (Veerle Baetens), who works in a nightclub and goes to recovery meetings, seems tougher and more levelheaded than either brother, though you have to wonder a bit about her taste in men. And you might also wonder where the boys‰Ûª mother (Viviane de Muynck) went wrong.

In any case, ‰ÛÏThe Ardennes,‰Ûù directed by Robin Pront, takes an effective (if not terribly original) pulp premise and executes it with a decent measure of soul and skill. The film‰Ûªs title refers to the densely forested part of Belgium where the  Battle of the Bulge was fought in World War II, and the plot swerves from the unspecified Flemish city where Dave, Kenny and Sylvie live toward that savage sylvan landscape. The brothers (and the audience) find a few surprises there, a handful of colorful secondary characters and some arresting nonnative fauna.

The machinery of the plot is propelled by a grim sense of lower-depth fatalism. Sylvie, in her meetings and in conversations with Dave, talks about taking control and making choices, but Kenny‰Ûªs return threatens to make a cruel joke of their optimism. The rules of this genre dictate that people can‰Ûªt change, that those who try to pull themselves out are dragged back in, and that blood loyalty and bloodshed are never very far apart.

In the minute or so before the opening titles of ‰ÛÏThe Ardennes,‰Ûù Dave, Kenny and Sylvie participate in a botched crime for which Kenny ‰ÛÓ Dave‰Ûªs brother and Sylvie‰Ûªs boyfriend ‰ÛÓ takes the fall. By the time he‰Ûªs out of prison four years (which is to say a few seconds) later, Sylvie and Dave have sobered up and conceived a child. This makes for an awkward Christmastime homecoming.

With an almost willful lack of fun, ‰ÛÏUnderworld: Blood Wars‰Ûù introduces new dangers (self-propelled bullets and nightshade ‰ÛÓ fatal for some vampires, but only painful and paralyzing for Selene) and backdrops, including a vampire outpost in the frozen north and what must be history‰Ûªs dullest vampire soiree. (After so many years undead, who could party?)

The ‰ÛÏUnderworld‰Ûù franchise ‰ÛÓ in which vampires and werewolves, called Lycans, use guns and swords to settle a centuries-old feud ‰ÛÓ showed signs of growing more playful with its fourth installment, ‰ÛÏUnderworld: Awakening‰Ûù (2012), which moved away from the series‰Ûªs labored mythology and threw in Stephen Rea as a mad scientist.

The series‰Ûªs strategy of bathing its imagery in blue has always been useful for obscuring murky special effects, but here, it seems like a taunt ‰ÛÓ a guarantee of visual monotony to complement the anemic entertainment value.

Returning, in her full leather get-up, is Selene (Kate Beckinsale, somehow still invested), a vampire ‰ÛÏdeath dealer‰Ûù wanted by both sides. Apparently, her blood and the blood of her daughter (who has gone into hiding since the last movie) can confer special powers on those infused with it ‰ÛÓ a property that has made the strains sought after by the vampire council member Semira (Lara Pulver) and a Lycan leader, Marius (Tobias Menzies).

Any hope of a similarly limber fifth outing dies immediately in ‰ÛÏUnderworld: Blood Wars.‰Ûù This film is so heavy with exposition that you would think that the director, Anna Foerster, and the screenwriter, Cory Goodman, had set out to complete a dissertation instead of a sequel.

The frantic plot concerns the Straw Hats‰Ûª visit to Gran Tesoro, a six-mile-long floating casino and entertainment complex impervious to government intervention, and run by the perfidious mastermind Gild Tesoro. Gamblers become starving indentured servants, and the Straw Hats liberate them in escalating battles rendered with a crude line and an often, well, golden palette. If you‰Ûªre a boy between, say, 8 and 12 and wired to the hilt on Coca-Cola, the shrill, exhausting ‰ÛÏGold‰Ûù might be for you. But only if.

In ‰ÛÏGold,‰Ûù we are fleetingly introduced to these youthful buccaneers, seemingly plucked from disparate movie genres: Zoro is a swordsman; Chopper, a cute, cartoony reindeer evoking a PokÌ©mon; Sanji, a ladies‰Ûª man; Franky, a cyborg; Usopp, a sniper; Brook, a skeleton. Their volatile leader, Luffy, can stretch and enlarge his body, like Plastic Man; his sentences almost always end in multiple exclamation points. The female members ‰ÛÓ Nami, a cat burglar, and Robin, an archaeologist ‰ÛÓ are eye-roll-inducingly buxom.

If you‰Ûªre not familiar with the anime franchise ‰ÛÏOne Piece,‰Ûù based on Eiichiro Oda‰Ûªs manga, you‰Ûªll be completely lost at its 13th cinematic entry, ‰ÛÏOne Piece Film: Gold.‰Ûù The movie, directed by Hiroaki Miyamoto, doesn‰Ûªt provide a back story for its abundant characters. All you need to know is that the heroes, the Straw Hat pirates, are seagoing adventurers on a planet dominated by a world government. The pirates don‰Ûªt loot vessels; they simply seek lost treasure. (The series title comes from the name of a trove in the first installment.)

Murray comes across as personable, friendly, extremely thoughtful and wholly admirable. The movie, perhaps without intending to, demonstrates that one needn‰Ûªt be a prickly person to be a wonderful artist. Meryl Streep, reading from Murray‰Ûªs journals, does well communicating her emotional and intellectual acuity. While remaining upbeat about the artist‰Ûªs legacy, ‰ÛÏEverybody Knows‰Ûù is underscored by a sense of just how much the art world lost when Murray left it.

This cogent, fascinating portrait of the artist, who died in 2007 at 66, was made over several years by Kristi Zea, best known for her work as a production designer on notable films directed by Martin Scorsese and Jonathan Demme (among them ‰ÛÏGoodfellas‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Silence of the Lambs‰Ûù). The movie shows the great variety of Murray‰Ûªs always vivid, colorful work, and culminates with a triumph not just for Murray but also, as the film takes pains to point out, for women in American art: a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. (An exhibition of her work is at the gallery Canada through Jan. 29.)

This brief feature is accompanied at Film Forum by a 30-minute short, ‰ÛÏThe 100 Years Show,‰Ûù a lively look at the Cuban-born artist Carmen Herrera, an art-world ‰ÛÏdiscovery‰Ûù as she approached her centenary. Now 101, she finally received a solo exhibition at a major New York museum (the Whitney Museum of American Art) last year.

While she achieved a good deal of recognition in her lifetime, Elizabeth Murray, the subject of this fine yet too-short documentary, remains an American artist who hasn‰Ûªt quite gotten her due. One hopes ‰ÛÏEverybody Knows ... Elizabeth Murray‰Ûù changes that at least a little.

The threads may not all be original, but they‰Ûªre kept nicely distinct. Rather than awkwardly intertwining, they merely brush up against one another. It‰Ûªs a portrait of similar struggles existing in proximity of time and place; of individual battles being fought side by side yet alone.

Overshadowing Idris Elba, one of the most dynamic actors around, isn‰Ûªt easy, but two of his cast mates get the better of things in ‰ÛÏ100 Streets,‰Ûù a converging-narratives film that‰Ûªs a mix of effective moments and predictable ones.

Mr. Elba‰Ûªs character, Max, is a former rugby star in London whose self-indulgence has led to estrangement from his wife, Emily (Gemma Arterton, in an underwritten role). Their fitful attempts to reconcile grow a bit melodramatic by the end of the film, which was directed by Jim O‰ÛªHanlon and written by Leon F. Butler, though Mr. Elba has plenty of gratuitous opportunities to show off his well-toned body.

The more compelling story lines belong to Charlie Creed-Miles as George, a mild-mannered cabdriver who seems a magnet for bad luck, and Franz Drameh as Kingsley, a small-time drug dealer with literary aspirations. Mr. Creed-Miles gives his character a convincing sense of being overwhelmed by the world, a defeatism that George‰Ûªs wife, Kathy (Kierston Wareing), tries to help him overcome. And Mr. Drameh at least sometimes rises above Kingsley‰Ûªs designated clichÌ© ‰ÛÓ that within every petty criminal there‰Ûªs a poet waiting to be drawn out (in this case by an aging thespian played by Ken Stott).

So when the couple, Anna and Otto Quangel (Emma Thompson and Brendan Gleeson), lose their only son in battle and embark on a campaign of micro-resistance, their grief is subsumed in clandestine defiance. Inscribing postcards with anti-Hitler propaganda ‰ÛÓ small sparks of revolutionary art ‰ÛÓ they leave them all over the city. To Otto, a factory foreman, they will be grains of sand in Hitler‰Ûªs war machine.

‰ÛÏAlone in Berlin‰Ûù proceeds like a train crossing a plain. Without twists or turns, hills or valleys, its dramatic engine chugs reliably forward, delivering its cargo of World War II tragedy with bland efficiency.

For some, that will be enough. Handsomely photographed (by the Belgian wizard Christophe Beaucarne) and unimaginatively directed by Vincent Perez, this stodgy story of how a long-married German couple became peas beneath the Nazi mattress has a comforting familiarity. The clean Berlin streets and dustily lighted apartments; the classical framing and detailed costuming; the German-accented English ‰ÛÓ there‰Ûªs nothing here to ruffle or rouse. Instead, like many such projects, the movie has a stilted worthiness that constricts emotion.

Adapted from Hans Fallada‰Ûªs 1947 novel (and based on a true story), ‰ÛÏAlone in Berlin‰Ûù is dour and flavorless. The actors do what they can to shade underwritten characters, but Mr. Gleeson‰Ûªs taciturn, perpetually drooping misery gives him the look of a disappointed bulldog. And Ms. Thompson‰Ûªs pinched, anxious briskness feels like a default response to a pared-down script. Together, they‰Ûªre gloomily stoic rebels, easy to admire but hard to mourn.

‰ÛÏBad Kids of Crestview Academy‰Ûù traffics in exploitation movie flourishes ‰ÛÓ with a salacious tease-dance atop a car, cheesy gore and uneven snarky humor ‰ÛÓ and employs the overfamiliar devices of multiple-point-of-view flashbacks to one incident (the death of Siouxsie‰Ûªs sister) and comic-book-style freeze frames to acknowledge its origins. Its most objectionable element is some cheap ethnic humor.
‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs time to break stereotypes, not reinforce them!‰Ûù Headmaster Nash says at one point. Alas, not in this movie.

The archetypes include Siouxsie, a motorcycle-riding rebel (Sammi Hanratty), investigating the death of her sister years before; a senator‰Ûªs petulant son (a worthy Colby Arps); a gay drug dealer (Matthew Frias); a clergyman‰Ûªs daughter (Sophia Taylor Ali); and a cat fancier (Erika Daly). Sean Astin plays Headmaster Nash (portrayed by Judd Nelson in the first movie), and Mr. Astin‰Ûªs daughter Ali has a part. Sufe Bradshaw of ‰ÛÏVeep‰Ûù is utterly squandered as a school official. Ben Browder (‰ÛÏFarscape‰Ûù), returning in the role of a janitor, makes his feature directing debut, but has something to learn about pacing.

The dark high school thriller-comedy has known countless variants, the apex perhaps being the immortal ‰ÛÏHeathers‰Ûù (1988). Limping into the pantheon is the flat ‰ÛÏBad Kids of Crestview Academy,‰Ûù a sequel to ‰ÛÏBad Kids Go to Hell,‰Ûù a 2012 adaptation of a 2009 comic-book mini-series. Like its predecessor, this new ‰ÛÏBad Kids‰Ûù is a ‰ÛÏBreakfast Club‰Ûù with bloodletting; here, prep-school students in Saturday detention are trapped on campus to die one by one at the hands of a mysterious predator.

Allison turns out to be a drag, including on the movie. Unconvincing in the extreme, she adds nothing of interest and succeeds only in drawing attention away from Claire, an already frustratingly diffuse character. Ms. Robinson and Ms. Howell have kitted out their movie handsomely, but there‰Ûªs not enough story here or enough anything else, namely a persuasive psychological portrait of Claire, to make up for that lack. The filmmakers make good use of their locations and the creeping camera movements and, on occasion, they brighten the gloom with daubs of color ‰ÛÓ with Connor‰Ûªs knitting, a gaudily painted car, the forest green ‰ÛÓ that add vibrancy to a tale that‰Ûªs mutely, almost reluctantly told.

An elliptical, deliberate slow boil, ‰ÛÏClaire in Motion‰Ûù is thicker with atmosphere than plot. It was written and directed by Lisa Robinson and Annie J. Howell (they also wrote and directed ‰ÛÏSmall, Beautifully Moving Parts‰Ûù), who have a nice way of unsettling a mood, destabilizing a scene and creating a sense of vague threat. When the movie opens, everything seems ordinary, banal: There‰Ûªs a woman in bed and a man fussing elsewhere in the room. Yet while she lies there, he remains obscured enough that you can‰Ûªt make out his face when he kisses her goodbye. He‰Ûªs already a mystery, at least to the viewer.

The filmmakers do get around to the standard introductions: Claire Hunger (Betsy Brandt) teaches math at the same Ohio college where her husband, Paul (Chris Beetem), is a professor of ornithology. Together with their son, Connor (Zev Haworth), they live in a nice house in the town of Athens, which appears almost as depopulated as a nuclear test site. The pervasive quiet reinforces Claire‰Ûªs isolation (her next-door neighbors seem to be her only friends), which seems a bit odd, especially after Paul goes missing. Where are the concerned friends, the worried relatives? (The absence of people here, like some of the rough technical edges, has an unfortunate way of taking you out of the movie.)

A few weeks after Claire reports Paul‰Ûªs absence, the search is dropped. It makes sense (small police department, limited resources, no clues), but leaves Claire without answers. It also ends up stranding the filmmakers, who cook up a narrative diversion in the figure of an arty grad student, Allison (Anna Margaret Hollyman). Paul liked to go off for some kind of extreme solo outdoors adventuring, heading into the deep forest, for instance, with little more than a backpack. As Allison explains to Claire over a succession of dead-end encounters, Paul was also cultivating an entirely separate life from his wife, one involving dubious art, confessional hugs and ukuleles.

After her husband goes missing, the title character in ‰ÛÏClaire in Motion‰Ûù takes sensible action. She reports his absence to the police, puts up missing-person leaflets and comforts their child. She also begins exploring the murkier corners of her husband‰Ûªs life, the places that he‰Ûªs never invited her into and that turn up a couple of mild surprises. Repeatedly, she returns to the dark, ominous forest where he apparently disappeared like some fairy-tale casualty; at times, she dreams of him and his caresses. She holds it together remarkably well, shedding few tears, which suggests promising complications.

This posturing vehemence, though, can be muted by discordantly obvious symbolism. (Do we really need the rape rubber-stamped by a shot of the motel clerk popping a cherry between her teeth?) As tinny honky-tonk and naturalistic noises jostle mischievously on the soundtrack, ‰ÛÏMA‰Ûù emerges as a cryptic, highly personal experiment. It‰Ûªs like looking into the richly churning imagination of someone who feels no need to explain herself.

‰ÛÏWho can find a virtuous woman?‰Ûù asks the onscreen quotation from Proverbs that opens the film, and it‰Ûªs clear that the director, Celia Rowlson-Hall (who is also the movie‰Ûªs writer, choreographer and star), has something to say about virtue. What that might be, however, is anyone‰Ûªs guess as her mute and scantily clothed Madonna emerges from the desert and flings herself onto the hood of an oncoming Oldsmobile. Chauffeured to a dusty motel by the driver (Andrew Pastides), she endures an apparent gang rape and, later, participates in a watery baptism and enacts a gender switch. O.K., then.

Part movie, part dance performance, part bizarre Nativity play, ‰ÛÏMA‰Ûù is the kind of picture that rarely sees the outside ‰ÛÓ or even the main stage ‰ÛÓ of a film festival. With virtually no dialogue and precious little recognizable narrative, this surreal take on the Virgin Mary‰Ûªs pilgrimage (with the American Southwest standing in for the Holy Land) is intermittently lovely and consistently confounding.

Alternately sexy and silly, galvanic and gentle, ‰ÛÏMA‰Ûù is best enjoyed as a slide show of visual blessings and, sometimes, bafflements. Whippet-thin and androgynous, this Virgin is a feral innocent, writhing across stony wilderness and motel carpeting like an ecstatic invertebrate. And Ms. Rowlson-Hall can really move: Back-bending in slow motion or cavorting in men‰Ûªs underwear, her bruised and abused body seems often more in need of an exorcist than a midwife.

An oil company, personified by its chief executive (a rapacious Rob Lowe), is drilling in North Dakota when it hits a water-table mother lode of biological activity. A geyser releases an entity that finds its way to the small-town high-school senior Tripp (Lucas Till, the new MacGyver), whose buff physique and cleft chin belie his outsider status. Tripp, living with his working-class mother (Amy Ryan) and resenting her sheriff boyfriend (Barry Pepper), is a gear head seeking ‰ÛÏsomething with four wheels that will get me out of this place.‰Ûù

Working at a junkyard, Tripp bonds with the creature, which he names Creech after an initial encounter redolent of the ‰ÛÏE. T.‰Ûù playbook. Creech, a huge cephalopod, subsists on oil, and takes up residence in Tripp‰Ûªs decrepit jalopy, sometimes impertinently seizing control. (It‰Ûªs an inspired C.G.I. creation, alternately threatening and childish, with expressive eyes, formidable teeth and an irrepressible chortle.)

Sometimes movies with the most unprepossessing titles can surprise you. Case in point: ‰ÛÏMonster Trucks,‰Ûù a spry, spirited and delightful family film that has nothing to do with giant-wheeled vehicles piling on top of one another in indoor arenas. Instead, it‰Ûªs an eco-fable devoid of didactic overkill, delivered with energy, winking mischief, unobtrusive effects and a skilled cast.

Back at the drilling site, Creech‰Ûªs relatives are captured, and the oil company dispatches a heavy (Holt McCallany) to apprehend Creech. It falls to Tripp, a sympathetic geologist (Thomas Lennon) and Tripp‰Ûªs friend Meredith (the winning Jane Levy, from ‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt Breathe‰Ûù and the underrated film ‰ÛÏFun Size‰Ûù) to reunite Creech with his kin. Antic effects-laden car chases in town and country ensue, leading to a tender climax. The director Chris Wedge (‰ÛÏIce Age‰Ûù) makes a nimble, largely live-action debut with this movie, whose heart, humor and gentle conscience keep it humming.

Mr. Millepied, the choreographer for the Darren Aronofsky film ‰ÛÏBlack Swan‰Ûù (where he met his wife, Natalie Portman) and former principal at New York City Ballet, doesn‰Ûªt do soft. He may be French, but in ‰ÛÏReset,‰Ûù Mr. Millepied ‰ÛÓ brash, funny, intelligent ‰ÛÓ is very much an American living in Paris. And most of us already know the job didn‰Ûªt work out in the end: Last year he announced his resignation as director of dance there.

For a year and a half, Benjamin Millepied led the Paris Opera Ballet, where among other things he worked to diversify the company and to rethink the institution‰Ûªs hierarchy. At one point in ‰ÛÏReset,‰Ûù the riveting documentary by Thierry DemaiziÌ¬re and Alban Teurlai that chronicles Mr. Millepied choreographing a new ballet, he grabs an injured dancer‰Ûªs foot and vigorously massages the heel. ‰ÛÏSofter is pointless,‰Ûù he says, ignoring her whimpers.

But ‰ÛÏReset‰Ûù also fleshes out the creative process and shows how, for Mr. Millepied, pleasure must always be part of dance. Did the film make me want to see Mr. Millepied‰Ûªs ballet, ‰ÛÏClear, Loud, Bright, Forward,‰Ûù on the stage? Yes. And that‰Ûªs high praise.

It‰Ûªs hard to make changes at the bureaucratic Paris Opera, yet Mr. Millepied ‰ÛÓ something of a real-life Rodrigo from ‰ÛÏMozart in the Jungle‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ weathers it all with cheerful tenacity. He can be elusive, especially to his assistant, who is continually asking, ‰ÛÏHave you seen Benjamin?‰Ûù In one meeting, she rattles off his list of appointments; he turns to the camera with a hand covering his mouth and says: ‰ÛÏLook at her diary. She‰Ûªs going to kill me.‰Ûù

This horror movie has a hook that‰Ûªs sharper than it sounds. ‰ÛÏThe Bye Bye Man‰Ûù melds the summon-the-evil-by-its-name convention familiar from ‰ÛÏCandyman‰Ûù and, in a lighter register, ‰ÛÏBeetlejuice,‰Ûù with the old try-not-to-think-of-an-elephant mind game.

What comes next is a very credible (that is, actually scary) series of shock scenes, followed by the inevitable further exposition. This is usually where such movies fall apart, but Jonathan Penner‰Ûªs sharp script (from a story by Robert Damon Schneck) and Stacy Title‰Ûªs assured direction keep the heat on, and there‰Ûªs some resourceful misdirection that deepens the story and intensifies the scares. It helps that the added moments of humor acknowledge that the movie‰Ûªs potent concept is also, well, ridiculous. Faye Dunaway and Carrie-Anne Moss, in small roles, contribute welcome Old Hollywood and genre-specific cred and chops. I saw this movie with a sneak-peek audience of regular New York movie folk, and it worked a treat on them. Got me good a couple of times, too.

Opening with an intentionally mystifying scene of mass murder in the late ‰Ûª60s, the movie shifts to the present day, and a familiar scenario: three college students, Elliot (Douglas Smith), his girlfriend, Sasha (Cressida Bonas), and his best pal, John (Lucien Laviscount), have rented a spacious off-campus house. Their ‰ÛÏsensitive‰Ûù (that is, psychic) friend, Jenna Kanell, feels the place has problems. Duly, doors open themselves, cabinets unlatch and a sÌ©ance reveals the never-to-be-said name of the title character. Soon poor Elliot is seeing a fellow in a long cowled robe, and he‰Ûªs not a member of the drone rock group Sunn O))) offering to play a free house party.

Stalking Oscar at his hotel office (Mr. Green appears as the concierge), Vincent meets Joseph (Fabrizio Rongione), Oscar‰Ûªs kind, disinherited brother. Joseph accompanies Vincent to the Louvre and teaches him about art and life. He may even be a match for Vincent‰Ûªs mother. (Her name, it turns out, is Marie.)
‰ÛÏThe Son of Joseph‰Ûù can be trying in its whimsy, yet it builds to a lovely finale that evokes the Bible, the French Resistance and the surreal.

EugÌ¬ne Green, a nearly five-decade resident of France born in New York, makes films that draw as much on architecture, paintings, music and theater as on cinema. If his unadorned high-art allusions can make him an acquired taste, his latest farce, ‰ÛÏThe Son of Joseph,‰Ûù is his most accessible film since ‰ÛÏThe Living World,‰Ûù from 2003.

Divided into five sections, each named after a biblical episode, ‰ÛÏThe Son of Joseph‰Ûù is a fanciful repackaging of the Nativity (the media notes, perhaps seizing on Hollywood‰Ûªs zest for recycling, call it a ‰ÛÏreboot‰Ûù): A sullen teenager, Vincent (Victor Ezenfis), raised by a nurse (Natacha RÌ©gnier), learns his father is a vain publisher, Oscar (Mathieu Amalric), who can‰Ûªt even keep track of how many children he has.

Mr. Green‰Ûªs taste for frontal compositions and clipped editing sometimes recalls the filmmaker Robert Bresson, although Bresson wasn‰Ûªt known for his throwaway humor. (Probably not many teenagers‰Ûª bedrooms include replicas of Caravaggio‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Sacrifice of Isaac,‰Ûù and Maria de Medeiros has a funny role as a perpetually confused literary critic.)
They do it for love. The most memorable performances are carried by a mysterious lilt that makes them the next best thing to dancing on air.

This movie, directed and produced by Dave Davidson and Amber Edwards, digs deeply enough into Mr. Giordano‰Ûªs world to convey the drudgery and headaches of being a bandleader: juggling personnel, scheduling, dealing with a musicians‰Ûª union and lugging around instruments. But for all the players‰Ûª expertise and devotion, their profession won‰Ûªt make them rich and famous.

You probably know the music of this passionate preservationist, which has been featured in Woody Allen‰Ûªs movies and the HBO series ‰ÛÏBoardwalk Empire.‰Ûù His devotion to stylistic authenticity infuses his band‰Ûªs performances to the degree that, to quote a ‰Ûª70s pop song title, ‰ÛÏeverything old is new again.‰Ûù Played with such vigor and attention to detail, it sounds utterly fresh.

Much of the space in Mr. Giordano‰Ûªs Brooklyn apartment is devoted to his ever-growing, meticulously annotated collection of 60,000 big-band arrangements. They are culled from his extensive search for original manuscripts and radio transcriptions of music that the film calls hot jazz. What the singer, pianist and cabaret performer Michael Feinstein is to vintage popular songs, Mr. Giordano is to hot jazz.

Born and based in Brooklyn, Mr. Giordano, 64, has been leading the Nighthawks, his 11-piece band specializing in the pre-swing era, for nearly four decades. He plays several instruments, including tuba, string bass and bass saxophone, and sings in a voice that evokes a less rambunctious Fats Waller. His popularity playing hotels has spawned a subculture of young fans who flock to his performances in period dress.

As you absorb the buoyant ‰Ûª20s and ‰Ûª30s jazz bubbling through the documentary ‰ÛÏVince Giordano:  There‰Ûªs a Future in the Past,‰Ûù you may well wonder if this is the happiest American music ever created. It‰Ûªs a peppy, carefree sound that conveys a frantic energy but is rendered with a light touch.

‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs a Future in the Past‰Ûù is a ground-level exploration of this historian at work, leading the Nighthawks or one of their satellite ensembles and traveling the country to examine and rescue old arrangements that have turned up in radio station archives and musicians‰Ûª basements. What others would dismiss as trash is the equivalent of discovering gold to Mr. Giordano.

Mr. Foxx plays Vincent Downs, a Las Vegas homicide detective whose teenage son (Octavius J. Johnson) is snatched by drug dealers. Or, more precisely, by guys who work for the guy (Dermot Mulroney) who works for the main drug dealer (Scoot McNairy). Vincent and his partner, Sean (T.I.), have stolen 25 kilos of cocaine for reasons as murky as the movie‰Ûªs nighttime cinematography. Vincent tries to return it, but his plans are complicated by the doggedness of an internal affairs officer named Jennifer Bryant (Michelle Monaghan). She has a partner (David Harbour, a walking spoiler alert). Vincent has an ex-wife (Gabrielle Union, deserving better in every way).

‰ÛÏSleepless,‰Ûù directed by Baran bo Odar, sets a low bar for itself, and then trips over it. What audiences want ‰ÛÓ what we deserve ‰ÛÓ from a movie like this isn‰Ûªt greatness, but competence. Reasonably exciting chases and fights; characters with at least minimal credibility; performances with a measure of wit, flair or intensity. Instead we get muttering and glowering from Mr. Foxx, a story that can‰Ûªt manage enough twists to tie a shoelace, and set pieces that have been done better in other movies. If the thing weren‰Ûªt so noisy, it might not even live up to its title.

At the beginning, Jennifer and Vincent are shown with matching cuts on their cheekbones. By the end, they will both be much bloodier. Vincent, stabbed in the gut when his son is taken, will be battered with hotel-kitchen utensils and other weapons during a long and hectic night at a dimly-lighted casino.

At least since the 2009 film ‰ÛÏTaken,‰Ûù the dad-to-the-rescue action movie has been a staple of the winter release calendar. ‰ÛÏSleepless,‰Ûù a sort-of-remake of the French thriller ‰ÛÏSleepless Night,‰Ûù represents Jamie Foxx‰Ûªs foray into late-midcareer Neesonism.

‰ÛÏLeonard Cohen: Bird on a Wire‰Ûù is an account of a particularly fraught period in the first phase of his stardom. Directed by the British documentarian Tony Palmer, it follows Mr. Cohen and his small band ‰ÛÓ two guitarists; a bass and fiddle player; Bob Johnston, the Nashville record producer and musical near-anarchist; and the backup singers Donna Washburn and Jennifer Warnes ‰ÛÓ on a spring 1972 tour of Europe that ended in Israel. It‰Ûªs a time Mr. Cohen later described as ‰ÛÏconfused and directionless.‰Ûù

The movie was completed in 1974, subsequently revised (the current print contains an in-memory-of dedication to Mr. Cohen‰Ûªs longtime lawyer, Marty Machat, who appears in the film and died in 1988), and only now is having a theatrical release. It follows the outline for road music documentaries that was later successfully sent up by ‰ÛÏThis Is Spinal Tap.‰Ûù Mr. Cohen granted extraordinary access to Mr. Palmer and his crew. There‰Ûªs footage of Mr. Cohen and his male band mates showering, even. During one backstage meet-and-greet, Mr. Cohen is baldly propositioned by a female fan, and he demurs with a combination of gentlemanly grace and camera-conscious awkwardness. He is polite and witty with interviewers. When one of them says of Mr. Johnston, ‰ÛÏI didn‰Ûªt know he was an organist,‰Ûù Mr. Cohen replies, ‰ÛÏHe‰Ûªs hardly aware of it himself.‰Ûù

The artist‰Ûªs lightheartedness, which might have been forced to begin with ‰ÛÓ while always a remarkable live performer, in the early part of his career, Mr. Cohen was also an often reluctant one ‰ÛÓ cannot hold. Technical problems plague the shows, as amplifiers unexpectedly feed back, demolishing the contemplative simplicity of the music. There‰Ûªs a tense confrontation with some truculent, dissatisfied fans in Berlin. Mr. Cohen‰Ûªs self-deprecating humor begins to take an edge. One night he strums his guitar and sings ‰ÛÏLeonard Cohen/[strum]/is going to sing his songs/[strum]/of anguish and despair.‰Ûù And on the last night of the tour, in Jerusalem, the artist crashes emotionally, and the question of whether he will rally provides some suspense.

The brilliant poet, novelist, musician and singer-songwriter Leonard Cohen, who died in November at 82, became a superstar as a senior. He brought his earnest voice and moody guitar into the 1960s counterculture when he was in his early 30s, and he made a substantial impact musically well into the 1970s. In that time, he was a cult artist on a very large scale, so to speak. But after the explosive popularity of his oft-covered 1984 song, ‰ÛÏHallelujah,‰Ûù and a management swindle that obliged him to become a road dog to restore his income, he became an arena-filling legend and, to his hard-core fans, a prophet.

Mr. Palmer captures all this with a keen eye. The movie is a worthy time capsule and a must for Cohen devotees. Its occasional meanderings into artiness, which take the form of interpolation of outside footage (war atrocities and home movies, mainly) are emblematic of the time it was made and mercifully brief.

The actor Kevin McCarthy, in conversation with Kurt Vonnegut (in whose play ‰ÛÏHappy Birthday, Wanda June‰Ûù McCarthy had acted), described how theater people, working together on a single project, would form the impression that they had bonded with their colleagues for life, and then pledge to always stay in touch. ‰ÛÏBut they don‰Ûªt!‰Ûù Mr. McCarthy exclaimed at the conclusion of his observation. This showbiz truth gets an extended play in the last third of ‰ÛÏStrike a Pose,‰Ûù as the six dancers meet for a filmed dinner. ‰ÛÏNo numbers tonight,‰Ûù one says in the middle of a hug. Not long afterward, another breaks that directive and says, ‰ÛÏTwenty-five years!‰Ûù

Beyond the personal stories, the movie frames the tour and ‰ÛÏTruth or Dare‰Ûù as landmarks in the push for gay rights and awareness, and makes a convincing case. A couple of the dancers read letters by fans from the Midwest and East Los Angeles, not known as bastions of gay acceptance, chronicling life-changing encounters because of ‰ÛÏTruth or Dare.‰Ûù But the Madonna collaboration had its issues. Mr. Trupin sued Madonna for invasion of privacy. Two other dancers took her to court on noncompensation complaints that were settled out of court. Madonna is not interviewed in the movie, and there‰Ûªs no indication that she was approached. The surviving dancers articulate their reasons and their regrets here.

The New Orleans-born hip-hop dancer Oliver Crumes III, the only heterosexual of the group, allows that before he met his tour colleagues, ‰ÛÏif someone was gay I would punch them out.‰Ûù A couple of the dancers tell of their struggles with drugs and alcohol; others describe their experiences with being H.I.V. positive. ‰ÛÏWhen I was diagnosed,‰Ûù recalls one, Carlton Wilborn, ‰ÛÏI was just ramped with fear and hatred of those lepers.‰Ûù Sue Trupin speaks of her son Gabriel Trupin, the seventh dancer, who died of AIDS in 1995.

Early in ‰ÛÏStrike a Pose‰Ûù there‰Ûªs an old clip from the TV program ‰ÛÏEntertainment Tonight‰Ûù about the 1991 movie ‰ÛÏMadonna: Truth or Dare,‰Ûù a documentary about her 1990 ‰ÛÏBlond Ambition‰Ûù tour. Describing the movie‰Ûªs supposedly scandalous contents, a correspondent notes, with an audibly raised eyebrow, ‰ÛÏThere are even scenes of two men kissing.‰Ûù As mortifying as it was to have sat through that nonsense then, it‰Ûªs even more embarrassing revisited here. Directed by Ester Gould and Reijer Zwann, ‰ÛÏStrike a Pose‰Ûù depicts the lives of the seven male dancers who worked for Madonna on that tour, and catches up with the six who are still with us today.

The movie begins with thumbnail portraits of the men, who appear in new interviews, conducted in both cinematically formal (in black and white, with the subject seated in front of a white backdrop) and at-home settings. Luis Camacho and Jose Gutierez were recruited by Madonna from the world of vogueing, which she celebrated in song. ‰ÛÏShe saw talent, she saw character, she saw artistic expression,‰Ûù says Mr. Gutierez, who still exhibits a fierce charisma.

‰ÛÏIn my lifetime I have seen how man, by burning oil, wood and coal, has been changing the earth‰Ûªs climate. I traveled back thousands of years to check whether what I‰Ûªd discovered wasn‰Ûªt just a quirk of nature.‰Ûù These simple, strong words in the film ‰ÛÏAntarctica: Ice and Sky‰Ûù are spoken by the French explorer and scientist Claude Lorius. His work in the Antarctic, beginning over 60 years ago, eventually unearthed compelling evidence that climate change was a man-made phenomenon.

Mr. Lorius, now in his 80s, stands silent amid snow both frozen and melting in new footage captured by the film‰Ûªs director, Luc Jacquet (‰ÛÏMarch of the Penguins‰Ûù). His persona is avuncular yet sometimes also accusatory. The movie, using a great deal of well-assembled archival footage, shows Mr. Lorius as a young man in the 1950s signing up for what he says he believed would be an ‰ÛÏadventure‰Ûù in the Antarctic. Although explorers had made it to the South Pole earlier in the 20th century, Mr. Lorius insists that it wasn‰Ûªt until the ‰Ûª50s that any scientist ‰ÛÏever gathered any meteorological or geophysical data‰Ûù from the bottom of the world. Mr. Lorius becomes a student of snow, a decoder of ice. Ceaselessly pursuing the coldest places on the planet ‰ÛÓ he fondly reminisces about reaching the Soviet base of Vostok in 1984, exulting about ‰ÛÏAmerican logistics for French researchers on a Soviet base in the middle of the Cold War‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ he makes a series of unsettling discoveries.

The movie is both heady (there are real thrills in the stories of exploration) and sobering (Mr. Lorius‰Ûªs findings are convincing). This is a cogent, accessible cinematic delineation of an increasingly crucial problem.

Yet the specifics of the tale matter less than its mythic presentation. Inspired by the Irish playwright John Millington Synge‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPlayboy of the Western World,‰Ûù Mr. Brosnan conjures a Bible-thumpin‰Ûª, biker-beatin‰Ûª hellhole of perverted preachers and leather-vested louts. This is his first feature, and he is not shy about it, hurling his lurid vision onto the screen with cheeky confidence. And the actors rise to meet him, especially the fine Candace Smith as Asher‰Ûªs only friend and the movie‰Ûªs sole human being.

Bathed in a funk of testosterone, and heaving with homophobia and misogyny, ‰ÛÏMy Father Die‰Ûù is a trashy jewel. As with the Rubens painting of Saturn devouring one of his sons that punctuates certain scenes, you kind of can‰Ûªt stop looking at it.

The disjunction of the gorgeous and the gag-inducing is one of the film‰Ûªs hallmarks. The sliver of a story (by the director Sean Brosnan, the son of the actor Pierce Brosnan) is an Oedipal nightmare involving a deaf-mute son, Asher (a marvelous Joe Anderson), and his monstrous father (Gary Stretch), as they race to kill each other. Of course, there is history, and it‰Ûªs nasty ‰ÛÓ as we learn from lucent black-and-white flashbacks and Asher‰Ûªs oddly poetic internal monologue.

The miasma of warped masculinity that blankets Sean Brosnan‰Ûªs Louisiana revenge tale, ‰ÛÏMy Father Die,‰Ûù is well nigh impenetrable. But now and then it lifts a little, and when it does, it‰Ûªs possible to drink in the swampy beauty of Marc Shap‰Ûªs bayou cinematography. Through his lens ‰ÛÓ which accomplishes the equivalent of wrapping rotten remains in fine silk ‰ÛÓ this horror show of blood, muck and bad behavior is rendered almost palatable.

Colin Day‰Ûªs fascinating documentary ‰ÛÏSaving Banksy‰Ûù rightly honors that renowned  pseudonymous street artist whose work (often in public spaces, like  a resort town) combines stenciled imagery with clever, cryptic phrases. But ‰ÛÏSaving Banksy‰Ûù has a larger goal: pointedly weighing graffiti‰Ûªs populist ethos against art-world profiteering.

Graffiti art can be ephemeral: a spray-painted image ‰ÛÓ until somebody defaces it, or a property owner paints over it ‰ÛÓ is, at least briefly, free for everyone to behold. Banksy‰Ûªs public art endures, partly because of extraordinary efforts to salvage it. When the artist visited San Francisco in 2010, his work popped up in various neighborhoods. One artist-collector, Brian Greif, had part of a wall, with Banksy‰Ûªs rendering of a rat, meticulously carved out of a Victorian building on Haight Street. He seeks a museum that will share it with the public in perpetuity.

Mr. Greif‰Ûªs effort contrasts with that of Stephan Keszler, an art dealer with a gallery in Southampton, N.Y., who excavates Banksy‰Ûªs works from public sites and sells them for his own gain. Banksy (who has never revealed his identity) condemns such sales, as does Ben Eine, one of many street artists interviewed here. Mr. Eine says Mr. Keszler is regarded by such painters as ‰ÛÏa shyster‰Ûù; Mr. Keszler, who displayed a few Banksys at Art Miami in 2012, says he enhances Banksy‰Ûªs reputation.

‰ÛÏSaving Banksy‰Ûù owns its sympathies: ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs the poor street kids and the multibillionaires,‰Ûù Mr. Eine says. ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre doing everything for nothing, and they‰Ûªre walking home with Banksys for a million dollars.‰Ûù

At once solemn and preposterous, sinister and sentimental, efficient and overwrought, ‰ÛÏSplit‰Ûù represents something of a return to form for its writer and director, M. Night Shyamalan. Or maybe I should say a return to formula. The movie, shot in and around Philadelphia, Mr. Shyamalan‰Ûªs hometown, proceeds nimbly and with suave misdirection toward a pair of rug-pulling final twists that an attentive viewer will probably be able to anticipate. It‰Ûªs not exactly a Choose Your Own Adventure, but you can opt either for the pleasure of surprise at the end or for the satisfaction of working out the puzzle as you go along.

Mr. McAvoy, for his part, revels in the chance to use his sensitivity for evil, and to showboat his way through a series of appropriately overwrought characterizations. This breathlessly melodramatic thriller shouldn‰Ûªt be taken as a psychological case study, any more than Mr. Shyamalan‰Ûªs laughable ‰ÛÏLady in the Water‰Ûù should be mined for clues about the habits of film critics.

Dennis and company, meanwhile ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs mostly Barry, actually ‰ÛÓ consult with a therapist, Dr. Fletcher, who lives alone in a gracious, book-stuffed rowhouse and who is played by the wonderful Betty Buckley. Dr. Fletcher‰Ûªs primary function is to explain the movie to the audience, foreshadowing the climax with her heterodox pseudo-scholarly theories about her many-sided patient, but Ms. Buckley also provides a dimension of warmth and wit that ‰ÛÏSplit‰Ûù would be much duller and uglier without.

‰ÛÏSplit‰Ûù is lurid and ludicrous, and sometimes more than a little icky in its prurient, maudlin interest in the abuse of children. It‰Ûªs also absorbing and sometimes slyly funny. Some years back ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs startling to contemplate just how long ago it was ‰ÛÓ Mr. Shyamalan was puffed up into a cinematic visionary, hailed on the cover of Newsweek as ‰ÛÏThe Next Spielberg.‰Ûù That hype (and his own self-aggrandizing tendencies) placed a disproportionate burden of significance on a filmmaker who has always been, at heart, a superior genre hack.

He uses Ms. Taylor-Joy‰Ûªs enormous dark eyes as a mirror and a lure for the audience‰Ûªs attention. He delays the inevitable, inevitably deflationary revelations for as long as possible, minimizing the obligatory third-act flurry of chasing, fighting and bloodletting. And he sneaks in a few self-referential winks, including an allusion to his last really good movie that feels at once like a promise of better mischief to come and an implicit apology for all the disappointment in between.

One of the young women ‰ÛÓ a gothy, spooky misfit named Casey (Anya Taylor-Joy) ‰ÛÓ is singled out for special attention from the camera (though not, at least initially, from Dennis and his colleagues). Her fellow abductees, Claire (Haley Lu Richardson) and Marcia (Jessica Sula), alternate between panic and defiance, but Casey counsels patience and watchfulness. Flashbacks to a hunting trip she took as a 5-year-old (Izzie Leigh Coffey) in the company of her father (Sebastian Arcelus) and uncle (Brad William Henke) seem to explain the source of her survival skills, though it turns out that those memories have another, darker meaning as well.

Thanks to ‰ÛÏThe Sixth Sense‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏUnbreakable‰Ûù back around the turn of the century, Mr. Shyamalan stands as a pioneer of spoiler-centric cinema. Like those movies, and like his later, lesser entertainments (‰ÛÏThe Village‰Ûù; ‰ÛÏThe Happening‰Ûù), ‰ÛÏSplit‰Ûù is all plot, an ingenious (and also ridiculous) conceit spun into an elegant ribbon of suspense. The less said about that plot, therefore, the better.

What I can safely divulge is that three teenage girls are kidnapped after a birthday party by a close-cropped guy named Dennis in a buttoned-up shirt. He is obsessed with cleanliness, and he sounds weirdly like John Turturro for a guy supposedly from Philly. In fact, Dennis is played by the soft-eyed, shape-shifting British actor James McAvoy, as are the other 23 personalities residing in the body of a guy who shares the surname of a famous (and famously odd) Philadelphia-born artist.

‰ÛÏSplit‰Ûù is being released by Universal under the Blumhouse label, a brand associated with unpretentious, clever, neo-traditionalist scare-pictures like ‰ÛÏInsidious,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏParanormal Activity‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Purge.‰Ûù That seems like the right company for Mr. Shyamalan, and the January pre-Oscar doldrums may be the perfect moment to appreciate his skills. He is a master of mood, pace and limited perspective, moving the camera so that the thing you most desperately want to see ‰ÛÓ and are most afraid of seeing ‰ÛÓ remains teasingly out of sight.

These ‰ÛÏalters‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a word familiar to fans of the Showtime series ‰ÛÏUnited States of Tara‰Ûù and other pop-cultural treatments of a controversial and often poorly understood psychological disorder ‰ÛÓ are a diverse bunch. Some are male, some female, at least one is a child (named Hedwig) and another (named Barry) is a gay stereotype. What they want with their captives is not immediately clear. What Mr. Shyamalan wants is to strip them down to their underwear and to explore, exploit and occasionally subvert the basic tropes of the female-victim psycho-slasher movie.

The young women tell us of their lives before incarceration, filled with abuse, addiction, murder, teenage marriage and pregnancy. Their stories make a pointed contrast with their routines inside, as they tease one another or sing songs at a table.

Although the movie bears some resemblance to the films made by Frederick Wiseman within institutions, the acknowledged presence of the director, Mehrdad Oskouei, creates a constant tension. The girls ‰ÛÓ identified by first names or nicknames like ‰ÛÏNobody‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏ651‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ show varying degrees of comfort with Mr. Oskouei‰Ûªs questions, some matter-of-factly discussing drugs or stabbings, and others seemingly reluctant to look toward the camera.

At one point, the director mentions that he has a 16-year-old daughter. ‰ÛÏYou shouldn‰Ûªt have told us,‰Ûù a girl replies. ‰ÛÏShe is being raised in love and comfort. We are being raised in rot and filth.‰Ûù
So if ‰ÛÏStarless Dreams‰Ûù inspires conflicted feelings in viewers, it may be by design. It‰Ûªs hard not to want to flee, and it‰Ûªs hard to look away.
Yet ‰ÛÏStarless Dreams‰Ûù suggests that the center‰Ûªs grounds, where the girls play in the snow or work in a greenhouse, are kinder than the world outside, and that release is a fraught prospect.

‰ÛÏStarless Dreams‰Ûù opens with a girl being fingerprinted as she enters a female juvenile detention center in Tehran; repeated glimpses of newly released inmates waving goodbye are as far from the grounds as the movie ventures. Within the walls, this uncomfortably intimate documentary finds horror, hope and counterintuitive poetry.

The first person he encounters, on a drive through the countryside, is a young man named Yoan (Basile Meilleurat), whom he tries to pick up with lines that are tired in any language. (‰ÛÏHave you ever been in a movie?‰Ûù ‰ÛÏWould you like to audition?‰Ûù) When those advances don‰Ûªt work, LÌ©o moves on to Marie (India Hair), a shepherdess ‰ÛÓ the farmer‰Ûªs daughter in the dirty joke ‰ÛÓ with whom he has more success. It‰Ûªs hard to say if he seduces her or the other way around, but after some explicit sex (inspired less by pornography than by Gustave Courbet‰Ûªs painting ‰ÛÏThe Origin of the World‰Ûù), they have a child. It‰Ûªs her third, and his first.

Alain Guiraudie‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏStaying Vertical,‰Ûù a minor sensation at Cannes in May, starts like a thriller, proceeds like the setup to a dirty joke and ends like a folk tale. In the middle it‰Ûªs more or less a comedy about a feckless guy taking care of a baby.

The mood, however, is hardly madcap. It‰Ûªs more like sadcap. Mr. Guiraudie, whose earlier films include ‰ÛÏStranger by the Lake,‰Ûù has an eye for rural French landscapes and an ear for deadpan conversation. His hero, a stalled screenwriter named LÌ©o (Damien Bonnard), has a passive-aggressive habit of showing up and hanging around, as if he thinks that charming other people and annoying them amounted to the same thing.

‰ÛÏStaying Vertical‰Ûù is the opposite of a romantic comedy, though, so Marie takes off with her other sons, leaving LÌ©o to care for the infant. Marie‰Ûªs father, Jean-Louis (RaphaÌÇl ThiÌ©ry), tries to help out, sort of. After arguing with LÌ©o about the relative merits of sleep-training and co-sleeping ‰ÛÓ a debate that plenty of more conventional modern parents have had ‰ÛÓ Jean-Louis spirits the child away to a hillside to serve as wolf bait. The wolves that menace Marie‰Ûªs flocks supply Mr. Guiraudie with a folkloric dimension, and a haunting climax.

LÌ©o‰Ûªs motives are at times as obscure as Mr. Guiraudie‰Ûªs, and the film‰Ûªs studied obliqueness is intriguing as well as puzzling. Its manner of punctuating tedium with shock at times feels strained ‰ÛÓ an attempt to exploit dwindling resources of cinematic provocation ‰ÛÓ but ‰ÛÏStaying Vertical‰Ûù still has a rough gravity that holds your attention and sticks in your mind. Something about the strangeness of the people and the harsh indifference of the nature that surrounds them feels real, even if realism in the conventional sense may be the last thing on the filmmaker‰Ûªs mind.

Otherwise, LÌ©o resumes his pursuit of Yoan, argues with Yoan‰Ûªs grizzled, rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll-loving guardian (Christian Bouillette) and fails to write a script, promising his producer pages and begging for money in advance. He visits a woman (Laure Calamy) in the forest who is equal parts shaman and therapist.

The real Ray Kroc (1902-1984), as business-school students and more than a few fast-food consumers might know, is the entrepreneur who put the big numbers on the McDonald‰Ûªs sign. In the 1950s, that number was a lowly one million, but has since been replaced by the unfathomable, somewhat terrifying ‰ÛÏbillions and billions.‰Ûù Kroc liked to call himself the founder of McDonald‰Ûªs. His memoir, ‰ÛÏGrinding It Out: The Making of McDonald‰Ûªs,‰Ûù promises that it is ‰ÛÏThe personal story behind founder Ray Kroc‰Ûªs amazing success!‰Ûù Some of that sentence is true; the success part is, at any rate. Certainly it was a McGreat success, though one larded with McFibs.

As Ray‰Ûªs ambition grows, he also grows more self-interested, adapting a purely instrumental approach to other people that seeps into his home life. One truism about great-man movies is that you can‰Ûªt have one without a nagging or a loving wife. Ray has both. Laura Dern plays Ethel the nag, the starter wife who enters frown first. Ms. Dern does what she can with bad lighting, drab surroundings and an underconceived character. As Joan, Ray‰Ûªs third wife, Linda Cardellini fares better. For one thing, she gets to smile (she lights up the room and Ray), wears pretty clothes and enjoys the fruits of his achievements. (The second Mrs. Kroc, Jane Dobbins Green, remains M.I.A.)

The director, John Lee Hancock, keeps things overly neat and tidy (it all shines or gleams), but he also keeps the story humming even when business talk threatens to slow it down. Like Ray, he seems lifted by the McDonalds, and there‰Ûªs real heart and pleasure in a flashback  in which they figure out their system‰Ûªs choreography, moving young, confused workers around like chess pieces. The McDonalds‰Ûª introduction of Fordism to their business turned employees into factory workers and changed the restaurant industry, though the movie elides the global stakes. Mostly, it sticks to milestones and showdowns up until the handshake deal that changed everything.

Mr. Hancock tends toward needless fussiness, overshooting and overcutting when he should let the camera run. (I lost count of all the angles he uses to show Ray reading a map.) That‰Ûªs too bad because some of the movie‰Ûªs best moments involve Ray alone, including a scene in which ‰ÛÓ in boxer shorts, a bottle nearby ‰ÛÓ he drops the needle on a motivational record. As an actor, Mr. Keaton often comes across as jittery as a thoroughbred at the gate, so when he goes still it feels as if something important is happening. Ray remains an unanswered, not especially compelling, question, but Mr. Keaton comes close to making you believe there‰Ûªs soul to go with the fries and freneticism.

‰ÛÏThe Founder‰Ûù opens in 1954 with Ray racking up miles selling milkshake mixers. He has his pitch down cold, but the customers aren‰Ûªt buying. His fortunes change when he comes across a bustling burger joint in San Bernardino, Calif., called McDonald‰Ûªs, where crowds of smiling customers sail through fast-moving lines. He‰Ûªs impressed by the turnout, but he‰Ûªs more taken with the seamless efficiency of the McDonalds‰Ûª Speedee Service System. The brothers bring Ray into their business, showing him how it‰Ûªs done, not realizing that they‰Ûªve invited a snake into their garden. Mr. Keaton nearly levitates off the floor in moments like this, creating a contact high.

A cautious revisionist job, ‰ÛÏThe Founder‰Ûù tells an old-fashioned sweet-and-sour fable of good American capitalism versus bad, and how Ray Kroc built his fortune by steamrolling Mac and Dick McDonald ‰ÛÓ the brothers who built the first McDonald‰Ûªs ‰ÛÓ before going in for the corporate kill. History has at times portrayed these brothers as naÌøve, almost as patsies. ‰ÛÏThe Founder,‰Ûù by contrast, suggests that the McDonalds weren‰Ûªt remotely rapacious enough to fend him off. They‰Ûªre proud and satisfied by what they‰Ûªve built and the warm, mournful performances of Nick Offerman as Dick and the invaluable John Carroll Lynch as Mac are arguments for decency. (That‰Ûªs nice, but this is still all about Ray.)

Ray Kroc, the whirling center of ‰ÛÏThe Founder,‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt come across as a meat-and-potatoes man ‰ÛÓ much less a mogul destined to peddle burgers and fries. As played by Michael Keaton, an actor who generates terrific centrifugal force, Ray seems more like a guy who fuels up on 10 cups of coffee before calling it a night with a bottle of Scotch. ‰ÛÏThe Founder‰Ûù never figures out what makes him spin and run and keep on running, but it does give you Mr. Keaton zinging around like the Road Runner. His kinetic performance doesn‰Ûªt enhance the movie; it is the movie.

Filmmakers used to polish up a halo to tell a great man‰Ûªs story; now they tend to carefully complicate the picture, underscoring his weaknesses and vices, boozing and philandering. Even with a few pins stuck in him, the great man remains great and very much the charismatic, triumphant individual. That‰Ûªs true of Ray, too, who for all his bad deeds never comes across as a true heavy. Mr. Keaton is good company, for one, and villainy just doesn‰Ûªt work in entertainments like this, which can‰Ûªt risk turning us off. Happily, there are always lawyers, in this case, Harry J. Sonneborn (B. J. Novak), who slithers up to Ray to explain where the money is. All Ray does is follow it.

Water is one of the great achievements of modern digital animation. Recent Hollywood movies like ‰ÛÏMoana‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏFinding Dory‰Ûù display glistening waves, plump raindrops and churning ocean depths with gaudy trade-show flash. ‰ÛÏThe Red Turtle,‰Ûù a feature by the Dutch animator Michael Dudok de Wit, hews to a quieter, proudly analog (or at least analog-evoking) approach. The waves that toss the nameless protagonist, a presumably shipwrecked fellow with black-dot eyes and an inky beard, are proudly two-dimensional, and look as if they had been rendered with a pen and a brush rather than a mouse and a software application.

The red sea turtle, an enigmatic and beautifully drawn creature that seems to have some kind of grudge against our hero, shows up just when you start to wonder if it will. Every time the man tries to leave the island, the turtle smashes his raft and knocks him back over the sandbar onto the beach. This leads to a confrontation that nudges the story all the way into the realm of fable. I won‰Ûªt say exactly what happens, except to note that it‰Ûªs both enchanting and a little queasy-making. But new characters do appear, fleshing out the drama and the imagery. Events take place that allow Mr. Dudok de Wit to make the most of his subdued palette and his spare, lyrical draftsmanship.

‰ÛÏThe Red Turtle‰Ûù practices a minor, gentle magic. It wants you to smile and say, ‰ÛÏAhh,‰Ûù rather than gasp and say, ‰ÛÏWow.‰Ûù But somehow the understatement can feel a bit overdone, as if the film were hovering over you, awaiting an expression of admiration. And it is hard not to admire the earnest artistry on display, even though it may also be hard to be as moved or enraptured as you suspect you should.

The film, a French-Belgian-Japanese co-production made under the auspices of Studio Ghibli  (home of the great Hayao Miyazaki) in Tokyo is also notable, at least in contrast to most American commercial animation, for the absence of celebrity voices or, indeed, of any human speech at all. The score, by Laurent Perez del Mar, does include some wordless choral vocalizing, but the story, like the visual style, is simple and elemental, like a picture book that needs no words.

The story has a wide-eyed, mutedly whimsical charm, with a light washing of eco-mysticism. Some of what happens may, on reflection, seem a little disturbing. The hapless mariner washes ashore ‰ÛÓ as such sailors usually do ‰ÛÓ on a deserted island, a tropical, rock-capped outcropping with wide, sandy beaches flanking a dense bamboo forest. There is a freshwater lagoon, and a few animals around for company and food, including sea lions and a squadron of quizzical crabs that silently and collectively perform the necessary cute-cartoon-sidekick duties.

For Nick Sand and Tim Scully, lysergic acid diethylamide was where it, really everything, was at. Both were in their 20s when they first experimented with psychedelics, an experience they say in the movie indelibly changed each for good and, some might say, bad. A California native, Mr. Scully had been studying at Berkeley before coming under the influence of Owsley Stanley, an intimate of the Grateful Dead and fervent advocate for acid. The more voluble Mr. Sand, a Brooklynite, entered the scene through Millbrook ‰ÛÓ the estate in upstate New York where Timothy Leary and friends partied for years ‰ÛÓ eventually going west. (In the early 1960s, Leary helped oversee the Harvard Psilocybin Project, researching LSD.)

The title of the documentary ‰ÛÏThe Sunshine Makers‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ about two trippy American renegades who produced millions of hits of LSD and helped turn on the United States of Acid ‰ÛÓ sounds like one of those old citrus labels that growers used to slap on wooden crates. With names like Morning Glory, these crates promised a ray of sun in each juicy bite. In 1970, Florida anointed itself the Sunshine State, but this documentary suggests that way out West, where much of this acid was produced, was where the sun shone the brightest.

Whether together or apart, Mr. Sand and Mr. Scully seemed to be operating on a similar wavelength, and the movie gets a lot of mileage from their sometimes excellent, at times hair-raising, occasionally puckishly funny and altogether wild adventures. At least according to ‰ÛÏThe Sunshine Makers,‰Ûù theirs is the story of two young men who found and (arguably) lost their way in the ‰Ûª60s, a tale that has resonance for the bigger sociopolitical picture. Both Mr. Scully and Mr. Sand saw themselves as missionaries of a type, spreading transcendence one hit at a time. Mr. Sand says that during one early enlightened moment, a voice told him, ‰ÛÏYour job on this planet is to make psychedelics and turn on the world.‰Ûù He obeyed that voice unconditionally.

The director, Cosmo Feilding Mellen, fluidly knits together a lot of information, people and places, sights and sounds, including some faded, pretty far-out archival footage of Mr. Sand and Mr. Scully making acid in labs back in the day. (The editor Nick Packer deserves credit as well.) As Mr. Mellen plaits together these individual histories, he incessantly toggles between past and present. Some of the flashbacks to the ‰Ûª60s are as familiar as hippie chicks and the corner of Haight and Ashbury, but Mr. Sand and Mr. Scully are true individuals, with delightful quirks and weird tales that keep the material from genericism. (There are several scenes of Mr. Sand practicing yoga in the nude, a lifelong habit that he‰Ûªs continued into his 70s.)

‰ÛÏThe Sunshine Makers‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt exactly an advocacy movie, but Mr. Mellen‰Ûªs sympathies are transparently with his subjects, even if he does check in (humorously and a touch condescendingly) with some of the cops who once chased down Mr. Sand and Mr. Scully. At times, it all seems a bit too, well, sunny, especially given what happened after Mr. Sand and Mr. Scully‰Ûªs production increased and their stacks of cash grew. (Another documentary, ‰ÛÏOrange Sunshine,‰Ûù focuses on the Brotherhood of Eternal Love, which distributed their acid.) Still, even if you never shake the feeling that there‰Ûªs more to this story, more darkness and scares, there‰Ûªs no question that hanging out with Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn on acid has its appeal.
But the movie benefits from an added layer: A screenwriting teacher who gets to know three teenagers awaiting trial.

The process of transforming real details into fiction seems to make the young men especially introspective. A scene in which Juan calls a girl he had a crush on, while a listening staff member roots for him, provides the film‰Ûªs most oddly affecting moment.

The teacher, Gabriel Cowan (also a producer of the film), leads a workshop at Barry J. Nidorf Juvenile Hall in the Sylmar neighborhood of Los Angeles. Together, he and the three inmates ‰ÛÓ Juan Gamez, Jarad Nava and Antonio Hernandez (Mr. Hernandez is released partway through the movie) ‰ÛÓ write a screenplay for a short film Mr. Cowan plans to make, inspired by the teenagers‰Ûª lives. We see excerpts from the result.

‰ÛÏThey Call Us Monsters‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt shy from the consequences of the violence the prisoners were accused of (we meet a paralyzed victim of a shooting), even as it suggests that the system ‰ÛÓ from a state senator who warns of ‰ÛÏmini-Charlie Mansons‰Ûù to lawyers resigned to stiff sentences ‰ÛÓ proceeds almost mechanically.

‰ÛÏThey Call Us Monsters,‰Ûù directed by Ben Lear (Norman Lear‰Ûªs son), might seem like a straightforward advocacy documentary. It concerns juveniles in California, accused of violent crimes, who are facing trial as adults with the prospect of spending the rest of their lives in prison.

The documentary might gain from longer-term or return treatment, particularly now that a California bill offering early parole hearings, under consideration for much of the film‰Ûªs running time (and shown passing in 2013), has taken effect.

Veering from hard-man posturing to roguish whimsy, Mr. Fassbender anchors a story (by Alastair Siddons, who previously worked on a documentary about a clan like this) that‰Ûªs more successful in texture than in logic. Stealing, racing and setting fire to random automobiles, the crew is a blight on the beauty around them. They‰Ûªre like a scraggly bunch of bored adolescents.

Neither does some of the dialogue i the first feature from Adam Smith, who might have considered using subtitles ‰ÛÓ at least when his robbers are wearing balaclavas. What we do hear, though, is pungent and colorful as Colby and his heir, Chad (Michael Fassbender), lock horns for control of Chad‰Ûªs future. Illiterate and weary of wandering, Chad wants a better life for his two kids ‰ÛÓ you can tell because he has plastic covers on his couch ‰ÛÓ while Colby prefers to fill their heads with primitive beliefs and gutter yearnings.

But they‰Ûªre also real, their decrepit campground and chafing interactions realized with rough authenticity. Though thematically vague, thinly plotted and without a reliably sympathetic soul to cling to, the movie has a mutinous energy and an absurd, knockabout charm; even its violence is more quirky than brutal. Like the Cutlers, it drifts and dreams, going nowhere and achieving nothing.

‰ÛÏBlessed are the cracked,‰Ûù says Colby Cutler (Brendan Gleeson), menacing patriarch to a ragtag clan of thieving Irish travelers parked in a verdant swath of English countryside. He‰Ûªs talking about Gordon (Sean Harris), a filthy lunatic whose relationship to the group is unclear. But he could be talking about his entire brood, whose marginal, scrabbling existence makes no sense at all.

Pier Paolo Pasolini and Catherine Breillat are other apparent reference points, but those artists, for all their sophistication, produced work seemingly animated by raw anger. ‰ÛÏWe Are the Flesh,‰Ûù its abundance of repellent imagery notwithstanding, has an air of the academic about it. That is, its lead performer, Mr. HernÌÁndez, comes off like that obnoxious fellow in your college acting class who ‰ÛÏspontaneously‰Ûù sheds all his clothes during the first stretching exercise, while Mr. Rocha Minter takes the role of the guy in your M.F.A. program who is maybe a little too eager to demonstrate that he can outdo the radical French intellectual Georges Bataille.
Mr. Rocha Minter, who is in his 20s, has obvious filmmaking talent, but he is also, to judge by this evidence, a sensationalist dilettante with a mean streak. He should go far in the business.
The obvious precursor to Mr. HernÌÁndez‰Ûªs character is Coffin Joe, the sadistic anti-messiah in a series of grimy, powerful 1960s films by the Brazilian director and actor JosÌ© Mojica Marins.

‰ÛÏWe Are the Flesh,‰Ûù the debut feature by the Mexican writer and director Emiliano Rocha Minter, is set some time after the end of civilization (or so it seems ‰ÛÓ stick around for the ‰ÛÏtwist‰Ûù ending). The movie finds young adults, a brother and sister (Diego Gamaliel and Maria Evoli), coming upon and forming an alliance with a hermit (NoÌ© HernÌÁndez) in a vacant apartment building.

Incest, menstrual-blood play, torture and cannibalism ensue. The Mexican national anthem is sung by the characters during a particularly fraught sequence, to let you know that the whole thing is a metaphor. And a classical piece by Bach accompanies a flesh-eating orgy to let you know that the director has seen ‰ÛÏA Clockwork Orange.‰Ûù

Not that the ladies mind, firing double-entendres and jets of pheromones whenever he‰Ûªs around.
