His latest mission is to retrieve a stolen superweapon known as Pandora‰Ûªs Box, which will involve assembling an oddball cohort ‰ÛÓ including a lion-loving sniper (Ruby Rose) and a concussion-damaged stunt driver (Rory McCann) ‰ÛÓ and a great deal of kicking and punching and smirking. Acting is pretty much surplus to those requirements, though it seems no one told Nina Dobrev, who plays a tech-support geek with more verve than she mustered in six seasons of ‰ÛÏThe Vampire Diaries.‰Ûù

Weirdly retro in style, the movie has a mocking ‰ÛÏAustin Powers‰Ûù flavor. Villains travel with bikini babes Velcroed to each hip, and women slink and pose as if inspired by boom-chicka-boom music only they can hear. Characters are simply triggers for the overwrought action sequences, though between the Edward Scissorhands editing and occasional wobbling background, even those are less than distinct.

Silly as it is, ‰ÛÏXander Cage‰Ûù nevertheless purveys a deeply depressing view of heroism, one without conscience, compassion or moral qualms. Xander might dally with women, but it‰Ûªs mayhem that owns his heart.

Props to Vin Diesel for not sliding gently into late middle age ‰ÛÓ much like his character, Xander Cage, in the so-called ‰ÛÏTriple-X‰Ûù franchise. In ‰ÛÏXXX: Return of Xander Cage,‰Ûù Mr. Diesel might be pushing 50, but physically he hasn‰Ûªt changed much since 2002, when Xander, a pumped-up spy, went into exile at the end of the first movie. He still looks like a hard-boiled egg sitting on top of a fire hydrant.

The movie, directed by Lasse Hallstrom and based on a novel by W. Bruce Cameron, serves up one cloying story after another as it drags us through the multiple lives of a dog named Bailey (voiced by Josh Gad). Bailey dies, as dogs do, yet keeps being reincarnated, as a different breed and sometimes a different sex.

Along the way, though, he has various other owners, allowing the movie to indulge in assorted hero-dog fantasies. Save people from a burning house? Check. Plunge into raging waters to keep a child from drowning? Check. Nudge a lonely woman into a romantic relationship? Check. Only ‰ÛÏTimmy has fallen into a well‰Ûù is missing.

He has a few cute mannerisms and tricks that are consistent from life to life, which ultimately becomes tear-jerkingly important as he tries to find his way back to Ethan (Bryce Gheisar, K. J. Apa or Dennis Quaid, depending on which year and dog it is), an early owner with whom he was especially tight.
You don‰Ûªt need an animal-rights group‰Ûªs boycott to give you permission to avoid ‰ÛÏA Dog‰Ûªs Purpose.‰Ûù You can skip it just because it‰Ûªs clumsily manipulative dreck.

It‰Ûªs also family friendly, the vignettes being nothing but a string of nonthreatening clichÌ©s with a dog injected into them. Which brings up another shortcoming of this film: It seems likely to prompt youngsters to ask for a dog, but it depicts almost none of the challenges and responsibilities of pet ownership. In this glossy world, dogs require little maintenance. They‰Ûªre just there, at the ready, waiting for you to fall into a river so they can pull you out.

The PETA opposition will no doubt trouble some of the dog lovers at whom this film is aimed. (Reviewer discloser: have a cat; am neutral about dogs.) They may not be able to resist anyway, because hey, it‰Ûªs dogs delivering insipid lines about bacon and the joys of eating from the garbage.

It was that raging-waters scene, by the way, that incurred the wrath of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, which has urged a boycott of the film. A video published by TMZ showed a dog resisting being put in the water during the scene‰Ûªs filming; others have said the video is misleading.

Like Hubert Sauper‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWe Come as Friends‰Ûù and Michael Glawogger‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWorkingman‰Ûªs Death,‰Ûù the movie sees a perverse, almost science-fiction beauty in the ravages of destruction. Mr. Zhao‰Ûªs camera rides along on mine tracks; the screen turns an iridescent red with the flames of ironworks. The final sequence ‰ÛÓ the Paradise section ‰ÛÓ observes a trash picker in a ‰ÛÏghost city,‰Ûù an uninhabited municipality built during a boom, and an almost comically pointless result of the toils we‰Ûªve witnessed.

Although ‰ÛÏBehemoth‰Ûù uses ‰ÛÏThe Divine Comedy‰Ûù as a template for its structure and narration, this documentary from Zhao Liang (‰ÛÏPetition‰Ûù) is a feat of pictorial storytelling. Unfolding with little exposition, it finds horror and surrealism in Inner Mongolia, where migrant iron and coal workers are shown as cogs of the monster of economic progress in China. A late shot shows tombstones of the deceased, with construction trucks (‰ÛÏthe monster‰Ûªs playthings‰Ûù) driving on higher ground in the distance.

If the movie‰Ûªs goal is to accord humanity to forgotten workers, it‰Ûªs easy to be of two minds. Mr. Zhao does not identify his subjects or ‰ÛÓ for the most part ‰ÛÓ give them a direct voice. Yet, ‰ÛÏBehemoth‰Ûù can be uncomfortably intimate. It ponders faces and blistered hands, and shows bottles of black fluid being extracted from workers, a consequence of pneumoconiosis, or black lung disease.
‰ÛÏBehemoth‰Ûù proceeds placidly, making it easy to become lulled. Its haunting power grows in retrospect ‰ÛÓ as if you‰Ûªve returned from a journey and can‰Ûªt believe what you‰Ûªve seen.

Kenny Wells, the feckless owner of a Nevada mining company, is the latest entry in the Matthew McConaughey gallery of charming rogues. Swaybacked and paunchy, with a thinning dome and an appetite for Winstons and Seagram‰Ûªs that would keep both brands in business if the rest of the world went cold turkey, Kenny doesn‰Ûªt quite have the wolfish charisma or the mystical intensity of some of Mr. McConaughey‰Ûªs other recent characters. But like them ‰ÛÓ like Mick Haller in ‰ÛÏThe Lincoln Lawyer,‰Ûù Ron Woodroof in ‰ÛÏDallas Buyers Club‰Ûù and that guy in those car commercials ‰ÛÓ he is fun to watch and hard not to root for.

What holds your attention is the question of whether that description fits Kenny as well. He could just as well be the opposite ‰ÛÓ a dishonorable success. He is far from a subtle guy, but Mr. McConaughey is a sly enough actor to make us wonder whether we‰Ûªre in the company of a fool or a con artist and to make us question whether there‰Ûªs really a difference. His wild, abrasive and improbably delicate performance is what makes ‰ÛÏGold‰Ûù watchable, even if the rest of the movie doesn‰Ûªt supply sufficient reason to keep watching.

‰ÛÏGold,‰Ûù which chronicles a few of Kenny‰Ûªs rises and falls in the 1980s, describes itself as ‰ÛÏinspired by actual events,‰Ûù but inspiration is precisely what the film, directed by Stephen Gaghan from a script by Patrick Massett and John Zinman, seems to lack. Mr. McConaughey is a ball of profane, entrepreneurial energy bouncing around in a vacuum. The story swings from the Nevada desert to the Indonesian rain forest to Wall Street boardrooms, and the screen bristles with signifiers of capitalist activity: meetings, phone calls, stock tickers. But the movie isn‰Ûªt really doing any work. It‰Ûªs just looking busy.

With this material, he could have gone in any number of interesting directions, which may have been part of the problem. ‰ÛÏGold‰Ûù could have been a biting satire of greed and folly, a neo-Conradian tale of Western misadventure in Asia, a rousing fable of underdog triumph or a caper comedy. It tries, in its frantic, clumsy fashion, to be all of those things, and comes close enough to succeeding to qualify as an honorable failure.

But enough goes wrong along the way ‰ÛÓ with the movie, I mean, not with Mike and Kenny‰Ûªs scheme ‰ÛÓ to make the outcome feel almost moot. The film is well cast: You can‰Ûªt really go wrong with Bill Camp, Corey Stoll, Stacy Keach and Bruce Greenwood. It‰Ûªs beautifully shot (you can‰Ûªt go wrong with Robert Elswit, either). There is a pleasingly sleazy, swaggering, brown-tinted ‰Ûª80s vibe. And there are flickering reminders of other ambitious, money-chasing mock epics, as if the filmmakers were hoping an algorithm would deposit ‰ÛÏGold‰Ûù in the queues of viewers who liked ‰ÛÏAmerican Hustle,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Big Short‰Ûù and Mr. Gaghan‰Ûªs own ‰ÛÏSyriana.‰Ûù

Having nearly run the family prospecting business into the ground (so to speak), Kenny gambles on the expertise of a Mike Acosta (Ìädgar RamÌ_rez), a geologist with an almost mystical reputation. They strike gold in Indonesia, and a gilded future opens up for Kenny and his longtime girlfriend, Kaylene (Bryce Dallas Howard). There are shadows and complications, of course, including the corruptions of wealth, the treachery of rivals and Kenny‰Ûªs own impulsiveness. Broad hints are dropped that things will end badly.

But whether agonizing over the Bible or flirting with Buddhism (in the form of a cute young Buddhist named Nico), Michael comes across as a thoroughly unlikable hypocrite, spouting hateful religious rhetoric one minute and ogling young men the next.

Nico, voicing what we‰Ûªve all been thinking, says, ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre very confused.‰Ûù Mr. Kelly is a patient, if unimaginative, filmmaker, but the movie‰Ûªs unvarying tone and unquestioning indulgence of Michael‰Ûªs repetitive spiritual flailings quickly become tiresome. His wishy-washy soul-searching isn‰Ûªt nearly compelling enough for us to care whose bed ‰ÛÓ or church ‰ÛÓ he winds up in.

After watching ‰ÛÏI Am Michael,‰Ûù Justin Kelly‰Ûªs dreary gay-conversion biopic, I felt rather sorry for James Franco. As Michael Glatze, a gay-rights agitator who struggled to become a straight Christian pastor, Mr. Franco broods and puzzles and vacillates. But he often seems abandoned by a director whose approach is so noncommittal and dramatically limp that it strands the actor, and his character, in a bland purgatory of conflicting motivations.

While intellectually laudable, Mr. Kelly‰Ûªs determined objectivity is so distancing that it takes an inherently intriguing story (based on a 2011 article in The New York Times Magazine) and sucks the life out of it. Shuffling along on the prompting of Michael‰Ûªs conflicted voice-over, the movie watches as he films a documentary about queer youth, suffers panic attacks, alienates his partner (Zachary Quinto, whose directness and intensity are welcome counterpoints to the general insipidness) and eventually finds God and a fiancÌ©e (Emma Roberts).
‰ÛÏGod is testing me,‰Ûù he moans, believing that he‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏa heterosexual person with a homosexual problem.‰Ûù

Despite its subtext about the economic rivalry between China and India, the film, written and directed by Mr. Chan‰Ûªs frequent collaborator Stanley Tong (‰ÛÏSupercop,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏRumble in the Bronx‰Ûù), mostly affords Mr. Chan the opportunity to mug, share a car chase scene with a lion (seemingly with a digital assist) and thwart assailants in a pallid variation on his acrobatics of old. A lively closing dance sequence, after an earnest, underwhelming climax, pays affectionate tribute to Bollywood production numbers. But you won‰Ûªt find Mr. Chan‰Ûªs customary bloopers over the closing credits. For Mr. Chan, the era for elaborate body stunts, be they botched or successfully executed, seems to have ended.

Here he plays Jack Chan, a professor of antiquities in China, who leads students as well as his martial-arts-trained nephew (Aarif Rahman, performing much of the fisticuffs) in a treasure hunt that takes them to the China-India border (Iceland stands in); Dubai; and Jaipur, India. Also seeking the ancient riches, for sympathetic ends, is a gorgeous South Asian yoga practitioner (Disha Patani), and, for evil ones, an Indian patrician (Sonu Sood). Snakes, in ‰ÛÏIndiana Jones‰Ûù style, play an occasional supporting role.

‰ÛÏI love Indiana Jones,‰Ûù Jackie Chan‰Ûªs character says at one point in ‰ÛÏKung Fu Yoga.‰Ûù And in this harmless romp, Mr. Chan, now 62, plays an archaeologist. But he does not wield a whip nor wear a fedora nor, for that matter, display the vigor of a young Harrison Ford or a young Jackie Chan.

Eric (Brett Dalton) and his girlfriend, Colleen (Emily Atack), are visiting Italy when he decides to propose, and is rejected. Colleen goes home to the States to think it over, but Eric stays in Florence, where he discovers two things: a local sport called calcio storico, and an attractive local woman, Stefania (Alessandra Mastronardi).

Calcio storico, a team sport, is what you might get if you put soccer, American football, rugby and boxing into a blender. It‰Ûªs bone-crunching and virtually rule-free. Back in the United States, Eric had come close to making the National Football League, and he finds that his abilities transfer well to calcio storico. Unfortunately, the leader of the team he talks his way onto, Paolo (Alessandro Preziosi), also happens to be Stefania‰Ûªs boyfriend.

The male-fantasy earmarks of ‰ÛÏLost in Florence,‰Ûù a guy-perspective romance written and directed by Evan Oppenheimer, are hard to ignore, but it‰Ûªs still a reasonably pleasant film. Florence looks great; the cast is appealing; and you‰Ûªll learn about a rough-and-tumble sport you may not have encountered before.

Things go pretty much where a reader of lad magazines would want them to: climactic game decided at the last second; two gorgeous women competing for the same man. The story may not stay with you, but don‰Ûªt be surprised if you come away with a strong desire to visit Florence.

The therapeutic value of art is an important subject, and it‰Ûªs heartwarming to see the spunk of children like Tain Gregory, who auditions with a lively recitation of Lewis Carroll, or Sammy Vertucci, who describes the challenges of playing a magical creature. The filmmaker, Lloyd Kramer, interviews their parents and survivors of the shooting, including Becky Virgalla, a reading consultant at Sandy Hook at the time. Nelba MÌÁrquez-Greene and Jimmy Greene remember Ana, the daughter they lost.

Yet it‰Ûªs possible to think these things and still have reservations about the movie‰Ûªs techniques. ‰ÛÏMidsummer in Newtown‰Ûù leans heavily on maudlin musical cues, cheapening its subjects‰Ûª words. Some tragedies defy conventional representation. Unlike the play it documents, this documentary shows few signs of thinking outside the box.

The power of the testimony and the horror of the circumstances present a challenge for assessing ‰ÛÏMidsummer in Newtown‰Ûù as a documentary. Unquestionably, these voices need to be heard, and the creation of a joyous stage play ‰ÛÓ a way to say, ‰ÛÏLook at these children‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ sends a vital symbolic message.

The preparations for a community theater production of ‰ÛÏA Midsummer Night‰Ûªs Dream‰Ûù might seem like standard documentary material. But ‰ÛÏMidsummer in Newtown‰Ûù was made in Newtown, Conn., and follows the 2014 production of ‰ÛÏA ROCKIN‰Ûª Midsummer Night‰Ûªs Dream,‰Ûù a musical version of Shakespeare‰Ûªs play mounted by NewArts, an organization that aims to help residents heal by fostering the performing arts. Many of the cast members of ‰ÛÏA ROCKIN‰Ûª Midsummer Night‰Ûªs Dream‰Ûù are children, survivors of the 2012 school shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary.

The first words spoken in ‰ÛÏParis 05:59 ThÌ©o & Hugo‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏYou always keep your eyes shut?‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ come almost 20 minutes into a dreamily choreographed free-for-all in the basement of a gay Parisian sex club. The speaker is ThÌ©o (Geoffrey CouÌÇt), a curly-haired faun who seems simultaneously fascinated and terrified by the orgy of licking and thrusting around him. A first-time visitor adrift in a writhing sea of modelesque faces and substantial penises, ThÌ©o is a perfect surrogate for unsuspecting audiences.

The man he‰Ûªs addressing is Hugo (FranÌ_ois Nambot), whose eyes catch ThÌ©o‰Ûªs, and the club‰Ûªs revelers instantly recede ‰ÛÓ no longer participants, but witnesses. The artifice of the staging suggests that there‰Ûªs something magical about the pair‰Ûªs instantaneous connection, yet it‰Ûªs also quite funny: Feet incongruously dressed in bright sneakers and jolly-looking socks, the two wear their nakedness like playful children.

This gives the sequence an innocence that softens its unabashed explicitness. Leaving the club in the wee hours, they cycle and wander through silently sleeping streets, grab food from a vendor and catch the first metro to ThÌ©o‰Ûªs apartment. Their odyssey, told in real time and with the help of occasional onscreen reminders, shares the gentle walking-and-talking air of Richard Linklater‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBefore Sunrise.‰Ûù Unlike that film‰Ûªs characters, however, ThÌ©o and Hugo have thoroughly explored each other‰Ûªs bodies before opening up their minds.

The consequences of that will cause the men to fight and the film to shift to an almost clinical tone as the realities of gay romance ‰ÛÓ and how Paris seeks to protect its more reckless lovers ‰ÛÓ temporarily derail the couple‰Ûªs growing infatuation. The movie might have a fairy-tale quality, but its writers and directors, Olivier Ducastel and Jacques Martineau, are committed to those realities. The specifics of the sex club, its lube and condoms and Handi-Wipes within easy reach, are neither highlighted nor disguised. And a lengthy emergency room visit delivers a harsh reminder that desire carries no free passes.

Light on plot yet heavy on chemistry, ‰ÛÏParis 05:59‰Ûù is at times a little precious. But the two leads are so believably besotted that their occasional immaturity doesn‰Ûªt rankle. (One of the film‰Ûªs loveliest tics is to keep catching ThÌ©o‰Ûªs watching Hugo with a small, secretive smile, as if he couldn‰Ûªt believe his luck.)

Responding to the shifts in mood, the director of photography, Manuel Marmier, moves smoothly from the vampiric red lighting of the sex club to the gold-and-carbon beauty of a predawn Paris. Subsidiary characters ‰ÛÓ an elderly woman on the MÌ©tro; a Syrian kebab vendor ‰ÛÓ add subtle political commentary and local color, but ThÌ©o and Hugo have eyes only for each other. At once hopeful and pragmatic, their love has been sparked by sex; which will outlive the other remains to be seen.

Set in Gujarat, in the 1980s and ‰Ûª90s, the movie depicts an India of petty corruption, with cops and politicians on the take, and honor among thieves more aspirational than real. ‰ÛÏThis world is broken,‰Ûù Raees says in voice-over. ‰ÛÏYou have to turn crooked to fix it.‰Ûù And so he does, in a time-honored movie way. In one scene, he beats up a derelict factory owner at a drive-in, as the big screen shows Amitabh Bachchan, Hindi cinema‰Ûªs original Angry Young Fix-It Man, threatening a boss who is careless with workers‰Ûª lives.

The ‰ÛÏking of Bollywood,‰Ûù Shah Rukh Khan, rarely plays the villain. His specialty has been goofball sweetie-pies: romantics, naÌøfs, the occasional superhero with a runny nose. So it‰Ûªs not surprising that as the criminal title character in Rahul Dholakia‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRaees‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a bootlegger turned kingpin turned politician turned folk hero ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs more populist do-gooder than villain, a man whose heart is mostly gold, tarnished but unmistakable.

Avoiding flabby subplots, Mr. Dholakia keeps ‰ÛÏRaees‰Ûù taut and suspenseful, even at two and a half hours, though it probably has a song too many. (A classic Item Girl number, with Sunny Leone, seems torn between leering and being frank about the sexual threat inherent in ‰Û_ leering.)

Raees is a Muslim with ecumenical good will: He sends meals to Hindu families in need as well as Muslims. And he has a stated belief that ‰ÛÏno faith is greater than business.‰Ûù But in real life, business can have borders ‰ÛÓ some drawn, like India and Pakistan‰Ûªs, by faith. Indian film producers voted last year not to employ Pakistanis, and Pakistan has banned Indian shows. That means Mahira Khan (no relation to Shah Rukh), the Pakistani actress making her Hindi movie debut as Raees‰Ûªs wife, has been barred from promoting the film in India, and it won‰Ûªt be shown in Pakistan. Politics 1, Culture 0.

Nevertheless, the movie percolates enough that even when, at its climax, it shamelessly recycles a grisly punch line from 1987‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRoboCop,‰Ûù it‰Ûªs kind of endearing, not least because Mr. Anderson and company make it work.

Because their director, Paul W. S. Anderson, is an exceptional talent in action cinema, and because their star, Milla Jovovich, is a charismatic, exceptional and very credibly kinetic action performer, the movies in the ‰ÛÏResident Evil‰Ûù franchise, of which this is the sixth, have always been a terrific time. Provided you like that sort of thing ‰ÛÓ that sort of thing being post-apocalyptic and necessarily grim sci-fi mayhem adapted from a popular, genre-mashing video game.

There‰Ûªs some really hair-raising stuff here, including a rain-of-fire set piece for which Mr. Anderson‰Ûªs last film, ‰ÛÏPompeii,‰Ûù might have served as a kind of dress rehearsal. Among Alice‰Ûªs foes are hordes of flesh-eating undead, and it‰Ûªs to Mr. Anderson‰Ûªs credit that even in a pop culture glutted with postmodern zombies, he can make his creatures startle viewers. But the blindingly fast cuts and the inflated reprises of the franchise‰Ûªs greatest hits ‰ÛÓ the startling undead Dobermans of the first film are back ‰ÛÓ yield diminishing returns. This is, I think, the weakest picture in the franchise.

In ‰ÛÏResident Evil: The Final Chapter,‰Ûù Ms. Jovovich‰Ûªs Alice, a virally superpowered avenger on behalf of a highly diminished human population, is assisted by her onetime nemesis the Red Queen, an artificial intelligence program that takes the holographic form of a young girl. Deep in ‰ÛÏthe Hive‰Ûù of Raccoon City, where all the ‰ÛÏResident Evil‰Ûù trouble began, is a vial that can save humanity. A time-sensitive gauntlet is laid down, and the never-ending action begins.

The movie demolishes some myths: The director was not afraid of driving, but he was a very bad and easily distracted driver. While a demanding employer, he was a kind man: When Mr. D‰ÛªAlessandro‰Ûªs son was seriously injured, Kubrick was solicitous about getting him the best care, writing in one of his innumerable notes to Mr. D‰ÛªAlessandro (which he signed with an ‰ÛÏS‰Ûù), ‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt worry about the costs, I‰Ûªll take care of that.‰Ûù

On a snowy London evening in the early 1970s, when the roads were unusually hazardous, a minicab driver named Emilio D‰ÛªAlessandro was the only fellow willing to transport an unusual movie prop: a cumbersome Modernist sculpture of a phallus. That object, which he delivered to a film set in good, if not record, time, is familiar to anyone who‰Ûªs seen Stanley Kubrick‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏA Clockwork Orange.‰Ûù

Mr. D‰ÛªAlessandro, likable and sympathetic, admits that he didn‰Ûªt watch a single Kubrick film until he took a brief break from the director‰Ûªs employ between ‰ÛÏFull Metal Jacket‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏEyes Wide Shut,‰Ûù and that he told his boss that he‰Ûªd have preferred Charles Bronson in the lead role of ‰ÛÏThe Shining.‰Ûù But he‰Ûªs not always the best raconteur; he ends a story of a phone call between Kubrick and Federico Fellini without telling whether its purpose was even fulfilled. Still, for Kubrick enthusiasts, this picture will provide a fun and sometimes moving fix.

Kubrick was impressed with Mr. D‰ÛªAlessandro and hired him as a driver. ‰ÛÏS Is for Stanley,‰Ûù a documentary directed by Alex Infascelli, is the story of this man who, over 30 years, became much more than a driver to Kubrick. (It‰Ûªs based on Mr. D‰ÛªAlessandro‰Ûªs memoir, ‰ÛÏStanley Kubrick and Me.‰Ûù)

Last year, Jared P. Scott tackled financial inequality in ‰ÛÏRequiem for the American Dream,‰Ûù a film about Noam Chomsky, of which he was a director. In ‰ÛÏThe Age of Consequences,‰Ûù Mr. Scott looks at climate change from the perspective of military experts rather than that of scientists.

The information here is compelling and frightening, but the movie is ham-handed. Malcolm Francis‰Ûªs almost nonstop score is emphatic to a fault; interviewees extrapolate a ‰ÛÏperfect storm‰Ûù of concurrent catastrophes that could cripple the United States; there‰Ûªs no bright side, and scant hope, just 70 minutes of unrelenting bad news served with dollops of implicit audience-blaming. A tacked-on eight-minute ‰ÛÏcall to action‰Ûù coda feels halfhearted.

Michael Breen, a former Army officer, considers the role of climate change in human conflicts. ‰ÛÏThink about relationships we don‰Ûªt often look at,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏThe civil war in Syria, now going on for years, hundreds of thousands dead ‰ÛÓ the entire region is in chaos as a result.‰Ûù The movie details how a three-year drought helped precipitate that war.

At one point, a historian observes that ‰ÛÏadvanced societies were very vulnerable to confusing lifestyle with life itself.‰Ûù This may be true, but delivered in this tricksy, overdetermined way, it‰Ûªs likely to elicit a pot-calling-the-kettle-black response from overwhelmed viewers.

Talking about one of the strategies of the Islamic State, also known as ISIS, the retired Brig. Gen. Stephen Cheney states, ‰ÛÏYou control the water, you control the livelihood of the people.‰Ûù Climate change affects the amount of water, and so terrorist organizations move to where the water is. The connection between environmental disaster and terrorism is drawn, persuasively. (The ‰ÛÏMad Max: Fury Road‰Ûù scenario in which a despot clings to power by holding on to a water supply starts to look mildly plausible.)

Set in a declining Australian logging town, the drama swirls around Christian (Paul Schneider), a grumpy prodigal son. Returning home after 15 years in the United States, Christian is a newly sober drunk dragging an arsenal of anger and resentment. Its object is his father, Henry (Geoffrey Rush), owner of the town‰Ûªs recently shuttered sawmill and imminent bridegroom to his significantly younger and absurdly gorgeous housekeeper (Anna Torv).

Not to mention unearned, as the script barely sketches its characters before expecting us to care about their fates. Henry, in particular, is an indistinct patriarch whose charms, if he has any, remain hidden. And the great Sam Neill, as Oliver‰Ûªs father, brings quite astonishing nuance to a role that requires him to do little more than care for injured wildlife.

Constructed gingerly around a soon-to-explode family secret, ‰ÛÏThe Daughter‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a soapy take on Henrik Ibsen‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Wild Duck‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ creates a superficial tension by situating its escalating emotions within icily contained visuals. For a while, this slow-burn approach by the writer and director, Simon Stone, works: Stabilized by mostly unimpeachable performances, the movie hugs the rails of credibility more tightly than its melodramatic material deserves.

Picking up the slack, the director of photography, Andrew Commis, communicates despair through melancholy tracking shots of lonely woods and isolated homesteads, boarded-up businesses and packing-up families. But the intimacy needed for the tragedy to resonate is mostly lacking, and Mr. Schneider is unable to make Christian more than an instrument of combustion: Having clumsily lighted the movie‰Ûªs fuse, he slides into the wings. By ensuring that everyone is as miserable as he is, he proves far more reprehensible than any of the people whose lives he has so callously ruined.

Reworking his stage adaptation of Ibsen‰Ûªs play ‰ÛÓ a study of weaponized truth ‰ÛÓ Mr. Stone concocts a predictable stew of ancient transgressions and undeserved recriminations. The characters don‰Ûªt have conversations so much as helpfully recite their back stories, and the long-buried secret is soon so obvious that the movie‰Ûªs last-act hysteria feels forced and a little ridiculous.

Separated from his long-suffering wife, Christian is made even grumpier by the marital happiness of an old school friend, Oliver (Ewen Leslie, terrific), whose familial contentment acts as a goad. Devoted to his wife and teenage daughter (Miranda Otto and a wonderfully expressive Odessa Young), Oliver, with his energy and positivity, is unprotected from Christian‰Ûªs vindictiveness; he‰Ûªs a mirror that Christian can‰Ûªt wait to crack.

That life invades the couple‰Ûªs household with shocking force. Rana is assaulted in the shower, and her attacker vanishes, leaving behind his pickup truck. The crime reveals tensions and fissures within her marriage, and also beyond it. Rana, whose head was injured in the attack ‰ÛÓ other possible traumas are left implicit ‰ÛÓ is terrified and distraught, but Emad seems more concerned with the injury to his own manhood. The absence of the police suggests a lack of trust in official authority so complete that it is scarcely worth mentioning. Emad‰Ûªs search for answers, and for something like justice, turns him into a reluctant vigilante, and ‰ÛÏThe Salesman‰Ûù is unsparing in its portrayal of the moral emptiness of personal vengeance.

Rana and Emad, a childless married couple who look to be in their mid-30s, are both actors, members of a theater company engaged in a production of Arthur Miller‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDeath of a Salesman.‰Ûù Onstage, they play the Lomans, Willy and Linda, whose lower-middle-class American world is made to look both familiar and exotic. Some of the play‰Ûªs sexual frankness has been blunted by Iranian government censors ‰ÛÓ in a pivotal scene, Willy‰Ûªs mistress shows up in his hotel room wearing a hat and a belted red raincoat, rather than a nightgown ‰ÛÓ and its themes of striving and sacrifice seem distant from Rana and Emad‰Ûªs life. Though they are not wealthy, the fact that they ‰ÛÏwork in culture‰Ûù gives them a certain cachet, and they sometimes radiate a quiet sense of superiority in interactions with neighbors and acquaintances.
[See where to stream Asghar Farhadi‰Ûªs dramas at Watching, The New York Times‰Ûªs film and TV recommendation site.]

The apartment that Emad and Rana move into ‰ÛÓ thanks to the generosity of a colleague ‰ÛÓ isn‰Ûªt actually haunted, but like many films about real estate ‰ÛÏThe Salesman‰Ûù is to some extent a horror movie. The previous tenant was a single woman with a young child, and the stuff she left behind is more than just annoying clutter. It‰Ûªs a collection of clues to an unacknowledged mystery, haunting traces of an invisible life.

It is in the midst of this painful tale of crime and punishment that the spirit of Willy Loman makes its improbable, powerful and surprisingly literal return. ‰ÛÏThe Salesman‰Ûù is about trust and honor, about violence against women in a patriarchal society, about the woe that is in marriage, but it is also about death, a salesman and the hidden brutality of class. Not since Pedro AlmodÌ_var‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAll About My Mother,‰Ûù which brilliantly re-engineered ‰ÛÏA Streetcar Named Desire,‰Ûù has a classic of the American stage been put to such ingenious cinematic use. Mr. Farhadi‰Ûªs control is astonishing, as is the discipline of the actors. Their final scenes are at once riveting and hard to watch. Attention, as someone once said, must be paid.

At the beginning of ‰ÛÏThe Salesman,‰Ûù Emad (Shahab Hosseini) and Rana (Taraneh Alidoosti) must evacuate their Tehran apartment. There are cracks in the walls, and the high-rise building is in danger of collapsing. That flawed edifice might stand as a kind of inverse metaphor for the film itself, which is a marvel of meticulous construction. With exquisite patience and attention to detail, Asghar Farhadi, the writer and director, builds a solid and suspenseful plot out of ordinary incidents, and packs it with rich and resonant ideas.

The ghost of Willy Loman nonetheless hovers over ‰ÛÏThe Salesman,‰Ûù suggesting an interpretive puzzle. The choice of this particular play-within-the-film can‰Ûªt be arbitrary, but its meaning is not immediately apparent. For most of its running time, the movie seems occupied with its own dramatic issues, principally the aftermath of a shocking and apparently inexplicable act of violence.

Admirers of his earlier films ‰ÛÓ including ‰ÛÏAbout Elly,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Past‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏA Separation,‰Ûù a foreign-language Oscar winner in 2012 ‰ÛÓ will not be surprised. Mr. Farhadi has distinguished himself in his generation of Iranian filmmakers as an astute psychological realist and a fastidious storyteller. Although his films take place in a thoroughly modern, urban environment, there is something satisfyingly old-fashioned about his approach to contemporary life, an understated belief in the ethical value of addressing the complexities of experience through the clarity and subtlety of narrative art.

The Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin is a complicated man. And that much is made clear in ‰ÛÏMr. Gaga,‰Ûù Tomer Heymann‰Ûªs documentary about his life and work, which opens with Mr. Naharin‰Ûªs instructing a dancer on how to fall to the floor after simulating a seizure of sorts. His dissatisfaction is palpable, yet his terse directives begin to seem contradictory. He wants the dancer to be conscious of what she‰Ûªs doing, but also to fall naturally. Despite expending much effort, she is showing her boss exactly what he doesn‰Ûªt want to see.

Mr. Naharin is an intriguing figure. But ‰ÛÏMr. Gaga‰Ûù is a scattered and somewhat confused film. It tells a love story, that of Mr. Naharin and his first wife, Mari Kajiwara, whom he met when she was dancing in New York for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and who died in 2001. It tells of a late-‰Ûª90s controversy in Israel in which Mr. Naharin resigned, with his troupe, from a performance commemorating the country‰Ûªs 50th anniversary after a conflict over his company‰Ûªs costuming.

The film‰Ûªs title, ‰ÛÏMr. Gaga,‰Ûù may bring to mind a certain pop star, but it is actually derived from a dance language Mr. Naharin developed over the years, one he is shown demonstrating to nondancers of varying ages and abilities. The practice was born from Mr. Naharin‰Ûªs long-held conviction that ‰ÛÏphysical pleasure from physical activity was part of being alive.‰Ûù Later, he talks about applying the principle of ‰ÛÏconnecting effort and pleasure‰Ûù to his choreography.

All I could think about was how bruised her side was going to be. Mr. Naharin, however, is not a sadist. As years of rehearsal and performance footage demonstrate, Mr. Naharin, leader of the Batsheva Dance Company, based in Tel Aviv, doesn‰Ûªt ask his dancers to do anything that he wouldn‰Ûªt do himself, or subject them to anything he wouldn‰Ûªt put himself through.

But in between strong vignettes, it presents portions of Mr. Naharin‰Ûªs work willy-nilly; the archival dance footage is often murky, and the newly shot dances are captured with little imagination or energy. The filmmakers‰Ûª disinclination to contextualize Mr. Naharin‰Ûªs sometimes prickly personality is also bothersome. A more finely focused treatment would have made a much better summation of, or introduction to, Mr. Naharin‰Ûªs work.

Holding it all together is an exploration ‰ÛÓ always intriguing if not always coherent ‰ÛÓ of the myths and puzzles of female sexuality. In this, in its rigorous attention to the expressive possibilities of costume and dÌ©cor, and in its mixing of knowing allusiveness with earnest feeling, ‰ÛÏThe Lure‰Ûù would make an apt companion for Anna Biller‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Love Witch‰Ûù in a feminist genre-scrambling exploitation double feature.

As it happens, the club, with its seedy glamour and its muted sparkle, represents a partial concession to realism. Ms. Smoczynska shot much of ‰ÛÏThe Lure‰Ûù in an abandoned Warsaw cabaret, decorating it to evoke the ‰ÛÏdancing restaurants‰Ûù of the Communist era. An aura of nonspecific nostalgia hangs in the air. We are not exactly in the present and not precisely in the past, but in a dreamy cinematic space where distinctions of genre and tone are pleasantly (and sometimes shockingly) blurred.

The object of mermaid lust plays bass in the house band, whose other members include, on drums (Andrzej Konopka) and lead vocals (Kinga Preis), a middle-aged couple whose relationship offers a quiet rebuke to Silver and Gold‰Ûªs romantic ideas about humanity. The musical numbers ‰ÛÓ written by Barbara and Zuzanna Wronska of the Polish band Ballady i Romanse ‰ÛÓ add a jolt of rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll energy and a swirl of camp decadence to a story that swerves, sometimes smoothly and sometimes jerkily, from parody to fairy tale to gleeful gore.

As folkloric Polish musical sex-comedy horror movies go, ‰ÛÏThe Lure‰Ûù is pretty interesting. The first feature directed by Agnieszka Smoczynska, the film follows two mermaid sisters onto land, where they look for love, feast on human flesh and find work singing and stripping at a nightclub that might have come from an early David Lynch movie or a vintage-‰Ûª80s music video.

Gold (Michalina Olszanska) and Silver (Marta Mazurek) come ashore because one of them is smitten with a hunky unnamed human (Jakub Gierszal). In their natural habitat, the seductive sisters have enormous, slimy tails. Out of water, they temporarily exchange these for legs, becoming anatomically identical to terrestrial women in all respects but one. Below the waist, they are (as the club‰Ûªs manager puts it) ‰ÛÏas smooth as Barbie dolls,‰Ûù and their lack of genitalia proves to be a source of protection and frustration in their new environment.

The stylistic and cultural differences between the films are also worth noting. Ms. Biller‰Ûªs fantasy of power, desire and vengeance is at once angrier and more playful than Ms. Smoczynska‰Ûªs fable of heartbreak and sisterly solidarity. While the sirens in ‰ÛÏThe Lure‰Ûù exercise and experience an attraction that is sometimes fatal, their adventures are chronicled in a spirit that is more fatalistic than furious. A fish out of water is by definition an absurd figure, and also, potentially, a tragic one.

Unlike Mr. Morris‰Ûªs work, ‰ÛÏA Good American‰Ûù is less interested in ambiguity than advocacy. Mr. Binney, an outspoken critic of the N.S.A., who appeared in Laura Poitras‰Ûªs Edward J. Snowden documentary, ‰ÛÏCitizenfour,‰Ûù describes an ‰ÛÏarrogance of power‰Ûù that he has seen from the time of the Vietnam War to his departure from the N.S.A. in October 2001. Thomas A. Drake, a former N.S.A. official turned whistle-blower, says that, running ThinThread after the Sept. 11 attacks, he discovered critical intelligence the agency didn‰Ûªt know it had.

The movie takes some time to explain that conclusion, winding its way through Mr. Binney‰Ûªs biography and how he gained expertise in the emerging field of metadata. The filmmaker, Friedrich Moser, borrows heavily from Errol Morris, employing re-enactments, moving graphics and a Philip Glass-like score.

‰ÛÏA Good American‰Ûù opens with the voice of a woman calling from a hijacked plane on Sept. 11. The documentary then moves to an explosive assertion: It says that ThinThread, a data collection program, ‰ÛÏabsolutely would have prevented 9/11.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs according to William E. Binney, a former technical director at the National Security Agency and the principal subject of this film.

His story goes beyond the scope of the film. Mr. Drake‰Ûªs disclosure of internal information about ThinThread and Trailblazer, a rival program, to The Baltimore Sun led to a major leak prosecution case. (He received a plea deal on a minor charge and served no time.) ‰ÛÏA Good American‰Ûù gets bogged down in details and personnel talk, but its subjects have an urgent narrative to tell.

So Lance winds up at a community food-delivery service and soon becomes friendly with Miss Maddy (Loretta Devine), whose artistically talented grandson Ty (Khadim Diop) is involved with the kind of gang business that got Lance locked up in the first place.

From the way the scene is framed, viewers can tell the beginning of this powerful movie is in fact its tragic-seeming end. On a rainy night in Harlem, a muscular man sits on a milk cart, smoking a cigarette, waiting. What he‰Ûªs waiting for, a police car, is not long in coming. In voice-over, the man introduces himself as L, adding: ‰ÛÏCheck with your crew. Find out who I am.‰Ûù

The movie‰Ûªs wide-screen framing, ruthless plot reversals and say-what-you-mean writing sometimes recall a master of socially conscious cinema from another era, Sam Fuller. But this is a picture with its own strong voice. It‰Ûªs not perfect ‰ÛÓ a subplot that has Lance fending off advances from his supervisor is arbitrarily sexist. Although it does give rise to the movie‰Ûªs funniest dialogue exchange. And the actual ending, while troubling, holds out a tenuous kind of hope.

The film, ‰ÛÏChapter & Verse,‰Ûù is directed by Jamal Joseph from a script he wrote with Daniel Beaty, who also gives a superb performance in the lead role of an ex-convict re-entering society. After that opening, the movie flashes back to a newly released L (short for Lance; the scene in which he explains his name is as warmly funny as it is heartbreaking), seething with frustration as he fails to find work repairing computers. ‰ÛÏI got two computer certificates,‰Ûù he complains to his halfway-house officer. The response isn‰Ûªt sympathetic: ‰ÛÏI took piano lessons. You don‰Ûªt see [me] at Carnegie Hall.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏDark Night,‰Ûù written and directed by Tim Sutton, is a movie about a massacre at a movie theater. It was inspired by, and explicitly refers to, the fatal shootings committed by James Holmes at an Aurora, Colo., showing of the film ‰ÛÏThe Dark Knight Rises.‰Ûù The wordplay of the title is sufficiently egregious that a potential viewer is apt to think, ‰ÛÏWell, if it got a distributor, it has to be better than that.‰Ûù It is not.

Until its climax, which clearly seeks to be congratulated on its restraint, ‰ÛÏDark Night‰Ûù is not much more than an arty bore, its visual approach drawing from thematically related (and much better) films, such as Gus Van Sant‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏElephant‰Ûù and Steven Soderbergh‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBubble.‰Ûù Despite filming in a style some might describe as clear and plain, Mr. Sutton cannot contain his patronizing attitude toward his mostly young Middle American characters. One, a seemingly appearance-obsessed woman, is introduced in a screen-filling shot of her rear end clad in psychedelic-colored tights.
The movie takes place in Florida, in the aftermath of the Aurora shooting, and follows a small group of characters who converge in another movie theater, at which another shooting occurs.

Mr. Sutton is also not above some ‰ÛÏwho‰Ûªs gonna do it?‰Ûù manipulation. One character is an alienated teenager with a crew cut. I wonder how the system has failed him. And whoa, what‰Ûªs this? An Iraq war veteran cleaning guns? Watch out for that guy! Or maybe not.

In the end, Mr. Sutton‰Ûªs main concern for his imagined victims (and perhaps for the real victims of the Aurora shooting) seems to be that they will never see their sad lives illuminated in a film by Tim Sutton.

Speaking of whom, we have the ever-expressionless Chace Crawford, who plays the lead, Jacob, like a lobotomized inmate of the former mental hospital of the title. To claim an inheritance, Jacob breaks into the long-shuttered institution, seeking the death certificate of a relative who stands between him and the cash. Accompanying him are a shifty pal (Brandon T. Jackson), a hot barmaid (Ms. Dushku) and her mentally unstable brother, Scott (P. J. Byrne), an amateur historian who‰Ûªs obsessed with this particular loony bin.

A strange mix of the recycled and the surreal, ‰ÛÏEloise‰Ûù flatlines long before its most hilariously bizarre scene: a ghostly patient-staff party with swing music, jitterbugging nurses and drive-by abominations. Now those are the seeds of a movie I could get behind.

Filmed in the real Eloise, a gargantuan, 900-acre complex in Michigan that closed in the early 1980s, the movie traffics in the usual haunted-hospital clichÌ©s: the sadistic doctor (Robert Patrick) and his grisly therapies; the linebacker orderlies; the corridors crammed with the lame and the halt. While Jacob and the barmaid unearth a shared family history ‰ÛÓ and Scott charges around like a dog in a bacon factory ‰ÛÓ the director, Robert Legato, gives us no sense of their relative locations. Instead, we follow flashing torches through pitch-black rooms and wait for this motley crew of idiots to be picked off.

Life is tough for skilled if unremarkable actresses like Eliza Dushku, who, despite early success, can be left foraging among fair-to-middling television series and forgettable movies. Even so, her career dips to a new low with ‰ÛÏEloise,‰Ûù a horror movie of such ineptitude that it invites sympathy for even its least gifted participants.

The film has accidental topicality now with the debate over immigration swirling, but you don‰Ûªt need to burden it with politics to be touched by its tale of a child who is pulled by two very different cultural worlds. Best of all, the story has some surprises as it makes its way toward the inevitable where-is-he-now moment when we see how young Smith‰Ûªs life turned out.

The film, directed by Frank Lotito, uses the device common in coming-of-age movies, narration by the adult Smith (Samrat Chakrabarti). The movie has a roughly equal number of clumsy moments and sweet ones. In the most endearing vignette, young Smith goes hunting with Butch, learning a lesson about guns and a lesson about himself as well.

The nostalgic haze that used to be associated with the 1950s seems to have drifted forward in time in recent years, with the latest example being ‰ÛÏGrowing Up Smith,‰Ûù a gentle cross-cultural film about a 10-year-old boy from India who is navigating childhood with his immigrant family in a generic American suburb in 1979.

He is Smith Bhatnagar (his parents wanted a common American moniker but didn‰Ûªt quite grasp the distinction between first and last names), and if the actor playing him, Roni Akurati, isn‰Ûªt as polished as some young stars, he‰Ûªs good enough for the material. Smith has a crush on a neighbor, Amy (Brighton Sharbino), who befriends him in a neighborhood and school that seem full of bullies intolerant of his accent and culture. Amy‰Ûªs father, Butch (Jason Lee), the movie‰Ûªs best-developed character, becomes a rock for Smith despite battling personal demons.
‰ÛÏOklahoma City‰Ûù suggests that conspiracy theories today have consequences for tomorrow ‰ÛÓ a message with terrifying implications in an age of fake news.

The documentary never loses sight of the 168 who died in the bombing. The director, Barak Goodman, includes interviews with an impressive array of witnesses and first-responders: a surgeon, the police, employees at the Murrah building‰Ûªs Social Security Administration and Housing and Urban Development offices. A mother remembers envisioning digging for her son in the rubble.

But by situating the 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in the decades-spanning context of the growth of antigovernment militias in the United States, the movie emphasizes a chilling (if not altogether new) point: that Timothy McVeigh, who was executed in 2001 for the bombing, did not emerge from a vacuum.

Yet ‰ÛÏOklahoma City‰Ûù makes the unsettling case that McVeigh‰Ûªs ideology was not isolated. He called the bombing a ‰ÛÏcounterattack,‰Ûù a response to government raids at Ruby Ridge, in Idaho in 1992, and outside Waco, Tex., in 1993. The movie covers both incidents at surprising length, with cleareyed explanations of how they fueled anger on the far right. (Ruby Ridge will have an episode of its own on Feb. 14.)

Because the documentary ‰ÛÏOklahoma City‰Ûù is an episode of ‰ÛÏAmerican Experience,‰Ûù opening theatrically before airing on PBS on Tuesday, and because it documents events that were widely broadcast on television, much of the movie plays like a tightly edited rundown of familiar material.

Baldwin is a double character in Mr. Peck‰Ûªs film. The elegance and gravity of his formal prose, and the gravelly authority of Mr. Jackson‰Ûªs voice, stand in contrast to his quicksilver on-camera presence as a lecturer and television guest. In his skinny tie and narrow suit, an omnipresent cigarette between his fingers, he imports a touch of midcentury intellectual cool into our overheated, anti-intellectual media moment.

A former child preacher, he remained a natural, if somewhat reluctant, performer ‰ÛÓ a master of the heavy sigh, the raised eyebrow and the rhetorical flourish. At one point, on ‰ÛÏThe Dick Cavett Show,‰Ûù Baldwin tangles with Paul Weiss, a Yale philosophy professor who scolds him for dwelling so much on racial issues. The initial spectacle of mediocrity condescending to genius is painful, but the subsequent triumph of self-taught brilliance over credentialed ignorance is thrilling to witness.

To call ‰ÛÏI Am Not Your Negro‰Ûù a movie about James Baldwin would be to understate Mr. Peck‰Ûªs achievement. It‰Ûªs more of a posthumous collaboration, an uncanny and thrilling communion between the filmmaker ‰ÛÓ whose previous work includes both a documentary and a narrative feature about the Congolese anti-colonialist leader Patrice Lumumba ‰ÛÓ and his subject. The voice-over narration (read by Samuel L. Jackson) is entirely drawn from Baldwin‰Ûªs work. Much of it comes from notes and letters written in the mid-1970s, when Baldwin was somewhat reluctantly sketching out a book, never to be completed, about the lives and deaths of Medgar Evers, Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr.

‰ÛÏI want to be an honest man and a good writer,‰Ûù he wrote early in his career, in the introductory note to his first collection of essays, ‰ÛÏNotes of a Native Son.‰Ûù The disarming, intimate candor of that statement characterized much of what would follow, as would a reckoning with the difficulties of living up to such apparently straightforward aspirations. Without sliding into confessional bathos, his voice was always personal and frank, creating in the reader a feeling of complicity, of shared knowledge and knowing humor.

‰ÛÏI Am Not Your Negro‰Ûù is a thrilling introduction to his work, a remedial course in American history, and an advanced seminar in racial politics ‰ÛÓ a concise, roughly 90-minute movie with the scope and impact of a 10-hour mini-series or a literary doorstop. It is not an easy or a consoling movie, but it is the opposite of bitter or despairing. ‰ÛÏI can‰Ûªt be a pessimist because I‰Ûªm alive,‰Ûù Baldwin said. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm forced to be an optimist.‰Ûù

Reflections on those men (all of whom Baldwin knew well) and their legacies are interspersed with passages from other books and essays, notably ‰ÛÏThe Devil Finds Work,‰Ûù Baldwin‰Ûªs 1976 meditation on race, Hollywood and the mythology of white innocence. His published and unpublished words ‰ÛÓ some of the most powerful and penetrating ever assembled on the tortured subject of American identity ‰ÛÓ accompany images from old talk shows and news reports, from classic movies and from our own decidedly non-post-racial present.

Baldwin could not have known about Ferguson and Black Lives Matter, about the presidency of Barack Obama and the recrudescence of white nationalism in its wake, but in a sense he explained it all in advance. He understood the deep, contradictory patterns of our history, and articulated, with a passion and clarity that few others have matched, the psychological dimensions of racial conflict: the suppression of black humanity under slavery and Jim Crow and the insistence on it in African-American politics and art; the dialectic of guilt and rage, forgiveness and denial that distorts relations between black and white citizens in the North as well as the South; the lengths that white people will go to wash themselves clean of their complicity in oppression.

In that exchange, as in a speech for an audience of British university students, you are aware of Baldwin‰Ûªs profound weariness. He must explain himself ‰ÛÓ and also his country ‰ÛÓ again and again, with what must have been sorely tested patience. When the students erupt in a standing ovation at the end of his remarks, Baldwin looks surprised, even flustered. You glimpse an aspect of his personality that was often evident in his writing: the vulnerable, bright, ambitious man thrust into a public role that was not always comfortable.

A flippant ‰ÛÓ though by no means inaccurate ‰ÛÓ answer would have been 1619. But a more constructive response might have been to recommend Raoul Peck‰Ûªs life-altering new documentary, ‰ÛÏI Am Not Your Negro.‰Ûù Let me do so now, for that reader (if he‰Ûªs still interested) and for everybody else, too. Whatever you think about the past and future of what used to be called ‰ÛÏrace relations‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ white supremacy and the resistance to it, in plainer English ‰ÛÓ this movie will make you think again, and may even change your mind. Though its principal figure, the novelist, playwright and essayist James Baldwin, is a man who has been dead for nearly 30 years, you would be hard-pressed to find a movie that speaks to the present moment with greater clarity and force, insisting on uncomfortable truths and drawing stark lessons from the shadows of history.

‰ÛÏI Am Not Your Negro‰Ûù reproduces and redoubles this effect. It doesn‰Ûªt just make you aware of Baldwin, or hold him up as a figure to be admired from a distance. You feel entirely in his presence, hanging on his every word, following the implications of his ideas as they travel from his experience to yours. At the end of the movie, you are convinced that you know him. And, more important, that he knows you. To read Baldwin is to be read by him, to feel the glow of his affection, the sting of his scorn, the weight of his disappointment, the gift of his trust.

A few weeks ago, in reaction to something we had written about blackness and whiteness in recent movies, my colleague Manohla Dargis and I received a note from a reader. ‰ÛÏSince when is everything about race?‰Ûù he wanted to know. Perhaps it was a rhetorical question.

Recounting his visits to the South, where he reported on the civil rights movement and the murderous white response to it, Baldwin modestly described himself as a witness, a watchful presence on the sidelines of tragedy and heroism, an outsider by virtue of his Northern origins, his sexuality and his alienation from the Christianity of his childhood. But he was also a prophet, able to see the truths revealed by the contingent, complicated actions of ordinary people on both sides of the conflict. This is not to say that he transcended the struggle or detached himself from it. On the contrary, he demonstrated that writing well and thinking clearly are manifestations of commitment, and that irony, skepticism and a ruthless critical spirit are necessary tools for effective moral and political action.

The existence of the child, Gardner (Asa Butterfield), is classified, and he grows up on Mars. Gardner mourns the fact that few know he exists and ruefully watches the copy of ‰ÛÏWings of Desire‰Ûù a German scientist left behind. This sullen teenager has (naturally) a robot friend and (somehow) a video-chat pal on Earth. Because the screenwriter is Allan Loeb (‰ÛÏCollateral Beauty‰Ûù), she is called Tulsa (Britt Robertson).

On a mission to colonize Mars, the lead astronaut (Janet Montgomery) learns she is pregnant. This news upsets Nathaniel Shepherd, the wild-haired mogul responsible for the venture, who fears the consequences of subjecting a fetus to zero gravity. He is played by Gary Oldman, clearly way too enthusiastic about this gig.
Committed to this preposterousness, the movie is consistently tougher to resist than it might seem.

With the disappearance of video stores, there is something heartening about the existence of ‰ÛÏThe Space Between Us,‰Ûù a cheesy hunk of science fiction from Peter Chelsom that once would have drawn curious young eyes to VHS shelves. Set in the near future, it plays like a transmission from 1986, when a boy and a spaceship‰Ûªs robot pilot could raise hell in ‰ÛÏFlight of the Navigator,‰Ûù and Steven Spielberg set the blockbuster template to emulate.

Their inevitable meeting ‰ÛÓ something about using carbon nanotubes to strengthen Gardner‰Ûªs bone density is muttered ‰ÛÓ occasions an Earth road trip. Gardner must learn about human customs, convince his girlfriend that he‰Ûªs not a weirdo and find his father before his space-addled heart gives out.

Here, though, the gently nostalgic mood and sleepy pacing effectively erase the movie‰Ûªs necessary edge. Anne‰Ûªs garden has more life than the central love affair, and Grover never emerges as more than a collection of traits designed to prove that even a Chinaman, as the biddies unwittingly call him, can be civilized. Adding too much soap ‰ÛÓ Sophie‰Ûªs slow-motion walk of shame is especially worthy of an eye roll ‰ÛÓ and too little acid, Ms. Greenwald neuters some of her characters and blurs others. The history between Sophie and Anne‰Ûªs African-American housekeeper is particularly fuzzy, though the fabulous Lorraine Toussaint plays her with more majesty and shading than her few lines would seem to permit.

Tepid and tentative, ‰ÛÏSophie and the Rising Sun,‰Ûù based on a 2001 novel by Augusta Trobaugh, is an old-fashioned ode to female solidarity. Romance drives the plot, but women control the narrative ‰ÛÓ and, by extension, their fates. As such, it fits in perfectly with the best work of its director, Maggie Greenwald, whose 2001 Appalachian drama, ‰ÛÏSongcatcher,‰Ûù also dealt with bigotry and a different kind of forbidden love. That film, and her 1993 Western, ‰ÛÏThe Ballad of Little Jo,‰Ûù were deeply feminist, unabashedly provocative stories about singular women battling the prejudices of their times; period pieces with contemporary resonance.

The veneer of decorum that cloaks the fictional fishing village of Salty Creek, S.C., does little to smother the stink of prejudice in ‰ÛÏSophie and the Rising Sun,‰Ûù a genteel love story set in the autumn of 1941 during the run-up to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

Elevated by fine performances and Wolfgang Held‰Ûªs lushly sensual cinematography, ‰ÛÏSophie‰Ûù nevertheless feels over-managed and self-satisfied. With only a little less politeness and a lot more passion, its message of inclusion and resistance might have landed with the force it deserves.

Up steps Anne (Margo Martindale), a stalwart widow and the movie‰Ûªs moral fulcrum. Soon Grover is settled in Anne‰Ûªs guest cottage and impressing his benefactress with his impeccable manners and mad skills with begonias. Equally won over is Sophie (Julianne Nicholson), the town spinster, though more by the newcomer‰Ûªs shirtless physique and way with watercolors. (She paints landscapes; he paints her.) When the canoodling starts and Ruth gets wind of their decorous romance, the onset of war becomes the least of Sophie‰Ûªs problems.

A place of sanctimony and twitching curtains, where the Garden Club and the Missionary Ladies Society occupy idle minds and hands, Salty Creek is a haven for matrons like Ruth (Diane Ladd), who can‰Ûªt help getting up in everyone‰Ûªs business. So when a near-unconscious Asian chap named Grover Ohta (Takashi Yamaguchi) spills off the bus one day, beaten and bleeding, the wagging tongues could power several car batteries.

Every now and then, as when Jackie is onstage ‰ÛÓ isolated in the harsh lighting and facing down a show-me world that has become increasingly foreign to him ‰ÛÓ you can see the movie that ‰ÛÏThe Comedian‰Ûù might have been. There‰Ûªs a kernel of an idea here about an older performer struggling to be funny in a changed reality (its technology, its women), but to pull that off would require true, deeply felt hostility, something this movie doesn‰Ûªt want or can‰Ûªt risk. Jackie isn‰Ûªt tough enough because the movie isn‰Ûªt, so his comedic personality never gels. He‰Ûªs meant to be an insult comic, but his discontent only rises to genuine anger with physical violence. His is the wrong kind of punch.

Is it too much to want someone to bring the funny in a movie about a comic? The enervating, would-be laugh-in ‰ÛÏThe Comedian‰Ûù opens this week, presumably on the strength of its headliner, Robert De Niro. He‰Ûªs ill-served by this movie, but he‰Ûªs been worse elsewhere, which isn‰Ûªt much of a comfort as this one drags into hour two. Like every exalted star, Mr. De Niro generates good will because of who he is and despite his ups and downs, the afterglow of his great performances enveloping him like a luminous cloud. So it takes a significantly bad movie to wipe the audience‰Ûªs smile off this fast.

Jail turns out to be a blip on Jackie‰Ûªs modest, wobbly career upswing, beginning at a cable station where he and his enduringly patient agent, Miller (Edie Falco), meet the enemy: the younger generation. It‰Ûªs a nowhere scene, but worth mentioning because it introduces a generational divide and a patronizing attitude toward women that winds throughout. The cable executive turns out to be a tough chick, Carol (Beth Malone), a brittle smiler with short hair who puts her feet up on the table where her eager minions sit like schoolkids. The meeting is a wash (it plays like a metaphor for Hollywood), but is soon forgotten down at the soup kitchen, where Jackie is doing community service.

There‰Ûªs a lot of story, but mostly the filmmakers rack up the miles and Jackie wears through shoe leather moving from here to there. At the soup kitchen, he finds a sympathetic (and hostage) audience in the homeless clientele and a counterweight to the cable executive in Harmony (Leslie Mann), who‰Ûªs also doing community service. Ms. Mann giggles and laughs too much, which fits Harmony‰Ûªs role as a prop. She exists to humanize Jackie, hoot at his groaners and, in one scene, gaze adoringly at him while at his feet. She beds him because she has daddy issues; their age difference suggests that the filmmakers share those issues. Mr. De Niro‰Ûªs old pal, Harvey Keitel, plays papa.

The director, Taylor Hackford, never makes any of this pop, which isn‰Ûªt a surprise given the material. He also doesn‰Ûªt give you much to look at other than street scenery and Mr. De Niro‰Ûªs mug, which the actor bunches up while cycling through soft, sour moods (aggravated, exasperated), occasionally dropping a smile that might as well be a frown. It took a near-village to write the script, which is credited to Art Linson, the stand-up Jeff Ross, Richard LaGravenese and Lewis Friedman. (The stand-up Jessica Kirson, who appears in the movie, was a consultant.) Billy Crystal shows up for a heartbeat; Jimmy Walker, Charles Grodin, Richard Belzer and Cloris Leachman hang out a touch longer.

The setup sounds promising. Mr. De Niro plays Jackie Burke, a stand-up and ex-sitcom star on a downward slide. He‰Ûªs not killing it the way he once did, and it takes only a few minutes onstage to see why: ‰ÛÏLet‰Ûªs talk about this abortion of a town you live in,‰Ûù he tells one crowd. That‰Ûªs his way of warming up the room, but the chill remains palpable. Jackie is an insult comic, but his barbs have no edge, no zing, no wit. (It‰Ûªs unclear if they ever did.) Early on he gets a break after he attacks a heckler and the assault becomes a YouTube sensation, notoriety that earns him brief jail time and new attention.

‰ÛÏThis Is Everything,‰Ûù directed by the Oscar-winning documentarian Barbara Kopple, is produced and presented by YouTube Red, the for-pay arm of that video service, and it‰Ûªs to the company‰Ûªs credit that the abuse Ms. Lazzarato suffered in her channel‰Ûªs comments section back in the day isn‰Ûªt soft-pedaled. While Ms. Kopple is best known for the strong voice and sharp eye she brings to projects about social injustice (her Academy Award-winning ‰ÛÏHarlan County USA‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAmerican Dream‰Ûù chronicled labor conflicts in the heartland), in this movie the political takes a relatively distant back seat to the personal.

Gigi Lazzarato is very much a self-generated celebrity of the 21st-century vintage. That sounds like a possibly bad thing, and one of the achievements of ‰ÛÏThis Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous‰Ûù is its very entertaining demonstration that it‰Ûªs not ‰ÛÓ at least not necessarily.

Adam Wescott and Scott Fisher, Ms. Lazzarato‰Ûªs management team, are executive producers for the film, and to a great extent ‰ÛÏThis Is Everything‰Ûù seems to follow an agenda set by them in tandem with the movie‰Ûªs subject, which is largely commendable in its pitch for acceptance and against bigotry. Still, I wish there were more behind-the-scenes material showing those managers trying to oversee the Gigi Gorgeous brand.

Ms. Lazzarato, better known as the transgender YouTube star and model Gigi Gorgeous, was designated male at birth, in 1992. In camcorder footage from the ‰Ûª90s, her father, David, invokes ‰ÛÏAmerica‰Ûªs Funniest Home Videos‰Ûù as the infant then named Gregory Allan Lazzarato does something winsomely amusing. Parental documentation, including a period when Greg was a teenage diving champion, turns to self-documentation on YouTube, with a series of videos on makeup application, each lesson capped with the directive to ‰ÛÏStay gorgeous.‰Ûù

Most of the footage in the first two-thirds is archival, with clips shot by Ms. Lazzarato as she chronicles surgical procedures during her transition from male to female. Her brothers and mother are spectacularly supportive. (‰ÛÏI think gender‰Ûªs a false construct,‰Ûù one brother, Adam, tells the camera.) Her father is more hesitant and circumspect, and there‰Ûªs conflict. Ms. Lazzarato sometimes seems to goad her father, and is reflective and a little regretful after he finally gets it.

Discussing a New York Fashion Week jaunt, one of them says it would be ‰ÛÏmore credible‰Ûù than seeing her attend a ‰ÛÏRuPaul‰Ûªs Drag Race‰Ûù season premiere, and then envisions Ms. Lazzarato in a Target ad. But the goal here is not to analyze postmodern celebrity culture. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm a real person, too,‰Ûù Ms. Lazzarato says near the end. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm literally just like you.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs the brief.

Squealing tires, firing guns, free-floating nihilism and an occasional look-at-me name check (Simone de Beauvoir) are all part of the package in ‰ÛÏWar on Everyone.‰Ûù A compendium of strained talk and post-Tarantino clichÌ©s, this is a deeply disappointing new picture by the writer and director John Michael McDonagh, whose first two movies ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏThe Guard‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏCalvary‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ popped with bright colors, splenetic jokes and actual ideas about people and the world. Mr. McDonagh‰Ûªs palette and spleen remain mostly intact, but here he‰Ûªs neglected to include a story or point.

Working with the cinematographer Bobby Bukowski, Mr. McDonagh splashes on the color (red walls, red blood), plays with negative space and at times crowds bodies into tight spaces, creating much-needed tension. His two stars are naturally appealing, but neither seems at ease with Mr. McDonagh‰Ûªs writing, with its on-and-off rhythms, cliffhanger pauses and ugly slurs. There‰Ûªs a nice scene in which Terry and Bob give chase, their dark bodies popping against the background, Mr. Skarsgard‰Ûªs long limbs pinwheeling. And the 1970 Monte Carlo that Terry drives sure is sweet. Mostly, though, the Hobbesian war of the title feels as if it‰Ûªs been waged by Mr. McDonagh alone.

Mr. McDonagh is fond of face-offs and showdowns, of two people going at it hammer and tongs, sometimes with a touch of philosophy and literal blunt instruments. Here, his dialecticians are Terry (Alexander Skarsgard) and Bob (Michael PeÌ±a), light-fingered Albuquerque detectives. They‰Ûªre a regular Mutt and Jeff duo, except that they‰Ûªre not funny or charismatic or much of anything at all. Mostly, they are just vaguely sketched conceits ‰ÛÓ jaded, corrupt, yammering ‰ÛÓ who look good in suits, smack around generic villains and make nice with the ladies.

Those peepers belong to Raymond (Frank Langella), a retired doctor who‰Ûªs unwilling to endure further treatment for a hopeless heart condition. But when he announces his intention to travel from New York to Oregon to seek legal approval to end his life comfortably, his family rebels. His overly clingy daughter (Christina Applegate) whines that it‰Ûªs a family decision. His resentfully dipso wife (Mary Kay Place) adds even more mood-enhancing substances to her primarily liquid diet. And his controlling son-in-law, Brian (Billy Crudup), resolves to use the lengthy road trip to change Raymond‰Ûªs mind.

A depressing slog that could have been so much more, ‰ÛÏYouth in Oregon‰Ûù suggests that loving someone gives us the right to override their decisions. As Raymond‰Ûªs family nags and wheedles and bickers, his desire to escape the lot of them is the most urgent and understandable emotion onscreen.

The only person involved in the making of ‰ÛÏYouth in Oregon‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a gratingly awful family drama about assisted suicide ‰ÛÓ who seems to grasp the movie‰Ûªs thematic potential is its cinematographer, Ross Riege. His warmly lighted, softly smudged images convey a world becoming slowly less distinct, as if being viewed through increasingly distanced eyes.

Transforming a profoundly personal and painful decision into a springboard for slapsticklike setups and predictable dysfunction, the director, Joel David Moore (working from Andrew Eisen‰Ûªs screenplay), squanders the opportunity to explore our need to die with dignity. Dragging two estranged sons into the argument ‰ÛÓ both of whom committed the unforgivable crime of making their own choices ‰ÛÓ Brian seems more intent on elder abuse than active listening.

In case you‰Ûªve forgotten, the foundation of the franchise is a short videotape full of unsettling images that unsuspecting people keep stumbling upon; anyone who watches it dies seven days later. The original Japanese film, by Hideo Nakata, was an influential hit, and the 2002 American version was pretty successful, too, boosting the career of its star, Naomi Watts. (‰ÛÏThe Ring Two,‰Ûù in 2005, didn‰Ûªt do as well.)

‰ÛÏRings,‰Ûù the latest sequel in the franchise that began with the Japanese film ‰ÛÏRingu,‰Ûù is short on outright frights, but some effort certainly went into the storytelling. For one thing, by the time this one‰Ûªs over, fans will know a lot more about the mysterious Samara, the dead girl who continues to terrify the living via a grainy videotape. And those nearing or in college ‰ÛÓ the demographic being aimed at here ‰ÛÓ will learn an important lesson: Beware of any professor who tries to recruit you for a research study.
Ms. Lutz is appealing, though, and fans of the franchise will probably be pleased with the elaboration. Too many horror sequels are content merely to recycle what worked the first time.

There is no Ms. Watts in ‰ÛÏRings,‰Ûù directed efficiently by F. Javier GutiÌ©rrez, but there is a heroine in jeopardy, Julia, played by Matilda Lutz. Julia‰Ûªs boyfriend, Holt (Alex Roe), has gone off to college and been sucked into a research project by Gabriel (Johnny Galecki, of ‰ÛÏThe Big Bang Theory‰Ûù), a professor who accidentally acquired the lethal videotape at a flea market. Gabriel has realized that the curse can be beaten if, during the seven-day period, the afflicted person gets someone else to watch the tape, and so his research is predicated on a sort of lethal pyramid scheme.

Julia is determined to rescue Holt at any cost; Vincent D‰ÛªOnofrio makes an embarrassing appearance as a blind cemetery caretaker; and Samara (Bonnie Morgan) is given a full back story. The death-by-VCR conceit has been pretty thoroughly exhausted at this point, imitation being the sincerest form of flattery ‰ÛÓ see, for instance, ‰ÛÏBeyond the Gates,‰Ûù which came out in December. So this film doesn‰Ûªt find any fresh ways to make you jump out of your seat.

Mr. Arnett anchors the movie, though he‰Ûªs nicely book-ended by Michael Cera, as the excitable pip-squeaker Dick Grayson, and Ralph Fiennes, who voices Alfred, Bruce Wayne‰Ûªs trusted butler and operational aide-de-camp. Some of the wittiest moments happen early, before the story machinery starts humming, and involve Batman-Bruce wandering his mansion in his fetishlike mask and a silky red bathrobe, nuking his lobster dinner and giggling solo at ‰ÛÏJerry Maguire.‰Ûù If Christopher Nolan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDark Knight‰Ûù cycle suggests that Batman teeters on actual madness, ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie‰Ûù ups the ante by insinuating that he has fully settled into near-Howard Hughes eccentricity.

So, as far as commercials go, ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie‰Ûù is just swell. But because its primary function, outside of making bank, is to extend two brands ‰ÛÓ Lego and Batman ‰ÛÓ it can‰Ûªt help but disappoint. One reason that the first ‰ÛÏLego‰Ûù movie worked as well as it did is that its novelty and trippier moments conveyed a sense of play and unboundedness, which is part of the appeal of Legos themselves. (It‰Ûªs the better movie and ad.) The Batman story, by contrast, proves to be a prison, one its creators never escape. They toss around the superstuff and giggle at the legend, but they‰Ûªre finally confined by the superhero story and its corporate sanctity. It‰Ûªs a bottom-line bummer.

As gateway drugs go, ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie‰Ûù is pretty irresistible. It‰Ûªs silly without being truly strange or crossing over into absurdity. Along the way it pulls off a nifty balancing act: It gives the PG audience its own Batman movie (it‰Ûªs a superhero starter kit) and takes swipes at the subgenre, mostly by gently mocking the seriousness that has become a deadening Warner Bros. default. ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie‰Ûù can‰Ûªt atone for a movie as grindingly bad as the studio‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBatman v Superman: Dawn of Justice,‰Ûù which stars Ben Affleck as the Gotham City brooder, but at least someone on that lot gets the joke.

Not too much nuttiness, mind you, just enough to keep the jokes pinging and zinging, at least until the story amps up. Most of that involves the Joker (Zach Galifianakis), who‰Ûªs not the transgressive opposition but a whining smiler desperately yearning for Batman‰Ûªs attention. This isn‰Ûªt as funny or engaging as the filmmakers seem to think, partly because a child-friendly Joker can‰Ûªt have the scariness or anarchic threat that distinguishes this character‰Ûªs better iterations. (He can‰Ûªt compete partly because he‰Ûªs nowhere near as loopy as this Batman.) Mostly, the Joker is the master of ceremonies for the rest of the villainous horde, a motley crew of creatures that includes Harley Quinn (Jenny Slate), who‰Ûªs mostly a trauma trigger for ‰ÛÏSuicide Squad,‰Ûù another supersplat.

Basing movies on kiddie playthings is ingenious: It turns every Lego brick into a Rosebud sled, a portal into childhood. That makes resistance fairly futile, or at least tough, especially when the crew ushering you into the past is up to the task, as is the case here. Chris McKay directed this one, working from a jammed script by Seth Grahame-Smith, Chris McKenna, Erik Sommers, Jared Stern and John Whittington. (Phil Lord and Christopher Miller, who directed ‰ÛÏThe Lego Movie,‰Ûù helped produce ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie.‰Ûù) The whole vibe is, as the first ‰ÛÏLego‰Ûù movie insisted with its deliriously catchy anthem, awesome, so, relax, enjoy the show, go with the flow. I mean, who hates Legos? Isn‰Ûªt that like hating childhood?

The cast and crew of ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie‰Ûù sustain that joke admirably, filling in its 104-minute running time with loads of busy action, deadpan humor, visual comedy, reflexive bits and an overfamiliar story line. It features the usual cavalcade of marquee-ready talent (Rosario Dawson, Conan O‰ÛªBrien, Mariah Carey), the comic and less so, but owes much of its pleasure and juice to Will Arnett, who voices Batman. The movie puts a goofy spin on the Batman saga, but it squeezes its brightest, most sustained comedy from Mr. Arnett‰Ûªs hypnotically sepulchral voice, which conveys the entire bat ethos ‰ÛÓ the Sturm und Drang, the darkness and aloneness, the resoluteness and echoiness ‰ÛÓ in vocal terms. It‰Ûªs blissfully self-serious, near-Wagnerian and demented.

As an object, ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie‰Ûù looks as good as its predecessor, ‰ÛÏThe Lego Movie.‰Ûù This one is similarly shiny and bright, though sometimes as teasingly dark as Batman. Even when the story drags, which it does as the action grows frenetic, the shiny and bright bits catch the eye. As in the first movie, the character design does much of the most meaningful work because it conveys part of what‰Ûªs enjoyable about Legos, including their smooth-to-the-touch plastic surfaces and knobby bits (studs in Lego lingo), which you can almost feel in your hands as you watch. One of the satisfactions of Legos is their touch sensation, a sense memory that‰Ûªs imprinted on brains, too.

Well, of course not, though that gets to what‰Ûªs frustrating about these movies, which are so insistently good-natured and relentlessly hyped that it feels almost churlishly old-school raising even modest objections to the fact that ‰ÛÓ in addition to being, you know, fun ‰ÛÓ they‰Ûªre also commercials. It‰Ûªs not new or news that movies have long sold stuff, including studio tie-ins and toys, as Walt Disney explained by example decades ago, though, like Pixar, he was also in the business of storytelling and not merely corporate-brand storytelling and building. Certainly there are worse things in life and definitely worse movies, including the ‰ÛÏTransformers‰Ûù blockbusters, which sell both toys and war.

Their paths occasionally cross with Elizabeth (Anna Camp) and Drew (Justin Chatwin), a couple in their 30s who are wondering if their relationship has hit an endpoint. Of the two pairs, this one is the least well developed, and sometimes the back and forth between Elizabeth and Drew seems to be out of some generic-argument handbook.

The movie, which Ms. Baig also wrote, looks in on two couples at a hotel on the same night. The younger pair, high school students at their prom, aren‰Ûªt a couple at all when the story begins, though they have known each other for years. Bea (Isabelle Fuhrman) has been dumped by her date. Andy (Kyle Allen) is indifferently taking pictures for the yearbook. Their mutual prom-night misery brings them together.
Ms. Baig, though, does have some place she‰Ûªs trying to get to, and in short order she arrives there. The journey could be a bit more eventful, but the payoff is charming.

Minhal Baig‰Ûªs first feature, ‰ÛÏ1 Night,‰Ûù seems to be merely a sweet but slight romantic study for most of the way, yet a little flourish at the end makes it a much smarter film than it appeared. It also makes you curious to see what this young director will do next.

In the midst of an epic phoning session, Brady and Sam receive a call of their own, and the man on the other end of the line has the kind of calm but sinister voice that cuts through their cockiness. What really gets their attention, though, is that he seems to know everything about them, including what they had been doing only moments earlier. Soon he‰Ûªs feeding them video that shows he is also menacing their loved ones, including Sam‰Ûªs girlfriend, Peyton (Bella Dayne), the only character here you might remotely care about.

Brady (Garrett Clayton) and Sam (Gregg Sulkin), his best friend, are among a group of youths who amuse themselves by making prank calls, which they record and post online, with viral results. How best to discourage young people from this kind of thoughtless cruelty? Turn the tables on them, of course.
Do teenagers really still make prank phone calls? And even if they do, here in the age of caller ID does anyone still answer a phone displaying an unknown number?
