The writer, Joe Johnson, and directors, Damien MacÌ© and Alexis Wajsbrot, have a few surprises, but not enough to make this anything other than a formulaic story of teenagers behaving badly and getting what‰Ûªs coming to them.
Such questions are invited by ‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt Hang Up,‰Ûù an unnecessary horror film out of the ‰ÛÏI Know What You Did Last Summer‰Ûù playbook.

Mr. Homme, in this telling (which HBO will broadcast on Monday), steered Mr. Hughes to a rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll career to give his friend focus after some personal setbacks, and he speaks with admiration about how Mr. Hughes found a new purpose when he stepped onstage. But Mr. Homme, who is also a member of Queens of the Stone Age, often doesn‰Ûªt tour with Eagles of Death Metal, and he was not part of the lineup that played the Bataclan on the fateful day.

Colin Hanks has a lot of experience as an actor but little as a documentary filmmaker. He set himself a formidable challenge with ‰ÛÏEagles of Death Metal: Nos Amis (Our Friends),‰Ûù his documentary about the American rock band that was performing at the Bataclan concert hall in Paris on Nov. 13, 2015, when terrorists killed 90 people there.

The film has a lot of emotion to capture as it chronicles the band‰Ûªs return to Paris three months after the attack to, in a sense, complete the concert that the terrorists interrupted. It‰Ûªs a pileup of sorrow, survivor guilt, anger and defiance that sometimes grows unruly. Mr. Hanks tries to give the journey a through-line by focusing on the friendship between the band‰Ûªs founders, Jesse Hughes and Josh Homme, a device that works early but then is overwhelmed by the events of Nov. 13.

The vivid recollections of the attack by survivors, including Mr. Hughes, take over the film midway through, and the friendship story line never quite re-establishes itself. The return concert, too, ends up feeling less cathartic than it might have; it‰Ûªs more coda than main focus.

Attempting to simplify a dauntingly complex tangle of rights and responsibilities, the director, Mary Mazzio, has shaped her material into a classic heroes-and-villains showdown. Leading the white hats is the inexhaustible Erik Bauer, a strip-mall Atticus Finch wrapped in denim and moral determination; on the other side there‰Ûªs Homer King, described by the film as a former pimp, who shares the grooming tactics he used to control the children he calls ‰ÛÏjust a product.‰Ûù His few minutes of screen time will freeze the breath in your throat.

They might also numb the critical thinking that allows you to notice the movie‰Ûªs lack of clear definitions for terms like sex trafficking and child sex (which mean different things in different states). How it fails to consider the criminalization of sex work as a possible barrier to rooting out those who exploit minors. Or how the plaintiffs‰Ûª demand for age verification of the women in online ads could be almost impossible to put in effect.

Instead, Ms. Mazzio, a onetime lawyer, ushers us through court rulings and Senate hearings marked by heartening successes and crushing setbacks. The movie‰Ûªs most persuasive section shows evidence of possible collusion between the site and some of its advertisers; yet despite an abundance of legal expertise, no one is on hand to substantively address First Amendment rights, or to examine claims that the website is a useful ally in locating and prosecuting traffickers.
Some documentaries inspire so much sympathy for their subjects ‰ÛÓ and outrage on their behalf ‰ÛÓ that it‰Ûªs all too easy to miss the fact that what we‰Ûªre watching is more advocacy than argument.

‰ÛÏI Am Jane Doe,‰Ûù a chronicle of the  continuing fight to hold an online classifieds site liable for the extreme harm resulting from some of its escort ads, falls into that category. Spearheaded by a handful of anguished mothers whose daughters were sold into sex slavery, by way of the website Backpage.com, before they were 16, the serpentine legal proceedings have so far consumed six years and countless courtroom hours. Their greatest obstacle is a 1996 law declaring that websites can‰Ûªt be held responsible for third-party content.

Without these balancing voices, ‰ÛÏI Am Jane Doe‰Ûù coalesces into a steamroller of pain that squashes our ability to see beyond its wounded families. It‰Ûªs the tale of a crusade whose horrifying details resist Jessica Chastain‰Ûªs silky narration. Yet there‰Ûªs a reason that so far the website keeps winning, and it‰Ûªs worth at least considering that it might not be a negligible one.

John might remind you of James Bond, but he has no interest in the honeys. Carnage is his release, and the camera plays along, gazing up at his aspirational buttocks as he slides a knife from his back pocket, and circling his twisting torso with rapt attention. A brilliantly stylized foreplay sequence is constructed around assassin-related paraphernalia, and both Ian McShane and Laurence Fishburne ‰ÛÓ as the respective heads of separate killing squads ‰ÛÓ remind us of madams, pimping death across continents.

They just couldn‰Ûªt leave it alone. The original ‰ÛÏJohn Wick,‰Ûù about an Ì_ber assassin who‰Ûªs reluctantly drawn out of retirement, was a near perfect synergy of simple premise and intricate movement ‰ÛÓ an action movie that danced. But the lightness and winking quality that softened the slaughter are less evident in ‰ÛÏJohn Wick: Chapter 2,‰Ûù an altogether more solemn affair weighed down by the philosophy that more is always more.

Some of this world-building is fun, and almost all of it is dazzling, but the emotional sterility of John‰Ûªs life will burden a franchise. At some point, he‰Ûªll have to care about more than his dog.

That means almost doubling the body count as John (Keanu Reeves, still superstoic and hyper-pliable) is once again yanked out of seclusion, this time to fulfill a debt to an Italian mobster by killing the mobster‰Ûªs sister (Claudia Gerini). The plot matters only inasmuch as it allows the returning director, Chad Stahelski, to stage his spectacular fight sequences in various stunning Roman locations, where they unfold with an almost erotic brutality. In this movie, the camera contemplates weaponry with more lip-licking awe than is ever afforded Ms. Gerini‰Ûªs curves.

One restaurant cat earns its love old-school style, by snaring vermin. Another is so meek (or haughty, depending on how you look at it) that it never enters the high-end delicatessen it‰Ûªs made its home, but signals frantically at the window when it‰Ûªs hungry. The movie is replete with ingeniously constructed mini-narratives, including a turf war. The mesmerizing score by Kira Fontana, interspersed with well-chosen Turkish pop, is a real asset.

The movie hits a somber note near the end, noting that Istanbul‰Ûªs modernization is crowding out both individuated neighborhoods and cats. The animals, one human says, can ‰ÛÏrekindle our own slowly dying love of life.‰Ûù That‰Ûªs one way of putting it, I guess. In any event, I give ‰ÛÏKedi‰Ûù four claws up.

‰ÛÏKedi‰Ûù (‰ÛÏFeline‰Ûù), a frequently enchanting documentary directed by Ceyda Torun, showcases some of these feline personalities and the humans who look after them. There‰Ûªs a good deal of projection in the verbal accounts of the animals‰Ûª lives, but the movie, with its mobile camera low to the ground or looking down at cat-navigated rooftops, doesn‰Ûªt do much to contradict the indirect anthropomorphizing. There‰Ûªs a lot of action at piers and fish markets.

If I correctly recall whatever cat domestication lore I‰Ûªve absorbed over the years, the creatures we now sometimes refer to as ‰ÛÏhouse cats‰Ûù were tolerated because they were quite useful. Cats, for instance, would keep rodents away from granaries. They were cared for by humans, but not coddled, maintaining a certain measure of independence. The street cats of Istanbul, who would probably be considered an animal-control problem in the United States, are, in a sense, throwbacks to those ancients.

Still, ‰ÛÏLand of Mine‰Ûù is an interesting addition to the growing roster of recent European films ‰ÛÓ Paul Verhoeven‰Ûªs queasy ‰ÛÏBlack Book‰Ûù may be the best-known example among American audiences ‰ÛÓ that search out the grayer areas of World War II and its aftermath. Mr. Zandvliet is less interested in the stark battle between good and evil than in the shifting ground of power and responsibility, and the way that every person carries the potential for decency and depravity.

In 1945, Germany ended its occupation of Denmark, leaving hundreds of thousands of land mines buried on the beaches of that country‰Ûªs western coast. The dangerous job of clearing them was given to German prisoners of war, a punishment that seems at once intuitively fair and obviously cruel. That ethical tension ‰ÛÓ between justice and vengeance ‰ÛÓ is the subject of Martin Zandvliet‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLand of Mine,‰Ûù a tight and suspenseful film that is one of the five nominees for the foreign language film Oscar.

But the war hasn‰Ûªt extinguished his humanity, and ‰ÛÏLand of Mine‰Ûù is partly the story of his awakening compassion. He requisitions food for the prisoners, leads them in a friendly soccer game on a stretch of beach that has been cleared of explosives and tries to protect them from the abuse of his superior officer, Capt. Ebbe Jensen (Mikkel Boe Folsgaard) and other Allied soldiers.

It might be easier for a viewer to forgive the victors for holding a grudge than to forgive their intended victims, however innocent and vulnerable those young men may seem. Mr. Zandvliet stacks the deck in making Captain Jensen as cold and sadistic as any central-casting Nazi, and in portraying the Germans as terrified, ordinary kids. Their complicity with wartime horror lies beyond the film‰Ûªs scope, which makes its exploration of postwar moral ambiguity feel incomplete.

Mr. Zandvliet doesn‰Ûªt flash back to the sergeant‰Ûªs wartime experiences. He doesn‰Ûªt need to, since Mr. Moller‰Ûªs haunted eyes and weary countenance make it clear that his character has witnessed and suffered terrible things. In the first scene, driving his jeep past a column of retreating Germans, he pulls over to attack one who is taking home a Danish flag as a souvenir. Rasmussen‰Ûªs hatred for his defeated enemy is boundless. ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt care if you die,‰Ûù he tells his young charges, who work long, hazardous shifts on the edge of starvation.

He tackles these themes in a way that is both effective and conventional. The ever-present danger of an explosion ‰ÛÓ and the certainty that someone is going to be blown up at some point ‰ÛÓ creates an undercurrent of dread that the director does not hesitate to manipulate. He takes a messy, murky reality and wraps it up into a compact narrative that is just a little too neat.

Filled with picturesque, windswept shots of sand and surf, ‰ÛÏLand of Mine‰Ûù focuses on the fate of about a dozen young captives, some of whom look more like boys than fighting men. They are billeted in a shack near a coastal farm, under the command of Sgt. Carl Rasmussen (Roland Moller), a Clark Gable-handsome martinet with a square jaw, a neat blond mustache and very little patience.

A bonfire of documentary ethics, ‰ÛÏLeft on Purpose‰Ûù combines two nonfiction subgenres. The first is the embed-with-a-hoarder movie (‰ÛÏGrey Gardens,‰Ûù the recent ‰ÛÏAlmost There‰Ûù), in which the camera follows a disheveled subject who has partly withdrawn from society and lives in a clutter-filled home.

In the second, the documentary itself functions as a sort of final testament (‰ÛÏFarewell to Hollywood‰Ûù). Here, a man tells his friends, including this film‰Ûªs director, Justin Schein, that he plans to commit suicide.

Arguments over whether the documentary‰Ûªs existence honors Mr. Vishner‰Ûªs wishes and spirit ‰ÛÓ and whether continuing to film was appropriate ‰ÛÓ lead in circles. (In fairness, he is shown getting medical care, and Mr. Schein becomes a helpful presence in his life.) But tickets can‰Ûªt come with enough steel wool.

But alcoholism complicates this stance. The movie opens with Mr. Schein delivering beer to Mr. Vishner and noting how troublesome it is for him to become an enabler. As a doctor later notes, the continued film project is at once a lifeline for Mr. Vishner and a source of pressure for him to act. (‰ÛÏNot being able to see the movie is one of my few regrets,‰Ûù Mr. Vishner tells Mr. Schein in what appears to be their last meeting. Mr. Vishner killed himself in 2013 at 64. Some friends and the filmmaker are shown finding the body.)

The man is Mayer Vishner, at various times an activist with the Youth International Party (better known as the Yippies), a managing editor of LA Weekly and a tender of LaGuardia Corner Gardens in Greenwich Village. He sees ending his life as an extension of his longtime advocacy for individual agency. (‰ÛÏAs my friend, you have to participate in this political act,‰Ûù he tells a member of his circle.)

This is also a very polite film. When, in a moment of frustration, Seretse swipes his arm across his desktop, knocking papers off it, Ms. Asante cuts before a single sheet, or any other object, hits the floor. For all that, the movie depicts the appalling political gamesmanship that conspires to keep Seretse and Ruth apart (including, in a shocking twist, a betrayal by a historical figure who‰Ûªs almost exclusively lauded in pop-culture portrayals) with consistent clarity. And while her filmmaking style can sometimes come across as staid, her sense of pace is always acute.

Addressing a world that is still (even after the precedent set by the presidency of Barack Obama) increasingly afflicted by institutionalized racism and all manner of bigotries, ‰ÛÏA United Kingdom‰Ûù looks back to mid-20th-century history to create a love-conquers-much-if-not-all tale of interracial marriage and international politics.

Here, as with her 2014 feature, ‰ÛÏBelle,‰Ûù Ms. Asante addresses contemporary concerns via period romance, and her commitment to the romance is not a feint. At one point the movie shows political unrest churning into violence, and juxtaposes that with a scene of the pregnant Ruth going into labor. Were you to bet that the movie would follow the childbirth thread, you would win.

The best reason to see ‰ÛÏA United Kingdom,‰Ûù however, is the performance by Mr. Oyelowo, who is also one of the film‰Ûªs producers. As written by Mr. Hibbert, Seretse Khama is a character of stock wisdom and nobility ‰ÛÓ on introduction, practically his first words are ‰ÛÏI see an Africa that‰Ûªs about unity, inclusion and equality.‰Ûù But Mr. Oyelowo, who is one of the best actors working today onstage or onscreen, imbues his portrayal of Seretse (who in 1966 became the democratically elected president of the independent Botswana) with a disarming delicacy and vulnerability that make the strengths he is later forced to show all the more convincing. It is remarkable, genuinely riveting work.

For all the tumult surrounding them, the couple remain the focus of the film. The director, Amma Asante (working from a script by Guy Hibbert, who adapted Susan Williams‰Ûªs 2006 nonfiction book ‰ÛÏColour Bar‰Ûù), emphasizes this in her staging of the unequivocal and unaffected affection and regard they exchange.

The other actors are also very fine for the most part: Ms. Pike‰Ûªs Ruth conveys a commanding intelligence, and Vusi Kunene and Terry Pheto are two different kinds of proud in portraying Seretse‰Ûªs disapproving kin. (Tom Felton, as an underhanded British bureaucrat, seems to be hard pressed to avoid twirling his waxed mustache, on the other hand.) But it‰Ûªs Mr. Oyelowo who truly makes ‰ÛÏA United Kingdom‰Ûù a deeper, more rewarding film.

The story is of Seretse Khama, heir to the kingship of an African people, who was attending school in Britain during the late 1940s. At a church dance, Seretse, played by David Oyelowo, meets Ruth Williams (Rosamund Pike). The two eye each other warily as the band bleats. He asks her if she likes jazz; she insists she does, only not as she‰Ûªs ever heard any British musicians play it. Soon they are swapping 78s by mail, and dating. One night he kneels to propose.

There are, of course, complications. A good number of them are predictable, but they go deeper than a viewer unfamiliar with their story might have expected. Seretse‰Ûªs homeland, Bechuanaland (now Botswana), an African protectorate under British control, sits directly above South Africa, which in the late 1940s was instituting the murderous policy of apartheid. The British, therefore, were deeply invested in not alienating South Africa‰Ûªs rulers. And Seretse‰Ûªs uncle is not keen on the returning king bringing home a white queen.

Given how Ms. James and Ms. Taylor-Johnson are said to have clashed over the making of the first movie, it is easy to guess who the dominant player was in ‰ÛÏFifty Shades Darker,‰Ûù and it probably wasn‰Ûªt the new director, James Foley. He‰Ûªs a professional with real credits, so I assume that he‰Ûªs not finally responsible for the ineptitude of ‰ÛÏFifty Shades Darker,‰Ûù which ranges from continuity issues to unsurprisingly risible writing. There are also abrupt swings in tone, dead-end detours and flatline performances, including from Ms. Johnson. The sex is strained and certainly seems to burn serious calories (Christian flips Anastasia like a pancake), but finally pales next to the commodity fetishism. The use of Ben and Jerry‰Ûªs vanilla ice cream, however, made for great product placement.

The big tee-hee about the ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù phenomenon is that it‰Ûªs brought ostensibly scandalous heterosexual sex ‰ÛÓ with its whips and restraints ‰ÛÓ out of the shadows and into the mainstream. The likes of Madonna and the photographer Helmut Newton had primed that pump long ago, turning dominance, submission and toys into an acceptable spectacle. But it apparently took a writer as terrible as E L James, the author of the ‰ÛÏFifty Shades‰Ûù series, to really hit the commercial sweet spot. The result is a clutch of best sellers, a hit movie (based on the first book, ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù) and now a sequel, ‰ÛÏFifty Shades Darker,‰Ûù that‰Ûªs almost bad enough to recommend.

Well, not quite, though it‰Ûªs always instructive to watch how many different ways one movie can go wrong and to guess what happened between a first feature and a second. For all its flaws, ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù had a competent director, Sam Taylor-Johnson, who mostly wrung a watchable movie out of the material, partly by letting lightness and laughter in. It also had a natural star in Dakota Johnson, one of those unforced charmers who can deliver bad lines so gracefully that, after a while, you don‰Ûªt much care about their quality. With low-key charisma, she drew you toward her, so that your attention and hopes fell on her instead of the nonsense surrounding her. She was a stealth weapon.

There‰Ûªs not much else to say except that the all-media screening of ‰ÛÏFifty Shades Darker‰Ûù I attended had scarcely begun before it turned into a live edition of the TV show ‰ÛÏMystery Science Theater 3000.‰Ûù At least some of the few hundred moviegoers seem to have arrived with modest expectations; others had seen ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey,‰Ûù so presumably knew better. Soon, though, the individual scattered titters and excited murmurings began to shift and to harmonize as skeptics and true believers alike became as one, joined by the display of so much awfulness. Afterward, we lit cigarettes and murmured about what fun we had even though we also agreed that we could never go there again.

I was still rooting for Ms. Johnson in ‰ÛÏFifty Shades Darker,‰Ûù even if it proved tough going. Once again, the story involves the on-and-off, tie-her-up, tie-her-down romance between Anastasia Steele (Ms. Johnson) and her billionaire boyfriend, Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan), a guy with sculptured muscles, expensive playthings and dreary issues. Stuff and kink happens: A gun is fired, a would-be rapist is punished and Anastasia is bound hand and foot. Mostly, she advances and retreats (repeat), mewls and moans, and registers surprise each time Christian tries to dominate her outside the bedroom, evincing the kind of stalkerlike behavior that usually leads to restraining orders.

‰ÛÏSex Doll‰Ûù is a salacious title, but this superficially mysterious character study from Sylvie Verheyde is constructed more like a Russian doll: The script peels away layers of possibility until it becomes clear that there is almost nothing underneath. The movie doesn‰Ûªt credit any source material, but it plays like a poorly dramatized magazine exposÌ©.
That‰Ûªs better than the last line, however, which comes after ‰ÛÏSex Doll‰Ûù has given up its secrets, which aren‰Ûªt especially shocking to begin with.

Early in the film, Virginie meets Ruppert (the gangly Ash Stymest, speaking quite a bit of French), after he trails her and a friend (Lindsay Karamoh) into a nightclub. While the skull-and-crossbones tattoo on Ruppert‰Ûªs hand isn‰Ûªt a red flag for Virginie, his persistence in following her ought to be. There is also his reaction when she asks him to share a childhood memory: ‰ÛÏI haven‰Ûªt got any memories,‰Ûù he says, the sort of line a screenwriter might try (Ms. Verheyde wrote, in addition to directing) that would probably prompt questions in real life.

Preserving a sense of intrigue, at least for a while, is Hafsia Herzi, whom devoted art house moviegoers will recognize as a bright spot from films by Abdellatif Kechiche, Alain Guiraudie and Bertrand Bonello. She plays Virginie, a high-end prostitute living and working in London for a madam (Karole Rocher, whose look and manner suggest a Gallic Julianne Moore) who treats her like a prized possession.

As a result, most emerge with little more than a single defining trait ‰ÛÓ the modest one; the headstrong one; the outsider ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs nevertheless enough to keep us engaged. The movie‰Ûªs rough-and-tumble look works in its favor, and the occasional doldrums allow for reflection on the obstacles, military and otherwise, the women face daily. The absence of overt political statements, however, makes it all the more shocking when one woman is fired on by a border guard. Maybe trying to train near an Israeli detention center wasn‰Ûªt such a good idea.

Situated in the West Bank ‰ÛÓ and with the Israeli occupation a constantly nagging background presence ‰ÛÓ the story bounces among five young women as they navigate a sport whose judges might not be entirely neutral and whose rules can seem arbitrarily enforced. Racetracks are improvised in parking lots and empty market squares, and training spaces are elusive. The rush of racing, though, offers release and distraction from other frustrations in the women‰Ûªs lives ‰ÛÓ though with five subjects to cover in only 80 minutes, Ms. Fares is by necessity less than probing.

Subtly rebellious and defiantly optimistic, ‰ÛÏSpeed Sisters‰Ûù masks the sound of gunshots with the roar of revving engines. For these women, driving symbolizes a freedom they can otherwise only imagine.

Unconventional in form as well as content, ‰ÛÏSpeed Sisters‰Ûù is a sports-underdog documentary that pays only lip service to the genre‰Ûªs typical strive-setback-win narrative arc. Loose and unforced, this debut feature from Amber Fares explores the rewards and challenges of belonging to the first female streetcar racing team in the Middle East.

In the plot, Ash (Asa Spurlock) and Connor (Mr. Fessenden) are held captive after stumbling upon three crooks hiding out in a somewhat secluded trailer. One of those bad guys, Charlie (Larry Fessenden, the director‰Ûªs father, who is also the cinematographer), has been shot, and a maniacal hit man is determined to fill him and his accomplices (James Le Gros and John Speredakos) with more lead.

‰ÛÏStray Bullets‰Ûù feels as if it were made by a capable high schooler, and that‰Ûªs not a slight. Indeed, the director, Jack Fessenden, had to juggle ‰ÛÏtrigonometry homework or my ‰Û÷Canterbury Tales‰Ûª reading‰Ûù with his moviemaking responsibilities, he says in his production notes. He was all of 16 when he finished this crime tale.

Those qualities aside, there‰Ûªs no getting around an ending that unspools in cheesy slow-motion, or several illogical scenes that meander. It‰Ûªs unsurprising to learn that ‰ÛÏStray Bullets‰Ûù was first planned as a 30-minute film; conversations seem drawn out, names are constantly repeated, and plot threads lead nowhere, as if to fill time.

The project‰Ûªs back story is often more interesting than what plays out onscreen. The young Mr. Fessenden is credited as writer, director, actor, editor and composer; he put the movie together with the help of friends, props found on Craigslist and his father‰Ûªs small production company. His script features a hint of tension and some dry humor.

Still, Mr. Fessenden‰Ûªs ambition is admirable, and there‰Ûªs more than a little raw skill on display. If this, his first feature, isn‰Ûªt always worth recommending, his talents are certainly worth encouraging.

The film moves at a slow pace, but it‰Ûªs not quite as languorous as other contemporary Asian pictures. Ms. Towira‰Ûªs shooting style is efficient and relatively unadorned in the first half. As the movie progresses, she adds something small to its minimalist vocabulary. When she resorts to a simple dissolve during the boat trip, for instance, the effect seems to turn the whole movie into something more enigmatic. For all the built-up dread in ‰ÛÏThe Island Funeral,‰Ûù the movie ends on a note that‰Ûªs both lyrical and terribly mournful.

The three are not particularly voluble ‰ÛÓ they present quite a contrast to the motor-mouthed, pop-culture heads that American films invariably serve up when focusing on this age group. In between their bickering, they anxiously discuss news of oppression, unrest and terrorism in the far-from-Bangkok province they‰Ûªre traveling to. (Their aim is to visit Laila and Zugood‰Ûªs aunt.) Tensions over religious differences in the country get an airing.

On a night drive, which plays like a scene from a David Lynch film with the volume dialed way down, Laila believes she sees a woman fleeing some horror. Eventually they find themselves being taken by boat to a remote place where freedom still reigns ‰ÛÓ a place that, it is made plain, is dying.

The Thai director Pimpaka Towira‰Ûªs second feature, ‰ÛÏThe Island Funeral,‰Ûù is a road movie that‰Ûªs as mesmerizing as it is tense. The film begins with three young adults ‰ÛÓ Laila (Heen Sasithorn); her brother, Zugood (Aukrit Pornsumpunsuk); and his unnamed pal (Yossawat Sittiwong) ‰ÛÓ standing by their idling car, wondering how to get to where they‰Ûªre going. Laila is disdainful of her brother‰Ûªs map-reading abilities, while the pal is frustrated that he can‰Ûªt access GPS from his phone.

There‰Ûªs a bit of Guillermo del Toro‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCrimson Peak‰Ûù in the exuberant gothic creepiness, especially as the plot moves from corporate thriller to psychological melodrama to full-on creep show, complete with incest, medical experiments and ghoulish aristocratic shenanigans. And while these recent movies are the most obvious and distracting influences, an intrepid viewer will pick up hints of Hitchcock and Kubrick (and also, but only at the very end, of Spielberg), of ‰ÛÏSuspiria‰Ûù and Mario Bava.

Still, the company isn‰Ûªt bad. Mr. DeHaan brings an air of curdled innocence that inspires an interesting ambivalence. You sort of root for his character, a Wall Street hotshot named Lockhart, but you also kind of hope he suffers, since he‰Ûªs a selfish, ill-mannered jerk. Dispatched by his bosses to retrieve an executive who has vanished in Switzerland, Lockhart, who is haunted by memories of his father‰Ûªs suicide, finds himself in the company and eventually the care of Dr. Volmer (Jason Isaacs), a suave Continental with unnervingly impeccable manners. Mr. Isaacs is the kind of silken, charismatic villain that you can‰Ûªt wait to see again.

Not wondering in the ‰ÛÏWhat does it mean?‰Ûù sense, mind you. Anyone who has even a slight acquaintance with Freudian theory or Japanese erotica will grasp the psychosexual significance of those eels, who live in the aquifer underneath an Alpine spa and occasionally make their way into the plumbing and beyond. My questions are of a more basic nature: How did they get down there in the first place? Are they an invasive species or part of the native ecosystem? What evolutionary process might account for their curiously symbiotic relationship with the spa‰Ûªs human residents?

You will notice a lot of Martin Scorsese‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏShutter Island‰Ûù here, as a dogged young man (Dane DeHaan) makes his way through an asylum-like complex of buildings in search of answers, only to become ever more deeply ensnared in the place‰Ûªs sinister mysteries. You may also catch echoes of Paolo Sorrentino‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏYouth‰Ûù in the mountain rest-cure setting, the weary disdain for modern life and the visual voluptuousness. Mr. Verbinski doesn‰Ûªt so much observe shiny surfaces and opulent furnishings as caress them, sending a frisson of visual delight through his camera as it glides down corridors and soars over wooded glades.

Outside of a sushi context, I don‰Ûªt usually spend much time thinking about eels, but ‰ÛÏA Cure for Wellness‰Ûù gave me no choice. Ever since the screening, I‰Ûªve been wondering about those slithery creatures, which you may have noticed in the trailers and the posters, where a bunch of them share a bathtub with Mia Goth, one of the movie‰Ûªs stars.

It‰Ûªs all in good fun, really, though two and a half hours may be more of this kind of fun than a body can stand. You might feel like you‰Ûªre in the company of a manic cinephile friend breathlessly recounting his favorite movie scenes in no particular order. You admire his devotion, his taste and his scholarship, but in the end the experience is probably more satisfying for him than it is for you.

It would be unfair to blame the director, Gore Verbinski, or the screenwriter, Justin Haythe, for declining to provide a thorough explanation. ‰ÛÏA Cure for Wellness‰Ûù defiantly and splendidly flouts the tenets of plausibility and coherence, which have never interested Mr. Verbinski very much. His rÌ©sumÌ©, after all, includes ‰ÛÏThe Lone Ranger‰Ûù (also written by Mr. Haythe), ‰ÛÏRango‰Ûù and, most notably, the first three ‰ÛÏPirates of the Caribbean‰Ûù movies. He comes by his knack for enjoyable nonsense as honestly as his taste for aquatic fauna.

More plot summary would be an offense against Mr. Verbinski‰Ûªs demented inventiveness. Lockhart also encounters a curious elderly patient (Celia Imre), a heavy-eyed limo driver (Ivo Nandi), a tavern full of hostile young locals and a dreamy girl named Hannah (Ms. Goth, looking like a ‰Ûª70s fantasy hybrid of Shelley Duvall and Sissy Spacek). There are clues and false leads, shocking discoveries and bouts of talking-bad-guy exposition, narrow escapes and fights to the death. And those eels, of course. You‰Ûªll figure it all out for yourself, or not. In any case, the moral of the story turns out to be a bit of advice often given to travelers: Don‰Ûªt drink the water.

The eels may be the key to the puzzle posed by his latest project, or they may be (forgive me) a red herring. Maybe it would be best to drop the piscatory metaphors altogether. ‰ÛÏA Cure for Wellness‰Ûù is a lustrous box of genre candy, the self-revealing work of an auteur who has laid bare not so much his psyche as his online streaming queue. To watch this movie is, above all, to make a list of all the other movies it evokes, sometimes with a literalness that treads the boundary between homage and outright plagiarism.

Everything looks right in place in Anne Hamilton‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAmerican Fable,‰Ûù all measured and ready to go. There‰Ûªs Gitty (Peyton Kennedy), a wide-eyed 11-year-old girl, who lives with her farmer parents, Abe and Sarah (Kip Pardue and Marci Miller), and oddly hostile older brother, Martin (Gavin MacIntosh), on an isolated swath in the American heartland. It seems so peaceful or would if the wolf weren‰Ûªt howling at Red Riding Hood‰Ûªs door, bringing intimations of danger: angry talk, a slammed-down phone, a brandished ax and weird doings.

Gitty doesn‰Ûªt grasp what‰Ûªs going on with the family‰Ûªs farm, but, like so much in ‰ÛÏAmerican Fable,‰Ûù her naÌøvetÌ© comes off as forced, scripted rather than innate. Even so, her confusion starts to make sense given this story, which turns on her involvement in a ludicrous kidnapping scheme that‰Ûªs neither persuasively real enough to believe nor fantastical enough to work for the fairy tale that Ms. Hamilton seems to be trying to create. The introduction of an outsider (Richard Schiff), a hapless moneyman who‰Ûªs disparagingly likened to an animal by a villain, is especially unfortunate because it flirts with an anti-Semitic stereotype.

The fading amber light, the waving green fields, the meandering young girl ‰ÛÓ opens on a pretty pastoral scene. Still, as the gliding camera keeps pace with this girl, a strange undercurrent disturbs the air, creating pinpricks of doubt about just how tranquil the scene is. There‰Ûªs something about how red her top looks in the golden light, something about the quiet, something which suggests that the camera isn‰Ûªt merely on the prowl but also out for blood. It‰Ûªs a nice opening for a movie that spirals into nonsense.

This stereotype isn‰Ûªt exploited, developed or renounced. It‰Ûªs just yet another loose end that flutters in ‰ÛÏAmerican Fable‰Ûù alongside the predictably doomed pet chicken; the equally ill-fated neighbor; the nod to Ronald Reagan; the snippet from Yeats; the portentously injured fawn; and the sleek mystery woman (Zuleikha Robinson) whose woo-woo vibe and long gloves read like a nod to Jean Cocteau‰Ûªs film ‰ÛÏOrpheus.‰Ûù Ms. Hamilton also appears to have a fondness for Charles Laughton‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Night of the Hunter,‰Ûù which finds echoes here in the otherworldly starry night, a diabolical figure on horseback and a psycho with knife skills.

Indeed, the movie‰Ûªs most authentically romantic moment occurs not between Clara and her suitors, but between her sister and brother-in-law (TiarÌ© Scanda and K. C. Clyde), whose marriage might be showing some strain. In a single, brief conversation, they reveal more about the nature of long-term love than Clara will ever comprehend.

Our messed-up heroine is Clara (Karla Souza, clearly delighted to escape the constraints of her lugubrious character on ‰ÛÏHow to Get Away With Murder‰Ûù), an OB-GYN by day and a drunken karaoke singer by night. Fumbling hookups with random men temporarily banish her loneliness without extinguishing her torch for Daniel (JosÌ© MarÌ_a Yazpik), the lover who abandoned her eight years earlier. Guess who shows up, though, to a family wedding to derail Clara‰Ûªs fledgling bond with a cuddly Australian co-worker (Ben O‰ÛªToole)? And guess whose clothing soon evaporates in the heat of Daniel‰Ûªs twinkling attention?

Toggling between Los Angeles and Mexico, English and Spanish, this sophomore feature by Catalina Aguilar Mastretta asks Clara to choose between naughty and nice. The setup is commonplace, but the scenery is delicious, the dialogue refreshingly tart and the keen supporting cast frisky or affecting, as the occasion demands.

Romantic comedies are essentially cinema‰Ûªs comfort food, and expecting them to stray from formula is almost as fruitless as expecting McDonald‰Ûªs to alter the flavor of its fries. So to say that ‰ÛÏEverybody Loves Somebody‰Ûù is predictable is no real criticism, as being able to foresee the ending ‰ÛÓ almost from the beginning ‰ÛÓ is exactly what most viewers expect.

Ice Cube brings his own history to the project, at one point quoting a famously inflammatory N.W.A lyric and glancing back to the days when, as one of my colleagues put it, ‰ÛÏeveryone was scared‰Ûù of him. Campbell certainly is, especially after a series of misunderstandings leads Strickland to challenge him to the after-school face-off that gives the movie its name.

I‰Ûªll be honest with you. I was in a pretty foul mood when I went to see ‰ÛÏFist Fight.‰Ûù It was Wednesday. It was February. It was 2017. And while I can‰Ûªt exactly say that the movie cheered me up, it did give me something I needed. Not catharsis or uplift but a bracing dose of profane, sloppy, reasonably well-directed hostility. We take what we can get.

All of which is fairly tiresome. But it‰Ûªs also possible to read ‰ÛÏFist Fight‰Ûù against the interracial buddy-movie grain, seeing Strickland rather than Campbell as the protagonist, and taking Strickland‰Ûªs anger as a principled response to circumstances rather than as evidence of a mood disorder. The big fight takes place against a background of layoffs and budget cuts. The teachers are harassed by the students and undermined by the administration, yet they persist in the work of education. Strickland is an agent not of guilty racial fear but of righteous class consciousness. The lesson he imparts to Campbell is one of public-sector workers‰Ûª solidarity. By all evidence, he‰Ûªs a pretty good teacher, with good reason to stay mad. Which cheered me up, I must say.

There is an obvious racial dimension to their conflict, though ‰ÛÏFist Fight‰Ûù tiptoes around it, winking and whispering, with typical big-studio timidity. (The most recent season of the HBO comedy ‰ÛÏVice Principals‰Ûù came closer to touching the hot core of resentment in a Southern public school setting.) And it is certainly possible to interpret this movie as yet another fable of a white man‰Ûªs redemption at the hands (or fists, as the case may be) of a black man. We know that Campbell has a young daughter (Alexa Nisenson) and a pregnant wife (JoAnna Garcia Swisher). We learn nothing at all about Strickland, except that he is the subject of wild legends among the student body. His job in the movie is to teach Campbell some hard lessons about being a man.

The movie, directed by Richie Keen from a script by Van Robichaux and Evan Susser, breaks no new ground. It‰Ûªs a bad-teacher comedy about a school staffed with stock figures played by reliable performers. There‰Ûªs a grouchy principal (Dean Norris), a horny guidance counselor (Jillian Bell), a dweeby security guard (Kumail Nanjiani), a nutty football coach (Tracy Morgan) and a femme fatale French instructor (Christina Hendricks). They provide a Greek chorus of goofiness behind the main conflict, which is between Mr. Campbell (Charlie Day), an anxious English teacher, and his profoundly irritable colleague, Mr. Strickland (Ice Cube), whose subject is history.

A bit of context: It‰Ûªs the last day of school, and the seniors are pulling pranks ‰ÛÓ involving a horse, paintball guns and a lot of penis graffiti ‰ÛÓ at the Atlanta high school where the two adversaries work. This provides an extra dollop of slapstick chaos, but the kids are peripheral to the movie‰Ûªs main interest, which is in the mismatch and implicit bromance between Ice Cube and Mr. Day. Each one does what he‰Ûªs expected to do. Mr. Day twitches and babbles and blinks his eyes rapidly. Ice Cube bellows and glowers and doesn‰Ûªt blink at all.

Given the deepening dread and uncertainty over immigration issues, ‰ÛÏFrom Nowhere,‰Ûù Matthew Newton‰Ûªs wrenching, if somewhat chaotic, film about undocumented high school students in the Bronx could hardly be more pertinent. It‰Ûªs one thing to read about roundups of suspected illegal immigrants; it‰Ûªs quite another to observe the anxiety of smart, talented teenagers trying to keep their cool while under the watchful gaze of immigration officials and the police.
The bright, peppy, Peruvian-born Alyssa (Raquel Castro), the class valedictorian, has the most difficulty compiling evidence for the lawyer, and is also the least developed character.

‰ÛÏFrom Nowhere‰Ûù focuses on three promising students whose caring teacher Jackie (Julianne Nicholson) has arranged for them to meet with an immigration lawyer (Denis O‰ÛªHare) who is working pro bono to help them achieve political asylum before they graduate. To bolster their cases, he asks them to supply detailed evidence of the horrors they fled. Asylum is more likely to be granted if their histories involved genocide, genital mutilation or a dictatorship.

‰ÛÏHow could I think I had anything to teach these kids about reality?‰Ûù a disheartened Jackie muses in a final conversation with the lawyer, during which she learns which student has the best chance of receiving asylum. ‰ÛÏThey could teach me about reality.‰Ûù

The most promising student is Moussa (J. Mallory McCree), whose frightened mother (Chinasa Ogbuagu) brought the family from Guinea to the United States to live with a man who subsequently abandoned them. Now the family is behind in the rent and facing eviction.

Bitter, cynical Sophie (Octavia Chavez-Richmond) is from the Dominican Republic and lives with an uncle who treats her as a household slave in an extended family where he resents her presence (another mouth to feed). Because his beer-drinking buddies make surreptitious passes at her when they come over to watch sports, she trusts no one, and her rage threatens to boil over. Her defensive hauteur leads her fellow students to think she is crazy.

In his director‰Ûªs statement, Mr. Newton declares that he didn‰Ûªt set out to make a political film. But recent government actions lend a painful urgency to these interwoven stories. With the fear of deportation hanging over their heads, these adolescents are forced to weigh major life decisions at an age when their American-born peers are fretting about the already stressful challenges of dating and getting into college.

‰ÛÏFrom Nowhere‰Ûù culminates in a celebratory graduation ceremony. But by this time excruciating choices have been made, and the uncertain future of a student who chooses to leave the country gives the film an underlying sadness. Their ordeal feels cruel, unnecessary and infuriatingly real.

The tensions among these boisterous teenagers are palpable in scenes of their being stopped on the street at night by the police and interrogated, and at a post-prom party that threatens to erupt into a brawl. Even among the faculty members, the atmosphere is so tense that Jackie is taken aside by a superior and questioned about her possibly inappropriate relationship with Moussa.

Written and directed by Kazik Radwanski, ‰ÛÏHow Heavy This Hammer‰Ûù is set in Toronto and depicts Erwin (Erwin Van Cotthem ‰ÛÓ yes, it is also another movie that signals its ostensible naturalism by having the characters take the names of their performers) not communicating with his wife (‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt want to talk about it anymore‰Ûù is a frequent line), getting a little rough at rugby, singing along to Flemish songs in his car, and eventually leaving his wife and their two kids. He lets a room adjacent to a bar, always a good idea for an emotionally stunted adult male.

‰ÛÏHow Heavy This Hammer‰Ûù opens with a medium close-up of its protagonist, Erwin, a jowly, bespectacled, middle-aged man. He sits before a computer screen, slack-jawed, the image of the medieval video game he‰Ûªs playing reflected in his glasses, while RenÌ©e Fleming sings the famous ‰ÛÏCasta Diva‰Ûù aria from Bellini‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNorma.‰Ûù
Another week, another movie about the Tragedy of Modern Life that kicks off with a ‰ÛÏwhat an incredible irony‰Ûù cultural juxtaposition.

We never see Erwin at work, which allows the movie to eschew an ‰ÛÏalienated labor‰Ûù analysis and concentrate on the more currently fashionable ‰ÛÏdeclining masculinity‰Ûù theme. Whatever investigation it‰Ûªs attempting, the movie is leaden in its pacing ‰ÛÓ the first 15 minutes feel like an hour ‰ÛÓ and its constricted shooting style, practically all hand-held almost close-ups, is transparent in its contrivance of realism.

‰ÛÏHow Heavy‰Ûù comes off like a loose remake of Rainer Werner Fassbinder‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWhy Does Herr R. Run Amok,‰Ûù with the running amok and the why removed. For that, it deserves points for novelty, I suppose.

‰ÛÏIn Dubious Battle‰Ûù wants to be a noble period piece in the mode of a John Sayles film like ‰ÛÏMatewan.‰Ûù But it is too flat-footed and sloppy to explore the obvious parallels between then and now, and the movie is peppered with gratuitous star cameos that distract rather than enlighten. At least it means well.

James Franco‰Ûªs screen adaptation of John Steinbeck‰Ûªs 1936 novel, ‰ÛÏIn Dubious Battle,‰Ûù about striking California fruit pickers, is the farthest thing imaginable from the titillating provocations for which Mr. Franco is notorious. Along with his films based on William Faulkner‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAs I Lay Dying‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Sound and the Fury,‰Ûù it belongs to the literary subgenre that might be called James Franco‰Ûªs eat-your-spinach movies.

Directed by Mr. Franco from a screenplay by Matt Rager (who also wrote the script for Mr. Franco‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Sound and the Fury‰Ûù), it stars Mr. Franco as Mac, a fiery union organizer who, with his much younger protÌ©gÌ©, Jim Nolan (Nat Wolff), sets out to organize apple pickers in the fictional Torgas Valley of Central California.

The rebellious fruit pickers are soon feuding among themselves, and before long organized protest morphs into dissension, chaos, arson and death. The movie‰Ûªs latter half is a mess; pivotal characters aren‰Ûªt properly introduced, and the rusty dialogue clanks so heavily you feel you are watching a vintage made-for-television movie.

The first novel in Steinbeck‰Ûªs Dust Bowl trilogy, which also includes ‰ÛÏOf Mice and Men‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Grapes of Wrath,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏIn Dubious Battle‰Ûù is Mr. Franco‰Ûªs stodgiest movie: a traditional historical drama replete with stale boilerplate dialogue and a choppy narration about the early days of the American labor movement. It was a time when striking workers risked brutal, sometimes murderous retaliation by greedy bosses and their rich cronies.

Mac is fiercely idealistic but unscrupulous, and Jim a starry-eyed naÌøf. Both belong to ‰ÛÏThe Party‰Ûù (read Communist). When the laborers learn that their promised pay has been reduced from $3 to $1 a day, they are ripe for the plucking as potential union members. Robert Duvall, with his usual aplomb, plays the evil landowner Bolton, who appears gun in hand with his posse.

‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªve got to be taught to hate and fear,‰Ûù says an old song about bigotry. But to hear the former far-right Hungarian politician Csanad Szegedi tell it, he was essentially a self-taught anti-Semite. In ‰ÛÏKeep Quiet,‰Ûù a documentary directed by Sam Blair and Joseph Martin, Mr. Szegedi recalls the pride he felt as a student reading far-right newspapers pushing a nationalist narrative.

Anne Applebaum, a historian and columnist for The Washington Post, notes in the film that Hungary ‰ÛÏis a part of the world where history has been manipulated.‰Ûù Using video footage from the early 2000s to track Mr. Szegedi‰Ûªs rise to the vice presidency of the nationalist Jobbik party, the film shows a TV ad in which the Jobbik platform is put forth: ‰ÛÏProtect Hungarian lands! Restore law and order! Multinationals must pay taxes! To jail with the culprits! Because Hungary belongs to the Hungarians!‰Ûù For his part, Mr. Szegedi disdains what he calls ‰ÛÏcosmopolitan‰Ûù Jews who insist ‰ÛÏall Hungary gave the world was peach schnapps and baggy pants.‰Ûù

Then Mr. Szegedi learns an inconvenient truth: He is of Jewish lineage. His grandmother was an Auschwitz survivor. His colleagues initially suggest that this could be a good thing, inoculating the party from accusations of race hate. That strategy seems to last about half a minute, and Mr. Szegedi is expelled. He begins to embrace his Jewish identity, perhaps out of necessity. ‰ÛÏWhy didn‰Ûªt you stop me?‰Ûù he asks his family about his political activity. Even if you are unmoved by Mr. Szegedi‰Ûªs personal story (I found him somewhat sympathetic), what ‰ÛÏKeep Quiet‰Ûù tells us about its larger themes is upsettingly pertinent.

The film begins with the two friends reuniting, and they soon embark with Jessie on a spontaneous road trip that takes them to eastern Pennsylvania, where they visit a rodeo and an amusement park and play a game called ‰ÛÏtruth or drink.‰Ûù Amid gales of tipsy laughter, they pour out their confessions of naughty misdeeds and in quieter moments murmur endearments and exchange kisses. Each seems to be waiting for the other to define their relationship and carry it to the next level, but it doesn‰Ûªt happen.

Three years pass, and Sarah drives to Tennessee to attend Mindy‰Ûªs wedding to Leif (Ryan Eggold). Already there are signs Mindy is not fully committed to her fiancÌ©, and is going through the motions for reasons that are never explained. And when Mindy‰Ûªs bitter, hard-boiled mother (Rosanna Arquette) arrives, her gimlet eye zeros in on her daughter‰Ûªs ambivalence and she bluntly asks her why she is going through with the wedding.

Sarah, who has a 3-year-old daughter, Jessie, communicates with her mostly absent husband, Dean (Cary Joji Fukunaga), via Skype. Scenes of Sarah and Jessie gently roughhousing capture the blissful mother-daughter bond with a poignant intensity, wrapping the viewer in the blanket of their intimacy.

From the moment Sarah appears, tugs of longing and desire after their lengthy separation are as palpable as ever. The two steal time to be alone together as the final preparations are being made for a wedding filled with raucous off-color humor.

Ms. Keough‰Ûªs soft, shy performance is as compelling as her chilling portrayal of a high-end escort in the Starz series ‰ÛÏThe Girlfriend Experience,‰Ûù but completely opposite in tone. It is matched in power by Ms. Malone‰Ûªs frisky but wary Mindy in a movie devoid of overt sexual politics in which ‰ÛÏthe L word‰Ûù (lesbian) is never spoken.

When Sarah (Riley Keough) and Mindy (Jena Malone), best friends since childhood, gaze at each other in ‰ÛÏLovesong,‰Ûù emotions of longing and uncertainty, interrupted by bursts of joy and laughter, cascade across their faces. This exquisite, beautifully shot meditation on love clouded by fear and doubt is the fourth feature by the Korean-American filmmaker So Yong Kim (‰ÛÏTreeless Mountain‰Ûù), which she wrote with Bradley Rust Gray. Little is resolved, and it will leave you contemplating the mysteries of relationships.
Balancing its heavy subject matter with a tone of airy resilience, ‰ÛÏMy Name Is Emily‰Ûù follows two unhappy teenagers across Ireland and up to the doorstep of adulthood.

It‰Ûªs a sometimes rocky road cinematically, slipping from enchanting to trite, magical to indulgent with some regularity. Yet thanks to beautifully warm performances and Seamus Deasy‰Ûªs easy-on-the-eyes cinematography, this slight first feature from Simon Fitzmaurice (who is paralyzed by the motor neuron disease A.L.S.) might just charm you into submission.

Wistful flashbacks and a self-aware narration fill us in on Emily (Evanna Lynch), 16, an outsider as much in her foster home as in her Dublin school. Her mother is dead and her eccentric father, Robert (the great Michael Smiley), is in a rural mental hospital ‰ÛÓ at least until Emily and her only friend, Arden (George Webster), arrive to break him out.

Displaying the same ethereal quality she brought to the character of Luna Lovegood in the ‰ÛÏHarry Potter‰Ûù movies, Ms. Lynch makes Emily a lonely mermaid, more at home in water than on land. Tootling along country roads in a canary-yellow vintage Renault, she and Arden have mild adventures amid glowing scenery. Their halting attraction is sweet, but it‰Ûªs in the brief glimpses of Robert‰Ûªs unstable passions that the movie finds its true subject, illuminating with touching honesty the heightened joys and terrors of madness. In Robert, we see the glittering panic of parenthood, of the realization that we can never possess enough knowledge to nourish a brand-new soul.

Snarling digital monsters, a glowering Matt Damon and battalions of unfaltering Chinese warriors mix it up in ‰ÛÏThe Great Wall,‰Ûù a painless, overstuffed spectacle that works overtime as a testament to China‰Ûªs might. Set once upon a time, the movie spins a legend that never was: Every 60 years, slavering creatures emerge from beyond to sharpen their teeth on human bones and stuff their bellies on meat. The whole thing plays out as if it had been thought up by someone who, while watching ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones‰Ûù and smoking a bowl, started riffing on walls, China and production money.

In such formations, bodies are abstracted into larger geometric shapes and people transform into a collective mass ornament. This transformation obviously takes on sinister meaning when such formations are adapted for, say, Nazi propaganda, as demonstrated in the film ‰ÛÏ Triumph of the Will.‰Ûù

The threadbare story turns on a swaggering mercenary, William (Mr. Damon), who‰Ûªs trying to find what he calls ‰ÛÏblack powder,‰Ûù a.k.a. gunpowder. He and a sidekick, Tovar (Pedro Pascal, from ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones‰Ûù), end up at the Great Wall, where after some macho posturing and chest thumping, they join forces with the wall‰Ûªs guardians, including an English-speaking military genius, Lin Mae (Jing Tian); an adviser, Wang (Andy Lau); and an assortment of supporting glowerers (Hanyu Zhang, Eddie Peng Yu-Yen and Ling Gengxin). Willem Dafoe, the whites of his eyes shining, is there, too, slinking around as Ballard, a Western prisoner who long ago also sought the black powder.

Mr. Damon, wearing hair extensions and employing an on-and-off Irish accent, looks uncharacteristically ill at ease during much of this. He may be the headliner, but he‰Ûªs also just one of this movie‰Ûªs many, many whirring parts. ‰ÛÏThe Great Wall‰Ûù flirts with romance and bleats out a little propagandistic blather about the benefits of bilateral action, but the focus throughout remains on multitudes of shifting, surging bodies ‰ÛÓ human and beast, digital and not ‰ÛÓ that, as they ebb and flow, resemble a Chinese military pageant and a lavish Busby Berkeley number. At times the effect brings to mind the German theorist  Siegfried Kracauer‰Ûªs ideas about Berkeley-like revues or, as he wrote in 1927, ‰ÛÏindissoluble girl clusters whose movements are demonstrations of mathematics.‰Ûù

That‰Ûªs about it, plus striking locations (the Rainbow Mountains), digital wizardry and battles between hordes of critters (called Tao Tei) and legions of soldiers. These are distinguished by skill and hue, like the blue-clad Crane Corp, who bungee-jump off the wall with spears. Outside of the bromantic quipping between William and Tovar, the dialogue is aggressively simple (no frills, no poetry) and skews along the lines of ‰ÛÏRelease the Kraken‰Ûù or, in this case, bring out the flaming balls of death and so forth. This seems to suit the director, Zhang Yimou (‰ÛÏHero‰Ûù), who lavishes much of his attention on the wall, which amusingly suggests a giant Swiss Army knife, scissors included.

In ‰ÛÏThe Great Wall,‰Ûù though, the bodies are divided into two distinct, oppositional configurations: the raw and the cooked. On the one side are the monsters that ‰ÛÓ despite being nicely designed zeros and ones ‰ÛÓ suggest a wildness that cannot be denied. On the other are the meticulously choreographed warriors, who never seem less human than when joined together.

The Mexican comedy ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre Killing Me Susana‰Ûù deserves kudos for having abrasive, capricious characters, but the director, Roberto Sneider, may have taken a cue from them: His movie is erratic, jumpy (thanks to a needlessly affected editing style) and not entirely in control of its message.

The would-be equal-opportunity squabbling tips a bit toward sexism in the treatment of Susana, and whether these two should get back together or seek alternatives (Eligio‰Ûªs eye wanders to an Iowan played by Ashley Hinshaw) never becomes urgent. Maybe they deserve each other? Maybe they deserve this movie.

After outrunning campus security officers ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs a wanted man for about five minutes ‰ÛÓ Eligio finds Susana flourishing in her writing and tentatively romancing a Polish poet (Bjorn Hlynur Haraldsson). The married couple‰Ûªs surprise makeup sex suggests a chronic love-hate relationship, or at least that someone thought the best way to jolt an uninteresting movie was to turn up the heat.

Through a web search (apparently Susana‰Ûªs common last name is no obstacle), Eligio learns that she‰Ûªs gone to a writer‰Ûªs program in Iowa. He leaves in pursuit, with the zeal of a stalker and no planning whatsoever. His hapless interactions with United States customs officers would be unamusing in any case, but the timing ‰ÛÓ with border entry in the news ‰ÛÓ doesn‰Ûªt help.

The title‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏme‰Ûù is Eligio (Gael GarcÌ_a Bernal), a soap opera actor with a rather one-sided notion of marital fidelity. One morning he awakes to find that his wife, Susana (VerÌ_nica Echegui), has disappeared. This surprises Eligio, who thinks their marriage is great.

Set in an isolated, semirural small town close enough to Canada that a nearby service station has a ‰ÛÏpetrol‰Ûù sign, ‰ÛÏAs You Are‰Ûù chronicles the vexed friendship of two teenage boys in the early 1990s.

The director, Miles Joris-Peyrafitte, making his feature debut, is in some respects very resourceful. Setting the movie in the middle of nowhere, he is largely able to sidestep the slavish (and sometimes unsuccessful) attention to period detail that‰Ûªs become de rigueur for such pictures. But much of the movie, from its attempts to capture the confusing exhilaration of youthful experience to its predictable progressive character dynamics, is labored. (Turns out that Tom, an Army veteran, is not as kind a person as he initially seems. Wow, I didn‰Ûªt see that coming.) And the lifting of motifs and imagery from Fassbinder and Bresson can‰Ûªt help but come off as academic. Mr. Joris-Peyrafitte clearly has a way with actors, though, and perhaps this will yield more palatable results in the future.

Jack (Owen Campbell) meets the substantially more confident Mark (Charlie Heaton of ‰ÛÏStranger Things‰Ûù) when Mark‰Ûªs seemingly nice enough father, Tom (Scott Cohen), begins romancing Jack‰Ûªs mother, Karen (Mary Stuart Masterson). They bond quickly over their shared taste in alternative rock (the movie‰Ûªs title is derived from a Nirvana song), are stomped by thuggish peers (most of whom look to be about 30), and are befriended by a somewhat less immediately alienated misfit (Amandla Stenberg). That things will end badly is signaled in the opening sequence, featuring an enigmatic overhead shot of the two boys walking into the woods, the sound of gunfire, and static low-resolution shots of the characters answering questions at a police station.

The topic is worthy, but the execution is painfully heavy-handed. Keening choirs and cadaverous extras bear witness as Yuri (Max Irons) leaves the family farm and his childhood sweetheart, Natalka (Samantha Barks), to attend art school in Kiev. While Joseph Stalin seizes Ukrainian land and grain, and Yuri entangles himself in the anti-Bolshevik resistance, Natalka fends off the creepy attentions of the village‰Ûªs Soviet overlord (Tamer Hassan). Can she get close enough to kill him before she‰Ûªs forced to eat his vile-looking borscht?

Mr. Mendeluk has Ukrainian roots, but he also has an unfortunate taste for clunky symbolism, zooming in his camera on ominously crushed eyeglasses and a blood-flecked loaf of bread like a spaniel scenting pheasant. His emotional investment in the material is clear, but the millions who died during this real-life tragedy deserve a stronger memorial than this one.

Directed by George Mendeluk and filmed, very prettily, in Ukraine by the British cinematographer Douglas Milsome (whose dusty landscapes were a highlight of the 1989 television mini-series ‰ÛÏLonesome Dove‰Ûù), ‰ÛÏBitter Harvest‰Ûù feels awkward and parochial. Unlike Natalka, the movie has no backbone, flopping from scene to scene without any sense of scope or spectacle.

Politics, romance, faith and famine are mashed into a single misshapen meatball in ‰ÛÏBitter Harvest,‰Ûù which follows two Ukrainian lovebirds through a mass starvation in the early 1930s known as the Holodomor.

By the time Chris and Rose pull up to her parents‰Ûª house ‰ÛÓ a stately brick building with imposing white columns and rocking chairs on the front porch ‰ÛÓ ripples of unease have disturbed the calm. The nicer Rose‰Ûªs parents, Dean (Bradley Whitford) and Missy (Catherine Keener), behave, the greater the ripples. They don‰Ûªt blink at him or his race (Ms. Keener is a virtuoso of the deadeye stare), but instead adopt the forced geniality of people who seem anxious to hide their discomfort. Missy‰Ûªs the watchful one, while the voluble Dean cozies up to Chris, dropping embarrassing slang and relating an odd story about Jesse Owens, the black Olympian who shocked Hitler.

It‰Ûªs a jarring moment that might have been catastrophic for the movie if Mr. Peele didn‰Ûªt quickly yank you back into its fiction. (He‰Ûªs got great timing, no surprise.) There‰Ûªs relief when the offscreen world recedes just then. Yet part of what makes ‰ÛÏGet Out‰Ûù both exciting and genuinely unsettling is how real life keeps asserting itself, scene after scene. Our monsters, Mr. Peele reminds us, are at times as familiar as the neighborhood watch; one person‰Ûªs fiction, after all, is another‰Ûªs true-life horror story. ‰Ûù For his part, Chris, separated existentially, chromatically and every other way, spends so much time putting the white world at ease that he can‰Ûªt recognize the threat coming for him.

In ‰ÛÏGet Out,‰Ûù an exhilaratingly smart and scary freakout about a black man in a white nightmare, the laughs come easily and then go in for the kill. The writer and director, Jordan Peele (of the comedy sketch show ‰ÛÏKey & Peele‰Ûù), knows how to make shadowy streets into menacing ones and turn silences into warnings from the abyss. His greatest stroke in ‰ÛÏGet Out,‰Ûù though, is to have hitched these genre elements to an evil that isn‰Ûªt obscured by a hockey mask, but instead throws open its arms with a warm smile while enthusiastically (and strangely) expressing its love for President Obama.

Mr. Peele knows that threat, plays with it and eviscerates it with jokes and scares, only to top it off messily with full-on Grand Guignol splatter. But some of his finest, most genuinely shocking work is his quietest. One of the best scenes I‰Ûªve seen in a long while finds Chris talking with one of the parents‰Ûª black servants, a maid, Georgina (a fantastic Betty Gabriel). Chris confesses that he gets nervous when around a lot of white people, an admission that Georgina answers by advancing toward him with a volley of ‰ÛÏno, no, no,‰Ûù cascades of tears and a smile so wide it looks as if it could split her face in two. Something has gotten under her skin and it‰Ûªs frightening.

Mr. Peele is best known for his work with Keegan-Michael Key on their titular comedy sketch show, where politics mixed freely with the laughs. Together they starred in the 2016 comedy ‰ÛÏKeanu,‰Ûù a lampoon of action cinema that was a (slack) piece with the movie love that was a mainstay of their show. In one memorable bit from the show, heckling cinephiles voice their complaints (‰ÛÏthis movie has an inconsistent visual language!‰Ûù); in another, two friends realize that the reason the zombie hordes aren‰Ûªt attacking them is they‰Ûªre flesh-eating racists. ‰ÛÏGet Out‰Ûù expands on, and considerably deepens, a similar idea by turning white racism into disquieting genre shivers.

But Mr. Peele is after more than giggles and shocks; he‰Ûªs taking on 21st-century white racism and its rationales. The opener ‰ÛÓ a black man talking on a cellphone on an empty suburban street ‰ÛÓ briskly sets the tone, unsettles the mood and announces Mr. Peele‰Ûªs way with metaphor. He‰Ûªs working within a recognizable horror-film framework here (the darkness, the stillness), so it‰Ûªs not surprising when a car abruptly pulls up and begins tailing the man. You may even snicker because you think you‰Ûªve seen this flick before. Except that when this man anxiously looks for a way out, the scene grows discordantly disturbing because you may, as I did, flash on Trayvon Martin.

Those arms and smiles all but engulf Chris (the British actor Daniel Kaluuya, going deep in a breakthrough performance), a photographer with a sweet pad, adorable dog and equally frisky, adoring girlfriend, Rose (a perfectly cast Allison Williams, from the HBO show ‰ÛÏGirls‰Ûù). The story opens with them preparing for a long weekend with her parents. ‰ÛÏDo they know I‰Ûªm black?‰Ûù Chris gently asks. They don‰Ûªt, but Rose assures him not to worry, and off they go into the countryside and narrative complications. Mr. Peele, making his feature debut, sets a cozy, innocuous scene complete with coos and loving glances, a tranquillity that shatters with an eerily inopportune deer crossing.

Few films elicit as many satisfyingly divergent responses as ‰ÛÏLes Hautes Solitudes.‰Ûù By turns alluring and alienating, and wholly silent, it was made in 1974 by the French director Philippe Garrel and is receiving its belated New York theatrical release at the Metrograph. Experimental by design, though perhaps a bit by accident, it mostly consists of images of the American actress Jean Seberg, who, after her debut as a celluloid saint in ‰ÛÏSaint Joan,‰Ûù went off to peddle papers and make love to Jean-Paul Belmondo in Jean-Luc Godard‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBreathless.‰Ûù By the time Seberg made ‰ÛÏLes Hautes Solitudes,‰Ûù her most famous roles were behind her; five years later, she was dead from an apparent suicide.

Other beauties come and go in ‰ÛÏLes Hautes Solitudes,‰Ûù principally the American actress Tina Aumont, a feral stunner with slashing cheekbones, whose dark mane creates a sharply chromatic contrast with Seberg‰Ûªs blondness. Here and there are also shots of the French actor Laurent Terzieff, who appears, Narcissus-like, gazing at his reflection. Mostly the camera looks at Seberg, who looks right back at it, though sometimes away from it, too, glancing up or down or sideways. Occasionally, the close-ups are tight enough that her face looms; at other times, she is framed in a head-and-shoulders shot, much like a classical Greek bust. Every so often, she lies in bed or crouches in a corner.

The film‰Ûªs silence works as a kind of invitation, encouraging you to infer meaning and jump to conclusions as one image gives way to the next. You fill in the gaps between them, a process similar to how viewers create meaning through montage, shot by shot. The images in ‰ÛÏLes Hautes Solitudes,‰Ûù though, seem more casually strung together than assembled for specific meanings. That makes sense. In 2011 Mr. Garrel told the French magazine Les Inrocks that the idea ‰ÛÏwas to make a film out of the outtakes of a film that never existed in the first place.‰Ûù One of the pleasures of ‰ÛÏLes Hautes Solitudes‰Ûù is that it encourages you to take up filmmaking, as you write that nonexistent movie in your head.

While these images seem to reveal all, they disclose nothing beneath the surface. All that we know is what we see onscreen and that Seberg‰Ûªs face is delicate and lightly creased. She‰Ûªs rarely shown smiling, although there are instances when she laughs emphatically, moments that feel uncomfortable and artificial, as if she were trying out an emotion she had forgotten. We know the texture of her skin; the patterns on the walls; the depth of field; the quality of the light; the contrast of the black-and-white film; the level of grain; the dowdiness of her clothes. She‰Ûªs partial to granny dresses, or maybe they‰Ûªre nightgowns, and when she stands in front of a window, the sunlight glows softly, creating a kind of ravishing halo effect: Saint Jean.

Here, Seberg makes love only to the camera, though she often seems averse to or exasperated by its attentions. Or is she despairing or depressed? It‰Ûªs impossible to know, and neither she nor the film says. ‰ÛÏLes Hautes Solitudes‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt only silent (no audible dialogue, no music), it also has no explanatory text of any kind (subtitles included) or opening and closing credits. Instead there are faces, most female, beautiful and on the young side. The first belongs to the German singer Nico, Mr. Garrel‰Ûªs onetime companion, who‰Ûªs best known for chanteusing with the Velvet Underground. The title of one of their lovely dirges, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll Be Your Mirror,‰Ûù could serve as a tagline for ‰ÛÏLes Hautes Solitudes.‰Ûù

The boy‰Ûªs given name is Icare, the French version of Icarus, which has some pretty heavy mythological connotations. That may be why he prefers to be called Courgette (Zucchini). It‰Ûªs more down to earth. He spends his time flying a homemade kite from the window of an attic room decorated with his mother‰Ûªs empty beer cans. There are quite a few of those. Zucchini‰Ûªs father, whose likeness decorates the kite, is long gone, and an unfortunate accident soon removes Zucchini‰Ûªs mother from the picture.

Also, because ‰ÛÏMy Life as a Zucchini‰Ûù is an animated film ‰ÛÓ a loving work of stop-motion cartoon handicraft and a long-shot Oscar nominee ‰ÛÓ it is more charming than grim. The orphan at large in the world is a fixture of folklore and literature as well as social-service case files, and Mr. Barras‰Ûªs film, with its bigheaded, asymmetrical modeling-clay figures and off-kilter picture-book backdrops, explores a harsh situation with gentle whimsy.

Zucchini, who is 9, is sent to a group home in the countryside, where he falls in with other abused, neglected and abandoned children. Perhaps because ‰ÛÏMy Life as a Zucchini,‰Ûù directed by Claude Barras and based on a book by Gilles Paris, comes from France (and Switzerland), the orphanage is a place of kindness rather than terror. The French republican imagination assumes that institutions are benevolent. Wickedness resides in individuals, in this case the parents whose failures and outright crimes have damaged the innocence of Zucchini and his new friends.

The point of the story, in any case, is not horror but healing. It‰Ûªs a bittersweet celebration of friendship and empathy, as Zucchini makes peace with a bully named Simon and develops a crush on a newcomer named Camille. There is an enchanting ski trip, a smattering of pranks and misunderstandings and a touch of suspense, all rendered in expressive and imaginative visual detail. The animation technique is in some ways cruder than the digital dazzle that kids see all the time, but also more soulful. The round, wide-eyed faces of the orphans are not as perfectly detailed as those of their counterparts in some of this movie‰Ûªs Oscar rivals, but they are enigmatic and individual in ways that are hard to forget.

Still, a bit of caution may be in order for parents. While nothing shown onscreen is graphic or disturbing, the movie is frank about the way the characters have been treated and also about their natural curiosity regarding the adult world. Viewers who have read contemporary young-adult literature will be able to handle it, though their parents may feel uncomfortable at times. Children of Zucchini‰Ûªs age or younger might be freaked out.

The filmmaker narrates, speaking at the beginning of his return to Paraguay after a 40-year absence. ‰ÛÏNow I‰Ûªm the one behind the window,‰Ûù he notes as he shoots an art gallery opening in the country‰Ûªs capital, AsunciÌ_n. Mr. Dubosc shows some of the art on view, which leads him to reflect on the political turmoil of the time he was first there in the late 1960s, when he was making his earliest films.

The French documentarian Dominique Dubosc is a secret too well kept. Despite a filmography comprising two dozen pictures, he is credited with only two directorial efforts on the United States-based Internet Movie Database. The memory-piece aspect of his latest film, ‰ÛÏParaguay Remembered‰Ûù (its original title is the more evocative ‰ÛÏMemoria Desmemoriada,‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏForgetful Memory‰Ûù), may therefore be elusive for those who see its North American theatrical debut. That‰Ûªs a shame, because this quiet movie, shot in black-and-white and color, is an unhurried, beautiful, and pained work that through simple means resonates on various levels.

He also chronicles visits with old friends and contemporary activists. Keeping his camera at a discreet distance from his subjects, he conjures, through images and words, an ever more disquieting set of truths about history and memory. Mr. Dubosc speaks calmly, but with clear pain and anger, about the dictator Alfredo Stroessner, who was in power during the filmmaker‰Ûªs first trip, and the varied forms of resistance to his regime; he speaks with dry irony of what he sees as the lukewarm reforms of Federico Franco, who was president in 2012-13, and calls Barack Obama, then still the United States president, ‰ÛÏlord of the drones.‰Ûù (Anthology Film Archives is screening this picture through Thursday, in tandem with a mini-retrospective of Mr. Dubosc‰Ûªs earlier works on Saturday and Sunday.)

You may be familiar with Mr. Phillips from his web series ‰ÛÏHenry‰Ûªs Kitchen,‰Ûù on which he plays the worst chef ever, or from this movie‰Ûªs 2010 forerunner, ‰ÛÏPunching the Clown,‰Ûù in which he also played a version of himself as an archetypal schlemiel.

While in Los Angeles, he stays with his best friend, Jillian (Tig Notaro), and her wife, Zoe (Stephanie Allynne). The couple ask him to impregnate Zoe ‰ÛÏthe old-fashioned way,‰Ûù and the encounter that ensues is a cringe-inducing debacle. It is one of many humiliations, which begin when he finds his car stolen, then leaves his cellphone in a taxi and has a series of ugly exchanges with the dispatcher. These vignettes are connected by excerpts from an interview with a sympathetic Sarah Silverman.

‰ÛÏSisyphus meets Charlie Brown.‰Ûù In the television satire ‰ÛÏPunching Henry,‰Ûù that is the concept for a reality comedy series being pitched by Jay Warren (J.K. Simmons), a hard-boiled producer determined to make a hit show based on the humiliating misadventures of its hapless star, Henry Phillips.

Mr. Phillips‰Ûªs self-deprecating humor is amusing but not funny enough to give him the edge he needs to rise up and conquer. In a field where the aspiring comic needs to ‰ÛÏkill‰Ûù to succeed, he manages to leave only a few self-administered scratches.

A folk musician who accompanies himself on guitar while singing his verbose streams of consciousness, Mr. Phillips‰Ûªs stage alter ego is a mild-mannered Everyman whose nice-guy persona invites cruel heckling. The movie, directed by Gregori Viens, depicts the typical comedy club audience as being inhabited by the human equivalent of wild dogs snarling over scraps of rotten meat. Mr. Phillips, billed as a ‰ÛÏrambling troubadour extraordinaire,‰Ûù is persuaded to return to Hollywood ‰ÛÓ where he bombed five years earlier ‰ÛÓ to star in a series as ‰ÛÏa loser‰Ûªs loser with no friends, no money and no love life,‰Ûù but is nevertheless likable. At one point, television executives unsuccessfully try to make a video of Henry go viral, but it‰Ûªs actually an audience member‰Ûªs YouTube video of Henry falling off the stage that gives him his big break (if that‰Ûªs what you‰Ûªd call it).

Garry Shandling, who died last year, and to whom the movie is dedicated, may have the most sage advice. He calls stand-up comedy a ‰ÛÏcalling,‰Ûù which he warns ‰ÛÏis too painful and difficult‰Ûù for anyone to pursue casually.

Pared down, this overcrowded movie could be a teaching tool in a comedy school. But as one comic after another recalls triumphs, misadventures and painful lessons learned, the stories become redundant.

‰ÛÏDying Laughing‰Ûù changes topics every few minutes. But one of the longer sections is devoted to life on the road, with its terrible food, miserable lodgings, deadly boredom, loneliness and hostile audiences. In a segment dealing with hecklers, Sarah Silverman good-humoredly recalls hearing someone in the back of a club letting out a light whistle as if a bomb were dropping.

‰ÛÏThe last philosophers‰Ûù is the label Chris Rock bestows on stand-up comedians in Paul Toogood and Lloyd Stanton‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏDying Laughing.‰Ûù In the movie, more than 50 comics, famous and obscure, are interviewed; they offer a vision of their profession akin to that of a solo traveling circus in which every venture into the arena is a risky do-or-die high-wire act.

Some of the most harrowing confessions are firsthand descriptions of bombing in a comedy club or being booed offstage by a bloodthirsty mob. The more famous and successful comics tend to be better psychologically armored than the others. Jamie Foxx says having a lot of money can cushion the pain of a poorly received performance. But the overall mood of this film, which is more downbeat than some might expect, is anxious, combative and at times self-pitying. Failure is always a possibility, and it is accompanied by the terrifying sensation that one comic describes as falling and never landing.

Jerry Seinfeld, one of the most self-assured performers, lauds comedy as being ‰ÛÏbeyond art ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs magic.‰Ûù He describes his first impression of a comedy club audience as ‰ÛÏa dead-silent room of unhappy people.‰Ûù

As Bodi pursues his dream, a pack of wolves pursues him; grown-ups will enjoy hearing the distinctively enraged voice of Lewis Black as the head wolf. The film, based on a Chinese graphic novel and directed by Ash Brannon, keeps its animation simple and its story lines clear, which makes it reliable fare for the 10-and-younger set. The only disappointment, given the subject, is that it‰Ûªs not a full-on musical ‰ÛÓ it has musical flourishes, yes, but nothing as memorable as ‰ÛÏLet It Go.‰Ûù

The title character of ‰ÛÏRock Dog‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt likely to end up on anyone‰Ûªs Top 5 list of animated heroes, but the film does have a thoroughly enjoyable rocker in it. And an appealingly nasty wolf, too.

Bodi (the voice of Luke Wilson) is a mastiff who ‰ÛÓ as all young animated characters must ‰ÛÓ chafes at his assigned role in life, which is to guard the sheep on Snow Mountain. Blame radio. He has accidentally come into possession of one, and the music he hears on it makes him long to try the rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll life.

He‰Ûªs especially enamored of Angus Scattergood, a legendary rocker whose voice is provided by Eddie Izzard in a delightful performance. Bodi leaves Snow Mountain and largely by accident makes his way to Angus‰Ûªs mansion, whose excessive security features are a comic high point of the film.

Melanie is both necessary to the survival of her companions, since her fellow hungries won‰Ûªt bother her, and an existential threat to the human race. Ms. Justineau insists on treating her more as a protÌ©gÌ©e than a potential predator. Dr. Caldwell, the scientist, sees her as a useful laboratory specimen, while the soldiers view her as a devious and powerful enemy. They keep her handcuffed except for reconnaissance missions; on one, Melanie devours a stray cat.

Ms. Nanua is an appealing, relaxed performer, and her convincing portrayal of a clever, decent, good-humored young person is the key to the film‰Ûªs effectiveness. ‰ÛÏThe Girl With All the Gifts‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt really venture into new territory, but it does a decent job of reminding us why zombies are so scary, and so interesting.
