The ambiguous humanity of zombies ‰ÛÓ the porousness of the boundary between us and them ‰ÛÓ is a staple of the genre. When the inevitable crisis arrives, sending Melanie and Ms. Justineau on a perilous journey in the company of a research scientist (Glenn Close) and two soldiers (Paddy Considine and Fisayo Akinade), ‰ÛÏThe Girl With All the Gifts‰Ûù settles into a familiar rhythm. Sessions of flesh-eating and hungry-slaughter alternate with slow-burning philosophical debates.

The specifics of Melanie‰Ûªs situation are laid out in the first act. She lives in a research compound with other, similar children, locked into a prisonlike cell and into a daily routine that is a cruel, dystopian parody of normalcy. The inmates, referred to by the guards as ‰ÛÏabortions,‰Ûù are shackled to wheelchairs and brought into a classroom. Their instruction is more for purposes of research than education, but at least one teacher, Ms. Justineau (Gemma Arterton), goes against protocol and treats her students as if they were human beings. Which is what they seem to be, at least until their hunger is activated.

‰ÛÏThe Girl With All the Gifts,‰Ûù directed by Colm McCarthy, is a moderately engrossing, reliably gory British variation on the tried-and-true zombie-apocalypse theme with a first-rate cast. The formula, worked almost to death ‰ÛÓ or is it undeath? ‰ÛÓ on ‰ÛÏThe Walking Dead‰Ûù and elsewhere, has been tweaked a bit. The shambling, vacant-eyed cannibals are called ‰ÛÏhungries,‰Ûù and their infection seems to be fungal rather than viral. Also, some are cute, normal-seeming children, including the title character, a young girl named Melanie (Sennia Nanua).

Mr. Byrne decided this was a kind of American folk art, and conceived a concert event in which multiple musical artists, himself included, would accompany color guard routines. The concerts ‰ÛÓ on two consecutive evenings at Barclays Center in Brooklyn ‰ÛÓ took place in June 2015. ‰ÛÏContemporary Color,‰Ûù directed by the brothers Bill and Turner Ross, and co-produced by Mr. Byrne, records not just the concerts but also the emotional backstage buzz of young performers working on a scale and in a context they have never encountered before. Many of these teenagers are also on the brink of separating from their colleagues after graduation. (In some cases these are best friends; it‰Ûªs implicit in the makeup of a lot of these groups that color guards are a way for nonjocks to be part of their schools‰Ûª sports scene.)

Several years ago, a high school color guard contacted David Byrne ‰ÛÓ the composer, performer and all-around multimedia artist ‰ÛÓ seeking permission to use one of his songs in a routine the group was developing. Not entirely familiar with what a color guard was, he investigated, and came away enchanted. Color guards meld elements of marching band and pep squad into a dance-oriented amalgam, and perform during sporting events halftimes and in intramural competitions.

Color guard routines are mini-narratives, but the ‰ÛÏContemporary Color‰Ûù directors largely decline to follow them, nervously cutting to backstage action when a hook eludes them. When a color guard truly connects with a magnetic musical performer (as is the case with St. Vincent‰Ûªs collaboration with the color guard Field of View, from West Chester, Pa.), or the combination of music and choreography guides the filmmakers to an impressionistic approach (as with DevontÌ© Hynes and the color guard the Black Watch, from Mount Laurel, N.J.), the application of cinema to live performance yields exceptional results. But over all, this movie is less ‰ÛÏyou are there‰Ûù than ‰ÛÏyou had to be there.‰Ûù

This is a lot for one 90-minutes-and-change movie to bite off, and that‰Ûªs not even taking into account the performers of note enlisted for the event. Because Mr. Byrne, as the leader of Talking Heads, was an essential component of ‰ÛÏStop Making Sense‰Ûù (1984) ‰ÛÓ almost universally acknowledged as one of the great concert movies ‰ÛÓ perhaps there‰Ûªs an unfair expectation for the filmmakers here.

It‰Ûªs undeniable, though, that this movie could have used the earlier film‰Ûªs focus and commitment to coherence. ‰ÛÏStop Making Sense,‰Ûù directed by Jonathan Demme, follows the Talking Heads concert staging (largely conceived by Mr. Byrne) in a hand-in-glove fashion; the movie presented the rock concert as a discrete narrative.

And the poses are fierce, though here they are struck in various makeshift spaces ‰ÛÓ high school gymnasiums, it appears at times, rather than ballrooms. The kids frequently trek from Harlem to the Christopher Street pier, where they marvel at what they perceive to be the blatant homophobia of the police officers in this relatively gay-friendly neighborhood. The semiotics of the scene are as complex as those of the last generation who hosted the dance balls. As one (unofficial) ball competition coach advises about another performer‰Ûªs stance, ‰ÛÏNo one can tell you what you‰Ûªre not, because you‰Ûªre real,‰Ûù with the last word in a set of inflected quotation marks.

One subject, speaking of trying in his early teens to come to grips with discovering that he was gay, says: ‰ÛÏI thought, no, that can‰Ûªt be possible. It‰Ûªs not true.‰Ûù American society is full of people who shrug off the struggles of such individuals as ‰ÛÏlifestyle choices,‰Ûù and the current sociopolitical climate is inarguably actively encouraging a backlash in transgender tolerance. ‰ÛÏKiki‰Ûù shows us a group of brave and beautiful souls for whom the struggle is, unfortunately, probably about to get even harder.

Jennie Livingston‰Ûªs 1991 film, ‰ÛÏParis Is Burning,‰Ûù was a vivid look at an influential gay subculture in New York before the term L.G.B.T.Q. even existed. The ‰ÛÏParis‰Ûù crew, made up largely of black and Hispanic transgender women and drag performers, took its outlandish ballroom competitions from Harlem to Times Square and the Village, jolting the pop culture of the time. It also chronicled their individual struggles to survive.

More than 25 years later, ‰ÛÏKiki,‰Ûù a new documentary directed by the Swedish filmmaker Sara Jordeno (and credited as a film by Ms. Jordeno and Twiggy Pucci GarÌ_on), explores the contemporary Harlem gay and transgender scene. Yet the absence of elder mentors is sadly conspicuous. It‰Ûªs possible that many, maybe most, of that earlier generation is no longer with us.

People who live outside of the places where the AIDS crisis hit hardest tend to mistakenly believe that it‰Ûªs under control. ‰ÛÏKiki,‰Ûù a spiritual descendant of Ms. Livingston‰Ûªs film, implicitly insists the devastation that H.I.V. and AIDS wrought persists. As a partial result, the queer and transgender teenagers of the post-ballroom culture, which they call the ‰ÛÏKiki scene,‰Ûù have, it seems, only themselves to rely on. Even those who have at least one supportive parent, as Mr. Pucci GarÌ_on does, carry a kind of visual loneliness despite their ability to strike a pose.

Ms. Jordeno chronicled her tight-knit group for several years, and was able to document two of her subjects, Gia Marie Love and Izana Vidal, at various stages of their transitioning to women. These are tough but tenderhearted young people who speak frankly about their various challenges, including the lure of sex work ‰ÛÓ relatively easy money in a world that still doesn‰Ûªt much like seeing trans people working ‰ÛÏstraight‰Ûù jobs.

The people around her are a little more distinctive, but only because they have entirely conventional roles to fulfill, more like video game avatars than flesh-and-blood beings. Samantha has a mom and a dad and an annoying younger sister, a jerky boyfriend she‰Ûªs planning on sleeping with for the first time, another boy who is not-so-secretly in love with her, and a squad of friends. They can be sorted into the wild one, the responsible one and the Queen Bee ‰ÛÓ identities that are signaled, day after day, by obvious behavioral cues. There is also a weird girl who is tormented by Samantha and her crew, and whose fate turns out to be the axis on which the movie‰Ûªs world turns.

Samantha (Zoey Deutch) is the nicest member of a foursome of mean girls at a high school somewhere in the Pacific Northwest. ‰ÛÏBefore I Fall‰Ûù takes place on the last day of her life. This is no spoiler: Samantha perishes in what has to be among the most heavily foreshadowed car accidents in recent movies, on a misty road in the dead of night. But then she wakes in a cycle of repetition reminiscent of ‰ÛÏGroundhog Day,‰Ûù living through the same sequence of events again and again until she gets it right.

The filmmakers take the sting out of death in two ways: by dissolving tragedy in a dubious, not-quite-religious metaphysical scheme and by making the principal characters so generic that they barely exist in the first place. Ms. Deutch is an alert and engaging performer, but Samantha is almost entirely devoid of interests, tastes or ideas.

‰ÛÏBefore I Fall‰Ûù is tactful rather than maudlin, tasteful rather than lurid, soothing rather than creepy. None of that is good news. Ms. Russo-Young‰Ûªs earlier films (including ‰ÛÏYou Won‰Ûªt Miss Me‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏNobody Walks,‰Ûù which she wrote with Lena Dunham) can be intriguingly oblique, using the natural diffidence of millennial characters to suggest hidden reservoirs of frustration, hostility, sorrow and desire. There is no such subtext here, no rough patches or sharp edges of individuality, and therefore nothing to care or wonder about. The twists are smoothed out, the dots are connected and the day finally ends, almost as if it had never happened at all.

The film, directed by Ry Russo-Young, written by Maria Maggenti and based on Lauren Oliver‰Ûªs young-adult novel, isn‰Ûªt a comedy but rather a dutiful entry in the intermittently popular dying-girl melodrama genre. The damp, forested Pacific Northwest setting puts us in the ‰ÛÏTwilight‰Ûù zone. The mood of morbid, smiling-through-tears sentimentality recalls ‰ÛÏThe Fault in Our Stars,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏMe and Earl and the Dying Girl‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏIf I Stay.‰Ûù

Anthony (Taylor John Smith) is a basketball star at a private high school in New York who is good enough to be drawing interest from Cornell. The league championship game is looming, but Anthony has distractions, many of them caused by his father (Michael Shannon), whose drinking and gambling are spiraling out of control.

For two-thirds of the way, ‰ÛÏWolves‰Ûù is a decent high school sports movie thanks to actors who are really committed to its somewhat formulaic characters. But then it‰Ûªs as if Bart Freundlich, who wrote and directed, loses confidence in the performances and decides he‰Ûªd better throw in every clichÌ© in the genre.

Suddenly Anthony has more than his father to worry about, and the adversity just keeps piling up, building to a ridiculously improbable climax. Too bad ‰ÛÓ the actors do nice work before things derail.

This is stock plotting ‰ÛÓ the athlete sidetracked by domestic matters at a crucial moment ‰ÛÓ but Mr. Smith and especially Mr. Shannon sell the conceit well, aided by fine performances from Carla Gugino as Anthony‰Ûªs mother and Zazie Beetz as his girlfriend. Yet just when the film seems as if it will choose the road rarely taken by movies involving sports ‰ÛÓ the subtle road, the one that doesn‰Ûªt involve last-second heroics on the court or diamond or field ‰ÛÓ Mr. Freundlich veers into thudding excess.

The tricky mentor-protÌ©gÌ© relationship between Rahim and Aiman, who‰Ûªs 28, is the heart of this moderately gripping film, directed by Boo Junfeng, that by its end tells you more than you want to know about this form of capital punishment. The two appear to bond early, as when Aiman guides Rahim to a store from which he can replenish his dwindling supply of rope. By then, we‰Ûªve learned that Aiman, a polite, handsome Malay, is the son of a killer executed by Rahim years earlier.

‰ÛÏThe trick is to place the knot just behind the left ear and above the jaw.‰Ûù Those instructions on how to carry out a ‰ÛÏhumane‰Ûù hanging are given early in the Singaporean film ‰ÛÏApprentice‰Ûù by Rahim (Wan Hanafi Su), the chief executioner at a high-security prison, to his new assistant, Aiman (Fir Rahman). Rahim takes enormous pride in his work, which he has been doing for 30 years, and he, at least outwardly, exhibits no qualms about his profession. When their time comes, he boasts, the death-row prisoners feel no pain because they die instantly. Rahim assures one man before he‰Ûªs hanged that he is being sent to ‰ÛÏa better place.‰Ûù

A former army officer who was involved in gang violence when he was younger but has since changed his ways, Aiman lives with his older sister Suhaila (Mastura Ahmad), with whom he has a tense relationship. The dour Suhaila, who raised her brother almost single-handedly, is about to leave Singapore to marry her Australian fiancÌ© and is critical of her Aiman‰Ûªs new job.

At first ‰ÛÏApprentice‰Ûù seems to be a basic revenge film in which Aiman stalks the man who killed his father. But it becomes psychologically more complex as it reveals Rahim‰Ûªs buried rage and guilt over his occupation and Aiman‰Ûªs ambivalence when offered the chance to step into his new boss‰Ûªs shoes. ‰ÛÏApprentice‰Ûù largely skirts the issue of capital punishment while letting it be known that most of the other guards don‰Ûªt want the job. Killing a fellow human being is not easy.

Veering between clunky social commentary and inspired observation (like a hilarious skewering of Brooklyn baby showers), ‰ÛÏCatfight‰Ûù is an acid attack on callous privilege. And if it seems to take a little too much pleasure in the sight of women waling on each other, it also serves as a proudly unsubtle reminder of the fragility of civility. If we need one, that is.

The two leads are mesmerizing, hurling themselves into their physically demented roles with ferocious commitment. Veronica, trophy wife to a slick SoHo war profiteer (Damian Young, always an asset), is an entitled lush who‰Ûªs constantly dashing the artistic hopes of their sensitive son. Ashley is a furiously unsuccessful artist whose bloody, politically charged canvases keep her dependent on her long-suffering partner (Alicia Silverstone). Neither gives a fig for the real war playing out in the background, relayed through the jaded banter of a late-night television host.

Suspended animation is, like the bust-ups, a recurring motif in this wildly uneven yet weirdly hypnotic satire from Onur Tukel. Drawing its energy from revenge and its jagged humor from a black well of contempt for the wealthy, the movie fashions a world in which the only likable characters are the crazy and the doomed.

The battle that gives ‰ÛÏCatfight‰Ûù its title and dramatic framework is a series of three hyperviolent encounters between Ashley (Anne Heche) and Veronica (Sandra Oh), two equally despicable New Yorkers. Former college frenemies whose fortunes have radically diverged, the women harbor an unspecified grudge that flares to life during a chance encounter and leaves Veronica in a two-year coma.

‰ÛÏDonald Cried‰Ûù is an acutely insightful, exquisitely written and acted triumph for Mr. Avedisian, who understands how the past permanently clings to us. The childish Donald, whose bedroom walls are plastered with horror-movie and heavy-metal posters, lives in a state of arrested development and works for a musclebound goon who verbally abuses him. His most precious possession is a signed picture of a porn star.

Observing the reunion of two former high school friends in Kris Avedisian‰Ûªs squirm-inducing comedy ‰ÛÏDonald Cried‰Ûù is like watching an ostensibly friendly game of catch in which the players tossing a baseball throw it so hard that it becomes a potentially lethal weapon. At first you root for one side to knock out the other, but the balance of sympathy slowly shifts.
A movie of intensely compressed emotions that barely misses a note, ‰ÛÏDonald Cried‰Ûù puts you excruciatingly in the moment. You long to flee, but it‰Ûªs so good that you can‰Ûªt avert your gaze.

Not soon after Peter arrives he discovers he left his wallet ‰ÛÓ with his cash, credit cards and identification ‰ÛÓ on the bus. Suddenly helpless, he is forced to turn to Donald, who still lives across the street. He is the last person he wanted to see.

The town, through Peter‰Ûªs eyes, is a suffocating Nowheresville peopled with losers idling their time away. As you learn more about Peter, he emerges as a gloomy middle-age man riddled with guilt about abandoning his grandmother for big-city pursuits. Donald, although pathetic in many ways, has maintained a sense of moral responsibility, however warped and childlike.

The not-so-friendly former buddies who reconnect in Warwick, R.I., are Peter (Jesse Wakeman), a glum, selfish Manhattan banker who has returned home for the first time in many years to settle the affairs of his grandmother after her death in a nursing home, and his neighbor Donald (Mr. Avedisian), who never left.

The movie forcefully reminds you that the past you thought you had left behind still hurts, and that the old wounds you imagined had healed have simply been covered over. Returning to the place where you grew up, your younger, more vulnerable self takes over whether you like it or not.

Donald, who wears a goofy grin throughout much of the movie, is cringingly obsequious to Peter, who we learn, always treated him condescendingly. As much as Peter needs Donald, he can‰Ûªt disguise his desire to escape him as quickly as possible. But Donald, determined that they hang out and relive the past, contrives ways to prevent Peter from escaping.

As Donald‰Ûªs reluctant companion, Peter is forced to join a pickup football game in the snow, and to visit a hostile former acquaintance who reminds him of how he used to torment Donald. In the creepiest moment, Peter is pressured to visit their old hide-out in an abandoned train tunnel where they used to smoke pot. Once there, Donald jokingly pulls a gun on him.

But ‰ÛÏJunction 48‰Ûù hits its stride as soon as Kareem takes the stage and raps about Lod‰Ûªs drug culture and police harassment. The simultaneously tensest and most optimistic sequence occurs when Kareem attends an after-party with the Israeli nationalist rappers who preceded him. (‰ÛÏThey apologized for ‰Ûª67 and for ‰Ûª48,‰Ûù he later says to Manar, jokingly, referring to the wars in those years, when she asks how it went.)

Familiar genre trappings do little to dispel the groove of ‰ÛÏJunction 48,‰Ûù which does for the Israeli city of Lod what ‰ÛÏ8 Mile‰Ûù aimed to do for the suburbs of Detroit. This energetic drama from the Israeli-American director Udi Aloni casts the real-life rapper Tamer Nafar as Kareem, an aspiring musician from the mixed-population city (also Mr. Nafar‰Ûªs hometown), where Kareem, one of Israel‰Ûªs Arab citizens, faces regular discrimination and the feeling of a dead end.

‰ÛÏJunction 48‰Ûù takes some time before letting its charismatic star ‰ÛÓ who wrote the screenplay with Oren Moverman (of ‰ÛÏTime Out of Mind‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Messenger‰Ûù) ‰ÛÓ take the mike. We learn that Kareem‰Ûªs parents are also artists. (They perform music at a political gathering shortly before his father is killed in a car accident.) We meet his girlfriend, Manar (Samar Qupty), who is wary of Kareem‰Ûªs appearing at a Tel Aviv club that doesn‰Ûªt typically host Arabic-language rappers.
‰ÛÏJunction 48‰Ûù is more than a mere crowd-pleaser, and it refuses easy catharsis, ending with a cliffhanger. But since this is a movie about deciding to act, maybe that‰Ûªs the perfect note.

Much of ‰ÛÏLogan‰Ûù is an extended chase sequence, with Logan et al. forced on the run while pursued by the corporate concern. There are detours and kind strangers, open skies and endless miles, carnage and politics. En route, Mr. Mangold occasionally resorts to clichÌ©, but many of his choices feel fresh, paradoxically because he has the heart of a classicist. He has watched his share of Clint Eastwood and old Hollywood, too. He‰Ûªs also a sentimentalist, as his nod to the 1953 western ‰ÛÏShane‰Ûù suggests. (‰ÛÏA gun is a tool,‰Ûù that film‰Ûªs gunslinger says, ‰ÛÏas good or as bad as the man using it.‰Ûù) The romance of the righteous kill remains a cinematic article of faith.

‰ÛÏLogan‰Ûù is a strong argument for bringing the comic-book movie down to earth. It solidly hits its marks as it moves the franchise furniture around, and features striking special-effects scenes in which the world shudders to a near standstill. Here, though, the pyrotechnics serve the story and are of a piece with a scaled-down realism that acknowledges ‰ÛÓ in its scars, viscera and flood of parentless children ‰ÛÓ the cost of the endless fight. It loves that fight, of course: That‰Ûªs entertainment. But as it intimately tethers you to Logan and Laura, at times uncomfortably (their claws were made for impaling), it reminds you that these mutants are never less than human.

The opener is kinetic, efficiently staged, casually sadistic and near-ritualistic in how it conforms to the genre playbook. Logan is napping in his parked car not far from the United States-Mexico border when he is awakened by a gang trying to steal his tires. It‰Ûªs an archetypal poke-the-bear scene, the sort in which the hero announces his bona fides by eradicating villains too stupid to know what they are up against. Logan calls out to them, as if giving them fair warning. It‰Ûªs pointless. Like most generic bad guys, these exist purely to wind the hero up ‰ÛÓ they‰Ûªre the action-movie equivalent of foreplay ‰ÛÓ and soon Logan is slicing and dicing, spearing bodies like kebabs.

‰ÛÏLogan‰Ûù is good enough that you might forget it‰Ûªs a comic-book movie. It‰Ûªs another entry in the tireless X-Men saga but doesn‰Ûªt play like a retread or an ad for the next installment; instead, it plays, looks and sounds like a movie ‰ÛÓ an old-school meets new-school pulp filled with intimations of mortality, and raw, ugly violence. Once again, Hugh Jackman has saddled up to play the Wolverine, a mutant who also goes by Logan, and has always been the most satisfying character in the series. Mr. Jackman‰Ûªs charm can lighten the glummest dirge, but for comic-book agnostics the real appeal is Logan‰Ûªs reluctance to get involved, an ambivalence that can feel familiar to viewers exhausted by the same fight.

This is the ninth time that Mr. Jackman has played Logan, and while the character‰Ûªs claws are intact, the movie is a major narrative and stylistic shift in its franchise universe. It was directed by James Mangold, who shares script credit with Scott Frank and Michael Green, and has the clarity and directness of a classic genre picture. It‰Ûªs part western, part neo-noir, the kind of movie in which a stranger steps from the shadows and shakes off his isolation and existential burden long enough to right whatever wrong needs righting. You know him: He‰Ûªs the man with the tight smile and split lip, the one whose hard talk never fully obscures his wounded soul.

Scenes like these turn characters into garbage that the hero has to bag up and toss. That‰Ûªs standard genre posturing, but Logan is as much a hero as an outlier and can‰Ûªt descend into nihilism. He needs a cause, a banner to hoist. So the movie complicates its bloodletting, including through a story line about corporate violence run amok in a near-lawless future. Enter the rogue geneticist (played with restrained flair by Richard E. Grant) with a venal aide-de-camp (a charismatic Boyd Holbrook) and an army of paramilitary cyborgs. These, in turn, connect to Laura (a terrific newcomer, Dafne Keen), a watchful, feral child who is fleeing across borders.

Before long, Logan is playing the resistant head of a household that includes Laura as the ultimate in uncontrollable spawn and a sickly Professor X (Patrick Stewart) as their noble paterfamilias. Mr. Stewart, using a rasp that suggests decay is working its way out from the inside, does some beautiful work, especially with Mr. Jackman. Pushing and pulling at each other, they create a shared vulnerability that‰Ûªs expressed both in physical degradations ‰ÛÓ the movie is filled with ravaged, traumatized bodies ‰ÛÓ and in the contrapuntal play between Logan‰Ûªs gruff tenderness and Professor X‰Ûªs floundering. (He‰Ûªs Gramps by way of King Lear.)

In onstage segments taped in front of an audience, and in scenes enacted in other locations with an ensemble, he details his tribulations with accountants and the Internal Revenue Service. Cute tales of his career and childhood are also thrown in, as are recollections of his family and his unlikely success in finding love.

‰ÛÏLove & Taxes‰Ûù may have worked better onstage, where Mr. Kornbluth‰Ûªs smaller insights and asides would have greater effect; here such musings tend to get swallowed on the screen. Still, he brings humor to a situation ‰ÛÓ paying taxes ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs agonizing to plenty of people. That alone is a minor marvel.

The stories are, by and large, inoffensive. Mr. Kornbluth, well-directed by his brother, Jacob Kornbluth, is a comfortable presence, shuffling and schlubbing through his own life. In the scripted scenes he‰Ûªs aided by an excellent supporting cast, including Harry Shearer as a Hollywood dealmaker, and Robert Reich, the labor secretary under President Bill Clinton, playing a former I.R.S. commissioner.

Likability goes a long way in ‰ÛÏLove & Taxes,‰Ûù a comedy that relies on the friendly style of its star to carry a rambling story. If there aren‰Ûªt many big laughs here, there are enough smiles to make the time pass pleasantly enough.

Based on a one-man autobiographical stage show, the movie finds Josh Kornbluth recounting his ‰ÛÏpossibly real-life exploits‰Ûù of failing to file tax returns for seven years, and the troubles that resulted from his attempts to rectify the situation.

It takes place in Ghana, where Iddrisu (Jacob Ayanaba), studying to become a doctor, lives in the city of Kumasi. His father‰Ûªs death calls him home to the farming village of Nakom, where Ms. Pittman served in the Peace Corps.

In a social structure that accords more agency to men than women, Iddrisu has a sister, Damata (Grace Ayariga), who laments not having money for her own education, and a brother, Kamal (Abdul Aziz), who is perpetually absent. We later learn that Kamal is responsible for impregnating Uncle Napoleon‰Ûªs granddaughter (Esther Issaka).

There is nothing in ‰ÛÏNakom‰Ûù that will surprise moviegoers who watch it solely for its plot. But this low-key, engaging feature from Kelly Daniela Norris and T.W. Pittman, shown in last year‰Ûªs New Directors/New Films series, allows its setting to become a major character ‰ÛÓ and in this case, that‰Ûªs enough.

Regarded by his family as a big-city boy uninterested in traditions, Iddrisu re-acclimates to a rural lifestyle. Torn about how long to stay, he has competing obligations to his scholarship and to a debt that Uncle Napoleon (Thomas Kulidu), Iddrisu‰Ûªs father‰Ûªs brother, gives him until the harvest to pay off.

Some of the complications are standard melodrama; others concern more quotidian matters, like when to plant before the rain and where to sell harvested onions. A strong nonprofessional cast and a use of long takes enhance the sense of immersion in a truly organic production.

Slapstick and sap vie for prominence in ‰ÛÏTable 19,‰Ûù a comedy so lazy that it actually features someone falling off a log. Also submitted for our hilarity are such reliables as the pot-smoking old lady and the elaborate cake that will never reach the finale intact. Most likely, neither will your patience.

More aptly titled ‰ÛÏSix Sad People You Might Meet at a Wedding,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏTable 19‰Ûù is so awkwardly structured and tonally off-kilter that its moments of catharsis feel wholly unearned. Were it not for the caliber of the tablemates ‰ÛÓ especially Lisa Kudrow and Craig Robinson as a miserable married couple and Stephen Merchant as a maladroit ex-con ‰ÛÓ the movie would fall as flat as mother-of-the-bride karaoke. The publicity notes tell us it took the director, Jeffrey Blitz (helped by Mark and Jay Duplass), two years to hammer out the screenplay. And that might be the saddest thing of all.

The table in question is parked on the periphery of a wedding reception and designated, per the seating plan, for ‰ÛÏthe randoms‰Ûù: those guests one feels obliged to invite but who, one hopes, will decline. Chief among them is Eloise (Anna Kendrick), the mysteriously demoted maid of honor and recent dumpee of the best man (Wyatt Russell, still in no danger of outshining his father, Kurt). Inexplicably pining for this charmless doofus, Eloise alternates between stalking him and trying to make him jealous, endeavors equally bereft of laughs and dignity.

The director Eduardo Williams is quite aggressive about pushing at the boundaries between documentary and fiction film in his debut feature, ‰ÛÏThe Human Surge.‰Ûù  His camera follows its subjects, initially young people in impoverished areas around Buenos Aires, from a respectful distance and records, it seems, the most quotidian details of their lives. (It was shot in two formats, Super 16-millimeter film and digital.)

The action is all relatively realistic, but then someone will drop a cryptic or surreal observation. (For instance, ‰ÛÏIn the future the noise level of the food court will be accepted as silence.‰Ûù) A scene of teenage boys engaging in tentative sex play with one another for a webcam show is presented with sufficient flatness of affect to make a viewer suspect that Mr. Williams is also interested in blurring the lines between verisimilitude and tedium. Just when you think you‰Ûªve got the movie pegged, it pulls a daring switch of perspective. While the thrill of that little coup is short-lived, it suggests that Mr. Williams may come up with something more substantial with his next feature.

A young man wades through a flooded area, then drops in on a house full of friends, or perhaps relatives; he wanders into a bedroom, where he chats with a teenage girl about the house‰Ûªs lack of Wi-Fi. Logging on is a leitmotif in the film, which ends with a young woman, in a village halfway around the world from the movie‰Ûªs starting point, repeatedly asking (it‰Ûªs very annoying) where she can find a ‰ÛÏcybercafe.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs as counterfeit as it comes, but just when you think it couldn‰Ûªt get more artificial, Harriet and Anne are joined by Brenda (AnnJewel Lee Dixon), a young black girl. Harriet more or less goes shopping for Brenda at a community center, having decided that she needs a charity case to pad out her obituary. There‰Ûªs some scathing satirical potential in this setup ‰ÛÓ the privileged white doyenne exploiting black poverty ‰ÛÓ but that would require backbone, edge and honesty, none of which this movie finally has. And so Harriet, Anne and Brenda bond, smile and even dance, sharing and learning from one another with forced laughter and false tears.

Shirley MacLaine enters beautiful scowl first in ‰ÛÏThe Last Word,‰Ûù a sweet-and-sour dramatic comedy that would be unbearable without her. She plays Harriet Lauler, a retired advertising executive who has effectively walled herself up in a grand, immaculate house that‰Ûªs a testament to her former glory but so quiet it might as well be her mausoleum. Frankly, it‰Ûªs a wonder no one has strangled her yet. Unapologetically domineering, Harriet all but grabs the garden clippers from her exasperated gardener and pushes her blissfully patient cook out of the kitchen. She knows better, does better, always has, always will. Her elbows aren‰Ûªt sharp; they‰Ûªre lethal.

Too bad she has to share it. The story proper begins after Harriet has a brush with death and, somewhat worriedly, decides that she needs to arrange an obituary worthy of her status. She makes a study of the genre, underlining what goes into a good death notice: friends (she has none), family (a question mark), and something unusual, a so-called wild card. This leads her to the local newspaper, which owes her for her longtime patronage, and straight to Anne (Amanda Seyfried), a reluctant obituary writer who‰Ûªs dragooned into service.

There is more to Harriet than meets the eye, of course, including secrets and lost connections, and if the movie simply stayed focused on her it might have been considerably better. The director, Mark Pellington, who scatters photos of the young Ms. MacLaine in the house like religious relics, clearly adores her. Some of the movie‰Ûªs most satisfying moments show Harriet alone in her house, lingering in its empty rooms, needlessly fussing over its sterile perfection and staring into the distance. Ms. MacLaine, 82, holds the screen effortlessly.

Ben-Gurion‰Ûªs message, in the sessions conducted five years before his death, is, at this point, largely a peaceful, nonexpansionist one that contrasts sharply with many of the Israeli voices in the settlement film. It conveys a satisfying, informative portrait of a well-read man who looks back at his life, good decisions and bad, with wisdom and intelligence.

The Israeli settlement movement is always in the news. It was central to the diplomatic dance surrounding Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu‰Ûªs recent visit with President Trump. Now the issues of Israeli sovereignty are revisited in two new films.
Some of today‰Ûªs settlements of spacious homes with swimming pools have tunnels that allow residents to zip to Israel proper. Keeping settlers safe, the film notes, is costly.

The film takes viewers into the living rooms (and, in one case, the yurt) of Jews who have moved onto Palestinian land. Packed with maps and facts, the documentary pointedly notes that the approximately 400,000 settlers stand in the way of peace by ensuring that the land will not revert to Palestinian control.

When the settlement movement began, David Ben-Gurion, one of the Zionist founding fathers and Israel‰Ûªs first prime minister, was just leaving politics. ‰ÛÏBen-Gurion: Epilogue‰Ûù is a refreshing and effectively edited documentary that has at its core a six-hour black-and-white interview conducted in 1968. Lost for decades, it was trimmed and shaped by the writer and director Yariv Mozer, and interleaved with news footage and other clips that contain everything from historic moments of oratory to charming shots of the elder statesman doing a headstand on the beach or sharing a piano bench with Ray Charles.

Then there are the outpost dwellers, who strike out to build towns in as yet untouched occupied areas. Most settlers interviewed are united in their outspoken love of the land. Some talk about hating and hurting Palestinians.

Mr. Dotan talks to Palestinians whose olive groves have been disturbed by settlers or who have seen their land gobbled up by the illegal construction of outposts by renegades. Their frustrated accounts illuminate some subtexts for the rock-throwing boys of the Palestinian uprisings.

Shimon Dotan‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏThe Settlers‰Ûù gives the headlines a firm grounding in context. While any explanation of this fraught phenomenon feels like an oversimplification, Mr. Dotan sorts out the forces and personalities that shaped the movement, going back to the 1967 Six-Day War that provided the territorial gains that enabled some Israelis, with a range of ideologies, to stake out newly occupied lands.

And so as the film passes the two-hour mark, it begins to feel as if it‰Ûªs treading water. People of faith already know that there are no cut-and-dried answers to the kinds of questions Mack is asking. The intended audience here, though, will at least come away with plenty of fodder for postviewing discussion groups.

Mack wallows in grief and survivor‰Ûªs guilt, as well as anger, much of which is directed at God. Then a mysterious note from Papa ‰ÛÓ his wife‰Ûªs pet name for the Almighty ‰ÛÓ invites him to revisit the remote shack where the police believe his child was killed. There he meets the divine trinity of some Christian faiths: Papa (Octavia Spencer), his son (Avraham Aviv Alush) and the Holy Spirit (Sumire).

She never really does. Not to be sacrilegious, but as a film character, Papa doesn‰Ûªt have a lot of depth; for much of the movie it‰Ûªs as if Mack has stumbled into a very nice bed-and-breakfast and God is the universe‰Ûªs most benevolent innkeeper.

Many faith-based films settle for a Jesus-loves-me climax without digging far into theological matters. This one at least asks the difficult questions. It‰Ûªs at its best when Mack is grilling Papa on matters like why she allows children to be murdered.

The movie, based on William P. Young‰Ûªs best seller and directed by Stuart Hazeldine, is about the spiritual journey of Mack (Sam Worthington), whose youngest child is abducted and murdered while he is watching over her and her two siblings on a camping trip.
‰ÛÏStop talking in riddles,‰Ûù he admonishes her after yet another vague answer.

First things first: ‰ÛÏThe Shack,‰Ûù a Christian-themed movie with laudable ambitions, will resonate with lots of people who feel Hollywood does not generally understand or care about their world. That said, a bit more editing to remove some of the airiness would have made for a better film.

If current political shenanigans haven‰Ûªt already invigorated your respect for unglamorous gumshoe reporting, then ‰ÛÏWater & Power: A California Heist‰Ûù should do the trick. Guided by the work of a handful of burr-like journalists, this dense and disturbing documentary dives into the regulatory quagmire of California water rights with more courage than hope.

Bristling with this kind of detail ‰ÛÓ and a relentless focus on the agribusiness billionaires Stewart and Lynda Resnick, whose profits seem immune to drought ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏWater & Power‰Ûù unleashes a geyser of facts. Fed-up residents tell of contaminated drinking water or no water at all; but only when the movie turns from small-town specifics to the uncertain future of our global water markets does the real chill set in.

‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs like a priesthood,‰Ûù the environmental lawyer Adam Keats says, describing the cabal of players who dominate the state‰Ûªs continuing tug of war between public and private interests. Undaunted, Ms. Zenovich leads us through a major restructuring of the water supply in the 1960s and a 1994 renegotiation that included the hotly disputed privatization of a critical underground reservoir. This last was so contentious that the mediator had to use cymbals to quiet the raised voices.

It‰Ûªs a lot to tackle in just 80 minutes, but the director, Marina Zenovich, is not one to be deterred by complicated stories. The scrupulous avoidance of glib conclusions that distinguished her best-known film, ‰ÛÏRoman Polanski: Wanted and Desired,‰Ûù is fully in evidence here. Even so, she has an uphill battle to wrestle clarity and a compelling narrative from dry wells and decades of back-room deals ‰ÛÓ even with appropriate clips from Mr. Polanski‰Ûªs 1974 water-rights drama, ‰ÛÏChinatown.‰Ûù

But the tradition of Disney features, both live action and animated, rigorously places spectacle in the service of plot. The audience needs to be, by turns, reassured and surprised, guided through startling and suspenseful events toward a never-in-doubt conclusion. The new ‰ÛÏBeauty and the Beast,‰Ûù written by Stephen Chbosky and Evan Spiliotopoulos, smoothly modernizes ‰ÛÓ and to some degree sanitizes ‰ÛÓ a story with a potentially thorny psychosexual subtext, a tale of male animality and female captivity. He‰Ûªs a beast and a prince. She‰Ûªs his prisoner and his therapist. It‰Ûªs a little kinky if you stop to think about it, and also (to use a more responsible word) a little problematic.

Ms. Watson, already something of a feminist pioneer thanks to her portrayal of Hermione Granger in the ‰ÛÏHarry Potter‰Ûù movies, perfectly embodies Belle‰Ûªs compassion and intelligence. Mr. Stevens, blandly handsome as a human prince, is a splendid monster, especially when the diffidence and charm start to peek through the rage. The awkward business about imprisonment turning into true love is handled smoothly. If you want a hot and haunting ‰ÛÏBeauty and the Beast,‰Ûù check out Jean Cocteau‰Ûªs version, or the fan-fiction-inspiring television show from the 1980s. This one is chaste and charming.

The only possible answer is Emma Thompson, whose Mrs. Potts is joined by other household objects with the voices (and, briefly, the faces) of movie stars. Stanley Tucci and Audra McDonald are the excitable harpsichord and the operatic wardrobe; Ewan McGregor and Ian McKellen are the suave candelabra and the anxious clock. Gugu Mbatha-Raw is the lissome feather duster. Young Nathan Mack is Chip, Mrs. Potts‰Ûªs son. Their singing and banter is so vivid and so natural that you almost take for granted that they appear to be mechanical objects clicking and whirling in physical space, sharing the frame with human characters.

To quote a lyric from one of the songs in ‰ÛÏBeauty and the Beast,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏthere may be something there that wasn‰Ûªt there before.‰Ûù The familiar elements are all in place, of course. It‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBeauty and the Beast,‰Ûù for goodness‰Ûª sake: a tale as old as time, a song as old as rhyme and all that. And there are inspired flights of nostalgia as well, visual evocations of the predigital glory of Busby Berkeley, Ray Harryhausen and other masters of fantastical craft.

This was by no means a foregone conclusion. The reanimation of beloved properties ‰ÛÓ to use the grim business nomenclature of Hollywood ‰ÛÓ often leads to hack work and zombie-ism, as old archetypes are shocked to life and arrayed in garish, synthetic modern effects. That might easily have happened here. Look (I mean: don‰Ûªt look) at the horrors that have been visited, in recent years, on Alice in Wonderland and Peter Pan and the Wizard of Oz. And even if Disney had done a more convincing upgrade, on the model of last year‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏJungle Book,‰Ûù a new ‰ÛÏBeauty‰Ûù could have offended fans of the 1991 animated feature simply by existing. That movie, a high point of the ‰Ûª80s and ‰Ûª90s Disney revival, is close to perfect. What singing teapot would dare to challenge Angela Lansbury?

There are a few moments ‰ÛÓ a climactic high-elevation fight scene that looks like every other climactic high-elevation fight scene; a chase through the forest involving wolves ‰ÛÓ where the digital seams show, and you‰Ûªre aware of the cold presence of lines of code behind the images. Most of the time, though, you are happily fooled. More than that: enchanted. The most dazzling visual flights are matched to the best of Howard Ashman and Alan Menken‰Ûªs songs. ‰ÛÏBe Our Guest‰Ûù in particular is a choreographic extravaganza that enfolds decades of Disney history (all the way back to ‰ÛÏSnow White‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏFantasia‰Ûù) in contemporary cinematic craft.

It‰Ûªs Disney! Which means there will also be a villain and a comical sidekick, who steal many scenes on the way to their comeuppance. That would be Gaston (Luke Evans), a narcissistic cabbage-stomping former soldier and his adoring pal LeFou (Josh Gad). Gaston is sweet on Belle, and his excitement at her unambiguous refusals makes him the film‰Ûªs avatar of nastiness. No redemption here. He goes from annoying to evil when he stirs up the anti-intellectualism and xenophobia of a populist mob to serve his own egomaniacal ends. The residents of the castle fight back because their humanity is at stake. It‰Ûªs just a fairy tale.

But this live-action/digital hybrid, directed by Bill Condon and starring Emma Watson and Dan Stevens in the title roles, is more than a flesh-and-blood (and prosthetic fur-and-horns) revival of the 26-year-old cartoon, and more than a dutiful trip back to the pop-culture fairy-tale well. Its classicism feels unforced and fresh. Its romance neither winks nor panders. It looks good, moves gracefully and leaves a clean and invigorating aftertaste. I almost didn‰Ûªt recognize the flavor: I think the name for it is joy.

Variations on the beauty-beast theme are hardly scarce. What else is ‰ÛÏTwilight‰Ûù (the last two movie installments were directed by Mr. Condon)? Or ‰ÛÏFifty Shades of Grey‰Ûù? ‰ÛÏBeauty and the Beast‰Ûù decisively removes itself from such company by insisting on the heroism and competence of its heroine, Belle, a bookish and ingenious young woman who lives with her father (Kevin Kline) in a picture-book French village.
‰ÛÏScary, huh?‰Ûù he taunts his host after one particularly intense rant. ‰ÛÏMakes you wonder what I‰Ûªm capable of.‰Ûù Indeed it does.

Dogged throughout by irate church representatives, Mr. Theroux exhibits an amiable diffidence that dilutes their threats, employing their own jargon (‰ÛÏHe seems enturbulated‰Ûù) to reveal them as more silly than sinister. The same cannot be said of the rather unnerving Mr. Rathbun, whose coaching of the actors seems to release a personality that‰Ûªs much missed and usually hidden.

Absent the heft and thoroughness of Alex Gibney‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGoing Clear,‰Ûù the hilarious precision of ‰ÛÏSouth Park‰Ûù or the deep-dive empathy of Leah Remini‰Ûªs current television exposÌ©, ‰ÛÏMy Scientology Movie‰Ûù relies on a shaggy, meandering charm. At times it plays like an extended skit on ‰ÛÏThe Daily Show‰Ûù; yet its disorder also makes its insights ‰ÛÓ like how strongly the church‰Ûªs training sessions resemble acting classes ‰ÛÓ feel refreshingly organic.

With a quirky rÌ©sumÌ© that includes two documentaries about the Westboro Baptist Church, the British journalist and filmmaker Louis Theroux has proved himself a seasoned chronicler of human eccentricity. His style can best be described as inoffensively resolute: He doesn‰Ûªt badger, but neither does he back off.

That chummy persistence serves him well in ‰ÛÏMy Scientology Movie,‰Ûù an offbeat attempt to illuminate the church‰Ûªs psychological grip on its members. Denied access or interviews, Mr. Theroux and his director, John Dower, hit on the idea of using actors to recreate the insider practices described by the whistle-blower and former church disciplinarian Marty Rathbun ‰ÛÓ most notably, the abuse of senior officials at the hands of Scientology‰Ûªs longtime leader, David Miscavige.

Ewan McNicol and Anna Sandilands, the directors, allow for sly humor amid scenes that are often quiet yet never timid. As the filmmakers draw surprising information from their subjects, your own emotions may shift when the person you thought you knew is shown in a new light. Those are perplexing moments. They are also the mark of a very fine film.

‰ÛÏUncertain‰Ûù looks at this remote outpost of 94 people and surveys its biggest problem ‰ÛÓ the nearby lake, which provides a livelihood for many of its citizens, is being choked by an invasive weed. It‰Ûªs an environmental catastrophe, and at times an allegory for these rural lives and the modern world. But it‰Ûªs also frequently just a side note to the three men whose interviews make up the bulk of the film.

They talk of being shot, and of shooting others; of trying to get drunk or find God; of following dreams and abandoning hope. While scenes of the lake and land are magnificent, there are repulsive sights and stories, too. Whether inspiring or upsetting, all feel authentic.

‰ÛÏThis is Mother Nature‰Ûªs favorite place; heaven and home, and a little bit of hell, too,‰Ûù one man says of Uncertain, Tex., the setting of a mesmerizing documentary that takes its title from the town‰Ûªs name. His statement may be true, and sadly, so may be his next: ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs heartbreaking to know the only place like this is going away.‰Ûù

Each of those three is endearing and exasperating: Wayne, a friendly hunter with a disturbing past; Henry, a wizened fisherman whose wife of more than 50 years has died; and Zach, a young man struggling to move away and manage his own troubles.

‰ÛÏSuntan‰Ûù opens as a dumpy, raccoon-eyed but generally agreeable middle-aged physician named Kostis (Makis Papadimitriou) arrives on the Greek island of Antiparos. It‰Ûªs a rainy winter, but a local rouÌ© promises that with the tourist season, opportunities for amorous activity will be overwhelming. Kostis seems unconcerned.

Then summer comes, and with it one spectacularly attractive young patient. Entranced, Kostis takes to the island‰Ûªs nude beaches to find the woman, Anna (Elli Tringou), and once he does, tries to ingratiate himself into her hedonistic band, which adopts him as both a quasi-mascot and an emotional punching bag.

At least until the disturbing finale, the director, Argyris Papadimitropoulos (who wrote the screenplay with Syllas Tzoumerkas), chronicles these misadventures with an effective detachment that‰Ûªs not entirely neutral. ‰ÛÏSuntan‰Ûù has an undertone of resigned misanthropy, but mostly, this isn‰Ûªt a movie about what the filmmaker thinks of the characters and their milieu. Replete with sometimes startling imagery (the removal of sand from an eye), ‰ÛÏSuntan‰Ûù captures a set of specific feelings: the exhilaration and embarrassment of falling, followed by the desperate denial that one has landed in a very bad place.

Like far too many erotically bedazzled men, regardless of age, size or shape, Kostis has pretty much no chill. He is overeager to please, and then to possess. When Anna, on a whim, indulges his desire, he is astonished by what seems to be his vindication. Then, of course, he freaks out. The group goes on an excursion without telling him; after Anna and her friends return, Kostis chastises her, then follows her around.

Liz and the Reverend share history, which Mr. Koolhoven slowly reveals in flashbacks that skew progressively more surreal. As one brutal chapter of her life slips into the next, God is invoked by name and mocked by example, and Liz learns many lessons, all horrible. She kills a pig (in an appalling, needlessly extended scene); loses her parents; loses her only friend; loses her tongue; loses herself; finds happiness but loses that, too. Like the heroine of a silent-era serial or a 1970s slasher flick, she takes a licking and just keeps on ticking.

As Liz runs from one end of this movie to the other, dodging and enduring peril, Mr. Koolhoven seems to be trying to say something about God and male dominance, misogyny and female resilience. Or maybe he loves Cormac McCarthy (or Lars von Trier). It‰Ûªs hard to know, because far too often in ‰ÛÏBrimstone‰Ûù you can‰Ûªt hear the signal for the falling blades, snapping necks, tumbling bodies and thundering gunfire. Given its bloodlust, ‰ÛÏBrimstone‰Ûù might have been better if Mr. Koolhoven had roughed up the story more (and not only his heroine) and gone for full-on exploitation. There‰Ûªs a nice, nasty little movie in here somewhere.

The carnage pushes you away (and wears you down), even as the genre, industrious cast, beautiful landscapes and stark, often striking visuals pull you in. Dakota Fanning plays Liz, a frontierswoman in America who lives on her family farm and serves as a midwife for the locals. A mute, Liz communicates with her husband and children with her expressive eyes and hand gestures, using her youngest as a conduit to the larger world. It looks like a sweet slice of heaven until the arrival of a new minister, a grim reaper with a jagged scar and bad vibe whom everyone calls the Reverend (Guy Pearce) but seems straight out of hell.

It doesn‰Ûªt take long before ‰ÛÏBrimstone‰Ûù makes good on the promise ‰ÛÓ and threat ‰ÛÓ implicit in its title. A western horror show with an unrelenting Old and New Testament kick, it opens on an ambiguous scene that soon gives way to a world of terrors, many involving children and parents. In one scene, a fetal hand juts out of the womb; in another, a man is gutted and his entrails are draped over his still-breathing body. It‰Ûªs a hard, ugly world, or so the Dutch writer and director Martin Koolhoven keeps insisting for 149 grueling minutes.

But this isn‰Ûªt a work of investigative journalism. Though it is gratifyingly informative ‰ÛÓ a visit to a nonprofit recycling depot in Brooklyn is as eye-opening as a great school field trip ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏCanners‰Ûù is a testament to its director‰Ûªs indefatigable humanism, and to the human beings who feed it. The movie follows the money, a nickel at a time, and discovers something far more valuable.

Mr. Kirchheimer doesn‰Ûªt appear on camera, but he is a presence in the film all the same. It is clear that the can collectors trust him, which means that, through the wonderful alchemy of cinema, it feels as if they trust you. And that trust, in turn, delivers a powerful ethical message about what it means to live in a city, and how each of us can choose to acknowledge or ignore our fellow citizens.

Manfred Kirchheimer, born in Germany in 1931, is an indispensable New York filmmaker, a noticer and a listener without peer. His best-known work is probably ‰ÛÏStations of the Elevated,‰Ûù a short documentary from 1981 that is a wordless, jazzy, poetic hymn to public transportation, graffiti and the battered glory of a rough time in the city‰Ûªs history. Though his new feature, ‰ÛÏCanners,‰Ûù takes place in the present, a relatively safer and more prosperous era, it demonstrates that New York remains, in several senses, a tough place.

The film consists of interviews with about a dozen people who scavenge bottles and cans from garbage bins and recycling piles, collecting a nickel for each one at supermarkets and redemption centers. There are easier ways to make money. A shopping cart loaded with overstuffed bags represents a full day‰Ûªs work and a payout of $30 or $40. And the stories Mr. Kirchheimer‰Ûªs subjects tell about themselves are full of hardship and heartbreak. They are chronicles of drug addiction, unemployment, mental illness, incarceration and homelessness. But the people telling them are too busy and too candid for self-pity. You are struck by their openness, their optimism and their patience.

‰ÛÏCanners‰Ûù offers some practical lessons as well, and some fine examples of informal civic cooperation. Doormen and superintendents who are treated with respect respond with kindness. The canners work alone or with partners, and generally share territory without conflict. There are intimations of a grimmer side to the work, stories of harassment by the police and exploitation by unseen entrepreneurs who reap profits from the labor of scared and defenseless immigrants.

It was beauty that killed the beast, or so it has been repeatedly claimed. In 1933 it was Fay Wray‰Ûªs scantily clad beauty who took the rap for bringing Kong down off the top of the Empire State Building. (Fighter planes with machines guns helped.) By 1976, the beauty-beast relationship had grown rather more complicated, and Jessica Lange was weepily begging Kong to hold onto her. In the 2005 redo it was Naomi Watts‰Ûªs turn to shed tears for him. In ‰ÛÏKong: Skull Island,‰Ûù the big guy has a new look and a new gal pal, Mason Weaver (Brie Larson), who‰Ûªs somewhat feistier and certainly more sensibly dressed than her predecessors. She points and she shoots, and not just her camera.

If all goes according to corporate plan, Kong will be slugging it out with Godzilla soon enough. That doubtless excites studio executives and some fans, but the promise of a return engagement drains much of the pathos from Kong. In many ways ‰ÛÏSkull Island‰Ûù looks and plays like its antecedents, despite the cosmetic tweaks, digital effects and attempts at inclusive casting. Like those earlier films, it too asks the critical question in many such tales ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏMirror, mirror on the wall, who‰Ûªs the most monstrous of them all?‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ through an ape who, because he‰Ûªs a close relative, turns our gaze back on ourselves. Kong is the beast we know, the beast we deny, the beast we fear, the beast we kill.

Here, though, Kong is no longer the beast we love, the tragic captor-swain who, if he didn‰Ûªt always win the affections of his prisoners, achieved immortality by seducing viewers. ‰ÛÏSkull Island‰Ûù is adept at goosing you; it deploys action-movie feints and horror-film frights capably amid its clichÌ©s and deaths. Every so often it also pauses and allows Kong and Mason to move you. As each recognizes the other, they bridge the divide, but perhaps because their relationship is more empathetic than romantic, these encounters don‰Ûªt have the resonance they should. Alas, beauty no longer has her beast, the beast no longer has his beauty and this darkness has no heart even if it will have a sequel.

‰ÛÏSkull Island‰Ûù pretty much exhumes the same story conceived for the 1933 classic. This time, the adventurers include a group of government-backed scientists run by Bill Randa (John Goodman), who has his glinting eyes on a mysterious, seemingly unexplored island. Mysteries were made for solving, and this island, Randa reasons, may contain all manner of wonders, or perhaps something beyond human imagining. So, with a military unit led by Lt. Col. Preston Packard (Samuel L. Jackson), the scientists ship out, accompanied by Mason, a no-nonsense war photographer who‰Ûªs soon trading barbs and looks with the world‰Ûªs prettiest mercenary, James Conrad (Tom Hiddleston).

Over the years, critics have pushed and pulled at ‰ÛÏKing Kong,‰Ûù denouncing its representation of the islanders (played by black actors in the 1933 film) and reading it metaphorically through black masculinity and white femininity. Later Kong movies have tried to sidestep criticism by changing the representation of the islanders while leaving beauty and the beast intact. Yet even as ‰ÛÏSkull Island‰Ûù avoids some stereotypes, it embraces others, partly through a struggle that pits a pathological black character against a pair of white saviors. Kong, meanwhile, at times feels sidelined, brought out every so often to wreak havoc and briefly exchange soulful looks with Mason.

‰ÛÏSkull Island‰Ûù has momentum, polish and behemoths that slither and thunder. The sets and creature designs are often beautifully filigreed, but the larger picture remains murky. Backed by government and guns, the scientists prove to be colonialists by another name, an idea that the filmmakers bat around a bit, including in allusions to Joseph Conrad‰Ûªs novella ‰ÛÏHeart of Darkness.‰Ûù These references pad ‰ÛÏSkull Island,‰Ûù giving audiences (and critics) something to chew on and help explain the repeated, near-fetishistic nods to ‰ÛÏApocalypse Now,‰Ûù Francis Ford Coppola‰Ûªs 1979 Vietnam-era retelling of the Conrad novel: the fireball sun, the military helicopters in formation and even a napalm attack.

The filmmakers fold a lot of moody detail into the introductions, including real locations and the fog of war: The story takes place in 1973 and the movie was primarily shot in Vietnam. (It was directed by Jordan Vogt-Roberts from a script by Dan Gilroy, Max Borenstein and Derek Connolly.) If the sweat, bantering grunts and teeming bars feel borrowed from innumerable other movies, they are also mostly on hand to get the story up and the characters running, which happens once the travelers pierce the thick clouds surrounding Skull Island. There, they meet the enemy and the enemy is ‰ÛÓ surprise ‰ÛÓ us, although there are plenty of digital terrors red in tooth and claw.

You can‰Ûªt keep a good monster down, especially in Hollywood. After years in storage, the mighty ape with the big teeth and the thing for pale blondes has been dusted off and digitally turbocharged for ‰ÛÏKong: Skull Island.‰Ûù Once again, a lot of the noise and action involve guns, monsters and crashing jungle chases, but the most promising moments involve King Kong and the really little lady he unexpectedly meets. In the past, their brief encounter made for some strange moments, none weirder than in the original 1933 film when Kong pauses while undressing his human doll to smell his fingers.

If that weren‰Ûªt enough, there‰Ûªs also a Dennis Hopper-like character right out of ‰ÛÏApocalypse Now,‰Ûù a loopy, grizzled survivor named Hank Marlow who is played by John C. Reilly in charming crazy mode (the narrator in ‰ÛÏHeart of Darkness is also a Marlow). Marlow pops up after Kong makes his star entrance swatting down helicopters and scattering survivors. Far larger than his forebears, Kong looks as big as a mountain here. Supersizing is a default mode of the contemporary blockbuster, but in this case a pumped-up Kong may have something to do with his role in an evolving studio franchise featuring monsters (a.k.a. MonsterVerse) that kicked off with the 2014 ‰ÛÏGodzilla.‰Ûù

Kristen Stewart, who plays Maureen, has something in common with other stars of Mr. Assayas‰Ûªs films, notably Maggie Cheung in ‰ÛÏIrma Vep‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏClean‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a quality of self-enclosed detachment that becomes its own peculiar form of intensity. She possesses an uncanny ability to turn her natural charisma into diffidence. You can‰Ûªt take your eyes off her, even as she seems to be making every effort to deflect your attention, to obscure her radiance, to disappear onscreen.

Maureen herself sometimes seems more spectral than physical, even as her bodily presence, slipping in and out of rooms and clothes that don‰Ûªt belong to her, is the film‰Ûªs singular constant and the source of its curious emotional power. She is in limbo, caught between worlds, suffering from the disorientation that so often accompanies mourning. Her untethering from reality is echoed in the film‰Ûªs matter-of-fact departure from realism, and her inertia is the expression of an overwhelming sorrow. ‰ÛÏPersonal Shopper‰Ûù is sleek and spooky, seductive and suspenseful. It flirts with silliness, as ghost stories do. And also with heartbreak.

Maureen, who works as a personal shopper for a spoiled celebrity named Kyra, certainly brushes up against glamour, and occasionally tries on a piece of Kyra‰Ûªs borrowed couture. But she dwells mostly in a benumbed, stressed-out limbo, in frenzied motion from one nowhere to the next. Her human connections are often mediated by screens. She video-chats with her boyfriend, a tech consultant on assignment in Oman. She exchanges feverish texts with a stranger on a train from Paris to London and back. When asked what she‰Ûªs doing in Paris, Maureen answers, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm waiting.‰Ûù

In ‰ÛÏClouds of Sils Maria,‰Ûù Mr. Assayas‰Ûªs previous film, Ms. Stewart‰Ûªs character, another celebrity assistant, did vanish. You might say she ghosted. This time she summons ghosts, thanks to a plot contrivance that makes the most of Ms. Stewart‰Ûªs elusive magnetism. Maureen‰Ûªs lost brother is not the only one: Other ectoplasmic apparitions make themselves known, and without quite preparing you for it, ‰ÛÏPersonal Shopper‰Ûù becomes a sneakily effective horror film, complete with a gruesome murder and Hitchcockian flourishes of menace and misdirection.

Like many other characters in the films of Olivier Assayas, Maureen, a young American woman living in France, belongs to a relatively privileged slice of the international nomad class. The old-fashioned term ‰ÛÏjet set,‰Ûù with its connotations of glamorous indolence, doesn‰Ûªt quite fit. Mr. Assayas‰Ûªs world is populated by figures in perpetual transit: actors, corporate executives, terrorists. Their identities have been dissolved by perpetual displacement. We remember their faces (which are often the faces of movie stars), even if we‰Ûªre not quite sure who they are.

What she‰Ûªs waiting for is a sign from her twin brother, Lewis, whose recent death partly explains his sister‰Ûªs dazed, blunted affect. If ‰ÛÏPersonal Shopper,‰Ûù Mr. Assayas‰Ûªs new movie, is a supernatural thriller and an unnerving inquiry into the drift and mystery of modern life, it is also a raw and smoldering study in grief.

Some viewers may balk at Mr. Assayas‰Ûªs supernatural literalism. Surely he‰Ûªs too subtle and cerebral a filmmaker for things that go bump in the night. But the hauntedness of contemporary existence ‰ÛÓ the sense that ordinary experiences of work, sex and travel unfold within invisible networks in response to unseen forces ‰ÛÓ is a theme he often revisits. His camera moves stealthily, hovering at shoulder level like a stalker or a spy, silently observing people who believe themselves to be alone. The viewer is less a sharer of Maureen‰Ûªs solitude than an intruder, and the cool allure of ‰ÛÏPersonal Shopper‰Ûù is accompanied by a not-unpleasant tingle of voyeuristic shame.

That repulsion is soon replaced by a craving that will drive Justine closer to her sister and fellow student (Ella Rumpf, terrific) and further from her classmates. Her transformation suffuses the film with animalistic energy ‰ÛÓ like a cat, she chews on her hair, then vomits it up ‰ÛÓ and her isolation produces a melancholy that permeates even her erotic encounters, where the connection between sex and sustenance is presented with nerve-twanging literalness.

Like Jorge Michel Grau‰Ûªs social-decay fable, ‰ÛÏWe Are What We Are,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏRaw‰Ûù is an astonishingly bold debut feature that embeds cannibalism in a framework of environmental chaos and familial dysfunction. There‰Ûªs no love here, and no comfort; yet the movie‰Ûªs genius is to make us feel for Justine. Ultimately, she‰Ûªs just a scared teenager with the world‰Ûªs worst eating disorder.

‰ÛÏRaw,‰Ûù Julia Ducournau‰Ûªs jangly opera of sexual and dietary awakening, is an exceptionally classy-looking movie about deeply horrifying behavior. Infusing each scene with a cold, unwelcoming beauty, the Belgian cinematographer Ruben Impens makes his camera complicit in the trashy goings-on. Sneaking beneath bedsheets and sliding over young flesh, his lens takes us places we may not want to go.

Unfolding during rush week in a nightmarish veterinary school, where freshmen are relentlessly hazed, and every night is a bacchanal, the movie clings nervously to the virginal Justine (Garance Marillier). A jumpy faun in a concrete jungle, Justine is a legacy student and lifelong vegetarian. So when a hazing ritual requires her to swallow raw offal, the angry crimson rash that flares on her body seems a physical manifestation of her extreme disgust.
‰ÛÏThe Ottoman Lieutenant‰Ûù is an overwrought nurse romance merged with a history lesson, a combination that is hard to take as seriously as the film wants to be taken.

The doctor whose plea caught Lillie‰Ûªs attention, Jude (Josh Hartnett), is surprised when she shows up at the mission, but not only welcomes her, he also quickly develops a romantic interest in her. Unfortunately for him, he is not the title character. That honor goes to Ismail (Michiel Huisman), the military officer who was Lillie‰Ûªs reluctant escort to the remote site. He and Lillie clash at first, so you know they‰Ûªll soon be hot and heavy for each other, a particular problem in this time and place because he is a Muslim, she a Christian.

Hera Hilmar is Lillie, a young nurse in Philadelphia who hears a fund-raising presentation about a medical mission in a far-off land and makes a quixotic decision to go there. It‰Ûªs 1914, and the mission is in Van, part of the Ottoman Empire (now eastern Turkey), a place where complex political, religious and ethnic tensions are coming to a boil at the dawn of World War I.

Forbidden love! Two men fighting over a woman! Panoramic horse rides though golden meadows while danger lurks! The film, written by Jeff Stockwell and directed by Joseph Ruben, has all the elements of a type of female fantasy that has seemed out of step since the 1950s. It aims to be an epic in the ‰ÛÏDoctor Zhivago‰Ûù mold, but somehow the crashing score and picture-postcard images only diminish the world-shaking events swirling around this romantic triangle.

Acting prowess is in vast abundance in the moody romance ‰ÛÏThe Other Half.‰Ûù Tatiana Maslany (the dazzling star of ‰ÛÏOrphan Black‰Ûù) plays Emily, a bipolar painter and teacher; Tom Cullen (Lord Gillingham on ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey‰Ûù) portrays Nickie, a brooding cabdriver and musician whose brother vanished almost five years ago. When these two meet, passionate sparks fly, but not without consequences.

But he has difficulty in tying up the loose ends of his story, which takes an abrupt melodramatic turn before concluding. Mostly he appears to savor the time spent with such attractive and talented performers. And that may be enough for many viewers as well.

The haunted Nickie (on his arm he has a tattoo of the date his sibling went missing) is a British expatriate in the United States, with a short fuse and a tendency toward violence. His estrangement from his parents doesn‰Ûªt help. As for Emily, her erratic behavior has made her father (Henry Czerny) pessimistic about the odds of her ever maintaining a long-term relationship. When the lovebirds edge closer to matrimony, he becomes a major obstacle to their future happiness.

Joey Klein, the director and screenwriter, making his feature debut, draws rich dynamics from the relationship, which tempers Nickie‰Ûªs rage and forces Emily to manage her mood swings better. Mr. Klein is aided inestimably by his cinematographer, Bobby Shore, who has a gift for dark, voluptuous compositions and impressionistic flourishes. And Mr. Klein is well served by his actors, who exude conviction, charisma and palpable ardor.

An unexpected legacy touches off reminders of his student days, his first love, his most significant friendship. All of these seem far away from the life he has come to live, as a tidy, proper and emotionally detached camera shop owner, mostly in the company of his ex-wife (Harriet Walter) and daughter (Michelle Dockery). We suspect there are sad reasons for this; we soon learn they are worse than sad, and Tony will have to face his part in them.

Freya Mavor and Charlotte Rampling are hauntingly enigmatic and ravishing as his former love, young and old, and Joe Alwyn as the ex-friend is charismatically cerebral. Directed by Ritesh Batra from a screenplay by Nick Payne, the film maintains intrigue and emotional magnetism as its mystery unfolds. Unfortunately, it goes wobbly in the last quarter, as Tony‰Ûªs refusal to face up to his past actions begins to look less willful and more stupid. The film then totters into a redemptive sentimentality that wouldn‰Ûªt even play if it were made to seem more earned.

Adapted from a brief but emotionally potent 2011 novel by Julian Barnes, ‰ÛÏThe Sense of an Ending‰Ûù initially honors its source material by taking clever, inventive cinematic liberties with it. The book, a first-person account of its aged protagonist, Tony Webster, has a bifurcated structure: ‰ÛÏhow I remembered these events‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏwhat really happened.‰Ûù Flashbacks arrive in blink-and-you-miss-them bursts that then expand to explain the significance of a look or a gesture; memory becomes a form of time travel, putting Tony (Jim Broadbent) inside his own recollections, taking the place of his young self.

Gardens, of course, must be cultivated, and thus they are rich allegorical territory for storytellers of all sorts. Simon Aboud, the writer and director here, works some obvious parallels as he tells the story of a timid young woman, her cranky old neighbor and the garden that separates them, but enjoyable performances keep the tale from becoming too heavy-handed.
With spring imminent, backyard putterers are turning their thoughts to the garden, which makes ‰ÛÏThis Beautiful Fantastic,‰Ûù a charming tale about one, all that much sweeter.

You know how this kind of story goes ‰ÛÓ Bella and Alfie, the polar opposites, warm to each other. Through gardening, he helps her come out of her shell and make progress toward her goal of writing children‰Ûªs books. At the same time, she helps him shed some of his bitterness. It‰Ûªs nicely played, with Jeremy Irvine of ‰ÛÏWar Horse‰Ûù adding a quirky touch as a patron at the library where Bella works who is as imaginative and cloistered as she is.

Bella (Jessica Brown Findlay, who played Sybil Crawley in ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey‰Ûù) is, we‰Ûªre told in narration early on, ‰ÛÏthe oddest of oddballs,‰Ûù a woman with an obsessive-compulsive touch inside her small home but complete disregard for yard maintenance. Her crotchety neighbor, Alfie (the always entertaining Tom Wilkinson), growls at her about the ‰ÛÏunmitigated eco-apocalypse‰Ûù that used to be a garden, but then again, he growls at everyone, including Vernon (Andrew Scott), the young man who prepares his meals.

In the film, a group of psychiatric patients becomes stranded in the countryside after a bus breaks down. The patients take up residence in a farmhouse, forming a microcosmic civilization that soon falls prey to varied discontents. The opening credits, a series of still photos in which a woman in sunglasses strikes wacky poses while text announces the soundtrack, may lead you to expect hippie whimsy of the worst sort. But the movie, shot mostly in crisp, sometimes smoky black and white, is far better, a quirky but purposeful grafting of Mack Sennett to the French New Wave.

In late 1964, Tom White, an American living in Paris, encountered the avant-garde troupe the Living Theater, also from the United States. While the group was waiting for its leaders, Julian Beck and Judith Malina, to return from the States (they were serving brief prison terms related to back taxes; the long story was recounted in The New York Times last year), the members paired up with Mr. White to make a film. That loose-narrative movie, ‰ÛÏWho‰Ûªs Crazy?,‰Ûù had its New York premiere last year and is screening here again this week.

Yet it‰Ûªs the soundtrack that has the staying power. Ornette Coleman, with the bassist David Izenzon and the drummer Charles Moffett, improvised much of its bracing free jazz, which isn‰Ûªt always conventionally effective ‰ÛÏmovie music.‰Ûù But it‰Ûªs always something special, and during the second set of opening credits (another long story), Coleman is joined by Marianne Faithfull, singing the skewed ballad ‰ÛÏSilence.‰Ûù Far out, as they used to say in the ‰Ûª60s.

But marry, it seems, they must. Shashank Khaitan builds his romantic comedy ‰ÛÏBadrinath Ki Dulhania‰Ûù (‰ÛÏBadrinath‰Ûªs Bride‰Ûù) around a self-possessed heroine ‰ÛÓ Vaidehi (Alia Bhatt), whose dreams may be ill-defined but don‰Ûªt necessarily include marriage.

Vaidehi is up against a lot: The first scenes of ‰ÛÏBadrinath‰Ûù remind us comically, but baldly, that baby boys are still considered assets while girls are liabilities. (Instead of the usual note that no animals were hurt during its filming, this movie starts with a disclaimer about the 1961 Dowry Prohibition Act.)

Recent Bollywood movies have tried out, hesitantly and conservatively, versions of the Modern Woman: Heroines can have careers; they can live alone in the big city; they can even (if very rarely) have sex before marriage.

Complications ensue, including a second-act detour to Singapore, where Vaidehi is studying to become an air hostess. (This is the best career Mr. Khaitan could dream up for his heroine?) Badrinath turns up in Singapore, too, and it‰Ûªs on this non-Indian ground that the movie hammers home its point: A real man is one who respects women, or in his case, learns to. (And, yes, it‰Ûªs sad that the movie‰Ûªs simple moral has currency in present-day America as well as in India.)

If ‰ÛÏBadrinath‰Ûù ends up being less about female empowerment than about schooling gents on a cardinal rule, its pop comes from Ms. Bhatt. Hindi cinema conventions and Mr. Khaitan‰Ûªs script may constrict Vaidehi‰Ûªs options, but Ms. Bhatt cannot be contained. Without ever falling into the clichÌ©s of spunky Bollywood heroine, she effortlessly embodies that admirable thing: a modern woman.

Badrinath (Varun Dhawan), the fellow who falls for Vaidehi ‰ÛÓ at a wedding, of course ‰ÛÓ comes from a well-to-do family in Jhansi, Uttar Pradesh, that practically screams patriarchy. (His mother and sister-in-law are mainly silent; his father is a scowling tyrant with a sadistic streak.) Badrinath may be a notch or two above Vaidehi socially, but as she points out to him, he‰Ûªs not her equal: She‰Ûªs smart and ambitious; he‰Ûªs neither. He is, though, sweet and persistent. Reader, she agrees to marry him.

The title character (Anton von Lucke), seen in flashback, is a handsome German in his 20s who died in the trenches and is memorialized throughout the movie. You feel the anguish of his parents, Hans and Magda Hoffmeister, a doctor and his wife in Quedlinburg, Germany, and his depressed fiancÌ©e, Anna (Paula Beer), who lives with them. Another mourner, unknown to them, is his French friend Adrien (Pierre Niney). A willowy mustached French soldier with doe eyes and a timid manner who traveled from Paris to Germany, this mysterious stranger is first spotted by Anna while laying flowers at Frantz‰Ûªs grave.

‰ÛÏFrantz‰Ûù takes pains to show both sides‰Ûª lingering hostility after a devastating and (the movie implies) senseless war. In a powerful antiwar diatribe, Hans scolds a collegial gathering of fathers who lost their sons in battle. ‰ÛÏWho killed your boys? Who sent them to the front?‰Ûù he asks accusingly. ‰ÛÏWe did: their fathers. We are responsible.‰Ûù

In its second and weaker half, the film becomes a modernist fable, a kind of multiple-choice question that, in the light of today‰Ûªs ambiguous moral climate rife with terms like truthiness, alternative facts and fake news, throws the past into shadowy half-light.

Can carefully constructed lies heal the emotional wounds of war? That unsettling question goes to the heart of ‰ÛÏFrantz,‰Ûù FranÌ_ois Ozon‰Ûªs sleek, somber adaptation of Ernst Lubitsch‰Ûªs 1932 antiwar film, ‰ÛÏBroken Lullaby,‰Ûù set in Germany and France in the aftermath of World War I.

In its early scenes, ‰ÛÏFrantz‰Ûù sustains the mood of a solemn, romantic period piece whose dignified melancholy is deepened by Philippe Rombi‰Ûªs Mahler-influenced soundtrack, sighing discreetly in the background. At crucial moments, this mostly black-and-white film breaks into color. The first blush occurs when Adrien mentions Frantz‰Ûªs favorite canvas, a Manet painting of a man with his head thrown back. When that work is finally shown, it depicts a young man‰Ûªs suicide. By the time Adrien returns to Paris, he and Anna have developed a deep unvoiced attraction.

For an antiwar film, ‰ÛÏFrantz‰Ûù is low-key. It doesn‰Ûªt rub your face in gore or stir your adrenaline; there are no battle scenes, and only fleeting images of ruined cities and wounded soldiers; and a mood of bitterness, despair and exhaustion prevails. The movie even goes out of its way to evoke the cultural similarity of two warring nations, geographical neighbors, who appreciated the same music and art. Parallel scenes show Germans and Frenchmen bellowing patriotic anthems even after the Armistice.

‰ÛÏFrantz‰Ûù soon makes a sharp departure from ‰ÛÏBroken Lullaby,‰Ûù with Anna assuming center stage, and the movie taking on the tone of an Alfred Hitchcock mystery. After one of her letters to Adrien is returned without a forwarding address, she boards a train to Paris, hoping to find him. As if shedding a skin, the film shucks off its elegiac, white-gloved manners to explore a slippery realm of secrets, lies and moral uncertainty that eventually leads her to consult a priest for advice on how to proceed. The scene poses profound questions about honesty and the possibility for redemption if the truth is withheld.
In the language of T. S. Eliot, ‰ÛÏHumankind cannot bear very much reality.‰Ûù That might be amended, substituting ‰ÛÏthe truth‰Ûù for reality.
