Anna is so touched by Adrien that she brings him home to meet the Hoffmeisters, but Hans resists accepting him. ‰ÛÏEvery Frenchman is my son‰Ûªs murderer,‰Ûù he declares, then softens when Adrien tells him about his and Frantz‰Ûªs long walks and museum visits, their shared pacifism and tastes in music and poetry. Hans relents, and as the days pass, Adrien becomes a surrogate son whose recollections bring the couple consolation.

As they converse, Adrien recalls a close friendship that began in Paris before the war, in which the two often visited the Louvre. Both played the violin, and this being an Ozon film, where the possibility of romantic attraction is always in the air, the movie leads you to wonder if they were lovers.

I won‰Ûªt reveal the lie that propels the story except to say that it‰Ûªs a whopper: a big one invented to comfort the aggrieved at a moment when the Great War seemed to have undermined the sanity of a world thrown into chaos by mass slaughter.

The Japanese actor Hiroshi Abe has one of the great hangdog faces in cinema today. At least that‰Ûªs the case in ‰ÛÏAfter the Storm,‰Ûù a new film from the writer-director Hirokazu Kore-eda. Tall and lean, Mr. Abe has handsome features ‰ÛÓ floppy dark hair across his forehead, prominent cheekbones and a long jaw line. But here, playing Ryota Shinoda, a onetime literary sensation fallen on hard times professionally and personally, he also has lines around and bags under his eyes, a perpetual five o‰Ûªclock shadow and a downcast mouth. He looks as if he could be trouble.

Mr. Kore-eda, whose most noteworthy family dramas include ‰ÛÏStill Walking‰Ûù (2009) and ‰ÛÏLike Father, Like Son‰Ûù (2014), works in a quiet cinematic register, and the slightest error in tone could upend the whole enterprise. Slow-paced, sad, rueful and sometimes warmly funny, ‰ÛÏAfter the Storm‰Ûù is one of his sturdiest, and most sensitive, constructions. ‰ÛÏI really just can‰Ûªt understand how things turned out like this,‰Ûù one character says while sitting out the storm.

As Ryota scrambles to somehow get ahead, Kyoko seems befuddled by her own resentments and prospects for the future. Meanwhile, the young Shingo bristles at a potential stepfather who offers baseball coaching along the lines of ‰ÛÏTo be the hero, you have to get a hit‰Ûù even though the situation under consideration calls for drawing a walk. At one point, Ryota, Yoshiko, Kyoko and Shingo all have to pull together during an overnight typhoon that strands them in Yoshiko‰Ûªs apartment, which is cozy and conspicuously lacking in privacy.

As it happens, he is trouble mostly for himself, although he manages to irritate his ex-wife, Kyoko (Yoko Maki), because of his inability to pay child support for their son, Shingo (Taiyo Yoshizawa), and frustrate his sister (Satomi Kobayashi), whom he hits up for money with grim regularity. Ryota, having never followed up on his award-winning first novel, now works as a private detective. (The novel is another thing his sister is annoyed about; ‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt you dare write about us again,‰Ûù she snaps at one point.) It‰Ûªs a gig that gives him many opportunities to alter the calibration of his moral compass ‰ÛÓ in one scene he tries to talk a subject of an investigation into buying the evidence he‰Ûªs gathered against her. He also spies on his ex-wife, and is less than thrilled to learn that her unctuous new boyfriend has bought Shingo a snazzy baseball mitt.

As perplexed as they are about how they got into such a mess, the characters are nonetheless obliged to move forward as some kind of family, and the story patiently brings them closer to a reconciliation with that fact. Beautifully acted by a great cast (particularly Mr. Abe, who can make a sonata of frustration out of burrowing into a stale frozen treat with a spoon), ‰ÛÏAfter the Storm‰Ûù brings this intimate struggle to moving life. It‰Ûªs a film that sticks with you.

Ryota‰Ûªs aging mother, Yoshiko (Kirin Kiki), loves him unconditionally, though, and she doesn‰Ûªt give him a hard time when she walks in after he‰Ûªs clearly been rifling through her apartment, trying to find a family heirloom to pawn. She lives alone (the family‰Ûªs patriarch has died, presumably recently) in a Tokyo apartment complex far removed from the bustling city we are accustomed to seeing in Japanese films, or films about Japan. The neighborhood isn‰Ûªt showy, but it‰Ûªs a pleasant, relatively tree-lined environment, and its older residents get together in informal groups to listen to and discuss Beethoven. Nevertheless, Yoshiko is a little preoccupied with what she sees as the approaching end of her life.

The ‰ÛÏAnimal Farm‰Ûù meets ‰ÛÏTexas Chainsaw Massacre‰Ûù climax yields some clever twists. But ‰ÛÏThe Belko Experiment‰Ûù made me think that maybe it‰Ûªs time to stop trying to solve the trolley problem (that is, do you sacrifice one life to save five workers from being killed by a runaway train?) and start worrying about the people who invent such conundrums.

Directed by Greg McLean (whose 2005 film, ‰ÛÏWolf Creek,‰Ûù had a similar morbid interest in bullying its audience) from a script by James Gunn (currently relegated to delighting adolescents of all ages with the ‰ÛÏGuardians of the Galaxy‰Ûù franchise), the movie might have been better served by a director not hellbent on rubbing pretty much every head wound in the viewer‰Ûªs face. Mr. McLean, perhaps determined to leave no clichÌ© unturned, also wallows in the cheap and hackneyed irony of choreographed slaughter accompanied by Dvorak and Tchaikovsky.

‰ÛÏThe Belko Experiment‰Ûù is a grisly, sick-making exercise in sadism that tries to camouflage its base venality in a thought-experiment plot. The movie opens on an unusual day at the Colombian outpost of the Belko Corporation: Heavily armed security guards and bomb-sniffing dogs monitor the gates, and send certain staff members back home.

Shortly after the workday starts, an announcement over the P.A. instructs the staff to kill two people in the next half-hour ‰ÛÓ or else more will die at the command of an unseen force who can kill with the flick of a switch. Then metal shutters and walls seal off the building, and the 80 nervous employees realize this isn‰Ûªt a practical joke but rather a kill-or-be-killed game. The potheads at the bottom of the corporate ladder start screwing things up for everybody, while upper management (Tony Goldwyn, abetted by some twisted minions) takes the homicidal initiative.

A tubby lunatic, brandishing a firearm, is heading for your front door. Do you and your family A) run as far and as fast as you can, or B) stand and watch him shuffle interminably toward you? If you‰Ûªre Jesse (Ethan Embry), a tortured artist, option B seems the logical choice; this is a man so lacking in common sense that, after moving into a creepy country home where two people have already died, he doesn‰Ûªt even bother to change the locks.

To enjoy ‰ÛÏThe Devil‰Ûªs Candy,‰Ûù then, one must tolerate slapdash writing (by the director, Sean Byrne) and profoundly irritating adult behavior. Yet Mr. Byrne ‰ÛÓ relying almost entirely on a doom-metal soundtrack, game performers and a grungy palette of oily browns and moldy greens ‰ÛÓ somehow whips his ingredients into an improbably taut man-versus-Satan showdown. In this, he‰Ûªs helped immeasurably by Simon Chapman, a cinematographer who knows where to park his camera and when to hold it steady.

The result is a commonplace sophomore feature that looks pretty great (in a just-crawled-out-of-the-swamp way) and sounds like the headache from hell. As Jesse‰Ûªs new home directs its malevolent energy into his brain and onto his increasingly violent canvases, its psychotic former resident (Pruitt Taylor Vince) becomes obsessed with Jesse‰Ûªs teenage daughter (Kiara Glasco). Watch closely: You may never get another chance to learn how to free yourself from a duct-tape swaddle.
‰ÛÏYou like it, it‰Ûªs fun?‰Ûù
‰ÛÏIs it?‰Ûù asks his co-star Lindsay Burdge as an actress and love interest named Lindsay.

Some movies about making movies (Truffaut‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDay for Night,‰Ûù for one) are charming. The self-references here, while intriguing, approach a comic navel-gaze. ‰ÛÏActor Martinez‰Ûù has a saving grace, however: Ms. Burdge (‰ÛÏLace Crater,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Midnight Swim‰Ûù), radiating her customary charisma. ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs an actress,‰Ûù says a friend of Arthur about a character in a dream he had. ‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs not a bird. She‰Ûªs not ‰ÛÓ she‰Ûªs not real.‰Ûù Not Ms. Burdge. She‰Ûªs an actress, and very real.

Acting may be his first love, but it‰Ûªs no picnic, given his directors‰Ûª demands. They want Arthur to recall his divorce and cry on camera, insisting he not ‰ÛÏphone it in.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThese guys are really blurring all the lines,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏSo my brain is all scrambled.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏI do.‰Ûù

Arthur seems to regret those words as ‰ÛÏActor Martinez‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ about the making of a loose semidocumentary focused on the title character ‰ÛÓ progresses. A computer repairman by day, Arthur hires two directors (yes, Mr. Ott and Mr. Silver) for a genre movie with him in the lead, but they have other ideas, like recording his life and expecting him to deliver vivid emotion. Soon the opaque, somewhat hapless Arthur is striving with his collaborators to arrive at their docudrama‰Ûªs narrative.
‰ÛÏActing is weird,‰Ûù says the actor Arthur Martinez, playing an actor named Arthur, in Mike Ott and Nathan Silver‰Ûªs metanovelty ‰ÛÏActor Martinez.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏUh huh. Very strange.‰Ûù

To his critics, Mr. Ackman was a wealthy investor manipulating the market to his advantage. But he achieved partial vindication in July. In a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission after an investigation, Herbalife agreed to pay $200 million in consumer relief and restructure its practices.

Mr. Ackman‰Ûªs hedge fund, Pershing Capital Management, went short against Herbalife, betting $1 billion against its stock. He publicly maintained that the company‰Ûªs business model was a pyramid scheme, and that his efforts were a moral quest to expose fraud that had taken a particular toll on Latino consumers. (He pledged to donate his personal profits. Mr. Ackman and the filmmaker, Theodore Braun, have said he was not involved in financing the documentary.)
Herbalife did not participate in this decidedly partisan film, although its departing chief executive, Michael O. Johnson, is among the representatives seen in footage drawn from other sources.

The topic of ‰ÛÏBetting on Zero‰Ûù might initially seem better suited to the business pages. The film chronicles the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman‰Ûªs crusade against Herbalife, a nutritional-products company that sells its goods through a chain of civilian distributors.

Even without an upbeat ending, though, ‰ÛÏBetting on Zero‰Ûù would be persuasive advocacy. Mr. Ackman comes across as sincere in his outrage and cogent in his presentations. Even more valuable is the opportunity to meet and learn about Herbalife‰Ûªs purported victims, from Queens to Chicago to Oklahoma.

Casey‰Ûªs dad, Wayne, an abusive alcoholic and corrupt sheriff (a bristling Bill Paxton, in one of his final film roles), has ties to drug runners. When Jonas overhears Wayne killing some of his criminal acquaintances, he plots an escape for Casey from her domestic hell. He steals a bag of drug money from Wayne, and soon the young couple, with dreams of finding freedom by the ocean, are hounded by the sheriff and his police accomplice (Colm Feore).

Nathan Morlando‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMean Dreams‰Ûù may use a time-honored premise ‰ÛÓ young lovers on the lam (see: ‰ÛÏBadlands‰Ûù) ‰ÛÓ but it does so with such quiet, gently appealing assurance that it makes the template seem fresh again. Jonas (Josh Wiggins, who made an effective screen debut in ‰ÛÏHellion‰Ûù in 2014) is a 15-year-old high school dropout working on his parents‰Ûª struggling farm when he meets Casey (the Canadian actress Sophie NÌ©lisse, from ‰ÛÏThe Book Thief‰Ûù), who with her father has just moved in down the road.

Mr. Morlando ‰ÛÓ working with his skilled cinematographer, Steve Cosens, from a tight script by Kevin Coughlin and Ryan Grassby ‰ÛÓ capitalizes on rural Canadian locations in autumn and the chemistry of his young, talented stars. As the bravura composition of the group-murder sequence illustrates, Mr. Morlando knows how to stage a scene with tasteful understatement. Without stooping to titillation, he underscores the bond between Jonas and Casey, whose fate, though far from secure, leaves the viewer with hope and with cherished memories of their company.

Elsewhere, Ms. Elon and Mr. Touitou, a French-Algerian Jew, confront a growing sense of alienation from each other. Initially optimistic, he struggles to find work and denounces the racism that he sees in the country. ‰ÛÏBeing part of this place as a Jew, I feel like I‰Ûªm part of their building,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs like being part of the stones that they put into the new settlements.‰Ûù
But leaving is fraught as well. ‰ÛÏP.S. Jerusalem‰Ûù reflects not only on lost possibilities for Israel but also on lost friendships.

An exemplar of how to make the personal political, the movie finds many of its most revealing moments with Tristan, their oldest child, who attends what‰Ûªs described as the only school in Jerusalem where Jews and Arabs study together. (The students occasionally seem like unfiltered mouthpieces for their parents.) Ms. Elon must explain settlements and mandatory conscription to her son. He forms a close friendship with an Arab boy.

In ‰ÛÏP.S. Jerusalem,‰Ûù the filmmaker Danae Elon moves back to the city of her youth, where her father, the Israeli author Amos Elon, begged her never to return. But after his death in Italy in 2009, and shortly after learning she was pregnant again, Ms. Elon left Brooklyn for Jerusalem with her partner, the photographer Philip Touitou, and their small sons. Ms. Elon‰Ûªs experiences living in Jerusalem as an insider-outsider are the subject of this essay documentary, which ruminates on how Israel has changed since Ms. Elon‰Ûªs youth and how Israel changes Ms. Elon‰Ûªs family.

It‰Ûªs around 2025, and Abby Dixon (Sarah Habel) is a loyal engineer for the Auxilisun company, whose tri-fission engine saved the world from a fossil-fuel crisis by converting nuclear waste into usable energy. When a desert outpost ‰ÛÓ what Abby calls ‰ÛÏthe largest nuclear waste facility in the Southern Hemisphere‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ ceases its communications, Abby volunteers to investigate.

Dagen Merrill‰Ûªs sci-fi thriller ‰ÛÏAtomica‰Ûù comes from Syfy Films, so we‰Ûªre not talking about ‰ÛÏArrival‰Ûù-level effects or sophistication. Much of it, however, was shot in a former Titan II missile silo, which lends the film a gritty veracity you don‰Ûªt find in a green-screen digital setting. And while its premise and some of its effects may be B-movie grade, ‰ÛÏAtomica‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ like the best B movies ‰ÛÓ delivers an unexpectedly rewarding kick.

Inside the cavernous containment center, she meets one of its two occupants: Robinson Scott (Dominic Monaghan), an erratic janitor who might be experiencing psychosis from prolonged solitude. The other resident, Dr. Darius Zek (Tom Sizemore), a scientist, is out in the irradiated desert, where the air is toxic. After he is found and brought back to the complex, a game of hidden motives and identities commences, and Abby must uncover the truth.

Mr. Monaghan relishes his colorful role, while Mr. Sizemore nicely underplays his. Ms. Habel, though game, strains for authenticity. But the revelations in the script (by Kevin Burke, Fred Fernandez-Armesto and Adam Gyngell) have weight, introducing larger issues at play, and the ending stays with you.

‰ÛÏSong to Song‰Ûù is filled with beautiful people adrift in beautiful (glass) houses and natural settings. All this loveliness has its pleasures, but Mr. Malick‰Ûªs visual choices also give the film a commercial luster that can rob that beauty of its power. That‰Ûªs partly because the advertising world and mainstream cinema have long pilfered his aesthetic, turning it into a sales pitch. Mr. Malick is enraptured with beauty as an expression of God and as a path to God. But in ‰ÛÏSong to Song‰Ûù both the familiarity of his aesthetic and the inability of some of his actors to summon an inner light create immaculately photographed surfaces rather than immanence. You see the poses, not the divine.

The first section traces the earlier, joyful moments shared by Faye, Cook and BV; by the final section, Faye is stepping once more into a natural pool of water, challenging Heraclitus‰Ûªs observation that you cannot step into the same river twice (life changes). Throughout, Mr. Malick inserts shots and short scenes that seem more like shards of memory, like those flashes from the past that suddenly materialize in the temporal slipstream. Faye and Cook gaze at each other warily; Faye and BV embrace; Faye and Cook embrace; at one point, all three fly off in a private plane to Mexico, where they cavort on a beach, wander around and get drunk amid a relay of looks.

That‰Ûªs disappointing, even if there‰Ûªs also much here that‰Ûªs exhilarating, including the film‰Ûªs ambitions and its seriousness. Seriousness in cinema is often viewed with suspicion and that‰Ûªs as true now as it was when, say, Antonioni shook up the art. The difference is that now seriousness (and beauty and grace) is rarely part of a wider discussion, because that conversation is dominated by corporate cinema, where there‰Ûªs often little to argue over and get excited by. There is, by contrast, much to admire in ‰ÛÏSong to Song‰Ûù and much to argue with, including its ideas about pleasure and women. So go, fall into its embrace, resist its charms, argue. This may not be a film to love, but it is a film to see.

Despite Ms. Smith‰Ûªs electric sincerity this exchange finally feels false because Ms. Mara can‰Ûªt convey the interiority that it requires, the kind of astonishing inner truth ‰ÛÓ call it a fever or call it grace, passion or holiness ‰ÛÓ effortlessly expressed by Ms. Smith and manifest in Leonardo‰Ûªs Madonna. Mr. Malick‰Ûªs filmmaking, with its storytelling ellipses and visual fragments, places a heavy burden on his performers, who need to build their characters primarily through individual voice-overs and in onscreen silence or near-silence, in gestures and movement. Mr. Fassbender does this brilliantly; too often, Ms. Mara and Mr. Gosling seem to be running through different acting exercises.

There‰Ûªs much to take in here, including the film‰Ûªs narrative fragmentation, which requires you to go with the flow as you also puzzle together the story‰Ûªs parts, themes and circling characters: Faye (Rooney Mara), a musician trying to find her way in Austin, Tex.; Cook (Michael Fassbender), a music producer and Faye‰Ûªs sometime lover; and BV (Ryan Gosling), a musician and Faye‰Ûªs other lover. A few other lovelies float in as well, including Rhonda (a moving Natalie Portman), a waitress who marries Cook; Amanda (Cate Blanchett), who has an affair with BV; and Zoey (BÌ©rÌ©nice Marlohe), who has an affair with Faye. Holly Hunter, Iggy Pop, Johnny Rotten and Val Kilmer also drop in.

Cook‰Ûªs world is a stage show or so he tells BV, a sentiment that Mr. Malick seems to share. It‰Ûªs a beautiful, seductive show, an endless carnival (with little actual work or sweat) filled with jostling, occasionally colliding bodies that ‰ÛÓ whether playing onstage, thrashing in a mosh pit or seductively grinding on the floor ‰ÛÓ seem to be reaching, reaching, always reaching for something beyond these earthly, fleeting, sensual delights. As in Mr. Malick‰Ûªs 2016 film ‰ÛÏKnight of Cups‰Ûù (about a screenwriter), sex and especially sex without love inevitably proves to be a crucial false promise, a temptation that leads to suffering, cascading tears and sometimes catastrophic, even fatal falls.

One of the loveliest images in ‰ÛÏSong to Song,‰Ûù the latest from Terrence Malick, is of ripples expanding across a small pool of water, echoes of a woman‰Ûªs quick step. Mr. Malick, one of cinema‰Ûªs philosopher kings, embraces fluidity as a visual principle and his films are filled with life‰Ûªs ebb and flow ‰ÛÓ its swirling waters, swooping birds, stirring trees, billowing curtains, and gliding people and cameras. He loves silence and stillness, and the image of sunlight caressing a woman‰Ûªs motionless face. But he is a searcher, and that searching informs his visual style with its restless, moving pictures.

During this idyll, play turns into a rehearsal for a possible future that‰Ûªs telegraphed by a baby whom BV holds in one scene and by a tiny, elderly woman trembling alone in another scene. Cook also speaks in muted voice-over about Faye and BV as if telling himself a story. ‰ÛÏThey have a beauty in their life,‰Ûù he murmurs, ‰ÛÏthat makes me ugly.‰Ûù You have to take his word for it, because there‰Ûªs very little here that‰Ûªs intentionally ugly in ‰ÛÏSong to Song.‰Ûù Ugliness hovers like a threat, but is often only inadvertently conveyed, as when the film reduces Mexicans to touristic props. Cook, by contrast, just seems like a rich, bored henhouse fox who throws parties where women wait to be chosen and where one lies on a table like a centerpiece, food covering her naked body.

Mr. Malick began embracing narrative fragmentation years ago and it has increasingly characterized his films. Most movies rely on formulas, employing three or four acts, story beats and character arcs that are so standard you almost intuitively know when something will happen if not what. There will be a crisis; there will be a tidying up. ‰ÛÏSong to Song‰Ûù has distinct sections, but Mr. Malick frames them his own way. They move the narrative forward, but inside these sections time can seem to stutter, like a song on repeat. Many scenes are so short that they don‰Ûªt seem to be overtly driving the story forward, but instead pile up and nearly swirl, like leaves caught in a gust.

‰ÛÏSong to Song‰Ûù continually flits ‰ÛÓ like the butterfly seen in one fleeting shot ‰ÛÓ from theme to theme, from love (always love) to fidelity, betrayal, identity, art, freedom, captivity, forgiveness and mercy. God is there, too, in nature and in the glowing, streaming sunlight, but also in a Madonna painted on the side of a building and in a Leonardo drawing of the Virgin Mary. The Leonardo shows up in a scene with Patti Smith, who plays herself (St. Patti) and compares Mary‰Ûªs face to Faye‰Ûªs. Ms. Smith tears a hole in the film because she‰Ûªs so thrillingly present, so alive; playing against Ms. Smith, Ms. Mara seems lost and she just disappears, poof, like a snuffed-out candle.

Ghosts of the past, both literal and figurative, haunt ‰ÛÏT2 Trainspotting,‰Ûù Danny Boyle‰Ûªs droll and wistful return to the Scottish reprobates who, 21 years ago in ‰ÛÏTrainspotting,‰Ûù made heroin addiction a blast and bodily waste a metaphor for squandered lives.

If all this sounds unbearably depressing, be cheered. ‰ÛÏT2‰Ûù never strays too far from laughs, most memorably in an exhilarating sequence that sends Renton and Simon to plunder a private club where partying Protestants belt out sectarian ditties. Leading the throng in a hastily composed anti-Catholic refrain, the two have never seemed so exultantly alive.

To that end, Mr. Boyle wisely doesn‰Ûªt try to surpass, or even repeat, the mad, frenetic rhythms of the original. Gone is the druggy propulsiveness, the ecstasy of the high that injected such improbable joy into those wretched, long-ago lives. In its place is a more cautious, altogether creakier energy, one that touchingly mirrors the emotional and physical states of men who are neither as spry nor as carefree as their younger selves. Euphoria has faded, and disappointment and disillusion have moved in.

This time, though, their purpose is more poignant. Playing with memory ‰ÛÓ the characters‰Ûª and our own ‰ÛÓ allows Mr. Boyle and his cinematographer, Anthony Dod Mantle, to conjure some of the movie‰Ûªs loveliest, most melancholy images: the smudged shape of Renton‰Ûªs dead mother sitting at her kitchen table; Spud detoxing on the floor of his crummy apartment, his anguished shadow looming, ‰ÛÏNosferatu‰Ûù-like, above him.

But while ‰ÛÏT2‰Ûù might be middle-aged, it‰Ûªs very far from moribund, the despondent base notes shouldering a story of revenge and regret, amity and acceptance. Orchestrating an orgy of nostalgia ‰ÛÓ the train-patterned wallpaper in a childhood bedroom; scattered flashbacks to the men‰Ûªs earlier capers ‰ÛÓ Mr. Boyle reprises the dodgy camera angles and tricky visuals that beckon us back to the first film with shameless deliberation.

Excremental flourishes notwithstanding, that gloriously scabrous picture also kick-started the careers of its director and stars, most of whom are back to illustrate the consequences of a misspent youth. Renton (Ewan McGregor) has returned to Edinburgh from Amsterdam, ready to face the music for absconding with his pals‰Ûª share of the loot from the previous movie‰Ûªs drug deal. Simon (Jonny Lee Miller) is still scraping by on the criminal fringes, trying to transform his rundown bar into an upscale brothel. And Begbie (Robert Carlyle) ‰ÛÓ whose drug of choice has always been violence ‰ÛÓ has just wangled an appropriately bloody escape from prison.

It‰Ûªs fitting, then, that Veronika ‰ÛÓ the only character untouched by the original movie‰Ûªs damaged universe ‰ÛÓ should be the catalyst for this picture‰Ûªs ouroboros-style ending. As Spud fends off his cravings by scribbling the stories of his youth, one habit substitutes for another and we are reminded of how little we change. And how much we sometimes wish that we could.

Aside from a warmly stabilizing performance by Anjela Nedyalkova as Veronika, a Bulgarian prostitute and Simon‰Ûªs business partner, the film‰Ûªs women are barely seen and quietly worn down. Kelly Macdonald reappears as a successful, adult version of the schoolgirl Renton once deflowered, but the light in her eyes has gone out. Similarly, Spud‰Ûªs girlfriend (Shirley Henderson) and Begbie‰Ûªs wife (Pauline Turner) pop in only briefly, their faces betraying decades of emotional strain.

Then there‰Ûªs sweet, pathetic Spud (Ewen Bremner), still chasing the dragon and explaining to a support group why the biggest obstacle to sobriety is daylight saving time. His rant is hilarious, the patter rapid and twisted and defiantly, exuberantly Scots. (The script is once again by John Hodge, drawing from the novels of Irvine Welsh.) Though a few words were subtitled after I saw the film, the general absence of translation is fully in line with a middle-finger attitude that the first movie cherished and its successor urges its characters to question.

The too-brief filmography of the Taiwanese director Edward Yang is one of the most vital in all of cinema. Yang, who was in his 30s when he began his filmmaking career in the 1980s, made seven features; his final film, the intimate but also nearly epic ‰ÛÏYi Yi‰Ûù (2000), was until recently the only one to have received a proper release in the United States. (He died of cancer in 2007.) His most challenging masterpiece, ‰ÛÏA Brighter Summer Day‰Ûù (1991), was released in theaters stateside in 2011 and on DVD and Blu-ray last year; now, a restoration of ‰ÛÏTaipei Story‰Ûù (1985), Yang‰Ûªs spectacular second feature, is having an official theatrical release in the United States before being released on DVD.

The presence of a jaded architect in any film brings to mind Michelangelo Antonioni, and Yang had a clear affinity with that Italian filmmaker. Yang‰Ûªs scenes of alienated urban structures are frequently staggering; throughout his body of work, he had a real knack for making the banal look uncanny. His approach to narrative yields frequent surprises in terms of emotional impact. Scenes end or are suspended after an uncomfortable truth between characters comes to light, or after an awkward question is asked. He doesn‰Ûªt withhold information as a rule but applies this device to heighten the viewer‰Ûªs involvement. Yang‰Ûªs frequent use of cutting on the down beat, so to speak, gives the action a musical quality; the rhythms pop like bebop.

Ultimately, ‰ÛÏTaipei Story‰Ûù is bleak yet exhilarating. Yang‰Ûªs vision was bitter, but hardly without compassion, and he pulls it off here with a quiet confidence that he used to yield greater dividends in his subsequent film, the even more complex ‰ÛÏThe Terrorizers‰Ûù (1986). Now, maybe that will be the next of Yang‰Ûªs films to soon become more accessible to audiences here.

The film charts a slide in its characters‰Ûª lives from ‰ÛÏmeh‰Ûù to miserable to potentially catastrophic. Yang‰Ûªs perspective imbues the narrative with a powerful, increasing sense of dread. The film‰Ûªs finale lives up to that feeling, but in a way the viewer won‰Ûªt see coming ‰ÛÓ very much like life itself.

The central story is of Chin (Tsai Chin, a Taiwanese pop star and the director‰Ûªs wife at the time), a young woman who hopes her professional advancement can lift her out of a dreary family home, and Lung (Hou Hsiao-hsien, himself a great director and also a writer of this screenplay), her seemingly aimless, baseball-obsessed boyfriend. The opening scene shows them looking at a potential new apartment for Chin; ‰ÛÏnot bad,‰Ûù is the ultimate verdict, and that sentiment is about as good as it gets for these two. Almost as soon as Chin moves into the place, she loses her job and briefly engages a jaded architect at her former company in what could be the prelude to an affair.

As we learn more about Chin and Lung, our impressions of them shift. The once seemingly ambitious Chin allows herself to be pulled into listlessness and hedonism, while Lung, a onetime baseball player now working as a fabric seller and weighing a move to the United States, is running himself ragged trying to do right by everybody in his circle. He tries to bail out Chin‰Ûªs father, a crooked and lazy businessman who is indebted to some loan sharks, and comes to the aid of a former teammate, who is driving a cab day and night to support three kids and a wife who is gambling his earnings away. Lung can‰Ûªt seem to get anything going for himself, though, and his quick temper can sometimes get the better of him. ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre living in a fairy-tale world where only your pity can save us,‰Ûù an ex-lover chides him late in the film.

At one point, Mr. Zahedi mentions a failed project about the artist Joseph Cornell. It‰Ûªs possibly the most shocking statement in this often jaw-dropping movie. In a nearly three-decade career, Mr. Zahedi has only ever made films about himself. His most frequently cited picture, ‰ÛÏI Am a Sex Addict,‰Ûù from 2006, is as accurately titled as this presentation. Mr. Zahedi‰Ûªs onscreen persona is all about absolute discomfiting candidness. ‰ÛÏPeople don‰Ûªt love honesty,‰Ûù he notes, while he‰Ûªs stubbornly committed to complete disclosure in his art. And not just for himself. This proves maddening for his collaborators, some of whom are played by actors and others appearing as themselves. His teaching career is threatened. Things also get hectic for his wife.

For much of ‰ÛÏThe Show About the Show,‰Ûù its director and star, Caveh Zahedi, talks directly to the camera, briskly recounting the endless misadventures he and others experienced while producing an initially sexually explicit semidocumentary series for the nonprofit cable network BRIC TV. (This movie is in fact a revised compilation of the programs.)

This is an undeniably fascinating film despite, or perhaps because of, the repellent actions Mr. Zahedi depicts himself taking. ‰ÛÏThe Show About the Show‰Ûù contains ostensible cinÌ©ma vÌ©ritÌ© footage, staged re-enactments of events and re-enactments of re-enactments. It gets a bit dizzying. And it features a vast array of New York indie film luminaries ‰ÛÓ the ‰ÛÏGirls‰Ûù actor and filmmaker Alex Karpovsky and the critics Eric Kohn and Godfrey Cheshire.

But Mr. Zahedi remains the focal point. For all his candor, there‰Ûªs something sinister about him. His refusal to acknowledge the plain implications of what honesty on his terms demands suggests someone whose evident disingenuousness masks something even worse.

‰ÛÏThis show is about holding authority accountable,‰Ûù Mr. Youssef says. It‰Ûªs a brave stance in the face of oppression, and a worrisome one, too, knowing the threats he has encountered. This first-rate documentary generates similar mixed feelings at a time when freedoms seem to be threatened everywhere. After watching, you come away feeling more proud of those freedoms, and more concerned for their future.

As protests over the president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, turned bloody in 2011, Bassem Youssef, a surgeon, sought to aid the injured. What he saw on Cairo‰Ûªs streets was different than what was being discussed on television, so with the help of a friend he made an internet show that later became a network program.

Sara Taksler, the film‰Ûªs writer and director (and a producer for ‰ÛÏThe Daily Show‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ Mr. Stewart appears in several scenes here), provides a succinct account of events in Egypt. For those unfamiliar with the fate of ‰ÛÏThe Show,‰Ûù she also leaves a few tense, what-will-happen moments. Interviews with Mr. Youssef and his staff members are both optimistic and anxious, as are the street scenes with those who praise the host and those who seek his execution.

That program, ‰ÛÏThe Show,‰Ûù poked fun at current events and politicians and became immensely popular. For comparison, we‰Ûªre told that ‰ÛÏThe Daily Show‰Ûù with Jon Stewart averaged about two million viewers in the United States, while Mr. Youssef had an audience of some 30 million in Egypt. The country‰Ûªs new leadership soon chafed at Mr. Youssef‰Ûªs jibes. Arrest warrants and censorship followed.

There‰Ûªs a lot to laugh at, and to learn from, in ‰ÛÏTickling Giants,‰Ûù a documentary that starts off by telling the story of one man and ends up speaking volumes about satire, freedom of expression and political pressure.

So to have Anna, a television actress, bemoan the confines of her industry creates an unfortunate disjunct that weakens the narrative and lessens our sympathy. For that reason, ‰ÛÏA Woman, a Part‰Ûù is most effective when picking at the rivalries and resentments that can bloom among longtime friends, illustrating the chasm between our memories and theirs. That void opens slowly, but if you‰Ûªre patient, it might just pull you in.

Touching on issues of artistic survival and the porous boundary between work and pleasure, Ms. Subrin, an accomplished visual artist and filmmaker, sifts addiction, celebrity and the plight of the aging actress into something rarefied yet real. A strong, intelligent screen presence, Ms. Siff can make the simplest line feel pregnant with possibility. And Ms. Seymour is the perfect counterpoint, giving Kate a warm vulnerability that‰Ûªs never overplayed or milked for sentiment.

‰ÛÏI feel like you want something from me,‰Ûù remarks Kate (Cara Seymour), welcoming yet wary. At 50, Kate is no longer an actor and is facing financial and other crises of her own. As is Isaac (John Ortiz), a playwright and the third member of their former theater group. With a teetering marriage and vague future, the gentle Isaac could have seemed a mere go-between for his two circling friends; but Mr. Ortiz is so quietly compelling that he makes Isaac‰Ûªs modest ambitions feel improbably consequential.

In the hands of lesser performers ‰ÛÓ and in defiance of Chris Dapkins‰Ûªs clear, bright cinematography ‰ÛÓ this debut feature would feel unbearably hermetic, its navel-gazing angst wearyingly indulgent. The slighting of women in the entertainment industry (one of Ms. Subrin‰Ûªs central concerns) has been explored in multiple ways in a variety of venues. Yet, as Ms. Siff demonstrates in her own career (she‰Ûªs currently enjoying her second season as a rivetingly inscrutable performance coach on Showtime‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBillions‰Ûù), television now has no shortage of challenging roles for women. Whatever their age.
Unresolved feelings and unsatisfied ambitions animate ‰ÛÏA Woman, a Part,‰Ûù Elisabeth Subrin‰Ûªs sophisticated take on female friendship and professional frustration.

For Anna (Maggie Siff), the 44-year-old star of a popular, long-running television series in Los Angeles, burnout is imminent. Weakened by an autoimmune disease and weary of her brittle character, she abandons the series and returns to New York City to reconnect with the friends and collaborators who helped spark her career. But a lot can happen in two decades, and Anna is about to learn that the bits of ourselves we leave behind can‰Ûªt always be reclaimed.

At 22, Ms. Hepnarova was disdained by her family, resigned to her sexuality but frustrated and bored by the women she was sleeping with, and reflexively shunned by most of her lumpen colleagues. In the film, she cultivates a vengeful monstrousness and then clings tight to it. ‰ÛÏI know I‰Ûªm a psycho, but an enlightened one,‰Ûù she says at one point. ‰ÛÏOne day you‰Ûªll pay for your laughter and my tears.‰Ûù Her resolve gives her an appalling confidence.
Anchored by a startling performance by Michalina Olszanska, the Czech film ‰ÛÏI, Olga Hepnarova‰Ûù is an austere, hypnotic story of sadness, madness and murder.

Early in the movie, Ms. Olszanska, a slight, narrow-shouldered woman, plays Olga as someone trying to recede into herself, slumping and looking to the ground as she puffs on a cigarette. By the time of her trial, at which she pleads guilty and demands the death penalty, she is stiff, straight, defiant. Modern civilizations are haunted by crimes like this; ‰ÛÏI, Olga Hepnarova‰Ûù persuasively suggests that the only understanding we can have of them is a terrifying one.

The filmmakers piece together a fictionalized account of the life of Olga Hepnarova, who on July 10, 1973, drove a truck onto a sidewalk in Prague and hit at least 20 people, eight of whom died. Before committing her crime, she explained her actions in a letter, which the film shows her composing. It‰Ûªs a deeply discomfiting document. But the writer-directors Tomas Weinreb and Petr Kazda ‰ÛÓ shooting in black and white, which contributes both a documentary feel and an expressive vocabulary ‰ÛÓ are astute and effective in showing the circumstances that fed Ms. Hepnarova‰Ûªs mental illness and led to her homicidal break from the world.
Rocking a dirty mind and a sick sensibility, the British import ‰ÛÏPrevenge‰Ûù sends a pregnant serial killer on a darkly comedic odyssey dictated by her malicious fetus.

At its core, though, ‰ÛÏPrevenge‰Ûù is a brilliantly conceived meditation on prepartum anxiety and extreme grief. Vividly evoking the impotence of imminent motherhood (punched up by the 1970 hit ‰ÛÏVehicle‰Ûù on the soundtrack and the disorienting tipsiness of Ryan Eddleston‰Ûªs camera angles), Ms. Lowe makes Ruth a deeply conflicted avenger. You‰Ûªll laugh, you‰Ûªll squirm, you‰Ûªll want to get sterilized immediately.

Yet what hoists this bloody battiness above much of the scrappily low-budget horror pack is the smartness of its execution and the strength of the movie‰Ûªs central performance. As Ruth, a profoundly lonely expectant mother, Alice Lowe (who also wrote and directed) personifies weaponized gestation. Lumbering and implacable, she bears down on her victims in zombielike obedience to the tiny voice emanating from her uterus.

‰ÛÏBaby will tell you what to do,‰Ûù a chipper midwife (Jo Hartley) says soothingly, unaware that Ruth knows all too well that her womb has a view. In a series of gory vignettes that jab insistently at sexism and gender, Ms. Lowe (who, at the time of filming, was barely a month shy of her own delivery date) carefully builds thematic layers. And what initially registers as simple retaliation for the gutter misogyny of random creeps ‰ÛÓ like a slimy pub D.J. (Tom Davis) who is sliced with Lorena Bobbitt-like specificity ‰ÛÓ soon evolves into payback for those who may have caused the death of the baby‰Ûªs father.

Not onscreen, though. The movie version of ‰ÛÏWilson,‰Ûù directed by Craig Johnson (‰ÛÏThe Skeleton Twins‰Ûù) from a screenplay by Mr. Clowes, illustrates the difficulty of translating an idiosyncratic temperament from one visual medium to another. The dark, comic poignancy of the book is drowned in garish, self-conscious whimsy, and the work of a talented ensemble is squandered on awkward heartstring snatching.
Antic, joyless and sloppy, ‰ÛÏWilson‰Ûù tries to provoke and beguile you, but the best you can manage is to feel sorry for it.

Wide-eyed and gaptoothed, with heavy-framed glasses and a copper-and-silver beard, Woody Harrelson plays Wilson as a kinetic ball of conflicting impulses. He‰Ûªs unpleasant, but not in an especially interesting way, and ingratiating in a way that‰Ûªs even drearier. The other people in Wilson‰Ûªs life ‰ÛÓ his foils, enablers and marks ‰ÛÓ are played by capable actors. Laura Dern is his wayward ex-wife, Pippi. Cheryl Hines is her judgy sister, Polly. Judy Greer is Wilson‰Ûªs dog-sitter, and Isabella Amara is the almost-grown daughter he never knew he had. Mary Lynn Rajskub and the character actress Margo Martindale each have a few minutes of screen time.

Wilson ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs not clear if that‰Ûªs his first or last name ‰ÛÓ is a misanthrope with a sentimental streak, a guy whose grouchiness is leavened by oddball touches of Minnesota Nice. He is furiously disdainful of most of the people he meets, but also has a habit of sidling up to them and initiating awkward conversations with a smile halfway between a snarl and a leer. Humanity annoys him, and he‰Ûªs happy to return the favor.

Which makes him, on paper, an intriguing character. By ‰ÛÏon paper‰Ûù I mean, specifically, in the pages of Daniel Clowes‰Ûªs graphic novel ‰ÛÏWilson,‰Ûù a funny-sad, episodic portrait of everyday loneliness and longing. American literature ‰ÛÓ and American comic-book literature in particular ‰ÛÓ hardly lacks for disaffected, middle-age white guys, but Wilson has his own special brand of abrasive charm.

As is often the case with well-intentioned, misbegotten projects, you‰Ûªre happy to see them even as you wonder how they ended up here. The same is true of the composer Jon Brion, a usually brilliant musical artist whose score in this case is an unpalatable cocktail of jauntiness and melodrama, swamping the action rather than complementing it.

‰ÛÏAmerican Anarchist‰Ûù makes for unsatisfying viewing, although it‰Ûªs possible it couldn‰Ûªt have been otherwise. The meat of this documentary is a dialogue between the director, Charlie Siskel (‰ÛÏFinding Vivian Maier‰Ûù), and William Powell, author of ‰ÛÏThe Anarchist Cookbook.‰Ûù Released in 1971, the book gives instructions for making bombs.

‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt think I hoped they would do anything with it, quite frankly,‰Ûù Mr. Powell, who was 65 during filming, says of his prospective readers. That sentiment captures the disconnect between the author, who describes the book as the work of an angry 19-year-old, and his legacy. In 2013, in an article for The Guardian, Mr. Powell explained his desire for the book to ‰ÛÏquickly and quietly go out of print.‰Ûù (He never controlled the copyright.)

But ‰ÛÏAmerican Anarchist‰Ûù also suggests that Mr. Powell, who became a teacher and advocate for special-needs children, walled himself off from his influence. Mr. Powell cites the Columbine killings, nearly three decades after publication, as the first time he learned of a connection between the book and violence. Mr. Siskel confronts him with reported links to other attacks, including the Oklahoma City bombing and the Aurora, Colo., theater shootings. ‰ÛÏThis is the first time that I‰Ûªm becoming aware of the laundry list of associations that the book has had,‰Ûù Mr. Powell says.

A study in denial, ‰ÛÏAmerican Anarchist‰Ûù may be illuminating for being unilluminating. The film closes by noting Mr. Powell‰Ûªs sudden death in July, which, unlike the book, has left only traces online.

And that‰Ûªs too bad, because had there been, the talented Michael PeÌ±a wouldn‰Ûªt have had to work so hard to hold this minimally amusing mess together. As Ponch, an undercover federal agent investigating corruption in the California Highway Patrol, Mr. PeÌ±a struggles to make his character more than a walking erection. That‰Ûªs tough when your new partner, Jon (Dax Shepard, who also wrote and directed), seems so fixated on his own equipment that he keeps forcing you to look at it. The mixed messages are clamorous.

Exhibitionism aside, Jon is a battle-scarred motocross rider who has joined the patrol to impress his estranged wife (Kristen Bell, Mr. Shepard‰Ûªs real-life spouse). Together, the partners chase unidentifiable men in full-face helmets and converse about what constitutes an acceptable masturbation schedule. A corpulent and clearly embarrassed Vincent D‰ÛªOnofrio slips in and out of the frame as a dirty cop, and the delightful Rosa Salazar, playing a sexily competent colleague, deserves much more attention than the hardware-obsessed script is willing to give her.

A fascination with posteriors ‰ÛÓ both human and feline ‰ÛÓ isn‰Ûªt the worst thing about ‰ÛÏCHIPS,‰Ûù but it‰Ûªs up there. Borderline incoherent and unrepentantly lewd, this buddy-cop comedy (based on the 1977-83 television series of the same name) substitutes cars, ‰Ûªcopters and motorcycles for actual characters. The language might be mature, but don‰Ûªt be misled: There‰Ûªs nothing here that rises above the level of the playground.

‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt think we went more than three days on this movie without blowing something up,‰Ûù Mr. Shepard says in the publicity notes, betraying the picture‰Ûªs true intent. Yet beyond checking genre boxes, the action sequences, while undeniably flashy, often have debatable narrative utility. The accomplished cinematographer Mitchell Amundsen brings what context he can to the pyrotechnics, but not even he can perk up the movie‰Ûªs drearily staged indoor setups. Focusing his camera intently on a cat‰Ûªs backside, he must surely have been questioning his life choices.

The story unfolds in two eras. In 1947, a policeman, Proctor (Danny Goldring), and his deputy, Waterhouse (Ted Levine), dispose of two bodies in a lake. The amoral Proctor doesn‰Ûªt hesitate, but Waterhouse, plagued with regret, demands that Proctor relinquish his badge. Decades will pass before they settle scores.

Ms. Isler deftly blends vulnerability and cool intent. But the anchor is Mr. Levine (Captain Stottlemeyer in the TV series ‰ÛÏMonk‰Ûù), winningly combining paternal concern and flinty resolve. The backwoods creepiness might not linger, but his performance does.

The film toggles between time periods, as we learn the extent of Proctor‰Ûªs evil ‰ÛÓ he shakes down a Gypsy mother for cash and sex ‰ÛÓ and the lengths Jake might go to revive her sibling. And we see the bond between Jake and Waterhouse and how their fates entwine.

Cut to 1977, when Waterhouse‰Ûªs granddaughter, the teenage Jake (Samantha Isler, a daughter of Viggo Mortensen in ‰ÛÏCaptain Fantastic‰Ûù), is despondent over her brother‰Ûªs death in the same lake. She is tempted by three Gypsies (led by a threatening Troy Ruptash) to participate in a ritual to resurrect her brother with another person‰Ûªs murder.

Hunter Adams‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDig Two Graves‰Ûù is that rare chiller conjuring eeriness and dread without defaulting to abundant gore or flagrant nudity. While its elements ‰ÛÓ small-town police corruption; supernatural powers in an Old World brood (here, Gypsies); an adolescent girl‰Ûªs confrontation with a traumatic past ‰ÛÓ are familiar, it bears a haunting ambience as agreeable as it is ephemeral. Mr. Adams is clearly skilled with story structure, cinematography and his actors.

He had arrived in New York a decade earlier, a jug-eared, fleet-fingered teenage prodigy discovered by Dizzy Gillespie and nurtured by Art Blakey. Slender, stylish and ebullient, Morgan played the trumpet with speed, precision and an infectiousness that Mr. Collin wisely pauses to savor.

In February 1972, in the midst of a blizzard, the jazz trumpeter Lee Morgan died after being shot in a Manhattan nightclub by his common-law wife, Helen. The shooting was tragic and traumatic for those who were there ‰ÛÓ one of Morgan‰Ûªs band mates stayed away from New York for many years after ‰ÛÓ but for the rest of the world, it has the qualities of a sad, strange, faded tabloid story.

You are always aware that Morgan is missing from their company, that he should have grown into an elder statesman alongside them. Regret isn‰Ûªt the film‰Ûªs only key, though. Helen, Lee‰Ûªs senior by more than a decade, restored him to health and nurtured a creative rebirth. ‰ÛÏI Called Him Morgan‰Ûù lingers in the period of their happiness, as Helen recalls it, and doesn‰Ûªt strain to make sense of the senseless violence that ended it.

‰ÛÏI Called Him Morgan,‰Ûù a suave and poignant documentary by Kasper Collin, dusts off the details of Morgan‰Ûªs life and death and brushes away the sensationalism, too. This is not a lurid true-crime tale of jealousy and drug addiction, but a delicate human drama about love, ambition and the glories of music. Edged with blues and graced with that elusive quality called swing, the film makes generous and judicious use of Morgan‰Ûªs recordings. The scarcity of film clips and audio of Morgan‰Ûªs voice is made up for by vivid black-and-white photographs and immortal tracks from the Blue Note catalog.

What happened that night seems as simple and as mysterious as a murder ballad, and yet at the same time, more a terrible accident than a full-blown tragedy. It‰Ûªs startling to realize how young Morgan was ‰ÛÓ 32 or 33, depending on which news article you believe ‰ÛÓ given how much he had lived. But that‰Ûªs what art does, including documentary film: It expands the scope of life and distills its beauty and its pain.

There are fewer pictures of Helen Morgan, who didn‰Ûªt like to be photographed. But shortly before she died, in 1996, she recorded a series of interviews with Larry Reni Thomas, an adult-education instructor and radio host in Wilmington, N.C., where she was living at the time. Her voice ‰ÛÓ candid, funny and haunting ‰ÛÓ offers the counterpoint in a double biography, a chronicle of tenderness and self-destruction.

He also lingers over the reminiscences of Morgan‰Ûªs colleagues ‰ÛÓ including Wayne Shorter, Paul West and Jymie Merritt ‰ÛÓ whose testimony provides a lesson in musical history and a primer on jazz aesthetics. Their bearing in interviews carries some of the essential qualities of the music: the wit, the dignity, the mixture of passionate feeling and critical intelligence. You could listen to these men talk all day, and then listen to them play all night.

The former Helen More grew up in poverty in rural North Carolina and escaped, at 17, to New York, where she established herself as, among other things, a kind of den mother to the jazz scene. Her apartment in the West 50s, not far from Birdland, was a place where musicians gathered to mingle, listen to records and eat her famous cooking. One of them was Lee Morgan, who met his future lover at a low point in his career, in the mid-1960s, when he risked squandering his early promise and crossover success in the service of his heroin habit.

Some of those he talks to mouth platitudes about everyone‰Ûªs getting along around the dinner table, but others aren‰Ûªt so simplistic, mentioning things like the difficulty Palestinian restaurants have in attracting a diverse clientele during times of tension. And not all speak admiringly of the melting-pot approach to cuisine; some resent Israelis‰Ûª helping themselves to the cooking traditions of other cultures.

‰ÛÏIn Search of Israeli Cuisine‰Ûù starts out seeming as if it might be indistinguishable from any of the countless globe-hopping foodie shows on television. As it goes along, though, this documentary by Roger Sherman at least touches on issues like culinary appropriation and national identity as defined through food. When it‰Ûªs not being overly promotional, it can be interesting.

It‰Ûªs too bad the film doesn‰Ûªt have more of this feisty interplay ‰ÛÓ long stretches are just the usual food-speak about local ingredients and childhoods spent watching Grandma cook. Its best segments, though, are an informative take on a subject that is still very much evolving.

The restaurateur Michael Solomonov serves as a guide, touring the country to interview chefs and others about their dishes and their views on cooking. The film looks a lot like a garden-variety food show on TV, with endless shots of food being prepared, Mr. Solomonov sampling the finished product and assuring the cook (and moviegoers) that it‰Ûªs really tasty.

It‰Ûªs when he asks his subjects about the intermingling of cultures and nationalities in Israel, and whether such a relatively young country can even have a culinary identity, that the film catches hold.

The astronauts on board are on a mission to retrieve samples from Mars. The biggest find is a single-cell organism: proof of life on another planet. Because movie monsters never stay small, Calvin (as a girl on Earth names it) soon grows into a kind of iridescent snail. Hugh Derry (Ariyon Bakare), an exobiologist, marvels that each of Calvin‰Ûªs cells can perform every somatic function. Miranda North (Rebecca Ferguson), who is from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and makes fruitless arguments for quarantines, translates: Calvin can simultaneously be all muscle, all brain and all eye.

The primary suspense comes from wondering whether the killings will follow the reverse order of star billing. The humans include Jake Gyllenhaal as a medic, who is growing loony from too much time in space. (Having seen military carnage, he doesn‰Ûªt much care for Earth, anyway.) Hiroyuki Sanada plays the flight engineer with a newborn at home. In the best scene, Ryan Reynolds, as the crew‰Ûªs mechanic, charges into the lab to rescue Hugh and is trapped with an extremely irritated Calvin, then in his jellyfish stage. (Despite the promise of an all-muscle, all-brain, all-eye creature, the effects artists seem to have gotten their visual ideas by playing mix-and-match at an aquarium.)

It sounds like a trap ‰ÛÓ and it is. And not just because Calvin, at first playfully curious toward Hugh, turns hostile after a moment of human error. No, it‰Ûªs a trap because the movie, having started so promisingly, quickly settles for becoming yet another clone of ‰ÛÏAlien,‰Ûù as space travelers play a deadly game of hide-and-seek with a shape-shifting Martian. (Not counting the android in that Ridley Scott 1979 film, ‰ÛÏLife‰Ûù even has the same number of crew members.)

In an opening sequence, ‰ÛÏLife‰Ûù allows viewers to float through an international space station. The camera zips around corners and turns upside-down in a feat of impossible (and most likely effects-massaged) cinematography. It‰Ûªs tempting to tune out the exposition and simply concentrate on the director Daniel Espinosa‰Ûªs dazzling imagery, even if it now looks familiar from ‰ÛÏGravity‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAvatar.‰Ûù

And as the astronauts contend with airlocks, busted equipment and escape pods, it becomes increasingly difficult to pretend that this isn‰Ûªt territory where more inventive screenwriters (Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick, the writers here, are also responsible for ‰ÛÏDeadpool‰Ûù) and stronger visual stylists have gone before. The movie isn‰Ûªt, to paraphrase a line from ‰ÛÏSpaceballs,‰Ûù the stupidest combination you‰Ûªve ever heard. But it‰Ûªs not very good, either.

‰ÛÏAi-yi-yi-yi-yi!,‰Ûù says Alpha 5, the robot sidekick to Zordon, in ‰ÛÏSaban‰Ûªs Power Rangers,‰Ûù uttering his signature exclamation. Alpha 5 (voiced by Bill Hader) is not the only holdover in this slick repackaging of ‰ÛÏMighty Morphin Power Rangers,‰Ûù the shrill and unfathomably popular 1990s Fox Kids‰Ûª  series  (adapted by Haim Saban from a Japanese TV show) about teenage superheroes in color-coded costumes. But Mr. Hader‰Ûªs dialed-down take reflects the movie‰Ûªs tempered refinement of the original.

Gone are the antiseptic characterizations of the ‰ÛÏMorphin‰Ûù days; ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre all screw-ups,‰Ûù says Jason (Dacre Montgomery), a.k.a. the Red Ranger, a fallen football star. Kimberly (Naomi Scott), the Pink Ranger, is a guilt-ridden former mean girl; the sullen Trini (Becky G), Yellow, is sorting out her sexual orientation; Zack (Ludi Lin), Black, tends his ailing mother in a mobile home. Billy (R J Cyler, the funniest, most talented fresh face here), Blue, is a timid savant ‰ÛÏon the spectrum,‰Ûù he says.

‰ÛÏSaban‰Ûªs Power Rangers,‰Ûù plotted by a small army of writers and directed by Dean Israelite, jumps right into an origin story. Zordon (Bryan Cranston) is a protector of humanity who centuries ago led a team of Rangers destroyed by the dastardly Rita Repulsa (Elizabeth Banks). Now, after lying dormant for centuries, she and Zordon are revived, and Zordon, who lives trapped in a vast wall monitor, must recruit a new crew to fight her.
‰ÛÏSaban‰Ûªs Power Rangers‰Ûù may surpass the original, but for what lesson? The value of teamwork? More likely, of a franchise payoff.

They share a ‰ÛÏMatrix‰Ûù-like discovery of their powers, conferred by mysterious colored coins, and come across Zordon and Alpha 5‰Ûªs underground chamber, where destiny ‰ÛÓ and a requisite training montage ‰ÛÓ awaits. Ms. Banks chews scenery as Rita while her monstrous minion devours the Rangers‰Ûª California hometown. When the Rangers engage in ‰ÛÏTransformers‰Ûù-lite mayhem, an intriguing group portrait collapses into generic pyrotechnics, the dialogue running from ‰ÛÏBring it on!‰Ûù to ‰ÛÏLet‰Ûªs do this!‰Ûù
Anshai Lal‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPhillauri‰Ûù is a Bollywood movie toggling between a contemporary screwball rom-com and a sweeping historical love story. Balancing both proves to be challenging.

Mr. Lal, making his feature directorial debut, clearly understands the camera and special effects. But working from a script by Anvita Dutt that reaches too far in too many directions, he is undone by his own ambition.

Soon Kanan is haunted by the glowing ghost of Shashi (Anushka Sharma, no relation to Mr. Sharma), a friendly female spirit only he can see, who has a connection to the tree. His initial terror of, and conversations with, a seemingly nonexistent woman gives his fiancÌ©e pause.

In a sprawling home in Punjab, the families of Kanan (Suraj Sharma), a 26-year-old aspiring rapper, and his longtime girlfriend, Anu (Mehreen Pirzada), prepare for their wedding. But Kanan has his doubts ‰ÛÓ he thinks he might be too young for marriage ‰ÛÓ and to make matters worse, his family insists he first participate in a ceremony marrying him to a tree. (In this way, he is told, the hapless Kanan can avoid the usual fate of a manglik, a person born ‰ÛÏunder a cursed star.‰Ûù)

We shuttle between eras until the threads converge in a present-day supernatural spectacular in Amritsar, attended by a legion of wraiths. Yes, Shashi‰Ûªs soul finds peace, and Kanan and Anu become ready for marriage. But by then credibility has been drained and the drama has proved exhausting, unhelped by the listless male leads. (Ms. Sharma and Ms. Pirzada bring the spark here.)

Just when you think ‰ÛÏPhillauri‰Ûù is becoming a ‰ÛÏGhost Town‰Ûù- or ‰ÛÏTopper‰Ûù-type romp, it switches gears, as Shashi imparts her own past. Flash back to almost a century ago, when she was a poet, secretly submitting verse to a newspaper under an assumed name. When she meets another poet, Phillauri (Diljit Dosanjh), a dashing ne‰Ûªer-do-well, they fall into a love forbidden by Shashi‰Ûªs pious brother. It‰Ûªs painful to witness the script‰Ûªs transformation of Shashi at that point from a hardheaded freethinker into a lovelorn obsessive. But things become worse for her: The abuses of British rule ‰ÛÓ specifically the Jallianwala Bagh Massacre, in Amritsar, Punjab, in 1919 ‰ÛÓ lead to a dire personal loss.

Ms. Epperlein grew up there, in the city once (and once again) known as Chemnitz, which East Germany rulers renamed after the father of their ideology. The Socialist Unity Party of Germany (as the Communists were officially known) conceived Karl-Marx-Stadt as a showcase of productivity and prosperity, an industrial powerhouse devoted to the supremacy of the East German proletariat.

In ‰ÛÏKarl Marx City,‰Ûù she steps in front of the camera and returns to her hometown, excavating the zone where family and national history intersect. Accompanied by a third-person voice-over narration ‰ÛÓ she is not ‰ÛÏI‰Ûù but ‰ÛÏshe‰Ûù in her own story ‰ÛÓ Ms. Epperlein interviews her mother and brothers, historians and archivists, members of the Stasi and their victims.

In addition to illuminating the inner workings of everyday political terror, she tries to shed light on a family tragedy. In 1999, 10 years after the collapse of East German communism, Ms. Epperlein‰Ûªs father committed suicide. Fifteen years after that, his only daughter forces herself to confront the awful possibility that he might have collaborated with the Stasi. So many people did.

‰ÛÏKarl Marx City,‰Ûù Michael Tucker and Petra Epperlein‰Ûªs unsettling new documentary, is a smart, highly personal addition to the growing syllabus of distressingly relevant cautionary political tales. The volumes currently crowding bookstore front tables ‰ÛÓ George Orwell‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏ1984,‰Ûù Sinclair Lewis‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏIt Can‰Ûªt Happen Here,‰Ûù Hannah Arendt‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Origins of Totalitarianism‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ offer time-tested prophecies and autopsies of dictatorship. ‰ÛÏKarl Marx City‰Ûù supplements their theories and speculations with everyday facts about life in the supposed workers‰Ûª paradise of the German Democratic Republic.

Ms. Epperlein conducts her inquiry armed with a giant, fuzz-covered microphone and adorned with a pair of heavy black headphones. This equipment looks a bit comical, but its presence is as much a declaration of ethical principles as an arresting visual joke. The Stasi took pictures and made recordings in secret; its surveillance was stealthy, invisible. Ms. Epperlein ‰ÛÓ who with her cropped blond hair and regal bearing resembles Robin Wright in ‰ÛÏHouse of Cards‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ becomes a walking emblem of honesty and transparency, an embodiment of the documentary ideal.

The mystery of her father‰Ûªs life and death provides ‰ÛÏKarl Marx City‰Ûù with suspense, and with a concrete sense of profound moral and emotional stakes. Repressive regimes excel at creating ambiguity, at making complicity easier than resistance and at blurring the lines between heroes and villains. Ms. Epperlein and Mr. Tucker, shooting in black and white and making judicious use of historical footage, brilliantly evoke a landscape of gray areas. They also uncover glimmers of decency, loyalty and solidarity ‰ÛÓ the tiny cracks in the totalitarian edifice that foretold its eventual and inevitable collapse.

After the Berlin Wall came down in 1989, Ms. Epperlein made her way to the West. She and Mr. Tucker, an American-born filmmaker, together made a series of tough-minded, intellectually curious shorts and features, including ‰ÛÏGunner Palace‰Ûù (2005), one of the first documentaries about the Iraq War and still one of the best.

That isn‰Ûªt always an obvious distinction. The Stasi security service deployed hundreds of thousands of East German citizens as spies and informants, creating a climate of near-total surveillance and pervasive paranoia. Stasi agents routinely collected information from colleagues and neighbors, and broke into apartments in search of incriminating evidence. What they usually found, according to one former officer, were hand-copied West German television schedules and overnight bags packed in anticipation of flight or arrest.

Although CÌ©zanne played to the hilt the role of contemptuous bohemian rebel, he came from a wealthy family from which he was largely estranged. Zola, who was born in poverty, assiduously worked his way up the social ladder. Paradoxically, his raw realistic novels shocked the very bourgeoisie he professed to loathe but whose approval he eagerly courted.

‰ÛÏCÌ©zanne et Moi‰Ûù offers a pungent, demystifying portrait of the rowdy late-19th-century Parisian art world where famous painters and poets mingled and jostled for position at dinner parties and art openings filled with shoptalk, backbiting and intrigue.

The film, an intimate, searching portrait of the turbulent friendship between the two geniuses directed by DaniÌ¬le Thompson (‰ÛÏAvenue Montaigne‰Ûù), completely avoids the tone of pious reverence typically adopted in stories about famous artists and writers. Instead it focuses on the insecurity, competitiveness and complicated love lives of these two ambitious men of opposite temperament. Anyone who has spent much time in artistic and literary circles will recognize that this is how it is even today.

Mr. Canet‰Ûªs Zola, who resembles William Hurt in one of his more prim, buttoned-up roles, seems miscast as the author who maintains an unswerving loyalty to CÌ©zanne in his life if not in his writing.

‰ÛÏWith you I never know if I‰Ûªm dealing with a dog, a cobra or a butterfly,‰Ûù the writer Ìämile Zola (portrayed by Guillaume Canet) says out of frustration and impatience to the Post-Impressionist painter Paul CÌ©zanne (Guillaume Gallienne) in ‰ÛÏCÌ©zanne et Moi.‰Ûù

Instead of trying to explain CÌ©zanne‰Ûªs vision and its evolution, the movie shows it in a remarkable final montage of his paintings of Mont Sainte-Victoire, the ridge overlooking Aix-en-Provence that captivated his imagination. As CÌ©zanne puts it in the film: ‰ÛÏI like to paint the fluidity of air, the heat of the sun, the violence of the rocks.‰Ûù

Mr. Gallienne, who dominates the film, gives an electrifying portrait of CÌ©zanne as a scruffy, driven wild man who even as his career seems stalled, declares, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll never stop painting; I‰Ûªll die painting.‰Ûù Charismatic but scary, flashing a furious, wide-eyed glare that could turn people to stone, CÌ©zanne is a foul-mouthed misogynistic boor and selfish voluptuary who shocked polite society with his profanity and who in his later years was obsessed with his declining virility.

It also makes a point of showing the profound self-doubt that led CÌ©zanne to attack his canvases in fits of rage and Zola to consider destroying his manuscripts. Creativity for both men, who were acutely aware of their diminishing powers as they aged, is more agonizing than ecstatic.

‰ÛÏCÌ©zanne et Moi‰Ûù begins in 1888 in MÌ©dan, northwest of Paris, when Zola, then in his late 30s, was a world-famous author and the reputation of the late-blooming CÌ©zanne was gathering steam. It then immediately flashes back to 1852, when they were rambunctious schoolboys, with CÌ©zanne the daredevil who took Zola the follower under his wing. The movie restlessly jumps around in time, cramming almost more information than you can take in. And it is so eager not to come off as a lecture in art history the film presumes a high level of knowledge of French culture and history ‰ÛÓ more than most American viewers might possess.

There is an abundance of gorgeous outdoor scenes, many set in Aix-en-Provence, where CÌ©zanne is shown at work amid the fullness of nature. And famous paintings of the period are alluded to both in the dialogue and in shots that evoke the imagery of Manet‰Ûªs masterpiece, ‰ÛÏLe DÌ©jeuner sur l‰ÛªHerbe.‰Ûù

The friendship is all but shattered with the publication of Zola‰Ûªs novel ‰ÛÏL‰ÛªOeuvre,‰Ûù whose barely disguised portrait of CÌ©zanne as a ‰ÛÏcastrated, defeated, pathetic loser,‰Ûù in the painter‰Ûªs words, hurts him to the quick. Even at the best of times, CÌ©zanne views Zola as a timid romantic fool, at odds with his literary persona as a brutal social realist.

What if life‰Ûªs greatest mystery were solved? How would the world react? ‰ÛÏThe Discovery,‰Ûù a star-laden film with simultaneous theatrical and Netflix releases on Friday, begins with that earthshaking premise but then turns small, a shift that leaves you feeling as if you‰Ûªve seen only half the movie.

The tale becomes part puzzle, part science-fiction thriller and part love story as Will and Isla clash with Thomas over his work and its implications. The cast also includes Jesse Plemons, Riley Keough and Mary Steenburgen, and the story stays intriguing for much of the way, but eventually things cease to make sense. You‰Ûªre left thinking that the most interesting stuff was what happened immediately after ‰ÛÏthe discovery,‰Ûù the part of the yarn that the film skips over.

The mystery in question is whether there is an afterlife. Robert Redford plays Thomas, a scientist who proves that the answer is yes, news not greeted with the joyous reaction that you might expect. It instead prompts an epidemic of suicides, since people who encounter mildly troubling problems no longer see a reason to try to work through them ‰ÛÓ why bother when death is just a transition?

We learn all of that, though, mostly secondhand. The story, written by Justin Lader and Charlie McDowell and directed by Mr. McDowell, picks up two years after the finding, as Will (Jason Segel), Thomas‰Ûªs son, is on his way to visit his father. On an otherwise empty ferryboat he encounters the enigmatic Isla (Rooney Mara), whom he will meet again after he arrives at his destination.

To keep the zoo from being closed, the quick-witted couple come up with the idea of converting it into a hog farm, which would produce meat to feed the German soldiers. The animals subsist on garbage retrieved from the Warsaw ghetto in daily truck runs. Jan‰Ûªs plan is to smuggle Jews hidden under the refuse to the zoo, where they are secreted in the basement of the house occupied by the family, which includes their young son, Ryszard (played at different ages by Timothy Radford and Val Maloku).

What does it say that the most stirring scenes in a movie that avoids graphic depictions of Nazi barbarism involve the heroic title character, Antonina Zabinska (Jessica Chastain), lovingly interacting with the animals in the Warsaw Zoo, which she runs with her husband, Jan (Johan Heldenbergh)?

A subplot involves Antonina‰Ûªs precarious balancing act as she charms the besotted Lutz, and resists surrendering to his increasingly aggressive moves as her jealous husband watches nervously from a distance. The screenplay is so frightened of this material that it isn‰Ûªt always clear whether she has succumbed. But as Lutz evolves from a charmer into a bad, bad Nazi, the question of did she or didn‰Ûªt she give in seems a feeble attempt to pump romantic excitement into a drama in dire need of moral complexity.

In these tender moments, ‰ÛÏThe Zookeeper‰Ûªs Wife,‰Ûù directed by Niki Caro (‰ÛÏWhale Rider‰Ûù), from an anemic screenplay by Angela Workman, shucks off its modesty and transforms into the sentimental portrait of a beautiful woman and the animals she cares for like a devoted parent. You can trust animals, but not people, she declares.

Except for its scenes involving animals, this handsome, excessively fastidious screen adaptation of Diane Ackerman‰Ûªs 2007 nonfiction best seller is a polite but pallid recycling of Holocaust movie tropes with epic pretensions. The book tells the true story of a Polish couple who rescued about 300 Jews from the Warsaw ghetto during the Holocaust and sheltered them in their zoo.

Ms. Chastain‰Ûªs watchful, layered performance helps keep the film on an even keel, but it is not enough to prevent ‰ÛÏThe Zookeeper‰Ûªs Wife,‰Ûù with its reassuringly cuddly critters, from feeling like a Disney version of the Holocaust.

It at least sustains a cool pictorial grandeur in its portrayal of the Nazi invasion of Poland as bombers sweep the skies and armored tanks roll into Warsaw as the city erupts in panic, its peace and quiet shattered in one horrifying instant. As bombs rain on the zoo, the frightened, confused animals run wild in the streets, and amid the chaos an elephant is shot.

Her beloved charges get more screen time than the Jews whose lives the couple saves and who mostly remain anonymous, their personal stories left untold. They creep out of hiding and convene like a ghostly family when Antonina signals them by playing the piano.

After the invasion, Antonina and Jan are greeted with unctuous cordiality by Lutz Heck (Daniel BrÌ_hl), a suave Nazi zoologist who offers to transport the zoo‰Ûªs most prized animals to Berlin for safekeeping. During their stay, he says, he plans to use them for selective breeding.

‰ÛÏ‰Û÷Schindler‰Ûªs List‰Ûª With Pets‰Ûù: That‰Ûªs my suggested alternate title for ‰ÛÏThe Zookeeper‰Ûªs Wife.‰Ûù This mild-mannered Holocaust film probably wasn‰Ûªt conceived as family fare but is so timid and sanitized it almost feels safe for children.

The most emotional scene has nothing to do with Nazis, Jews or the Holocaust. In this surefire set piece, which feels shoehorned into the film, Antonina saves the life of a baby elephant to which she administers CPR, risking being trampled by the adorable creature‰Ûªs agitated mother. Otherwise, ‰ÛÏThe Zookeeper‰Ûªs Wife‰Ûù plays like a medium-gloss rerun of other more gripping depictions of Nazi evil and Jewish suffering.

There are ample opportunities for the movie to stir up fear each time the truck leaves the ghetto, but the film has little appetite for cliffhanging suspense. The fugitives who emerge from under the garbage don‰Ûªt look much the worse for wear. Although not without moments of terror and desperation, the screenplay‰Ûªs leisurely timing subverts their dramatic impact.

Shot over three years in and around New York, the movie reveals a cohort that‰Ûªs highly articulate and shockingly self-aware. There are seven in all, but the film‰Ûªs emotional anchors are Lena and her closest friend, Ginger. Slender and grounded, Lena continually surmounts the fallout from her parents‰Ûª financial troubles. The moody Ginger, though, seems more lost, struggling with acting ambitions and a painful lack of closeness with her father.

As a result, ‰ÛÏAll This Panic‰Ûù can feel glancing, its more painful revelations sliding in unheralded and slipping away just as quietly. What‰Ûªs left is a dreamy diary of a time that passes so quickly yet impacts so profoundly.

Having grown up clicking and posing, the teenage girls in ‰ÛÏAll This Panic‰Ûù are as comfortable in front of a camera as professional actors. And that‰Ûªs good news for this limber, light-footed documentary, which becomes a cinematic confidant for their fears and confessions, dreams and insecurities as they dance on the boundary between high school and adulthood.

‰ÛÏPeople want to see you, but they don‰Ûªt want to hear what you have to say,‰Ûù says Sage, pointing astutely to the way young women are often objectified in our culture. Perhaps in agreement, the camera keeps as close as a best friend, catching the teens in artfully blurred compositions and the softest of natural light. Yet through often banal conversations about hookups and hanging out, Ms. Gage remains alert to each telling, throwaway remark.
Adopting a meandering, free-flowing structure and woozily intimate photography, the director, Jenny Gage, and her husband, the cinematographer Tom Betterton, follow close and listen well.
1. Don‰Ûªt surround your heroine with buffoons. At a legal-proofreading job, Carrie‰Ûªs colleagues (Vanessa Bayer and Desmin Borges) are straight out of a Mike Judge movie.
Ms. Powley is a miracle worker.

Her character, Carrie Pilby ‰ÛÓ from a Caren Lissner novel ‰ÛÓ is a 19-year-old Brit fresh out of Harvard (she skipped three grades) and living in New York. A prodigy who can read 17 books in a week, she regards others with unmitigated exasperation. Her therapist (Nathan Lane) gives her a list of suggestions, including ‰ÛÏgo on a date‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏget a pet.‰Ûù Here are suggestions for ‰ÛÏCarrie Pilby.‰Ûù

In 2015, Bel Powley stole Sundance with her performance in ‰ÛÏThe Diary of a Teenage Girl.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏCarrie Pilby‰Ûù poses a tougher test. Might she single-handedly redeem 90 minutes of contrived nonsense?

3. Celebrate awkwardness, to a point. When Carrie finally has a great date, the director, Susan Johnson, films the actors in an unbroken take so lengthy it‰Ûªs unclear whether we should admire the unforced banter or the camera operator‰Ûªs virtuosity.

2. Limit your clichÌ©s. It‰Ûªs enough to saddle Carrie with a dead mother, a distant father (Gabriel Byrne) and a past affair with a professor (Colin O‰ÛªDonoghue). There‰Ûªs no need for the professor to have hoarded Carrie‰Ûªs treasured copy of ‰ÛÏFranny and Zooey,‰Ûù or to make retrieving it a dopey plot point.

4. Situate your ending one subway stop away ‰ÛÓ as opposed to having Carrie‰Ûªs obvious soul mate (William Moseley) live across the hall. And don‰Ûªt give him a quirky hobby, like playing the didgeridoo.

It closes with Mr. Lynch‰Ûªs work on his first feature, ‰ÛÏEraserhead‰Ûù (1977), following his artistic development from an upbringing in which he says his mother refused to let him have coloring books ‰ÛÓ the lines were somehow too restrictive ‰ÛÓ through his education as a painter.
Mostly, the documentary is a fond portrait of how one man nurtured his artistic temperament and risked being misunderstood ‰ÛÓ sometimes by his own family.

Mr. Lynch charts the shift from an idyllic early childhood in Idaho to a darker period after a family move to Virginia. He repeatedly credits the encouragement of the artist Bushnell Keeler and he  calls Philadelphia, where he attended the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, a city that would ‰ÛÏsuck your happiness away and fill you with sadness and fear.‰Ûù (Images of his paintings and a rumbling Lynchian score infuse even his folksiest utterances with a sense of menace.)

The ‰ÛÏTwin Peaks‰Ûù television revival is finally arriving in May, but David Lynch fans have had a long spell of contenting themselves with leftovers. (The director‰Ûªs last feature was ‰ÛÏInland Empire‰Ûù in 2006.) The documentary ‰ÛÏDavid Lynch: The Art Life‰Ûù benefits from confining itself to a less-examined period.

Bouncing his young daughter on his knee, or at work in his studio, Mr. Lynch is less cryptic in this film directed by Jon Nguyen, Rick Barnes and Olivia Neergaard-Holm than in the 2007 documentary ‰ÛÏLynch.‰Ûù

With its use of archival clips, men talking into the camera and narration by Meryl Streep, ‰ÛÏFive Came Back‰Ûù might seem like standard documentary filmmaking. But it‰Ûªs easy to overlook the complexity of its editing, which distills a trove of footage in superbly illustrative ways.

So perhaps ‰ÛÏFive Came Back‰Ûù was destined to become a Netflix series. Divided into three parts, this screen adaptation is a companion piece and a stand-alone work, and itself superlative film criticism. Directed by Laurent Bouzereau, ‰ÛÏFive Came Back‰Ûù will be shown theatrically in New York and Los Angeles starting Friday, when it also begins streaming on Netflix.

Above all, ‰ÛÏFive Came Back‰Ûù is an invitation to see more: It‰Ûªs hard to watch it without wanting to visit (or revisit) Wyler‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMrs. Miniver‰Ûù or Ford‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThey Were Expendable.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs further proof, if any were needed, that these men weren‰Ûªt simply creating propaganda, but art that would endure.
