But if you were to watch ‰ÛÏFive Came Back‰Ûù with the sound off, the shots that might most catch your eye are Stevens‰Ûªs extraordinary images of the liberated streets of France and of the horrors of the Dachau concentration camp. His subsequent film version of ‰ÛÏThe Diary of Anne Frank‰Ûù (1959), sometimes ridiculed for its counterintuitive use of CinemaScope and the casting of the model Millie Perkins, may be the movie that gains most in retroactive inflections.

Recounting the stories of five Hollywood directors who served in World War II with cameras in tow, the 2014 book ‰ÛÏFive Came Back,‰Ûù by the journalist Mark Harris, is an extraordinarily detailed account of how the men brought the war home for viewers. Still, it has a problem endemic to film books: It lacks clips.

Sidestepping the impossible task of compression, this chronological series takes the gambit of having each director‰Ûªs story relayed by a contemporary counterpart. The pairings aren‰Ûªt always the expected ones.

The explication of Frank Capra falls to Guillermo del Toro, who shares insights into Capra‰Ûªs populism, his immigrant‰Ûªs can-do mentality and his shrewdness as an entertainer. Paul Greengrass, no stranger to drama in the air (‰ÛÏUnited 93‰Ûù) or on the sea (‰ÛÏCaptain Phillips‰Ûù), seems to understand Ford intuitively. Of Ford‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏThe Battle of Midway‰Ûù (1942), he notes the dangerousness of the camera placement and moments when violence visibly distresses the image. Francis Ford Coppola defends John Huston‰Ûªs use of staging in ‰ÛÏThe Battle of San Pietro‰Ûù (1945) as potentially capturing the essence of the situation more completely than straight documenting might have.

Steven Spielberg, whose own movies share obvious affinities with those of Frank Capra and John Ford, is the surrogate for William Wyler. Mr. Spielberg‰Ûªs eye is one of the series‰Ûª strongest assets: He extols the aerial photography in ‰ÛÏThe Memphis Belle: A Story of a Flying Fortress‰Ûù (1944), an account of a B-17 bomber‰Ûªs mission, and later notes how Wyler avoided camera motion until a crucial scene in ‰ÛÏThe Best Years of Our Lives‰Ûù (1946), one of several postwar films held up as examples of how the directors‰Ûª experiences overseas transformed their movies.

Of the wartime directors, George Stevens, whose story is told by Lawrence Kasdan, arguably has the spottiest critical reputation, and he vanishes for long stretches of ‰ÛÏFive Came Back‰Ûù until his teaming with John Ford to film the D-Day invasion.

As the title suggests, ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell‰Ûù is haunted, including by the original manga, its sequels and several excellent animated movies: the first, also titled ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell,‰Ûù and the entrancingly lovely ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell 2: Innocence,‰Ûù both directed by Mamoru Oshii. The new ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell‰Ûù was directed by Rupert Sanders, who has made commercials and one other feature, ‰ÛÏSnow White and the Huntsman.‰Ûù He likes a dark palette and is good with actors, but there‰Ûªs little here that feels personal, and he mostly functions as a blockbuster traffic cop, managing all the busily moving, conspicuously pricey parts.

The most important leviathan, of course, is Ms. Johansson, whose mysterioso cyborg, Major, effortlessly slides right into this scene, with her preternaturally still face ‰ÛÒ often as blank as a mask ‰ÛÒ and the ports in the back of her neck that she uses to jack into cables and other characters. These artificial orifices are pleasingly mysterious and highly suggestive, at once creating a sense of human vulnerability and raising the possibility of the posthuman. Major occasionally stuffs goo in her ports and also uses them to plug into others. About the only part of her that‰Ûªs human is her soul, or ‰ÛÏghost‰Ûù in the story‰Ûªs poetic parlance. The rest of Major is a bendable, mendable shell, which makes her well suited for hard-core tactical work with a police outfit known as Section 9.

Enjoy these credits because they offer some of the more arresting, inventive images in this visually cluttered yet often disappointingly drab movie. A live-action version of a famed Japanese manga by Shirow Masamune, ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell‰Ûù is one of those future-shock stories that edges around the dystopian without going full-bore apocalyptic. To that end it is set in a possible future world that looks distant enough to seem exotic and familiar enough to seem plausible. The original manga takes place in what‰Ûªs described as a ‰ÛÏstrange corporate conglomerate-state called ‰Û÷Japan,‰Ûª‰Ûù while this movie unwinds nowhere in particular, just a universal megalopolis filled with soaring gray towers.

Anyone who has seen Ridley Scott‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBlade Runner‰Ûù or that film‰Ûªs innumerable 2.0 follow-ups (‰ÛÏStrange Days,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Fifth Element‰Ûù) will recognize this ‰ÛÏGhost‰Ûù cityscape, with its jumbled forms, neo-noir shadows, patina of art-directed decay and its conspicuous Asian-Hollywood fusion touches. Some of this tickles the eye, like the semi-translucent, pony-size koi fish that float through the air, seemingly just because they look cool. The koi don‰Ûªt seem to be selling anything other than the movie‰Ûªs production values and visual concept; elsewhere, enormous spectral human figures loom over buildings like embodied billboards, nicely evoking rampaging movie monsters of the past.

The characters understand one another, presumably because they‰Ûªre beyond mere language and, in any event, they sometimes communicate telepathically. At first, the fact that they can speak to one another comes across as an inventive flourish, but like so much in ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the toddling geishas, the Asian extras ‰ÛÓ it helps to reduce an entire culture to a decorative detail. The movie has been widely criticized for casting Ms. Johansson in a role that was, of course, originally Japanese, a decision that isn‰Ûªt offset by an absurd narrative twist that seems to have been created to forestall criticism but will only provoke further ire. This isn‰Ûªt just appropriation; it‰Ûªs obliteration.

That‰Ûªs too bad, especially because the original ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell‰Ûù is such a delightful philosophical plaything, with pleasures that simultaneously bewitch the eye and enchant the mind. This version, by contrast, ditches the original‰Ûªs big, human, all-too-human questions, but keeps all the firing guns and car chases, the action clichÌ©s and intentional genre stereotypes. Stripped of its deeper-dish musings, the story turns into a perfectly watchable, somewhat bland action movie, tricked out with sharp details, some fine actors and one slumming legend, the director-actor Takeshi Kitano, who plays Aramaki, Major‰Ûªs boss. He only speaks in Japanese; Major and almost everyone else speak in English.

Like the greatest screen goddesses, Scarlett Johansson rises above it all. In the thrill-free science-fiction thriller ‰ÛÏGhost in the Shell,‰Ûù her character comes at you in pieces, emerging first during the opening credits in the form of a metallic skeleton. It‰Ûªs a good look ‰ÛÓ it evokes the original Terminator ‰ÛÓ but soon the skeleton is being dipped like a chip in whitish goo. This technological soup gives the metallic frame a humanoid cladding, making it more reassuringly and pleasantly familiar, from bosomy top to round bottom. It looks like a giant dream Barbie, hairless pubis and all.

Ms. Bishop gave birth to Caitlin (an inspiring rock of fortitude here), shortly after getting married in 1985. Separated, she grew mildly paranoid, flitting among homeless shelters, medical centers and jail. Though Joan sought to be her legal guardian, a judge found that Linda, after months in New Hampshire State Hospital in Concord, did not require one. (Linda, who wanted her independence, was lucid before him.) Refusing medication, Linda was released; because of New Hampshire‰Ûªs personal privacy laws, Joan and Caitlin weren‰Ûªt notified. A few days later, she discovered the uninhabited house. Subsisting on apples from an orchard and rainwater, she wrote constantly, spiraling into religious reveries. Her dead body was found there in 2008.
This documentary, coupled with Ms. Aviv‰Ûªs article, addresses unresolved issues of personal autonomy versus a patient‰Ûªs inability to protect herself. It will haunt you.

Ms. Bishop‰Ûªs life, treatment and destiny are described on camera by a police officer, a judge, psychiatrists, a social worker and Ms. Bishop‰Ûªs steadfast sister, Joan, and daughter, Caitlin. But the film also adds lyrical location footage and readings from Ms. Bishop‰Ûªs journals (by the actress Lori Singer) that pull you into her mind as it unraveled in an empty farmhouse during a brutal New England winter.

In 2011, The New Yorker published ‰ÛÏGod Knows Where I Am,‰Ûù an unsettling article by Rachel Aviv recounting the fate of Linda Bishop, a single mother with bipolar disorder and psychosis who fell through the cracks of New Hampshire‰Ûªs medical establishment. Now Ms. Aviv is a consulting producer for Jedd and Todd Wider‰Ûªs affecting documentary of the same title, which adds vivid colors to the tragic tale.

Between these flares of violence, the director, Rod Blackhurst, maintains an almost hushed atmosphere as Ann (Lucy Walters) tends to her meager forest encampment. Alone but resourceful, she toils silently to stay alive, digging slugs from rotting tree bark and listening to a recorded emergency message that bleats from a hand-crank radio. The words are in French, which she doesn‰Ûªt understand, but their urgency is clear.

Softly lighted and bleakly bucolic, ‰ÛÏHere Alone‰Ûù sacrifices momentum for a dreamy tension that tightens when Ann encounters an injured man (Adam David Thompson) and his teenage stepdaughter (Gina Piersanti). Distrust and betrayal stain the story, yet Mr. Blackhurst resists cynicism; even when our humanity is in tatters, he suggests, the mothering instinct remains damn near indestructible.

Given the familiarity of its premise ‰ÛÓ a handful of survivors brave the aftermath of a deadly, rage-inducing virus ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏHere Alone‰Ûù is unexpectedly engaging. More psychodrama than postapocalyptic adventure, the movie parcels out its scares in small, effective jolts, delivering just enough menace to remind us of the stakes.

Pared to the bone and more suggestive than declarative, David Ebeltoft‰Ûªs screenplay interrupts these long, meditative stretches with flashbacks to the fates of Ann‰Ûªs husband (Shane West) and infant daughter. At other times, the serenity of the woods (the movie was filmed in upstate New York) is punctured by the screams of the infected who stand between Ann and her food supply. Always, through peace and peril, the camera hugs her side like a bodyguard, its fidelity a constant insistence on the significance of her survival.

If you‰Ûªve ever visited a Caribbean island and been discomfited by the social divisions between visitors and the local population, you‰Ûªll relate to much in Logan Sandler‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLive Cargo.‰Ûù The movie, shot in the Bahamas, where Mr. Sandler spent some of his teenage years, captures the grittier, lesser-seen corners of a tourist destination.

Despite its tantalizing plot elements, this is a story woefully short on specifics. (The script is by Mr. Sandler, in his feature debut, and one of the film‰Ûªs producers, Thymaya Payne.) But the talented actors give their all. Nadine and Lewis, visiting a home owned by Nadine‰Ûªs family, share intimate moments and minimal, frustratingly simple conversations seemingly intended to evoke an Antonioni film. Mr. Wisdom and Mr. Howze exude vivid conviction, with Mr. Howze‰Ûªs character given rounded dimensions usually denied an antagonist. Mr. Dillon, however, struggles with the underwritten Myron.

Two narratives run side by side: One concerns a couple ‰ÛÓ Nadine (Dree Hemingway of ‰ÛÏStarlet‰Ûù) and Lewis (Lakeith Stanfield from ‰ÛÏAtlanta‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏGet Out‰Ûù) ‰ÛÓ trying to stay together after an incalculable loss; the other follows a mayor, Roy (Robert Wisdom of ‰ÛÏThe Wire‰Ûù), as he protects an aimless youth, Myron (Sam Dillon), from recruitment by a human trafficker, Doughboy (Leonard Earl Howze).

Absolutely breathtaking black-and-white neo-noir cinematography by Daniella Nowitz adds depth and emotional context. But it can‰Ûªt fully flesh out the story, which reaches its climax with a storm and the discovery of a vessel of dead and dying emigrants. We are largely left with the images, which take us far, if not far enough.

The directing debut of Osgood Perkins (son of Anthony Perkins), ‰ÛÏThe Blackcoat‰Ûªs Daughter‰Ûù bewitches with silky-smooth camera movements and a rolling, reverberating musical score (by Elvis Perkins, the director‰Ûªs brother). Yes, it‰Ûªs a horror movie (the murder scenes suggest that the director has watched ‰ÛÏPsycho‰Ûù more than once), but even its most brutal acts pulse with inchoate sadness. Deceptively simple scenes ‰ÛÓ like a stunning, slow-motion shot of Rose posing for her school photograph ‰ÛÓ insinuate a wealth of information, but the movie doesn‰Ûªt hanker to be understood. It just wants your surrender.

In an isolated Roman Catholic boarding school for girls, Kat (Kiernan Shipka, all grown up from her role as Sally Draper in ‰ÛÏMad Men‰Ûù) and Rose (Lucy Boynton) are left alone during midterm break. Neither set of parents, for reasons not immediately clear, has arrived to pick them up, and their only company is two strange female teachers. In another location ‰ÛÓ and perhaps another timeline ‰ÛÓ a third girl (Emma Roberts), who may have escaped from a mental hospital, is given a ride by a grieving couple (James Remar and Lauren Holly). All three narratives will converge, but not before a great deal of blood has been spilled.

Playing out in gloomy interiors and frigid exteriors, ‰ÛÏThe Blackcoat‰Ûªs Daughter‰Ûù is a stealth weapon. Slow and seductive and deliberately vague, this deeply unsettling tale of lost parents and troubled daughters exudes atmosphere while hoarding facts. Yet the movie is so perfectly acted and gorgeously filmed (the cinematographer is Julie Kirkwood) that we don‰Ûªt mind its coyness; the twanging notes of trepidation make us almost grateful for the leisurely build.

That‰Ûªs because the title character is voiced by Alec Baldwin, and all of his various past personas, especially the one from ‰ÛÏ30 Rock,‰Ûù somehow make hearing his distinctive voice coming from a cartoon infant all that much funnier.

The story, based on a picture book by Marla Frazee, is told from the viewpoint of Tim (Miles Bakshi or, when he‰Ûªs in narrator mode, Tobey Maguire), a 7-year-old only child who is not happy when his parents (Lisa Kudrow and Jimmy Kimmel) tell him a brother is on the way. Tim has a vivid imagination, and in his eyes the baby arrives wearing a business suit, bosses his parents around and has dubious intentions.

It‰Ûªs a movie whose story is aimed at the siblings of newborns ‰ÛÓ the 8-and-under crowd, more or less. They‰Ûªll follow the plot for most of the way; they just might be puzzled by their accompanying parent‰Ûªs reactions. ‰ÛÏWhat‰Ûªs so funny, Dad?‰Ûù

The contrast between the helpless-infant stage of life and corporate-speak is funny but fairly high-concept for a kiddie movie, and the plot grows denser as it goes along and the baby and Tim reluctantly join forces to stop a conspiracy by which puppies would corner all the love in the world. The film, directed by Tom McGrath (‰ÛÏMegamind,‰Ûù the ‰ÛÏMadagascar‰Ûù movies), is also full of homages and such that no young child is going to get. Psst: Hey grown-ups, no need to tell the kids that; just let them squirm while you enjoy the adult flourishes.
The animated feature ‰ÛÏThe Boss Baby‰Ûù has some hilarious moments. If, that is, you‰Ûªre a grown-up.

If the movie industry gave out awards for Most Accurate Title, the Catalan writer and director Albert Serra‰Ûªs new film would walk away with one. As it happens, Mr. Serra did receive France‰Ûªs prestigious Jean Vigo award for ‰ÛÏThe Death of Louis XIV,‰Ûù which stars Jean-Pierre LÌ©aud as the French monarch.

Louis XIV reigned for 72 years, until his death in 1715. He knew no other life save that of king. Mr. Serra‰Ûªs depiction of the monarch‰Ûªs final days shows a mostly bedridden Louis keeping to his dimly lit, ornately appointed bedroom. Bedecked in elaborate clothing and ridiculously oversize hairpieces, he is initially in a relatively content state. He gossips and indulges in what some might call mild locker-room talk with his doctors, asking one whether a certain marquise is beautiful naked. This state doesn‰Ûªt last. He has night sweats; he calls for water; when water is brought to him, he demands that it be served in a particular piece of crystal. It was perhaps once good to be the king; now it‰Ûªs confusing. And it will get worse before he gives up the ghost.

Mr. LÌ©aud, who has been a star of French cinema for most of his life (at 13, he created the character of Antoine Doinel in FranÌ_ois Truffaut‰Ûªs 1959 classic, ‰ÛÏThe 400 Blows‰Ûù), clearly knows something about living in a kind of box, and he plays Louis as a tired but majestic wreck. He‰Ûªs riveting, and a little alarming. As for Mr. Serra, while he often enjoys playing the foppish provocateur in his interviews, his film is sober, meticulous and entirely convincing in its depiction of period and mortality.

The movie begins on Ludlow Street, with Mr. Conrad making a multichannel recording of the goings-on in the block where he worked with the underground filmmaker Jack Smith, the future Velvet Underground members Mr. Cale and Lou Reed, and on his own projects. He fed himself with 15-cents-a-pound chicken hearts and worked temp jobs while applying the mathematics he was trained in to works both visual and musical, including the hallucinatory film ‰ÛÏThe Flicker.‰Ûù

Mr. Conrad could also be antic. Sawing at his violin, he evokes a character that could be played by a young Buck Henry in a Christopher Guest film. But, ultimately, he‰Ûªs not sendup worthy: he‰Ûªs the real deal. ‰ÛÏI want to make abstract art that‰Ûªs funny, happy, energetic, joyful,‰Ûù he exclaims at one point. That he did. This movie is a good introduction to it.

While he conceived and created some of the most prescient, influential and galvanic music of the second half of the 20th century, Tony Conrad would have bristled if you had called him a composer. ‰ÛÏOne of the things the music represented was the absence of the composer,‰Ûù Mr. Conrad says in the new documentary ‰ÛÏTony Conrad: Completely in the Present.‰Ûù He considered this to be the case for his early ‰Ûª60s work with John Cale, Marian Zazeela, Angus MacLise and, most crucially, La Monte Young ‰ÛÓ someone who very much considers himself a composer. Mr. Conrad‰Ûªs ideological break with Mr. Young is one of the many fascinating episodes of Mr. Conrad‰Ûªs productive life (he died last April at  76) covered in this film directed by Tyler Hubby.

What feels completely authentic, however, is the pain that Ms. Arnow‰Ûªs parents experience when she cruelly shows them footage of her having sex with the man they despise. At times like this, we suspect that James could be the more well-adjusted of the two.

While James is making our ears bleed with his excruciating singing and scattershot offensiveness (he describes President Obama as ‰ÛÏa mulatto,‰Ûù then admits he doesn‰Ûªt know what the word means), Ms. Arnow wonders if he‰Ûªs good dating material. He‰Ûªs certainly perfect for a woman whose apparently abysmal self-esteem ‰ÛÓ she even calls a friend for help in deflecting the insults of her perpetually naked editor, Max ‰ÛÓ requires a degree of emotional abuse that James is happy to provide.

Ugly to look at and even uglier to listen to, Joanna Arnow‰Ûªs whiny documentary ‰ÛÏi hate myself :)‰Ûù plays like an especially brutal exercise in self-analysis. The therapist, in this case, is Ms. Arnow‰Ûªs camera, which she wields remorselessly throughout her yearlong relationship with James, a would-be performance artist and a fully credentialed lush.
‰ÛÏYou pulled the wrong fish out of the water,‰Ûù he tells her, unaware that he might have been exactly the fish she wanted.
It‰Ûªs a pretty standard sadomasochistic setup, only without the kinky accouterments.

‰ÛÏYou could just admit that you like it when James degraded you,‰Ûù Max says. But that would require admitting that her supposed self-scrutiny ‰ÛÓ like James‰Ûªs infantile provocations and Max‰Ûªs clothing-optional put-downs ‰ÛÓ is the pose that it appears to be. It takes an especially robust sense of self to so openly invite ridicule, rendering the film‰Ûªs title somewhat less than credible.

Mr. Rock‰Ûªs story is, in many respects, typical; he falls prey to excesses in the ‰Ûª80s and ‰Ûª90s, and suffers a health catastrophe in 1997. Quadruple-bypass surgery is no picnic, but the director Barnaby Clay‰Ûªs treatment of the event (which includes having the present-day Mr. Rock verbally extemporize on a soundstage while an actor lies on a hospital bed, playing Mr. Rock‰Ûªs younger self) suggests that Mr. Rock is the only person ever to undergo the procedure.

So it‰Ûªs a little mystifying that this film‰Ûªs title, ‰ÛÏSHOT! The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock,‰Ûù dances around the name. But there‰Ûªs a lot about this intermittently engaging movie that‰Ûªs mystifying. Mr. Rock and his camera captured a statistically improbable number of genuinely emblematic images of late-20th-century pop culture luminaries: Bowie, Iggy Pop, Lou Reed, Debbie Harry. For all that, the movie‰Ûªs approach is gratuitously grandiose. Mr. Rock himself seems to fall in line with it early on, making pronouncements like ‰ÛÏThe lysergic experience opened up my third eye, you might say.‰Ûù To echo Reed‰Ûªs sentiment from early in this movie: ‰ÛÏOh, spare me.‰Ûù

The footage of Mr. Rock today, in better health and photographing contemporary acts like TV on the Radio and Father John Misty, shows a loose, funny charmer who still loves his work. ‰ÛÏSHOT!‰Ûù could have used more of that fellow.

Mick Rock is a great name for a young Englishman with a camera, especially one who photographed Syd Barrett and David Bowie in the late 1960s and early ‰Ûª70s. The subject of this documentary notes more than once that his name, which is his real one, practically determined the course of his life and career.

Walter Hill is a smart veteran genre filmmaker (‰ÛÏ48 Hrs.,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏSouthern Comfort,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏLast Man Standing‰Ûù) who‰Ûªs never been above a little lurid sensationalism. But using forced gender-reassignment surgery as a major plot hinge for his latest movie, ‰ÛÏThe Assignment,‰Ûù is arguably a miscalculated provocation.

In a story built on multiple flashbacks and flash forwards, the viewer learns of a hired killer named Frank Kitchen (Michelle Rodriguez) who is abducted and made into a woman by a mad, disgraced plastic surgeon whose brother was killed by Frank. This is not as novel a hook as it might initially sound: At times, Mr. Hill‰Ûªs movie, which he wrote with the longtime journalist Denis Hamill, plays like an EC Comics mutation of Pedro AlmodÌ_var‰Ûªs 2011 film, ‰ÛÏThe Skin I Live In.‰Ûù

Because Mr. Hill is still, in most respects, Mr. Hill, a lot of the movie is more watchable than it has a right to be. But ultimately, ‰ÛÏThe Assignment‰Ûù ends up being ridiculous even by its own nonsensical standards.

‰ÛÏThe Assignment‰Ûù is not overtly transphobic, as such, though I‰Ûªd stand down to anyone calling it insensitive. (It‰Ûªs been criticized by Glaad and other gay, bisexual and transgender groups.) But male-gaze presumptuousness is only its most immediate glaring problem. The tricksy structure doesn‰Ûªt have much of a payoff (even though Mr. Hill constructs sequences with deft fluidity). And the role of the surgically altered assassin defeats poor Ms. Rodriguez. Utterly recognizable behind a fake beard during her scenes as a man, she signals her post-surgery confoundedness by making like Marlon Brando in ‰ÛÏThe Wild One‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏOn the Waterfront.‰Ûù (Sigourney Weaver has a better, easier time of it as the haughty surgeon.)

The title character in ‰ÛÏTruman‰Ûù is a dog, but this film‰Ûªs director, Cesc Gay, does not excessively exploit him for cheap sentiment. Given the film‰Ûªs story ‰ÛÓ about JuliÌÁn (Ricardo DarÌ_n), an actor dying of cancer in Madrid, and TomÌÁs, an old friend (Javier CÌÁmara) who visits him for four days ‰ÛÓ it must have been tempting.

The through line here is JuliÌÁn‰Ûªs attempt to find a home for Truman, his beloved bull mastiff. Again, mawkishness is largely sidestepped. But ‰ÛÏTruman‰Ûù has a different flaw: its insistence on excusing tired standards of machismo, however understated. The friend victimized by JuliÌÁn‰Ûªs affair with his wife? He is happily remarried to a much younger woman, now pregnant. The quietly supportive TomÌÁs can express his grief over JuliÌÁn‰Ûªs coming demise only while in bed with JuliÌÁn‰Ûªs cousin, Paula (Dolores Fonzi), after making love ‰ÛÓ that is, by cheating on his own wife. There is sensitivity in ‰ÛÏTruman,‰Ûù but only so much.

This well-made, low-key drama, written by Mr. Gay and TomÌÊs Aragay, offers some insights into terminal illness. JuliÌÁn, a hacking, aging voluptuary, chastises a couple he knows for avoiding him in public because of their inability to face his illness. And he apologizes to a longtime acquaintance, whose wife he once seduced, for causing his divorce. Certainly, JuliÌÁn, played with grizzled authority by Mr. DarÌ_n, is no saint: Visiting his son, Nico (Oriol Pla), who attends college in Amsterdam, he tries to hide the extent of his condition, only to learn afterward that his ex-wife had already informed Nico of it.

I don‰Ûªt want to say too much more about how this works out, but one thing that it means is that Mr. Sudeikis, to some degree, upstages Ms. Hathaway. Both play ingeniously against type, but while she is an anti-princess from the start ‰ÛÓ with some of the thrilling unpleasantness that galvanized ‰ÛÏRachel Getting Married‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ he takes his nice-guy persona and turns it inside out. His affable detachment, which has made him a reliable, if not always memorable, performer, slowly gives way to something darker, stranger and more interesting.

If it weren‰Ûªt for a teasing scene at the beginning and the existence of reviews like this one, you might mistake ‰ÛÏColossal‰Ûù for a certain kind of diffident, funny-sad, exasperating drama. The kind in which a youngish adult, bruised by bad luck and bad decisions, returns to a hometown awash in nostalgia and old friends. Romance and rue, gray skies and dead leaves, whispery song lyrics over sensitively strummed guitars on the soundtrack. I don‰Ûªt know about you, but I saw ‰ÛÏGarden State‰Ûù back in 2004 and don‰Ûªt feel a need to revisit that particular horror.

Mr. Vigalondo, a genre swashbuckler whose oeuvre includes the hectic, Hitchcockian thriller ‰ÛÏOpen Windows,‰Ûù starring Elijah Wood and Sasha Grey, has given that textbook wisdom a new spin. ‰ÛÏColossal‰Ûù has such an easygoing, offhand vibe, and takes such pleasure in its characters‰Ûª foibles, that it camouflages its deep subject, which is rage. Gloria and Oscar only look like slackers. They are twinned ‰ÛÓ and also opposed ‰ÛÓ volcanoes of frustration and resentment. The disproportion between their personal feelings and the wanton destruction of real estate and innocent life is both comical and horrific, and also oddly persuasive. Inside each of us is a colossus with the power to smash everything to pieces.
And ‰ÛÏColossal‰Ûù itself wrings a great deal of fun ‰ÛÓ and also some genuine terror, by no means all of it monster-related ‰ÛÓ from its blithely bizarre conceit.

But not everyone‰Ûªs inner giant is the same. Mr. Vigalondo‰Ûªs film is nowhere near as ambitious or as rigorous as Jordan Peele‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGet Out,‰Ûù but it shares that movie‰Ûªs interest in using horror movie tropes to unlock heavily defended areas of social unease. Starting out as the portrait of an irresponsible woman, ‰ÛÏColossal‰Ûù turns into a critique of male self-pity, as Gloria‰Ûªs problems collide with, and are overwhelmed by, Oscar‰Ûªs sense of aggrieved entitlement.

Oscar and Gloria were in elementary school together, and they catch up at the attractively run-down bar he inherited. He gives her a job, but mostly they hang out after closing time, depleting the liquid inventory with the help of a couple of other familiar small-town, indie-movie types: the bitter wiseacre (Tim Blake Nelson) and the sexy dimwit (Austin Stowell). Like I said: romance and rue, with Life Lessons and Second Chances in the forecast.

Luckily, Nacho Vigalondo, the writer and director of ‰ÛÏColossal,‰Ûù has a different kind of horror in store for us, and for his train-wreck heroine, an unemployed ‰ÛÏinternet writer‰Ûù named Gloria. Played by Anne Hathaway with heavy bangs and a blunt disavowal of her own charm, Gloria has a taste for alcohol and an aversion to honesty. When her fed-up British boyfriend (Dan Stevens) throws her out of the New York apartment they have been sharing, she crawls back to the house of her (conveniently absent) parents in some generically semi-picturesque American place. Her pity party is interrupted by Oscar (Jason Sudeikis), who pulls up in his pickup truck and offers a ride down memory lane.

Except that ‰Û_ frankly, I‰Ûªm reluctant to say, though the movie is, to some extent, spoiler-proofed by its loose, make-it-up-as-we-go-along structure. A giant, lizardlike creature ‰ÛÓ a kaiju, if you insist ‰ÛÓ is terrorizing Seoul, halfway around the world from wherever Oscar and Gloria are. Eventually, it will battle a giant robot. What this has to do with two self-absorbed Americans is at first baffling, then intriguing, and finally obvious. Which doesn‰Ûªt ruin anything. We learned back in ninth-grade English that monsters are metaphors, and it‰Ûªs an insight that never gets old.

Octavia Spencer also pops up in this otherwise fleet-footed film, but the supporting role ‰ÛÓ if you can call it that ‰ÛÓ is paltry. She‰Ûªs brilliant in her few scenes, yet hardly plays as full-fledged a character as she did in another film about mathematicians, ‰ÛÏHidden Figures.‰Ûù If only there were a court for this injustice.

The gifted child here is a 7-year-old math prodigy, Mary (Mckenna Grace, charmingly precocious), who is being raised by her uncle Frank (an impressive Chris Evans). He wants a normal life for Mary; her mother, also a math genius, was under pressure and committed suicide when Mary was a baby. So they live a simple life with their one-eyed cat in Florida, where Frank fixes boat engines; the grime under his nails (and the beer he swigs) suggest that he‰Ûªs firmly rooted in the working class.

Yet Frank and Mary‰Ûªs strong bond ‰ÛÓ one of the film‰Ûªs most convincing parts ‰ÛÓ is tested when he sends her off to the first grade. She‰Ûªs been home-schooled, but Frank thinks it‰Ûªs time she tried ‰ÛÏbeing a kid.‰Ûù While Mary can solve differential equations, she has less-than-advanced social skills and manners. Her teacher (Jenny Slate) recognizes her abilities immediately, and floats the idea that Mary would be better served at a prep school. Frank objects, but it‰Ûªs too late: Soon Frank‰Ûªs rich mother (a haughty Lindsay Duncan) arrives from Boston to usher Mary off to a life of higher learning. Next stop: the local court, where a fight for her ‰ÛÏbest interest‰Ûù ensues, bogging down the story.

What‰Ûªs in a child‰Ûªs best interest? It depends on who‰Ûªs answering the question. That‰Ûªs the crux of ‰ÛÏGifted,‰Ûù the director Marc Webb‰Ûªs return to small-scale features after tangling with Spidey.

Anyway, the director, Zach Braff, better known as that actor from ‰ÛÏScrubs,‰Ûù keeps things moving briskly and surrounds the leads with a well-chosen supporting cast that includes Ann-Margret, John Ortiz and Kenan Thompson. It‰Ûªs strictly comfort food, 99 percent predictable, though the 1 percent that isn‰Ûªt ‰ÛÓ you‰Ûªll know it when you see it ‰ÛÓ is deftly executed.

It‰Ûªs a remake of a 1979 movie that starred three big names on the back end of their careers, George Burns, Art Carney and Lee Strasberg. The new version matches that star power with Michael Caine, Alan Arkin and Morgan Freeman, working amusingly together as retirees who find themselves in need of money or excitement or both and decide to rob a bank.
Call it the old-dudes-acting-up genre. It‰Ûªs always good for a pleasant, nontaxing romp, and that‰Ûªs precisely what the caper film ‰ÛÏGoing in Style‰Ûù delivers.

These types of films always take pains to point out that gray hair and wrinkles don‰Ûªt equal comatose ‰ÛÓ before the story is through, pot has been smoked, vigorous sex has been enjoyed, and the gents have done an almost perfect job of outsmarting the detective (Matt Dillon) who is investigating the robbery. On the other hand, Christopher Lloyd turns up as a wild-eyed eccentric who embodies an awful lot of senior-citizen stereotypes.

You might think of Romeo Aldea (Adrian Titieni) as a helicopter parent, a father whose heavy investment in his daughter‰Ûªs success seems both laudable and a little frightening. For Romeo, a doctor in a provincial Romanian city, Eliza (Maria Dragus) ‰ÛÓ his only child, in her last year of high school ‰ÛÓ represents his only basket and all the eggs inside. He clings to the faith that his thwarted ambition, his battered idealism and his dented self-esteem will all be vindicated if Eliza wins a competitive scholarship to study in England. He and his depressive wife, Magda (Lia Bugnar), who lived in exile before their return to Romania after the end of Communism, are not up to leaving again. Eliza‰Ûªs escape would be an antidote to her father‰Ûªs disappointment with the spiritually and morally desolate place his country has become.

And his sense of superiority to his surroundings ‰ÛÓ the idea that he and Madga uphold values that their compatriots have long since abandoned ‰ÛÓ is challenged. In order to save Eliza‰Ûªs chances, he ventures into the world of favor-trading and back-scratching that he had always disdained, turning to a high-ranking police officer (Vlad Ivanov, a guarantor of Romanian cinematic authenticity) and a local politician (Petre Ciubotaru) in an effort to rig Eliza‰Ûªs test scores. He tries to convince himself (and his accomplices are happy to assure him) that it‰Ûªs all no big deal, just the way things are done.

Compared with what the characters in Mr. Mungiu‰Ûªs other films have faced ‰ÛÓ an illegal abortion in ‰ÛÏ4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days‰Ûù; a fatal exorcism in ‰ÛÏBeyond the Hills‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the predicament of Romeo and his family might seem trivial. But Mr. Mungiu, one of the crucial figures in the post-dictatorship flowering of Romanian cinema, has a gift for infusing daily routines with an almost metaphysical sense of dread. Mr. Titieni, a heavy, serious presence with palpable kindness in his features, makes us believe that nothing less than Romeo‰Ûªs soul is at stake. And Ms. Dragus, who slowly takes possession of the film‰Ûªs moral center, beautifully dramatizes the dilemma of a child who wants to be both obedient and independent. Romeo‰Ûªs dreams for Eliza are rived with contradiction: He wants her to be free, but never imagined that she would want to free herself from him.

‰ÛÏGraduation‰Ûù is long and intense, a rigorously naturalistic film that at times feels as claustrophobic and suspenseful as a horror movie. Like Mr. Mungiu‰Ûªs other work, it is a thriller of sorts, built around an excruciating ethical problem. He is unstinting in his sympathy and unsparing in his judgment. Romeo is a decent man, but his belief in his own decency is a toxic kind of vanity. His actions don‰Ûªt so much make him a hypocrite as reveal him to be yet another of the clueless, puffed-up patriarchs who afflict Romanian cinema (and not only that, of course). And also, for all his sins, a pretty good dad.

‰ÛÏGraduation,‰Ûù Cristian Mungiu‰Ûªs nerve-racking and humane new film, provides plenty of visual and narrative evidence in support of Romeo‰Ûªs pessimism. Mr. Mungiu‰Ûªs camera stalks Romeo through a drab landscape, where ugly old buildings are falling down, and ugly new ones are going up, where gray and brown are the dominant colors, and where nothing quite works. When Eliza is attacked ‰ÛÓ she injures her arm fighting off an attempted rape ‰ÛÓ her father‰Ûªs worst intuitions are confirmed. But his plans are also threatened, since the trauma of the assault threatens to affect her performance on a crucial exam. She is also seeing a boy Romeo doesn‰Ûªt much like. His parental anxiety slides toward panic.

Unavoidably, the material puts Mr. Herzog on geographic and thematic territory previously charted by David Lean. (The heroine, like the protagonist of Mr. Lean‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLawrence of Arabia,‰Ûù is shown in the Nafud Desert, the site of ‰ÛÏthe sun‰Ûªs anvil‰Ûù in that great 1962 film.) T. E. Lawrence himself appears; he is played, in a winking turn, by Robert Pattinson, who can be seen to even better effect ‰ÛÓ in the same period ‰ÛÓ in James Gray‰Ûªs coming ‰ÛÏThe Lost City of Z.‰Ûù

Filmmakers can be the victims of their own histories, and it‰Ûªs tempting to knock ‰ÛÏQueen of the Desert‰Ûù for not being ‰ÛÏAguirre, the Wrath of God‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏFitzcarraldo.‰Ûù The movie, written and directed by Werner Herzog, was largely dismissed when it played at the Berlin Film Festival in 2015 and is only now opening in the United States.
Wrath-of-god level? No. But explorers need to work with what they find.

Mr. Herzog‰Ûªs aesthetic adventurousness also makes him a bit of a mismatch with the conventional way he has chosen to relay Bell‰Ûªs exploits, which include attempts to make inroads with the Bedouins and the Druse and (eventually) advising the British on the carving up of the Middle East. Bell is embodied, in a commanding and versatile performance, by Nicole Kidman, who supplies a gravitas and emotional complexity worthy of the woman she plays.

That makes him a natural fit to tell the life story of Gertrude Bell, the British adventurer, archaeologist and linguist who has been labeled the female Lawrence of Arabia. (One of her less couth colleagues in the film calls her a ‰ÛÏchattering windbag of conceited, gushing, heavy-chested man-woman.‰Ûù)

But if Mr. Herzog mostly seems content to follow Hollywood rules, there are respects in which he improves on them. He has cast Arab actors in Arab roles, a change from the practice in Mr. Lean‰Ûªs era. And unlike Mr. Lean, he doesn‰Ûªt sentimentalize the landscape, which is not to say that ‰ÛÏQueen of the Desert‰Ûù is an ugly film. Even the stodgiest biopic would be redeemed by Mr. Herzog‰Ûªs eye. The shots that track Bell into her meetings with Arab leaders may have you catching your breath.

The first half dwells on Bell‰Ûªs romance with a junior diplomat (James Franco, surprisingly credible as a dashing Brit). In one of the few moments that smacks of true Herzogian weirdness, Mr. Franco‰Ûªs character takes Bell to the top of a tower where human remains have been left and asks to kiss her in front of a vulture. By the time Bell‰Ûªs affections turn to a married miliary officer (Damian Lewis), the movie has abandoned most of its eccentricities.

Mr. Herzog has spent his career making movies about quixotic quests. When these films are at their finest, Mr. Herzog can seem as driven and half-mad as his characters. Like his heroes, he has plunged into the Amazon to face what he once called, in the documentary ‰ÛÏGrizzly Man,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏthe overwhelming indifference of nature.‰Ûù

Over all, the movie, directed by Dan Harris and featuring name actors like Kal Penn and Janeane Garofalo in small roles, has a focus problem that leaves its humorous moments obscured and its intentions hazy.

The film is an adaptation by Stephen Karam (a hot playwright thanks to ‰ÛÏThe Humans‰Ûù) of his own play, which had a run in New York in 2007. It‰Ûªs about three high school students who band together to rail against grown-up hypocrisies and to try to create a forum where they can express themselves.

The three form a debate club, and a trip to a state competition that goes hilariously wrong is the film‰Ûªs high point. A later scene involving a preposterous musical number staged in front of the school board is supposed to be the climax but was probably funnier onstage than it is here.

Diwata (Sarah Steele, who played the role onstage a decade ago) is a musical-theater nut with an interesting take on ‰ÛÏThe Crucible.‰Ûù Howie (Austin P. McKenzie) is a gay student at a school that doesn‰Ûªt want to acknowledge the existence of gay students. Solomon (Liam James) wants to do crusading student journalism but is frustrated by censorship.

At any high school anywhere, there are always students who don‰Ûªt quite fit in, and it‰Ûªs a good thing there are, because an entire genre of movies and television shows wouldn‰Ûªt exist without them. ‰ÛÏSpeech & Debate‰Ûù is the latest film to explore that universe, doing so with some interesting performances in an indistinct package.

Yet the script is incapable of penetrating the moral thicket that the actors and the cinematographer, Zachary Galler, have so carefully woven. Ambiguities are hacked away, until what‰Ûªs left feels more like a salute to karma than like a candid reckoning with a gift that‰Ûªs as much curse as miracle.

For perhaps the first time, James (an exceptional Dan Stevens) is experiencing temptation. The shrinking of a pituitary tumor has restored the sight he lost as a teenager, and he‰Ûªs less than happy with what he sees. On a quest to upgrade his home, his job (as a mortgage-refinancing drone), and his wife (the gorgeous Malin Akerman, here reverse-engineered to look homely), James becomes the epitome of soulless ambition.

‰ÛÏYou don‰Ûªt want to lose control,‰Ûù he tells his wife when she balks at his newly unilateral decision-making. An image makeover and an affair with a sexy co-worker (Kerry BishÌ©) accompany his corporate ascent, but it‰Ûªs his psychological torment that the director, Ido Fluk, is most eager to plumb, and he does so with captivating sensuousness.

There are some gnarly questions ‰ÛÓ of faith, love and self-worth, for starters ‰ÛÓ at the heart of ‰ÛÏThe Ticket,‰Ûù if only its makers had chosen to address them. Instead, this unquestionably adult drama about a blind man who can suddenly see unfolds with an emotional sophistication that far outstrips its narrative nerve.

For a while, this makes ‰ÛÏThe Ticket‰Ûù a fascinating character study expressed through whispered conversations and flickering light and shade. Its emotions ‰ÛÓ like the jealousy of James‰Ûªs blind best friend (Oliver Platt) ‰ÛÓ feel brutally honest, as does its understanding of the allure of being desired without being pitied.

Young Milo has problems. Not only is he picked on by the bullies in the New York public-housing complex where he lives, but he also craves human blood. As if an impoverished adolescence weren‰Ûªt messy enough.

Milo lives with his older, protective brother, Lewis (a worthy Aaron Clifton Moten); their parents are dead. Milo ‰ÛÓ often sequestered in his bedroom, studying his videotape horror library (including ‰ÛÏThe Lost Boys,‰Ûù but also Michael Almereyda‰Ûªs indie ‰ÛÏNadja‰Ûù) ‰ÛÓ meticulously maintains a journal of his sanguinary pursuits. When he meets Sophie (Chloe Levine), a neighbor living with an abusive grandparent, she appreciates his quiet, intelligent sensitivity. Of course, his penchant for graphically violent documentaries is off-putting, but nevertheless they form a relationship, which is eventually threatened when she discovers his notebooks.

We never quite learn how Milo (Eric Ruffin of ‰ÛÏThe Good Wife‰Ûù) becomes a vampire in Michael O‰ÛªShea‰Ûªs modestly appealing debut feature, ‰ÛÏThe Transfiguration,‰Ûù or whether he simply imagines he is one and kills accordingly. But there are clues as to why. Most concern empowerment.

Ms. Levine strives with her underwritten role as a flailing rag doll with a dream. Mr. Ruffin must carry the film, projecting interior activity and suggesting information where the script (by Mr. O‰ÛªShea) does not. That he imbues the film with a weight greater than its words is a testament to his skill as an actor. But ‰ÛÏThe Transfiguration‰Ûù does have something to say about class and the sometimes raging consequences of economic deprivation. And does so ‰ÛÓ forgive me ‰ÛÓ with taste.

Love and laughter flow so naturally in ‰ÛÏTheir Finest‰Ûù that it is almost (almost) easy to forget there‰Ûªs a war on. An unalloyed charmer, the movie tells a story of familiar British grit and resolve during World War II from an attractively different angle: that of an advertising copywriter, Catrin Cole (Gemma Arterton), who‰Ûªs recruited by the government to join the film industry. Britain wants the United States to enter the war, and has decided cinematic propaganda is the way it can persuade the movie-mad Yanks to sign up. The world is facing a historic catastrophe, after all; but for this ambitious young woman it‰Ûªs also a bittersweet opportunity.

It‰Ûªs the latest addition to an appealing British subgenre: the home-front story that reminds you that among grim air raids and explosions, people also just lived their lives, sometimes with laughter and unexpected new freedoms, as in John Boorman‰Ûªs 1987 autobiographical film, ‰ÛÏHope and Glory,‰Ûù about childhood during the Blitz. The director of ‰ÛÏTheir Finest,‰Ûù Lone Scherfig, is Danish (her breakthrough was ‰ÛÏItalian for Beginners‰Ûù), but she has carved out a curious niche making British period stories, most notably ‰ÛÏAn Education.‰Ûù She has fine timing and wit ‰ÛÓ the behind-the-scenes filmmaking sections in ‰ÛÏTheir Finest‰Ûù are delightful, note-perfect sendups ‰ÛÓ and while her visuals tend to be overly buffed, she‰Ûªs more ambitious with her performers, who retain their rough, human edges.

After being called up to duty, Catrin is paired with Tom Buckley (Sam Claflin), a dyspeptic screenwriter who nonetheless grasps her talent. With British men off fighting the Nazis, the domestic film industry needs all the help it can get, even if this means deviating from its entrenched sexism. For Catrin, who‰Ûªs shacked up in a bleak London flat with her husband, Ellis (Jack Huston), the new career and its opportunities are as welcome as the pay. La vie bohÌ¬me doesn‰Ûªt seem to be cutting it, especially because Ellis ‰ÛÓ a struggling painter given to slashing, cluttered canvases in shades of dung (the movie is clearly on the side of the popular arts) ‰ÛÓ insists on stirring up trouble.

As the film-within-the film progresses and as Catrin struggles with her own drama (and romantic agonies worthy of a classic women‰Ûªs picture), a few others muscle into the boys‰Ûª club, including Phyl (Rachael Stirling), a dispenser of feminist truths in slacks. The character who most beautifully embodies the story‰Ûªs ideals, though, is Sophie (Helen McCrory), who, as a talent agent, brings man and dog to heel in a few short, barbed scenes. She‰Ûªs the kind of no-nonsense woman you can imagine contributed to the real war effort, including in the film industry. ‰ÛÏTheir Finest‰Ûù is too understandably serious to be called a romp, yet it has a buoyancy that lifts you and, in Ms. McCrory, a woman who does, too.

A pleasant, somewhat stolid presence, Ms. Arterton nonetheless manages, mostly through sheer screen time, to create a character who can hold her own against these free-ranging peacocks, none prouder and screechier than Buckley, a romantic foil whose sourness Mr. Claflin keeps in check with glints of soul. It‰Ûªs an alluring performance, pitched between leathery guardedness and vulnerability, and spiked with the genial self-abnegation that defined Hugh Grant‰Ûªs early career. Mr. Claflin could have run off with ‰ÛÏTheir Finest,‰Ûù except that he‰Ûªs just one in a gang of wily thieves who include Eddie Marsan, Jeremy Irons, Jake Lacy, Richard E. Grant (king of the reaction shots) and that sly puss Bill Nighy as a faded star in permanent high dudgeon over his career.

Adapted by Gabby Chiappe from a novel by Lissa Evans, ‰ÛÏTheir Finest‰Ûù settles into focus once Catrin and Buckley start working on a film intended to rally the United States to the cause. Initially assigned to writing ‰ÛÏthe slop,‰Ûù or women‰Ûªs dialogue, Catrin quickly rises to the occasion, typing reams of dialogue while gracefully, sometimes messily navigating a crowd of tetchy narcissists, mostly male. Even with so many men away at war, Catrin is outnumbered at work, which makes sense, given the film industry. Yet partly because ‰ÛÏTheir Finest‰Ûù is so wonderfully cast, both Ms. Arterton and her character often come close to being upstaged by their scene-stealing male cohort, a somewhat perilous turn for a female-driven story about a woman finding herself and her voice.

Mr. Shinkai plays with the obvious comedy of Mitsuha and Taki‰Ûªs surreal changeover, and, as confusion gives way to a realization of what‰Ûªs happening, they adjust. Mitsuha, delighted to find herself sometimes living in Tokyo, adapts surprisingly well to Taki‰Ûªs body and, especially, his habit of visiting cafes (where she gorges on sweets, spending his money). There are tricky moments, too, like her unexpected, chaste flirtation with Taki‰Ûªs female co-worker, who warms to his new ‰ÛÏfeminine‰Ûù side. Other than Taki‰Ûªs borrowed breasts (which he continues to enjoy in vaguely onanistic fashion), he mostly goes with the flow when he‰Ûªs in Mitsuha‰Ûªs body, sometimes with messy hair and manspreading.

It isn‰Ûªt until well into ‰ÛÏYour Name,‰Ûù a wistfully lovely Japanese tale about fate and time, that its two teenage characters meet. By that point, Mitsuha (a girl yearning to leave her small town) and Taki (a boy in Tokyo) have come to know each other as well as two people can. For reasons they don‰Ûªt understand, each‰Ûªs consciousness has been temporarily jumping into the other‰Ûªs physical shell, only to jump back. This happens at night, which means that Mitsuha regularly wakes up in Taki‰Ûªs body, and he wakes up in hers, a swap that he likes to confirm by fondling his (her) breasts.

It‰Ûªs thoroughly charming and gently comic and, if Mr. Shinkai finally plays it safe about what it means for an adolescent boy and girl to trade bodies and lightly toy with gender, he complicates the story in other ways. Gradually, elements that at first seem like contextual details ‰ÛÓ a Shinto temple; a racing comet; and a traditional sake called kuchikamizake, fermented with the spit of a virgin ‰ÛÓ shift from background to foreground, becoming part of the body-switching story. It‰Ûªs a narrative progression that at certain moments is echoed by the actual animation, as when the smudged, watercolorlike landscapes movingly overwhelm the cartoonish forms of Mitsuha and Taki.

By the time these two (and you) have figured out what‰Ûªs happening, and why, Mr. Shinkai has set another change in motion, and ‰ÛÏYour Name‰Ûù has shifted from a comedy of confusion into a deeply moving meditation on nation, history, catastrophe and memory. It‰Ûªs a touching, soaring switcheroo, one that Mr. Shinkai achieves with help from Masayoshi Tanaka, who did the character design, and Masashi Ando, the animation director and a veteran of Studio Ghibli. ‰ÛÏYour Name‰Ûù is being released in the United States in Japanese ‰ÛÓ Ryunosuke Kamiki voices Taki; Mone Kamishiraishi voices Mitsuha ‰ÛÓ and in an English dub. If possible, stick with the original.

There‰Ûªs more to their confusion than they can fathom, which is understandable, given the trippy complications conceived by the film‰Ûªs writer-director, Makoto Shinkai. ‰ÛÏYour Name‰Ûù is a body switching story, but it‰Ûªs also about tradition and impermanence, disasters and destinies. For Mitsuha and Taki, there are other, more immediate concerns, like being profoundly alienated from the body each is actually inhabiting, which, of course, is another way to describe adolescence (and other maladies). The story opens just as Mitsuha awakens ‰ÛÓ or, rather, her physical body does ‰ÛÓ and a shocked Taki realizes that he‰Ûªs crossed over an inexplicable rainbow. Meanwhile, back at his home in Tokyo, a horrified Mitsuha, now somehow in this boy‰Ûªs body, registers that he/she has to use the bathroom.

As caressing goes, it‰Ûªs about as clean a scene as it gets, partly because Taki is an anime character, which means that there‰Ûªs a cartoonish quality to how his enormous, jewel-like eyes widen, and how patches of red bloom on his smooth cheeks. He‰Ûªs embarrassed, and while you may laugh ‰ÛÓ in sympathy, in recognition or just because it‰Ûªs a funny setup ‰ÛÓ his familiar anime look, his pert nose and pointy chin, as well as some of his expressions, put distance between you and him. The beauty of ‰ÛÏYour Name‰Ûù is that, as in the best animated movies, the thin black lines of the character design invariably dissolve, and all that remains are Taki and Mitsuha, thoroughly mixed-up teenagers.

Movies are filled with body snatchers and switchers, some malevolent and others benign, and ranging from science-fiction freakouts to Disney staples like ‰ÛÏFreaky Friday,‰Ûù about a girl and a mother swapping bodies and problems. A lot of these stories skew comic (body anxiety can be good for giggles), and they usually involve an outrageous exchange that turns into an exercise in radical empathy: Two people trade places, and each is forced to experience what the other does and feels. In a sense this kind of swap, even at its goofiest, evokes the transporting process of the fictional experience as we ‰ÛÓ viewers, readers and gamers ‰ÛÓ temporarily inhabit another being‰Ûªs consciousness.

Still, the story breaks ‰ÛÏunique views‰Ûù records for the government-aligned website Julia oversees ‰ÛÓ mostly by people ridiculing Tzanko in the comments section. Things turn even more awkward: Julia confiscates Tzanko‰Ûªs wristwatch, which he calls Glory (it‰Ûªs an heirloom of sorts), and substitutes it with his chintzy digital award. Tzanko‰Ûªs quest to get the original watch back results in a bureaucratic nightmare.

Not a predictable one, however, which is all to the benefit of this incisive, funny cinematic parable, shot and edited in a disarming, documentarylike style. (A lot of shallow-focus, follow-the-character sequences lend the story a bracing immediacy.) . Julia and her husband are trying to have a child, and for a while this plot thread seems an odd way to solicit sympathy for a character who behaves monstrously more than 85 percent of the time. As it happens, the filmmakers have something quite a bit more grim up their sleeves. The variable incongruities of ‰ÛÏGlory‰Ûù give it a queasy power uncommon in contemporary cinema. It‰Ûªs the feel-bad movie of the spring.
‰ÛÏWhy don‰Ûªt I just film some other guy?‰Ûù a functionary offers to Julia, not so helpfully.

In his dimly lit apartment, Tzanko sets his analog wristwatch, eats his breakfast, puts on his fluorescent-orange vest and sets off to work. And on this day he discovers a substantial amount of cash strewn about on the tracks he helps maintain, but instead of stuffing his pockets he reports the find. While his colleagues take to mocking him dryly (over beers later on, they point out a bill on the floor of the bar and ask him what he‰Ûªs going to do about it), higher-ups in the organization decide to celebrate him.

The ensuing media to-do is not a conventional success. Managed by a harried publicist, Julia (Margita Gosheva), who wears mostly sleeveless dresses and has a habit of placing folded tissues under her arms during stressful times (which are plentiful), the campaign has a hard time assimilating the shaggy, stammering Tzanko.

It‰Ûªs always been difficult to be an honest, moral person in a corrupt world, and as ‰ÛÏGlory,‰Ûù a new movie from Bulgaria, demonstrates, it‰Ûªs also increasingly ridiculous. Directed by Kristina Grozeva and Petar Valchanov from a script they wrote with Decho Taralezhkov, ‰ÛÏGlory‰Ûù opens on a typically colorless morning (we infer) for Tzanko, a bushy-haired state-railroad employee portrayed by Stefan Denolyubov. His extravagant beard will immediately register as the kind that is not a hipster accouterment.

Both the old cars and Dom‰Ûªs unsteadiness set up a movie that clearly still needs to contend with Mr. Walker‰Ûªs death even as it delivers the goods. To that end, the filmmakers quickly isolate Dom from his crew (Tyrese Gibson, Ludacris, et al.) and give him a proxy heartbreak. Elsewhere, the franchise‰Ûªs increasingly most valuable players, Dwayne Johnson and the bouncy Jason Statham, take care of business, going hard and funny. Kurt Russell shows up as a man in black with a newbie played by Scott Eastwood, whose resemblance to Big Daddy Clint adds intertextual genre frisson. Charlize Theron slinks in as a villainous hacker in silly blond dreads, jetting around while doing a lot of fast, furious typing.

Zoom, crash, repeat with squealing, burning and flaming tires ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs all predictably absurd and self-mocking, and often a giggle when not a total yawn. The tedium that sets in is a function of the blockbuster ethos in which everything must smash and ignite so that a solitary man can emerge phoenix-like to fight another franchise fight. Yet while Dom endures baptisms of fire, he is never genuinely alone. Part of the draw of the ‰ÛÏFast and Furious‰Ûù movies has always been their multicultural cast, but the series‰Ûª strength is a utopian communitarianism that insists the group must be greater than any one man or nation. That‰Ûªs why Dom will only ever be the franchise‰Ûªs co-pilot; it‰Ûªs the crew that rules.

Family is the most important word in these movies, the one that‰Ûªs dropped with moist emotion and hushed Sunday-sermon reverence. It‰Ûªs the idea that has held the franchise together ‰ÛÓ movie to movie, race to race, prayer to prayer ‰ÛÓ in an episodic soap about kith, kin and custom cars. It‰Ûªs what connects this franchise to its fans, another kind of family, though one that pays to sit down at the table. It‰Ûªs what has always bound Dom to his wife, Letty (Michelle Rodriguez), and the rest of his crew, most crucially Brian, the cop-turned-soul-partner played by Paul Walker, who died in an off-set car collision in 2013.

Mr. Gray, an action-movie veteran, gets that party started quickly. Dom and Letty are hanging out in the new Havana, which in this case means chatting in Spanish and English while checking out a vintage car with a boat motor under the hood. It‰Ûªs a nice emblem of the movie‰Ûªs old-school opener, which involves some macho posturing that leads to Dom racing in a rusted-out beater. As he drives, ripping past one classic American car after another, he clutches the wheel, the camera pointing up at him. Like a supermodel‰Ûªs long legs, Mr. Diesel‰Ûªs sculptured, often-bared arms are one of his trademarks, and they do a lot of work, signifying strength and command. Here, though, they shudder.

The new movie‰Ûªs title, ‰ÛÏThe Fate of the Furious,‰Ûù seems like a nod to the lingering existential crisis created by Mr. Walker‰Ûªs death, as do the tears that fall in the story. They‰Ûªre shed over time but before they are, the movie does what‰Ûªs expected, which is cut loose attractive characters in different choreographed formations in assorted machines and locales. Directed by F. Gary Gray (‰ÛÏStraight Outta Compton‰Ûù), this one opens in Havana, where the young local beauties swirling around Dom and Letty move and dress more or less like the other young beauties in the series, as if they were part of a continuing global house party, this time with Che Guevara and prettily peeling buildings.

Punctuated by crashes and drums of doom, the movie moves to a dependable blockbuster beat, as a little exposition is followed by an action scene, and more exposition is followed by a bigger, noisier, nuttier action scene. As the cars zig and the story line zags, these sequences grow baroque, defying reason and gravity, which have progressively come under siege in this franchise. In New York, cars swan-dive off buildings or cut corners like rampaging dogs or, outfitted with Bond-like gizmos, harpoon a bucking ride. There‰Ûªs an odd Melville thing going on here: In a Bond-esque battle in Russia that typifies the franchise‰Ûªs expanded reach, a submarine breaches like Moby-Dick.

One of the givens of ‰ÛÏFast and Furious‰Ûù is that the latest movie will be bigger and more enjoyably ludicrous than the last. The miniskirts will be shorter, the toys zoomier, the stunts more delirious. Yet, like every successful series, this one delivers its sleek new bits and pieces in reassuringly familiar packaging. James Bond has queen and country. Vin Diesel‰Ûªs Dominic Toretto ‰ÛÓ the monotonal ‰ÛÏFast and Furious‰Ûù paterfamilias ‰ÛÓ has cars and camaraderie, an ideal combo for movies about American outsiders whose home has always been one another.
For all its visual and sonic pleasures ‰ÛÓ see it in a theater with a good subwoofer ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏAll These Sleepless Nights‰Ûù feels simple-minded in its commitment to drift above all else.

Favoring lyricism above substance, ‰ÛÏAll These Sleepless Nights‰Ûù is almost a pure right-brain movie. What it omits may be as interesting as what‰Ûªs onscreen. Older adults rarely appear, and money is apparently no object. (When Kris moves into his own apartment, we‰Ûªre probably meant to enjoy the gorgeous skyline view instead of asking about the rent.)

‰ÛÏI wonder whose life they got the data from,‰Ûù he asks in voice-over. Your own inclination to ask such questions, instead of surrendering, may be a litmus test for your enjoyment of Michal Marczak‰Ûªs movie, a sometimes entrancing, sometimes tiresomely coy documentary-fiction hybrid that sketches Kris‰Ûªs young adulthood in a blur of moony impressions.

Mr. Marczak‰Ûªs impressive, weightless-seeming camera work follows Kris and his roommate and friend Michal (Michal Huszcza) on an odyssey of romantic confusion. They flirt with women, attend parties until dawn and gyrate to a perpetual backbeat. Kris in particular can‰Ûªt stop dancing, even ‰ÛÓ as the precious finale has it ‰ÛÓ in street traffic.

As the Warsaw-set ‰ÛÏAll These Sleepless Nights‰Ûù begins, the protagonist, Kris (Krzysztof Baginski), relates some unattributed wisdom. He has heard that if you tallied a lifetime‰Ûªs experiences, you would get seven months of sex, 17 hours of breakups and 51 days of deciding what to wear.
The actors, if that‰Ûªs the word, play characters who share their names. (There are moments, as when Kris smacks his head against a pole, when the film seems devoted to accidents.)

Ms. Suwichakornpong has suggested that ‰ÛÏBy the Time It Gets Dark‰Ûù is a reflection on the impossibility of making a historical film. More directly, it seems to concern the difficulty of getting into another‰Ûªs shoes.

‰ÛÏBy the Time It Gets Dark‰Ûù has clearly been thought through, but it‰Ûªs so cryptic that it cries out for, if not perfect explanations, perhaps footnotes. It‰Ûªs so conceptual that it offers little for those not in sync.

In the most easy-to-follow scenes, we meet one of the former student protesters in the present day (initially played by Rassami Paoluengtong) as she shares her recollections with a filmmaker (Visra Vichit-Vadakan, at first) writing a screenplay about her. ‰ÛÏI appropriate someone‰Ûªs life and turn it into a film,‰Ûù the filmmaker explains. ‰ÛÏMaybe because my life is quite mundane.‰Ûù

In a baffling midpoint rupture, the movie abandons its principal characters and shifts focus to an actor (Arak Amornsupasiri). An earlier scene is restaged with different cast members. Another scene turns out to be a movie within the movie.

‰ÛÏBy the Time It Gets Dark,‰Ûù the second feature from the Thai director Anocha Suwichakornpong, tiptoes around an event in October 1976, when students at Thammasat University in Bangkok were violently suppressed while protesting the return of a military leader.

That context is never fully clarified in the movie, a continually mutating narrative that has little interest in providing bearings or telling a straightforward story, though we see the crackdown staged for a photo shoot, and the preparation for the protests in a flashback.

The director, John Scheinfeld (‰ÛÏThe U.S. vs. John Lennon‰Ûù), has amassed a wide array of Mr. Coltrane‰Ûªs collaborators, friends, influences and chroniclers (including Ben Ratliff, formerly of The New York Times). But for every talking head with serious musical insight, like Wynton Marsalis, we get another like Bill Clinton ‰ÛÓ a jazz fan, but probably mostly present because he was too prominent to cut.

The film shows other signs of injudicious editing. ‰ÛÏWe were there for a reason, which was to create beautiful music,‰Ûù says the pianist McCoy Tyner of playing with the John Coltrane Quartet, adding with a laugh, ‰ÛÏI use the word ‰Û÷beautiful‰Ûª because I can‰Ûªt think of a better word.‰Ûù Carlos Santana and John Densmore, the Doors‰Ûª drummer, offer fawning platitudes.
But while the recordings are wall-to-wall, this somewhat busy documentary rarely accords time for simply listening.

‰ÛÏChasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary‰Ûù portrays the legendary saxophonist as a tirelessly forward-thinking artist. (His music, the philosopher Cornel West says in the film, was more of a thermostat than a thermometer.) But as a biographical movie, ‰ÛÏChasing Trane‰Ûù sticks to a conventional, dully informative format. Its ideal venue is a Coltrane tribute event or a classroom.

More productive, this film includes Mr. Coltrane‰Ûªs performances, along with home movies, family interviews and the musician‰Ûªs own words, read by Denzel Washington. Occasionally it delves into musical analysis, discussing how spirituality and events (the 1963 church bombing in Birmingham, a 1966 visit to Nagasaki) affected Mr. Coltrane‰Ûªs compositions, style and shows.
The barbarity described in ‰ÛÏFinding Oscar‰Ûù is stomach-turning, but moments of courage still shine through in this unsettling yet vital documentary.

The film, directed by Ryan Suffern, at times plays out like a thriller as witnesses come forward and skeletons are exhumed. Mr. Suffern‰Ûªs pacing is energized but respectful, and his script, written with Mark Monroe, smartly summarizes events of the time.

Despite recounting brutality, ‰ÛÏFinding Oscar‰Ûù manages to generate some hope as human-rights workers, prosecutors and forensic scientists seek justice for victims of these war crimes. What starts out as a study of savagery becomes a lesson in determination.

Two boys were abducted and then reared by soldiers‰Ûª families. One boy, Oscar RamÌ_rez, was 3 and grew to believe that the people raising him were his real family. Years later investigators began a search for Oscar ‰ÛÓ as an adult, he‰Ûªd moved to the United States ‰ÛÓ deeming him to be ‰ÛÏliving evidence‰Ûù of the mass killing. If he were located, a DNA sample could be obtained; that would match bodies at the site, and strengthen a case against the soldiers accused of the murders.

In 1982, a band of Guatemalan soldiers entered the tiny village of Dos Erres, looking for anti-government guerrillas. They found none, and soon began raping and murdering the residents. More than 200 bodies, some still alive, were thrown into a well and buried.
Finding him, though, would create a problem. ‰ÛÏHow do you tell someone, ‰Û÷You‰Ûªre not who you think you are, and your life up until now has been a lie‰Ûª?‰Ûù one interviewee says.

The organ in question is a human heart, which first belongs to Simon (Gabin Verdet), a tow-haired surfer of 17, before being transplanted into the body of Claire (Anne Dorval), a dying mother of two doting college-age sons. Between those events lies a voluptuous wallow in sound and image, at times so captivating that we barely notice it‰Ûªs an ideational wasteland.

If you have ever been moved to tears by a television commercial, then prepare to be devastated by ‰ÛÏHeal the Living,‰Ûù one of the most gorgeous and beautifully acted sales pitches you are ever likely to encounter. What you‰Ûªre being asked to buy, however, is not cereal or sugary soda; no, this juggernaut of sentiment ‰ÛÓ whether intentionally or not ‰ÛÓ plays like nothing so much as a hugely expensive advertisement for organ donation.

Moving among three distinct groups of people ‰ÛÓ Simon‰Ûªs grieving parents (Emmanuelle Seigner and Kool Shen), his medical team and Claire and her family ‰ÛÓ the director, Katell QuillÌ©vÌ©rÌ©, exerts a firm grip on the story‰Ûªs emotional calculus. Working with the cinematographer Tom Harari (and from the 2014 novel by Maylis de Kerangal), she constructs distractingly dreamy scenes that cleverly, repeatedly, bring characters toward us: Simon sliding through the barrel of a monster wave; Juliette, in flashback, gliding forward as if on invisible wires.

And so we are mesmerized by an opening sequence that fluidly follows Simon from the bed of his girlfriend, Juliette (GalatÌ©a Bellugi), to the early-morning ocean. The velvety silence and slow-swelling breakers lead us seamlessly to a car, a sleepy driver and a road that appears to dissolve into rippling water ‰ÛÓ brain death delivered with tender poetry.

Small personal details, like the erotic fantasies of a novice nurse and a transplant specialist‰Ûªs love of goldfinches, lend color without meaning, functioning merely as simplistic reminders that medical professionals are people, too. In the background, Alexandre Desplat‰Ûªs swoony score piles on the sentiment, but it‰Ûªs all just empty calories; what this movie desperately needs is conflict.

Unlike Simon, tunneling fearlessly beneath the water, ‰ÛÏHeal the Living‰Ûù is content to skate on the surface, leaving as little lasting impression on our minds as Simon‰Ûªs surfboard on the deep blue ocean.

Not a chance. Here, everyone is loving and admirable and largely untroubled by religious or philosophical considerations. Simon‰Ûªs parents may be separated, but they make the decision to donate without real argument or extensive soul-searching. The transplant liaison is compassionate to an almost laughable degree, halting Simon‰Ûªs organ removal to place the sound of surf in his ears. And the recipient, a beautiful musician whose estranged lover returns at exactly the right moment, could not be more worthy if she were tending to a houseful of orphans.

Gina (Melanie Lynskey), who is white, and Mack (Nelsan Ellis), who is black, move from trendy and comfortably diverse Brooklyn so that she can take a new job in a small town in Washington State. Their son, Clark (Armani Jackson), is getting ready to start sixth grade.

Their new community has apparently never seen such a family, but the reaction of the locals isn‰Ûªt hostility, it‰Ûªs awkwardness. Everyone tries too hard, and no one tries harder than two girls (Miranda McKeon and Oona Laurence) who befriend Clark. They‰Ûªre eager to fit him into their idea of what a black child should be.

Rob Meyer, directing a script by Annie J. Howell, could easily have made this a movie about those reactions, which seem a little last century; the list of towns where a biracial couple is a novelty is fairly short at this point. Instead, he smartly stays focused on Gina, Mack and Clark, who in different ways are thrown out of their comfort zones by the reception they receive. Countless movies have examined what happens when a country mouse goes to the city; this one shows that leaving a gentrified urban oasis for a small-town world can be just as jolting.

‰ÛÏLittle Boxes,‰Ûù a mildly comic story about a biracial family that relocates to an exceedingly white town, feels a bit out of phase, but it‰Ûªs delicately observed and does a nice job of staying within itself. It avoids the big confrontation or grand statement; doing so allows it to be an effective, if somewhat uneventful, study of the Brooklyn bubble effect.

‰ÛÏI think he‰Ûªs one of the greatest artists that we have today ‰ÛÓ but he could also be the worst,‰Ûù a collector says in ‰ÛÏMaurizio Cattelan: Be Right Back.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs one of several bits of hyperbole in a documentary that works best when it stops overanalyzing its subject and instead focuses on his mischievous art.

When the experts arrive, the fun stalls. There‰Ûªs blather about artists as brands, and attempts to study Mr. Cattelan‰Ûªs past. Opposing voices or opinions from museumgoers are scarce, while professional assessments are neither novel enough to challenge the art enthusiast nor clear enough to engage the newcomer.

When Maura Axelrod, the film‰Ûªs director, examines those and recalls Mr. Cattelan‰Ûªs pranks (including his use of doppelgÌ_ngers, and a time when he broke into a gallery, stole objects and exhibited them as his own), the result is uproarious and thought-provoking. It‰Ûªs hard not to grin at his huge sculpture, placed outside a stock exchange, of a raised middle finger, or to be awed by his 2011 retrospective, which hung from a truss atop the Guggenheim‰Ûªs rotunda.

Still, the art is the star and Ms. Axelrod features plenty of it. She also outlines a knowing path through Mr. Cattelan‰Ûªs career, leaving just enough room to have you wondering if the artist is more of a con man than a genius. On that, make your own decision. No expert is needed.

For more than 20 years Mr. Cattelan has garnered praise and scorn for his works, like a sculpture of Pope John Paul II struck by a meteorite; a functioning 18-karat-gold toilet; and a statue of a praying Adolf Hitler.

Don‰Ûªt take my word for it, though: Time itself is unreliable in this sometimes beautiful, always cryptic tale. Set in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco, the story follows a small caravan of nomads transporting a dying sheikh to his final resting place in the legendary golden city of Sijilmasa. But when the sheikh dies and two roguish members of the entourage want to bail on their hazardous mission, up pops Shakib (a rivetingly weird Shakib Ben Omar) ‰ÛÓ armed with a quiverful of faith-based harangues ‰ÛÓ to urge them to continue.

Emphasizing the puniness of men‰Ûªs desires against the majesty of the mountains, the cinematographer, Mauro Herce, seems to argue that the question is irrelevant. Flying high and wide, he forges belief and fear into a bond with a landscape that doesn‰Ûªt care whose wishes prevail. The naturalistic sound design agrees, sifting scrabbling stones and rushing water into the thrumming silence of snow and sand. The sum is a movie that panders not at all to Western sensibilities, giving few pointers on a theme beyond the fortifying power of faith. For some viewers, that will be plenty.

At best ambiguous and at worst unfathomable, ‰ÛÏMimosas,‰Ûù the sophomore feature from the Spanish director Oliver Laxe, merges harsh reality and offbeat mysticism into a reflection on the tug between our higher powers and baser instincts.

We have seen Shakib earlier, in a more modern setting, preaching inexpertly to a crowd of mocking cabdrivers who treat him as some kind of holy fool. Is he a guardian angel or the Devil‰Ûªs helper, leading the men to their doom?

The movie‰Ûªs flat animation style ‰ÛÓ Jane Samborski is the lead animator ‰ÛÓ and purposefully crude character depictions are initially deceptive. (Its personages look as if they‰Ûªve been drawn with a Sharpie, in a style reminiscent of Charles M. Schulz and Gary Panter.) As the picture continues, its brightly colored visuals grow ever more psychedelic and phantasmagoric. This makes the mode of narrative and humor ‰ÛÓ which I‰Ûªll call strained, half-curdled, self-regarding millennial whimsy ‰ÛÓ go down a little easier. The voice work, from a cast that also includes Jason Schwartzman and Lena Dunham, is very good, though not unexpected.

Hot on the heels of ‰ÛÏThe Death of Louis XIV‰Ûù comes another candidate for Most Accurately Titled Film of 2017. Tenderhearted readers, fear not; this is neither a documentary nor a live-action depiction. ‰ÛÏMy Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea,‰Ûù written and directed by Dash Shaw, is an eccentric and lively animated fantasy.

‰ÛÏHigh School‰Ûù opens as many high school movies do, with a bus ride. During this one, the dorky hero, Dash (yes, this is one of those films in which the creator is also its vexed but lovable lead character), chats with his best buddy, Assaf (voiced by Reggie Watts), about their work for the school paper, whose editor, Verti (Maya Rudolph), will come between the two. But teenage angst and jealousy are soon to take a back seat to survival after an earthquake pitches the cliffside high school into, yup, the sea. Dash soon finds himself joining forces with the popular girl and a grizzled but resourceful lunch lady to avoid not just sharks but suddenly deadly cliques.

And there is something almost selfless in Norman‰Ûªs hustle. He doesn‰Ûªt want wealth or power as much as he longs for proximity to them, for entree into a world where important things happen. He calls himself a businessman or a consultant, but he is really running a kind of social pyramid scheme, promising extravagant returns on small investments of kindness and courtesy.

The full, spoilerish title of Joseph Cedar‰Ûªs new movie ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏNorman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is more or less literally accurate, though it might be argued that ‰ÛÏfixer‰Ûù is a bit euphemistic, if not downright fantastical. In his own mind, Norman Oppenheimer, a well-dressed, well-spoken Manhattanite played with feeling and mischief by Richard Gere, is what‰Ûªs known in Yiddish as a macher. He travels the circuits of money and influence, always just a few capillaries removed from the beating heart of power. His mental Rolodex swells with the names of the good and the great, every one of them ‰ÛÏa very close friend.‰Ûù He‰Ûªd be happy to introduce you.

Which pretty much describes ‰ÛÏNorman‰Ûù itself. It‰Ûªs only after the plot has unfolded, with antic elegance and brazen unpredictability, that the risks involved become apparent. The dangers are everywhere: overly broad humor; obnoxiously shticky performances; sentimental tribalism; easy moral point-scoring. None materialize. It‰Ûªs startling, given how much farce is on display ‰ÛÓ in the rise-and-fall structure of the narrative; in the madcap scenes of narrowly missed (or fully achieved) catastrophe; in the play of mistaken and forged identities ‰ÛÓ how much genuine feeling also comes through.

It‰Ûªs no accident that some of Duby‰Ûªs words about Norman ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏscheming‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏbloodsucking,‰Ûù in particular ‰ÛÓ evoke the historical language of anti-Semitism. Mr. Cedar, a New York-born Israeli filmmaker, has a sharp eye for intra-Jewish conflict, for the narcissism of large and small differences that can cause the unity of God‰Ûªs chosen people to splinter like matzo. His previous film, the sublime academic comedy ‰ÛÏFootnote,‰Ûù mined father-son rivalry and scholarly antagonism for biblical pathos and borscht belt humor. ‰ÛÏNorman‰Ûù traces fault lines, more cultural and temperamental than ideological or religious, between the members of the diaspora (or at least the New York wing of it) and their cousins in the Promised Land.

It‰Ûªs less that Mr. Cedar blends realism with absurdity than that he refuses to acknowledge any distinction between them.
