Basketball came naturally to Kenny Anderson. A sensational point guard from Queens, he was named a high school all-American four years running. After Anderson spent two years at Georgia Tech, the New Jersey Nets made him the No. 2 pick in the 1991 N.B.A. draft. He was all of 20.

Ms. Campbell follows Anderson on a memory tour, visiting places and people from his past. At the LeFrak City housing complex, where he grew up, former neighbors still love him. His onetime agent, David Falk, suggests that he mentor N.B.A. rookies about the hazards of early wealth. Kenny Smith, another great guard from Queens, urges him to figure out what he wants to do next and ‰ÛÏjump in the pool, man.‰Ûù You still got game, Kenny, his friends tell him. Just drive.

The film wastes little time getting to that nightmare of genocidal self-destruction, but not before deftly covering the history preceding it: Cambodia‰Ûªs prestige during the Angkor Empire in the ninth to 15th centuries; its years as a protectorate of France from the mid-19th century until its independence in 1953; a cultural flowering in the 1950s and early ‰Ûª60s; and the impact of the United States‰Ûª bombing campaign during the Vietnam War. When a military coup in 1970 begot a government unfriendly to Communists, civil war ensued, presaging the ascendance of Pol Pot and the Communist Khmer Rouge in 1975.

In 2012 the Cornell physics professor and documentarian Robert H. Lieberman directed ‰ÛÏThey Call It Myanmar,‰Ûù an impressive portrait of that country as it struggled to emerge from military rule. Mr. Lieberman‰Ûªs latest, ‰ÛÏAngkor Awakens: A Portrait of Cambodia,‰Ûù scrutinizes another Southeast Asian country as it fitfully sheds the effects of a four-year national trauma: the Khmer Rouge.

And then, until 1979, came the horrors of a paranoid totalitarian dictatorship: the extermination of intellectuals; starvation; mass graves; the mountains of skulls made famous in the film ‰ÛÏThe Killing Fields.‰Ûù An estimated two million perished. The graphic evidence here, in testimony on camera and in period photographs, is absolutely harrowing.

But ‰ÛÏAngkor Awakens‰Ûù concludes optimistically. Today, a young internet-savvy generation composes a majority. As that group deals with parents and grandparents still tormented by what one commentator calls ‰ÛÏbroken courage‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a form of post-traumatic stress ‰ÛÓ it offers hope to a badly scarred nation.

Mr. Schreiber has his own ideas about which real-life figures he should be playing. He is both the star and a producer of ‰ÛÏChuck,‰Ûù a biopic of Chuck Wepner, a New Jersey-born-and-bred boxer (nicknamed, to his chagrin, the Bayonne Bleeder), whose improbable 1975 bout with Muhammad Ali inspired Sylvester Stallone‰Ûªs screenplay for ‰ÛÏRocky.‰Ûù

This is a pretty good boxing picture, with credible redemption notes, but one character could be summing up the whole enterprise when she says to Chuck: ‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs more to you than meets the eye. Not much. But just enough.‰Ûù

Mr. Schreiber has almost no physical resemblance to Wepner, in his heyday a burly, mustachioed redhead. Mr. Schreiber is a terrific actor, however, and he pulls it off. His portrayal works partly because of its understatement. He doesn‰Ûªt try to Jersey things up too much, so to speak; nor does Elisabeth Moss, as the philandering boxer‰Ûªs long-suffering wife. Naomi Watts, on the other hand, playing a later love of Wepner‰Ûªs, clearly relishes the opportunity to perform in a vintage glitter sweater and painted-on jeans.

Wepner‰Ûªs story is not entirely unfamiliar. In the movie, credited to four screenwriters (including Mr. Schreiber), and directed by Philippe Falardeau, Wepner is a more or less lovable rapscallion, whose relentless post-Ali-bout partying features a disastrous introduction to cocaine. A derailed stint in showbiz, courtesy of Mr. Stallone, and some trouble with the law follow.

It is unlikely that anyone will ever film a fictional chronicle of the English rock band King Crimson, but if anyone were to do so, Liev Schreiber would be a good choice to play its leader, Robert Fripp. The two have a definite resemblance, and share a near-formal bearing in public.

Deadpan humor is a slippery creature; miss the tone by just a little, and the potential wriggles away. ‰ÛÏTake Me,‰Ûù an extremely droll parody of a male-female cat-and-mouse thriller, is a case in point.

Mr. Healy also directed, which might have been a mistake. Another set of eyes might have coaxed more complementary performances out of the two leads, who individually are amusing but seem as if they‰Ûªre operating on different comedic planes. Still, the movie‰Ûªs moderately diverting, and the veteran actor Jim O‰ÛªHeir is funny as another client of Ray‰Ûªs who requests a kidnapping as a means of eating healthier.

Pat Healy plays a sad sack named Ray with a kidnap-fantasy business: He abducts people at their request for therapeutic or thrill-seeking purposes. Anna (Taylor Schilling of ‰ÛÏOrange Is the New Black,‰Ûù who is the best thing about this movie) requests his services, but she doesn‰Ûªt want merely the usual eight-hour adventure. She wants an entire weekend, and she wants it rough.

Thus begins a blunder-filled odyssey that soon has Ray and, presumably, the viewer wondering who is manipulating whom and whether Ray has even snatched the right person. Parts of it work, but the overall package is never really suspenseful enough to have you on edge or overtly funny enough to be a lark.

Elle Fanning is the character whose birth name was Ramona but who is well on the way to becoming Ray, a decision that, of course, is fraught with all sorts of obstacles. Bullies send Ray home with a black eye for no particular reason. His own relatives can‰Ûªt stop referring to him with feminine pronouns. His mother, Maggie (Naomi Watts), tries to be supportive but is still full of doubts. His grandmother Dolly (Susan Sarandon) is in a lesbian relationship and living a life with all the trappings of liberal New York bohemianism, but she, too, is balking.

Ray is courageous just for making the decision to change sexes. The film ‰ÛÓ which, by the way, includes a surprising amount of droll humor ‰ÛÓ would be better if it trusted the audience to recognize this, rather than piling ordeals worthy of the Labors of Hercules onto its protagonist.

That alone would make for a movie‰Ûªs worth of material, but ‰ÛÏ3 Generations,‰Ûù directed by Gaby Dellal (who wrote the screenplay with Nikole Beckwith), crams in much more. Because Ray is underage, the consent form for the transition requires both parental signatures, and the father (Tate Donovan) has not been part of the family for years. The search for him and his reaction to the request still aren‰Ûªt enough; the movie adds yet another complication late in the game, a plot twist that strains credulity.

Good intentions abound in ‰ÛÏ3 Generations,‰Ûù a movie about a New York teenager transitioning from female to male, but they lead to a certain overzealousness. The makers of this film really, really want you to know that a young person in this situation has to deal with a lot.
‰ÛÏWhy can‰Ûªt she just be a lesbian?‰Ûù Dolly says.

There are a few dramatic incidents, including outbreaks of emotional and physical violence, but the real action in the film is interior, and Mr. BrizÌ©‰Ûªs greatest skill is his ability to imply the deep and complicated emotions beneath the placid, decorous surface of Jeanne. ‰ÛÏA Woman‰Ûªs Life,‰Ûù like ‰ÛÏThe Measure of a Man,‰Ûù moves calmly and deliberately, but it never feels slow. Instead, its images and scenes are suffused by an intensity that seems almost to be a quality of the light and air as they play across Ms. Chemla‰Ûªs watchful, sometimes inscrutable features.

One name for that elusive quality might be empathy, but it might be something even simpler. The attention that this film gives to its main character ‰ÛÓ and requires of its viewer ‰ÛÓ seems perfectly proportionate. A life is a small thing, and only one thing. But it‰Ûªs also everything.

It would be wrong to say too much about the heartbreak that Jeanne endures, though none of it is altogether surprising. Straying husbands and feckless sons are hardly uncommon in literature or in life, but such knowledge would hardly be much consolation for any specific wife or mother. And the power of Mr. BrizÌ©‰Ûªs film ‰ÛÓ and of Ms. Chemla‰Ûªs quietly volcanic performance ‰ÛÓ lies partly in the way ordinary disasters erupt in Jeanne‰Ûªs life, at once challenging her passivity and emphasizing her helplessness.

In some ways, the movie is a striking departure from Mr. BrizÌ©‰Ûªs previous feature, ‰ÛÏThe Measure of a Man,‰Ûù which starred Vincent Lindon as a displaced worker buffeted by the disruptions of 21st-century capitalism. But in spite of their obvious differences of gender, class and period, the two protagonists share a common plight, and Mr. BrizÌ©‰Ûªs interest in them is rigorously consistent. He is concerned, above all, with individual dignity, and the forces that conspire to undermine it.

In Jeanne‰Ûªs case, those forces are, in a word, men. Not all men: Her father is a kind patriarch, and the early part of ‰ÛÏA Woman‰Ûªs Life‰Ûù unfolds in a pastoral paradise of parental affection and abundant leisure. Surrounded by sunlight, flowers and gentle breezes, Jeanne dwells in a vision of happiness. The arrival of a handsome suitor (Swann Arlaud) followed by a healthy baby seems to promise a deeper bliss, but things don‰Ûªt quite work out that way.

‰ÛÏA Woman‰Ûªs Life‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a more literal translation of the French title would just be ‰ÛÏA Life‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is the new film by StÌ©phane BrizÌ©. Based on a novel by Guy de Maupassant, it traces the fluctuating fortunes of Jeanne Le Perthuis des Vauds (Judith Chemla), an aristocratic landowner in 19th-century France, through marriage and motherhood.

The pathos and wonder of ‰ÛÏA Woman‰Ûªs Life‰Ûù comes from its recognition that Jeanne is at once a captive of cruel circumstances and a willful, intelligent human being. Her kinship with other 19th-century fictional heroines ‰ÛÓ Emma Bovary, Jane Eyre, Anna Karenina ‰ÛÓ is evident. She suffers, but she also reads, thinks and desires, and strives to find a zone of freedom within boundaries dictated by fate and society.
As quaint as the specters it works to expunge, ‰ÛÏAnother Evil‰Ûù is an ultra-low-budget ghost story with an off-kilter sensibility that initially intrigues but ultimately fizzles.

The outcome looks cheap and is only mildly amusing. Yet there‰Ûªs something earnestly odd and original at play in the movie‰Ûªs desire to ask the tired, haunted-house setup a fresh question: When your ghostbuster is more terrifying than your ghost, who you gonna call?

Blame can‰Ûªt be assigned to the two leads, who find unlikely layers of crazy and comedy in their diametrically different characters. Dan (Steve Zissis, whose touchingly vulnerable performance in the HBO series ‰ÛÏTogetherness‰Ûù cemented that show‰Ûªs tone of romantic resilience) is a Los Angeles painter whose weekend cabin has sprouted a pair of annoying apparitions. Os (Mark Proksch) is the gung-ho exorcist whose second opinion is solicited after his predecessor advises calm and tolerance. With his cowboy hat and wealth of supernatural experience, Os seems to be the more sensible hire.

He also appears weirdly intense about his profession, initiating a series of loony ghost-nabbing procedures interspersed with pitiable confidences about his pending divorce and weakness for cats. His increasingly unsettling behavior begins to worry Dan. And as the story slides from gentle quirkiness into scary-psycho territory, the writer and director, Carson Mell, struggles to stretch what could have been a fairly strong short film to feature length.
‰ÛÏTrans-fixed,‰Ûù from 1974, featured the artist nailed to a car, while other pieces had him further punishing his body and making it, along with his pain, a kind of canvas and paint.

Questions instantly arise: Is this really art? What exactly is art supposed to do? Yet interviews with Burden and others shy away from arguments ‰ÛÓ few dissenters are given a say, and are essentially dismissed. True, discussions of art tend to be subjective and open-ended. But these works were made to be debated with a passion that is sometimes lacking here.

Danger marked Chris Burden‰Ûªs art: He had himself shot, starved, kicked and crucified for his work. Strange, then, that ‰ÛÏBurden,‰Ûù a documentary about this artist, plays it safe. This is a film unafraid to look at his acts, but timid when approaching his ideas.

Timothy Marrinan and Richard Dewey, the directors, were close to their subject ‰ÛÓ in a Q. and A. on the movie‰Ûªs website, they talk of gaining Burden‰Ûªs trust and developing a relationship with him. Their dedication to his career is praiseworthy, and their film recommendable for its devotion to the artist, who died in 2015. Still, while the older, reflective Burden might have embraced the documentary, you suspect that his angry young self would have relished more scrutiny.

Burden, who created large sculptures late in his career, was best known for his early performance pieces, among them ‰ÛÏShoot,‰Ûù from 1971. In it, a friend fired a rifle at him from a few yards away. The intent was to graze Burden‰Ûªs upper left arm; instead, the bullet went through it.

For the most part, Mr. Gunn puts much of his storytelling energy into filling in Quill‰Ûªs origins, after having already dispatched Mom in the first movie. This doesn‰Ûªt sound promising and isn‰Ûªt, alas, despite the good will that Kurt Russell brings to the part of Quill‰Ûªs father, Ego. At one point, Mr. Russell, or some version of him, assays the role with a weird, disrupting digital face-lift that‰Ûªs meant to suggest the young Ego, but really only makes you contemplate whether this Benjamin Button-style age-reversing is going to become an increasingly standard (and creepy) industry practice. It‰Ûªs a distraction that shows a filmmaker making a bad decision mostly, it seems, because he can afford to.

These introductions are fairly chaotic, which is the usual blockbuster way. The point is to telegraph the movie you‰Ûªre about to watch ‰ÛÓ the threats, fights and winks followed by more threats, fights and winks ‰ÛÓ as well as to reintroduce the crew members, their skills, traits and foibles. Alternately bulgy and sleek, hairy and shticky, they make for often-amusing company, even if this time Zoe Saldana, as Gamora, the green-skinned Amazon with grave daddy issues, feels more sidelined than before. One problem, it seems, is that Mr. Gunn is still holding off on developing the romance between her and Peter that was teased in the first movie, probably because he‰Ûªs saving it for the next installment.

Still, before Mr. Russell is swallowed up by the story and digital effects, he holds you with the laid-back vibe of a Hollywood veteran whose tan and crinkly smile tell you that sunsets and Goldie Hawn are waiting for him back in Cali. He brings an unforced looseness to the movie that it very much needs, especially after Mr. Pratt slips into a more sober register in his daddy dearest scenes. Mr. Gunn likes to play a scene straight and then jokingly pull the rug out from under it, a trick that, among other things, helps soft-sell the violence. But the father-son stuff plays flatly less because it‰Ûªs been told before (like, forever) than because he can‰Ûªt figure out how to playfully kink it up.

At times, Mr. Gunn‰Ûªs ambitions badly backfire. Like the first movie, this one is jammed with action-driven sequences, some wildly bloated and most of them cartoonish. For one fight, though, he cranks the music and lets the screen bleed as the ostensible good guys kill one villain after another, the casualties falling to the sound of a head-bobbing song. Tonally, the episode feels unpleasantly sour and wrong for this young series, which is best when it goes light; it‰Ûªs a bummer watching another director attempt the kind of smiling sadism that not even Martin Scorsese and Quentin Tarantino can always pull off.

The larger problem, as it becomes progressively evident, is that this series lacks a resonant origin story, a myth, on which a world, multiple stories and a fan base can rest. The Guardians‰Ûª personal stories are continuing to emerge, and the meme that‰Ûªs in circulation is family, which at times makes it feel as if the movie is taking cues from the ‰ÛÏFast and Furious‰Ûù franchise. This explains the testy, at times violent and generally dreary exchanges between Gamora and her sister, Nebula (Karen Gillan), a bald badass itching to deliver payback for their rotten childhood. The performers look fierce as they slam around, squaring jaws and giving good side-eye, but it just feels like narrative filler.

In moments like this, Mr. Gunn loses sight of the insouciance and feeling that were crucial to making the first movie work. ‰ÛÏGuardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2‰Ûù certainly has its attractions, but most of them are visual rather than narrative. Among the most appealing are the animated diorama-like tableaus that Ego uses to narrate his life, each a clue to his character. His private planet, meanwhile, is a kaleidoscopic fantasia that suggests modestly trippy science-fiction and heavy-metal cover art. This look ‰ÛÓ with its softly clashing colors and soaring stalagmites ‰ÛÓ seems designed to instigate, at least in some, flashbacks to stacks of yellowing paperbacks and lovingly played rock albums.

It‰Ûªs tough being a hitmaker who isn‰Ûªt weighed down by corporate expectations, but for a while, Mr. Gunn does a pretty good job of keeping the whole thing reasonably fizzy, starting with an opener that winks at the audience with big bangs and slapstick. The movie begins in medias res, with Quill and the gang facing down a blobby adversary with fat, snapping tentacles and rows of nasty teeth ‰ÛÓ the better to eat them with or just tear them limb from limb. The Guardians take whacks at the blob, jumping and thrashing around a patently digital environment that‰Ûªs vaguely far-out and indeterminate.

‰ÛÏGuardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2‰Ûù has all the digital bells and whistles as well as much of the likable, self-aware waggery of the first. In many respects, it‰Ûªs not much different except it all feels a bit strained, as if everyone were trying too hard, especially its writer-director, James Gunn. Most of the ragtag futuristic fighters who powered through Vol 1. three years ago are back on board and led by Peter Quill (Chris Pratt), a cheerily roguish type who calls himself Star-Lord. The name still brings a light smile, even if the movie can‰Ûªt help but feel as deadly serious as any other lucratively branded Marvel property.

Like some of the canned music (Fleetwood Mac, the Electric Light Orchestra), the movie‰Ûªs visual design gestures toward the past but mostly comes across as a generational yearning for such memories. Perhaps like some directors, Mr. Gunn fondly or regretfully looks back on a time when studio filmmakers could more or less do their own thing cinematically. Or maybe he just likes songs like ‰ÛÏCome a Little Bit Closer,‰Ûù a Top 40 hit about a fickle dance partner that works as a nice metaphor for every movie that wants to fall into the audience‰Ûªs embrace, at least on opening weekend. The difference is that while the first ‰ÛÏGuardians‰Ûù earned that love as if by accident, this one begs for it.

All that tell and no show. Interviews with Mr. Schnabel reveal few interesting points, while a grating soundtrack telegraphs how it thinks you should be feeling. Worse still, there‰Ûªs far too little art. The pieces shown, many of them beguiling, practically beg for their close-ups and for some exploration.

No commercials are shown during ‰ÛÏJulian Schnabel: A Private Portrait.‰Ûù They would only be redundant. Instead this documentary serves as a feature-length advertisement for the artist, and is about as daring as a billboard for skim milk.

In an interview for the publicity notes, Mr. Schnabel called the film ‰ÛÏvery useful, helpful and informative,‰Ûù a phrase that seems more fitting to describe a computer‰Ûªs user manual. Like a manual, this film appears incapable of conveying any genuine joy or anger or excitement, offering only words that sound a lot alike. And when everyone is saying the same thing, something starts to feel suspect.

Instead, Pappi Corsicato, the director and a friend of Mr. Schnabel‰Ûªs, hurries back to the fawn fest; there‰Ûªs also scant mention of the controversies that have arisen during, and are now inseparable from, Mr. Schnabel‰Ûªs career. It‰Ûªs somehow perverse that an artist this prime for discussion is given nothing but monotonous praise, while his work is treated as an afterthought.

Surveying Mr. Schnabel‰Ûªs life from his boyhood through his success in the art world and as a film director, the movie includes interviews with family members who pile on the adulations from the first minutes to the final scenes. Jeff Koons, Bono, Al Pacino and other celebrities also check in to extol Mr. Schnabel‰Ûªs brilliance.

Cultural sensitivity about mental illness has increased to the extent that using a psychiatric hospital or its residents as metaphors for society in general is considered in bad taste, at least. But either nobody has told this to the Italian film director Paolo VirzÌÂ, or he just doesn‰Ûªt care. The analogy he draws between Italy and two initially opposed women in an institution is the linchpin of his ‰ÛÏLike Crazy,‰Ûù an energetic, visually attractive but ultimately irritating comedy-drama.

On the sun-dappled grounds of the self-described progressive Tuscan mental hospital called Villa Biondi, an expansive, voluptuous motormouth named Beatrice (Valeria Bruni Tedeschi) swans around as if she owned the joint, even impersonating an admitting doctor to bamboozle a newly admitted younger woman, Donatella (Micaela Ramazzotti). Angular, birdlike and tattoo-dotted, Donatella is Beatrice‰Ûªs polar opposite, so naturally they have to share a room, and will eventually escape the psychiatric clinic together.

The story line‰Ûªs resolution hits a big chord of romanticized preposterousness, but because Mr. VirzÌÂ is a truly skilled filmmaker, he‰Ûªs able to tack on a coda sufficiently lyrical that you may almost fall for it. I just became that much more irritated.

Ms. Bruni Tedeschi portrays Beatrice with awe-inspiring, electric vigor, but the character remains a kind of cipher, a device to unlock the tragic dimensions of her new friend‰Ûªs story. Ms. Ramazzotti has a quiet strength playing a depressive knocked around by life and subsequently denied the opportunity to be a mother to her child. Yet even as the movie is conscientious in its depiction of Beatrice‰Ûªs and Donatella‰Ûªs symptoms, it winds up doing some effectively fabulist sentimental hedging to support both its societal critique and its female-bonding theme. (The movie does shoehorn in what appears to be an overt homage to ‰ÛÏThelma and Louise.‰Ûù)

‰ÛÏRisk,‰Ûù Laura Poitras‰Ûªs new documentary, was first shown at the Cannes Film Festival last May and has been updated since then. Even so, it feels unfinished in a way that is at once fascinating, frustrating and entirely understandable. The story Ms. Poitras has to tell is still unfolding, and opinions about the person at its center ‰ÛÓ the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange ‰ÛÓ continue to evolve.

The movie also examines ‰ÛÓ not always explicitly, and not entirely by design ‰ÛÓ the workings of a contemporary personality cult. Mr. Assange, who muses on his ‰ÛÏgod complex‰Ûù and his capacity for martyrdom, likes to surround himself with disciples. Fidelity to the message melts into loyalty to the messenger, even if the message itself can sound a bit blurry. In one interview, Mr. Assange explains the need to balance principles and pragmatism, and in another he speaks of the necessity of a global outlook in trying to change the world. But he demurs when asked about the changes he would like to see come about, and never arrives at a clear articulation of principle. He insists on transparency while choosing to remain opaque.

Much of the film casts a weirdly nostalgic spell, as it transports the audience back to a recent moment in history that nonetheless seems very far away. From 2010 to 2013, when most of the interviews in ‰ÛÏRisk‰Ûù were conducted, Mr. Assange emerged as a glamorous and controversial figure, a media-savvy and politically astute champion of radical transparency dogged by accusations of sexual misconduct.

It is appropriate, though not entirely satisfying, that ‰ÛÏRisk‰Ûù ends in a swirl of confusion. Events since Cannes have upended many of the arguments that the film might have clarified. The pressing empirical questions about Mr. Assange now have to do with the extent and nature of his intervention in the election. Those questions ‰ÛÓ about Russia, the F.B.I. and members of the Trump campaign ‰ÛÓ can‰Ûªt yet be answered by a movie, much less a movie review. And the deeper historical and ideological questions that the film poses will also take a long time to work out.

The one that haunted me most goes something like this: What if some of the organizations and individuals that seemed, not so long ago, to be pushing liberal democracy to live up to its potential were actually contributing to its demise?

It would be simplistic to describe ‰ÛÏRisk‰Ûù as the chronicle of Ms. Poitras‰Ûªs disillusionment with Mr. Assange. She is a discreet and careful observer, inserting herself into the story only when it might seem evasive to do otherwise and refraining from passing judgment on Mr. Assange. But any interesting portrait is necessarily the record of a relationship between artist and subject, each of whom is invested in controlling the outcome. And to some degree in spite of Ms. Poitras‰Ûªs journalistic intentions ‰ÛÓ though very much as a consequence of her rigorous honesty ‰ÛÓ the picture that emerges is complicated, unsettling and intriguingly ambivalent.

With weary impatience, Mr. Assange describes the sexual assault allegations against him as the product of a feminist conspiracy. ‰ÛÏRisk‰Ûù takes them seriously, and sheds light on the ugly thread of misogyny and predation that runs through so much of the tech world ‰ÛÓ in Silicon Valley executive suites as well as in gamer message boards and hacker collectives ‰ÛÓ and that has been dismissed or denied for far too long.

WikiLeaks, which specialized in the highly publicized release of huge troves of classified documents and communications, challenged governments and journalistic conventions. The organization and its allies seemed to be on the vanguard of a global movement toward openness and democracy, enabled by digital technology and fueled by the idealism and skepticism of an army of hackers.

‰ÛÏWhy does he trust me?‰Ûù Ms. Poitras asks in one of the voice-over diary entries that punctuate ‰ÛÏRisk.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt think he likes me.‰Ûù That is hard for the viewer to judge, since the filmmaker doesn‰Ûªt appear on camera and her subject does not exactly exude warmth. But the trust is evident in his candor and in the remarkable access she was granted, both in the estate in Norfolk, England, where Mr. Assange was confined during his period of house arrest and in the Ecuadorean embassy in London, where he sought asylum to avoid extradition to Sweden.

Things look different now. The connotations of the word ‰ÛÏhacker‰Ûù have darkened, and so, perhaps, have perceptions of the digital future. This is partly because the political and media context ‰ÛÓ and indeed the apparent direction of history ‰ÛÓ have changed dramatically. Remember Barack Obama‰Ûªs first term? Remember the Arab Spring? Remember social media before the trolls and fake-news hucksters took it over?

‰ÛÏRisk‰Ûù will take you back, briefly, to that era. It is possible to imagine circumstances ‰ÛÓ a different result in the 2016 presidential election, say, but not only that ‰ÛÓ in which this movie would be a more or less straightforward prequel to ‰ÛÏCitizenfour,‰Ûù Ms. Poitras‰Ûªs Oscar-winning documentary about Edward J. Snowden. That film is in a sense tucked inside ‰ÛÏRisk,‰Ûù as Ms. Poitras abruptly leaves London, where she met with Mr. Assange, for Hong Kong, summoned by a message from an anonymous whistle-blower who will turn out to be Mr. Snowden. She sees less of Mr. Assange after that, and you get the impression that he was not altogether pleased with the shift in the filmmaker‰Ûªs (and the rest of the world‰Ûªs) attention away from him.

You won‰Ûªt find greedy televangelists or much about militant theocracies here. ‰ÛÏSacred,‰Ûù comprising three segments, celebrates perhaps the most worthy of religion‰Ûªs functions: providing ceremonies for rites of passage. ‰ÛÏInitiation‰Ûù concerns birth, glimpsing, among other things, an Ethiopian baptism, a bris in New York City, an Egyptian father‰Ûªs chanting the call to prayer to his newly born son. ‰ÛÏPractice‰Ûù visits a Hasidic gathering in Ukraine where men meet prospective wives, and follows a married Japanese couple at the Mara Kannon Shrine in Yamaguchi, where phallic statuary is said to promote fertility. In ‰ÛÏPassage,‰Ûù a wizened Ethiopian man ends a pilgrimage for absolution, while a Connecticut woman with emphysema extols the value of prayer.

The TV journalist Bill Moyers once said of the mythologist Joseph Campbell that he ‰ÛÏwas one of the most spiritual men I ever met, but he didn‰Ûªt have an ideology or a theology.‰Ûù The same might be said of Thomas Lennon, who directed ‰ÛÏSacred,‰Ûù a kaleidoscopic travelogue depicting demonstrations of faith worldwide. Mr. Lennon (no relation to the ‰ÛÏReno 911!‰Ûù comedian) enlisted 40 filmmakers in 25 countries to record scenes large and small, and the results are surprisingly cohesive.

There are excesses: in the Philippines, a grisly re-creation of Christ‰Ûªs Crucifixion on Good Friday, and, in Sierra Leone, a belief that the recent Ebola epidemic was a manifestation of divine anger. But mostly we see personal quests for grace and meaning, evident in scenes of a solitary Buddhist monk at Mount Hiei in Japan, completing circuits around the mountain to attain enlightenment. During such intimate moments, outside of organized hierarchies, ‰ÛÏSacred‰Ûù succeeds most.

The documentary filmmaker Wang Bing is a dogged chronicler of China‰Ûªs downtrodden: His ‰ÛÏTie Xi Qu: West of Tracks‰Ûù was a nine-hour look at the decline of an urban industrial district, while ‰ÛÏ‰ÛªTil Madness Do Us Part‰Ûù offered a nearly four-hour immersion in a mental hospital that resembled a prison or a purgatory.

Incorporating his typically arduous, slow-paced style, Mr. Wang doesn‰Ûªt make things easy for viewers. His subjects aren‰Ûªt identified directly; the person speaking is frequently off camera. This vagueness may be a universalizing strategy, reflecting a place where people are, in one man‰Ûªs words, ‰ÛÏhere one minute, gone the next.‰Ûù But it‰Ûªs also a double-edged sword that prevents most participants from standing out.

Mr. Wang spends time on the Chinese side, observing daily life in refugee camps and at other sites along the mountainous border. The refugees cut sugar cane to sell and scrounge for money for personal transport. We learn of separated families. It‰Ûªs a mild shock whenever someone uses a cellphone ‰ÛÓ a rare reminder of modernity.

His ‰ÛÏTa‰Ûªang‰Ûù also documents a kind of limbo. During armed clashes in Myanmar in February 2015, refugees from the Ta‰Ûªang and other ethnic minority groups in the country‰Ûªs northeastern Kokang region fled across the border into China.

What does come through in ‰ÛÏTa‰Ûªang‰Ûù is the refugees‰Ûª camaraderie. They listen to music or share stories around campfires. Children mimic the sounds of gunfire nearby. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm not scared. At least I‰Ûªm not alone,‰Ûù a woman says near the end, in what may be the movie‰Ûªs message.

The couples have met to hash out their response to an incendiary and horrific incident involving their teenage sons. But the story (by the director, Oren Moverman, adapting the 2009 novel by Herman Koch) takes so long to unveil its secrets that they emerge with far less force than they should. And despite frequent flashbacks and Bobby Bukowski‰Ûªs richly dimensional photography, the movie has a static, stagy look that amplifies the oppressiveness of its increasingly unpleasant exchanges.

‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre gonna talk tonight,‰Ûù the politician Stan Lohman (Richard Gere) says at the beginning of the ridiculous restaurant meal that serves as the framework for ‰ÛÏThe Dinner.‰Ûù Stan‰Ûªs determination is cheering, especially when we learn that one of his dinner guests ‰ÛÓ his brother, Paul (Steve Coogan) ‰ÛÓ is resolutely incapable of listening to any voice but his own.

What we‰Ûªre left with is a morality play in which three deeply deplorable people ‰ÛÓ and one surprising white knight ‰ÛÓ wrestle with class privilege, mental illness and extremely silly food. As for Paul, I expect he was a lot more bearable on the page than in our faces.

And that‰Ûªs a huge problem for the movie, never mind for Stan. Cynical and sometimes venomous, Paul‰Ûªs rants and digressions ‰ÛÓ employed to forestall a critical family discussion ‰ÛÓ commandeer so much screen time that you wish he‰Ûªd choke on his so-called Thumbelina carrots. (This is the kind of establishment where descriptions of the food take longer than its actual preparation.) A mentally unstable former history teacher, Paul is resentful of Stan‰Ûªs success and heedless of the entreaties of his wife (Laura Linney) and the admonitions of his sister-in-law (Rebecca Hall) to hold his tongue.

Sadly, that‰Ûªs only one problem with this overdetermined, fussily managed romance. Falling with a thud between two stools, it has neither the zip nor the zaniness of farce nor the airy vivacity of the best romantic comedies. The sugary, violin-heavy score that elbows its way into virtually every scene might beg to differ, but its cudgeling chords can‰Ûªt force enchantment when, improbably, Mary and Michael‰Ûªs jaded passions are rekindled.

That would require a screenplay (by the director, Azazel Jacobs) with sparkle and energy instead of one that takes forever to nudge characters from staring to kissing. No one suffers more from this programmatic approach than Ms. Winger, whose warm, loamy sexiness demands roaming privileges. Only watch her in ‰ÛÏThe Sheltering Sky,‰Ûù playing a dissatisfied wife who finds her true self in the middle of the desert. She‰Ûªs the beating heart of that movie, turning what could have been a sterile exercise in alienation and ennui into something vibrantly human.

If all middle-aged marrieds were having as much sex as Mary and Michael (Debra Winger and Tracy Letts) in ‰ÛÏThe Lovers,‰Ûù then the ratings for ‰ÛÏNCIS‰Ûù would go into a tailspin. Yet the extracurricular bonking that they gingerly enjoy ‰ÛÓ she with a needy writer (Aidan Gillen) and he with a neurotic ballet dancer (Melora Walters) ‰ÛÓ appears to bring only marginally more pleasure than their sclerotic union.

Which brings me to a third stool that Mr. Jacobs (who also directed and helped to write the smart, adorably prickly HBO series ‰ÛÏDoll & Em‰Ûù) could have claimed. Beneath its mushy music, ‰ÛÏThe Lovers‰Ûù nurses something altogether more sour and more fruitful: a self-sabotaging desperation that you can sense Ms. Winger straining to vocalize. It isn‰Ûªt love that Mary and Michael are seeking; what really turns them on is sneaking around.

The manifestoes (the film draws from many more than 13 texts; some are merely one-line maxims) are not just read, they‰Ûªre performed. And they‰Ûªre all presented by the chameleonic actress Cate Blanchett. More than a performer, Ms. Blanchett is also a movie star, albeit a very particular caliber of movie star. Which is one of several reasons ‰ÛÏManifesto‰Ûù works as well as it does in cinematic form.

In installation form, 13 readings play out simultaneously on 13 screens, challenging the viewer to pluck coherence from an audiovisual Babel of sorts. In the movie version, the scenes are laid out in a linear fashion, but one scene is divided so that the film begins and ends with it.

In some cases, the words and actions are at odds. For the Fluxus manifesto, which denounces hierarchical culture and the elevated position of the artist within that culture, Ms. Blanchett vehemently enacts the text in the guise of a temperamental, overbearing Russian choreographer. The juxtaposition of words, images and settings is sometimes brilliantly comedic, as when Ms. Blanchett, portraying a big-haired TV news anchor with a smile that looks as if it were enforced by law, converses about Conceptual art with a remote weather reporter, also played by Ms. Blanchett.

Some of the settings are on the nose, but that does not mean they are ineffective. The Dada manifesto, announcing the death of art, is set at a funeral. Claes Oldenburg‰Ûªs incantatory brief for pop art (‰ÛÏI am for an art that is political-erotical-mystical‰Ûù) is said as a prayer at the table of a family meal. (That the family is staid and middle-class and Southern tilts to a certain irony, however.)

Movies adapted from art installations rarely come off well, even when the artwork has a strong cinematic element. Julian Rosefeldt‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏManifesto,‰Ûù which originated as an art installation, has toured the world, recently roosting at the Park Avenue Armory in Manhattan. It consists of filmed readings of various artistic and political manifestoes, dating from Marx and Engels‰Ûªs 1848 ‰ÛÏCommunist Manifesto‰Ûù and moving through the 20th century to Dada, Fluxus and even Lars von Trier‰Ûªs Dogme 95 rules for filmmaking.

As an installation, ‰ÛÏManifesto‰Ûù may have seemed like a sensory onslaught. As a movie, it‰Ûªs a very elaborate intellectual exercise, immaculate in every technical detail. (The sound design, by Fabian Schmidt and Markus Stemler, is particularly extraordinary.) And Ms. Blanchett‰Ûªs work here is aptly cerebral. As virtuosic as her performances are, they‰Ûªre purposely conscious of themselves. As an oblique examination and critique of political and art history and their various interactions over the 20th century, ‰ÛÏManifesto‰Ûù is both witty and provocative. It is not, however, a motion picture for people seeking a plot.
Similarly, Tom keeps repeating, to Danny or anyone with an ear, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm trying to help.‰Ûù Soon the question becomes, is he really? And if so, whom?

What does Danny want? For one thing, he wants Tom to believe him when he says he didn‰Ûªt commit the crime for which Tom helped put him away. But Danny sure doesn‰Ûªt act innocent, and he becomes ever more brazen as he pesters Tom and tries to put himself in Lauren‰Ûªs good graces ‰ÛÓ for legal reasons, Tom is prohibited from telling his wife who Danny really is.

Josh Charles and Julia Stiles star as Tom and Lauren, a married couple in a relatively bucolic section of Connecticut. Walking by a river, Tom praises the air quality and takes a little verbal jab at New York City, apparently a place where Lauren likes to spend more time than he does. Their banter is interrupted when the couple see a young man deliberately fall into the water. Tom jumps in and rescues him, and not with ease; their back-and-forth tugging makes the viewer wonder if the title event is about to happen. In the aftermath, Lauren is full of admiration: ‰ÛÏYou risked your life for a total stranger,‰Ûù she tells her husband.

Only he didn‰Ûªt. The jumper, it turns out, is Danny Miller, and Tom, a criminal psychologist specializing in underage offenders, worked with him several years back when Danny was on trial for a bizarre murder ‰ÛÓ a crime he did time for. Now he‰Ûªs out of prison, has been assigned a new name, and is very persistent in his attention to both Tom and his parole officer, Angela (Tracie Thoms).

Avan Jogia, who plays Danny, makes a meal of a role that zigzags between menacing and pathetic; his intensity and bearing remind me of a young Colin Farrell. Leo Fitzgerald is also excellent as a cultish writing instructor who seems to revel in inappropriate behavior.

So, yes, there are a bunch of creepy-stalker tropes we‰Ûªve seen before; add to these the plot point that Tom and Lauren are trying to conceive, and that Lauren is a visual artist frustrated that her career has stalled. Yet, there are intriguing ambiguities at play here. Ms. Gordon frequently keeps her camera (Radium Cheung is the cinematographer) at a remove from the characters, using shallow-focus shots in which a foreground or a background object (a hanging lamp, a door frame) compromises the ostensible perfection of the composition. This contributes to an unbalanced feel.

Ms. Gordon‰Ûªs movies regularly highlight characters who are forced to take a hard look at who they are, and how what they do, or what they‰Ûªve done, has changed them. Her 1983 feature, ‰ÛÏVariety,‰Ûù one of her best-known works, is about a young woman in Manhattan who takes a job working the box office at a Times Square porn theater and develops some obsessions that take her to even more dangerous places.

After being psychologically pummeled by Danny in this film, Tom learns quite a few things about himself. The person he becomes as a result of his ordeal is as much of a surprise to him as it is to us.

The term ‰ÛÏpsychological thriller‰Ûù is often applied, with varying degrees of aspiration or hope, I suppose, to movies that have very little to do with either category. The psychological component is frequently the one more egregiously lacking. ‰ÛÏThe Drowning,‰Ûù directed by Bette Gordon from Stephen Molton and Frank Pugliese‰Ûªs adaptation of Pat Barker‰Ûªs 2001 novel, ‰ÛÏBorder Crossing,‰Ûù distinguishes itself by applying a depth of psychological observation that yields a genuinely unsettling vision.

What follows is a Michelin-starred commercial for French cuisine gussied up as Anne‰Ûªs journey of self-discovery. When not inhaling jus d‰Ûªagneau and crÌ¬me brÌÈlÌ©e ‰ÛÓ and a cheese basket the size of a small fishing boat ‰ÛÓ the two visit famous landmarks and exchange flirty glances. But when Anne finally peels off her pantyhose, it isn‰Ûªt to indulge in a roadside quickie; it‰Ûªs to repair the Peugeot‰Ûªs broken fan belt. So practical, these American women!

Between promoting her son-in-law‰Ûªs band and tediously freeze-framing Anne‰Ûªs amateur snapshots, Ms. Coppola (best known for her riveting 1991 documentary about the making of ‰ÛÏApocalypse Now‰Ûù) never realizes Anne as more than a bland accessory who lets men tell her what to eat. Unlike Martine (Ìälise Tielrooy), a forthright Venusian beauty from Jacques‰Ûªs past.
‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªll never forget your travels with Jacques,‰Ûù Martine promises, flushed with remembered ecstasies. Oh, Martine, I‰Ûªm pretty sure we will.

Inspired by similar events in Ms. Coppola‰Ûªs past, the story fusses around Anne (an overqualified Diane Lane) as she trundles from Cannes to Paris in an old Peugeot. Anne‰Ûªs husband, a frantic Hollywood producer (a barely seen Alec Baldwin), has been urgently summoned to Budapest. So his amiable French business partner, Jacques (Arnaud Viard), has offered to drive Anne to her destination ‰ÛÓ via seemingly every notable restaurant en route.

‰ÛÏParis Can Wait,‰Ûù a smugly affluent Euro trifle and the first narrative feature from Eleanor Coppola (the wife of Francis Ford Coppola), is little more than an indulgent wallow in gustatory privilege. By the time the final meal is devoured, you‰Ûªll be wanting nothing so much as an antacid.

The title refers to the car culture that took hold among Mexican-Americans in Los Angeles and elsewhere, centered on custom-made vehicles built low to the ground and outfitted with hydraulic lifts. Miguel (DemiÌÁn Bichir), a pivotal member of a car club called the Coasters, is preparing his vehicle for a high-stakes competition. His reluctant assistant is his younger son, Daniel (Gabriel Chavarria), who would rather be honing his considerable skills as a graffiti artist than working on cars.

Miguel once hoped that Daniel‰Ûªs brother, Francisco (Mr. Rossi), would be the one to aspire to lowrider greatness, but Francisco ended up in prison instead. He completes his long sentence just before the big car competition, and both Daniel‰Ûªs and Miguel‰Ûªs lives are complicated by his reappearance. Also complicating things is that Miguel has remarried since the boys‰Ûª childhoods; Eva Longoria is underused as his current wife.

Cars could easily have been the stars of ‰ÛÏLowriders,‰Ûù but the film makes them supporting players in a family drama that‰Ûªs a mix of strong scenes and shopworn ones punctuated by clichÌ©s. The story has a boilerplate quality to it ‰ÛÓ father with a drinking problem; a pair of polar-opposite brothers ‰ÛÓ yet a standout performance by Theo Rossi (‰ÛÏSons of Anarchy‰Ûù) as the black sheep of the family overcomes a lot of the film‰Ûªs flaws.

There‰Ûªs nothing subtle about this examination of cultural and generational clashes, and sometimes the director, Ricardo de Montreuil, and the screenwriters, Elgin James and Cheo Hodari Coker, veer into clichÌ© land. They do a nice job, though, of slipping in explanatory tidbits to help along those unfamiliar with the lowrider world.

That‰Ûªs her mother‰Ûªs job. ‰ÛÏSnatched‰Ûù is an intergenerational buddies-on-the-run movie, a strangely popular subgenre nowadays. Emily‰Ûªs mom, Linda, is played by Goldie Hawn, who has been funny for a good half-century (going back to ‰ÛÏLaugh-In‰Ûù) and who is cruelly and inexplicably denied that privilege here. Linda, long-divorced and devoted to her two children (Emily‰Ûªs toxic-nerd brother is played by Ike Barinholtz), functions as an uptight, anxious foil to her wildly undisciplined daughter. In principle that may be a slightly stale premise. In practice it‰Ûªs just dull, and it‰Ûªs frustrating to see Ms. Hawn robbed of the opportunity to be silly.

In the first few scenes of ‰ÛÏSnatched,‰Ûù Emily Middleton (Amy Schumer) loses her retail job and her rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll boyfriend. Those are the high points of the movie, quick and nasty riffs to remind you of ‰ÛÏTrainwreck‰Ûù and raise your hopes for something similar. Those hopes are both fulfilled and disappointed.

Emily drags Linda on a trip to Ecuador that turns calamitous when the two women are kidnapped by a gang of South American baddies. By ‰ÛÏcalamitous‰Ûù I mean lazy, sloppy and witless. ‰ÛÏSnatched‰Ûù is one of those movies that subscribes to a dubious homeopathic theory of cultural insensitivity by which the acknowledgment of offensiveness is supposed to prevent anyone from taking offense. The idea is that if you use variations on the phrase ‰ÛÏThat‰Ûªs racist!‰Ûù as a punch line a few times, nothing else you say or do could possibly be racist. Including, say, populating your movie with dark-skinned thugs with funny accents and killing a few of them for cheap laughs.

Like most popular big-screen comic performers, Ms. Schumer is committed to consistency, or at least to exploiting a successful and familiar persona. She has become more or less what Will Ferrell was a decade and a half ago: the likable embodiment of various forms of human unpleasantness, a soft-bodied clown whose immunity to shame represents an appealing kind of innocence. Emily is self-absorbed, lazy and rude, but also so lacking in true meanness or guile and so dogged in her pursuit of shallow pleasures that she‰Ûªs kind of fun to be around. Even though she drinks too much, says obnoxious things and misbehaves in other ways ‰ÛÓ killing two people, for example, one with a shovel and the other with a harpoon ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs impossible to get mad at her, or even seriously annoyed.

Ms. Schumer has been criticized for this kind of thing before, and I suppose there‰Ûªs a certain integrity in blithely refusing to care. It‰Ûªs also true that comedy can be forgiven for a lot as long as it manages to make you laugh. Which ‰ÛÏSnatched‰Ûù did, in my case, a handful of times, including when Emily has a tapeworm and when her brother reaches out to the State Department for help rescuing his mother and sister. But though this movie ostensibly celebrates the spirit of adventure and openness to experience, it takes no risks and blazes no trails. It‰Ûªs ultimately as complacent, self-absorbed and clueless as its heroine, and not always in an especially amusing way.

Supplemental silliness is supplied, instead, by Mr. Barinholtz, by Wanda Sykes and Joan Cusack (as a pair of intense tourists), by Christopher Meloni (as an Amazonian adventurer) and by Bashir Salahuddin (as a State Department bureaucrat). The story is nowhere near as hilarious as the director, Jonathan Levine, and the screenwriter, Katie Dippold, would like us to believe. (And not up to the standard of ‰ÛÏThe Heat‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏGhostbusters,‰Ûù both of which Ms. Dippold was also involved in.)

Zweig is played beautifully by the Austrian actor Josef Hader; looking at him here one would never guess he began his career as a comedian. Barbara Sukowa is unsurprisingly great as Friderike, Zweig‰Ûªs ex-wife and conscience, trying to raise an increasingly self-pitying Zweig to recognize and act on his own compassion. One need not admire Zweig‰Ûªs writing to recognize the worth of this thoughtful treatment of one of the countless real-life tragedies of 20th-century history.

Zweig himself struggles to resist a continuing sense of despair while in exile in New York, then back in Brazil, as World War II rages in what seems to be another world ‰ÛÓ Zweig and his family and friends are always depicted in a kind of isolation.

‰ÛÏStefan Zweig: Farewell to Europe,‰Ûù a handsome, scrupulously serious film directed by Maria Schrader from a script she wrote with Jan Schomburg, hardly deals at all with Zweig‰Ûªs writing. But the movie does grapple with his thought, particularly his position on a writer‰Ûªs proper place in tumultuous times. The movie begins at a PEN conference in Buenos Aires, where a fellow writer confronts Zweig about his refusal to condemn Hitler and Germany. ‰ÛÏEvery gesture of resistance which is void of either risk or impact is nothing but a cry for recognition,‰Ûù Zweig insists.

The Austrian writer Stefan Zweig was internationally popular in the 1920s and ‰Ûª30s. His works continue to be adapted into films (the 1948 picture ‰ÛÏLetter From an Unknown Woman‰Ûù is the best of these), but his current literary reputation is muddled; in 2010, the esteemed translator Michael Hofmann wrote, ‰ÛÏThere is something touchingly wrong about Zweig.‰Ûù
The fight scenes are nasty, the language is harsh and the three leads are utterly convincing.

Fifty years after ‰ÛÏTo Sir, With Love,‰Ûù British youths still need rescuing by a concerned adult. Yet if ‰ÛÏUrban Hymn‰Ûù starts with that familiar dynamic, it stays surprisingly fresh thanks to three fine performances and a willingness to be uncompromising.

Yes, that plotline fuels the old myth of vocal or athletic ability as a magical way out of a disadvantaged life, but the movie, written by Nick Moorcroft and directed by Michael Caton-Jones, isn‰Ûªt content to be a feel-good story. Not every troubled young person has musical talent or can shed her surliness the first time a grown-up pays attention to her. One of those who doesn‰Ûªt and can‰Ûªt is Leanne (Isabella Laughland), Jamie‰Ûªs longtime friend, a street tough who is as eager to keep Jamie in juvenile delinquency as Kate is to save her.

Kate (Shirley Henderson) is starting a job as a social worker at Alpha House, a home for wayward children where violence rules and the staff makes little effort to rehabilitate the residents. Kate, however, is fueled by a personal tragedy in her past and wants to make a real difference, especially in the life of Jamie (Letitia Wright), a 17-year-old who has been hardened and embittered by a difficult upbringing. Only when Kate discovers that Jamie can sing does she find a way to connect with her and offer some exciting possibilities.
Things meander along to the inevitable blowup scene and a too-easy ending in which all is forgiven and personal growth has occurred, though not for the viewing audience.

Paul (Alex Karpovsky of ‰ÛÏGirls,‰Ûù failing to bring along any of that television show‰Ûªs cachet) is an aspiring comic who isn‰Ûªt funny, which is this movie‰Ûªs first problem. That character is already all over TV in various forms and has more than worn out its welcome and credibility. The conceit requires that the supposed comic keep getting jobs so that we can squirm at the sight of him (yes, it‰Ûªs usually a man, and white) bombing, but that‰Ûªs a stretch, and certainly a serious stand-up wouldn‰Ûªt keep repeating the same unsuccessful joke, as Paul does; he‰Ûªd try to improve.

Anyway, Paul‰Ûªs childhood friend Jason (Wyatt Russell), a successful folk-rock singer, invites Paul to open for him at a series of small-club concerts, and they embark on a road trip that of course finds them gradually getting on each other‰Ûªs nerves. The source of much of the tension is Bryn (Meredith Hagner), a singer whom Jason adds to the tour on a whim and whom both men view as a piece of sexual property. It‰Ûªs the old ‰ÛÏenlightened guys except when the tale needs them not to be‰Ûù school of storytelling. (The movie was written and directed by Jeff Grace.)
What do you get if you make a movie about an aimless, unpleasant road trip? Good guess. For verification, see ‰ÛÏFolk Hero & Funny Guy.‰Ûù

The documentary also sketches a political family tree that could be its own movie and that has Cohn, the chief counsel to Joseph McCarthy, at its head and branches out to include Mr. Stone and Mr. Trump. Mr. Stone wasn‰Ûªt yet 30 when he met Cohn in 1979. (At the time, Mr. Stone was helping to run Reagan‰Ûªs presidential campaign.) Cohn served as Mr. Trump‰Ûªs lawyer for years and, by many accounts, assumed the role of mentor. It was Cohn who introduced Mr. Stone to Mr. Trump; Mr. Stone decided that Mr. Trump was presidential material and, years later, has become identified as one of the president‰Ûªs outside advisers.

As it maps the road to Trumpville, the movie offers glimpses of Mr. Stone‰Ûªs youth, including an oft-repeated story about a light-bulb encounter with Barry Goldwater‰Ûªs book ‰ÛÏThe Conscience of a Conservative.‰Ûù An ideological true believer is born who backs legal pot and has a few Nixon-theme bongs that he likes to show off along with his other Nixonian paraphernalia. After a brush with Watergate, Mr. Stone pokes around here and there; works for both of Ronald Reagan‰Ûªs presidential campaigns; and helps establish a firm that grew into Black, Manafort, Stone and Kelly, one of a number of companies that earned the nickname ‰ÛÏthe torturers‰Ûª lobby‰Ûù for repping countries condemned as human-rights abusers.

Movies about colorful characters, be they saints or sinners, are often hijacked by their subject, so it‰Ûªs unsurprising that Mr. Stone, with his bespoke suits and Nixon tattoo, owns this one from the get-go. An energetic tour guide and three-ring circus of one, he seems happiest in front of the camera, which in turn eagerly laps him up. It‰Ûªs a familiar interdependency and, at times, this movie suggests that his most obvious talent is for self-promotion, one that‰Ûªs been aided by the attention of the news media. Among the few journalists who seem to have really gotten under his thick skin was Wayne Barrett, an investigative reporter for The Village Voice who died in January.

Skip to this Tuesday, when President Trump fired James Comey, the director of the F.B.I., noting his handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton‰Ûªs use of a private email server. Mr. Stone, 64, a giddily freewheeling Twitter user, greeted this news with a series of tweets, including one with a GIF of Mr. Trump stamped ‰ÛÏYou‰Ûªre Fired!‰Ûù and another that reads ‰ÛÏSomewhere Dick Nixon is smiling.‰Ûù On Wednesday, CNN reported that Mr. Stone had recommended that Mr. Trump fire Mr. Comey. The president responded via Twitter:

The movie spends considerable time tagging after the fast-moving Mr. Stone, tracking him from event to event, car to home to microphone, as when he swans into an outdoor rally during the 2016 Republican National Convention that registers as pro-Trump, though perhaps more anti-Clinton. There are signs and people milling about wearing shirts emblazoned with the words ‰ÛÏHillary for Prison‰Ûù; for his part, the uncharacteristically underdressed Mr. Stone seems almost naked in a T-shirt with Bill Clinton‰Ûªs smiling likeness and the word ‰ÛÏrape.‰Ûù The movie doesn‰Ûªt at this point identify Alex Jones, the radio host and conspiracy theorist (the ‰ÛÏPizzagate‰Ûù hoax), who can be seen hovering at Mr. Stone‰Ûªs side.

Whatever else, this is killer timing for Netflix, which is releasing ‰ÛÏGet Me Roger Stone‰Ûù on Friday in theaters and via streaming. That‰Ûªs especially true because in any other year and perhaps under any other administration, this documentary ‰ÛÓ the directors are Daniel DiMauro, Dylan Bank and Morgan Pehme ‰ÛÓ might have disappeared into the ether. But topicality is all or at least a large part of the movie‰Ûªs draw. A sometimes illuminating, often slapdash and frustrating affair that mixes on-the-scenes bits, found material and original interviews (with the likes of Jeffrey Toobin), it opens with Mr. Trump accepting the presidential nomination in July 2016 and ends soon after his election. Much of the rest is a chronological march through Mr. Stone‰Ûªs life, which is studded with scandal and boldfaced names like Roy Cohn.
And on Friday, ‰ÛÏGet Me Roger Stone‰Ûù will do its part to extend Mr. Stone‰Ûªs reach and his brand, both of which seem as unbounded as he does.

The indefatigable Mr. Stone continues to go go go, unapologetically. In January, he published his most recent book, ‰ÛÏThe Making of the President 2016: How Donald Trump Orchestrated a Revolution.‰Ûù On Monday, Alliance Strategies Group announced that it would ‰ÛÏexclusively represent‰Ûù Mr. Stone‰Ûªs online presence for ‰ÛÏdigital advertising opportunities,‰Ûù adding that he is ‰ÛÏmost well-known as President Donald Trump‰Ûªs confidant and political adviser of over 40 years and often viewed as the architect of the Trump presidential strategy.‰Ûù

Roger J. Stone Jr., the subject and star of ‰ÛÏGet Me Roger Stone,‰Ûù struts through this documentary with peacock feathers fully fanned. He‰Ûªs first heard from a perch in some luxury digs, dressed in a tailored chalk-stripe suit with an olive martini at the ready. ‰ÛÏMy name is Roger Stone,‰Ûù he says, ‰ÛÏand I‰Ûªm an agent provocateur.‰Ûù The scene suggests James Bond cosplay, although it‰Ûªs worth mentioning that the definition of an agent provocateur isn‰Ûªt a supercool British fantasy spy but someone who persuades others to do wrong.

Mr. Stone has been providing journalists with copy for years. In 1985, Jacob Weisberg profiled him in The New Republic (‰ÛÏThe State-of-the-Art Washington Sleazeball‰Ûù), drawing a line from Mr. Stone‰Ûªs lobbying work to those Reagan aides ‰ÛÓ Lyn Nofziger, Michael Deaver, Lee Atwater and Ed Rollins ‰ÛÓ who ‰ÛÏhave abandoned helping Reagan make conservative ideas reality in order to sell their connections to the highest bidders.‰Ûù The journalist Jane Mayer (‰ÛÏDark Money‰Ûù) effectively picks up that same thread in the movie when she says, ‰ÛÏLobbying had been considered kind of a sleazy business, but Roger Stone unabashedly came out and said, ‰Û÷I‰Ûªm going to make a pile of money off of this and no apologies.‰Ûª‰Ûù

So, who is Mr. Stone persuading? It‰Ûªs an inevitable question given his relationship with President Trump and how Mr. Stone‰Ûªs name just keeps popping up in the news churn. In a May 5 article in The New York Times, for starters, Mr. Stone confirmed that he was one of what the report called ‰ÛÏhigh-profile Trump campaign associates‰Ûù who‰Ûªd been asked by the Senate Intelligence Committee ‰ÛÏto hand over emails and other records of dealings with Russians as part of its investigation into Russian meddling in the presidential election.‰Ûù Mr. Stone said that he was ‰ÛÏeager, indeed anxious, to testify in full public session, have requested no immunity and am ready to go.‰Ûù

Mr. Jones isn‰Ûªt formally identified until well into the movie, a careless, exasperating decision. Like other documentaries, this one crams found footage into punchy montage sequences held together by (not always identified) voice-overs. The problem with this clip-art approach is that it tends to turn history into cultural wallpaper, as in the section featuring images of the unnamed Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, who ‰ÛÓ with the help of Roy Cohn ‰ÛÓ were executed in 1953 after being convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage. In other areas, the lack of specificity raises questions that remain unanswered, as when an image of the Pentagon flashes by without explanation.

Mr. Young has called the film a thesis on the psychology of destructive relationships (John exerts an abusive, Svengali-like influence over Evelyn). That‰Ûªs a valid perspective, but the movie shortchanges it with creaky plot mechanics, including a bit of contrived foreshadowing that only a screenwriter could love.

The setting for ‰ÛÏHounds of Love‰Ûù is Perth in 1987. Vicki (Ashleigh Cummings), a teenager distraught over her parents‰Ûª separation, is approached by Evelyn (Emma Booth) and John (Stephen Curry), who lure her to their home with the promise of pot. In a set piece that suggests the filmmakers took a morbid glee in staging this material, the couple chain a drugged Vicki to a bed, and she watches them writhe to ‰ÛÏNights in White Satin.‰Ûù

So perhaps it‰Ûªs best to set aside such reservations about the Australian film ‰ÛÏHounds of Love‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ which is hardly a brainless addition to the genre. It‰Ûªs a tense, sharply assembled debut feature from Ben Young. Its main problem, though, is that it never answers a basic question: Why are we watching this? That the news media in Western Australia has noted similarities to a real case ‰ÛÓ the 1986 murder spree of David and Catherine Birnie ‰ÛÓ only heightens the sense of exploitation. (There‰Ûªs no connection to the Kate Bush song.)
At its best, ‰ÛÏHounds of Love‰Ûù probes the relationship between Evelyn and Vicki, who is forced to write a note home saying she‰Ûªs run away.

Cinephiles who object to serial-killer movies for their subject matter risk hypocrisy, unless they‰Ûªre prepared to apply the same standard to ‰ÛÏPsycho,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Silence of the Lambs‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏSeven‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ some of the darkest and most enduring visions in cinema.

The galumphing digital elephants crashing through the hectic, murky opening of ‰ÛÏKing Arthur: Legend of the Sword‰Ûù are an early sign that this isn‰Ûªt meant to be your granddad‰Ûªs Arthurian legend. And, well, why should it be or how could it be, given who‰Ûªs behind the camera? The director Guy Ritchie likes his action fast and frenetic, and he‰Ûªs more focused on how things look ‰ÛÓ mostly, he‰Ûªs chasing that certain something called cool ‰ÛÓ than in narrative coherency or plausibility. And, anyway, those angry elephants are magical, just like the dragons swooping through the HBO show ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones.‰Ûù

Arthur and Vortigern mix it up amid a lot of shenanigans, detours and filler, some bad, some good and all of it disposable. Written by Mr. Ritchie, Joby Harold and Lionel Wigram, the movie is mostly about establishing Arthur‰Ûªs origin story, which turns on the usual reluctant hero coming to terms with his destiny, meaning Dad (Eric Bana) and Dad‰Ûªs mighty sword. This lineage and its burdens take a while to work through, primarily because this movie plays like the first installment in a hoped-for series. Merlin scarcely makes the scene, and Guinevere and Lancelot have yet to arrive to stir up trouble.

The opener is a clotted visual mess, which isn‰Ûªt surprising. But it is disappointing just because the whole thing ‰ÛÓ the landscape, castle and so forth ‰ÛÓ is so drearily fake and ugly, even if the elephants are kind of amusing and it‰Ûªs always nice to see Mr. Bana. The movie improves once Mr. Ritchie moves closer to his actors, a pleasantly diverting crew that includes Djimon Hounsou as a fixer extraordinaire and Astrid BergÌ¬s-Frisbey as a witchy woman of some type. They help sell the generic goods ‰ÛÓ basically, a band of merry, dirty dozen (or so) smarty-pants renegades giving it to the Man ‰ÛÓ and the results are easy enough to watch, especially if, like Mr. Hunnam, you don‰Ûªt embarrass easily.

It‰Ûªs hard not to attribute the existence of this new Arthurian tale in part to the global success of ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones,‰Ûù which has hooked legions on its epic soap opera, clashing swords, spurting blood and unending intrigue. (That show‰Ûªs Aidan Gillen pops up here too.) The Arthur story has played out differently across the centuries, from the Middle Ages to T. H. White‰Ûªs novel ‰ÛÏThe Sword in the Stone‰Ûù to Disney‰Ûªs 20th-century cartoon take, and each moment in time shapes the way it‰Ûªs told. In this case, that means something old, something blockbustery and that Guy Ritchie je ne sais quoi.

Put differently, this variation on the Arthurian legend fleetingly brings to mind ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones‰Ûù but mostly plays out according to the Ritchie template: a self-amused, endlessly resourceful laddish hero gets in and out of trouble with winks, smarts and brute force, sometimes in the company of Jude Law. This time the resident rogue is Arthur, played with easy, low-wattage charisma by Charlie Hunnam, who has a gift for delivering nonsense without seeming embarrassed. Mr. Law, who played Watson in Mr. Ritchie‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSherlock‰Ûù flicks, takes on mustache-twirling duties as Vortigern, a louche pouter who skulks around in black, doubtless dreaming of Richard III.

How ‰ÛÏThe Last Shaman‰Ûù came to be isn‰Ûªt discussed in the film, but this documentary might be less disquieting if it had been. After trying the hallucinogenic tea ayahuasca, Raz Degan, an Israeli-born actor, sought to make a movie about the brew‰Ûªs ostensible medicinal powers.

In the process, he met James Freeman, an American suicidal from depression. Fearing that his illness was intractable ‰ÛÓ despite medication, a hospital stay and electroconvulsive therapy ‰ÛÓ Mr. Freeman traveled to Peru for shamanic healing. (We meet his apprehensive physician parents in the Boston area.)

It‰Ûªs possible to have doubts about ayahuasca (which, we learn, has been increasingly commercialized) and still find Mr. Freeman‰Ûªs resolve uplifting. Even he acknowledges that novelty and psychosomatic benefits may contribute to his convalescence. During one stretch, he lives in isolation and keeps a video diary.

In an unfortunate choice, Mr. Degan augments the ayahuasca scenes with bits of freakout editing ‰ÛÓ as if he could show us what‰Ûªs inside Mr. Freeman‰Ûªs head. Perhaps the director is tipping his hand: It‰Ûªs hard to believe a disclaimer at the end, which says the film is not intended to suggest a course of treatment.

Mr. Degan is an unobtrusive presence in a film that would have benefited from overt, Socratic questioning. Mr. Freeman attends a shamanic ceremony in which a man has a fatal reaction to the ayahuasca. Later, in Peru, he meets a shaman from Kentucky who tells him that ‰ÛÏtrue healers don‰Ûªt charge.‰Ûù The most helpful shaman is Pepe, who lives in a Shipibo village.

Combine two Army Rangers and one pile of stones, throw in a disembodied voice and a whole heap of sand, and you have almost the entirety of ‰ÛÏThe Wall,‰Ûù a compressed thriller from Doug Liman that‰Ûªs more psychological standoff than traditional war game.

If you‰Ûªre the novice screenwriter Dwain Worrell, you introduce a gimmick: a sniper who really wants to talk. And as his voice on Isaac‰Ûªs mobile phone reveals, he‰Ûªs also educated, fond of Edgar Allan Poe, and knowledgeable about the movements of Isaac‰Ûªs unit. To reveal more would be unfair, but suffice to say that, like the entombed civilian contractor played by Ryan Reynolds in Rodrigo CortÌ©s‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBuried,‰Ûù Isaac knows that his escape might depend more on wits than weapons.

Yet the vein-popping mood is ultimately more exhausting than exciting. Where Mr. CortÌ©s used crucial voice work from a handful of notable actors to vary his movie‰Ûªs tone and lift us, psychologically at least, out of that tomb, Mr. Liman embraces the script‰Ûªs restrictions. The result is less like a movie and more like a palate-cleansing exercise ‰ÛÓ something that a big-ticket director might do just to see if he still can.

For a while, this formula works as Sergeant Isaac (Aaron Taylor-Johnson) hunkers behind a crumbling wall in a godforsaken swath of Iraq, pinned down by an unseen enemy sniper. The year is 2007, and the war is winding down; but Isaac and his commanding officer, Staff Sgt. Matthews (the professional wrestler and entertainment hyphenate John Cena), were responding to a distress signal when the sniper struck. Matthews has already been severely wounded and lies unconscious on the other side of the wall. What to do?

Working with an unusually small budget (this is no ‰ÛÏEdge of Tomorrow‰Ûù) and an uncomfortably tight shooting schedule (14 days in the California desert), Mr. Liman answers the siren song of minimalism with gusto if not complete success. In lieu of flying shrapnel and fancy production design, the director ramps the intensity to 11, then breaks the dial. Sweaty, square-jawed close-ups substitute for fighting, and fake blood is doled out by the thimbleful. Special effects are hoarded for maximum shock and awe.

Also like ‰ÛÏBuried,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Wall‰Ûù is essentially a one-man show, and Mr. Taylor-Johnson can‰Ûªt be faulted, somehow injecting energy and variety into his character‰Ûªs largely immobile plight. He‰Ûªs helped immensely by the director of photography, Roman Vasyanov (a favorite of the director David Ayer), who uses Super 16-millimeter film and natural light to fashion a hellhole of heat and thirst strewn with the debris of combat.

Like ‰ÛÏFill the Void,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Wedding Plan‰Ûù concerns marriage, something that the 32-year-old Michal (Noa Koler) desperately wants. On the verge of tying the knot, she asks her fiancÌ© why he‰Ûªs seemed distant. He admits that he doesn‰Ûªt love her, a confession he had been avoiding.

Like Ms. Burshtein, who also wrote the script, Michal doesn‰Ûªt fit ultra-Orthodox stereotypes. (She runs a mobile petting zoo, which hardly seems like a typical profession.) In a complicated role, the excellent Ms. Koler exudes a kind of flighty confidence: For all her nuptial-related anxieties, Michal is completely comfortable with who she is.

But ‰ÛÏThe Wedding Plan‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt settle, as the Hollywood version of this story might have, for offering a cavalcade of comically wrong men. It holds out a few different prospects for Michal and keeps her (and us) guessing until the end. It‰Ûªs a comedy in the Shakespearean sense ‰ÛÓ we know it will end with a wedding, groom or not ‰ÛÓ but Ms. Burshtein leaves open the possibility that it might be a broken one. The hoped-for marriage isn‰Ûªt just a test of Michal‰Ûªs happiness but also of her religiosity: A rabbi warns Michal against ‰ÛÏcounting on miracles,‰Ûù and wonders what will happen to her faith if she doesn‰Ûªt find a husband in time.

Ms. Burshtein asks viewers to take a leap of faith as well with a borderline surreal finale, which finds Michal, woozy in close-ups during a fast, trying to comprehend what‰Ûªs happening around her. It‰Ûªs a mystical touch ‰ÛÓ another tipoff that this ordinary-sounding movie is actually pretty special.

Taking the engagement‰Ûªs collapse in stride, Michal tallies the years she‰Ûªs been dating. Impulsively following through on her original plans, she books a wedding hall for the last night of Hanukkah. That gives her three weeks to find a groom ‰ÛÓ possibly more of a miracle than the Hanukkah lights.

The premise and the title of ‰ÛÏThe Wedding Plan‰Ûù suggest a bubbly rom-com, but this prickly, delicately layered film from Rama Burshtein ‰ÛÓ an ultra-Orthodox director based in Israel ‰ÛÓ has the tangled ambiguity of a Talmudic lesson. Like Ms. Burshtein‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFill the Void‰Ûù (2013), the story of a religious woman who must decide whether to marry her dead sister‰Ûªs husband, ‰ÛÏThe Wedding Plan‰Ûù manages to be respectful of traditions while at the same time feeling modern, even progressive.

Certainly, the matchmaking industry doesn‰Ûªt know what to make of her. Michal is set up with a succession of men, including one who is deaf and another who refuses to look at her. (If he only looks at the woman he marries, he explains, she‰Ûªll be the most beautiful woman in the world to him.) For a stretch, Michal‰Ûªs most likely candidate seems to be the nonreligious pop star (Oz Zehavi) she meets on a pilgrimage in Ukraine. Is he toying with her? Is she toying with him?

‰ÛÏTracktown‰Ûù nails the athletic details: the raw eggs and specialized diet; the sensuality of toned bodies in exertion; the glitter of sports celebrity. And the attendant anxieties: ‰ÛÏI look like a boy,‰Ûù Plumb nervously tells Sawyer when he first beholds her taut abdomen. There is a subplot concerning Plumb‰Ûªs estranged mother (Rachel Dratch, on point), but the film doesn‰Ûªt stray far from romance.

Plumb, who lives an insular existence with her father (Andy Buckley), is training with her best friend (Rebecca Friday) when she takes a shine to Sawyer (an affable, understated Chase Offerle), who works at a bakery on their route. After a doctor tells Plumb that she must rest for a day before competing in the Olympic trials ‰ÛÓ an option that‰Ûªs anathema to her ‰ÛÓ she drops in on Sawyer, and soon is visiting his truck camper, weighing her attraction against the demands of her sport.

Fact and fiction blend nicely in ‰ÛÏTracktown,‰Ûù the modest, appealing feature debut of Alexi Pappas, an American-born runner who competed for Greece at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro. Ms. Pappas ‰ÛÓ who, with Jeremy Teicher, also wrote, produced and directed ‰ÛÓ plays Plumb Marigold, an Olympic hopeful in Eugene, Ore., who discovers that there is life, and love, off the track.

Ms. Pappas has little dialogue, but the camera adores her expressive, wide-eyed face, which conveys plenty. It will be interesting to see her evolve as an actress. As a writer, she has sound instincts: ‰ÛÏTracktown‰Ûù is less about winning races and more about a greater victory, being true to yourself.

Beyond simple nostalgia, though, the appeal of this limp retread is difficult to discern. Peter McDougall‰Ûªs screenplay (once again based on the novel by Compton Mackenzie, which in turn was inspired by a 1941 shipwreck in the Outer Hebrides) resurrects key plot points without any obvious attempt to refresh or modernize. References to the Raj and Wallis Simpson might have slayed in 1949, but 21st-century audiences are unlikely to get the joke.

Filmed on the northern coast of Aberdeenshire, ‰ÛÏWhisky Galore!‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ unlike the liquid it lusts after ‰ÛÓ is dry, dull and without kick or color. Gone is the original‰Ûªs joyful sense of mischief; what‰Ûªs left is an inoffensive piece of twaddle that never fully appreciates the ineluctable bond between community spirit and a drop of the hard stuff.

If you‰Ûªre going to remake a classic Scottish comedy, then you‰Ûªd better have something fresh hidden up your kilt to make the effort worthwhile. And given that the original ‰ÛÏWhisky Galore!‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ Alexander Mackendrick‰Ûªs warmly funny 1949 tale of fictional Hebridean islanders driven to lawlessness after their wartime ration of whisky runs out ‰ÛÓ is well nigh unimprovable, the director Gillies MacKinnon has his work cut out.

As Macroon, the film‰Ûªs narrator and the island‰Ûªs widowed postmaster, Gregor Fisher leads a cast that‰Ûªs ill-served by the musty script. Whether rushing to salvage the cases of Scotch newly liberated from a foundering cargo ship, or scrambling to hide their spoils from a bumbling Home Guard captain (Eddie Izzard, creamy English vowels at the ready), the islanders are as uninteresting as Macroon‰Ûªs woolly cardigans.

In an early scene in ‰ÛÏAfterimage,‰Ûù the artist and theoretician Wladyslaw Strzeminski sits on the floor of his studio as he looks at a canvas. The camera then reverses angles, and viewers see the white canvas suddenly turn vivid red. Indeed, the entire studio is soon suffused with red, because a giant banner celebrating Stalin is being hoisted up the front of the building. Strzeminski crawls over to his window ‰ÛÓ he lost an arm and a leg from injuries suffered in World War I ‰ÛÓ and pokes at the banner with one of his crutches, rending the fabric somewhat, which attracts the attention of the apparatchiks in charge of the operation. And so Strzeminski‰Ûªs latest troubles begin.

This is an angry, vivid, passionate film. Cinema is worse off now that Wajda, one of the truly towering greats of the form, is dead; there is some consolation, though, that he went out with his boots still most defiantly on.

A committed avant-garde painter who tells his students that art is about an individual way of seeing rather than about rote reproduction of a collectively agreed-upon reality, Strzeminski collides with the latest modes demanded by Stalinist rule. ‰ÛÏAfterimage,‰Ûù the final film directed by the Polish master Andrzej Wajda, who died in 2016 at 90, depicts an appalling system, filled with complicit go-along-to-get-along citizens, grinding down Strzeminski, a real-life figure.

‰ÛÏHave you really met Marc Chagall?‰Ûù one of the bureaucrats asks Strzeminski shortly after she fires him from what will be his last paying job. The reaction shot is quietly devastating in the hands of the great Polish actor Boguslaw Linda, a Wajda veteran, who plays Strzeminski.

David, it turns out, has devoted the years since ‰ÛÏPrometheus‰Ûù to the study and cultivation of our beloved alien, while also harboring a grudge against the species that created him. Walter, in contrast, is more of a humanist, and the quarrel between them is not unlike the one between Magneto and Professor X in the ‰ÛÏX-Men‰Ûù movies (speaking of Michael Fassbender) or Koba and Caesar in ‰ÛÏDawn of the Planet of the Apes‰Ûù (speaking of posthumous James Franco). I will leave it to you to decide who has the better argument, and who deserves to prevail.

When the larval alien at last explodes out of a human torso, you may experience, along with the expected jolt of fright, a curious sensation of relief, even affection. So much has changed in the world, and in movies, since the first ‰ÛÏAlien‰Ûù freaked out audiences in 1979, that the appearance of a chittering, scurrying, fast-spawning extraterrestrial predator feels like a visit from an old friend. Humanity may have lapsed into terminal tedium or hubristic stupidity, but that creature, with long, slender limbs and a cranium like a speedskater‰Ûªs helmet, remains interesting.

The answer, in any case, can only be the Giger alien itself, a contribution to the pantheon of modern design up there with the Coca-Cola logo and the Nike swoosh. From spore to embryo to full-grown raptor and all the stages in between, this monster is the stubborn movie equivalent of an earworm ‰ÛÓ a lovable parasite, a squiggle of pop-cultural DNA that burrows into your rib cage and never goes away.
