Most of them do. Mr. Franco‰Ûªs character, the captain of the Covenant, is a goner at the outset, reanimated in videos that stir his widow‰Ûªs grief. The first mate (Mr. Crudup) assumes command and leads his subordinates onto the surface of the green but curiously lifeless planet, the exact spot where some of the Prometheus crew members ended up. There they meet a robot named David, who invites some of the astronauts back to his cave to look at his etchings.

To complain about its lack of ambition would be to misconstrue its intentions. Rather than setting out to conquer new worlds or excavate primal fears, this ‰ÛÏAlien‰Ûù is content to uphold a long-lived and well-regarded brand. Correcting some of the previous film‰Ûªs mistakes ‰ÛÓ not enough alien! too much mythological mumbo-jumbo best left to movies with ‰ÛÏStar‰Ûù in the title! ‰ÛÓ Mr. Scott parcels out carefully measured portions of awe, wonder and terror on the established installment plan. This episode needs to satisfy you just enough to make sure you come back for the next one.

David, in contrast, has a crisp British accent and an acquaintance with human culture that extends to Wagner and Michelangelo but is a bit wobbly on romantic poetry. Viewers who stayed awake through freshman English or the fifth season of ‰ÛÏBreaking Bad‰Ûù know full well that Byron didn‰Ûªt write ‰ÛÏOzymandias.‰Ûù I‰Ûªm telling you this so you aren‰Ûªt fooled (as I confess I was) into spending a few minutes feeling smarter than the screenwriters, John Logan and Dante Harper. I don‰Ûªt think that counts as a spoiler.

The story begins 10 years after the events of ‰ÛÏPrometheus‰Ûù and ends en route to a sequel that will bring us closer to the beginning of the cycle. (Arranging installments in sequential order is a totally old-fashioned, linear, 20th-century way of doing business.) As usual, a starship is plying the far reaches of space. As usual, the crew is a collection of talented actors obeying the imperatives of science-fiction seriousness. There are a bunch of married couples ‰ÛÓ James Franco and Katherine Waterston; Danny McBride and Amy Seimetz; DemiÌÁn Bichir and Nathaniel Dean; Billy Crudup and Carmen Ejogo ‰ÛÓ and others with enough personality to make us feel a little something when they die.

The same can be said about ‰ÛÏAlien: Covenant,‰Ûù which follows  ‰ÛÏPrometheus‰Ûù in Ridley Scott‰Ûªs 21st-century refurbishing of the franchise he initiated (with the crucial contributions of Sigourney Weaver and the graphic artist H. R. Giger) almost 40 years ago. It‰Ûªs an interesting movie. I wish I could be more effusive, but ‰ÛÏCovenant,‰Ûù for all its interplanetary ranging, commits itself above all to the canny management of expectations.

And Mr. Scott is, in any case, a nearly spoiler-proof filmmaker. Even his lesser efforts are infused with enough craft and energy to keep you engaged and surprised, and ‰ÛÏAlien: Covenant‰Ûù is no exception. The gloom and shadows of the inhospitable planet and the hushed, antiseptic corridors of the Covenant are superior horror-movie environments, and the fact that you know more or less exactly what‰Ûªs coming doesn‰Ûªt diminish the creepiness, or lessen the jolt when the thing you‰Ûªre dreading arrives.

David ‰ÛÓ seen in ‰ÛÏPrometheus‰Ûù and in a Kubrick-esque prologue here ‰ÛÓ is played by Michael Fassbender. So is another robot named Walter, a slightly updated model from the Weyland corporation. The differences between the two machines are striking. Walter wears his hair parted on the side and has been engineered to speak like someone from Wisconsin. (How does Mr. Fassbender do it?)

In interviews, Green Berets describe ferocious events, like the annihilation of a Taliban convoy, and sorrowful moments, like battlefield errors that led to the friendly-fire deaths of several Americans.

Other scenes touch on post-traumatic stress, combat tactics, civilian readjustment and more. It‰Ûªs a lot to cover in under 80 minutes, and Mr. Barker sometimes spreads himself too thin ‰ÛÓ clarifying details are frequently not supplied. A tighter focus, like those employed by the documentaries ‰ÛÏCitizen Soldier,‰Ûù which followed deployed National Guard members, or ‰ÛÏThank You for Your Service,‰Ûù which looked at suicides among military veterans, could have fostered a clearer narrative.

This documentary, directed by Greg Barker, recounts secret missions by Special Forces who were sent to Afghanistan immediately after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Within weeks, small teams of these soldiers formed coalitions with the Afghan Northern Alliance, waged war on enemies and, at the time, drove the Taliban from power.
You‰Ûªll have to wade through several topics to get to the heart of ‰ÛÏLegion of Brothers,‰Ûù but once you‰Ûªre there, some intense stories make the effort worthwhile.

To his credit, Mr. Barker doesn‰Ûªt disregard the frustration and confusion that go hand-in-hand with bravery and dedication. One officer, recalling his decision to approve airstrikes that killed scores of Taliban fighters, is confident that his decision saved his own men. Yet he remains stunned by the immense power and complexities of modern warfare. ‰ÛÏI felt like I should have been looking the enemy in the eye before I killed them,‰Ûù he says.

The bits familiar from every other family trip comedy turn up with numbing predictability: the wretched hotel, the overheated minivan, the stops at tawdry roadside attractions, the vomit scene. All of the principal cast members are new, but the director, David Bowers, isn‰Ûªt; he did installments No. 2 and 3 as well as this one, the fourth, and his preference for ‰ÛÏhey, look at me‰Ûù acting from the child stars is again on full display. Bathroom humor, none of it funny, abounds.

The ‰ÛÏDiary of a Wimpy Kid‰Ûù movie franchise has been dormant for five years, so the new installment, subtitled ‰ÛÏThe Long Haul,‰Ûù was an opportunity to rejuvenate this never very good series with some recasting. Unfortunately, the fresh blood has been saddled with a tired story, the family road trip that goes outlandishly awry, and the result is another forgettable film.

The title character, Greg (Jason Drucker); his older brother, Rodrick (Charlie Wright); and their toddler sibling, Manny (Wyatt and Dylan Walters), are dragged by their parents (Alicia Silverstone and Tom Everett Scott) on a lengthy trip to visit the family matriarch for her 90th birthday. The two older boys conspire on a plan to take a detour to a video game conference, where Greg hopes to repair damage done by a viral video that made him infamous.

It‰Ûªs all based on the characters created by Jeff Kinney (who wrote this script with Mr. Bowers), which remain much more tolerable as stick figures, the way he renders them in his books, than they do in the flesh.

Employing neither computer-generated effects nor a distracting score, ‰ÛÏThe Survivalist‰Ûù bolsters its pitiless tone and uneasy mood with natural woodland sounds and the unreliable light of fire and lamp. Observing the film‰Ûªs horrors ‰ÛÓ a maggoty wound, a crudely improvised abortion attempt ‰ÛÓ with the same neutral gaze as its softer moments, Mr. Fingleton seems to acknowledge that when society falls apart, empathy might be the first and most regrettable casualty.

He‰Ûªs also blessed with an unwaveringly steady hand (as is his director of photography, Damien Elliott) that persists through moments of stark brutality. Set in an indeterminate time and place ‰ÛÓ after an unexplained oil-related catastrophe ‰ÛÓ the story plays out in a leafy wood where an unnamed man (Martin McCann) subsists on meager crops and painful memories. These recollections are signaled by a crumpled photograph and sudden, sparse flashbacks that flare and fade.

Impressively lean and rigidly controlled, ‰ÛÏThe Survivalist‰Ûù achieves, at times, the primitive allure of a silent movie. And that‰Ûªs not simply because of the characters‰Ûª reticence (the entirety of the dialogue could probably fit on a single page), but because the film‰Ûªs Irish writer and director, Stephen Fingleton, has an intensity of purpose that infects his characters‰Ûª every move and gesture.

The arrival of a starving mother and daughter (perfectly embodied by Olwen FouÌ©rÌ© and Mia Goth) disrupts the survivalist‰Ûªs methodical routines and hardened emotions. Sex can be traded for food and shelter, but trust has no price; and as relationships shift and outside perils multiply, the movie‰Ûªs real tension is cooked in the constantly adjusting space that separates these three characters. To survive, three must become two.

None of it is quite believable. Ms. Swicord ‰ÛÓ and Mr. Cranston, too ‰ÛÓ seem trapped in Wakefield‰Ûªs solipsism. On the page, other people can be perceived through the screen of a narrator‰Ûªs consciousness: Diana‰Ûªs unreality is a symptom of her husband‰Ûªs self-absorption, an index of his unreliability. But onscreen, Ms. Garner disappears more thoroughly than Mr. Cranston, and it‰Ûªs frustrating rather than illuminating to see her reduced to a cipher and a symbol of someone else‰Ûªs discontent. And that condition itself is weak tea and stale beer, beyond the reach of philosophical intrigue or even ordinary curiosity.

Wakefield watches as Diana‰Ûªs initial shock gives way to grief and then ‰ÛÓ maybe a little too quickly ‰ÛÓ to resignation, and he reminisces about their courtship and early marriage. She was a dancer when they met, dating a friend of his (Jason O‰ÛªMara), and Wakefield narrates with cruel relish the way he stole her affections and spirited her away to the suburbs. There, she raised the children and worked at an art museum, while he feathered the nest and rode the Metro-North rails.

In spite of Mr. Cranston‰Ûªs guile and grit, Ms. Swicord‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWakefield‰Ûù is something less than that. The film, scrupulously faithful to its source, is decidedly literary, but not in an especially satisfying way. In its view of suburban discontent and masculine malaise, it leans on borrowed insights and an unearned aura of significance. Too mannered for realism and too thin for fable, it spins its wheels in a social and intellectual void filled only by Wakefield‰Ûªs voice-over musings and the shadow of Doctorow‰Ûªs virtuosity.

He remains there for months, becoming something of a living poltergeist, invisibly haunting the domestic space that had once belonged to him. There are other ways to describe him: as a creepy voyeur, sadistically observing the pain and confusion his departure has caused; as a mock-heroic dissident, rejecting the emptiness and inauthenticity of modern middle-class existence; or even, more philosophically, as ‰ÛÏthe Outcast of the Universe.‰Ûù

Now, his clothes filthy and his beard overgrown, Wakefield ventures out at night to scavenge his neighbors‰Ûª trash. On occasions when he goes out in daylight, he is confident that no one will recognize him. His emotions swing from liberation to anguish, with a consistent note of contempt ‰ÛÓ for his family, for his circumstances and above all for himself.

That last phrase comes from a sketch, also called ‰ÛÏWakefield,‰Ûù by Nathaniel Hawthorne. The movie, written and directed by Robin Swicord and starring Bryan Cranston and Jennifer Garner, isn‰Ûªt based on that tale, but on a much longer 2008 story by E. L. Doctorow, which elegantly updates and expands some of Hawthorne‰Ûªs themes. The idea of escape ‰ÛÓ specifically the male fantasy of flight from a supposedly female-dominated world of family and responsibility ‰ÛÓ is at least as old as Rip Van Winkle, and Doctorow‰Ûªs text is in part a sly and self-conscious commentary on that literary tradition. His Wakefield is a creature of words, less a man than a conceit.

The title character in ‰ÛÏWakefield‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ we learn in due course that his first name is Howard ‰ÛÓ commutes home every evening to his handsome suburban house from the Manhattan law firm where he‰Ûªs a partner. One night, aided by the serendipitous convergence of a delayed train and a dead cellphone battery, he slips out of his routine and into an odd kind of exile. Instead of walking in the front door to greet his wife, Diana, and their twin daughters, Wakefield betakes himself to a storage room above the garage, where he can observe his own absence through a small window.

In a moment that seems unintentionally revealing, he adds, ‰ÛÏI felt that our handling of the bank was consistent with how we would have handled the bank if we were investigating a bank that serviced a South American community or the Indian community.‰Ûù

The film persuasively argues that any fraud at Abacus occurred at a low level, and that the bank dealt with it swiftly and properly. The prosecution was, in its view, an arrogant waste of resources and possibly an act of scapegoating. (The flip side of the banks that were too big to fail, the journalist Matt Taibbi says in the film, is this bank, which was ‰ÛÏsmall enough to jail.‰Ûù) The documentary also shows how Abacus had played an important role as a neighborhood banker in an immigrant community.

Abacus was, a title card at the end asserts, ‰ÛÏthe only U.S. bank indicted for mortgage fraud related to the 2008 crisis.‰Ûù Was the government giving a pass to big fish and picking on a small one ‰ÛÓ perhaps with a tinge of racism in its motives? Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the district attorney who oversaw the case, called the accusations of cultural bias ‰ÛÏentirely misplaced and entirely wrong.‰Ûù

The filmmakers have asked that the trial‰Ûªs verdict, announced in June 2015, be withheld from reviews to preserve suspense. An eye roll is the proper response, along with ‰ÛÓ in the online version of this review ‰ÛÓ a link to the New York Times article on the trial‰Ûªs outcome, which Mr. Sung is shown reading in the film. His hero is James Stewart in ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs a Wonderful Life,‰Ûù and things worked out O.K. in that movie.

At least he agreed to be interviewed, which isn‰Ûªt always the case in documentaries that fall so firmly on one side of a case. The movie makes no secret of its affection for the Sung family, which was well equipped professionally, if not financially, for an expensive legal battle. Of Mr. Sung‰Ûªs four daughters, three were trained as lawyers ‰ÛÓ including Jill Sung, the bank‰Ûªs chief executive, and Vera Sung, a director of the bank ‰ÛÓ and another had even worked in the district attorney‰Ûªs office that prosecuted the case. The sisters have great charisma onscreen, although their mother, Hwei Lin Sung, earns the biggest smiles.

The veteran documentary director Steve James is best known for ‰ÛÏHoop Dreams‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Interrupters,‰Ûù two expansive Chicago films that on the surface concerned basketball and violent crime but had much to say about the American dream and the potential for self-invention. His crowd-pleasing new documentary, ‰ÛÏAbacus: Small Enough to Jail,‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt aspire to the same scale as those films, but like them, it‰Ûªs a kind of stealth home movie: a portrait of two generations of an immigrant family in the United States.

Born in Shanghai, Thomas Sung founded the Abacus Federal Savings Bank in Chinatown in 1984, hoping to make it easier for s Chinese immigrants to get loans. The bank became a community hub, but in 2012, the Manhattan district attorney‰Ûªs office charged it with mortgage fraud, also indicting 19 of its former employees.

The story needs the perfect Maddy, and Ms. Meghie finds her in Amandla Stenberg (Rue from ‰ÛÏThe Hunger Games‰Ûù), who is utterly convincing as a teenager full of longing but resigned to her circumstances. Nick Robinson (‰ÛÏMelissa & Joey‰Ûù) pairs with her nicely as Olly, who has his own burdens thanks to a father with a drinking problem.

Anika Noni Rose plays Maddy‰Ûªs mother, a doctor who is fiercely protective, though the role is left a bit underdeveloped. Also pivotal to the tale is Carla (Ana de la Reguera), Maddy‰Ûªs longtime nurse, who takes the leap of faith that furthers Maddy and Olly‰Ûªs relationship.
The story loses credibility at the end, but the demographic that is the main target here won‰Ûªt care; it will be caught up in the romance, rooting for a young couple that‰Ûªs hard not to like.

A new family moves in next door that includes Olly, a boy who likes to dress in black but has a gentlemanly soul. He sees Maddy in the window and strikes up a friendship with her that begins with handwritten signs, and progresses to texting and beyond.

With a pair of irresistible leads and a straightforward love-overcomes-adversity story, ‰ÛÏEverything, Everything‰Ûù scores a direct hit on the teenage-girl market. Others might find it pretty enjoyable as well.

Stella Meghie directed this adaptation of Nicola Yoon‰Ûªs young-adult novel about a teenager, Maddy, who has spent her life inside a sterile house because of an immune system disorder that leaves her catastrophically vulnerable to diseases. (Did you just have a flashback to ‰ÛÏBubble Boy‰Ûù? Rest easy; this movie is a completely different animal.)

Advances in image-making technology ‰ÛÓ not just digital capture and storage, but ever-shrinking lenses and sensors ‰ÛÓ have brought new dimensions to the depiction of reality. ‰ÛÏHell on Earth: The Fall of Syria and the Rise of ISIS,‰Ûù directed by the intrepid journalist Sebastian Junger and the documentarian Nick Quested, contains imagery that was unimaginable not too many years ago.

The movie also tries to explain the causes of what‰Ûªs happening in Syria, and its repercussions. Flawed United States policies get a thorough airing; by the same token, you are left to wonder what could possibly represent a ‰ÛÏwinning‰Ûù policy here. In his narration, Mr. Junger compares the situation to a bar fight, ‰ÛÏwhere everyone jumps in and is throwing chairs at each other.‰Ûù He adds that in a proxy war, no one gets out clean.

A mostly impressive array of experts (including, in the movie‰Ûªs one unfortunate off note, Michael T. Flynn, who was forced to resign as national security adviser) adds to the merciless clarity of this tragic picture.

When I say ‰ÛÏunimaginable,‰Ûù I‰Ûªm not just talking about tech issues. The directors include footage recorded through a device in a motorcycle helmet worn by Mohammed Merah when he killed seven people in southwestern France in 2012. (The actual murders are omitted, but we see the aftermath.) The directors also show videos of the beheadings of several Western captives by masked Islamic State killers; these propaganda videos were noteworthy not just for what they showed, but also for their professional polish. Footage of two Syrian family men, identified only as Marwan and Radwan, who are trying to get themselves and their loved ones out of the country, had to be shot in secret, and looks it.

Her experiences presumably form the basis for the film‰Ûªs fictional protagonist, Angelina (Ana Cecilia Stieglitz), who travels to Anaconda Cosmica, a real retreat in Peru, hoping for help with a medical problem that is only alluded to.

It helps to know the back story: Leonor Caraballo, who directed the movie with Matteo Norzi and wrote it with Mr. Norzi and Abou Farman, was an artist who explored the medicinal and hallucinatory plants of the Amazon after she found out she had cancer. She died in 2015, before the film had been finished.

A variety of others are being treated there, for addiction, stuttering and more. Angelina forms a particular bond with Arturo (Arturo Izquierdo), a young shaman who is still learning that skill and finds out that he is losing his eyesight. Together they explore their fears with help from the psychedelic brew ayahuasca.

Translating hallucinogenic effects into film is risky business, but the inventive ‰ÛÏIcaros: A Vision‰Ûù takes up the challenge fearlessly as it delves into a story set in a healing center in the Peruvian jungle. You may find this sparse film maddeningly elusive, but chances are you‰Ûªll come out of it with your head spinning, in a good way.

But don‰Ûªt expect anything like a traditional cinematic story here. This is a movie about the experience (with a few understated pleas for the preservation of the rain forest), and it is adventurous in its use of surreal imagery to convey what the characters are experiencing. If it occasionally resembles a clumsily trippy music video, for the most part it stays intriguing. Mesmerizing, even.

A lot of movies about grief prefer that it be neat, orderly, follow certain patterns ‰ÛÓ bottled up emotions are expressed, tears are shed, a group hug resolves everything. But in real life, grief is rarely so cooperative. It makes its presence known at odd times and in unexpected ways, and it affects everyone differently.

Ms. Tamblyn dares to tell this story without actually telling the story ‰ÛÓ little is learned of Michael or why he killed himself, and his relationship with Josie is seen only in flashbacks and fantasies. The movie is an adaptation of a 2006 novel by Janet Fitch, but only in the sketchiest of ways. It‰Ûªs really all about the grieving and about how suicide‰Ûªs toll is measured in more than simply a life lost. It‰Ûªs not an easy movie to embrace, but it lingers.

Alia Shawkat (‰ÛÏArrested Development,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏSearch Party‰Ûù), who dominates this movie, is Josie, a habituÌ© of punk clubs who becomes unmoored after her lover, Michael (Rhys Wakefield), commits suicide. Equally at sea is Michael‰Ûªs mother (Janet McTeer), a classical pianist whose sorrow at first takes the form of lashing out at Josie. But as the two warily eye each other, something resembling mutual support occasionally surfaces amid the hostility.

That kind of grief ‰ÛÓ the real kind ‰ÛÓ is what the actress Amber Tamblyn is trying to capture in her directorial debut, ‰ÛÏPaint It Black,‰Ûù a convention-defying film about how two polar-opposite women react to the same loss.

Set in the mid-1970s and loosely based on the director‰Ûªs own experiences (previously explored in his stage play, ‰ÛÏKollektivet‰Ûù), Tobias Lindholm‰Ûªs screenplay sacrifices credibility for quirkiness. So when Erik and Anna (Ulrich Thomsen and a magnificent Trine Dyrholm) inherit a rambling mansion that they can‰Ûªt afford to live in, and decide to create a commune to defray expenses, naturally they choose housemates whose peculiarities far exceed their incomes.

Like Annette Bening‰Ûªs resilient matriarch in Mike Mills‰Ûªs recent and delightful ‰ÛÏ20th Century Women‰Ûù (which shares some thematic similarities with ‰ÛÏThe Commune‰Ûù), Anna is a woman of a certain age coping with uncertain times. It says much for Ms. Dyrholm‰Ûªs performance that we never doubt that she will prevail.

Though they provide color and friendly conflict, these folks are never more than narrative satellites, vehicles for embarrassing outbursts and sentimental health crises. Yet among the skinny-dipping sessions and eventful house meetings, Ms. Dyrholm quietly and affectingly takes Anna to the brink of despair and back again. A longtime news anchor whose career is threatened by stress and ageism and whose marriage to Erik ‰ÛÓ a crabby, self-centered professor ‰ÛÓ has begun to ossify, Anna seems the sole adult in a house filled with children. Even her wardrobe is out of sync with the other women‰Ûªs floaty, hippie layers.

Sweeter and soapier than we‰Ûªve come to expect from the Danish director Thomas Vinterberg, ‰ÛÏThe Commune‰Ûù swaddles the pain of a disintegrating marriage in a good-natured cocoon of laughter and larks.

Handsome and self-confident, Rodrigo lives a life of wealth and power in a gated compound, emerging occasionally to attend Mass and bathe in the flattery of a young priest. He hasn‰Ûªt paid in any way for the years he stole from Horacia. She observes him from a distance, and it is not clear ‰ÛÓ perhaps not even to her ‰ÛÓ whether she is planning to confront or kill him, or if witnessing the unfairness of their respective circumstances is all the justice she can expect.

Her name is Horacia, though she occasionally hides behind pseudonyms. We first encounter her in a rural women‰Ûªs prison, where she reads stories to her fellow inmates and tutors their young children. The place seems peaceful and humane (especially in contrast to what will follow), and Horacia, played with exquisite understatement by Charo Santos-Concio, seems resigned to her life there. But then, 30 years into her sentence, she is freed, and we learn that she was framed for murder by a former lover. The real killer confesses and commits suicide, sending Horacia on a journey into a tragic past and an uncertain future.

The setting is the modern Philippines (the main action begins in 1997), but the inspiration is ‰ÛÏGod Sees the Truth, but Waits,‰Ûù a story by Tolstoy, and the mood and pace evoke the rich pleasures of great 19th-century fiction. Mr. Diaz has explored this kind of transcultural and trans-historical cross-pollination before, notably in ‰ÛÏNorte, the End of History,‰Ûù which drew on Dostoyevsky‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCrime and Punishment.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Woman Who Left‰Ûù is less sprawling ‰ÛÓ more portrait than tableau ‰ÛÓ and it brings to the screen a character who is at once elusive and unforgettable.

Mr. Diaz‰Ûªs view of human affairs is pessimistic. He is fascinated by guilt and innocence but skeptical of the possibility of redemption. Yet his films, this one even more than ‰ÛÏNorte,‰Ûù are the opposite of despairing. The last shots of ‰ÛÏThe Woman Who Left‰Ûù are devastating, and the film makes uncompromising demands on your attention and your empathy. But it is also illuminating and, in its downbeat, deliberate way, exhilarating.

Mr. Diaz tells her story without flashbacks or gimmicks, with a plainness that masks the complexity of his ambitions. Stoical and selfless, Horacia resembles one of the suffering mothers of classic Hollywood melodrama. And her post-incarceration adventures unfold under film-noir-like shadows. She befriends outcasts and outlaws ‰ÛÓ notably a transgender prostitute (John Lloyd Cruz) and a street vendor (Nonie Buencamino) ‰ÛÓ and quietly stalks Rodrigo Trinidad (Michael De Mesa), the man who wronged her.

Which is not to say that this movie, which won the top prize at the Venice Film Festival last year, is unconcerned with showing what happens. Shot in a black-and-white palette that evokes both Italian neorealism and old television, ‰ÛÏThe Woman Who Left‰Ûù is carefully composed and hauntingly beautiful to behold. Like Mr. Diaz‰Ûªs earlier work, it is long and slow-moving, but at nearly four hours it feels less like a test of your endurance than an appeal to your appetite for character, incident and emotion.

The world of ‰ÛÏThe Woman Who Left,‰Ûù the new film by Lav Diaz, is saturated with violence. There are killings, rapes and beatings, episodes of revenge and casual cruelty, and the subtle but no less brutal operations of poverty, corruption and social injustice. But though we occasionally witness the immediate aftereffect of these acts, we virtually never see the acts themselves. In a departure from the usual cinematic practice that amounts to a critique of prevailing assumptions about the power of visual representation, Mr. Diaz insists that words can carry meaning more effectively than pictures.

While recognizing the psychological truth in that self-assessment, the film discreetly complicates it with Ms. Whelan‰Ûªs biography. (The X-ray of her 12-year-old spine, bent into an S-curve by scoliosis, is no fantasy image.) By the end, it‰Ûªs easy to understand the judgment of a colleague that this anti-diva changed the profession.

‰ÛÏRestless Creature‰Ûù is tightly edited but patient, with as many uneventful scenes of physical therapy and cocktail parties as more dramatic footage of surgery and is-she-pushing-too-hard suspense. Ballet dancers are experts in masking pain. But through trust established between the filmmakers and Ms. Whelan, this film allows us to see her stoic control, her superhuman strength under pressure, and also to see through it ‰ÛÓ to the self-doubt, the fear of losing her very identity.

The plentiful snippets of Ms. Whelan dancing signature roles give a cumulative sense of her gifts. Though a dance fan could wish for more sustained sequences, what comes across is less a performance than a person the viewer has come to know, dancing with people she loves in choreography made for her by friends (who may happen to be Christopher Wheeldon and Alexei Ratmansky). ‰ÛÏRestless Creature‰Ûù humanizes dance.
‰ÛÏIf I don‰Ûªt dance, I‰Ûªd rather die.‰Ûù

More remarkable, though, is how the film and Ms. Whelan, without falsification, turn an extreme form of midlife crisis into a heartening tale. ‰ÛÏRestless Creature‰Ûù makes the potential compensations of age seem as beautiful as any ballet.

Directed by Linda Saffire and Adam Schlesinger, ‰ÛÏRestless Creature‰Ûù captures Ms. Whelan in 2013 at 46, as she‰Ûªs struggling to recover from a potentially career-ending injury and facing pressure to give her final bows at New York City Ballet after nearly 30 years there. Following her as she begins to reinvent herself as a dancer outside of ballet, the film is both a comeback story and, more profoundly, a coming to terms with aging.

That‰Ûªs a rather melodramatic utterance, especially from a ballerina past the age when most retire. When Wendy Whelan, who has been called ‰ÛÏAmerica‰Ûªs greatest contemporary ballerina,‰Ûù says it in the documentary ‰ÛÏRestless Creature: Wendy Whelan,‰Ûù she undercuts the sentiment, acknowledging how ridiculous she might sound.

Still, she means it. Dance is her life. And her disarming combination of humility and honesty, making light of heavy emotions without concealing their true weight, has much to do with how this affecting film portrait can sneak up on you.
Ms. Whelan, who escaped injury for most of her career, says that she has lived her whole life in ‰ÛÏa fantasy world,‰Ûù believing she would never break. Grow up, she chides herself.

You shouldn‰Ûªt expect much in the way of cinema. The digital effects ‰ÛÓ fire and water, mostly ‰ÛÓ are lackluster, and the whole thing has a crummy, overcast, second-rate-theme-park look to it. Except for the bodies, of course, which are really all you came to see in the first place.

A partial exception is Priyanka Chopra, who appears not in a bathing suit but in a succession of slinky dresses that signify ‰ÛÓ along with her purring diction, her muscle-headed minions and her collection of champagne flutes and martini glasses ‰ÛÓ her character‰Ûªs supervillain status. That character, Victoria Leeds, is a drug dealer and would-be real estate mogul whose machinations threaten the Bay. And the only people with the integrity, gumption and sleuthing skills to save it are Mitch and his lifeguards. The Bay is their life, after all.

The film, directed by Seth Gordon (‰ÛÏIdentity Thief,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏHorrible Bosses‰Ûù), can be viewed from several perspectives, most notably the abdominal, the pectoral and the gluteal. If torsos and tails are not your thing, other aspects of human anatomy are also available for study. Arms and legs, for example. But though acres of flesh are exposed to view ‰ÛÓ most of it pleasingly sculpted ‰ÛÓ there is very little outright nudity and no sex to speak of.

For anyone contemplating the purchase of a ticket, the stakes are quite a bit lower. ‰ÛÏBaywatch,‰Ûù which, incidentally, features Mr. Johnson‰Ûªs most credible acting since ‰ÛÏThe Tooth Fairy,‰Ûù slots neatly into a subgenre that is perhaps too sloppy to have a name. But if you enjoy the ‰ÛÏ21 Jump Street‰Ûù or ‰ÛÏRide Along‰Ûù franchises, you won‰Ûªt have too bad a time. The soundtrack hums with well-chosen, not-too-obvious hip-hop, R&B and rock classics; the humor is knowing and naughty without risking serious offense; and an inclusive brand of meta-ness is practiced. You don‰Ûªt need to be privy to any particular ‰ÛÏBaywatch‰Ûù lore to get the jokes, and you‰Ûªll see a few nimble comic performers (Hannibal Buress, Yahya Abdul-Matteen II) in too-small roles.

You will, however, witness some rude and suggestive sight gags and an extended sequence in a morgue involving the genitals of a dead man. Those bits, and the energetic profanity in the script (written by Damian Shannon and Mark Swift), represent cosmetic alterations intended to secure an R rating, at the moment a mark of credibility in the world of big-screen comedy. Make no mistake, though: The project‰Ûªs essential network prime-time DNA remains intact. Like its source material, ‰ÛÏBaywatch‰Ûù is sleazy and wholesome, silly and earnest, dumb as a box of sand and slyly self-aware. It‰Ûªs soft-serve ice cream. Crinkle-cut fries. A hot car and a skin rash. Tacky and phony and nasty and also kind of fun.

Matt is a gold-medal-winning Olympic swimmer in disgrace, a bad boy in need of reforming. Ronnie is a pudgy nerd, with tech-geek skills and a brain-melting crush on C. J. Summer is there for Matt to ogle and flirt with, and to attest to the screenwriters‰Ûª utter inability to make a woman in a bathing suit an interesting character. Mr. Efron and Mr. Johnson are permitted to be funny and look sexy in their swimwear. The women mostly run to the rescue in their zippered one-pieces.

Not everything is surf and sand and eye candy, though. A movie requires a plot or five, and ‰ÛÏBaywatch‰Ûù barrels through enough action and story to fill a couple of hours. Mitch Buchannon (Mr. Johnson) is the guru and patriarch of a squad of lifeguards ‰ÛÓ a ‰ÛÏfamily,‰Ûù as every franchise team in this fast and furious age must be called. The other principal members are C. J. (Kelly Rohrbach) and Stephanie (Ilfenesh Hadera). They must supervise three trainees: Summer (Alexandra Daddario), Ronnie (Jon Bass) and Matt (Zac Efron, looking uncannily like a young, ripped and shrunken Mr. Hasselhoff).

In case the question should ever arise on a standardized test, the opposite of ‰ÛÏprestige TV‰Ûù is ‰ÛÏBaywatch.‰Ûù The series, which ran on NBC and in ubiquitous syndication through the 1990s, bequeathed a rich legacy of wet-suit fashion, Jet Ski safety and sunscreen awareness. In other news, Paramount has just released a movie called ‰ÛÏBaywatch,‰Ûù starring Dwayne Johnson in the role of the beach daddy originated by David Hasselhoff.

Mr. Wenders‰Ûªs film didn‰Ûªt do much of that; it was content to be a kind of hangout movie, capturing musicians playing dominoes while awaiting their turns at the microphone. ‰ÛÏAdios‰Ûù shows furious arguments at sound checks and reveals the ambivalence with which some of the musicians viewed newfound fame. It‰Ûªs not as poetic or immediately enjoyable as the first film. But it is tougher and more analytical, with real challenges embedded in its pleasures.

In Wim Wenders‰Ûªs 1999 documentary, ‰ÛÏBuena Vista Social Club,‰Ûù Ry Cooder, who helped unite once-forgotten masters of Cuban popular song for an album, told of something he learned to do early in the project. Upon hearing a particularly great tune, he would ask two questions: ‰ÛÏWho wrote it?‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏIs he or she still alive?‰Ûù

At that time, so many of the writers and players and singers were indeed still alive. Ibrahim Ferrer, the singer referred to in Mr. Wenders‰Ûªs movie as ‰ÛÏthe Cuban Nat King Cole,‰Ûù was making a meager living shining shoes a few blocks down the street from the studio where Mr. Cooder and Juan de Marcos GonzÌÁlez were working on what would become the 1997 album ‰ÛÏBuena Vista Social Club.‰Ûù That record, and Mr. Wenders‰Ûªs subsequent film, made international stars out of Mr. Ferrer and several other Cuban musicians who had thought time and the world had passed them by.

‰ÛÏBuena Vista Social Club: Adios,‰Ûù directed by Lucy Walker (and of which Mr. Wenders, among others, is an executive producer) is both an exemplary sequel and a vital, informative companion piece. It not only chronicles the late-life careers of the ‰ÛÏBuena Vista‰Ûù stars, many of whom have since died. But it also tells some painful and fascinating back stories, and insists on putting the music in its social and historical contexts.

Jason Bourque‰Ûªs modest, proficient thriller ‰ÛÏDrone‰Ûù scrutinizes the ethics of warfare by remote control, an issue dramatized with greater effectiveness in Gavin Hood‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏEye in the Sky,‰Ûù from 2016, and Andrew Niccol‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGood Kill,‰Ûù from 2015. Those films examined the moral struggles of military personnel as they conduct missions with clinical precision while far removed from danger. ‰ÛÏDrone‰Ûù sticks to the home front, following Neil Wistin (Sean Bean), a drone pilot on assignments for a covert C.I.A. contractor in Washington State, and Imir Shaw (Patrick Sabongui), a visitor to his home with an ulterior motive.

The movie opens with a bravura sequence set in Pakistan, and the script, by Mr. Bourque and Paul A. Birkett, worthily strives to balance sympathies between American interests and humans written off as collateral damage. But overheated family confessions meet SWAT team conventions at the climax, and little resonates in their wake.

Neil, an alcoholic who hides his actual job from the members of his family, is as removed from them as he is from the citizens in Pakistan he inadvertently kills with a missile controlled from his office. His wife, Ellen (Mary McCormack, solid), is having an affair. His sensitive son, Shane (Maxwell Haynes), bonded with Neil‰Ûªs father as the old man was dying, while Neil can‰Ûªt even compose a eulogy. When Imir stops by Neil‰Ûªs house and offers to buy a boat he has inherited, Neil, touched by his gentle earnestness, invites him over for supper, only to learn that Imir knows Neil‰Ûªs work history ‰ÛÓ and lost his wife and daughter in one of Neil‰Ûªs aerial assaults.

I can‰Ûªt speak from personal experience, but it seems the stages of captivity aren‰Ûªt too different from the stages of grief. Once disbelief subsides, Clare starts to rage, but Andi‰Ûªs living quarters are diabolically designed to contain her and her anger.

Teresa Palmer‰Ûªs work in the opening minutes of ‰ÛÏBerlin Syndrome‰Ûù succeeds in conveying the nearly tactile sensations of being an enthusiastic stranger in a strange land. Playing Clare, an Australian photographer looking for inspiration and adventure in Berlin, she seems to aspire to walk on air as she emerges from a subway station; a little later, leaning over the railing of the roof of the youth hostel where she‰Ûªs staying, she looks similarly ready to take off.

But soon this aspirant bird will be caged. A meet-cute with an intellectual schoolteacher named Andi (Max Riemelt) leads to flirtation, an intense sexual assignation and an unsettling discovery the morning after. She can‰Ûªt leave his apartment. It soon becomes horrifically apparent that the not-leaving component is part of a larger scheme that Andi has enacted before.

The movie is based on a 2011 novel of the same name by Melanie Joosten, but viewers of a certain age will detect an affinity with ‰ÛÏThe Collector,‰Ûù the 1965 picture by William Wyler, based on a John Fowles novel. The director, Cate Shortland, making her third feature, depicts both the degradations endured by Clare and the peculiar psychological ins and outs of the captor-captive dynamic in explicit, sometimes excruciating detail. Her insistent imagery and sometimes oblique narrative approach don‰Ûªt always deliver the dividends sought. But the movie identifies Ms. Shortland as a talent to watch. And it should constitute some kind of breakthrough for Ms. Palmer, who has not been given much of interest to do since she arrived in Hollywood a little over a decade ago.

The movie has a hopscotching-in-time structure, moving back from its New York scenes to the actions of the day in Argentina when Carmen and Camila meet and conspire. As frequently as the movie touches back down in Argentina, though, it is very much a New York story. Expanding on its opening shot, the movie often lingers in the middle of parks where lovers and friends meet, unhurriedly takes in car rides across borough-connecting bridges, and more. Sometimes the image turns to negative, and handwritten text decorates the outer edges of the frame.

In a quietly virtuosic opening shot, Mr. PiÌ±eiro‰Ûªs camera pirouettes on an apartment terrace, looking down at a park below, as a young woman speaks to her lover on a phone, picking him out in the park just as the camera does. Carmen (MarÌ_a Villar) is finishing an arts fellowship in New York; her lover, Lukas (Keith Poulson), is also her administrator. As if in a relay, Carmen returns to Buenos Aires and urges her friend Camila (Agustina MuÌ±oz), who‰Ûªs off to New York on the same fellowship, to make sure to touch Lukas‰Ûªs hair. Camila eventually acts on her friend‰Ûªs recommendation, but this spectacularly enigmatic character also has other agendas, including looking up an old lover and meeting her biological father.

Also in the mix: A mysterious woman who is sending postcards from a multistate road trip to Carmen‰Ûªs apartment in New York, though Camila is now staying there and receiving them. (This character, DaniÌ¬lle, is played by Mati Diop, the intriguing French actress who‰Ûªs been in films by Claire Denis and Antonio Campos.) All this activity tends to distract Camila from her actual work, a Spanish translation of ‰ÛÏA Midsummer Night‰Ûªs Dream.‰Ûù But she never becomes entirely disconnected from that beloved comedy and its life-as-a-dream theme.

Starting with ‰ÛÏRosalinda‰Ûù in 2010, the Argentine filmmaker MatÌ_as PiÌ±eiro has been making what he calls ‰ÛÏShakespeareads,‰Ûù modern-day stories inspired by the playwright‰Ûªs heroines. Which is not to say that you need to brush up on your Shakespeare to engage with ‰ÛÏHermia & Helena,‰Ûù the latest in Mr. PiÌ±eiro‰Ûªs series and the first one set in the United States.

All of these touches make ‰ÛÏHermia & Helena‰Ûù a peculiar film, one both steely and delicate. It is also an often amusing look at the contemporary mating mores of this fair city, with Mr. Poulson‰Ûªs portrayal of a nonchalantly sleazy womanizing hipster milquetoast particularly resonant. But the film belongs to Ms. MuÌ±oz. She‰Ûªs the kind of performer (like Setsuko Hara, the Japanese actress to whom the film is dedicated) you can‰Ûªt take your eyes off, even when she doesn‰Ûªt seem to be up to much of anything.

Through it all, we see Mr. Wong and his group come of age. As their battles intensify, things grow complicated, and threats are always present: Some activists confronting China have found themselves on trial or have just ‰ÛÏdisappeared.‰Ûù

To put this skinny young man onstage is to see him turn instantly captivating: Mr. Wong is energetic but composed, determined yet realistic. Scenes in which he questions Hong Kong‰Ûªs leader are bold on their own. When you consider that Mr. Wong was only a teenager at the time, they are astonishing. It‰Ûªs as if he had been ‰ÛÏdoing this for, like, 20 years,‰Ûù one interviewee says. That‰Ûªs an understatement.

Joe Piscatella, the director, dives in immediately to set a speedy pace. He also provides a quick summary of Hong Kong‰Ûªs recent history, and looks to the future. After the education controversy ends ‰ÛÓ no spoilers for those unfamiliar with the outcome ‰ÛÓ Scholarism joins a protest over Beijing‰Ûªs intervention in elections, then prepares to run candidates of its own.

The real-life lead here is Joshua Wong, who, as a 14-year-old in Hong Kong, made a breathtakingly brave stand against the Chinese government, which in 2012 began to institute a pro-Communist education program in that territory. China had taken control of Hong Kong in 1997 and had promised it autonomy, a vow that had weakened over time and would be violated further by the school proposal.

Mr. Wong and the organization he founded, Scholarism, recruited supporters (‰ÛÏIf you want to defeat Darth Vader, then you have to train some Jedi,‰Ûù one early member says), distributed leaflets and then occupied the square outside the Hong Kong government headquarters to protest the Chinese plan.

‰ÛÏJoshua: Teenager vs. Superpower‰Ûù has the three things any action movie needs: a valiant hero, a mighty enemy and a catchy title. That it‰Ûªs a documentary only makes the story more involving ‰ÛÓ and more worrisome ‰ÛÓ than most fictions.

‰ÛÏTeenager vs. Superpower,‰Ûù which won an audience award at the Sundance Film Festival, ends the way most action movies don‰Ûªt ‰ÛÓ with hero and villain still battling. Yet amid the fight, there‰Ûªs a sense of hope as we watch one tough kid turning into one tough man. With luck, that will lead to a sequel.

At first, the ragtag group numbered 10 or 20. ‰ÛÏThere seems to be no hope,‰Ûù Mr. Wong recalled feeling. ‰ÛÏBut a miracle happened.‰Ûù Within days, the crowd grew to over 100,000, many inspired by Mr. Wong‰Ûªs speaking skills.

These are quibbles, the sort of nits Deadheads pick while arguing over the band‰Ûªs best performances. Senator Al Franken is on hand to enthuse about his favorite version of ‰ÛÏAlthea‰Ûù: Nassau Coliseum, May 16, 1980. Right tour, wrong show, Senator: Try San Diego, July 1.

The film is neither comprehensive nor definitive. The promoter Bill Graham, as important to the Dead‰Ûªs success as anyone but constantly at odds with them, gets a passing mention; Robert Hunter, the reclusive lyricist behind many of the band‰Ûªs best songs, sits for one brief scene. And a project to define the band‰Ûªs place in social and cultural history stops short at Garcia‰Ûªs death, without discussing the Dead‰Ûªs continuing influence.

‰ÛÏLong Strange Trip,‰Ûù ambitiously assembled and elegantly directed by Amir Bar-Lev, fills that void. The band‰Ûªs main four surviving members ‰ÛÓ Bob Weir, Phil Lesh, Bill Kreutzmann and Mickey Hart ‰ÛÓ are all credited as executive producers and speak at length; Dennis McNally, the band‰Ûªs publicist and biographer, whose similarly titled history was clearly consulted, is a presence as well. A bountiful trove of archival images and rare footage sketches their communal life offstage and the counterculture in which they played so formative a part. Crew members, family and fans share memories and lore.

The film‰Ûªs four hours (with an intermission) cover a lot of ground: Garcia‰Ûªs teenage years in a bohemian Bay Area; the group‰Ûªs roots as a jug band; its members‰Ûª service as house musicians for the Acid Trips of Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters. Despite driving its music label crazy, the Dead eventually rise to the top of the touring charts, playing for monster stadium crowds through the 1980s and into the ‰Ûª90s.

More than that, ‰ÛÏTrip‰Ûù places the band at the ecstatic center of the counterculture. It includes glimpses of the notorious Neal Cassady, the link between Jack Kerouac and Kesey, and of Owsley Stanley, the LSD chemist who was also the Dead‰Ûªs sound engineer. One fascinating clip shows Garcia instructing Mr. Weir how to harmonize on ‰ÛÏCandyman,‰Ûù as the band moved from the psychedelic fringe to folk rock.
The Grateful Dead have been such fixed dark stars in rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll‰Ûªs cosmology that it‰Ûªs surprising there has never really been an extended cinematic exploration of the band.

The Dead, Mr. McNally contends, was ‰ÛÏthe greatest American band,‰Ûù mixing rock, blues, folk, soul, R&B, gospel, country and jazz into an improvisational musical gumbo that was risky and uneven but that promised something different, possibly transcendent, every night. Even so, Mr. Bar-Lev tells a familiar industry tale. The road and alcohol and drug use take a lethal toll on the band: first Pigpen McKernan; then Brent Mydland; then finally its charismatic, shamanistic lead guitarist, Jerry Garcia, in 1995.

Two appealing young people (Kaya Scodelario and Brenton Thwaites) meet on a quest for a mysterious and powerful object. They are joined by Sparrow and pursued by old and new enemies: the British Navy; the greedy pirate Hector Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush); and an army of ghouls led by the spectral Captain Salazar (Javier Bardem), known as the butcher of the sea.

This review will be short and dismissive. The movie under consideration ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏPirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is, by contrasts, long and punishing. Its pleasures are so meager, its delight in its own inventions so forced and false, that it becomes almost the perfect opposite of entertainment. To insist otherwise is a variation on the sunk cost fallacy. Since you exchanged money for fun, fun is surely what you must have purchased, and you may cling to that idea in the face of contrary evidence. But trust me on this: This movie would be a rip-off even if someone paid you to see it.

This goes on for more than two hours. You are invited to sit through every last name on the lengthy end credits for a teasing extra scene of a couple asleep on linen sheets, a reminder of how you might have better spent the time. It would be a spoiler to identify those bedfellows, but the bigger spoiler is that apparently another sequel is on the way.

Now and then you get a reminder of why you might have enjoyed the earlier movies. There are a couple of nifty Rube Goldbergian action sequences ‰ÛÓ one with a bank vault, the other with a guillotine ‰ÛÓ that recall the berserk inventiveness of Gore Verbinski, the original director. But otherwise, ‰ÛÏDead Men Tell No Tales,‰Ûù directed by Joachim Ronning and Espen Sandberg from a script by Jeff Nathanson, is a tedious rehash.

Because, to be honest, it‰Ûªs barely a movie at all. The first installments of the ‰ÛÏPirates‰Ûù franchise conquered skepticism with exuberance and charm. Somehow, a theme-park ride combined with clever, madcap visuals and Johnny Depp‰Ûªs scapegrace showboating added up to something fresh. But that spirit is long gone. Mr. Depp, as Capt. Jack Sparrow, goes through the motions like a washed-up rock star reprising his greatest hits in a half-empty auditorium. The images are so dark and muddy that you can‰Ûªt see what‰Ûªs going on well enough to know why you don‰Ûªt care. The plot twists, Easter eggs and surprises are either obvious or labored. You can‰Ûªt spoil something that‰Ûªs already thoroughly rotten.

The story begins when the women‰Ûªs balcony at the synagogue collapses during the bar mitzvah celebration for Ettie‰Ûªs grandson. The accident leaves the rabbi‰Ûªs wife in a coma and the rabbi in a state of shock, which puts the future of the congregation in limbo; rabbis have to supervise repairs. So when the charismatic young Rabbi David comes to their rescue, he‰Ûªs seen as ‰ÛÏan angel from heaven.‰Ûù Rabbi David may be a good man, but he‰Ûªs not exactly progressive. His more conservative views and strict reading of scripture soon run afoul of the women of this more moderate congregation, especially Ettie. The growing rift threatens to tear apart a few marriages, but there‰Ûªs never really any doubt about the couples‰Ûª eventual reunion, let alone which side will prevail.

‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt you want us there?‰Ûù an Israeli woman asks her husband in ‰ÛÏThe Women‰Ûªs Balcony,‰Ûù a charming exercise in gender politics as experienced via religion. The wife, Ettie (Evelin Hagoel), has just learned that their newly rebuilt Orthodox Jewish synagogue no longer has a separate section for women ‰ÛÓ which essentially means they have been barred from the gender-segregated services. The slight is a punch in the gut, but it also starts a revolution.

Still, Emil Ben-Shimon‰Ûªs smart direction (tight shots of narrow streets and even narrower dwellings really convey a sense of an insular community) and Shlomit Nehama‰Ûªs lighthearted and topical script ensure the proceedings not only hit all the right notes, but also entertain while being respectful of religious traditions. The entire cast is solid, but the women, especially Ms. Hagoel, bring depth to their comedic and dramatic turns. Ettie‰Ûªs wisdom is never more spot on than when she tells her grandson, ‰ÛÏGod gave us minds of our own.‰Ûù Indeed.

In adapting Mr. Hastings‰Ûªs journalism, David MichÌ«d, the writer and director of ‰ÛÏWar Machine,‰Ûù also streaming on Netflix, has taken some risks of his own. The movie is fiction, but it hugs the shore of reality, occasionally running aground on the facts. It‰Ûªs a bit awkward ‰ÛÓ though not unusual ‰ÛÓ for semi-invented characters to brush up against real people. Anthony Michael Hall plays a volatile colleague of McMahon‰Ûªs who seems to be based on Gen. Michael T. Flynn, whose more recent adventures may provide fodder for a sequel. The actual President Obama appears on a television news clip, and is played later in a brief scene on an airport tarmac by an actor named Reggie Brown. Ben Kingsley wickedly impersonates Hamid Karzai, at the time the president of Afghanistan.

McMahon is no tomcat, but no choirboy either. His attractive qualities of bluntness and loyalty are offset by a propensity for passive-aggressiveness in his dealings with civilian authority and a dogmatic attachment to some pretty dubious ideas. He is convinced that the war can be won and that he is the man who can win it. His hubris would be tragic if his overestimation of his own abilities were not so farcical.

But the particular book that inspired ‰ÛÏWar Machine,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Operators‰Ûù by Michael Hastings, is a sharp, nuanced deconstruction of the modern military mythology. The book grew out of a notorious Rolling Stone profile of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who was put in charge of the war in Afghanistan in 2009 and proceeded to blow up his own career. Mr. Hastings, who died in 2013, sketched a rollicking, damning portrait of a commander in over his head, enthralled by his own hype and in less than perfect control of his mouth. That‰Ûªs the guy Mr. Pitt is supposed to be.

But ‰ÛÏWar Machine,‰Ûù as its title hints, is not entirely about him. Mr. Pitt‰Ûªs performance is engaging and complicated ‰ÛÓ somehow recalling both the wily and ruthless Aldo Raine of ‰ÛÏInglourious Basterds‰Ûù and the lethally stupid Chad Feldheimer of ‰ÛÏBurn After Reading‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ but the film‰Ûªs most memorable words are none of the jargon that comes out of McMahon‰Ûªs mouth. In one indelible scene, a German member of Parliament (Tilda Swinton) delivers a calm, respectful and unsparing demolition of the American position. It is too long and complicated to quote here, but in another scene an Afghan villager offers a three-word summary: ‰ÛÏPlease leave now.‰Ûù

McMahon may be a blowhard and kind of an idiot, but he‰Ûªs not a bad guy. His judgment can be questioned, but not his sincerity. He is beloved by most of the men in his charge and unflinchingly committed to them. Their belief in him is exceeded only by his belief in himself as a legendary, larger-than-life figure. Everyone knows that he runs seven miles every morning, sleeps four hours a night and eats one meal a day. He his devoted to his wife (a wonderfully sly Meg Tilly) even though, as she points out over an anniversary dinner, they have spent 30 days in each other‰Ûªs company over the past eight years.

Mr. MichÌ«d‰Ûªs satirical intentions call out for something like the rapid-fire cynicism of Armando Iannucci, creator of ‰ÛÏVeep‰Ûù and director of ‰ÛÏIn the Loop,‰Ûù or the gonzo iconoclasm of David O. Russell‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThree Kings.‰Ûù But after a sluggish and chaotic start, ‰ÛÏWar Machine‰Ûù finds its groove and becomes its own thing: a mordant, cleareyed critique of American war-making that is all the more devastating for being affectionately drawn.

Mr. MichÌ«d, whose previous films include ‰ÛÏAnimal Kingdom,‰Ûù a gamy crime drama, and ‰ÛÏThe Rover,‰Ûù a dusty post-apocalyptic thriller, gestures toward the grim futility of the war on the ground. A subplot involves a young marine (Lakeith Stanfield), who questions the strategy he must nonetheless carry out, with terrible consequences. But most of the action is far from combat, consisting of hushed meetings and heated arguments.

‰ÛÏWar Machine‰Ûù effectively rebuts the evergreen notion that military leaders are held back from victory by politicians and bureaucrats. It‰Ûªs not that the political and diplomatic aspects of American policy are excused, but rather that failure, to reverse the old saying, has a thousand fathers. McMahon, clinging to his faith in the dubious doctrines of counterinsurgency, chases after an illusory victory that his allies, colleagues and bosses don‰Ûªt really believe in any more. Is he ridiculous or noble? A little of both, perhaps.

Bluff and bowlegged, with a neat side part in his hair and a spine as straight as a schooner‰Ûªs mast, Brad Pitt strides into ‰ÛÏWar Machine‰Ûù in a gust of masculine self-assurance. The sardonic tones of the accompanying narration ‰ÛÓ voiced by someone whose identity will be revealed later on ‰ÛÓ are an early indication that Mr. Pitt may not be the hero of the story. Glen McMahon, the four-star general he is playing, has no doubts on that score. McMahon, a man of many macho nicknames (the Glenimal, for example) is a man‰Ûªs man, a soldier‰Ûªs soldier, a warrior with the soul of a poet ‰ÛÓ the walking embodiment of just about every clichÌ© in the book.

That is a brilliant piece of casting. At its best, ‰ÛÏWar Machine‰Ûù crackles with irreverent wit, even if American political craziness circa 2009 looks tame compared with the 2017 version. It takes a while to get going, though. A raft of secondary characters is introduced via voice-over, but most of them fade into the desert-camo background. The few that stand out ‰ÛÓ Mr. Hall‰Ûªs fireplug, Topher Grace‰Ûªs glib fixer ‰ÛÓ make the labored introductions superfluous. And as you follow McMahon through the first stages of his new assignment, you may wish for a speedier, snappier rhythm.

In some bad movies, a consolation prize comes when the actors are able to transcend, or just steamroll, the weak material and serve up performance pleasures. But to watch John Slattery as Dwight D. Eisenhower bark at Mr. Cox‰Ûªs Churchill about not hosting Churchill‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏamateur theatrics‰Ûù because ‰ÛÏthere‰Ûªs a war on!‰Ûù is to witness the sorry spectacle of an actor utterly defeated by his script. It‰Ûªs depressing.

Winston Churchill the character has appeared in dozens of films, TV movies and mini-series over the years, and the portraits always hew to the gruff British bulldog conception of this 20th-century leader. ‰ÛÏChurchill,‰Ûù a new movie directed by Jonathan Teplitzky from a script by Alex von Tunzelmann, is laudable in its effort to shine a light on the Churchill who struggled in private with crippling depression ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏthe black dog,‰Ûù he called it. His accuracy-in-metaphor was such that sufferers of subsequent generations have frequently adopted the term.

The movie‰Ûªs ambition is the good news. The bad news is that it is a hash, choosing to jumble the historical record and frame a Churchill bout with depression against the D-Day invasion of France by Allied forces. While Churchill did express serious reservations about the operation in the weeks before it occurred, he was largely reconciled to the plan by the time it happened. This movie has Churchill, played with both grim determination and wild abandon by Brian Cox, railing against the high command in terms and gestures that mostly suggest a poorly run group therapy session.

The two don‰Ûªt fight over this so much as use it as an excuse to avoid each other, in a lighthearted sort of way ‰ÛÓ the movie is more comedy than drama. Dean goes from the East Coast to the West on a supposed business trip, and dithers around out there with his friend Eric (Rory Scovel).

Demetri Martin joins the ranks of comics who have written and directed films with the movie ‰ÛÏDean,‰Ûù a mild but respectable story about a father and son who react to grief differently and have to recalibrate their relationship as a result.

Mr. Martin plays the title character, an illustrator who has been at sea personally and professionally since his mother‰Ûªs death. Kevin Kline is Robert, Dean‰Ûªs father, who also feels the loss but is reconciled to moving on. Among the ways he plans to do so is to sell the house where he still lives and where Dean grew up, a decision Dean is not ready to accept.

Mr. Martin, taking a lesson from Woody Allen, gives his character lots of amusing opportunities to skewer pretentiousness. Like practically every comic who has written himself a movie script, he also gives his character a gorgeous woman (Gillian Jacobs) to fall into bed with, which leaves the movie less insightful than it might be.

For both Dean and his father, the cure for grief seems to be female companionship. (Mary Steenburgen plays Robert‰Ûªs potential partner.) That might be a way to rebound from romantic heartbreak; the death of a loved one is a very different matter. Still, if Mr. Martin‰Ûªs take on grief is facile, the movie overall is a pleasant trip, and Dean‰Ûªs doodles ‰ÛÓ by Mr. Martin himself ‰ÛÓ are a treat.

‰ÛÏLetters From Baghdad: The True Story of Gertrude Bell and Iraq,‰Ûù directed by Sabine KrayenbÌ_hl and Zeva Oelbaum, is an experiment in documentary form ‰ÛÓ an unfortunate choice that perhaps looked good on paper. Bell was born into a wealthy British family in 1868, and was an avid traveler from an early age. This movie focuses on her time in the Middle East during the early 20th century and her role in drawing the modern borders of Iraq, which the United States and other countries have expended a good deal of blood and treasure to maintain and defend.

The strategy does, however, enable the filmmakers to keep Bell in a bubble, inoculated from the disapproval her work received in subsequent years. While she is still highly regarded by many Iraqis, the scholar Edward Said was critical of her in his landmark study ‰ÛÏOrientalism.‰Ûù With this movie‰Ûªs framing, the directors don‰Ûªt even have to bring him up. There‰Ûªs much historical material here that‰Ûªs of high interest, and Ms. Swinton‰Ûªs performance of Bell‰Ûªs letters convey Bell‰Ûªs skills as a writer, but the movie is ultimately too conceptually labored for its own good ‰ÛÓ or that of its subject.

The directors asked the redoubtable Tilda Swinton to read Bell‰Ûªs letters, and, in configuring the film as if it were made after Bell‰Ûªs death in 1926, they cast actors in the roles of Bell‰Ûªs contemporaries, such as T. E. Lawrence, Vita Sackville-West and Arnold Wilson. The actors appear as documentary-style talking heads. (On second thought, I don‰Ûªt see how this idea could have looked good on paper.)

There are traces of early Wim Wenders in this story of immigrants adrift in a world not their own, trying to make the best of things. The movie‰Ûªs tree-falling-in-the-forest-with-no-one-to-hear-it denouement is an apt but not entirely hopeless metaphor for the condition of its characters.

Hamid (played by Mohsen Namjoo, a  singer-songwriter who has been called the Iranian Bob Dylan and who lives in exile in the United States) begins the broadcasting day by reading work by the Salvadoran poet Roque Dalton to his listeners. This confounds the station‰Ûªs owners, who have booked ads in anticipation of a station visit from Metallica. Yes, that Metallica, which is scheduled to jam on air with the real-life Afghan rock band Kabul Dreams. ‰ÛÏWaiting for Metallica‰Ûù could indeed be an alternate title for the movie, but this quiet, often sad film, directed by Babak Jalali, is about much more than that.

The fictional San Francisco radio station PARS-FM, where much of ‰ÛÏRadio Dreams‰Ûù is set, is a study in gray and yellow. Its broadcasting booth is illuminated by a single glowing bulb, and its walls are covered in egg-carton-like soundproofing baffles. Multiple clocks on a wall giving times for cities from around the world are the only decorative feature of an adjacent conference room. ‰ÛÏIf an Iranian in Tokyo is listening and it‰Ûªs 4 a.m. there, you know then to say good morning,‰Ûù explains the station manager, Hamid, a grave fellow with a wild mane of white hair. Cozy it is not, yet this Farsi-language station is a spiritual home for Hamid and the stateless musicians and business people who move in and out of the place during the course of a day.

Despite brief, almost inadvertent intimations of charm, she can be exasperating, as those who know her attest on camera, including the photographer Patrick McMullan and the Barneys creative ambassador, Simon Doonan. At a Paris soiree for one of her coffee-table monographs, she brusquely chastises a cellphone user; when someone offers to snap her picture at a red-carpet event, she shoves a passer-by out of the frame; and she castigates the filmmakers more than once.

Her motivation, apparently, stems from simple ambition. The daughter of a handsome man who died when she was young and a domineering, extremely fashion-conscious mother, Ms. Hartman grew up in the East Village, obsessed with Vogue magazine‰Ûªs visions of aesthetic perfection and determined to crack the ranks of its elite subjects. To this end she cultivated an arch, affected accent and persistently dogged the rich, famous and beautiful. Sure, tenacity pays off. But is rudeness a requirement, too?

Pushy, judgmental, tart-tongued and self-obsessed, the photographer at the heart of Otis Mass‰Ûªs penetrating documentary, ‰ÛÏThe Incomparable Rose Hartman,‰Ûù is, like her snapshots, a piece of work. Ms. Hartman made her name documenting the Studio 54 scene in the 1970s. (Her most famous image may be of Bianca Jagger at the nightclub, astride a horse.) Today she remains a tireless fixture of Manhattan night life, flitting about in her tinted glasses, cropped blond hairdo and high-end designer plumage, attending openings, parties and fashion events, in pursuit of revealing glimpses of the glitterati. And Ms. Hartman indisputably has a gift for capturing the spontaneous moment.

But I‰Ûªm getting ahead of myself. Diana Prince is, properly speaking, Princess Diana, daughter of Hippolyta, queen of the Amazons (Connie Nielsen). The girl (played in childhood by Lilly Aspell and Emily Carey before maturing into Gal Gadot) grows up on a craggy Mediterranean island, a Bechdel-test paradise of flower-strewn meadows, noble horses and mighty quadriceps. Like a Disney princess ‰ÛÓ the resemblance hardly seems accidental ‰ÛÓ she is free-spirited and rebellious, her loyalties split between two opposed parental figures. Diana‰Ûªs mother wants her daughter to mind her tutors and steer clear of the warrior traditions represented by Antiope (Robin Wright), the girl‰Ûªs aunt.

The question is not rhetorical, and I‰Ûªm relieved to report that the answer is no. Once franchise continuity is established ‰ÛÓ a mysterious package from Bruce Wayne arrives at the office of Wonder Woman‰Ûªs alter ego, Diana Prince, who works in the Louvre‰Ûªs antiquities department ‰ÛÓ we are transported back to the heroine‰Ûªs earlier life, long before she became mixed up with Wayne and Clark Kent. ‰ÛÏWonder Woman,‰Ûù directed by Patty Jenkins from a script by Allan Heinberg, briskly shakes off blockbuster branding imperatives and allows itself to be something relatively rare in the modern superhero cosmos. It feels less like yet another installment in an endless sequence of apocalyptic merchandising opportunities than like ‰Û_ what‰Ûªs the word I‰Ûªm looking for? A movie. A pretty good one, too.

Ms. Jenkins and Mr. Heinberg have synthesized a plausible modern archetype out of comic-book and movie sources that may have seemed problematic to modern sensibilities. Diana is erudite but unworldly, witty but never ironic, supremely self-confident and utterly mystified by the modern world. Its capacity for cruelty is a perpetual shock to her, even though she herself is a prodigy of violence. Her sacred duty is to bring peace to the world. Accomplishing it requires a lot of killing, but that‰Ûªs always the superhero paradox.

Even better, she is a glamorous and funny fish out of water. Diana and Steve are assisted in their mission by a quartet of misfit sidekicks: a Scottish sharpshooter (Ewen Bremner); a Native American scout (Eugene Brave Rock); a Middle Eastern fixer (Said Taghmaoui) and a plucky British suffragist (Lucy Davis). The field of possible supervillains includes Danny Huston as a German commander and Elena Anaya as a diabolical chemist. The great David Thewlis is on hand doing some of the things you might expect and also some things you might not.

But make no mistake: This is a star vehicle all the way. Ms. Gadot, who like the other Amazons speaks English with an accent (though hers, unlike Ms. Wright‰Ûªs or Ms. Nielsen‰Ûªs, may be a result of her Israeli background), has a regal, effortlessly charismatic screen presence. She and Mr. Pine, who has Paul Newman‰Ûªs seductive blue eyes and a hint of Clark Gable‰Ûªs raffish charm, give ‰ÛÏWonder Woman‰Ûù a jolt of classic Hollywood fizz. Their banter, long before that kiss, is lively and sexy, and their oil-and-water temperaments emulsify nicely.

‰ÛÏWonder Woman,‰Ûù though, resists the reflexive power-worship that drags so many superhero movies ‰ÛÓ from the Marvel as well as the DC universes ‰ÛÓ into the mire of pseudo-Nietzschean adolescent posturing. Unlike most of her male counterparts, its heroine is not trying to exorcise inner demons or work out messiah issues. She wants to function freely in the world, to help out when needed and to be respected for her abilities. No wonder she encounters so much resistance.

By which I mean that ‰ÛÏWonder Woman‰Ûù tells an interesting, not entirely predictable story (until the climax, which reverts, inevitably and disappointingly, to dreary, overblown action clichÌ©s). It cleverly combines genre elements into something reasonably fresh, touching and fun. Its earnest insouciance recalls the ‰ÛÏSuperman‰Ûù movies of the ‰Ûª70s and ‰Ûª80s more than the mock-Wagnerian spectacles of our own day, and like those predigital Man of Steel adventures, it gestures knowingly but reverently back to the jaunty, truth-and-justice spirit of an even older Hollywood tradition.

‰ÛÏWonder Woman‰Ûù begins with ominous, lugubrious music (composed by Rupert Gregson-Williams), a voice-over invocation of ‰ÛÏdarkness‰Ûù and an aerial view of the Louvre that seems full of sinister portent. The viewer may be forgiven a shudder of dread. Are we really going to pick up where ‰ÛÏBatman v Superman‰Ûù left off? Must we endure another dose of the grandiose self-pity and authoritarian belligerence that have characterized the DC-Warner Bros. synergy in the ‰ÛÏDark Knight‰Ûù era? (This is the cue for unhinged fans to come @ me on Twitter and accuse me of being a shill for Marvel and Disney. The rest of you are invited to keep reading.)

This is an origin story, first and foremost, establishing the mythic background and modern mission of its main character. That kind of movie can be tedious, but ‰ÛÏWonder Woman‰Ûù is leavened by touches of screwball comedy, espionage caper and romantic adventure, as well as by what might be the most credible superhero screen kiss since upside-down Tobey Maguire planted one on Kirsten Dunst way back in ‰ÛÏSpider-Man.‰Ûù

In the course of family arguments about Diana‰Ûªs destiny, the history of the Amazons is recounted, with emphasis on that tribe‰Ûªs ambivalent relations with men ‰ÛÓ meaning human beings generically and dudes in particular. There are none of the latter on the island, which has been sealed off from history and the rest of the world by a magic membrane. And then one day a screaming comes across the sky, and a World War I vintage fighter plane disgorges Steve Trevor (Chris Pine), a blue-eyed flyboy who is the living embodiment of the phrase ‰ÛÏnot all men.‰Ûù

Steve, a spy for the Allies, is wearing a German uniform and is pursued by a flotilla of Teutonic bad guys, who battle the Amazons on the beach. The action hops to London and then to the trenches of Belgium, where the War to End All Wars slogs interminably on. There are fistfights in alleys and more extensive episodes of combat, during which Diana makes use of her aunt‰Ûªs training, traditional Amazon weapons (notably a glowing piece of rope called the Lasso of Truth) and her own unique abilities. She deflects bullets and mortar shells on a sprint across no-man‰Ûªs land, tosses an armored truck and demolishes a church steeple.

In ‰ÛÏBand Aid,‰Ûù Anna (Zoe Lister-Jones of TV‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLife in Pieces‰Ûù) and her husband, Ben (Adam Pally), are in distress. Both are frustrated artists. She‰Ûªs a writer who drives for Uber; he‰Ûªs a graphic designer who has taken on corporate work. They feel increasing pressure to have a baby from friends and from Ben‰Ûªs mother, none of whom know about Anna‰Ûªs miscarriage. Their lives are consumed with petty squabbles.

‰ÛÏWhat if we turned all our fights into songs?‰Ûù Anna asks. And while the songs have adequate toe-tapping potential, they are primarily a storytelling device, a way of lending this couples-therapy comedy some distinction. (In addition to writing, directing and starring in the movie, Ms. Lister-Jones composed the music for the tunes, mostly with Kyle Forester, and wrote the lyrics.)

Some of the bigger laughs come from the periphery (a friend has a daughter named Isis ‰ÛÓ after the Egyptian goddess, of course). But the movie fires wide of the mark with Dave (Fred Armisen), the recovering sex addict and cocoa-fiend neighbor who becomes Anna and Ben‰Ûªs drummer. Over all, ‰ÛÏBand Aid‰Ûù is only sometimes as cutesy as its title.

Both leads are excellent together, and the movie is good at showing how Anna and Ben push each other‰Ûªs buttons. (Ms. Lister-Jones also has strong instincts for how to frame their spats visually.) At other times, ‰ÛÏBand Aid‰Ûù feels overly tidy. Will Anna and Ben fix the dripping kitchen faucet ‰ÛÓ metaphor! ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs seen in the first shot?

The boys‰Ûª nemesis is Mr. Krupp (Ed Helms), the school principal. Maybe someone has made a kids‰Ûª movie with a principal who isn‰Ûªt buffoonish or heartless, but here the stereotypes are embraced with a vengeance. Mr. Krupp has a sign on his desk that reads, ‰ÛÏHope dies here.‰Ûù When the boys hypnotize him, he turns into Captain Underpants, and the story goes into overdrive, with the Captain becoming the world‰Ûªs defense against the evil Professor Poopypants (Nick Kroll).

Yes, ‰ÛÏCaptain Underpants: The First Epic Movie‰Ûù has arrived. It‰Ûªs a frenetic animated film from DreamWorks whose title is really all you need to know. If your child would be amused by seeing the word ‰ÛÏunderpants‰Ûù in the name of a movie, this one will entertain. The film, based on Dav Pilkey‰Ûªs book series, is about two friends, George (voiced by Kevin Hart) and Harold (Thomas Middleditch), who spend their spare time pulling pranks and creating D.I.Y. comic books about Captain Underpants, a superhero whose outfit boldly acknowledges that many superhero costumes in fact are little more than fancy undies.

Superintendents know that the job of school principal is one of the toughest to fill in the education world. It will be a lot more so now that moviegoing children and taxpayers will expect principals to run around in their underwear battling giant toilets.

The plot verges on indecipherable as the movie rolls along, and the grown-up jokes grow scarcer. Poopypants has a ray gun that can make things (including anything in a bathroom) gigantic, which at least keeps the tale colorful. The best animated movies for children are sublime. This one generally settles for noisy, though it throws in a positive message at the end.

The most telling words in ‰ÛÏFrom the Ashes‰Ûù aren‰Ûªt spoken by experts (of which there are plenty) but by former coal miners, their worrying spouses and the parents of sick children who have been affected by the industry. It‰Ûªs one thing to hear about regulations and pollution levels and safety standards. It‰Ûªs another to listen to a laid-off father wonder how he‰Ûªll face his family, or watch a mother distraught over her asthmatic son.

Michael Bonfiglio, the film‰Ûªs director, provides a concise overview of the issues. While he‰Ûªs dedicated to giving a cleareyed look, an angry scowl would sometimes serve better ‰ÛÓ no business executives are chased down and held to task here, and politicians are blamed but only a few are named.

To be sure, ‰ÛÏFrom the Ashes‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt need much commentary from Washington or from corporate spokesmen as it interviews people in Appalachia or Wyoming whose land, air and water may have been spoiled by coal mining. Their dismay is real enough, and their sorrows say far more than statistics.

This documentary starts with a rundown of coal‰Ûªs part in American history, then moves on to a survey of current global economic and climate conditions. As for the future, we‰Ûªre told coal use will continue to decline, no matter what politicians and companies claim. The remaining mining jobs are dangerous and dirty, yet many workers fight for them and on behalf of the industry. When you‰Ûªre unemployed and have to choose between going hungry or taking work that contributes to global warming, well, you have no real choice.

John Butler, the director, who also wrote the script, fashions this uncaring environment in the tradition of ‰ÛÏIf ‰Û_‰Ûù (1969) and ‰ÛÏDead Poets Society‰Ûù (1989), which also lends its kindly professor archetype, here played by Andrew Scott (‰ÛÏSherlock‰Ûù), who intervenes in his students‰Ûª lives. Mr. Scott‰Ûªs performance brings much-needed sympathy and direction to the story; he‰Ûªs kind of an emotional foil to the wild-eyed but meek Mr. O‰ÛªShea and too-stoic Mr. Galitzine. As in many a high school movie, it‰Ûªs the seasoned teacher who brings the best out of his pupils, and here Mr. Scott draws the hidden potential not only from his students but also from the film.

‰ÛÏHandsome Devil‰Ûù transcends its well-worn classroom drama routine once the characters‰Ûª sexual identities become a talking point instead of a schoolyard taunt. The film‰Ûªs earnest message of acceptance is encumbered by stylistic choices, like a disruptive voice-over and clumsy split-screen montages contrasting the boys‰Ûª vastly different social experiences. The story flirts with daddy and betrayal issues but then fails to explore them fully.

Less lusty than the Smiths song of the same title, the sweet-natured drama ‰ÛÏHandsome Devil‰Ûù studies formulaic coming-of-age movies a little too closely. Ned (Fionn O‰ÛªShea), an artistically inclined misfit, is so miserable at his conservative Irish boarding school that he longs to be expelled. His situation does not improve when he meets his soft-spoken roommate, a rugby-playing transfer student named Conor (Nicholas Galitzine). But adolescent preconceptions about jocks and geeks are overcome, and the two form an unlikely friendship challenged by the school‰Ûªs homophobic atmosphere.

Expecting a big surprise might be missing the point. Mr. Nesher, who wrote the screenplay, is less interested in twists than in a broad subject, intergenerational reconciliation. (The finale is pointedly set against President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt‰Ûªs bridge-building address to the Knesset in November 1977.) ‰ÛÏPast Life‰Ûù is a page-turner that transforms into a clarion call: always compelling, but slightly stifled by noble intentions.

The movie begins in West Berlin in 1977, where Sephi (Joy Rieger), an Israeli singer and aspiring composer, performs as a soloist in a choral concert. Afterward, while admiring handsome German fans with a fellow choir member ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏ30 years ago, they‰Ûªd be waving ‰Û÷Heil,‰Ûª‰Ûù Sephi says ‰ÛÓ she is confronted by a Polish woman (Katarzyna Gniewkowska) who calls her father, now a gynecologist in Jerusalem, a murderer.
