Sephi‰Ûªs sister, Nana (Nelly Tagar), a magazine editor, is eager to investigate. Suddenly, the past is omnipresent. Thomas (Rafael Stachowiak), a West German composer who happens to be the Polish woman‰Ûªs son, becomes a visiting teacher at Sephi‰Ûªs Jerusalem music academy, with ambiguous intentions toward her. Nana receives a diagnosis of spleen cancer, which she is convinced is cosmic revenge for a sin their father will not reveal.

Despite a potboiler setup, the Israeli director Avi Nesher‰Ûªs film ‰ÛÏPast Life,‰Ûù inspired by Baruch Milch‰Ûªs memoir ‰ÛÏCan Heaven Be Void?‰Ûù and by the lives of Mr. Milch‰Ûªs daughters, is both more and less than a simple mystery about one man‰Ûªs actions during World War II.

‰ÛÏSami Blood‰Ûù relies so much on the expressive face of its lead actress, the powerful newcomer Lene Cecilia Sparrok, that at times it might as well be wordless. The film, the feature debut of Amanda Kernell, concerns Scandinavia‰Ûªs indigenous Sami people, who faced systemic discrimination in Sweden in the 1930s.

In a prologue, we meet a woman who calls herself Christina (Maj Doris Rimpi) as she is on her way to attend the funeral of her sister. Christina disdains Sami music (which includes a form of singing called ‰ÛÏyoiking‰Ûù) and seems to have adopted racist attitudes toward the Sami ‰ÛÓ despite being one herself.

The bulk of the film consists of a flashback that traces the roots of Christina‰Ûªs self-loathing. Even as an adolescent, Christina, then known as Elle Marja (Ms. Sparrok), shows a desire to be ‰ÛÏmore Swedish.‰Ûù

The film charts the evolution of Elle Marja‰Ûªs decision to shun her Sami lineage, a choice that earns her scorn from both sides. And while ‰ÛÏSami Blood‰Ûù can sometimes seem didactic, Ms. Kernell, who has Sami heritage, richly conveys a sense of the time and place, with elegant shots that glide through the Nordic wilderness.

School is a hostile place. When outsiders from Uppsala visit the institution, Elle Marja has her body measurements taken and is displayed naked before onlookers, who treat her like an anthropological specimen. Elle Marja is later told ‰ÛÓ despite her strong grades ‰ÛÓ that Sami brains aren‰Ûªt equipped to handle lifestyles that include conventional Swedish schools.

Gosuke (Sho Aoyagi) is the son of a murage ‰ÛÓ a leading blacksmith ‰ÛÓ and is destined to follow in his father‰Ûªs footsteps. But outraged by a villager‰Ûªs death at the hands of brigands, he resolves to become a samurai and enlists in the army of one Lord Oda. In a violent skirmish, he learns how grisly war can be, and deserts, to return to Tatara and the woman (Anna Ishii) he loves. There is no escaping the convergence of forces on his hometown, however, and he trains his countrymen to defend their land, schooling them in combat and the emerging technology of firearms. His mission is complicated when his friend Shinpei (Naoki Kobayashi) sides with a warlord.

Yoshinari Nishikori‰Ûªs period action film ‰ÛÏTatara Samurai‰Ûù does not skimp with its swordplay, but its narrative arc takes you to a resolution uncommon for its genre. Tatara, from the Japanese word for ‰ÛÏfurnace,‰Ûù is the name of the film‰Ûªs principal setting, a rural 16th-century village famous for its ironworks and the craftsmanship of its weaponry. This mountain hamlet is so coveted for its raw materials that it becomes the prize in a turf battle between two warlords.

Mr. Nishikori captures a sun-dappled Shimane Prefecture and the dynamics of Japanese feudal society, and his battle scenes have a laudably realistic grit, with minimal gore. (Regrettably, however, his female characters are largely sidelined.) Best of all, his hero, played with a quiet, nuanced gravity by Mr. Aoyagi, does not become a superhuman warrior but rather a weary veteran aspiring to civilization‰Ûªs higher ideals.

Those horrors are foreshadowed, of course. During a dinner party, Heinrich Himmler, the head of the SS (repeatedly identified for the benefit of the unschooled modern audience and played with lurid understatement by Eddie Marsan), halts conversation with an account of new mass-killing techniques currently in the R&D phase. His hosts, the exiled German Kaiser Wilhelm II (Christopher Plummer) and his wife (Janet McTeer), are put in an awkward position, since they had hoped that their guest would be their ticket back to power.

This is partly because Mr. Plummer, at this stage in his career, takes evident delight in the flourishes and extravagances that seniority affords. His Kaiser is full of mischief and vanity, in many ways a reprehensible figure but nonetheless able to charm his way out of the contempt he deserves. He might also have deserved a tougher, riskier, more robust movie, but on the evidence here he seems to have made the most of disappointment.

The Kaiser, a salty eccentric and a vocal anti-Semite ‰ÛÓ though hardly a vulgar, genocidal fanatic like Himmler ‰ÛÓ is languishing in a grand house in the Dutch countryside, having left his throne in Berlin after his country‰Ûªs humiliation in the previous world war. He receives daily briefings on military strategy (from a loyal aide played by Ben Daniels) and likes to show visitors his collection of military uniforms. The Empress runs the household with Prussian rigor and dreams of a restoration. Her husband makes some show of sharing her fantasy but seems to prefer splitting logs, feeding the ducks and flirting with a pretty young maid named Mieke (Lily James).

In recent years, some movies have reopened the World War II files ‰ÛÓ especially those parts dealing with the Nazi occupation of Europe and the resistance to it ‰ÛÓ in search of gray areas and moral puzzles rather than black-and-white tales of treachery and heroism. ‰ÛÏThe Exception,‰Ûù a new film based on a novel by Alan Judd, circles back to an older tradition. Apart from the swearing, the nudity and the nonmarital sex, it‰Ûªs the kind of suspenseful, romantic melodrama of awakened conscience that might have been made in Hollywood or Britain in the early years of the war, before the worst of its horrors were widely known.

She turns out to be a Jewish anti-Nazi partisan, and to complicate matters further she is the lover of Captain Brandt (Jai Courtney), a German officer in charge of guarding (and spying on) the Kaiser. The relationship between Mieke and Brandt, which begins with a smoldering exchange of glances and moves quickly from there, is the center of the film‰Ûªs intrigue. Is she entrapping him? Is he exploiting her? Are they good-looking people with libidos inflamed by wartime? All of the above?

These questions matter for the plot, and for the themes that the movie, efficiently directed by David Leveaux from a screenplay by Simon Burke, wants to explore. Mieke has already suffered at the hands of the Nazis. Brandt, with shrapnel under his skin and nightmares in his head, has too. As a German patriot he is conscious of his duty and troubled by the extremism of Hitler and the SS. He detests the local SS heavy (Mark Dexter), a sadistic and humorless true believer. Brandt thinks that atrocities like the one he witnessed during combat in Poland are aberrations and that the German state and the German military are fundamentally honorable and decent. Mieke, seeing that he possesses those qualities, tries to convince him of his error. ‰ÛÏThey are the rule,‰Ûù she says. ‰ÛÏYou are the exception.‰Ûù

That is a stirring sentiment, and ‰ÛÏThe Exception‰Ûù is a diverting and occasionally exciting film, though it is rarely disturbing or thought-provoking in ways the material might require. Mieke and Brandt, for all their sex and skulduggery, are less interesting than the Kaiser himself, a marginal player in this historical drama who nonetheless upstages everyone else.

Still, aspirations matter, and the cast members remain dedicated to their brooding roles as the script admirably reaches for emotions it only sometimes captures. That is until Mr. Schultz lets loose with an extraordinarily savage ending. If you can resist covering your eyes, it‰Ûªs worth watching for the primitive satisfaction that payback elicits. The climax, too, may seem risky after the slow-moving middle. But really, that part is the sure thing: Everyone loves revenge.
What starts in violence ends in viciousness, and then some, in ‰ÛÏVincent N Roxxy,‰Ûù a movie whose ambition makes up for quite a few of its misfires.

Gary Michael Schultz, the director, is committed to restraint ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs in no rush to get to the action, not when there‰Ûªs mood-building to be done. It‰Ûªs a gamble that usually pays off. His screenwriting skills (in a story credited to him and Keith Kjarval) aren‰Ûªt as steadfast. It‰Ûªs doubly disappointing to wait for a laconic character to say something, only to hear a line (‰ÛÏYou don‰Ûªt even know me!‰Ûù) that sounds so clichÌ©d.

The terse title characters then spend a good part of the film circling each other and quietly flirting ‰ÛÓ they‰Ûªre more sulky than sexy ‰ÛÓ as a sense of menace pervades the scenes: A crew of local losers goads Vincent and JC into fights, while past enemies threaten to track down the prospective lovers.

Part romance, part crime drama, the story opens as Vincent (Emile Hirsch) mysteriously flees a big city to return to his tiny hometown. As he‰Ûªs leaving, he meets Roxxy (ZoÌÇ Kravitz), whom he helps escape from a gun-wielding brute; before long, she has moved into a trailer outside the house Vincent shares with his brother, JC (Emory Cohen).

Over more than 4,000 images, Ms. Tan reads from a text ‰ÛÓ a letter, it seems ‰ÛÓ as a character named Mary, who addresses her dead partner, Hiroshi. Hiroshi responds in a Japanese-language voice-over read by the actor Hiroki Hasegawa. But the construction of these two characters is less interesting than the observations and histories they impart.

Fuji‰Ûªs place in Japanese culture is illuminated by way of a folk tale about a moon princess ‰ÛÓ the same story adapted by the Japanese animation master Isao Takahata in his 2014 film, ‰ÛÏThe Tale of the Princess Kaguya.‰Ûù The presence of Fuji in the monumental Katsushika Hokusai print ‰ÛÏUnder the Wave Off Kanagawa‰Ûù (also known as ‰ÛÏThe Great Wave‰Ûù)  is discussed, as are the enthusiasm for Hokusai‰Ûªs artwork in Antwerp, Belgium, in the 19th century, and how Japanese art influenced Vincent van Gogh. ‰ÛÏAscent‰Ûù also considers why the climactic battle in the 1960s kaiju, or giant-monster movie, ‰ÛÏKing Kong vs. Godzilla,‰Ûù was staged in the shadow of Fuji.

And yet the movie is long on lyricism and short on data. You learn how much time it might take to hike to the top of Fuji, an activity explored in much detail by both of its characters, but the actual height of the mountain ‰ÛÓ a volcano still active (fiery events in the 18th century are recalled in the film) ‰ÛÓ is never mentioned. While the idea of a feature comprising nothing but photographs and voice-overs might sound a little static, Ms. Tan keeps the movie moving, in both senses of the word, with her canny use of dissolves, deliberate camera movement within a frame, and an ingenious soundtrack that often hints that the images might ‰ÛÏcome to life‰Ûù at any second. Ultimately, ‰ÛÏAscent‰Ûù is a genuinely poetic portrait of a place, and various people‰Ûªs relation to it.

I have only seen Mount Fuji from the window of a train traveling from Tokyo to Kyoto. Its instantly recognizable silhouette conveys a feeling not just of majesty, but also of stillness. It is therefore apt that ‰ÛÏAscent,‰Ûù written, directed and partly narrated by Fiona Tan, is announced as a ‰ÛÏphoto film.‰Ûù All the images in this 80-minute feature are still. They are largely photographs of the mountain itself: in broad daylight, in the dark, covered in snow, in the background of bright panoramas of sunflowers or cherry blossoms.

There is a vague notion that Nick is struggling with dueling impulses toward good and evil, acting out his version of the Jekyll-Hyde predicament. A more interesting movie might have involved a similar struggle within Ahmanet, but a more interesting movie was not on anybody‰Ûªs mind.

Mr. Crowe plays another fixture in the Dark Universe, a label that strikes me as a bit of an exaggeration. Dim Universe would be more accurate, with respect both to the murky, ugly images and to the intellectual capacities of the script, written and conceived by a bunch of people who are capable of better. The old black-and-white Universal horror movies were a mixed bag, but they had some imagination. They could be creepy or campy, weird or lyrical. ‰ÛÏThe Mummy‰Ûù gestures ‰ÛÓ or flails ‰ÛÓ in a number of directions but settles into the dreary 21st-century action-blockbuster template. There‰Ûªs chasing and fighting, punctuated by bouts of breathless explaining and a few one-liners that an archaeologist of the future might tentatively decode as jokes.

Long story short: An ancient evil has been unleashed upon the world. Its agent is a long-buried pharaoh‰Ûªs daughter, Ahmanet (Sofia Boutella), who is covered with mysterious tattoos and convinced that Nick is her secret lover, or the god of death, or both. She gets inside his head, which is awkward both because he‰Ûªs kind of sweet on Jenny and because it‰Ûªs such an empty place. Ahmanet also has a retinue of zombielike minions at her disposal, who rampage through England on their way to a meeting with Russell Crowe.

‰ÛÏThe Mummy‰Ûù begins with a supposed Egyptian proverb to the effect that ‰ÛÏwe‰Ûù never really die; ‰ÛÏwe‰Ûù assume new forms and keep right on living. I‰Ûªm not an Egyptologist, but it seems just as likely that those words were lifted from a movie-studio strategy memo. Universal, lacking a mighty superhero franchise, has gone into its intellectual-property files, which are full of venerable monsters, and created a commercial agglomeration it calls the Dark Universe. ‰ÛÏThe Mummy‰Ûù is the first of a slew ‰ÛÓ a swarm? a pestilence? ‰ÛÓ of features reviving those old creatures, including the one from the Black Lagoon. We can also look forward to new visits from Frankenstein‰Ûªs monster and his bride, the Wolf Man and the Invisible Man, among others.

You‰Ûªve no doubt been told that if you can‰Ûªt say something nice, you shouldn‰Ûªt say anything at all. If I followed that rule, I‰Ûªd be unemployed. But still. There‰Ûªs no great joy in accentuating the negative. So I will say this in favor of ‰ÛÏThe Mummy‰Ûù: It is 110 minutes long. That is about 20 minutes shorter than ‰ÛÏPirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales,‰Ûù about which I had some unkind things to say a couple of weeks ago. Simple math will tell you how much better this movie is than that one. If you have no choice but to see it ‰ÛÓ a circumstance I have trouble imagining ‰ÛÓ you can start in on your drinking that much sooner.
It will be argued that this one was made not for the critics but for the fans. Which is no doubt true. Every con game is played with suckers in mind.

It sounds like fun. The ‰ÛÏMummy‰Ûù reboot from 1999, directed by Stephen Sommers and starring Brendan Fraser, was kind of fun. Monster movies frequently are. This one, directed by Alex Kurtzman and starring Tom Cruise, is an unholy mess. Mr. Cruise plays Nick Morton, a jaunty military daredevil with a sideline in antiquities theft and a nutty sidekick (Jake Johnson). When a caper goes wrong, the two call in an airstrike on an Iraqi village ‰ÛÓ I guess that‰Ûªs something people are doing for kicks nowadays ‰ÛÓ and a mysterious tomb is unearthed. Luckily, an archaeologist, Dr. Jenny Halsey (Annabelle Wallis), is on hand to explain what it‰Ûªs all about and also to affirm Nick‰Ûªs heterosexuality.

Yet this first feature from Ari Issler and Ben Snyder (who both wrote the script with Mr. Almanzar, a military veteran) refuses to revel in violence. Focusing instead on how time and distance can calm the heart and clear the mind, this small, intimate story highlights the relationships that drive Nelson‰Ûªs response when he‰Ûªs threatened by the fallout from a long-ago crime. His closest friends, unwilling to disrupt the neighborhood peace, warily decline to take sides in the approaching showdown; his sister (an impassioned Elizabeth Rodriguez) and his girlfriend (Shirley Rumierk) urge him to flee. He has until 11:55 to decide.

Unfolding over the course of a single, stressful day, ‰ÛÏ11:55‰Ûù follows Nelson (Victor Almanzar), a young Marine who returns home from Afghanistan to discover that he has simply exchanged one unfinished war for another.

Filming in the more disheveled sections of Newburgh, N.Y., the directors align Tim Gillis‰Ûªs softly bruised photography with a hip-swaying soundtrack of Latin, dancehall and reggae. Sincere, sometimes brief performances ‰ÛÓ including those of John Leguizamo as a disabled veteran, and Julia Stiles as the bitter wife of Nelson‰Ûªs nemesis ‰ÛÓ lend necessary oomph to a narrative that can, at times, verge on sleepy.

No one, however, adds more crackle than Ms. Rodriguez, whose bridling rage against Nelson‰Ûªs cautious buddies is no less than a howl of exhaustion at lives damaged by drugs, defined by muscle and dominated by male pride.

The hopeless polarization of American society is both a truism and a taboo. We may be divided by class, race, ideology and any number of other forces, but many of us also cling to the belief ‰ÛÓ or the delusion ‰ÛÓ that a larger consensus still holds us together. Failing that, we can at least still be nice to one another when the occasion requires. Can‰Ûªt we?

Mr. Arteta ‰ÛÓ who collaborated with Mr. White on ‰ÛÏChuck and Buck‰Ûù (2000) and ‰ÛÏThe Good Girl‰Ûù (2002), and whose other films include ‰ÛÏYouth in Revolt‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏCedar Rapids‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ doesn‰Ûªt push the evening toward melodrama or farce. He directs with a dry, BuÌ±uelian touch, savoring small absurdities and letting the larger themes hover in the soft Orange County air. It‰Ûªs up to Beatriz to bring them up, to spoil the party and bring the movie to life.

Beatriz, who lives with dogs and goats and who works mainly with cancer patients at an alternative-healing center, is undoubtedly good. But because she is a Mike White heroine, she is also complicated, sometimes abrasive and not always pleasant to be around. She demonstrates obvious kinship with the characters played by Molly Shannon in ‰ÛÏYear of the Dog‰Ûù (which Mr. White wrote and directed) and Laura Dern in the HBO series ‰ÛÏEnlightened‰Ûù (which he created). Her righteousness doesn‰Ûªt make her saintly. It makes her interesting.

Not well, unfortunately. I don‰Ûªt mean that something terrible happens, but rather that the filmmakers don‰Ûªt quite succeed in bringing their story to a credible conclusion. But having said that, I have to admit that I have no idea what such a thing might look like. ‰ÛÏBeatriz at Dinner‰Ûù is about unresolvable contradictions, after all, which may mean that its failures are less specific than systemic. I don‰Ûªt blame Mr. White or Mr. Arteta. I blame capitalism. I blame America.

The same word could apply to her nemesis and dinner-party sparring partner, a rich and powerful real estate developer with the slightly too on-the-nose name of Doug Strutt. Played with almost indecent relish by John Lithgow, Strutt has the smile of a cat who swallows a bushel of canaries at every meal. He is a big-game hunter and an all-around winner at the game of life, for whom money and wives (he‰Ûªs with his third, Jeana, played by Amy Landecker) are signs of achieved destiny. He‰Ûªs boorish, blustery and also charming in his way. And while he and Beatriz have nothing in common, each can lay claim to a kind of integrity, an honest view of the world and their existence in it.

The rest of the company is more ordinary ‰ÛÓ nice people, hypocrites, unable to comprehend the moral conflict raging in front of them. The hostess, Kathy (Connie Britton), who sincerely regards Beatriz as a friend, had insisted, over the objections of her husband, Grant (David Warshofsky), on including Beatriz after her car broke down in Kathy and Grant‰Ûªs driveway. Grant is a business partner of Doug‰Ûªs, involved in a deal that also includes Alex (Jay Duplass) who arrives with his wife, Shannon (ChloÌÇ Sevigny). Small talk is made and decorum is observed, until Beatriz figures out who Doug is and decides to confront him.

The seriousness of its themes in no way detracts from the delight in watching Ms. Hayek and Mr. Lithgow perform their eccentric, intricate dance. Their commitment to the idiosyncrasy and unpredictability of their characters creates an unusual kind of suspense, a slightly uncomfortable kind of increased alertness. Where will this argument go next? How will it end?

‰ÛÏBeatriz at Dinner,‰Ûù a new film directed by Miguel Arteta and written by Mike White, unflinchingly addresses that question, and declines to provide a comforting answer. The setting is a dinner party at a Southern California mansion made awkward by the presence of the title character, a massage therapist played with regal composure and understated mischief by Salma Hayek. The differences of background and economic status between Beatriz and her hosts are obvious enough, and the film hardly ignores them. But this is neither a simple satire of privilege nor a mock-provocative comedy of diversity and its discontents. It‰Ûªs about a clash of values, about unresolvable contradictions. Or to put it another way, about good and evil.

Fortunately, ‰ÛÏCamera Obscura‰Ûù has decent actors to flesh out its dubious premise, not least Mr. Denham (‰ÛÏBillions‰Ûù). As Jack‰Ûªs fiancÌ©e, Nadja Bobyleva has an appealing range, and Catherine Curtin (soon to be in the second season of ‰ÛÏStranger Things‰Ûù) ably portrays a skeptical police detective. But their diligent efforts cannot raise the whole enterprise above a mere exercise.

The horror movie ‰ÛÏCamera Obscura,‰Ûù the feature debut of the writer-director Aaron B. Koontz, is nothing if not an exhaustive compendium of fright-film motifs. The story concerns Jack Zeller (Christopher Denham), a photographer with post-traumatic stress disorder who returns to his Midwestern hometown from a combat assignment in the Middle East, only to receive a camera whose pictures, when developed, depict murder victims within Jack‰Ûªs compositions. Soon Jack is killing people himself ‰ÛÓ ostensibly to save others at risk (his motivation is murky) ‰ÛÓ and staging the crime scenes to resemble the images in the photos.

His mental unraveling in ‰ÛÏCamera Obscura‰Ûù somewhat echoes those in many horror outings (including, for starters, ‰ÛÏThe Shining‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏRepulsion‰Ûù). Other similarities to earlier movies abound, including a killer on grainy old videotape (ÌÊ la ‰ÛÏV/H/S/2‰Ûù); spectral photographic phenomena (shades of ‰ÛÏShutter‰Ûù); a soupÌ_on of torture porn (as in the ‰ÛÏSaw‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏHostel‰Ûù movies); dashes of morbid humor; and that hardy perennial the kitchen knife (but a special Tanaka knife). A flashback to Jack‰Ûªs battle trauma adds a modicum of social commentary. Centipedes make cameo appearances, while intimations of child abuse and stalking are wholly gratuitous.

‰ÛÏDawson City‰Ûù tells a number of stories: about how the addition of certain chemicals to cotton created an explosive (nicknamed gun cotton) that was developed into celluloid motion picture film; about a settlement of Native Americans that was muscled out of existence by white settlers trekking north during the gold rushes of the mid- and late-19th centuries; about the boom and bust cycles of Dawson City itself, which burned to the ground once a year for the first nine years of its existence.

It tells the stories of famous fortunes made in this vicinity, including that of one Frederick Trump, the president‰Ûªs grandfather. Future pioneers of Hollywood, such as the actor-director William Desmond Taylor and the theater entrepreneurs Alexander Pantages and Sid Grauman, somehow got their starts in this remote locale. As silent motion pictures became a worldwide attraction, Dawson City became the end of the line for film distribution routes. And after a given picture‰Ûªs run, individual distributors balked at paying for return shipment. The town inadvertently came to house a huge film library, which was eventually sent floating down the Yukon. Except, that is, for a portion that was buried, for an unusual and arguably hilarious reason.

The variety of action and modes seen in the newly discovered films, dramas with titles like ‰ÛÏThe Unpardonable Sin‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏA Stolen Paradise,‰Ûù suggest a vast unknown film history. They also remind any film scholar that no matter how seemingly voluminous your knowledge of movie history, it is likely to be only a fraction of a fraction of the entirety. In any event, ‰ÛÏDawson City‰Ûù now enters that time line as an instantaneously recognizable masterpiece.

Mr. Morrison‰Ûªs film tells the story of how that footage, and several hundred other reels of volatile nitrate film from the 1910s and ‰Ûª20s, were discovered decades after they were presumed to be permanently lost. But part of the point of ‰ÛÏDawson City‰Ûù is that the film prints had actually been forgotten ‰ÛÓ buried underground in an era when not much thought was given to their artistic or historical value. The discovery was made in 1978 in Dawson, also known as Dawson City, a Yukon River town in northwestern Canada. A local man who was clearing a lot with a backhoe suddenly found himself digging up film reels, and he paused. The story of the finding unfolds via television news clips from the late 1970s; then Mr. Morrison goes further back, using a wide variety of much older footage.

The filmmaker Bill Morrison customarily constructs his movies with footage from other films that are very old and whose prints are very worn. No matter the ostensible subject of his individual pictures, the overarching theme is impermanence; his best-known work, ‰ÛÏDecasia‰Ûù (2002), is an artfully edited assemblage of found footage whose visual appeal is the crumbling of the film emulsion itself. So it‰Ûªs a bit of a shock that ‰ÛÏDawson City: Frozen Time‰Ûù begins with a brightly colored, completely intact clip from a television show about baseball in which Mr. Morrison appears, talking to an enthusiastic host about newly discovered footage related to the Black Sox baseball-betting scandal of 1919.

Mr. Morrison constructs his frequently jaw-dropping narrative largely from what is left of that unearthed library. At times the story spins off, and Mr. Morrison takes the opportunity to put together delirious silent-film montages (accompanied by Alex Somers‰Ûªs evocative, modernist score) full of startling visual rhymes. In addition to being filled with as many twists and turns as a first-rate suspense thriller, ‰ÛÏDawson City‰Ûù is packed with near-metaphysical intimations, both awe-inspiring and humbling. It is in many respects close to a real-life version of Jorge Luis Borges‰Ûªs great short story ‰ÛÏThe Library of Babel.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏIt Comes at Night‰Ûù is very much worth seeing on its own. It‰Ûªs smart without making too big a deal of its own cleverness, and admirably thrifty. If you haven‰Ûªt seen ‰ÛÏKrisha,‰Ûù though, I‰Ûªd recommend a double bill, an early-career retrospective of the work of a spookily self-assured, slyly ambitious young filmmaker whose apparently modest stories have mighty implications.

Paul (Joel Edgerton) and Sarah (Carmen Ejogo), with their 17-year-old son, Travis (Kelvin Harrison Jr.), and a dog named Stanley have turned a rambling country house into a fortress and a sanctuary. Grieving after the death of Sarah‰Ûªs father (David Pendleton), they cling to a routine that they hope will keep them safe. Before long they are joined by another family, a younger, less somber mirror image of themselves: Will (Christopher Abbott), Kim (Riley Keough) and their little son, Andrew (Griffin Robert Faulkner).

Not that anyone else is all that terrible. The two sets of parents are surely doing their best. But when Paul asks, ‰ÛÏDo you know what people are capable of when they‰Ûªre desperate?‰Ûù it isn‰Ûªt exactly a rhetorical question. Rather, it‰Ûªs the problem Mr. Shults has set out to investigate, with a precision that is all the more unnerving for being fundamentally humane.

Both films are about the impulse to preserve a sense of normalcy in difficult circumstances, and both reveal the cruelty behind that impulse. Paul and Sarah are not only struggling to save their family but also to hold onto a civilization ‰ÛÓ a sense of order, of dignity, of stability ‰ÛÓ that is in the midst of collapsing. If, that is, it ever really existed in the first place.

‰ÛÏIt Comes at Night,‰Ûù a rigorous and astute film written and directed by Trey Edward Shults, plays the outside-in dialectic beautifully. Initially, the premise looks like one we‰Ûªve seen plenty of times before: An epidemic has wiped out a lot of the population; food and water are scarce; survivors barricade themselves against contamination from the sick and competition from the healthy.

Mr. Shults‰Ûªs first feature, the remarkable ‰ÛÏKrisha,‰Ûù  was a family drama that often felt like a horror movie. ‰ÛÏIt Comes at Night‰Ûù is the reverse. There are obvious differences of style and tone ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏKrisha‰Ûù was talky and busy; the new film is taciturn and austere ‰ÛÓ but the director‰Ûªs preoccupations are as consistent as his sensibility. In both cases, people are thrown together in a house by circumstances they don‰Ûªt control, and how they will deal with it all becomes an ethical text with stakes high enough to implicate the audience as well as the characters.

What happens is both shocking and, in retrospect, brutally inevitable. ‰ÛÏIt Comes at Night‰Ûù is pretty terrifying to sit through, but it may be even scarier after it‰Ûªs over, when you sift through what you‰Ûªve seen and try to piece together what it may have meant. Travis, who is plagued by nightmares, tries to do just that, and serves as the viewer‰Ûªs surrogate. His perspective seems to be the only one we can trust, and he seems relatively sensitive, decent and innocent.

Needless to say, the visitors bring complications as well as companionship. There is sexual tension between Travis and Kim, and masculine rivalry between Paul and Will. Mistrust simmers and occasionally breaks into the open. The forest, meanwhile, is full of strange sounds and movements. And the house is full of guns.

This is turning out to be quite a year for horror movies. Pure coincidence, of course. And while the genre waxes and wanes like the moon over a creepy old house, it is unlikely to disappear as long as we have fears that need purging. It‰Ûªs the nature of those fears that tends to shift over time ‰ÛÓ from the social to the psychological, from supernatural evil to human depravity, from what‰Ûªs out there to what‰Ûªs in here.

All of that is established quickly and obliquely. No zombies come shambling through the woods, and Mr. Shults doesn‰Ûªt jolt the audience with false scares or showy plot twists. He builds up the dread with ruthless efficiency and minimal gimmickry, relying on and refreshing some of the oldest techniques in the book. The camera glides down a long, dimly lighted corridor. The soundtrack pulses with dissonant chords and heartbeat rhythms. (The score is by Brian McOmber.) Daylight is scarce, and shadows are long.
‰ÛÏEverything you feel goes down-leash,‰Ûù a trainer tells her. ‰ÛÏIf you‰Ûªre not confident, he‰Ûªs not confident.‰Ûù

The movie also presents a somewhat idealized view of military service, especially for women. But the war isn‰Ûªt really the point here; the relationship between a woman and a dog is. After both return, injured, to the United States, the story turns to Leavey‰Ûªs battle to be given custody of Rex. If the conclusion doesn‰Ûªt bring a tear to your eye, you‰Ûªre way too cynical.

When the story you‰Ûªre telling involves a Marine and her combat dog, you know it‰Ûªs going to be high on emotion, both the pulse-pounding and the heartstring-tugging varieties. The key is to not overplay the hand. Gabriela Cowperthwaite seems to recognize that in her direction of ‰ÛÏMegan Leavey,‰Ûù letting this irresistible real-life story tell itself with a minimum of manufactured sentiment.

The title character (winningly played by Kate Mara) is a restless young woman who enlists as the Iraq war is starting, mostly to escape small-town nowheresville, and then by happenstance finds herself doing kennel-cleaning duty for the bomb-sniffing dogs at Camp Pendleton. She soon is in training herself with a German shepherd named Rex, learning the ins and outs of forming a partnership with a highly specialized animal.

The two are deployed to Iraq, and it‰Ûªs not hard to guess what‰Ûªs coming, since we have seen this type of harrowing work in documentaries and news coverage. The film‰Ûªs biggest flaw is that the pivotal scene isn‰Ûªt well set up; it seems as if Leavey‰Ûªs unit were sent to a wasteland full of explosives for no reason other than to be blown up.

Ms. Shannon‰Ûªs character is busy trying to get back in the romantic saddle and doesn‰Ûªt give him very good advice on alternative routes to college, especially considering that she‰Ûªs a teacher herself. That Miles is gay doesn‰Ûªt really factor into the story except that he gets advice and encouragement via primitive internet chats ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs 1999, remember ‰ÛÓ with a gay young man in Chicago. Maybe these tap-tap-tap exchanges with his online pen pal are supposed to generate nostalgia, but they only slow down a movie that‰Ûªs already kind of bland.

The film, which we‰Ûªre told is inspired by a true story, is about the title character (Tim Boardman), a gay high school boy in small-town Illinois in 1999, whose father dies as the movie opens. Miles and his mother (Molly Shannon) soon learn that the man had squandered Miles‰Ûªs college money on an affair, which leaves Miles desperate: He had been counting on escaping to Chicago for college.

There is no ‰ÛÏI‰Ûù in ‰ÛÏteam,‰Ûù the sports clichÌ© goes, but there is quite a lot of ‰ÛÏI‰Ûù in the story of ‰ÛÏMiles,‰Ûù which undercuts its efforts to be inspirational. It‰Ûªs hard to root for a protagonist who is focused only on his own narrow needs and seems indifferent to the broader issues his tale raises.

When he learns that Loyola University has a men‰Ûªs volleyball scholarship available, he vows to impress the coach, which means that he has to join the girls‰Ûª volleyball team at his high school, since it has no boys‰Ûª team. The film, directed by Nathan Adloff, who wrote the script with Justin D. M. Palmer, tries to frame this as some kind of empowering step, but because Miles never does more than pay lip service to an interest in volleyball, his teammates or the competitive imbalance his presence is perceived to create (opponents begin forfeiting), it‰Ûªs hard to see his quest as anything but selfish.
Absent fathers and mothers, building bridges with children ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏMoscow Never Sleeps‰Ûù could easily have unfolded in a much darker register. That it doesn‰Ûªt is both refreshing and deflating.

Viewers will eventually find out how the dying actor (Yuri Stoyanov) who sneaks out of the hospital and is roped into spending the day with insistent fans connects to the teenager (Anastasia Shalonko) searching for her father. Elsewhere, a businessman (Aleksey Serebryakov, from Mr. Zvyagintsev‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLeviathan‰Ûù) plans to fight the takeover of his project by the Russian government from outside the country. But the movie tiptoes around politics, focusing on the character‰Ûªs love-hate feelings toward Moscow and how his imminent departure affects his relationship with a singer (Evgenia Brik).
American cinephiles accustomed to the movies of Andrey Zvyagintsev and Yuri Bykov, among others, are used to seeing Russia portrayed as a dour caldron of corruption, desperation and suppression.

Citing ‰ÛÏShort Cuts,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏMagnolia‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏCrash‰Ûù as influences, Mr. O‰ÛªReilly has structured the movie as a series of interlocking stories. Most of it is set on City Day, the holiday that celebrates Moscow‰Ûªs founding.

‰ÛÏMoscow Never Sleeps,‰Ûù a Russian-Irish coproduction by the director Johnny O‰ÛªReilly, who was raised in Ireland and is now partly based in Moscow, seems intended as a counterweight. It depicts Moscow as a bright metropolis filled with immigrants, traffic jams, restaurants and clubs, the settings for familial dysfunction and frustrated love affairs. But while the tone is novel, at least by stateside art-house standards, dramatically ‰ÛÏMoscow Never Sleeps‰Ûù is resolutely familiar, even trite.

A young man, a strange woman and an unsettled death that may be a murder ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏMy Cousin Rachel‰Ûù vibrates with possibility. That‰Ûªs especially the case when Rachel arrives in Britain, sweeping into the family manor, wearing widow‰Ûªs weeds and a Mona Lisa smile. The story‰Ûªs gift and its lever, Rachel is the enigmatic, perhaps unknowable woman whose ambiguity is at once a kind of freedom (for her, at least in part) and a cause for suspicion (for everyone else, though chiefly Philip). She quickly pries open both the story and Philip, setting loose the emotions that had been straining beneath all the polite manners and smiles, the buttoned-up clothing and desires.

At least these bluffs should cry, given the emotional terrain that the director, Roger Michell, stakes out early with one lovely landscape shot after another, the airborne camera sailing over the luxuriant, seemingly endless green. All that natural beauty does its part to draw you in, as do the tight introductions, which Philip narrates with concision over radiant images from his formative years. By the time the story gets going, Philip is nearing 25 and in mourning after learning that Ambrose has died abroad. The cause is a tumor, although Philip believes the real culprit may be a woman he doesn‰Ûªt know: Ambrose‰Ûªs British-Italian wife, Rachel (Rachel Weisz).

‰ÛÏMy Cousin Rachel‰Ûù is based on a novel by Daphne du Maurier (1907-89), whose strong narratives, flair for ambiguity and Gothic tendencies make her a natural fit for the big screen. Alfred Hitchcock turned her novel ‰ÛÏRebecca‰Ûù into a thriller with Joan Fontaine and a brooding Laurence Olivier. Hitchcock also adapted du Maurier‰Ûªs story ‰ÛÏThe Birds‰Ûù (he had less happy results when he took on her novel ‰ÛÏJamaica Inn‰Ûù); Nicholas Roeg turned another du Maurier story into ‰ÛÏDon‰Ûªt Look Now.‰Ûù And while an earlier version of ‰ÛÏMy Cousin Rachel‰Ûù (1952) doesn‰Ûªt rank alongside these films, it does have two perfect stars: Olivia de Havilland and Richard Burton.

‰ÛÏMy Cousin Rachel‰Ûù is good enough to make you wish it were better. Set in the 1830s, it is the story of Philip Ashley (Sam Claflin), a callow, moist-eyed British gentleman farmer who ‰ÛÓ as he explains in voice-over ‰ÛÓ has been raised without women. Orphaned as a child, he has been ushered into a wholly male realm by his guardian, Ambrose (also Mr. Claflin), on a swath of land stretching to the coast, a rough and wild paradise, with thundering horses, heaving waves and jagged cliffs, that cries out for death and dark poetry.

Mr. Burton‰Ûªs febrile intensity gives that film a suggestion of madness, along with sweat and rays of heat, lacking in the remake. Mr. Claflin is a lightly attractive presence, but here he doesn‰Ûªt burn; he doesn‰Ûªt even smolder. And he‰Ûªs badly outmatched by Ms. Weisz, who fluently makes Rachel into a destabilizing force, a character whose mystery can make her gracious smiles seem etched in acid. Ms. Weisz consistently pushes the movie deeper, but all too often, the story returns to Philip so that he can fret, swig from a bottle and nurture his paranoia. He‰Ûªs a mess, but not an interesting one. He‰Ûªs also a puppy, as Rachel rightly notes at one point, in a film that yaps and nips but never bares its fangs.

That‰Ûªs too bad, because there‰Ûªs a juicy story here that keeps trying to slither out alongside the sexual politics, a tale of male sexual innocence that ‰ÛÓ as Philip falls for Rachel ‰ÛÓ becomes a study in male hysteria. Or perhaps that‰Ûªs not what it is; much depends on whether you believe that Philip is a reliable narrator or one of those dissemblers who‰Ûªs so good at lying to the world because he‰Ûªs incapable of telling himself the truth. For the most part, Mr. Michell slyly keeps you guessing as to who did what to whom, and whether Rachel is a man-killer or a wronged woman, or if Philip, having been brought up without women, has been bred to fear, worship and finally hate them.

Mr. Michell, whose films include the romantic comedies ‰ÛÏNotting Hill‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏMorning Glory,‰Ûù and the rather sharper, bristling drama ‰ÛÏThe Mother,‰Ûù keeps everything too buttoned-up in ‰ÛÏMy Cousin Rachel.‰Ûù The new movie looks and sounds quite fine, and there‰Ûªs a certain easy pleasure that comes from revisiting cinematically enhanced 19th-century Britain, with its silky frocks, perfectly cut posies and apparently happy peasants. It‰Ûªs all very pretty, but too often the movie‰Ûªs beauty isn‰Ûªt tethered to deep feeling or strong ideas, one reason you may often find your eyes and thoughts drifting away from the quietly escalating drama toward the vast green fields, the majestic horses and nice detail work.

The second-chance students featured in Andrew Cohn‰Ûªs compassionate documentary ‰ÛÏNight School‰Ûù have such modest goals ‰ÛÓ a living wage, a sense of self-worth ‰ÛÓ that the hurdles they must clear to achieve them seem shockingly daunting. And though you might settle down expecting a simple portrait of adult education, it won‰Ûªt be long before you realize that you‰Ûªre the one being schooled.

‰ÛÏThis is a social justice issue,‰Ûù the school principal, Brent Freeman, says, explaining his mission. But ‰ÛÏNight School,‰Ûù like Mr. Cohn‰Ûªs 2013 documentary, ‰ÛÏMedora‰Ûù (a moving portrait of a luckless Indiana high school basketball team, which he directed with Davy Rothbart), addresses larger social cracks only obliquely, and never in a way that disrupts the natural narrative flow.

All three are poor, driven, and troubled by personal and systemic challenges. Shynika, 26, an intermittently homeless fast-food worker, hopes to become a nurse; Greg, a young single father with a criminal record, needs to provide for a daughter who has epilepsy. And Melissa, a lonely grandmother in her 50s, makes a fifth attempt to pass an algebra class ‰ÛÓ just to prove to herself that she can.
The result is a movie about large setbacks and small triumphs, and the grit that takes you from one to the other.

The lessons, however, emerge so organically and unobtrusively that their import relies on a slowly thickening atmosphere of disadvantage. Moving into a volatile neighborhood in Indianapolis in 2015, Mr. Cohn followed three very different students for a year, observing without comment as they persevered to earn high school diplomas. (Instead of a G.E.D., this particular school, with African-Americans making up 92 percent of its students, offers the real deal.)

Salty of hair and weary of manner, Lee (Sam Elliott), an aging actor now reduced to using his treacle-and-tobacco voice to peddle barbecue sauce, knows he‰Ûªs a clichÌ©. And it‰Ûªs that awareness, conveyed in every pained glance and drawled syllable, that saves ‰ÛÏThe Hero.‰Ûù Without Lee‰Ûªs complicity in the triteness of his story ‰ÛÓ and Mr. Elliott‰Ûªs ability to sell it as a melancholy burden ‰ÛÓ this low-key feature by Brett Haley wouldn‰Ûªt be half as pleasurable.

Watch Lee‰Ûªs face scrunch with wry incredulity when he realizes that a gorgeous comedian half his age (Laura Prepon) is making moves on him. Later, when he hears her use his declining body as fodder for her stand-up routine, the camera braces with him for the impact of the crowd‰Ûªs laughter. This refusal to soft pedal the age difference ‰ÛÓ or pussyfoot around the tragedy of withered fame ‰ÛÓ prevents the film from sinking into sentiment. And Mr. Elliott, for whom the story was written and who appears in almost every scene, lends even the most hackneyed moments a faded authenticity.

So when a cancer diagnosis propels Lee to reconnect with his estranged daughter (Krysten Ritter) and take a last stab at cementing his movie-star legacy, his journey takes on a gentle urgency. Katharine Ross makes a brief but welcome appearance as Lee‰Ûªs thriving ex-wife, and the director of photography, Rob C. Givens, gives the California coastline a wistful majesty. But this film belongs to its star: Like the Dame Judi Dench character created by the comedian Tracey Ullman, he‰Ûªs a national treasure.

As played by Nathalie Baye, MarlÌ¬ne comes off as shallow yet enigmatic, with a big satisfied smile she has engineered for her customers and her intimates. She‰Ûªs a stark contrast to the tortured Diane. As Diane follows her and peers at her from her car, the viewer can almost see the grieving mother constructing an awful narrative around MarlÌ¬ne. That notion continues to grip Diane as she insinuates herself not only into MarlÌ¬ne‰Ûªs life, but also that of Michel, and of MarlÌ¬ne‰Ûªs daughter from a prior relationship. Diane‰Ûªs obsessive quest for closure has brought out a certain native cunning in her, but she‰Ûªs also dangerously naÌøve ‰ÛÓ she asks her private investigator to furnish her with a gun, which he doesn‰Ûªt even entertain. She receives more cooperation from a young drug runner working the Lake Geneva ferry, leading to a flirtation with criminality that provides a momentary distraction from sorrow.

Although its plot suggests a psychological thriller, ‰ÛÏMoka, ‰Ûù a new film from the Swiss director FrÌ©dÌ©ric Mermoud, mostly plays as a character drama with a long fuse. Its opening minutes constitute a quiet cinematic sonata of loss and grief, showing Diane (Emmanuelle Devos) lying in bed and smoking, visited by visions and flashbacks of her teenage son, Luc, who was killed in a hit-and-run. Months later Diane is still beside herself, partly because the driver hasn‰Ûªt been identified, let alone caught.

Something has to give, obviously, and the movie‰Ûªs climax has sufficient twists and turns for a conventional payoff. But the movie, adapted from a novel by Tatiana de Rosnay, is ultimately more concerned with the genuinely tragic dimensions of the story than its suspense angles. That point is driven home with a final scene that is likely to move audience members to tears, just as it does Diane. ‰ÛÏMoka‰Ûù is also a first-rate showcase for two of French cinema‰Ûªs finest actors, Ms. Devos and Ms. Baye, both of whom do career-high work here.

To that end, Diane has hired a private eye, who has compiled a portfolio of possible cars and descriptions of drivers in Ìävian, France, where the auto accident happened. Diane takes the ferry there from her home in Lausanne, Switzerland, and eventually fixates on a coffee-colored Mercedes (the movie‰Ûªs title derives from the hue of the car) and the two people who drive around in it, a salon owner, MarlÌ¬ne, and her lover, Michel.

Along the way, entertaining set pieces, such as a visit to a demolition derby gone wrong, and an evening trading war stories with a group of older racecars headed by Doc Hudson‰Ûªs guru, a truck named Smokey (voiced by Chris Cooper), keep the story humming quite comfortably. It all builds to a climax that‰Ûªs entirely satisfying and not particularly overwhelming. And that‰Ûªs fine. As someone who was nearly traumatized by ‰ÛÏToy Story 3‰Ûù and reduced to a sniveling wreck by much of ‰ÛÏInside Out,‰Ûù I welcome the occasional Pixar movie that doesn‰Ûªt morph me into a quivering jelly mound.

‰ÛÏCars 3,‰Ûù directed by Brian Fee from a script by Kiel Murray, Bob Peterson and Mike Rich (the story is credited to a whole other pit crew that includes Mr. Fee), isn‰Ûªt going to win any converts among those with an animus toward talking cars. But if you can roll with it, the movie is both breezy fun and a pain-free life lesson delivery vehicle.

And the lessons are right-on, for adults as well as children. One more thing: If you‰Ûªre intimidated by the movie‰Ûªs running time, note that the feature is preceded by a short, ‰ÛÏLou,‰Ûù which is very sweet and charming, and also that, as is customary with a Pixar movie, the end credits take a while.

It begins predictably, with the cheerful, cherry red Lightning McQueen (voiced with the usual winning pep by Owen Wilson) about to zip across another finish line in first place. Except he doesn‰Ûªt win ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs beaten by a new, sleek, black-with-purple-highlights racer by the name of Jackson Storm. This brash rookie, who is voiced with apt smarm by Armie Hammer, oozes, ‰ÛÏI can‰Ûªt believe I get to race Lightning McQueen in his farewell season.‰Ûù Lightning notes that it‰Ûªs not his farewell season and ‰Û_ well, you get the idea.

The conventional reviewers‰Ûª wisdom about Pixar‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCars‰Ûù movies is that they are colorful and engaging but hardly as breathtaking as much of the other output from that animation studio. There are some who think Pixar should aim for awe-inspiring every time, because why not? Then there are crankier critics who will point out that driverless talking cars just aren‰Ûªt terribly interesting, and can be a little goofy.

It‰Ûªs here that the movie‰Ûªs pedagogic mode starts, gently, to kick in. Lightning begins to realize that maybe he really is too old to be a champion on the track anymore ‰ÛÓ so what‰Ûªs next? And Cruz reveals her thwarted ambition to be a racer, a dream she abandoned out of fear the first time she was told to take her shot. In a quiet but ultimately forceful way, ‰ÛÏCars 3‰Ûù makes a case against sexism and for the joys of mentorship. Because the ‰ÛÏCars‰Ûù franchise has been Lightning‰Ûªs story, the male lead is, by that logic, the initial force moving the female-empowerment theme. That may strike some as a little patronizing. But the Cruz-Lightning dynamic eventually evolves into a genuine friendship that has a lot of appeal.

‰ÛÏThe racing world is changing,‰Ûù a friend advises Lightning, and our hero makes a small effort to adapt. Hooking up with a new corporate sponsor, he starts his off-season training at a top-tier site where, apparently, newbies such as Jackson Storm tone up. There, he‰Ûªs introduced to a plucky performance coach, a yellow car named Cruz Ramirez (voiced by Cristela Alonzo). She responds to Lightning‰Ûªs frequent angry, pessimistic outbursts with an instruction to ‰ÛÏUse that!‰Ûù

For a while, the movie is content to poke mild fun at America‰Ûªs enthusiasm for trendy self-help bromides and computer-age enhancement technology. There‰Ûªs a mild paradox that this entirely digital movie waxes so nostalgic for analog-age stuff: Art Deco diners, big-knob radios, funky garages. Lightning frequently flashes back to the advice and companionship of his old mentor, Doc Hudson (voiced by the great Paul Newman in the first ‰ÛÏCars‰Ûù movie in 2006, two years before his death, and who is again heard here). Acting on those memories, Lightning eventually persuades Cruz to get out and train with him, old-school style, at a nearby beach.

Less so are the movie‰Ûªs slapdash setup and paper-thin characterizations. Lisa (the appealing Mandy Moore), is a recent dumpee who‰Ûªs eager to prove to her ex that she‰Ûªs not nearly as boring as he believes. Her younger sister, Kate (Claire Holt), is merely the free spirit who goads Lisa into the water. Above them, an improbably cast Matthew Modine plays the captain of a boat so sketchy looking that it‰Ûªs a wonder any of his passengers make it back to shore.

Shot in gigantic water tanks outside London and in the Dominican Republic, ‰ÛÏ47 Meters Down‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ despite a clever final section ‰ÛÓ struggles to extract tension from clamor and agitation. Mr. Roberts should have studied Chris Kentis‰Ûªs 2004 frightener, ‰ÛÏOpen Water,‰Ûù which coaxed throat-closing dread from little more than a silent horizon and a diver‰Ûªs legs waving below the surface like fronds of seaweed. Sometimes it‰Ûªs scarier when no one can hear you scream.

In the lulls between bouts of yammering, however, the director, Johannes Roberts, concentrates on building a solid atmosphere of desperation as a winch accident deposits the women unceremoniously on the ocean floor. Captured by Mark Silk‰Ûªs darting camera, and in water so clouded that the computer-generated predators more than pass visual muster, their misadventures are casually entertaining.

Featuring multiple variations of ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs gonna be fine!‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe shark almost got me!,‰Ûù the superlatively lame dialogue spoken by the heroines of ‰ÛÏ47 Meters Down‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ two sisters who choose the wrong boat for their shark-cage diving expedition in Mexico ‰ÛÓ threatens to turn this would-be horror movie into a hoot.

That missed opportunity resonates particularly at the movie‰Ûªs end, when text lists an impressive number of statistics concerning his record sales and motion picture appearances. Viewers are also reminded that Shakur was only 25 when he died in September 1996 after being fatally injured in a drive-by shooting in Las Vegas. His killing has never been solved.

During his brief fireball of a career, the rapper Tupac Shakur was a galvanic, frequently confounding figure. ‰ÛÏAll Eyez on Me,‰Ûù a fictionalized film biography of Shakur, directed by Benny Boom and starring Demetrius Shipp Jr., is not only a clumsy and often bland account of his life and work, but it also gives little genuine insight into his thought, talent or personality.

From the opening, Mr. Boom‰Ûªs direction is uniformly uninspired: A reporter‰Ûªs prison interview with Shakur frames the movie‰Ûªs first half, and Mr. Boom blocks and shoots his scenes with dismal stolidness. Few sequences last longer than a couple of minutes; the movie plods along with a ‰ÛÏand then this happened‰Ûù dutifulness, occasionally cutting back to the prison interview to have the reporter ask a pointed question or two. This almost invariably allows the film to excuse Shakur for bad actions that the reporter brings up during the interview. (Speaking of which, the movie is genuinely distasteful in its casual misogyny when depicting the sexual abuse case for which Shakur was convicted in 1994.)
‰ÛÏYour stepdaddy is a revolutionary,‰Ûù Afeni, played by Danai Gurira, tells the young Tupac. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm gonna be a revolutionary,‰Ûù he replies.

Almost all the dialogue is that flat-footed. (Jeremy Haft, Eddie Gonzalez and Steven Bagatourian wrote the script.) It‰Ûªs a stark contrast to the almost always vivid power of Shakur‰Ûªs own words, which could be profoundly empathetic and pettily profane. Not enough of them are heard here, but when Mr. Shipp has some of them at his disposal, or is given enough space in a scene to maneuver into an actual characterization, he is very impressive. This movie fails his considerable talents; I hope that he is soon afforded a better vehicle for them.

Mr. Boom has genuinely good reason to chronicle Shakur‰Ûªs eventful life even before his birth. Shakur‰Ûªs mother, Afeni, who died last year, was a civil rights activist and a Black Panther; an early scene shows her emerging victorious from a conspiracy trial a month before giving birth to him.

But the intriguing, politically minded people he grew up among, as well as those he later made music and did business with, are portrayed in conventional, clichÌ©d ways. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªd rather die on my feet than live on my knees,‰Ûù Shakur‰Ûªs stepfather, Mutulu Shakur, proclaims at a meeting of a black community group.

The most exciting part of ‰ÛÏF(l)ag Football‰Ûù arrives at the end, when two bitter rivals face each other. But the most insightful scene comes in the middle of this documentary, when the New York Warriors of the National Gay Flag Football League take on a straight team from Long Island.

The Long Island players aren‰Ûªt told that most of the Warriors are gay, and excerpts shown from the game ‰ÛÓ no spoilers on the winner ‰ÛÓ feature some intense competition. After one Long Islander learns of the opposing players‰Ûª sexuality, he reacts with a shrug and with praise for their skills.

The film gains momentum, however, as the athletes experience hope, disappointment, pain and joy during the final contest. It should go without saying, but Mr. Greenleaf knows it‰Ûªs worth showing: On the field and off, we are all so much alike.

That‰Ûªs how you want life to be: people judged on their abilities and without foolish preconceptions. And if we‰Ûªre not there yet, this likable film at least offers several optimistic moments as Seth Greenleaf, the director, follows the Warriors, the L.A. Motion and other teams as they train for the yearly Gay Bowl flag football tournament. (The game, a variation on touch football, places a premium on speed; players are downed not by tackles, but when an opponent pulls a marker from the ball carrier‰Ûªs belt.)

Along the way, we listen to coming-out stories and look into the conflict between traditional views of masculinity, especially in sports (and in the N.F.L. in particular), and stereotypes of homosexuality. It‰Ûªs an interesting mix, though a few of the interviews meander, and, except for the championship, there‰Ûªs little sense of urgency onscreen.

Even before the arrival of the mysterious Mr. Yasaka (Tadanobu Asano), the marriage of Toshio (Kanji Furutachi), the owner of a small machine shop, and his self-effacing wife, Akie (Mariko Tsutsui), appears passionless. Polite but distant, they share meals and the care of their small daughter, Hotaru, with so little intimacy that when Toshio offers Yasaka a room and a job, he doesn‰Ûªt even ask his wife‰Ûªs opinion. All too soon, though, he‰Ûªll have cause to regret his impulsiveness.

A companion piece to Mr. Fukada‰Ûªs 2010 comedy, ‰ÛÏHospitalitÌ©,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏHarmonium‰Ûù binds not one but two broken families in a clammy union of tragedy and seduction. As Yasaka‰Ûªs presence in the household becomes ever more disruptive, the story veers in unexpected directions, leaping over years before landing with wrenching ambiguity. Yet the implacable pacing and Kenichi Negishi‰Ûªs unruffled cinematography shape Yasaka into a near-mythic instrument of destruction. His motives are murky for a reason: By committing the character to nothing, Mr. Fukada allows us to suspect him of everything.

‰ÛÏFor me, family is an absurdity,‰Ûù the director Koji Fukada says in the publicity materials for ‰ÛÏHarmonium,‰Ûù a rigorously grim drama that glides, slowly and inexorably, toward proving his point. Yet the atmosphere of dread that Mr. Fukada tends with such ruthless precision ‰ÛÓ and more than a little sadism ‰ÛÓ depends not on creepy camera moves or other visual trickery. Instead, this chilly tale of violent secrets and unvoiced misery relies heavily on the skill of actors who seem to know that one false move could tip the whole enterprise into comedy.

The film also doesn‰Ûªt make much effort to put her achievements in historical context. A number of skilled musicians, some of them household names, have been blind or faced other physical challenges. Despite a cameo by Stevie Wonder, that goes largely unacknowledged. It would have been nice at least to hear Ms. Flowers‰Ûªs thoughts on where she fits in this chain of rare talents. More outside assessments of her music also would have been welcome.

The film, by Lorenzo DeStefano, chronicles her musical development, but haphazardly, sometimes seeming more promotional than exploratory. We learn only a little about Ms. Flowers‰Ûªs creative process and the difficulties she and her family faced over the years.

A remarkable life story doesn‰Ûªt automatically make a good documentary. Certainly the journey of Rachel Flowers, a blind musician and composer, is impressive, but ‰ÛÏHearing Is Believing,‰Ûù a documentary about her, doesn‰Ûªt put enough effort into giving her tale depth and context.

After an aimless hour, the film eventually gets some traction with a segment in which Dweezil Zappa brings Ms. Flowers onstage during one of his concerts to perform works by his father, Frank Zappa. It‰Ûªs the climax of this film, but really Ms. Flowers‰Ûªs career is just beginning. There might be a better documentary to be made about her some years in the future.

Ms. Flowers, now 23, was born 15 weeks premature, and among the complications was the loss of her eyesight. Yet, as a toddler, she demonstrated profound musical ability, and she was soon adept on keyboards, flute and other instruments. A measure of YouTube fame followed.

Sordi‰Ûªs 10-second reaction to the question is worth the price of admission. His characterization of Giovanni, who‰Ûªs vulnerable, sometimes dim, ever teetering on the brink of showing his full desperation, is arguably the film‰Ûªs strongest selling point. (This stretch was good for Sordi; he also had a fantastic turn then as a reluctant hit man in the comedy ‰ÛÏMafioso.‰Ûù)

The circumstances under which De Sica made ‰ÛÏAfter the Fox‰Ûù are too complex to get into here. But as deftly demonstrated by ‰ÛÏIl Boom,‰Ûù a 1963 film he made that is only now getting a United States release, courtesy of Rialto Pictures and Film Forum, comedy was always a part of this director‰Ûªs skill set. Written by Cesare Zavattini, who did the screenplays for many of De Sica‰Ûªs best-known works, the movie skewers the mendacity inherent in the postwar economic resurgence in his country.

The Italian director and actor Vittorio De Sica is best known internationally for the searing, poignant, humanist pictures he made in the late 1940s and early ‰Ûª50s. These are classics of the so-called Neo-Realist movement that include ‰ÛÏShoeshine,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏBicycle Thieves‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏUmberto D.‰Ûù Careers in film often take unusual turns. My film students teared up at ‰ÛÏBicycle Thieves‰Ûù and then were both puzzled and amused when I showed them the opening of ‰ÛÏAfter the Fox,‰Ûù an elaborately silly 1966 caper comedy starring Peter Sellers that seems worlds away from ‰ÛÏThieves‰Ûù but was also, as it happens, directed by De Sica.

Not that De Sica‰Ûªs directorial signature is absent. His portrait of a different aspect of the Italian early ‰Ûª60s ‰ÛÏdolce vita,‰Ûù in which the entrepreneurial middle class rubs elbows with, and tries to wheel and deal with, the obscenely wealthy, is packed with trenchant observation and mordant wit.

Alberto Sordi plays Giovanni, a building contractor with big ideas and a lavish lifestyle that‰Ûªs mostly enjoyed by his wife, Silvia (Gianna Maria Canale), with whom he is quite properly besotted. But the movie begins with our hero in a bit of a spot, owing a large sum of money he can‰Ûªt pay. So convincing is his masquerade of affluence that when he asks a rich tennis partner for a loan, the other man assumes that Giovanni is joking. An appeal to his boss ends when that boss falls asleep in the middle of his pitch. During a heart-to-heart with the wife of a megarich industrialist, she makes him a proposition. ‰ÛÏWhat I‰Ûªm about to ask may surprise you: Would you sell an eye?‰Ûù
The audience won‰Ûªt learn much about this so-called echo world either, except that its signs ‰ÛÓ much like the name of the movie‰Ûªs novice director, Tim Smit ‰ÛÓ read backward.

The plot, unlike its execution, is not terrible. A parallel universe has been created as a new source of energy for our depleted world, but something screwy has happened and Will must hop over there to assess the situation. When he arrives, he encounters malignant drones and armed militants ‰ÛÓ none of whom are on board with his plan to destroy the new world to save the old one.

Visually, this translates to a video-game-style slog from Will‰Ûªs crash site to a tower where the titular switch will be flicked. Back home, a widowed sister and sick nephew ‰ÛÓ trying gamely to humanize a paper-thin lead character ‰ÛÓ stare at the sky and wonder why Uncle Will is never around long enough to tell them anything.

Maybe he was persuaded by his character‰Ûªs first-person perspective, a narrative device that requires him to appear on camera so rarely that most of his dialogue could have been phoned in from a beach in Belize. And that‰Ûªs exactly how disconnected he sounds when playing Will Porter, a scientist-pilot hired by a shady corporation to intervene when an experiment goes catastrophically awry.

One has to wonder what Dan Stevens ‰ÛÓ whose career since ‰ÛÏDownton Abbey‰Ûù hasn‰Ûªt exactly stalled ‰ÛÓ was thinking when he accepted the lead role in ‰ÛÏKill Switch,‰Ûù a pointless gush of science-fiction bilge.
‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt feel like I‰Ûªve done a very good job,‰Ûù Will says when his mission is over. True that.

Fiona decides to pay Martha a visit, bringing luggage more suited to mountaineering than a Parisian getaway. The luggage eventually makes its way to Dom (Mr. Abel), a hobo who is dashing enough to charm Fiona at a riverboat restaurant.
‰ÛÏLost in Paris‰Ûù grows a bit tiresome at feature length, but it‰Ûªs a winning divertissement.

Most of the pleasures of ‰ÛÏLost in Paris‰Ûù come from watching the coincidences multiply as Fiona, Dom and Martha narrowly miss one another. There is a case of mistaken identity at a funeral and a bit of acrobatic derring-do on the Eiffel Tower. In one sweet interlude, Ms. Riva and Pierre Richard (playing Martha‰Ûªs former lover) perform dance steps while seated on a bench, accentuated by close-ups of the pair‰Ûªs shoes.

‰ÛÏLost in Paris‰Ûù begins in a snowy Canadian outpost, where Fiona (Ms. Gordon) receives a letter from Martha (Emmanuelle Riva, of ‰ÛÏAmour,‰Ûù who died in January), an aunt who left for Paris decades earlier. Martha is 88 and a bit daffy. (She‰Ûªs shown putting the letter in the trash instead of a mailbox in a Mr. Magoo-style mishap. It‰Ûªs later rescued.)

In ‰ÛÏLost in Paris,‰Ûù the married directors and stars Fiona Gordon and Dominique Abel show a grace for physical comedy and pretzel-like pas de deux. If their fourth feature (their first three, including ‰ÛÏL‰ÛªIceberg‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Fairy,‰Ûù were directed with Bruno Romy) is mild by design, their style ‰ÛÓ equal parts Jacques Tati, Jerry Lewis, Wes Anderson and ‰ÛÏWallace & Gromit‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ isn‰Ûªt easy to pull off.

The film doesn‰Ûªt cop to that, which doesn‰Ûªt lessen its appeal. The distancing from the real Lewis registers as a commercial calculation, as does the emphasis on Maud and Everett‰Ûªs relationship, which here evolves into an achingly moving love story. How much of it is true, including that love‰Ûªs depths, remains unclear; certainly the movie deviates sharply in sweep and detail from some accounts, most notably Lance Woolaver‰Ûªs biography ‰ÛÏMaud Lewis: The Heart on the Door.‰Ûù Mr. Woolaver has called Lewis‰Ûªs life desperate and her husband terrible, and wrote a book that, as he told one interviewer, deflates the myth of her ‰ÛÏas a happy little elf in a bright house doing nothing but paint.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏMaudie‰Ûù is one of those movies that triumph over their worst instincts (and your well-honed doubts). There‰Ûªs a lot to get past, including an opener that engages in some generic place-setting, and a pushy score that insistently tries to lighten the darker moods. But stick with the movie for its leads, Sally Hawkins and Ethan Hawke, a beautifully matched pair who open up two closed people, unleashing torrents of feeling.

It gets going when Maud does, too. One day at the grocery store, she is nearly knocked over by a hard, loud wind that blows in and in time becomes her unlikely husband, Everett Lewis (Mr. Hawke). A reclusive fish peddler ‰ÛÓ much of the story takes place on the outskirts of a Nova Scotia town ‰ÛÓ he lives in a tiny white wooden house on a spit of land with only a couple of dogs and a flock of chickens for company. Having decided that he needs a housekeeper, he posts an ad in the store that Maud surreptitiously steals. She has figured a way out of Aunt Ida‰Ûªs dominion and straight into a new life.

Like many screen biographies, ‰ÛÏMaudie‰Ûù vacillates unsteadily between the brute realities of a difficult existence and its palatable imagery. The movie doesn‰Ûªt erase the hard edges of Lewis‰Ûªs life. Instead, it attenuates them ‰ÛÓ a brutal slap across the face, you suspect, stands in for more instances of physical abuse ‰ÛÓ and casts many of Maud and Everett‰Ûªs difficulties as personal ordeals, playing down the institutional forces, like an orphanage, that discreetly hover in the background. There‰Ûªs an argument to be made against such softening, though, as Lewis‰Ûªs work suggests, there‰Ûªs something necessary about the fantasies we make of our lives as we spin beauty and hope from despair.

Ms. Hawkins plays Maud Lewis, who, when the story starts, is in her early 30s and struggling to maintain a fragile independence. She‰Ûªs living with her Aunt Ida (Gabrielle Rose), a dour scold whose opprobrium has seeped into every corner of her house and who enters, haggling with a man who proves to be Maud‰Ûªs brother, Charles (Zachary Bennett). He has sold the family home, and is dumping Maud at Aunt Ida‰Ûªs for the foreseeable future. Maud pleads and protests, and then moodily waits for her story to begin.

That life emerges with pinprick detail, framed by windswept landscapes and the bright flowers and birds that Maud begins painting, painful stroke by stroke, on the shack‰Ûªs walls, steps, pots and windows, vivid manifestations of her will to create. Mostly, it is a life that emerges through the contrapuntal performances of Ms. Hawkins and Mr. Hawke, who, with bobbing heads, mutter and murmur, bringing you into the private world of two outsiders isolated by geography, poverty, disability, temperament and habit. It‰Ûªs easy, especially, to admire Ms. Hawkins‰Ûªs technical skill ‰ÛÓ the private smiles and halting, crooked walk ‰ÛÓ but the beauty of her performance is that soon you see only Maud.

Directed by Aisling Walsh, with a script by Sherry White, ‰ÛÏMaudie‰Ûù is based ‰ÛÓ or perhaps, more truly, inspired ‰ÛÓ by the life of Maud Lewis (1903-1970). A self-taught artist who lived in extreme poverty much of her adult life, Lewis struggled with what appears to have been juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, painting bold, colorful scenes of red trees and black cats with brushes tucked in a tiny, gnarled hand. If you didn‰Ûªt know her name, you might not know that she was real. The story‰Ûªs historical basis isn‰Ûªt announced; there are none of the usual biopic introductions, no text to set the time and place, only some brief, closing documentary images that suggest that the movie has gently prettified the truth.
A bunch of well-known faces look lost in ‰ÛÏOnce Upon a Time in Venice,‰Ûù which is billed as an action-comedy but has little comedy and less action.

The movie tries for propulsive Tarantino grit but ends up being just another annoying example of Hollywood‰Ûªs addiction to stories in which graying white men bed beautiful young women and beat up men much more youthful and fit than they are.

Bruce Willis stars as Steve Ford, a private detective in the Venice Beach section of Los Angeles whom the story puts through various indignities, including a naked skateboard ride, before eventually getting to the main yarn, which involves Steve‰Ûªs efforts to recover his stolen dog from a drug dealer. Also on hand is John Goodman, playing a good friend of Steve‰Ûªs who is going through a divorce, a side plot that has no real purpose; Mr. Goodman seems to have no idea how he landed in the movie.

Thomas Middleditch, who needs someone to explain to him the dangers of overexposure, plays his usual bumbling character, a gofer for Steve who also narrates the tale. The barely coherent script (the brothers Robb and Mark Cullen wrote the script, with Mark Cullen directing) involves cocaine, real estate and a man (Adam Goldberg) who wants Steve to find out who keeps painting pornographic graffiti on a building he owns.

American comedy has long depended on overgrown baby boys ‰ÛÓ Lou Costello, Will Ferrell ‰ÛÓ whose naÌøvetÌ©, entertaining misbehavior or outright stupidity suggests that men are finally as toothless as infants. It‰Ûªs a convenient fantasy (don‰Ûªt worry, ladies!), one that has grown less viable as women have gained power and autonomy offscreen. ‰ÛÏRough Night‰Ûù wants its female characters to get down, dirty and dumb, too, and indulge in their ostensible vices as unapologetically as any Zach Galifianakis boob. That‰Ûªs cool or might be if the jokes were a lot funnier and if this movie grasped that performing naughtiness is meaningless when men behaving badly is the rule of the land.

Those eyes get a workout when the women‰Ûªs weekend takes a detour that‰Ûªs straight out of ‰ÛÏVery Bad Things,‰Ûù a 1998 comedy about a bachelor party that turns deadly when a reveler accidentally kills a female prostitute. In response, the men embrace their worst instincts, which in this case means they hide one death and, in the process, instigate another. Boys will be boys and sometimes killers ‰ÛÓ or so ‰ÛÏVery Bad Things‰Ûù cheerfully suggests. ‰ÛÏThe Hangover‰Ûù basically packages such rotten male behavior for the mainstream, using a live hooker instead of a dead one and adding Mike Tyson, an errant tiger and a pileup of belabored high jinks. Women scarcely figure in its manly meltdown, which is the point.

It‰Ûªs all blithely formulaic and would be more irritating if the performers ‰ÛÓ who include ZoÌÇ Kravitz and Ilana Glazer ‰ÛÓ weren‰Ûªt generally so appealing. (Ms. Glazer is a star of the Comedy Central show ‰ÛÏBroad City,‰Ûù which Ms. Aniello and Mr. Downs also both work on.) The actors are playing types, not people, but most bring enough natural presence and good will to fill in their characters‰Ûª sketchy profiles. It helps, too, that Ms. Johansson and Ms. Glazer are gifted physical performers who can sell weak jokes, though no one steals a show like Ms. McKinnon, a brilliantly versatile comic who reaches Madeline Kahn-levels of eyeball-rolling, eyeball-popping and all-knowing dementedness.

In ‰ÛÏRough Night,‰Ûù Scarlett Johansson stars as Jess and is nearly eclipsed by Kate McKinnon, who plays one of her pals. A politician who‰Ûªs about to get married, Jess is on the verge of losing a state senate race to an opponent who has pulled ahead with some Anthony Weiner-esque penis pictures. That a competent female politician can‰Ûªt compete with literal penises suggests that the filmmakers have some ideas in store, something, say, that mines the comedy of our new Neanderthalism, an age partly defined by the reinvigorated war between the sexes and the triumphant rise and occasional fall of male members.

How low can she go? That‰Ûªs the question in the soft vanilla comedy ‰ÛÏRough Night,‰Ûù about five women who blunder into disaster over the course of a carousing bachelorette weekend. If you‰Ûªve seen ‰ÛÏThe Hangover‰Ûù and its sequels or various other movies of this familiar ilk, you have more or less seen ‰ÛÏRough Night.‰Ûù There‰Ûªs even a movie titled ‰ÛÏBachelorette,‰Ûù another would-be laugh-in about friends who go crazy ‰ÛÓ snort, snort, snort, chug, chug ‰ÛÓ until they‰Ûªre put back on the path toward happily ever after.

No such luck. The director Lucia Aniello, who wrote the script with Paul W. Downs, soon abandons any pretense that she is going to deliver more than goofs. Instead, she trots out clichÌ©s, including a flashback that shows Jess and another bestie, Alice (Jillian Bell), holding their own at a frat blowout. Here, partying hard is meant as a stand-in for equality, which is mighty low stakes on which to build a gender-flipping comedy. Nonetheless, Ms. Aniello barrels ahead with limp penis jokes, yuks and a little upchuck, throwing in a starry guest appearance and the requisite slow-motion wolf-pack shot of the women strolling in a line, an image so stale it‰Ûªs an entry on tvtropes.org.

‰ÛÏRough Night‰Ûù switches the gender lineup from ‰ÛÏVery Bad Things‰Ûù but with less (shallow) philosophizing and heterosexual panic. Much like their ‰ÛÏVery Bad‰Ûù counterparts, the women quickly embrace self-interest, which leads to unfunny gags with an inconvenient corpse. That women can be as deadly or immoral as men isn‰Ûªt new or interesting, and here it also isn‰Ûªt all that entertaining. What is notable is that ‰ÛÏRough Night‰Ûù makes room for the opposite sex (too many comedies are his or hers), specifically with some slow-building nonsense involving Jess‰Ûªs fiancÌ© (Mr. Downs), who crashes the party in adult diapers ‰ÛÓ which reads as a nice, sly wink at the comedy of male infantilism.

Inordinate time is spent with Hans Zimmer, whose symphonic-synthesizer scores define the current action-spectacle template. But he rightly says film composers are ‰ÛÏone of the last people on earth‰Ûù who regularly employ orchestra musicians. ‰ÛÏWithout us,‰Ûù he adds, ‰ÛÏthe orchestra might disappear,‰Ûù which would be ‰ÛÏsuch a loss to humanity.‰Ûù And who can argue?

In 1993, the documentary ‰ÛÏVisions of Light‰Ûù won critical love for its overview of Hollywood‰Ûªs classic cinematographers. Matt Schrader‰Ûªs tidy and informative ‰ÛÏScore‰Ûù lavishes similar adoration on moviedom‰Ûªs great composers. And why not? Their contribution can be as substantial as that of cinematographers, or even actors, though more subtle ‰ÛÓ but not always.

The greats are here, either discussed or appearing on camera themselves: Max Steiner (whose orchestral flourishes enriched ‰ÛÏKing Kong‰Ûù); Alex North (of ‰ÛÏA Streetcar Named Desire,‰Ûù whom the film credits with ushering jazz into scores); John Barry (whose James Bond theme would influence spy films in perpetuity); and giants on their own mountaintop, Bernard Herrmann and Ennio Morricone. (What, no Elmer Bernstein or Erich Wolfgang Korngold? But why quibble?) More recent innovators, like Trent Reznor (‰ÛÏThe Social Network‰Ûù), Danny Elfman (Tim Burton‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBatman‰Ûù) and Rachel Portman (‰ÛÏRace‰Ûù), speak eloquently. John Williams (‰ÛÏJaws,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏStar Wars‰Ûù) casts a very long shadow.

Example No. 1: Bill Conti‰Ûªs theme to ‰ÛÏRocky,‰Ûù as brash and manipulative an accompaniment to a workout montage as ever there was. From there, the movie recounts the early days of Wurlitzer organs and musicians improvising to silent movies for live audiences, before segueing into a brief, basic lesson in director-composer collaborations.

I‰Ûªm sure that I‰Ûªve forgotten some of the clichÌ©s and nonsense stuffed into ‰ÛÏThe Book of Henry,‰Ûù but here‰Ûªs a partial list: a sensitive child genius; a comically dysfunctional family; an overwhelmed single mother; a sassy waitress with a tattoo on her breast played by a name comedian; children acting like parents; parents acting like children; a young, beautiful female victim; the predator next door; an incompetent (but not unkind!) school bureaucrat; a fatal diagnosis; a ticking clock; a race against the clock; a cute doctor played by a TV actor whose name is on the tip of your tongue; and a female star who deserves far better.

A weepie, a thriller, a tragedy, a sub-Spielbergian pastiche, ‰ÛÏThe Book of Henry‰Ûù is mostly a tedious mess. It was directed by Colin Trevorrow and written by Gregg Hurwitz, and I suggest you skip it or catch it on streaming or on the back of an airplane seat, where presumably it will soon be playing. You may like a few things, especially Jaeden Lieberher, who plays Henry with real feeling and deserves a long career. But you may wonder how long Jacob Tremblay, who was so good in ‰ÛÏRoom,‰Ûù will be cast for his tremulousness.
