And you may also, after stifling your yawns, hope that the next time you see Naomi Watts it‰Ûªs in a movie that plays to her strengths and doesn‰Ûªt treat her or the audience so contemptuously.

Driven by a fresh-faced chauffeur (Freddie Highmore), the two are secretly monitored via hidden surveillance cameras by the British prime minister, Tony Blair (Toby Stephens); the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern (Mark Lambert); a British government operative (John Hurt); and, eventually, McGuinness‰Ûªs Sinn Fein compatriot Gerry Adams (Ian Beattie). After a minor car accident, Paisley and McGuinness walk to an empty church and cemetery where, among other things, they discuss the Bloody Sunday shootings in Londonderry in 1972 and the I.R.A. bombing in Enniskillen in 1987. Though the script tilts to the didactic, the performances are absolutely delicious, with Mr. Meaney droll and understated and Mr. Spall fiery and derisive, yet not above a joke.

The film begins in October 2006, at St. Andrews in Scotland, where Britain, the Irish Republic and Northern Irish parties ‰ÛÓ including the Democratic Unionist Party (the D.U.P.) and Sinn Fein ‰ÛÓ are negotiating what was called the St. Andrews Agreement, a power-sharing pact between Unionists and Irish republicans. The conceit is that the aging Paisley (Timothy Spall), who has a 50th wedding anniversary to attend in Belfast, and McGuinness (Colm Meaney) share a ride to the airport to ensure that neither is subject to an assassination attempt.

The film suggests that all became harmonious between the two, and, implicitly, their parties. In real life, the D.U.P. is now propping up Theresa May‰Ûªs government in Britain, while Sinn Fein has gained voting power and seems to be biding its time for Ireland‰Ûªs reunification. (Scotland, meanwhile, is pondering another independence referendum.) ‰ÛÏI play a long game,‰Ûù Mr. Meaney‰Ûªs McGuinness says. ‰ÛÏWe are Ireland. We are inevitable.‰Ûù

Wishful thinking predominates in Nick Hamm‰Ûªs drama ‰ÛÏThe Journey,‰Ûù an imaginary account of a conversation between former giants in Northern Ireland‰Ûªs Troubles: the Rev. Ian Paisley, who spearheaded the Democratic Unionist Party (he died in 2014), and Martin McGuinness, a Sinn Fein leader (who died in March).

But don‰Ûªt worry; if for some reason the drawn-out and incoherent battle scenes are what you liked about the earlier films, the climactic one here is still both of those things. The movie is shorter (by about 15 minutes) than the last one, though, and considerably more bearable.

Get to the fifth installment of a film series, especially a sci-fi action one with a reputation for mindless bloat, and you can generally assume you‰Ûªll be looking at the franchise‰Ûªs most dreadful offering yet. But ‰ÛÓ surprise ‰ÛÓ the fifth ‰ÛÏTransformers‰Ûù movie, ‰ÛÏThe Last Knight,‰Ûù is far from the worst in this continuing experiment in noisy nonsense based on Hasbro toys. That is thanks largely to two words: Anthony Hopkins.

Michael Bay again directs, and he and his writers (Art Marcum, Matt Holloway and Ken Nolan are credited with the screenplay, and those three along with Akiva Goldsman with the story) put more humanity and less clanking into this installment. Mr. Bay seems to rein in his tendency for high-speed pursuits and robotic clashes somewhat, and he varies the vroom-vroom car-chase stuff by throwing in a submarine chase.

He‰Ûªs a sort of keeper of the Arthurian/Transformers legend, and he knows that a long-forecast climactic battle is coming for control of Merlin‰Ûªs staff, an ancient relic that has formidable powers when wielded by the right person.

What Mr. Hopkins, a knighted Emmy and Oscar winner, is doing in a ‰ÛÏTransformers‰Ûù movie is unclear, but he brings a goofy dignity to the enterprise that elevates this chapter over its recent brethren. The storytelling is also an upgrade. For one thing, we finally are given a believable explanation for the purpose of Stonehenge.

As this story opens, Cade is one of the few humans who still has some affection for Autobots, the robotic immigrants from outer space who mean well but whose war with the Decepticons has resulted in all sorts of havoc on Earth. The rest of humanity is still annoyed with them for wrecking a perfectly good city, Chicago, earlier in the franchise.

In this case that person is Viviane (Laura Haddock), a British scholar who is skeptical of the Round Table tales and is also just the right age to be a potential romantic interest for Cade. As for Stonehenge, well, without giving away too much, let‰Ûªs just say that invaders from space are coming to suck the life out of our planet, and the great monument is not merely the clunkiest calendar ever made.

This movie series can only wish it had the depth and coherence of the ‰ÛÏStar Wars‰Ûù franchise, but the homage is nice, and Cogman and Edmund have some witty moments, something the more plodding sequels lacked.

Also in the mix are Lennox (Josh Duhamel), the military man from the previous movies; Jimmy (Jerrod Carmichael), Cade‰Ûªs jokey sidekick; and Izabella (Isabela Moner), the obligatory cute kid. The best touch, though, is Cogman (the voice of Jim Carter), Edmund‰Ûªs robotic butler, a sort of C-3PO with a temper (as a robot who aims a C-3PO joke at him finds out).

Autobots and Decepticons transform into motor vehicles and other things, a special-effects sight that apparently never grows old for fans of the series. And they have what seems like an ever-changing back story. The one conjured here involves Arthur, Lancelot, Merlin and the Dark Ages, which is where Mr. Hopkins‰Ûªs character, Edmund Burton, comes in.
Mark Wahlberg, who joined the franchise in the fourth film, the unwatchably long and convoluted ‰ÛÏTransformers: Age of Extinction,‰Ûù is back as the scruffy inventor Cade Yeager.

The movie cuts to a couple of young Chinese women on a pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela, depicting their adventures so far in a series of smartphone photos. They seem pretty normal. Lost in the woods, they come across a supine and unconscious Fernando. The two women revive him, feed him and later truss him up and suspend him from a tree while he‰Ûªs asleep. After Fernando awakes and manages to free himself, he spies on them outside of their tent. ‰ÛÏTomorrow, we‰Ûªll castrate him,‰Ûù one exclaims. These women are not so normal after all.
You do not have to be a Portuguese Catholic to appreciate ‰ÛÏThe Ornithologist,‰Ûù but I imagine that it really helps.

Fernando escapes, but other odd encounters await him. He finds the remains of his kayak, placed upright in the middle of what looks like a ritual circle. By night, he witnesses a group of costumed men whooping it up in what appears to be some kind of pagan frat ritual. By the time Fernando encounters a mute shepherd named Jesus, you may have figured out that ‰ÛÏThe Ornithologist‰Ûù is an allegory, or something like it. As it happens, it is an irrational, aspirational, surreal retelling of the story of St. Anthony.

Fernando, the title character, played by Paul Hamy, is camping out in this remote area of northern Portugal; with his binoculars at the ready, he is eager to get some work done. But a phone call with bad reception, in which a friend or relative reminds him to take his meds, vexes him a little. Soon, though, he has bigger troubles, as rapid water sends his kayak off course.

Mr. Rodrigues is an accomplished director whose best-known films in the United States ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏO Fantasma‰Ûù (2002) and ‰ÛÏTo Die Like a Man‰Ûù (2011) ‰ÛÓ were stylistically distinctive, relatively realistic treatments of queer themes. ‰ÛÏThe Ornithologist,‰Ûù while containing imagery that‰Ûªs influenced by Andrei Tarkovsky and Luis BuÌ±uel, is very much Mr. Rodrigues‰Ûªs own. His approach to this material occasionally brings homoerotic themes to the forefront, and is very 21st-century in its knowing detachment and occasional mischief. By the same token, though, there are times when he flirts with the ridiculous, and delves into it. Mr. Rodrigues ultimately delivers an intriguing, daring film that is likely to surprise both his fans and moviegoers unfamiliar with his work.

The movie, written and directed by JoÌ£o Pedro Rodrigues, begins with a quotation from St. Anthony about the warmth a person is apt to feel when he ‰ÛÏapproaches the Spirit‰Ûù openly. The initial images are of a marsh at dawn, populated by some exotic-looking and shy-seeming birds, and of a nest full of eggs.

Dr. Sarno, who specialized in rehabilitation medicine at New York University before retiring, has posited for decades that many types of chronic pain, particularly back pain, are caused by stress and repressed emotions. In such cases, he eschews drugs or surgeries. Instead, he counsels patients to consider the connection between their minds and their bodies, and that way decrease their discomfort through psychological understanding.

That thought is likely to enter your mind during ‰ÛÏAll the Rage,‰Ûù a documentary that has found itself one fascinating subject ‰ÛÓ Dr. John Sarno ‰ÛÓ yet too often pulls away from him to focus on the less compelling story of its director.

Nevertheless, ‰ÛÏAll the Rage‰Ûù overrides most of its shortcomings by keeping a breezy tone and by showing Dr. Sarno to be a convincing speaker, as well as an affable and somewhat crusty character. While this documentary leaves you wanting to know more about his beliefs, the introduction alone is valuable enough.

Michael Galinsky, one of the film‰Ûªs directors (with Suki Hawley and David Beilinson), sought Dr. Sarno‰Ûªs help for back pain. Recounting his own experiences for the documentary is an intriguing plan. But the scenes he chooses take up too much time ‰ÛÓ we meet Mr. Galinsky‰Ûªs cute children and hear of his complicated parents; we attend his brother‰Ûªs wedding ‰ÛÓ that could have been used to explore Dr. Sarno‰Ûªs views further, or to hear from some of the countless doctors who, it‰Ûªs said, dispute his claims and methods.
Director, distance thyself.

Such ideas, we‰Ûªre told, have caused Dr. Sarno, now in his 90s, to be shunned by the medical establishment. His theories and books, however, have been championed by the likes of Howard Stern and Larry David, who are interviewed here along with plenty of noncelebrities. Their testimonials come across as well informed and thoughtful.

Mr. Young, who also wrote the script, teases out the story in bits of coy hints and half-truths about a tragic accident, leaving too many questions unanswered. More than once, Brad mentions to others that he‰Ûªs a doctor but not why he‰Ûªs no longer practicing. The movie stumbles into the murky waters of colonization and racial politics when Brad, who is white, starts doing research on Jamaica, bringing up the island‰Ûªs history of slavery in between gorgeous pictures of beaches and photos of hunky black men.

Toying with issues of sexuality, trauma and race, John G. Young‰Ûªs romantic drama ‰ÛÏbwoy‰Ûù is another cautionary tale about meeting strangers online. Stuck in a bleak New York winter after the death of his son, a grieving man, Brad (Anthony Rapp), seeks solace by cruising a gay dating site. He falls into the virtual arms of Yenny (Jimmy Brooks), a charismatic young Jamaican, but their flirty and dirty texts and video calls soon morph into something devastating.

Brad is not yet out to his wife (De‰ÛªAdre Aziza). As the affair progresses, he struggles to control his temper around customers at work and looks pained every time his new love interest calls him ‰ÛÏDaddy.‰Ûù The film sets Brad up for a messy midlife crisis, and Mr. Young‰Ûªs hand-held camerawork brings little stability to the frame.

Although Mr. Rapp personifies Brad‰Ûªs repression, Mr. Brooks looks effervescent and playful during their video chats. He hides his intentions with excitable energy and a bright smile, which somehow feel less manipulative than the movie.

After rehearsals in Lititz, Pa., the players hit Barclays, where an audio glitch dampens Mr. Combs‰Ûªs entrance on a riser. On the film‰Ûªs soundtrack, Nina Simone‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏI Feel Good‰Ûù accompanies a glossy montage of stage footage, but the artists performing at the concert aren‰Ûªt heard until the closing credits, and only briefly. What ‰ÛÏCan‰Ûªt Stop‰Ûù mostly leaves you with is a sense of Mr. Combs‰Ûªs success.

Just try to keep up with the flurry of images in Daniel Kaufman‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCan‰Ûªt Stop Won‰Ûªt Stop,‰Ûù a whirl through the history of Sean Combs and Bad Boy, the entertainment company he founded and that often dominated hip-hop and R&B in the 1990s and 2000s. Mr. Combs, who topped Forbes‰Ûªs 2017 list of highest-paid celebrities, is a mogul in television, clothing, fragrances and spirits. ‰ÛÏCan‰Ûªt Stop‰Ûù sticks with the music, focusing on preparations for two Bad Boy reunion concerts in May 2016 at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

After glimpsing visitors and performers backstage ‰ÛÓ including Jay-Z, Faith Evans and Lil‰Ûª Kim ‰ÛÓ we learn of Mr. Combs‰Ûªs beginnings at Uptown Records, before his ascent with a string of platinum Bad Boy albums. Much time is devoted to Biggie Smalls and his 1997 killing in a drive-by shooting amid the coastal rap rivalry that also claimed Tupac Shakur. (‰ÛÏPuff was Big‰Ûªs big brother,‰Ûù Jay-Z says, invoking one of Mr. Combs‰Ûªs nicknames.) On camera, Clive Davis, Jimmy Iovine, Mary J. Blige and others testify to Mr. Combs‰Ûªs gifts. (Mr. Combs, of course, produced the film, with Heather Parry.)

The documentary acknowledges the gorilla in the garden: Monsanto, a leading exponent of modification, is ‰ÛÏone of the most-hated companies in the world.‰Ûù There are many reasons Monsanto raises hackles, Dr. Tyson acknowledges, but ‰ÛÏto be concerned about the safety of their G.M.O.s is to be misinformed.‰Ûù

Directed by Scott Hamilton Kennedy, ‰ÛÏFood Evolution‰Ûù hopes to demystify G.M.O.s and points to successes like Hawaiian papayas and Ugandan bananas, which were saved from devastating viruses. And while it gives opponents their say, the film rebuts their arguments, including reports that suggest G.M.O.s lead to a rise in farmers‰Ûª suicide rates and an increase in pesticide use. (The response to the first: correlation is not causation; to the second, yes, but those pesticides are far less toxic.)

With a soft tone, respectful to opponents but insistent on the data, ‰ÛÏFood Evolution‰Ûù posits an inconvenient truth for organic boosters to swallow: In a world desperate for safe, sustainable food, G.M.O.s may well be a force for good.

The food industry recruits scientists to speak on its behalf, but in press notes and email correspondence, the film‰Ûªs producers say no funding came from any Big Ag company or lobbying group. ‰ÛÏFood Evolution‰Ûù was commissioned by the nonprofit Institute of Food Technologists, and the filmmakers retained creative control.

The scientific method is under siege, and not just from naysayers who dismiss climate change or fear vaccines. G.M.O.s ‰ÛÓ genetically modified organisms ‰ÛÓ and the crops they enable have become another field of battle.

The film also speaks with food journalists (including Michael Pollan, a contributing writer to The New York Times Magazine) as well as farmers who have benefited from the technology. And if trust is an issue, Neil deGrasse Tyson, perhaps the most credible public scientist on the planet, is its narrator.

Shot over two years and in eight countries, the movie has a quirky lightness that prevents it from slipping into lecture. Its arguments range wide without going deep, but its factoids about the medical benefits of hanging out in a forest ‰ÛÓ and the cognitive costs of a noisy school or hospital ‰ÛÓ are fascinating and persuasive.

Gathering academics, audiologists and other experts who share his anticacophony view, Mr. Shen aims to show that excessive sound can negatively affect our bodies as well as our minds. His style is compare-and-contrast: rural versus urban, the natural world versus the electronic and synthetic. Tranquil scenes from an Iowa monastery and a national park give way jarringly to the metallic din in a subway station and the deafening clamor of a restaurant. A visit to Mumbai (believed to be the noisiest city in the world) will leave your ears ringing.

At times, the film‰Ûªs insistence on linking the silent to the sacred can border on preachy. But then we check in with Greg Hindy, a stoic searcher who stopped talking for a year while he walked across the United States. As he tromps over the Golden Gate Bridge with his little cart, holding handwritten signs up to the camera, he‰Ûªs not looking for God ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs just seeking the space to think.

‰ÛÏIn Pursuit of Silence‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt what you would call a well-rounded or intellectually rigorous documentary ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs too messianic for that ‰ÛÓ but it is an interesting one. Partly inspired by George Prochnik‰Ûªs 2010 book of the same title, this elegant sermon by Patrick Shen on why we should dial down the racket of our daily lives will make you consider turning off and tuning out.

Working with a team of co-directors ‰ÛÓ Lynn True, Nelson Walker, Ben Wu and David Usui ‰ÛÓ Mr. Maysles, who died at 88 a month before this movie‰Ûªs premiere at the 2015 Tribeca Film Festival, shot three round trips on Amtrak‰Ûªs Empire Builder route, which connects Chicago with Portland, Ore., and Seattle. (It splits into two segments west of Spokane, Wash.)

‰ÛÏIn Transit‰Ûù has been edited ‰ÛÓ by Ms. True ‰ÛÓ to privilege narrative over chronology. At any moment, the movie is liable to turn up at a different spot along the route, a sort of productive disorientation that contributes to a feeling of universality. Anyone who thinks the movie was easy to make should try getting watchable footage out of a train window. (A separate drive-along trip was necessary for the picturesque exterior shots.)

While observing roughhousing children, dining car meals, card games and a jam session, the movie makes room for perceptive observations on class, race and upbringing. At times, ‰ÛÏIn Transit‰Ûù seems utopian in its optimism that all it takes to get two people talking is to put them in adjacent seats. Here‰Ûªs a summer movie that is about ‰ÛÓ and offers ‰ÛÓ escape.

Some passengers have settled in for the long haul. Others, like the woman returning to Montana to reconcile with her family, or the expectant mother eager to reach Minnesota before she goes into labor ‰ÛÓ a prospect that alarms several conductors ‰ÛÓ are on board for only part of the way.

Other passengers seek to forget romance or to clear their heads. The mix is roughly even between those settling unfinished business and those, like the young man from Mississippi who left his job overnight, who have hopped aboard on impulse.

‰ÛÏIn Transit‰Ûù depicts cross-country train travel as a rare refuge of American idealism ‰ÛÓ the quintessence of the go-west spirit, even for passengers heading east. At 76 minutes, the movie may seem modest, but there are shades of Jack Kerouac and Studs Terkel in its chronicler‰Ûªs ambitions, and echoes of John Ford in its portrayal of how Americans form communities.

Yet ‰ÛÏIn Transit‰Ûù illustrates how their journeys mirror one another, and not just geographically. A 21-year-old heads to North Dakota, convinced that seven years of oil-boom work will earn him money for life. Another man, having already toiled there, heads in the opposite direction, to Indiana and the woman he loves, to settle down, something he thought he‰Ûªd never do. He worries about finding a job there.

Traveling between Chicago and the Pacific Northwest by train may not save you money, and it certainly won‰Ûªt save you time. But ‰ÛÏIn Transit,‰Ûù the last film from the great documentarian Albert Maysles (‰ÛÏSalesman,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏGrey Gardens‰Ûù), a founding figure of the direct cinema movement, suggests that we‰Ûªve lost something in an era of easy flying and road trips.

Bertrand Tavernier‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMy Journey Through French Cinema‰Ûù delivers what it promises. Even so, its explanatory title doesn‰Ûªt begin to convey just how exhilarating or inspiring a documentary this truly is, and how excellent a trip this well-respected French director takes you on. Deep, thoughtful, immersive, specific yet also wide-reaching, it is an exploration of French cinema by one of its own, a cinephile whose formative movie love evolved into a directing career that includes titles like ‰ÛÏCoup de Torchon,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏLife and Nothing But‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏCaptain Conan.‰Ûù

Mr. Tavernier‰Ûªs acknowledgment of his own precocity is amusingly self-aware and inviting; it quickly humanizes the documentary and suggests that, while Mr. Tavernier speaks with authority, this is also a highly personal enterprise. It is, after all, his journey, one that has its own routes, ports of call and charming idiosyncrasies. And while the movie more or less flows chronologically ‰ÛÓ he is born, he sees films, becomes a man, sees more movies, becomes a director ‰ÛÓ it isn‰Ûªt slavishly linear. Mr. Tavernier also likes to circle back to earlier periods, including ones he‰Ûªs passed over or through, returns that make for surprises and that reflect a profound, insistent sense of history.

Mr. Tavernier turned movie love into criticism but, like all good critics, he never fell out of love. It‰Ûªs delightful to share in that passion and a pleasure too that he‰Ûªs more interested in ideas and emotions than stories and plots. If you don‰Ûªt know the films he talks about, you may not grasp what they‰Ûªre about; it doesn‰Ûªt matter. He also doesn‰Ûªt identify everyone onscreen, mostly, I think, because he really wants you to watch and listen and, anyway, you can read their names in the credits. I suggest you sit through them with paper and pen so you can write down the title of every movie you‰Ûªve already seen (you‰Ûªll want to watch them again) and every title you‰Ûªve never heard of (because worlds await).

It begins once upon a time in Lyon, France, where Mr. Tavernier was born in 1941. He was born again, in a sense, when he saw ‰ÛÏDernier Atout.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThat‰Ûªs where a movie made its first real impact on me,‰Ûù he says over gleaming black-and-white images from a chase scene with fedored gangsters, motorcycle cops and lots of atmosphere. Mr. Tavernier could visualize that chase for years but it wasn‰Ûªt until a quarter-century later that ‰ÛÓ voilÌÊ! ‰ÛÓ he identified it as coming from a 1942 crime film directed by Jacques Becker. ‰ÛÏAt age 6,‰Ûù Mr. Tavernier says with a smile, ‰ÛÏI could‰Ûªve made a worse choice.‰Ûù

Although he pops up onscreen, Mr. Tavernier mostly guides you with his voice, which tethers you to his essayistic discussions. The movie is divided into sections that are punctuated by a fade to black and are, largely if not exclusively, centered on directors. Some are fairly straightforward; at other times, Mr. Tavernier pleasurably meanders as when, after a mention of boarding school, he moves onto topics like FranÌ_ois Truffaut and ‰ÛÏShoot the Piano Player‰Ûù (‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs the only film I saw booed on the Champs-ÌälysÌ©es‰Ûù); Henri Langlois, a founder of the CinÌ©mathÌ¬que FranÌ_aise; AndrÌ© Malraux‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏL‰ÛªEspoir‰Ûù; other critics (‰ÛÏwe wanted to decide for ourselves‰Ûù); and the director Edmond T. GrÌ©ville.

In ‰ÛÏMy Journey Through French Cinema,‰Ûù history is a thread that Mr. Tavernier uses to pull together different movies and makers, creating arguments ‰ÛÓ about art and life, time and space ‰ÛÓ that become autobiography. When Mr. Tavernier announces that Becker was ‰ÛÏone of the French directors who best understood and mastered American filmmaking,‰Ûù you hear admiration in his voice. And when he adds that Becker‰Ûªs passion for American cinema is evident in all his movies and lingers on that director‰Ûªs love of jazz, you may also flash on Mr. Tavernier‰Ûªs own jazz movie, ‰ÛÏ‰ÛªRound Midnight.‰Ûù (Mr. Tavernier also helped write an encyclopedic book titled ‰ÛÏ50 Years of American Cinema.‰Ûù)

Mr. Tavernier‰Ûªs descriptions oscillate between the precise and the sweeping, and every so often he floats on private currents of thought. Usually, you see what he says ‰ÛÓ words fit the images ‰ÛÓ but not always. I loved the sound of ‰ÛÏthe mise-en-scÌ¬ne flexes emotion like you flex your muscles,‰Ûù for instance, but didn‰Ûªt truly know what that was supposed to mean. He drops this line while discussing Becker‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCasque d‰ÛªOr‰Ûù over a scene in which a man (Serge Reggiani) looks yearningly at a dancing woman (Simone Signoret). Still, if you keep watching and listening (always a good idea), you too see the emotions ‰ÛÓ perhaps not flexing, but rippling ‰ÛÓ as she whirls, eyes fixed on the man not in her arms.

The first is that whatever you think of Gawker‰Ûªs decision to publish an excerpt from a sex tape featuring Mr. Hogan, a professional wrestler whose real name is Terry G. Bollea, the case had potentially far-ranging implications for the news media‰Ûªs ability to cover public figures. The $140 million judgment against Gawker, which filed for bankruptcy and was later sold to Univision ‰ÛÓ the suit was ultimately settled with Mr. Hogan for $31 million ‰ÛÓ sets a precedent that the movie argues could snuff out significant reporting. (Not all legal experts are so sure.)
The third, hardly a surprise, is that the presidency of Mr. Trump, who makes a regular target of reporters, represents a threat to news organizations interested in pursuing the truth.
In that sense, perhaps the hacky presentation is strategic ‰ÛÓ a way of incentivizing viewers to click off Netflix and read the news instead.

Brian Knappenberger‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏNobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press,‰Ûù which is being released simultaneously in theaters and on Netflix, draws a through-line from Hulk Hogan‰Ûªs privacy lawsuit against Gawker Media to the journalistic challenges posed by the presidency of Donald J. Trump, with three overarching points to make.

The second is that the lawsuit itself, subsequently revealed to have been bankrolled by Peter Thiel, the PayPal founder and Silicon Valley billionaire, represented a disturbing instance of a powerful figure secretly using wealth to stifle a voice he regarded as adversarial. The movie suggests that while moguls meddling in the news is at least as old as William Randolph Hearst, hidden puppeteering of this sort is new. About an hour in, the movie clumsily shifts focus, introducing former staff members of The Las Vegas Review-Journal who recount Sheldon Adelson‰Ûªs secretive acquisition of that paper, a publication that could theoretically serve as a check on Mr. Adelson‰Ûªs dealings.

But just because ‰ÛÏNobody Speak‰Ûù has a timely message doesn‰Ûªt make it an ideal messenger. Mr. Knappenberger seems to have created this impassioned defense of news organizations for moviegoers who don‰Ûªt keep up with the news. Almost nothing in ‰ÛÏNobody Speak‰Ûù breaks new ground. As if afraid of boring anybody, Mr. Knappenberger lays on a percussive synthesizer score so insistent and manipulative that it‰Ûªs like watching the movie with electrodes attached.

If freedom of the press includes the right to print all-caps headlines with exclamation points, it also includes the right to make a cinematic exposÌ© so bombastic that it poorly serves its own cause, however important.

The featured interviewees include the parties involved, mostly with the Gawker side (the site‰Ûªs founder, Nick Denton, and Albert J. Daulerio, who wrote the post that accompanied the Hogan video, are heard from). Among the outside experts are the First Amendment lawyer Floyd Abrams, who defended The New York Times in the Pentagon Papers case, and Margaret Sullivan, the Times‰Ûªs former public editor (now with The Washington Post). They frame the issues in reasonable sound bites, though Ms. Sullivan in particular has addressed the Gawker matter in more depth elsewhere.
‰ÛÏEverything is expensive in this country,‰Ûù goes a lively song that plays at a wedding, ‰ÛÏbut sadness you can get for free.‰Ûù And the men dance.

‰ÛÏHave you been injured before?‰Ûù he asks a patient, who answers no. ‰ÛÏThen you are not from Iraq,‰Ûù he says, smiling. Moments like this are few, though, as he documents the rising tide of danger and displacement that follows the 2011 withdrawal of coalition forces and the eventual arrival of the Islamic State. Throughout, his director (who was born and raised in Iraq and has been observing families in the region for years) maintains a determinedly hands-off approach. This allows Mr. Sharif‰Ûªs bewilderment over what he calls ‰ÛÏan undiagnosed war‰Ûù to become the story, one that speaks specifically to the profoundly destabilizing nature of lengthy conflict.
It also permits us to honor those whose spirits appear indestructible.
The look is rough, the emotions always hovering near the surface. Yet, buoyed by Mr. Sharif‰Ûªs cheery personality, these can sometimes be defiantly upbeat.

Maybe the most disturbing aspect of watching ‰ÛÏNowhere to Hide,‰Ûù Zaradasht Ahmed‰Ûªs sickeningly gripping portrait of a male nurse in Iraq, is accepting how close we are to the point where empathy itself has become collateral damage.

Detachment may be our survival mechanism, but for Nori Sharif, a young father of four and a dedicated medic in an emergency hospital not far from Baghdad, it‰Ûªs a luxury he can‰Ûªt afford. And when he‰Ûªs handed a small video camera by his director and asked to film his life, the resulting diary of perseverance and suffering has a raw immediacy that‰Ûªs both appropriate and involving.
‰ÛÏYou say I‰Ûªm an amazing lawyer,‰Ûù she tells him. ‰ÛÏWhat does that matter, if I can‰Ûªt change anyone‰Ûªs life?‰Ûù

Upon arriving in the poverty-stricken town she is confronted with unfriendly students and soon, much, much worse: One night she is beaten and raped. She believes that some of her pupils were involved, and the resulting suspicion and tension escalates: Her father arrives, seeking revenge, while Paulina fights to regain her bearings.

This parable-like tale opens in mid-argument, as the determined title character (Dolores Fonzi) is informing her somewhat cynical father (Oscar MartÌ_nez) of her plan to leave her comfortable home in Argentina to teach in a rural village.

It‰Ûªs frequently tough to decide if Paulina is misguided or admirable. Yet even if you disagree with the character‰Ûªs choices, you can feel her belief in them, and respect her resolve. Indeed, few satisfying answers arise here. But there‰Ûªs bravery in asking the questions, and this film knows something about courage.

As stinging as a slap in the face, ‰ÛÏPaulina‰Ûù feels as if it‰Ûªs waking you from a stupor, then shaking you, demanding that you ask yourself some impossible questions about idealism and justice. It‰Ûªs a severe story, made more so by its powerhouse lead actress.

Santiago Mitre, the director and one of the screenwriters (the film is based on a 1960 movie, ‰ÛÏLa Patota‰Ûù), trains his camera on tight shots of Ms. Fonzi then stays out of her way. Though a few conversations mark her mind-set, there is no speechifying or grandstanding. Ms. Fonzi‰Ûªs presence, arresting and often silent, speaks volumes.

All of which is to say that ‰ÛÏThe Bad Batch,‰Ûù a messy, sunbaked pop-culture cobbler written and directed by Ana Lily Amirpour, is both a bummer and a blast. It conjures a bare-bones, moderately plausible near future in which criminals and other undesirables are subjected to a modern variant of the ancient practice of ostracism. After being tattooed behind the ear, members of the Bad Batch are abandoned on the far side of a border fence ‰ÛÓ we don‰Ûªt know who paid for it ‰ÛÓ with a jug of water and a fast-food hamburger.

On the other side of an expanse of sandy flats, not too far from where the cannibals congregate, is a place called Comfort. A muttering wanderer (an unrecognizable Jim Carrey) deposits Arlen outside its gates. The residents of this relatively benign zone are kept safe by armed guards and ramparts made of shipping containers and kept happy with hallucinogens and dance music. The D.J. is played by Diego Luna. The patriarch of Comfort ‰ÛÓ church, state and pharmaceutical industry all at once ‰ÛÓ is a philosophical fellow with a droopy mustache and a retinue of pregnant concubines. He is played by Keanu Reeves.

But Arlen and the audience quickly learn that there are degrees of badness in this universe. The desert castaways have organized themselves into makeshift societies, two of which figure prominently in Arlen‰Ûªs subsequent adventures. First she encounters an encampment of bodybuilders who practice cannibalism and aggressive tanning amid broken-down trailers and airplane detritus. Arlen is kidnapped, drugged, chained up and invited to dinner, one limb at a time.

The opening sequence accompanies a young woman named Arlen (Suki Waterhouse) through this process. Her possessions include a couple of pairs of skimpy shorts, some voluntary skin ink and a sullen attitude. She wears the Bad Batch designation as a badge of honor.

‰ÛÏThe Bad Batch‰Ûù traffics in images and situations that evoke what used to be called exploitation movies, reveling in its own (and its heroine‰Ûªs) anarchic, transgressive energy. As such, it‰Ûªs good, dirty fun. But it also takes exploitation ‰ÛÓ of bodies, of feeling, of labor ‰ÛÓ seriously. You may wonder what the heck you‰Ûªre looking at, but that‰Ûªs kind of the point.

‰ÛÏY‰Ûªall are pure evil‰Ûù she will say when the time for revenge arrives, and while it‰Ûªs hard to argue ‰ÛÓ the knowledge has literally cost her an arm and a leg ‰ÛÓ nothing is quite as simple as that. One of the people-eaters is a cute little girl named Honey (Jayda Fink) with a nonpredatory fondness for bunnies. She and her dad (Jason Momoa) ‰ÛÓ a taciturn, muscular dude identified as Miami Man by the letters inked on his chest ‰ÛÓ become part of Arlen‰Ûªs initially feckless, increasingly determined existence. They serve as reminders of her own inconvenient humanity.

Ms. Amirpour‰Ûªs 2014 debut feature, the Persian-language feminist vampire melodrama ‰ÛÏA Girl Walks Home Alone at Night,‰Ûù has already acquired a cult following. Like that film, which had traces of Jim Jarmusch, David Lynch and Aki Kaurismaki in its DNA, ‰ÛÏThe Bad Batch‰Ûù is not shy about showing its influences, which appear to include ‰ÛÏMad Max,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏKill Bill‰Ûù and the lean, mean ‰Ûª50s oaters of Budd Boetticher.

But Ms. Amirpour‰Ûªs films are more than a sampling of her DVD collection; her engagement with familiar themes and classic tropes is as critical as it is admiring. ‰ÛÏThe Bad Batch,‰Ûù a tale of vengeance, violence, power and redemption built on the ethical foundations of the traditional western, scrambles and satisfies expectations at the same time. Arlen walks a well-trodden path from outlaw self-preservation to righteousness, with interludes of lust, confusion and drug-enhanced stargazing. She veers toward some stereotypes and refutes others, keeping herself and the viewer in a state of perpetual unbalance.

Future historians ‰ÛÓ assuming that any such creatures exist ‰ÛÓ will surely identify the present moment as a golden age of dystopia. They may argue about whether our ever-proliferating political, ecological, technological and zombie-infested nightmares offer caution or consolation. Think about how bad things could get! But then again: Look how much worse they could be. Reality, meanwhile, inspires these dire visions and competes with them for sheer relentless awfulness.

That fact alone might be reason enough to brace yourself for episodes of shocking violence and spend some time in Ms. Amirpour‰Ûªs world. Mr. Reeves in middle age is never not interesting, and he invests this role with the perfect alloy of gravity and goofiness. Happily, ‰ÛÏThe Bad Batch‰Ûù is much more than a sacrament for devotees of the Higher Keanuism. It is a fluent and knowing pastiche of genres and styles with a brazen and vigorous wit of its own.

I have called the film a fairy tale but you could also describe it as a horror movie, a quasi-western and a revenge melodrama, perhaps too many things at once. Most effectively, though ‰ÛÓ and largely thanks to Ms. Kidman‰Ûªs regal, witty performance ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs a comedy, a country-house farce about the problems caused by an inconvenient guest.

‰ÛÏNous sommes des filles‰Ûù the girls recite during their lessons, and ‰ÛÏThe Beguiled,‰Ûù which remakes and revises Don Siegel‰Ûªs 1971 film (with Clint Eastwood in Mr. Farrell‰Ûªs role), is in part an essay on the nuances and paradoxes of femininity. It‰Ûªs also the portrait of a group of ladies sorted by type and temperament. Miss Amy is sharp-witted and intellectually curious. Miss Jane (Angourie Rice), the princess of the group, is imperious and judgmental. Miss Emily (Emma Howard) is openhearted and obliging. Miss Alicia (Elle Fanning) is sullen and sneaky. Miss Edwina (Kirsten Dunst) applies herself to her duties with an air of disappointment. They find themselves competing for McBurney‰Ûªs favor as he sets about manipulating their vanities and insecurities, smiling like a tomcat who has stumbled into a cage full of canaries.

I say ‰ÛÏmay not‰Ûù because her intentions are somewhat opaque. This ‰ÛÏBeguiled‰Ûù (based, like the Siegel-Eastwood version, on Thomas Cullinan‰Ûªs novel) is a study in moods and implications, picking up difficult, volatile themes and then carefully putting them down again. The earlier film is a bracingly pulpy product of its moment, a time when American movies were breaking free of repressive codes and reveling ‰ÛÓ sometimes wallowing ‰ÛÓ in sexual display and rough violence. It‰Ûªs smutty and disturbing and feverish, rooting around in the muck of the unconscious and the mess of the American past and digging up all kinds of disturbing stuff.

That is only one of the questions that hover in the humid, crepuscular air. The soldier, Cpl. John McBurney by name, finds himself convalescing in a plantation house, formerly a girls‰Ûª boarding school, occupied by his rescuer, Miss Amy (Oona Laurence) and her teachers and classmates. The matriarch of the group ‰ÛÓ there are six of them in all ‰ÛÓ is Miss Martha (Nicole Kidman), who occupies an intriguing middle ground between fairy godmother and wicked stepmother, a zone that is familiar real estate for Ms. Kidman.

‰ÛÏThe Beguiled,‰Ûù Sofia Coppola‰Ûªs new film, looks like a historical drama ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs set in Virginia during the Civil War ‰ÛÓ but it often behaves more like a fairy tale. In the first scenes, a young girl ventures out into the woods to collect mushrooms and finds a strange man under a tree: a Union soldier with a badly wounded leg and a charming Irish brogue. Is he a prince or an ogre? (He‰Ûªs Colin Farrell, which may or may not clarify the issue.)

For this reason, ‰ÛÏThe Beguiled‰Ûù has generated some controversy, in particular for omitting all but the most cursory mention of slavery. While this doesn‰Ûªt strike me as an unfair criticism ‰ÛÓ as Corey Atad points out in Slate, an onscreen note explaining that ‰ÛÏthe slaves left‰Ûù carries understatement to the point of historical irresponsibility ‰ÛÓ it also risks applying a standard that may not be entirely relevant to Ms. Coppola‰Ûªs concerns.

Like many of the characters in Ms. Coppola‰Ûªs other films, Miss Martha and her charges dwell in a realm apart from the ordinary world, a gilded bubble that is both cocoon and prison. Some of this is a matter of circumstance. Versailles in ‰ÛÏMarie Antoinette,‰Ûù the Chateau Marmont hotel in ‰ÛÏSomewhere,‰Ûù the Tokyo Hyatt in ‰ÛÏLost in Translation‰Ûù and suburbia in ‰ÛÏThe Virgin Suicides‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Bling Ring‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ all of these are environments designed to quarantine their privileged residents from the disorder and misery of life.

Is McBurney a prisoner or a guest? Is he a threat to his hosts or is it the other way around? Who is beguiling whom? Ms. Coppola approaches these matters with her signature mix of intensity and detachment. Decorum is observed ‰ÛÓ grace is said before meals; corsets are tightened; French verbs are conjugated; everyone is called ‰ÛÏmiss‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ but under the surface all kinds of strong emotions seethe and simmer. Even at midday the place has a gloomy, twilight quality. (The cinematographer is Philippe Le Sourd.) Mist and cannon smoke from a distant battlefield hang amid the Spanish moss. The atmosphere is too genteel to be gothic, but it is haunted nonetheless, by intimations of disorder, lust and violence.

None of that applies to Ms. Coppola‰Ûªs film, which is less interested in battling repression than in observing its mechanisms and arguing, quietly and unmistakably, for its virtues. Her ‰ÛÏBeguiled‰Ûù is less a hothouse flower than a bonsai garden, a work of cool, exquisite artifice that evokes wildness on a small, controlled scale.

But Ms. Coppola also chooses to emphasize this removal, to narrow the perspective of her films by turning her gaze away from certain complications. In the case of ‰ÛÏThe Beguiled‰Ûù this means that the war and its causes are banished to the margins. Occasionally a Confederate officer will show up at the gate, and the military situation sometimes arises in conversation, but the conflict is more a premise than a subject. It could be a natural disaster or a zombie-movie epidemic ‰ÛÓ a background event that provides atmosphere and structure rather than meaning.

Ms. Kazan‰Ûªs work here is pivotal, especially given that she needs to make a lasting, expressive impact with Emily before the character disappears, and the narrative center of gravity shifts squarely to Kumail. In other words, you need to fall for Emily as much as Kumail does while she pokes and prods him, encouraging him to come out and play. When he‰Ûªs offstage, Kumail can seem as if he were waiting for something to happen, and when her parents arrive in Chicago, he recedes, turtle-like, creating a recessiveness that makes some of his deadpan discomfort even squirmier. Mostly, Mr. Nanjiani and Ms. Kazan look and sound ‰ÛÓ and, importantly, feel ‰ÛÓ like people, like people you know and might fall for.

In his stand-up, Mr. Nanjiani tells longish, confessional tales about, say, his attempts to be cool in school or watching a pornographic videotape in his parents‰Ûª home in Pakistan when the power went out. He can‰Ûªt get the tape out of the VCR, so he decides he has to ‰ÛÏpack my bags and walk the earth, which sucks because I love my parents and I‰Ûªm 12 years old.‰Ûù Taken out of context, of course, any given sentence in this kind of circuitous, long-form amble doesn‰Ûªt sound especially funny. But Mr. Nanjiani builds the bit artfully, aided by a stealthy persona that comes across as perfectly ordinary until he deploys a puckish smile, revs up his adenoidal whine and gets his heavy eyebrows dancing.

The movie‰Ûªs title is a giveaway: Emily‰Ûªs sickness is big, as well as terrifying and confounding, and it lands her in an intensive care unit, hooked to life support. Before long, she is in an induced coma; Kumail‰Ûªs doe eyes are watering; and you‰Ûªre wondering, wait, isn‰Ûªt this supposed to be a comedy? It is, and through sickness and nearly death, it remains a very funny one, too, producing a wide range of laughs, from staccato titters to abrupt guffaws and huge, body-shaking bursts. The ratio of jokes to screen time is satisfyingly high, and there are few stretches that aren‰Ûªt enlivened by humor that, joke by joke, with silliness and caustic asides, also deepens the movie.

I fell hard for both Ms. Kazan and Mr. Nanjiani and ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick,‰Ûù which tells a great story with waves of deep feeling and questions of identity and makes the whole thing feel like a breeze. Comedy is said to be hard; mostly, I think, by comics. Romantic comedy is apparently even tougher, at least from recent onscreen evidence. Few filmmakers know how to fit contemporary men and women, straight or gay, into narrative forms that were developed once upon a time. In ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick,‰Ûù Mr. Nanjiani and Ms. Gordon vault over that hurdle with openness and delight, revitalizing an often moribund subgenre with a true story of love, death and the everyday comedy of being a 21st-century American.

Love means having to say you‰Ûªre sorry ‰ÛÓ early and often. That‰Ûªs one of the truisms in ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick,‰Ûù a joyous, generous-hearted romantic comedy that, even as it veers into difficult terrain, insists that we just need to keep on laughing. Outwardly, the story seems familiar: A really nice guy falls for a woman he may not be worthy of and nearly blows it. What gives the movie both fizz and sting ‰ÛÓ and shows that there‰Ûªs plenty of juice and possibility left in the American romantic comedy ‰ÛÓ are its particulars, especially the comic Kumail Nanjiani, who plays a fictionalized version of himself, a Pakistani-American struggling to make it in stand-up while fumbling through the rest of his life.

Mr. Nanjiani (who shares his name with his character) plays a 30-ish guy navigating these two seemingly irreconcilable worlds and identities. A fledgling Chicago stand-up, Kumail is a regular at a club where, alongside his comrades ‰ÛÓ played by the real-life funny people Bo Burnham, Aidy Bryant and Kurt Braunohler ‰ÛÓ he routinely tries to make a roomful of people laugh. One evening, he teasingly mixes it up with a customer, Emily (a wonderful Zoe Kazan), a jittery charmer with a mile-wide smile whom he soon makes moves on. Flirtation leads to one and then another night together, and before long, they‰Ûªre frolicking in one of those time-is-passing montages.

As he does in his stand-up, Mr. Nanjiani, who immigrated to the United States when he was a teenager, mines the comedy of cultural difference in ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick‰Ûù with a light, sharp touch. In another, earlier bit, he talks about a roller-coaster ride, which he calls the scariest experience of his life, adding, ‰ÛÏand I grew up in Pakistan.‰Ûù In the movie, he drops a few terrorist-themed jokes so lightly that you‰Ûªre caught off guard as much by his casual delivery as by the actual gags. You sense that he‰Ûªs probably heard every ugly joke about Muslims imaginable, and so he‰Ûªs learned how to get there first, staking a claim on a contested subject, finding humor and strength in other people‰Ûªs stupidity.

In some ways, ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick‰Ûù plays like an extended version of one of Mr. Nanjiani‰Ûªs anecdotal tales, though one streaked in tears and featuring a cast that includes the perfectly paired Holly Hunter and Ray Romano as Emily‰Ûªs parents. Mr. Showalter, whose movies include ‰ÛÏHello, My Name Is Doris,‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt much of a visual stylist ‰ÛÓ the look of this movie is basically functional plus ‰ÛÓ but he‰Ûªs terrific with actors and understands that even minor characters should be people, not background. In ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick,‰Ûù you vividly see the person in each role, from nurse (Myra Lucretia Taylor) to would-be bride (Kuhoo Verma), which enriches the emotional texture and underlines that there‰Ûªs something at stake.

The real Emily is Emily V. Gordon, who‰Ûªs married to Mr. Nanjiani. They wrote ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick‰Ûù together ‰ÛÓ it was directed by Michael Showalter ‰ÛÓ creating comedy and drama from their lives. The story tracks the giddy start of their relationship, with its dazed smiles and intimacy, a romance that seems to collapse when she discovers that he hasn‰Ûªt told his family about her. Kumail‰Ûªs parents (Anupam Kher and Zenobia Shroff, both great), who live within dining distance, are trying to find him a wife and have been parading appealing prospects before him. He wants to please his folks, but he‰Ûªs falling for Emily. He can‰Ûªt decide what to do, so she breaks it off, but then falls gravely ill.

In the main, it‰Ûªs easy to go with Mr. Wright‰Ûªs flow, partly because he rarely steps off the gas. It‰Ûªs just go go go with an occasional stop for coffee or an amusingly testy sit-down with Baby‰Ûªs shadowy boss, Doc, one of those all-seeing, all-knowing criminal mystics whom Kevin Spacey gives ominous ooze and a daddy‰Ûªs mad (maybe nuts) indoor voice. Doc has something on Baby, who‰Ûªs been forced into a life of bad behavior and company. That Baby has had no choice but to drive along plays as knowingly implausible as it sounds. But heroic fatalism and unwilling villainy remain enduring cinematic tropes, including in gangster movies, even if it means holding convention over complexity.

This is how Baby rolls, with shifting gears, pumping feet and thumping tunes, and how Mr. Wright rolls here as well. There‰Ûªs a story, sure, about Baby getting in and out of trouble while finding love and money. He doesn‰Ûªt have much of an inner life, but he has skills, a heavy back story and a kindly foster father, Joe (CJ Jones, who helps give the movie its faint heartbeat), a deaf invalid with whom he signs. Baby also has tinnitus, which he quells with music; mostly, he has killer timing and gracefully elastic, reactive physicality that suggests Mr. Wright has put in time with the films of Jacques Tati.

In ‰ÛÏBaby Driver,‰Ûù the director Edgar Wright is out to show you a most excellent time. He‰Ûªs never been one of those filmmakers who expect you to be blinded by the bright sheen of his rÌ©sumÌ©, which includes comical genre rethinks like the zombie flick ‰ÛÏShaun of the Dead‰Ûù and the cop caper ‰ÛÏHot Fuzz.‰Ûù Mr. Wright works for your love, hard enough that you notice the whirring machinery if perhaps not the strain. He wants it easy and breezy, although mostly he wants it cool, whether the latest means to his end, Baby (Ansel Elgort), is smooth-moving like Gene Kelly or burning rubber like Steve McQueen.

That‰Ûªs wonderful company to keep and to learn from, especially when you‰Ûªre as cleverly attentive a student as Mr. Wright. Baby drives hard, fast, tight and seemingly oh so effortlessly, spinning wheels across pavement like a Russian Olympian on ice. In the eye-tickling opener ‰ÛÓ a wham, bam, we‰Ûªll-take-the-cash-ma‰Ûªam heist ‰ÛÓ Baby peels out in that red box (a souped-up Subaru) and motors into one of those warped Road Runner chases that builds momentum with near escapes, not-even-close winking and the twangy throbbing of ‰ÛÏBellbottoms,‰Ûù from the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, a group once unforgettably described by the critic Robert Christgau as ‰ÛÏavant-travestying da blooze.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏBaby Driver‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt avant-travestying; it‰Ûªs a pop pastiche par excellence, crammed with cubistic action; glowering and golly-gee types (played by the seductive likes of Jamie Foxx, Jon Hamm, Eiza GonzÌÁlez and Lily James); and an encyclopedia of cinematic allusions, all basted in wall-to-wall tuneage. At times, the whole thing spins like a tribute album, a collection of covers of varying quality: diner yaks ÌÊ la Quentin Tarantino, Godardian splashes of color. When it works, the allusions give you a contact high, like when a friend turns you on to a favorite movie. At other times, Mr. Wright‰Ûªs pleasure veers into the self-satisfied, and all that love feels smothering, near-bullying, like bro-cinephilia in extremis.

A genre ride with a rebuilt engine and a sweet paint job, ‰ÛÏBaby Driver‰Ûù is all about movement and sometimes stillness and how a beautiful man looks (feels, seems, is) even better when he‰Ûªs in glorious, syncopated, restless motion. The first time you see Baby ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs his handle, which suits Mr. Elgort, with his angelic face and young man‰Ûªs lissomeness ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs in the driver‰Ûªs seat, where he belongs. The car doesn‰Ûªt look like much, just a cherry-red box with doors and a spoiler. Like us, Baby is waiting for the action to start, seemingly sealed off from the outside world with his dark sunglasses and earbuds.

There‰Ûªs much to enjoy in ‰ÛÏBaby Driver,‰Ûù including the satisfactions of genuine cinematic craft and technique, qualities that moviegoers can no longer take for granted. The edits snap, the colors pop and the cinematography serves the performances and the story rather than embalming them in an emptily showy, self-regarding directorial conceit. The emotions are mostly rote and cold, but the car chases are hot ‰ÛÓ at once fluid, geometric and rhythmic, with a beat Baby carries with him out of the car whether he‰Ûªs on the stroll or the run. (The director of photography is Bill Pope; the editors are Paul Machliss and Jonathan Amos; and the stunt coordinator is Darrin Prescott, leading an army.)

‰ÛÏBaby Driver‰Ûù is so good that you want it to be better and go deeper, for it to put down its guns (or at least hold them differently) and transcend its clichÌ©s and cine-quotes so it can rocket out of the genre safe box into the cosmic beyond where craft and technique transform into art. That‰Ûªs admittedly somewhat of a greedy complaint, particularly given how much Mr. Wright does right and that he clearly wants you levitating out of your seat. It‰Ûªs difficult to carp about a director who wants to please the audience this much (instead of, say, the franchise suits). At the same time, you have to wonder where Mr. Wright might go if he cut loose from his influences and let a little feeling muss up his form.

The bond between Okja and Mija, who is an orphan, is the result of a contract neither one of them has read or signed. The pig is the physical and intellectual property of a multinational corporation, and as such she‰Ûªs destined not only for the usual slaughter but also for crass and cynical commercial exploitation. The girl, a serious and stubborn child (played with heroic dignity by An Seo Hyun), is fated to lose her only friend.

Okja is a most remarkable pig. As big as a medium-sized elephant, with a snout that looks more canine than porcine, she is slobbery and sometimes flatulent, but also loyal, gentle and brave. Okja is devoted, above all, to a girl named Mija. They have grown up together on a remote mountain farm that belongs to Mija‰Ûªs grandfather, inseparable companions in a classic literary and cinematic tradition.

The vet‰Ûªs arrival on Mija‰Ûªs granddad‰Ûªs farm, accompanied by Mirando suits and flacks (notably Yoon Jae moon and Shirley Henderson), signals the end of the film‰Ûªs pastoral interlude, a forest romp as lyrical and magical as anything by the great Japanese animator Hayao Miyazaki. Mr. Bong has an eye for natural beauty, and also a kinetic and rigorous sense of motion. Once it leaves the countryside, ‰ÛÏOkja‰Ûù turns into a swift urban caper, full of chases and other action-movie set pieces. Mija sets out to liberate her beloved pig, and is joined (and also partly thwarted) by members of the Animal Liberation Front, an earnest, not-always-competent militant group led by Paul Dano.

A conventional name for that something would be humanity, since ‰ÛÏOkja,‰Ûù not unlike ‰ÛÏE. T.,‰Ûù is about how a young person achieves moral insight by connecting with and fighting for a nonhuman creature. Okja‰Ûªs oppressors, like E. T.‰Ûªs, are part of a system that refuses to recognize her as anything more than a thing. In this case, that system is specifically the food industrial complex, and her tale is a clear and effective animal rights fable, or at least a protest against factory farming and genetic engineering. (Nobody advocates for the fish and chickens Mija and her grandfather eat at home.)

But anyone familiar with that tradition ‰ÛÓ I‰Ûªll mention ‰ÛÏOld Yeller‰Ûù and leave it at that ‰ÛÓ knows that stories of children and their pets are almost inevitably shadowed by tragedy and loss. The adult human world regards animals through a callous, utilitarian lens, as sources of food, labor or ornamental cuteness, a fact that ‰ÛÏOkja,‰Ûù Bong Joon-ho‰Ûªs wonderful new film, takes to a dystopian but also an unnervingly realistic extreme.

The audience already suspects as much. The first face we see belongs not to a cute computer-generated piglet but to Tilda Swinton, in braces and a blinding platinum bob. Her character, Lucy Mirando ‰ÛÓ chief executive of the Mirando Corporation, which she inherited from her father ‰ÛÓ steps in front of the camera to preside over the brightly greenwashed presentation of a diabolical initiative. A new superbreed of swine has been created, she says, and 26 shoats will be distributed to farmers around the world to be raised in sustainable, free-range conditions. After 10 years, they will participate in a kind of livestock beauty pageant, overseen by a popular television veterinarian played by an antic and abrasive Jake Gyllenhaal.

The pursuit of Okja jumps from Seoul to New York, and ends up at a nightmarish meat-processing plant in New Jersey. Mr. Bong, one of the great visual storytellers working in movies today ‰ÛÓ earlier films like ‰ÛÏThe Host‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏSnowpiercer‰Ûù have shown him to be an artist of Spielbergian exuberance and skill ‰ÛÓ never muddies the frame with extraneous stuff or slows the narrative with tedious exposition. The picture, which never stops moving, is dense with information and feeling. Barbs of satire pop up and are washed away on streams of strong emotion. It‰Ûªs all marvelously preposterous and yet, at the same time, something important is at stake.

This might make the movie sound heavier and more dogmatic than it actually is. But if you have seen ‰ÛÏSnowpiercer,‰Ûù a parable of global inequality set aboard a high-speed train, you know that Mr. Bong juggles delight and didacticism with exquisite grace. Rather than turn out cardboard heroes and villains, he savors the eccentricity of his characters, in the sheer weirdness of our ingenious and idiotic species. He is fascinated by the petty doctrinal arguments and personal rivalries in the ranks of the Animal Liberation Front and also by the boardroom intrigue within the Mirando Corporation. Keep your eye on Giancarlo Esposito, and your ear out for Lucy Mirando‰Ûªs sister, Nancy.

The human performers are all brilliant, but the movie belongs to its title character and her digitally conjured, genetically modified ilk. Okja is a miracle of imagination and technique, and ‰ÛÏOkja‰Ûù insists, with abundant mischief and absolute sincerity, that she possesses a soul.

They make a funny pair, by turns amusing and puzzling, though also melancholic and touching. For the most part, these variations seem by design in a movie that flirts with assorted narrative conventions and fluctuating moods without ever settling into a familiar template. It takes some time, though, to figure out what the writer-director Kirsten Tan has in store for Thana and Pop Aye, who are first seen trudging together along a dusty, bleak stretch of road. They‰Ûªre nowhere in particular, certainly nowhere remotely inviting, and before long they‰Ûªre trying to catch a ride, which is about as challenging as you might expect when one of the hitchhikers is an elephant.

There‰Ûªs a wonderful moment in ‰ÛÏPop Aye,‰Ûù when an elephant gives the camera ‰ÛÓ and you ‰ÛÓ the stink eye. Then again, maybe the elephant, called Pop Aye and played by a majestic giant named Bong, is just exhausted, namely with people. You can‰Ûªt blame him. He‰Ûªs been tramping around the countryside for much of the movie, usually in the fumbling company of Thana (Thaneth Warakulnukroh), an architect from Bangkok who, with his marriage on the rocks and his career seriously on the skids, has set off on his midlife crisis not behind the wheel of a new sports car but alongside an old elephant.

This narrative fragmentation can be needlessly frustrating rather than interestingly complex and, like some of Ms. Tan‰Ûªs other choices, register as more programmatic than organic. At times, the long shots create meaning, giving you information and giving you room and time to breathe, to look around and appreciate the very large animal dwarfing a man who seems to have shrunk inside himself; at other times, the long shots feel close to art-film mannerisms. Ms. Tan is on far stronger, truer ground when she moves away from Thana‰Ûªs home life with his wife, Bo (Penpak Sirikul in a thankless, shrewish role), and leaves behind psychological explanation and matrimonial strife.

Like all road movies, ‰ÛÏPop Aye‰Ûù also journeys into the interior lives of its characters, a trip that is aided and abetted by other travelers who briefly hop on and off: notably, a poetic squatter; a pair of bumbling cops, who bust Thana and Pop Aye for eating thrown-away melon; and a transgender woman who, with grit and dignity, is holding onto a marginal existence. Each adds another detail, a splash of color and real warmth, though I wish there was more about Pop Aye, more attention, more close-ups. He‰Ûªs beautiful and heartbreaking, both because of what he adds to the story but also for all the extracinematic meaning he can‰Ûªt help but bring, all the pain, all the tears.

Thana, it emerges, is on his way to his childhood home. His reasons emerge piecemeal, relayed in regular flashbacks that create a mosaic-like portrait of a man whose life somehow, somewhere went wrong. Not catastrophically wrong, mind you, just disappointingly adrift and askew. That seems to be the idea, although it takes an attentive, patient viewer to fit together the shards that Ms. Tan scatters throughout, and to see how the flashbacks to Thana‰Ûªs childhood, with its pleasures and dark secrets, fit in with his more recent slights and grievances, including the impending demolition of one of his buildings, a glass-tower monument to consumerism.
A charming hedonist becomes an unlikely would-be assassin in ‰ÛÏ13 Minutes,‰Ûù a respectful but labored biopic of a village carpenter whose 1939 plot to blow up the FÌ_hrer was foiled by bad timing.

With a little more shading and originality, ‰ÛÏ13 Minutes‰Ûù might have pushed beyond its familiar Nazi tropes to shape something more immediate and infinitely more potent: an ominous portrait of radicalization.

Though ruthlessly romanticized and swimming in Holocaust-drama clichÌ©s ‰ÛÓ like the pallidly venomous Nazi interrogator ‰ÛÓ the story of how Georg Elser (an endearing Christian Friedel) transformed from mischievous ladies‰Ûª man to determined bomb maker is worth the telling. And for a while, it‰Ûªs even quite gripping as we watch Elser painstakingly plant his intricate device in a vast beer hall in Munich where Hitler is to speak.

As it happens, the movie‰Ûªs most compelling interaction is between Elser and a cautious police chief played by the admirable Burghart Klaussner, who achieves more with pursed lips and lowered eyelids than most actors manage with a page of dialogue. It‰Ûªs a performance that leaves space for nuanced interpretation ‰ÛÓ something that the rest of this overly conventional picture sorely lacks.

As directed by Oliver Hirschbiegel, however, Elser‰Ûªs capture and lengthy questioning by the Gestapo is a wasted opportunity to illuminate the mind of a man whom historical accounts variously describe as apolitical yet deeply concerned with workers‰Ûª rights. Bucolic flashbacks to lakeside picnics, where ripe young women vie for Elser‰Ûªs floppy-haired attentions and accordion serenades, reveal little about his beliefs or ambitions. Neither does his awkward incursion into the dismal marriage of his lover (Katharina SchÌ_ttler) and her sozzled husband.

Austin Reading‰Ûªs horror movie ‰ÛÏDarkness Rising‰Ûù has the makings of a solid haunted-house story: creepy ghosts, maniacal dogs, nightmare-inducing dolls, demonic possession, cursed artifacts and a splattering of blood for good measure. However, tossing these ingredients together does not guarantee a decent scare.

Mr. Reading and the screenwriter, Vikram Weet, channel the likes of the original ‰ÛÏEvil Dead‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Amityville Horror‰Ûù in this story, but there are almost too many references to other movies for this one to become its own monster.

The devil is missing from the details, like the lack of dust and cobwebs in the dilapidated house or of bloody footprints after the mother walks on a wounded foot. Even when characters endure increasingly cruel scenarios, the movie feels deadly stiff.

Still grieving the murder of her baby sister by her mother, Madison (Katrina Law) returns to her abandoned family home with her cousin (Tara Holt) and fiancÌ© (Bryce Johnson) before the building is demolished. None of them know that the evil spirit that had possessed Madison‰Ûªs mother would remain, setting the stage for deadly consequences.

Although the script is stuffed with eerie objects and happenings, there is a sense of restraint that keeps ‰ÛÏDarkness Rising‰Ûù from becoming frightening. The cinematography seems static and distant, not so much trapped in a house of evil spirits as it is stifled by the space.

Mr. Berry decries the industrialization of agriculture, which he believes will lead us to forget the values that come from living off the land. Mr. Berry‰Ûªs advocacy has made him a hero for the organic-food movement. (He can count Mark Bittman, a former food columnist for The New York Times, among his fans.) The film introduces farmers sympathetic to his ideals, even if some have strayed.

Judging from his sonorous voice, he may have missed his calling in radio. Throughout ‰ÛÏLook & See,‰Ûù Mr. Berry is an almost spectral presence, heard in narration and seen in archival footage. Mr. Berry has been compared to Henry David Thoreau. A longtime resident of Port Royal, Ky., he writes about the environment and the lifestyle of farmers with a naturalist‰Ûªs curiosity and a poet‰Ûªs gift for description.

Wendell Berry is difficult to classify. ‰ÛÏSome people would think he‰Ûªs a novelist and some think he‰Ûªs an essayist and some think he‰Ûªs a poet ‰ÛÓ and it kind of drifts off into nothing in particular,‰Ûù his wife, Tanya Berry, says with a laugh toward the end of ‰ÛÏLook & See: A Portrait of Wendell Berry.‰Ûù Laura Dunn‰Ûªs documentary is not simply a biography but an attempt to show how Mr. Berry sees the world.

Not all the gambits and arguments are convincing. Using time-lapse photography to illustrate poetry seems overly literal. Dismissing ‰ÛÏpeople‰Ûªs acceptance of the money economy as the only economy,‰Ûù Mr. Berry says ‰ÛÏthe world, in fact, unless you‰Ûªre in prison, is full of free things that are delightful.‰Ûù He cites dandelions, but flowers are free only until someone finds a way to sell them. Still, it‰Ûªs a pleasure to spend 80 minutes in Mr. Berry‰Ûªs company.

Despite the urgency of the situation the musicians face, when they‰Ûªre not doing their work, the movie is quiet, observant, taking in the austere beauty of the land and the people. In a blink-and-you-miss-it shot, a young girl is seen crossing a dirt road, leading a younger boy with one hand and holding a machete in the other. It provokes a shudder, while the scenes in which the musicians play together elicit jubilation.

The takeover of northern Mali between 2012 and 2013 by radical Islamist forces got a powerful fictionalized treatment in the widely acclaimed 2014 film ‰ÛÏTimbuktu,‰Ûù directed by Abderrahmane Sissako. An issue touched on in that picture was the banning of music by the jihadists. And one of the performers in it was a real-life singer, songwriter and guitarist, Fatoumata Diawara. ‰ÛÏMali Blues,‰Ûù a new documentary directed by Lutz Gregor, tells the real-life story of Ms. Diawara and three other major Malian musicians as they collaborate in the capital city, Bamako.

Bassekou KouyatÌ© plays a ngoni, a wooden instrument from which, he explains in one scene, the Western banjo was derived. He puts his instrument‰Ûªs sound through a wah-wah pedal, adding a psychedelic aura to its already spiritual tone. He speaks of the griot tradition, while the younger Master Soumy embraces what he sees as the innate opposition of rap. Ahmed Ag Kaedi, a Tuareg guitarist with a gorgeous fluid tone, tells of having his equipment burned and his family told by jihadists that if they caught up with him, they would cut off his fingers. In one of the movie‰Ûªs most lyrical scenes, Mr. Kaedi and Ms. Diawara improvise a song together; Mr. Kaedi‰Ûªs pessimistic lyrics state ‰ÛÏWe got a curse and it won‰Ûªt go away‰Ûù while Ms. Diawara sings of ‰ÛÏsounds that unite.‰Ûù

This biopic, subtitled ‰ÛÏThe Courage of Knowledge,‰Ûù highlights about six years in the life of the great scientist of the title (played by Karolina Gruszka). It starts in 1905 when she and her husband, Pierre (Charles Berling), go to Stockholm to give their Nobel Prize lecture, then moves through his death and toward Marie winning her second Nobel. Those years were eventful, and Ms. Gruszka seems to be in constant, breathless motion, even when only maneuvering around a laboratory.

Such continuous activity, and an overcommitment by the film‰Ûªs director, Marie NoÌÇlle, to stage nearly every frame in what seems to be the utmost flattering angle and pose, sometimes distracts, making it tough to delve into the character‰Ûªs beautiful mind as she‰Ûªs either traveling to meet Einstein (Piotr Glowacki) on the beach, having a scandalous affair with the mathematician Paul Langevin (Arieh Worthalter) or trying to overcome the sexism that‰Ûªs palpably infuriating for being so ever-present.

Gauzy light glows in almost every scene of the solemn and seriously pretty ‰ÛÏMarie Curie.‰Ûù Whether that light is a symbol of scientific discovery or just a filmmaker‰Ûªs preoccupation with radiance, it‰Ûªs difficult to say. But either way, it‰Ûªs lovely to watch.

Still, if we don‰Ûªt always know what drives Curie, we see the determination itself. That‰Ûªs enough to keep the film moving along. Just as smartly, Ms. NoÌÇlle, who wrote the script with Andrea Stoll, highlights Curie‰Ûªs success as a result of hard work and personal struggle rather than simple, and stereotypical, ‰ÛÏeureka!‰Ûù moments. There‰Ûªs a lot of labor and conflict shown here, and rarely have they looked so good.

Over all, this is an exciting film if not a completely cohesive one, but Xia Tian‰Ûªs ultimate decision about her career is a disappointment. One more thing: Think twice about using retinal biometrics for identification. (You‰Ûªll see).

To say that this tense sci-fi thriller, directed by Chang (born Yoon Hong-seung) and produced by Jackie Chan, has a strong female lead is an understatement. Thanks to the portal, we are treated to three simultaneous manifestations of Xia Tian, which is about one more than we can easily keep track of when they are engaged in a gun battle.
Rule No. 1 for overstressed mothers engaged in top-secret research that might make them the target of an enemy: Don‰Ûªt let the babysitter leave your child alone.

That is the first mistake Xia Tian (Yang Mi) makes in ‰ÛÏReset‰Ûù as she tries to balance her life with her work: opening a wormhole to parallel universes. Sure enough, a ruthless operative (Wallace Huo) from a competing company is on the loose, willing to do anything to get the data Xia Tian and her colleagues are working on.

There is shooting and stabbing galore, a clever kidnapping-by-truck routine and breathtaking car chases, as well as a harrowing scene of our heroine sliding down a long conveyor belt that feeds a bubbling caldron of waste.

Because the process has not been completely successful, Xia Tian‰Ûªs lab has prohibited human subjects from entering the portal. But she takes the chance and bursts through when her little son‰Ûªs life is at stake to fight her competitor.

The females receive short shrift. Gru and Dru‰Ûªs mother (Julie Andrews) is a randy yet remote matriarch; Margo is a scold; Agnes lives to find a unicorn; and the formerly single Lucy finds fulfillment when she exults, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm a mom, I‰Ûªm a mom!‰Ûù The daughters, yes, are rescued from jeopardy. Not that a voluble little boy at my screening objected.

Gru and Lucy enlist Gru‰Ûªs long-lost brother, Dru (also Mr. Carell), to assist in Bratt‰Ûªs capture. Dru, who lives in a seemingly Mediterranean paradise called Freedonia (you heard that right, but the Marx Brothers references end there), is obscenely wealthy and has an indefinable blondish hairdo apparently trendy among the obscenely wealthy.

The latest animated ‰ÛÏDespicable Me‰Ûù outing shows signs of wear even as its energy level escalates. This time, the reformed villain Gru (voiced by Steve Carell) is in domestic bliss with his fellow secret agent Lucy (Kristen Wiig) and the three orphans ‰ÛÓ cute Agnes, mischievous Edith and bespectacled Margo ‰ÛÓ when he and Lucy are dismissed from the Anti-Villain League for letting a bad guy, Balthazar Bratt (Trey Parker), escape.

Gru and Dru bicker but find common cause when Bratt ‰ÛÓ a petulant, mulleted former 1980s TV child star ‰ÛÓ leads a giant robot of himself and an army of malevolent flying action figures on an invasion of Hollywood. Of course, the short, goggled and sometimes cyclopean minions are on hand, engaging in a prison food fight and dancing in a cancan-like production number. Innocuous pandemonium ensues in candy colors.

‰ÛÏHomecoming‰Ûù is more or less about how Peter Parker needs to stay forever young, ideally 15 or so years old. What‰Ûªs always been most appealing about Spider-Man is that he‰Ûªs a kid, if one who can spin big, sticky webs and swing from rooftop to rooftop, comparatively rinky-dink talents in the flying, magic-hammering superhero world. What makes Spider-Man different and, ideally, work as a character, giving him an off-kilter charm, is he retains the uncertainties and vulnerabilities of adolescence. For all his super-gifts and despite the weird and dangerous company he keeps, he is also a teenage boy ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs his Kryptonite, what cuts him down to recognizable human size.

That machine, known to executives and true believers as the Marvel Cinematic Universe, is vast, complicated, lucrative and ever-expanding. It‰Ûªs also intrinsically uninteresting for viewers (at least one!) who just want a good movie. Marvel has produced a string of movies of wildly divergent quality, but Sony has had a tougher time coming up with regular superhero successes. And so, after stumbling with its first ‰ÛÏSpider-Man‰Ûù resurrection, it cut a deal with Marvel, which is also not inherently interesting. Even so it‰Ûªs modestly amusing to consider that Sony, much like Peter Parker here, needed help getting off the ground again, and so Marvel stepped in to play its Tony Stark-like guide.

And then there‰Ûªs Michael Keaton, who‰Ûªs so very good in ‰ÛÏHomecoming‰Ûù that he suggests a future narrative path down which the older, more experienced Spider-Man might eventually go if ever allowed to truly grow up. Mr. Keaton plays the Vulture, the regulation baddie, who after weaponizing some extraterrestrial leftovers has become a criminal mastermind, with the usual yelling, minions and death. He flies around in a clunky winged apparatus that looks like something from the Wright Brothers‰Ûª steampunk phase. This makes for an amusing chunk of heavy-metal dÌ©cor, but is mostly resonant as a tepid joke about Mr. Keaton‰Ûªs aerial acrobatics in ‰ÛÏBatman‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBirdman.‰Ûù

It‰Ûªs tough to know who the biggest creative force is in a corporate entity like ‰ÛÏHomecoming‰Ûù and how much Mr. Watts contributed to its look, vibe and feel. The movie isn‰Ûªt visually distinctive over all, and while some of the better action scenes stick low to the ground, as when Spider-Man crashes through suburban backyards and plays bumper cars with trash cans, the airborne special-effects scenes are disappointingly lackluster, particularly in the age of ambitious, eye-stroking diversions like ‰ÛÏDoctor Strange.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs hard to think of a single image in ‰ÛÏHomecoming‰Ûù that will transcend a first viewing the way that Peter and M. J.‰Ûªs tender, topsy-turvy kiss did in Sam Raimi‰Ûªs first ‰ÛÏSpider-Man.‰Ûù

Mr. Watts‰Ûªs previous features include ‰ÛÏCop Car,‰Ûù a slick, small-scaled nail-biter about two boys in peril that showed he knows where to put the camera, is good with actors and has a sadistic streak, which together presumably clinched his big-studio future. ‰ÛÏCop Car‰Ûù is such an exercise in pressure-cooker cinema that it‰Ûªs surprising how tamped down the sense of danger is in ‰ÛÏHomecoming,‰Ûù even in some of the earlier sequences in which Peter is still puzzling out how to scuttle and swing as he vanquishes villainy. A brief scene of him sneaking into his bedroom (to avoid Marisa Tomei‰Ûªs Aunt May) has more tension than any single action set piece.

The Vulture is a mess of prickly contradictions, only some of which seem intentional. His criminality, rage and perhaps his madness have been stoked by class resentment and Mr. Keaton, with his white-hot menace and narrowing eyes, makes him a memorably angry man, not a caricature. The Vulture becomes a narrative counterweight to Tony Stark‰Ûªs self-satisfied billionaire. But the Vulture is also the biggest enemy facing Spider-Man, who ‰ÛÓ as this movie reminds you ‰ÛÓ is a working-class kid turned superhero. Here, Spidey is eager to do a billionaire‰Ûªs bidding, partly because he‰Ûªs being readied to join the Avengers. The question is when Spidey really grows up, who will he fight for and why?

For its initial hour, ‰ÛÏHomecoming‰Ûù moves along breezily enough, though sometimes with too much forced airiness. It works best when it sticks close to Peter and is content to be a light, good-natured story of a teenager who‰Ûªs navigating through, and often badly fumbling, the competing demands of school, home and his emergent Spidey self. Mr. Holland looks and sounds more like a teenager than the actors who‰Ûªve previously suited up for this series, and he has fine support from a cast that includes Jacob Batalon as Peter‰Ûªs best friend. Other good company includes Donald Glover, as a wrong-time, wrong-place criminal, and Martin Starr, who plays his teacher role with perfect deadpan timing.

Sony‰Ûªs latest Spider-Man movie is kind of like the first and fourth, even if it‰Ûªs hard to keep track of what happened when in this on-and-off again series. Once more, it spins on Peter Parker (the nice, boyish Tom Holland), a teenager who develops super-skills after he‰Ûªs bitten by a troublesome spider. The title of the likable, amusing ‰ÛÏSpider-Man: Homecoming‰Ûù indicates that this is a return, though to what exactly? To Queens? To youth? The rest of us can‰Ûªt go home again, but given that this is the second Spider-Man reboot in 15 years from Sony Pictures it seems Spidey has few other options.

The team behind ‰ÛÏHomecoming‰Ûù certainly gets that Spider-Man is a kid, even if the movie plays the naÌøf angle too hard at times, making Peter look not just inexperienced but also silly, a borderline dumb cluck. The movie ‰ÛÓ credited to six writers and directed by Jon Watts ‰ÛÓ opens sometime after Peter has been bitten. He‰Ûªs still trying to get his bearings and struggling to figure out the limits of his powers, which is complicated here by the fact that this is the first Spider-Man movie that Sony has made with Marvel Studios. It‰Ûªs a liaison that has brought Spider-Man into the Marvel worldwide domination machine, which is why he‰Ûªs being mentored in the way of the superhero by Marvel‰Ûªs Iron Man, a.k.a. Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr., who pops in and out).

Ms. Dorfman emerges as an artist of deep compassion, empathy, humor and wisdom. During a montage of photographs of Ginsberg, he is heard in a late-‰Ûª50s audio recording reading his great poem ‰ÛÏAmerica.‰Ûù Lines like ‰ÛÏAmerica when will you end the human war‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAmerica why are your libraries full of tears‰Ûù resonate with a particular poignancy even today, as does ‰ÛÏAmerica when will you be angelic.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe B-Side‰Ûù is a portrait of a genuine American angel.
