Lee (‰ÛÏThe Best Man‰Ûù) helps turn these types into characters efficiently and sympathetically ‰ÛÓ he knows how to light and frame a beautiful face ‰ÛÓ though every so often you sense he would like to cut loose visually. Mostly, he serves Kenya Barris and Tracy Oliver‰Ûªs script, which goes high, low and sincere as it mixes some slapstick in with the sober bits, giddily indulges its freewheeling silliness and drops heart-to-hearts ranging from a sharply comic lesson on white privilege to a hilarious riff on the joys of grapefruit sex. (Ms. Oliver and Mr. Barris, who created the sitcom ‰ÛÏblack-ish,‰Ûù also wrote ‰ÛÏBarbershop: The Next Cut,‰Ûù which Mr. Lee directed.)

That makes ‰ÛÏGirls Trip‰Ûù seem tamer than a movie like ‰ÛÏRough Night.‰Ûù But ‰ÛÏGirls Trip‰Ûù is also funnier; it‰Ûªs also more appealing because it knows that there‰Ûªs more at stake existentially for women, and especially for black women, than out-grossing men. The friends in ‰ÛÏGirls Trip‰Ûù have other issues to work on, all of which are grounded in ordinary life: how to live in the world with love and joy, how to nurture intimate relationships so they don‰Ûªt slip away, how to balance professional and personal obligations without going nuts, how to perform fairly tricky sexual acts without embarrassing you or your partner right out of bed ‰ÛÓ you know, the usual.

Girls gone wild, ladies on the loose, chicks out for kicks ‰ÛÓ the spectacle of women behaving badly is having its moment (again). In the 1930s, runaway brides ran amok with banter and high jinks; in the 1940s, femmes fatales did their men wrong with lipstick sneers and a bullet to the heart. The latest iteration of this type of movie often skews comic and generally involves a group of gal pals getting together for some ‰ÛÏwe time.‰Ûù They find trouble and, here‰Ûªs hoping, their bliss amid oceans of booze and maybe drugs, sometimes in the company of men, who are alternately helpful or hapless.

It‰Ûªs a lovely home in a heart-catching spot, and I could have watched Ms. Keller poke around it for hours. Alas, Mr. Schroeder, best known for ‰ÛÏReversal of Fortune,‰Ûù has tethered both his actress and this natural glory to an awkward, unpersuasive story, largely set in the early 1990s, that coalesces around the lingering effects of World War II on the German soul. The war‰Ûªs impact on Martha takes a while to emerge, ostensibly because she doesn‰Ûªt like to talk about it or even to identify as German. She also doesn‰Ûªt speak the language, even with her new neighbor, Jo (Max Riemelt), a young German D.J. camped out in a nearby house.

Inner peace and reconciliation ‰ÛÓ as well as historical memory and its burden ‰ÛÓ are at the heart of Barbet Schroeder‰Ûªs drama ‰ÛÏAmnesia.‰Ûù The story is simple, the emotions complex. It takes a while for the true depth of all the complicated, confusing feelings to surface, partly because the movie‰Ûªs most interesting character, the German-born Martha (Marthe Keller), has done a good job of barricading off part of her being. But don‰Ûªt weep too hard for her: She‰Ûªs built that wall in enviable splendor on the Spanish island of Ibiza, where she lives alone in a white house overlooking the blue, blue Mediterranean.

Jo has come to Ibiza for work, but he‰Ûªs soon scampering after Martha like a hungry puppy. She greets his attentions with a Mona Lisa smile; mostly she seems happy for the company. There‰Ûªs an agreeable timelessness to their blessedly languorous moments, to their talks and walks amid the beauty of Ibiza. ‰ÛÏAmnesia‰Ûù is filled with conversations ‰ÛÓ often delivered in somewhat dissonant, sometimes halting English ‰ÛÓ peppered with bits of exposition and quotidian asides about, say, cooking with herbs (a little lemon verbena is perfect for fish). Later, when everything has come to a head, the ease of all this talk gives way to lurching rounds of confession and accusation that stop the movie dead.

‰ÛÏAmnesia,‰Ûù Mr. Schroeder has said, is a story partly based on his mother, who refused to speak German, so perhaps it‰Ûªs no surprise that it‰Ûªs strongest when it focuses on Martha, a character Ms. Keller inhabits gracefully. You believe Martha, who‰Ûªs at home in the particular world that Mr. Schroeder has made for her. That‰Ûªs the case even when you don‰Ûªt wholly trust the words coming out of her mouth, especially when she‰Ûªs indulging Jo. Mr. Riemelt has a few fine moments in the movie, but over all his smiles tend to be too wide and his body language too eager when Jo is around Martha, which makes the evolution of their relationship and finally the movie feel forced.

Soon, the scene switches to another port, where a British teenager, George (Barry Keoghan), is helping a father and son (Mark Rylance and Tom Glynn-Carney) unload a small yacht that‰Ûªs been requisitioned for the Dunkirk mission. The three men instead set sail on their own, joining a civilian fleet ‰ÛÓ a rousing, motley armada of tugs, steamers, ferries and so on ‰ÛÓ that‰Ûªs racing across the Channel. A third, astounding narrative section soon opens in the air, where three British Spitfire planes are quickly engaged in battle against German planes headed for Dunkirk, racing through the vast canopy and bobbing under clouds as the sun flashes, temporarily blinding them.

The soldier who scrambles over the gate and onto the beach is called Tommy (Fionn Whitehead) in the credits, but I don‰Ûªt remember hearing or reading his name. Mostly, I just thought of him as Our Boy, less because of his youth than because of the vulnerability communicated through Mr. Whitehead‰Ûªs slight figure and tangible physical performance, his small and large gestures and moves: the darting, panicked eyes; the nervous, abrupt gestures; the hunched shoulders. In time, Tommy is joined by other soldiers waiting and running and ducking on the beach, the most important played by the equally fine Aneurin Barnard and the singer Harry Styles.

It‰Ûªs a somewhat perplexing, awkwardly funny moment ‰ÛÓ this is a manifestly serious situation, and you‰Ûªre about to watch a man defecate. You don‰Ûªt know whether to laugh, but before you decide, shots ring out and the soldiers start running, the camera quickly following. The haunted emptiness is suddenly filled with the sounds of frantic escape and whizzing bullets. And then the men begin falling, one, two, three, until just the unbuckling one remains, scrambling first over a gate and soon onto a beach where thousands of other soldiers are massed and waiting. He silently takes in the extraordinary scene and then hustles over to a dune to begin undoing his belt again.

Mr. Nolan‰Ûªs unyielding emphasis on the soldiers ‰ÛÓ and on war as it is experienced rather than on how it is strategized ‰ÛÓ blurs history even as it brings the present and its wars startlingly into view. ‰ÛÏDunkirk‰Ûù is a tour de force of cinematic craft and technique, but one that is unambiguously in the service of a sober, sincere, profoundly moral story that closes the distance between yesterday‰Ûªs fights and today‰Ûªs. Mr. Nolan closes that distance cinematically with visual sweep and emotional intimacy, with images of warfare and huddled, frightened survivors that together with Hans Zimmer‰Ûªs score reverberate through your body. By the time that plane is burning ‰ÛÓ and a young man is looking searchingly into the future ‰ÛÓ you are reminded that the fight against fascism continues.

By turns intimate and sweeping, the film opens with six soldiers walking away from the camera down a spookily deserted street. Their bodies are shown in full, head to toe, and they are flanked by low buildings, the sort that now look so charming in touristic photographs. Slips of paper swirl around the men like autumn leaves. A few grab at the papers. One tries slurping water from a nearby garden hose; another pokes a hand through an open window, searching for a smoke. Still another reads one of the papers, which shows a map of the surrounding area encircled by arrows and ominous words of warning in English. He then crumples it, unbuckles his belt and begins to squat.

Once Mr. Nolan begins switching between day and night, the lines dividing the three narrative segments mostly sharpen. Even as each section ‰ÛÓ with its individual dramas and perils ‰ÛÓ comes closer into view, Mr. Nolan keeps them all in dynamic play with one another. Some of this he achieves with stark visual echoes, as when water rushing into a downed Spitfire engulfs the pilot and elsewhere a soldier nearly drowns. (Tom Hardy plays the most critically important pilot, while a sympathetic Jack Lowden takes on a critical support role.) At one point, Mr. Nolan pulls the three narrative strands tightly together, creating a tremendous, enveloping sense of bone-deep dread.

‰ÛÏDunkirk‰Ûù is a World War II movie, one told through soldiers, their lived and near-death experiences and their bodies under siege. Names are generally irrelevant here; on the beach ‰ÛÓ and in the sea and air ‰ÛÓ what counts are rank, unit, skill and the operation, although more important is survival, making it through another attack and somehow avoiding exploding bombs. Mr. Nolan‰Ûªs emphasis on the visceral reality of Dunkirk leaves much unsaid; even in some opening explanatory text, the enemy isn‰Ûªt identified as Nazi Germany. The soldiers, of course, know exactly who they are fighting and perhaps even why, but in the field the enemy is finally the unnamed stranger trying to kill them.

Scarcely a word has been uttered up to this point, yet much has been expressed: isolation; danger; desperation; fear; relief; and sheer, extreme bodily need and effort. Throughout this de facto prologue, Mr. Nolan emphasizes the concrete details, making you acutely aware of the fine-grained textures ‰ÛÓ the sores and embedded dirt on a man‰Ûªs hands ‰ÛÓ and every resonant sound: the dribbling of water, the fluttering of paper, and the sharp crack and mechanical buzzing of rifle fire that turns into muffled thuds when bullets enter bodies. By the time the surviving soldier reaches the beach, you are already closely acquainted with his heavy breathing, wild fumbling and clumsy, chaotic running.

One of the most indelible images in ‰ÛÏDunkirk,‰Ûù Christopher Nolan‰Ûªs brilliant new film, is of a British plane in flames. The movie recounts an early, harrowing campaign in World War II that took place months after Germany invaded Poland and weeks after Hitler‰Ûªs forces started rolling into the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg and France. The plane, having glided to a stop, has been defiantly set ablaze by the pilot to avoid its being captured. It‰Ûªs an image of unambiguous defeat but also an emblem of resistance and a portent of the ghastly conflagrations still to come.

Mr. Nolan‰Ûªs elastic approach to narrative works beautifully in ‰ÛÏDunkirk,‰Ûù which oscillates among its three sections, each largely taking place in distinct locations in different time frames. The events on the beach ‰ÛÓ called the Mole for the breakwater that‰Ûªs used as a dock ‰ÛÓ unfold during one week. The events on the sea occur in one day, while the air scenes transpire in an hour. The locations and the time periods are announced onscreen. At first the dividing lines aren‰Ûªt always obvious as Mr. Nolan cuts from daytime scenes on the ground to those in the sea and in the air, a slight merging of space and especially of time that underlines the enormity of a fight seemingly without end.

War movies tend to play out along familiar lines, including lump-in-the throat home-front tales like ‰ÛÏMrs. Miniver.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏDunkirk‰Ûù takes place in battle, but it, too, is a story of suffering and survival. Mr. Nolan largely avoids the bigger historical picture (among other things, the reason these men are fighting is a given) as well as the strategizing on the front and in London, where the new prime minister, Winston Churchill, was facing the horrifying possibility of diminished military muscle. Churchill is heard from, in a fashion, but never seen. Mr. Nolan instead narrows in on a handful of men who are scrambling and white-knuckling their way into history on the sea, in the air and on the ground.

It‰Ûªs a characteristically complex and condensed vision of war in a movie that is insistently humanizing despite its monumentality, a balance that is as much a political choice as an aesthetic one. And ‰ÛÏDunkirk‰Ûù is big ‰ÛÓ in subject, reach, emotion and image. Mr. Nolan shot and mostly finished it on large-format film (unusual in our digital era), which allows details to emerge in great scale. Overhead shots of soldiers scattered across a beach convey an unnerving isolation ‰ÛÓ as if these were the last souls on earth, terminally alone, deserted. (Seen on a television, they would look like ants.) Film also enriches the texture of the image; it draws you to it, which is crucial given the minimalist dialogue.

The movie is based on a campaign that began in late May 1940 in the French port city of Dunkirk, where some 400,000 Allied soldiers ‰ÛÓ including more than 200,000 members of the British Expeditionary Force, the British army in Western Europe ‰ÛÓ were penned in by the Germans. The British, faced with the capture or possible annihilation of their troops, initiated a seemingly impossible rescue. Named Operation Dynamo, this mission has assumed near-mythic status in British history and been revisited in books and onscreen; it shows up in ‰ÛÏMrs. Miniver,‰Ûù a 1942 Hollywood weepie about British pain and perseverance in the war meant to encourage American support for the Allies.

‰ÛÏFirst Kill,‰Ûù a decently executed but generic thriller, is most notable for advancing the dubious theory that the best way to help a child who is being bullied is to traumatize the heck out of him.

As they arrive, the police chief (Bruce Willis, understated here) advises them to stay alert because some bank robbers have recently struck and are still at large. On their first foray into the woods, Will and Danny encounter two of them. Eventually Danny ends up as a hostage to one, Levi (Gethin Anthony, in the film‰Ûªs best performance), who teaches the boy more about self-confidence and dealing with adversity than Will ever did.

But to learn inner strength Danny sure does have to witness a lot of carnage. In addition to jumping on the anti-bullying bandwagon that is so popular on television and in film at the moment, the movie tries for a second bit of topicality by including a subplot pegged to the high cost of health care. It‰Ûªs an awkward attempt, and the movie, directed by Steven C. Miller, doesn‰Ûªt hold a lot of surprises, but there is worse terror-in-the-woods fare out there ‰ÛÓ rather a lot of it, in fact.

Will (Hayden Christensen) is a high-finance type whose son, Danny (Ty Shelton), a withdrawn 11-year-old, has become a mean boy‰Ûªs punching bag at school. Will‰Ûªs solution is to take his citified family (Megan Leonard plays the mother) on a trip to the small town where he spent his own boyhood and teach Danny how to hunt.

The film consists of loosely connected scenes with a general focus on adolescent girls swimming, cooking, getting sun and contemplating the independence of adulthood. ‰ÛÏKekszakallu‰Ûù eventually fixates on an almost-protagonist (Laila Maltz), who seems uninterested in work and unsure of what to study, and who somehow manages to have a car accident in a mostly empty lot.

The Argentine film ‰ÛÏKekszakallu‰Ûù seems designed as a test of how little the director, GastÌ_n Solnicki, can derive from the Hungarian composer Bela Bartok‰Ûªs only opera, ‰ÛÏBluebeard‰Ûªs Castle,‰Ûù while still citing it as his inspiration.

At festivals, ‰ÛÏKekszakallu‰Ûù won praise from critics, especially those who regard the blurring of fiction and documentary (Mr. Solnicki‰Ûªs background) as inherently chic. Two accomplished minimalists, Matthew Porterfield (the director and co-writer of the underseen ‰ÛÏI Used to Be Darker‰Ûù) and MartÌ_n Rejtman, are associate producers, and Mr. Porterfield is credited as a narrative contributor. But ‰ÛÏKekszakallu‰Ûù lacks the ballast of memorable images or scenes.

The ‰ÛÏinspired by‰Ûù credit for Bartok follows the title card, which appears roughly 17 minutes into this 72-minute film, an exercise in constructing a feature almost entirely from artfully composed, incident-lite tableaus. Even seasoned defenders of cryptic formalism may find it amorphous. The characters are never named, the camera work is static, and little that‰Ûªs conceptually interesting materializes.

From the ostensible Bartok source ‰ÛÓ wonderfully filmed by Michael Powell in the 1960s ‰ÛÓ Mr. Solnicki takes his title (Hungarian for ‰ÛÏBluebeard‰Ûù), snatches of music and perhaps the germ of a theme of women heading off into an unknown future.

Set in and around a national park in Australia, the story starts off with that charisma-free couple, Ian (Ian Meadows) and Samantha (Harriet Dyer), who plan to pitch their tent and spend time alone in the woods. She‰Ûªs prone to dispensing exposition (‰ÛÏI‰Ûªve got no reception,‰Ûù she says as she looks at her cellphone when they arrive), while he‰Ûªs more than happy to ask a weird stranger for advice.

‰ÛÏKilling Ground‰Ûù features a man and a woman who make head-slappingly dumb choices as they flee from a pair of killers who are just as inept. Yet in the end, the most regrettable decision may be that of audience members who fork over money to see the movie.

Mr. Power says his aim was to explore violence, and he generates some suspense from crosscutting the stories. But these personality-free characters fade from your mind even as you‰Ûªre watching the screen, making the brutality waged against them akin to animated mutilation of cartoon creatures. Certainly, the senselessness of bloodshed may be Mr. Power‰Ûªs point. But with this setup, such a message is all but muted.

Intercut with that story is the tale of a family who previously camped in the area. The two plots, featuring the same set of predators (Aaron Pedersen and Aaron Glenane), intertwine and, after a lengthy intro, move toward some revolting cruelness.

In his director‰Ûªs statement, Damien Power, who also wrote the script, cites ‰Ûª70s ‰ÛÏsurvival thrillers‰Ûù as his inspiration, and like ‰ÛÏThe Texas Chainsaw Massacre,‰Ûù this movie has the hallmarks of torture porn: gratuitous slaughter, remorseless murderers and gruesome acts.

Or, more to the point, it might remind oldish viewers of a certain kind of observant, clever but unambitious independent film that came to prominence in the era it depicts. The characters are not badly drawn, but they stay within the lines. Dana is the flakier sister, and also the more responsible one. Ali is quiet, guarded and critical. She is both more reckless and more grounded than her parents suspect.

‰ÛÏLandline‰Ûù was directed by Gillian Robespierre, who wrote it with Elisabeth Holm. They also collaborated on ‰ÛÏObvious Child,‰Ûù which starred Ms. Slate, and which was notable for the mixture of sweetness and candor it brought to the subject of abortion. There was something bracing, as well as brave, about that film‰Ûªs honesty. Oddly, the new one is much more cautious and decorous in its treatment of the emotional dynamics of a complicated family. For all the profanity and naughty behavior, it has the timid, ingratiating vibe of a television sitcom, sticking to safe and familiar emotional territory.

It‰Ûªs strange to think that if Ali and Dana were real, they would now be in their early and later 40s. The fact that they seem so much like present-day young people is less an anachronism than an aspect of the film‰Ûªs hopeful, soothing attitude. It‰Ûªs a peace offering from Generation X to the millennials, a gesture of solidarity from one cohort of the metropolitan upper-middle class to another. We‰Ûªre just like you, and we‰Ûªll all grow up eventually.

One of those antique data-storage devices provides the pretext for a bit of plot. Ali (Abby Quinn), the younger of the two Jacobs daughters, discovers a trove of erotic poetry her father has been writing to someone other than his wife. These proto-sexts are part of a small epidemic of infidelity among the Jacobses. Ali‰Ûªs older sister, Dana (Jenny Slate), recently engaged to her live-in boyfriend, Ben (Jay Duplass), sparks up some action on the side with Nate (Finn Wittrock), a guy she knew in college. ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre a family of cheaters,‰Ûù Ali says in disgust.

Nostalgia is not what it used to be. ‰ÛÏLandline,‰Ûù a fairly genial, diffident comedy about diffident, fairly generic people, plants its flag in 1995 and surveys a landscape of indie rock, ‰ÛÏMust See TV‰Ûù and the high-waisted bluejeans that have recently started coming back into fashion. Hillary Clinton is on television, sporting a hairband and a pink suit.

Mostly, though, as the movie‰Ûªs title whimsically suggests, the mid-90s were an era of adorably quaint technology. Characters make calls from pay phones and listen to messages on answering machines. They take pictures with boxy little cameras, rent videocassettes of movies and make mix tapes on actual cassette tape. The members of an upper-middle-class New York household share a single desktop computer, with a dot-matrix printer and a slot for floppy disks.

Mr. Turturro and Ms. Falco, with their lived-in faces and deeply seasoned acting technique, provide Alan and Pat with more individuality than the script does. The filmmakers seem hesitant to make any of their characters too interesting. Each one is an assemblage of surface quirks and emotional responses, neatly inserted into a series of dramatic and comic situations. Some of these pay off nicely, in particular when Ms. Slate and Ms. Quinn share the screen and capture the jumpy, push-and-pull rhythms of loving but not entirely compatible sisters.

The parents, meanwhile, are near-caricatures of middle-aged compromise. Alan (John Turturro) clings to his literary ambitions and works at an advertising agency. His wife, Pat (Edie Falco), works in environmental policy but doesn‰Ûªt talk much about it. They refer to a wilder life back in the ‰Ûª70s, but, like much else in the movie, that feels more like a talking point than like an aspect of authentic experience.

On his trip, shot in a documentary style that manages to generate real suspense, he catches up with friends and family, mostly circus folk too. One of them is caring for an aging chimpanzee named Lola, a showbiz vet who has a central role in Dario Argento‰Ûªs 1985 horror thriller ‰ÛÏPhenomena.‰Ûù Like Tairo, the animal represents a way of life that‰Ûªs going out with the tide of the postmodern. The conclusion is worth not giving away, but it‰Ûªs heartwarming without being cloying.

Tairo Caroli is a young man who‰Ûªs an animal tamer at a down-at-the-heels circus touring the outskirts of Rome. One of his big cats, Rambo, has just died; a couple of the others are indisposed. He‰Ûªs a bit of a knucklehead, picking little fights with colleagues, and one of these battles escalates. Tairo‰Ûªs good luck charm, a piece of iron that the 1957 Mister Universe and circus strongman Arthur Robin bent for Tairo when he was a boy, gets lost or stolen in an ensuing scrape. Downhearted and scared, Tairo takes to the road in search of Mr. Robin while Wendy, the circus‰Ûªs contortionist, seeks a variety of mild occult solutions to Tairo‰Ûªs seeming streak of bad luck.

The filmmaking team of Tizza Covi and Rainer Frimmel concoct fictional narratives around the real lives and professions of the nonactors with whom they work. This is an unusual formula but not an entirely novel one. While other examples of this method, or some variant of it, have yielded films that come off as condescending or creepily exploitative, Ms. Covi and Mr. Frimmel‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMister Universo‰Ûù is a disarming and humane picture, an unexpected delight.

‰ÛÏThis ain‰Ûªt got nothing to do with my life,‰Ûù DontÌ© Clark recalled thinking when, at 15, he picked up ‰ÛÏRomeo and Juliet.‰Ûù At 22, after years of seeing gang warfare and murder on the streets of his hometown, Richmond, Calif., he changed his mind. ‰ÛÏThat is our story,‰Ûù he now says of the play. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs just told in Verona. In a different language, a different time period.‰Ûù

This free-flowing style mimics the hip-hop and jazz-inflected rhythms of the student-poets. But it comes at a price; the portraits drawn of these young people frequently feel half-finished. As soon as a story or a profile turns compelling, the movie switches to another topic.

Mr. Clark is part of RAW Talent, a group of young people who write and perform poetry. The members decided to stage their own team-written script loosely adapted from ‰ÛÏRomeo and Juliet,‰Ûù and Jason Zeldes, the director of this documentary, ‰ÛÏRomeo Is Bleeding,‰Ûù followed along to learn about their lives and chart their progress (a plan similar to that of several films, including ‰ÛÏShakespeare High‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Hobart Shakespeareans‰Ûù).

For long stretches, ‰ÛÏRomeo Is Bleeding‰Ûù jettisons talk of Shakespeare altogether, though the real center of the film is, as it should be, the program members. They stay passionate despite discouraging circumstances. In Mr. Clark‰Ûªs case, he had few options. When asked to join the group, he said, ‰ÛÏIt was either that or the streets, so I write poetry.‰Ûù

Mr. Zeldes, who with Kevin Klauber also edited the documentary, uses fast cuts, varied camera angles and a patchwork of scenes to take in the varied perspectives of life in Richmond. The filmmakers walk with residents, ride with police officers and hear stories of young men who‰Ûªve been killed.

At the beginning of Kavi Raz‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Black Prince‰Ûù we hear in a stentorian voice-over that the Lion of Punjab, a Sikh king, was ‰ÛÏfearsome, fearless and feared.‰Ûù Alas, the poor Black Prince, son of the Lion ‰Û_ in Mr. Raz‰Ûªs movie he‰Ûªs muddled, moody and even a bit mousy.

His troubles are many: He was forcibly taken from Punjab as a boy and has lived in exile in England, where he has become a Christian like his guardians. And though Queen Victoria (Amanda Root, wasted) has taken him under her wing, Duleep wants to see his mother again. And he wants to be a Sikh. And he wants to rule Punjab.

The movie perks up briefly when the great Shabana Azmi appears, playing Duleep‰Ûªs mother, a woman losing her sight and possibly her mind. Ms. Azmi seems to understand what the movie needs: a jolt of emotion and some life, regal or otherwise.

A dramatic life does not necessarily a dramatic film make. Some of this story is told in quick flashbacks; but most of it unfolds in conversations in handsome period settings. Throughout, the characters‰Ûª interior lives are opaque. At one point Duleep, returning from a thwarted trip to India, stops in Cairo. Handing out diplomas at a girls‰Ûª school, he spies a beautiful young woman. Cut to: They have tea. Cut to: They‰Ûªre married. Cut to: They have three children. Soon, more brooding. (‰ÛÏSir, something sits heavy on your mind.‰Ûù)

Based on the true story of Duleep Singh, the last maharajah of Punjab, ‰ÛÏThe Black Prince,‰Ûù written and directed by Mr. Raz, never finds a rhythm. Worse, Duleep (Satinder Sartaaj) remains a handsome cipher, brooding in the shadows of his own story until, upon occasion, someone thinks to ask, ‰ÛÏWhat troubles you?‰Ûù

This movie‰Ûªs hero is Endel (Mart Avandi), a champion fencer on the run from Leningrad; his wartime past, if known, would get him charged as an enemy of the people. As the film opens, he arrives in a small town, Haapsalu, where he is hired at a school and given the task of running a sports club for the students.

Inspirational teachers aren‰Ûªt limited to any one time or place. ‰ÛÏThe Fencer,‰Ûù a Finnish-Estonian-German coproduction drawn from a true story, may be set in Estonia in the early 1950s, when the Soviet Union occupied the country, but it follows squarely in the footsteps of ‰ÛÏDead Poets Society‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏStand and Deliver.‰Ûù

Soon Marta (Liisa Koppel) stumbles on him as he practices fencing in the gymnasium, and she wants to learn the sport. When he starts a fencing group, the children quickly take to it, even as they‰Ûªre stuck with foils made from reeds in a nearby marsh. But the principal (Hendrik Toompere) fears that fencing isn‰Ûªt appropriately proletarian. (While the character may be a stooge, it might have been helpful to give him at least one scene of doing something other than thwarting or sneering at Endel.)

The director, Klaus Haro, films the proceedings involvingly enough, particularly when it comes time for the inevitable tournament; his flowing camera moves might be correlatives to the careful balancing required by fencing. But the movie is almost relentlessly predictable and formulaic ‰ÛÓ a story of one man‰Ûªs refusal to conform that dutifully hits all its marks.

SÌ©bastien Laudenbach‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Girl Without Hands‰Ûù is an animated adaptation of the Brothers Grimm fairy tale of the same title. Although this film‰Ûªs style is soft and colorful, it does not rub out the emotional sharpness of a story dealing with betrayal, suicide and death.

The result is a dazzlingly imaginative movie about survival. Left on her own, the woman in the story proves capable of taking care of herself, and later her child, once the constraints of comfort and gender roles are cast off.

Perhaps more striking than the adaptation of the harsh narrative is the movie‰Ûªs animation style. Mr. Laudenbach‰Ûªs drawing eschews clean ink lines for a minimalist and impressionist aesthetic. He allows the water color swatches that stand in for characters and landscapes to create a dreamlike world that appears poetically endless. When lines do appear, they are thick and textured, like those of a sumi-e painting from Asia.

An impoverished miller (voiced by Olivier Broche) unwittingly sells his daughter (AnaÌøs Demoustier) for a never-ending river of gold, unaware he‰Ûªs dealing with the Devil (Philippe Laudenbach, the director‰Ûªs father). Since the Devil cannot touch a girl so pure and clean, he persuades the father to chop off her hands, which had been washed by her tears. In turn, she leaves her father in disgust, making her way in the world until happening upon a prince (JÌ©rÌ©mie ElkaÌøm), the sympathetic and caring figure her parent never was. Yet it‰Ûªs hardly happily ever after for a young woman running from the Devil.

Still trying to keep up appearances, despite being in a bad place, BÌ©atrice reaches out to Claire for the standard-issue movie melodrama reason: She‰Ûªs gravely ill (with a brain tumor) and is afraid of dying alone. Yet she won‰Ûªt alter her behavior, which includes a lot of smoking and drinking, some hard-core gambling and extravagant dining. Claire gives BÌ©atrice advice, refuses her proffered gifts and tries brushing her off, but of course she cannot. The tremor becomes something of a genuine seismic event for Claire.

But it ends up where all of these movies do: spiritually (if you can call it that). Here the corporeal manifestation of the spiritual conclusion is three characters of a certain age in the cab of a moving 18-wheeler, smiling and singing along to Serge Reggiani. If there‰Ûªs an American remake of this, the singer will be Jim Croce.

BÌ©atrice is not the title character of this film, written and directed by Martin Provost. That is Claire, played by Catherine Frot, a superb and prolific actress whose work in French cinema is not nearly as well known here as Ms. Deneuve‰Ûªs is. Claire is fantastic at her job: calm, expert, compassionate. She cares deeply about her work, which, as the movie opens, takes place at a birthing clinic that will soon be closing. She cares so deeply, for instance, that she keeps trying to resuscitate a stillborn baby, long after everyone else has faced reality, in one of the movie‰Ûªs many realistic medical scenes. (This one, in particular, was sufficiently convincing to arouse my terrified curiosity as to how it was achieved. The other childbirth scenes, and there are a fair number, also look authentic.)

But then a voice from the past sends a tremor into her placid life. That would be Ms. Deneuve‰Ûªs BÌ©atrice, a former mistress of Claire‰Ûªs father (now dead), whose abandonment of both her lover and his daughter engendered heartbreak and worse 30 or so years earlier.

Because it is a French film, or rather the kind of French film that wants to serve its sentimentality with a dollop of prestige, ‰ÛÏThe Midwife‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt offer an entirely shameless version of the ‰ÛÏdying free spirit imbues uptight caretaker with a new lust for life‰Ûù scenario. It doesn‰Ûªt spoon-feed the viewer a lot of exposition, leaving parts of the back story a little enigmatic. It drops in peculiar little character touches, including one bizarre bit concerning the resemblance between Claire‰Ûªs son, Simon, and his dear departed grandfather.

Claire‰Ûªs job appears to be the main focus of a tidy, organized, somewhat lonely life. A single mother, she has a son with whom she shares a tight bond, but he‰Ûªs approaching adulthood and getting ready to strike out on his own. On weekends, and after biking home from the clinic, she tends a garden in a shared plot of land. Her neighbor there, a friendly, salt-of-the-earth truck driver named Paul ‰ÛÓ played with simple amiability by Olivier Gourmet, the wonderful actor and good-luck charm for the Belgian filmmaker brothers Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne ‰ÛÓ takes an immediate strong liking to Claire. But she‰Ûªs not terribly interested in making any human connections beyond those she has with the mothers she helps, and the babies she delivers.

Catherine Deneuve has played a wide variety of roles over the course of a career now spanning seven decades. But despite her exemplary range, many American viewers maintain an image of her as an aloof, exquisite, possibly imperious, possibly enigmatic beauty. This is largely because she looks like, well, Catherine Deneuve. The woman can‰Ûªt help it. Even when portraying the needy, nearly shambolic BÌ©atrice in ‰ÛÏThe Midwife,‰Ûù Ms. Deneuve is capable of vibrating with an elegance that implies both hauteur and froideur.

Yet couching these achievements in a testament to Joseph Pulitzer‰Ûªs enduring genius seems trivializing. The novelist Michael Cunningham admits that a different jury might not have awarded his book ‰ÛÏThe Hours‰Ûù (‰ÛÏanother reason the prize goes into the sock drawer,‰Ûù he says). More charitably, Junot DÌ_az says he is surprised by how often the prizes get it right.

Past winners, including Wynton Marsalis, Paula Vogel, Tracy K. Smith and Tony Kushner, share insights on their writing processes and how the recognition has affected their careers. Celebrities like Natalie Portman and Martin Scorsese read from winning works, with which they are sometimes oddly paired.

An excellent example of what not to award, however, comes from ‰ÛÏThe Pulitzer at 100,‰Ûù an hour and a half of congratulatory platitudes timed to the prizes‰Ûª centennial. Although produced independently, this documentary, directed by Kirk Simon, plays as if the Pulitzers were presenting an award to themselves.

Although the Pulitzer Prizes go to literature and drama, they still don‰Ûªt recognize cinema. But adding movies to the list might only raise questions. Who would judge? Should fiction and documentary receive separate awards?

The best anecdotes aren‰Ûªt simple victory laps. Nicholas D. Kristof, a New York Times columnist, who received the award for his reporting on the Tiananmen Square democracy movement and his columns about the genocide in Darfur, notes ‰ÛÏa certain irony in gaining from a surge in human misery.‰Ûù Carol D. Leonnig of The Washington Post recounts her prizewinning coverage of Secret Service lapses. John Filo and Nick Ut explain how they photographed famous images of the Vietnam era. Reporters from The Times-Picayune recall Hurricane Katrina.
Also: Interplanetary, interspecies sex might function better as a sick joke than an earnest metaphor. That‰Ûªs a matter of taste, I guess.

There is another possibility, though, which is that ‰ÛÏThe Untamed‰Ûù is not a slice-of-life tale pretending to be a monster movie, but rather a bone-dry comedy pretending to be both of those things. There is a fine line between horror and humor, and if you adjust your angle of vision accordingly, you can see the architecture of farce beneath the ornamentation of shock and suffering. The meticulous deadpan of the performances diverts attention from the absurdity of the circumstances. FabiÌÁn, ÌÅngel and Alejandra are joined in a classic triangle, which VerÌ_nica and the alien throw into high relief even as they disrupt it.

Mr. Escalante‰Ûªs previous film, ‰ÛÏHeli,‰Ûù was about a factory worker caught up in Mexico‰Ûªs drug violence. It contains several horrific ‰ÛÓ and now notorious ‰ÛÓ scenes of brutality, but what makes those moments especially unnerving is the low-key domestic naturalism in which they are embedded. Mr. Escalante is an exceptionally deft and subtle realist, and you sometimes feel, in ‰ÛÏHeli‰Ûù and even more so in ‰ÛÏThe Untamed‰Ûù that he is drawn to extremity partly out of boredom with his own skill. And so he turns a downbeat melodrama of unhappy marriage, bohemian drift and sexual duplicity into something bizarre and horrific.

The thing ostensibly arrived on an asteroid, but its more salient provenance is a pornographic tradition, notably but not exclusively Japanese, that occasionally slithers into the cinematic mainstream. The alien, whose gender is indeterminate, is awesome in bed, though not always gentle. While its partners, male and female, experience inexpressible and addictive bliss in its company, some of them also suffer grievous and even fatal injuries.

Resolutely unsmiling and studiously austere, ‰ÛÏThe Untamed‰Ûù behaves like a quiet horror movie with a lot on its mind. Its main characters, who live in the central Mexican city of Guanajuato, are young, gloomy, attractive men and women connected by friendship, family ties and sexual longing and divided by those same things. The movie, directed by Amat Escalante from a script he wrote with GibrÌÁn Portela, might be a dour, observant study of modern relationships among the urban middle class were it not for the presence of a slimy, many-tentacled space creature living in a cabin in the countryside.

The first one we meet is VerÌ_nica (Simone Bucio). While being treated for an alien-sex-related mishap she pretends is a dog bite, she befriends FabiÌÁn (Eden Villavicencio), a nurse. His sister, Alejandra (Ruth Ramos), is married to ÌÅngel (JesÌ_s Meza), a drunken macho sad sack who is having an affair with FabiÌÁn. FabiÌÁn, encouraged by VerÌ_nica, finds his way to the extraterrestrial love shack (which is tended by a sweet, hippie-ish older couple). But it‰Ûªs Alejandra, neglected by ÌÅngel and stressed out by their two young sons and ÌÅngel‰Ûªs domineering mother, who seems like the most likely victim. Or lover. Or whatever you call it.

Their mission ‰ÛÓ do I have to do this part? ‰ÛÓ involves justice for the planet MÌ_l. Before it was destroyed, MÌ_l was a beachy paradise, a perpetual Ibiza on the morning after the best rave ever, populated by hairless lizard supermodels. The key to their bliss is a pocket-size dinosaur that excretes pearls. Only one is left in the universe. Valerian and Laureline are its intrepid pet-sitters.

Much as I hesitate to predict the future in such crazy times, I feel I can say with certainty that 2017 will go down in film history as the Year of the Crazy Dane DeHaan Movie. Already so far we have seen Mr. DeHaan, a 31-year-old actor endowed with poise, intelligence and superb eyebrows, in Gore Verbinski‰Ûªs highly puzzling ‰ÛÏA Cure for Wellness.‰Ûù If you missed that one, it was more or less ‰ÛÏThe Magic Mountain‰Ûù with incest and bloodsucking eels.

I don‰Ûªt know, and I suspect Mr. Besson doesn‰Ûªt either. Though it is based on a popular graphic novel series by Pierre Christin and Jean-Claude MÌ©ziÌ¬res, ‰ÛÏValerian and the City of a Thousand Planets‰Ûù feels as if it were made up on the spot, by someone so delighted by the gaudy genre packaging at his disposal that he lost track of what was supposed to be inside.

Mr. DeHaan plays Valerian and Ms. Delevingne plays Laureline, who are not his-and-hers dental hygiene products but rather soldiers in some kind of space army. They are also at least potentially a couple, a fact which authorizes a lot of dialogue that might technically be called ‰ÛÏbanter‰Ûù but that seems to have lost its snap after passing through Google translate a few times too many. Anyway, Valerian and Laureline are as cute as a pair of baby salamanders.

That promise is faithfully kept, but there is so much more going on. To say that ‰ÛÏValerian‰Ûù is a science-fiction epic doesn‰Ûªt quite do it justice. Imagine crushing a DVD of ‰ÛÏThe Phantom Menace‰Ûù into a fine powder, tossing in some Adderall and Ecstasy and a pinch of cayenne pepper and snorting the resulting mixture while wearing a virtual reality helmet in a Las Vegas karaoke bar. Actually, that sounds like too much fun, but you get the idea.

She‰Ûªs in this movie! Believe the posters, even though she shows up late and leaves early. She‰Ûªs called Bubble, she dances on a stripper pole and changes costumes in the blink of an eye until Mr. Besson‰Ûªs script cruelly casts her aside. Why? So we can ponder the villainy of Clive Owen in uniform? So we can watch Mr. DeHaan and Ms. Delevingne doing their finger-puppet Rock Hudson/Doris Day act? So we can come up with names for Valerian and Laureline‰Ûªs babies?

What about the City of a Thousand Planets? It‰Ûªs a multicultural celestial metropolis where our heroes do a bit of chasing and fighting, and its population includes some fine specimens of modern digital and prosthetic creature design as well as a few that are a bit, let‰Ûªs say, problematic. The City might be an interesting place to spend some time if a busy and chaotic story didn‰Ûªt keep getting in the way, and if we were allowed to hang out for a little while longer with Ethan Hawke and Rihanna.

‰ÛÏValerian and the City of a Thousand Planets,‰Ûù Mr. DeHaan‰Ûªs latest eyebrow-raiser ‰ÛÓ speaking of which, it also stars Cara Delevingne, perhaps the supreme superciliary celebrity of our time ‰ÛÓ is a bit harder to describe. It was written and directed by Luc Besson (‰ÛÏThe Fifth Element,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏArthur and the Invisibles‰Ûù) a fact that promises greater emphasis on visual panache than on feeling or coherence.

This seems fitting for a man who helped create ‰ÛÏBlade Runner,‰Ûù a film that is, among other things, about the fragments we try to piece together to tell our stories. Early in ‰ÛÏEscapes,‰Ûù Mr. Almereyda inserts some text from an unnamed movie that reads, ‰ÛÏHollywood, the star-strewn land of ‰Û÷Make Believe,‰Ûª where enchanted people dreamed it would all come true.‰Ûù Mr. Almereyda makes that quote part of Mr. Fancher‰Ûªs story and it could easily be read as cynical. Except Mr. Fancher defies that reading. As it turns out, he really was one of those enchanted people who, despite being born in the shadow of the Hollywood sign, managed to push his way into an industry that he also transcended.

Mr. Fancher has recently bobbed up again in the entertainment news, a resurfacing largely traceable to the forthcoming release of ‰ÛÏBlade Runner 2049,‰Ûù a long-anticipated sequel that he helped write. The original ‰ÛÏBlade Runner,‰Ûù a cult film directed by Ridley Scott that became a cinematic landmark, long ago cemented Mr. Fancher‰Ûªs place in movie history, especially for cinephiles. Yet you discover ‰ÛÓ story by story ‰ÛÓ there‰Ûªs more to his biography than one glorious credit. At the same time, part of the pleasure of ‰ÛÏEscapes‰Ûù is how Mr. Almereyda, drawing deeply from the American pop archives (comics, old movies and television), connects the original ‰ÛÏBlade Runner‰Ûù to Mr. Fancher‰Ûªs life with its movie love, romanticism, beautiful women and mad, circuitous rides.

Mr. Fancher‰Ûªs life soon emerges as an argument for living beyond one‰Ûªs limits and for style as something in the veins, as life. He didn‰Ûªt just dress up in costumes ‰ÛÓ as amusing family photos illustrate ‰ÛÓ he seems to have willed himself over the rainbow again and again. ‰ÛÏI lived in a fantasy world,‰Ûù he says in onscreen text early in the documentary. ‰ÛÏI was a spy. I was a hero. I was Humphrey Bogart.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs no wonder that Mr. Fancher became an actor and that years later, in transforming Philip K. Dick‰Ûªs science-fiction novel ‰ÛÏDo Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?‰Ûù into ‰ÛÏBlade Runner,‰Ûù he helped create a futuristic world-weary shamus with sharp Bogart flavor.

‰ÛÏEscapes‰Ûù takes an aptly twisty approach to its subject. The title seems to refer to Mr. Fancher‰Ûªs talent for leaving one world for another, getaways that Mr. Almereyda has gathered into discrete chapters. The first opens with an offscreen Mr. Fancher discussing the Spanish word ‰ÛÏduende‰Ûù over battered black-and-white images of a man being shot out of a saddle in a western. ‰ÛÏAnything that has death in it,‰Ûù Mr. Fancher says, ‰ÛÏand wants to live beyond its limits ‰ÛÓ that is expressive and crazy ‰ÛÓ that has duende.‰Ûù Elsewhere, the poet Federico GarcÌ_a Lorca wrote that duende is ‰ÛÏnot a question of skill, but of a style that‰Ûªs truly alive: meaning, it‰Ûªs in the veins: meaning, it‰Ûªs of the most ancient culture of immediate creation.‰Ûù

The writer Hampton Fancher, one of the seers behind the 1982 masterpiece ‰ÛÏBlade Runner,‰Ûù has led the kind of fantastically eventful life that seems the stuff of fiction. Born in East Los Angeles in 1938 to a white American father and Mexican-American mother, he announced to them at 11 that he was leaving school ‰ÛÓ and did. He ran wild, studied ballet and, after seeing a biopic about the silent-screen legend Rudolph Valentino, renamed himself Mario Montejo. By 15, Mario was en route to Spain to study flamenco. On the ship home, Marlon Brando invited him to dinner. A bashful Mario declined.

Mr. Fancher relates this anecdote about traveling in fast, starry company in ‰ÛÏEscapes,‰Ûù a thoroughly charming, thoroughly engaging portrait of this great adventurer written, directed and produced by Michael Almereyda. I‰Ûªm not entirely sure that the Brando invitation is true, even if Mr. Almereyda offers photo evidence that appears to partly back up Mr. Fancher. Yet it scarcely matters. What‰Ûªs important is the story and how Mr. Fancher turns every walk down memory lane into a leisurely, surprise-filled stroll through a labyrinth, taking us right and then left and then down apparent dead ends before guiding us home. Of course, how Mr. Almereyda tells these stories matters too.

Mr. Fancher‰Ûªs movie love and way of spinning a yarn to its near-breaking point ‰ÛÓ one detour opens onto another ‰ÛÓ dovetail nicely with the cinephilia and playfulness that characterize Mr. Almereyda‰Ûªs movies (‰ÛÏExperimenter‰Ûù). He folds plenty of tangy bits into ‰ÛÏEscapes‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ Mr. Fancher palled around with fame and was romantically involved with Sue Lyon and Barbara Hershey ‰ÛÓ but the movie is more essayistic gloss than definitive biography. It‰Ûªs a liberating take. Because, as Mr. Almereyda marshals his material, which includes Mr. Fancher digressing at length as well as clips from his early TV and film work, ‰ÛÏEscapes‰Ûù dodges the dreary obligations of the standard documentary profile to become an exploration of life as (if we‰Ûªre lucky) a long, endlessly inventive tale.

Directed by Catherine Bainbridge, ‰ÛÏRumble‰Ûù takes a few serious turns even as it remains lively throughout. If you couldn‰Ûªt name two Native American musicians at the beginning of the documentary, you‰Ûªll remember at least a half-dozen after the end. And it‰Ûªs a good bet you‰Ûªll be searching for their albums, too.

Charley Patton, who profoundly shaped the blues, is profiled in another section before the film moves to Mildred Bailey, Jesse Ed Davis, members of the band Redbone and others, all of whom had Indian heritage. We hear about childhoods spent listening and learning from grandparents who passed on traditions, and of discrimination encountered in the broader world. ‰ÛÏBe proud you‰Ûªre an Indian, but be careful who you tell,‰Ûù Mr. Robertson, who is part Mohawk, says of a prevailing attitude when he was younger.

Shorter sections explore American Indian rhythms and beats that seeped into popular music, and the deep connections the players forged with African-American performers. Newsreels and old black-and-white photos provide historical context, and interviews add plenty of energy. Martin Scorsese and Iggy Pop offer insights, while Steven Van Zandt‰Ûªs enthusiasm is contagious. After hearing a story by Jackson Browne, you‰Ûªll listen to his ‰ÛÏDoctor My Eyes‰Ûù with different ears.

The survey starts with the guitarist Link Wray, who was Shawnee. Wray ‰ÛÏmade an indelible mark on the whole evolution of where rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll was going to go,‰Ûù Robbie Robertson of the Band says. Wray‰Ûªs 1958 single, ‰ÛÏRumble,‰Ûù was banned from airplay in several cities amid worries that it would incite teenage gang violence (despite being a wordless, instrumental tune), and Wray‰Ûªs guitar line seems to echo in every power chord you‰Ûªve heard.
It‰Ûªs been a terrific few years for music documentaries, and that winning streak continues with ‰ÛÏRumble: The Indians Who Rocked the World.‰Ûù

Sharing the same spirit of ‰ÛÏ20 Feet From Stardom‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏSearching for Sugar Man,‰Ûù which both put overlooked performers center stage, this film examines the influence of Native Americans on popular music. What at first seems like a thin topic ‰ÛÓ quick, name two American Indian musicians ‰ÛÓ becomes a master class in the mixing of cultures.
‰ÛÏYou trick people with your boyishness,‰Ûù Jean says.

Still, working with what was surely a minuscule budget, Ms. Jungermann supplies an awful lot of humor ‰ÛÓ some of it light, the best of it dark ‰ÛÓ in ‰ÛÏWomen Who Kill.‰Ûù Afterward, you may be compelled to go out for a drink, not just to discuss the story‰Ûªs peculiar ending, but also because this film‰Ûªs dryness leaves you feeling parched, in a very satisfying way.
The humor is dry and the acting deadpan in ‰ÛÏWomen Who Kill,‰Ûù a comedy that plays it droll and is all the funnier for it.

Those lines and dozens of others are made sharper by the cast members, whose expressions are locked into permanent poker faces. Ms. Jungermann, who also wrote and directed this, her first feature, knows how to devise fast-moving and clever conversations. She‰Ûªs even better at tacking a silence onto the end of a line, where it can prompt you to snort when you‰Ûªre done laughing.
‰ÛÏI can‰Ûªt help it I can lift semi-heavy things,‰Ûù Morgan replies.

Set in gentrified sections of Park Slope, Brooklyn, the tale centers on Morgan (Ingrid Jungermann) and Jean (Ann Carr), former lovers who still live together and produce the podcast of the title, which profiles female serial killers. Near the end of one episode, the two women debate which murderer is the hottest. Soon they go to a prison to visit a convict (Annette O‰ÛªToole, a hoot), and along the way argue over their breakup.

‰ÛÏI‰Ûªd rather be with somebody that scares me to death than somebody that bores me to death,‰Ûù Morgan says in a dig at her ex, who replies: ‰ÛÏGo ahead, move in with her and get married and have a family that she can stab in the middle of the night.‰Ûù

As the movie enters its second half, however, some of that repetitive wryness can lead to slow sections as the is-she-or-isn‰Ûªt-she-a-killer plot runs on, reaching for noir while relegating the wit to secondary status. Shannon Patricia O‰ÛªNeill, as Alex, a foul-mouthed friend, and Grace Rex, as Kim, her fiancÌ©e, add energy, but a bit more physical comedy would be welcome.

Later, at a food co-op, Morgan meets Simone (Sheila Vand), a mysterious beauty. They begin a romance that borders on the strange, then grows downright eerie when Jean begins to suspect that Simone is a serial killer. Before some enticing evidence surfaces, Morgan is skeptical, and wonders if Jean may just be jealous.

The answers, of course, can hardly be objective. The language of cinematic action ‰ÛÓ which Ms. Bigelow speaks as fluently and inventively as any living American director ‰ÛÓ is an idiom of feeling and visceral response. There are parts of ‰ÛÏDetroit‰Ûù that have a raw, unsettled authenticity, and others that sink in a welter of screaming and cursing.

The movie, which paints a sometimes muddled picture of a chaotic and contested moment in history, is admirably clear in this regard. It understands and strives to dramatize racism not as a matter of bad personal attitudes or equal and opposite prejudices, but rather as a structuring fact of American life, an apparatus of power, exclusion and control wielded against ‰ÛÏthem.‰Ûù

The film opens with the assertion that in Detroit and elsewhere in the mid-1960s, ‰ÛÏchange had to come‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏthe question was when and how.‰Ûù But the promise implied in that ‰ÛÏhow‰Ûù is one that ‰ÛÏDetroit,‰Ûù for all its impressive craft and unimpeachable intention, proves unable to fulfill. It is curious that a movie set against a backdrop of black resistance and rebellion ‰ÛÓ however inchoate and self-destructive its expression may have been ‰ÛÓ should become a tale of black helplessness and passivity. The white men, the decent ones as much as the brutes, have the answers, the power, the agency.

The Algiers becomes a trap, not only for the characters, who are stuck inside at the mercy of a maniac, but for the film itself, which loses its political and psychological coherence as the night drags on. Krauss, with his disconcertingly boyish looks and his sophomoric attempts to seem thoughtful, is a callow sociopath. His fellow officers Flynn (Ben O‰ÛªToole) and Demens (Jack Reynor) contribute sexual hysteria (when they see white women in the company of black men) and sheer idiocy. They are terrifying and contemptible ‰ÛÓ dismayingly believable figures from the prehistory of what is now called the alt-right.

Racial slurs fly fast and furious in Kathryn Bigelow‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDetroit,‰Ûù but the most troubling and divisive words uttered onscreen are variations on the simple pronouns ‰ÛÏthey‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏthem.‰Ûù The words may be perfectly neutral in themselves, but when used to separate one group of people from another they take on an insidious, implicitly violent connotation.

Ms. Bigelow and Mark Boal, the screenwriter (who collaborated with her on ‰ÛÏThe Hurt Locker‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏZero Dark Thirty‰Ûù), train their focus on two aspects of the Detroit story: the day-to-day texture of working-class black life and the operations of white supremacy in conditions of emergency. Balancing those concerns is no easy task, and the filmmakers don‰Ûªt take an easy route through their material. ‰ÛÏDetroit,‰Ûù like its namesake city, is populous and contradictory, with dozens of significant characters competing for attention as richly detailed scenes swell in crescendos of desperate suspense and sickening brutality.

Early scenes ‰ÛÓ following a gorgeous animated prologue that uses Jacob Lawrence paintings to evoke the decades of job discrimination, residential segregation and heavy-handed law enforcement that preceded the 1967 riots in Detroit and other Northern cities ‰ÛÓ zero in on the rebellion‰Ûªs immediate cause: a late-night police raid on an unlicensed saloon.

Down the hall is Greene (Anthony Mackie), a soldier just back from Vietnam. A few blocks away, Melvin Dismukes (Mr. Boyega), a black security guard protecting a grocery store, brings coffee to a group of National Guardsmen, a gesture of diplomacy as well as self-protection. ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt want those boys shooting at us,‰Ûù he tells his co-worker. Meanwhile, three patrolmen cruise the city. One of them, Krauss (Mr. Poulter), is still on the job after fatally shooting an unarmed looting suspect in the back.

‰ÛÏDetroit‰Ûù is set mainly during the rioting that convulsed that city in the summer of 1967, and in it ‰ÛÏthem‰Ûù is most often used ‰ÛÓ along with cognates like ‰ÛÏthose people‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏyou people‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ by white soldiers and police officers to refer to African-American citizens. (Nearly every white character with a speaking role wears a uniform of some kind.) Occasionally things go in the other direction, with ‰ÛÏthey‰Ûù referring to the white authorities, but the reversal doesn‰Ûªt indicate any kind of symmetry.

But as their villainy comes into relief, the humanity of their hostages begins to blur. In a horror movie, the monster is inevitably the center of interest, and once the first body in the motel falls, ‰ÛÏDetroit‰Ûù begins to trade its vivid sense of nuance ‰ÛÓ especially present in its delicate observation of Fred and Larry‰Ûªs friendship ‰ÛÓ for bluntness and sensationalism. A complex, dreadful piece of history becomes an undialectical ordeal of viciousness and victimhood.

Amid the fire and looting and the audio and video clips of the Michigan governor George W. Romney and President Lyndon B. Johnson, a narrower plot takes shape, a real-life horror movie folded into a baggier film that feels, by turns, like a combat picture, a cavalry western, a police procedural and a courtroom drama.

The nightmare that brought them all together is remembered as the Algiers Motel incident. It‰Ûªs a notably ugly chapter in the annals of late-60s urban violence, and one that has an especially grim resonance in our own time. Three black men were shot to death ‰ÛÓ nine other people were terrorized and beaten ‰ÛÓ after the police and guardsmen arrived at the motel, responding to reports of sniper fire.

At moments (the quietest as well as some of the most intense), you feel in tune with both the fine grain of experience and the larger sweep of history. The specific, close-up acts of cruelty you witness are comprehensible as manifestations of a systemic, continuing and frequently invisible pattern of injustice. The film‰Ûªs struggle against simplification ‰ÛÓ against the sentimentality, wishful thinking and outright denial that defines most Hollywood considerations of America‰Ûªs racial past ‰ÛÓ is palpable, almost heroic, even if it is not always successful.

The filmmakers seem aware of this problem. They try toward the end to give the movie back, in effect, to its African-American characters, to refuse to let racism have the final word and to free themselves of storytelling conventions that insist on comfort and consensus. It doesn‰Ûªt quite work. American movies have a hard time with division and with real-world problems that have yet to be solved. American politics does, too. The great virtue of ‰ÛÏDetroit‰Ûù is that it recognizes this difficulty. The failure to overcome it is hardly the film‰Ûªs alone.

What matters more to Ms. Bigelow and Mr. Boal than plot twists or surprises ‰ÛÓ and to an audience torn between the urge to lean in and the desire to look away ‰ÛÓ is the minute-by-minute unspooling of accident, error and intentional evil that produced a tragic result. The important thing is not the literal accuracy of the overall account (though Mr. Boal, a former journalist, has been diligent in his research) but its plausibility. Is this what could have happened? Does it feel true?

The opening 20 minutes register Ms. Bigelow‰Ûªs virtuosity as a choreographer of chaos. She illuminates volatile and unpredictable circumstances with amazing poise and precision, producing an intuitive understanding of events that quickly spiral beyond the control or comprehension of their participants. Her combination of efficiency and expressiveness is matched by the actors ‰ÛÓ a formidable, mostly youthful ensemble including John Boyega, Will Poulter, Algee Smith and Jason Mitchell ‰ÛÓ even though the script at times inhibits their range, locking them into simple stances of aggression and fear.

Real events depicted in movies can‰Ûªt exactly be given away, and this episode, while not as notorious as some other race-related murders of its era, isn‰Ûªt all that obscure. (It is the subject of a book by John Hersey, a writer for The New Yorker, published a year after the riots and reissued in 1997 with an informative introduction by the historian Thomas J. Sugrue.) The basic arc of the story ‰ÛÓ the killing of unarmed black men, the spasm of outrage, the impunity ultimately bestowed on the perpetrators ‰ÛÓ is always shocking and rarely surprising. I‰Ûªm sorry if that‰Ûªs a spoiler.

The fates of a collection of black and white Detroiters (as well as two unlucky visitors from Ohio) converge at a motel on the west side of the city. Two friends, Fred (Jacob Latimore) and Larry (Mr. Smith), are looking for a little fun after a disappointing evening at the Fox Theater downtown. They flirt with Karen (Kaitlyn Dever) and Julie (Hannah Murray), two white women, and join a makeshift party in a room belonging to Carl Cooper (Mr. Mitchell).

If there is a thesis in this new documentary, directed by Bonni Cohen and Jon Shenk (‰ÛÏAudrie & Daisy‰Ûù), it‰Ûªs that a rise in extreme weather is making the impact of climate change harder to deny. The movie touches on Hurricane Sandy, Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines, the wildfire in Fort McMurray, Canada, and the Zika virus. Mr. Gore visits Greenland and the flooded streets of the Miami area. (He acknowledges a complicated relationship with Florida.)
‰ÛÏThe dots are seldom connected in the media,‰Ûù he says at one point, but events like these are symptoms of global warming.

‰ÛÏAn Inconvenient Sequel‰Ûù delves deeper into the arcane details of compromise than its predecessor, with scenes of Mr. Gore working to find a middle ground between the needs of developed and developing nations. In a group meeting, Piyush Goyal, India‰Ûªs power minister, pushes back against Mr. Gore‰Ûªs desire to replicate in India the expanded use of solar energy in the United States. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll do the same thing after 150 years,‰Ûù Mr. Goyal replies.

In a summer movie landscape with Spider-Man, a simian army waging further battle for the planet and Charlize Theron as a sexy Cold War-era superspy, it says something that one of the most compelling characters is Al Gore.

As positive developments, he notes the 2015 launch of the Deep Space Climate Observatory satellite, and visits a small city in Texas whose Republican mayor has decided that renewable energy makes market sense.

‰ÛÏAn Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power,‰Ûù a follow-up to ‰ÛÏAn Inconvenient Truth,‰Ûù Davis Guggenheim‰Ûªs Oscar-winning documentary from 2006, is a reboot that justifies its existence ‰ÛÓ and not just because Mr. Gore has fresh news to report on climate change since his previous multimedia presentation played in multiplexes.

Mr. Gore likens President Trump‰Ûªs election to a quip often attributed to Mike Tyson: You always have a plan until you get punched in the face. The movie has been updated since its premiere at the Sundance Film Festival in January to include Mr. Trump‰Ûªs announcement of the United States‰Ûª withdrawal from the Paris climate accord, a decision that probably forecasts another sequel.

Now gray-haired and at times sounding angrier in his speeches, Mr. Gore, in ‰ÛÏSequel,‰Ûù takes on the air of a Shakespearean figure, a man long cast out of power by what he casually refers to as ‰ÛÏthe Supreme Court decision‰Ûù (meaning Bush v. Gore) but still making the same arguments that have been hallmarks of his career.

During the 2015 Paris Climate Change Conference, Mr. Gore, who wasn‰Ûªt an official negotiator, tries to persuade Lyndon Rive, then chief executive of the American company SolarCity, to grant India the rights to a patent on a type of solar technology. (The results aren‰Ûªt clear from the film; India signed on to the Paris agreement without making a deal with SolarCity and still hasn‰Ûªt made one.)

As she does, Ms. Theron locks down your attention immediately, holding you with her beauty and quiet vigilance. (She lets you see that she knows you‰Ûªre watching her.) Plenty of pretty people slide right off the screen. Ms. Theron, by contrast, holds you partly because she doesn‰Ûªt seem eager to let you in, keeping you curious as she keeps you at bay with reserve and sphinxlike smiles. This distance adds to her mystery and it also makes the eruptions of violence more electric. As ‰ÛÏMad Max: Fury Road‰Ûù confirmed, she‰Ûªs a natural warrior, but it‰Ûªs interesting here that each exertion and exhalation, each meaty, pulpy thump, also seems to be battering the fortifications that she has built around her.

For her part, Ms. Theron looks hot and color coordinated, with black-and-white outfits that suit her character‰Ûªs ambiguity. Lorraine smokes and drinks and likes cold baths, preferably filled with ice cubes that do wonders for bruises and nipples. When she isn‰Ûªt moodily bathing or staring ‰ÛÓ into a mirror, the distance, what have you ‰ÛÓ she does a surprising amount of walking. She goes here, promenades there, strolling down halls and mean streets that the director David Leitch turns into fashion runways. She doesn‰Ûªt slip into rooms, she cat-walks, making entrances as if looking for trouble or paparazzi; it‰Ûªs no wonder someone says she isn‰Ûªt well disguised. Ms. Theron really is ready to play Bond.

Lorraine gets plenty of opportunities to mix it up in Berlin, where the story soon turns into spy versus spy with washes of lurid color, topsy-turvy camerawork, loads of crashing cars and wall-to-wall pounding tunes. The airborne cars pirouette prettily, bashing and smashing with all the technological expertise production money can buy; the symphony of body blows, gun pops and crunching metal sounds fine and convincing. The tunes (‰ÛÏ99 Luftballons‰Ûù) basically just goose the violence and beg for laughs, having been chosen to elicit knowing smiles of recognition. At one point, James McAvoy sidles into the story looking all cool or something and wearing a smirk he needs to employ more cautiously.

This sort of spectacle ‰ÛÓ dress her up, dress her down, smack her around and wait for payback ‰ÛÓ isn‰Ûªt new, even if moviemakers like to insist otherwise. What‰Ûªs moderately different here is the sexed-up packaging of the violence in combination with Ms. Theron, who plays Lorraine Broughton, a spy in Her Majesty‰Ûªs Secret Service with a blond bob and a fondness for lethal heels. Like James Bond, Lorraine shoots to kill while remaining fabulously dressed to kill. This means she gets slammed around a lot, and takes almost as much punishment as she metes out. She‰Ûªs a punching bag, but she‰Ûªs also a fantasist‰Ûªs dream girl: the avenging goddess, destroyer of men.

Written by Kurt Johnstad, ‰ÛÏAtomic Blonde‰Ûù is based on ‰ÛÏThe Coldest City,‰Ûù a darkly shadowed, minimalist graphic novel written by Antony Johnston and illustrated by Sam Hart. As in the novel, the movie continually shifts between Berlin, where all the action happens, and an interrogation room in which Lorraine is being drilled by some intelligence types (John Goodman, Toby Jones). On the page, this bifurcation works, but on the screen it saps the story‰Ûªs momentum, partly because there‰Ûªs no violence in the room to distract from the genericism and puerility of the dialogue. At least in Berlin there are streets, beats and the sight of restlessly moving, twisting, slamming bodies.

Mr. Leitch was one of the directors on ‰ÛÏJohn Wick,‰Ûù a model of economic genre filmmaking, and he gives this movie‰Ûªs action scenes the same pummeling, visceral quality. Lorraine punches and is punched, and her body is soon mapped by bruises and abrasions. It‰Ûªs a lot of abuse for such puny returns, even if the fights are the best parts of ‰ÛÏAtomic Blonde.‰Ûù Mr. Leitch understands the expressivity of hand-to-hand fights and he frames them accordingly, pushing in when it counts and pulling back to show entire bodies in whirling motion. The closeness underscores the intimacy of battle while the distance underlines the performative aspect, allowing you to see both the choreography and the violent beauty moving forward and backward one bloody step at a time.

‰ÛÏAtomic Blonde‰Ûù is going to make an excellent highlight reel. It already is one, in a manner of speaking, given that its strengths are lavishly violent, inventively choreographed fights that have been glued together by nonsense and Charlize Theron. The nonsense involves spies chasing secrets in Berlin just before the fall of the wall, which may suggest John le CarrÌ© but plays closer to a dumb and dumber take on Boris and Natasha. Mostly, the movie is an excuse to watch a beautiful, deviously clever female avatar as she is stripped naked, dolled up and repeatedly beaten down only to rise again.

That‰Ûªs partly what ‰ÛÏBrigsby Bear‰Ûù is about, though mostly it‰Ûªs a sweet and sometimes delightful melancholic story of a lonely man saved by imagination and love. That sounds like a bushel of cornball and might have devolved into pure ick if the director, Dave McCary, didn‰Ûªt lead from the heart and wasn‰Ûªt adept at navigating seemingly clashing tones. He hooks you early with an uneasily ha-ha, strange opener in which James and two others ‰ÛÓ Jane Adams plays April while a warm, wonderful Mark Hamill plays Ted ‰ÛÓ engage in ‰ÛÏBrigsby‰Ûù banter. Soon, sirens are flashing and the movie darkens; a few beats later, it brightens, then swerves into silliness only to veer into seriousness.

Much of what follows involves James‰Ûªs confusing, awkward reintroduction into the world, or what some call adulthood. There‰Ûªs the family he‰Ûªs never met (Matt Walsh, Michaela Watkins, Ryan Simpkins); a friendly cop (Greg Kinnear); and a clueless therapist (Claire Danes). There are new buddies (Jorge Lendeborg Jr.), who with smiles, mood enhancers and some unpersuasive narrative nudging help usher James into the here and now. Yet James, having been cut off from Brigsby World, can‰Ûªt quit the bear, who‰Ûªs seen every so often saving the day in some of the wittily conceptualized, visually degraded television clips sprinkled throughout the movie. And, really, why should James turn off the love?

If this sounds familiar, it‰Ûªs no wonder. Who, after all, hasn‰Ûªt taped a Marilyn Monroe poster on her college-dorm door or hung a really nice poster for the film ‰ÛÏAnatomy of a Murder‰Ûù on a wall? People have been surrounding themselves with objects of worship since time immemorial, even if today‰Ûªs fetish is more likely to be a Chewbacca collectible than a terra-cotta object. Sure, in the age of global corporate media and cross-platform branding, fandom is a cradle-to-grave commodity lifestyle, from ‰ÛÏStar Wars‰Ûù onesies to superhero coffins. And, yes, this isn‰Ûªt always cosplay; it‰Ûªs a matter of life (and death).

The absurd and absurdly charming ‰ÛÏBrigsby Bear‰Ûù sounds, well, unbearable. It‰Ûªs the story of a young man who, after decades of being shut away from the world, splashes down in it like a space alien. There are reasons for his re-entry, though that‰Ûªs getting ahead of the story, which uses a queasy crime as a jumping-off point to spin a largely sweet, often very funny fairy tale about the perils and the sustaining pleasures of obsessive fandom. Mostly, it is an account of one man‰Ûªs great, mad love, one that‰Ûªs mocked, tested and deemed near-pathological ‰ÛÓ a familiar plight for many superfans.

Mr. Mooney, currently cutting it up on ‰ÛÏSaturday Night Live,‰Ûù manages the twists and tonal fluctuations in ‰ÛÏBrigsby Bear‰Ûù beautifully. (He wrote the story and shares screenwriting credit with Kevin Costello.) It‰Ûªs no surprise that he can sustain and complicate a deadpan. But what makes the character work is the unconditional emotional seriousness that shapes the performance, deepening each glance and gesture. Mr. McCary fills the movie with modest comic jolts, from James‰Ûªs shock of hair to the near-Lynchian cardboard surrealism of the ‰ÛÏBrigsby‰Ûù show. The biggest jolt, though, is how each laugh brings forth more feeling in a movie that flirts with tragedy but opts for joy.

The obsession in question is ‰ÛÏBrigsby Bear,‰Ûù an amusingly weird live-action children‰Ûªs television show that James (Kyle Mooney) has been faithfully watching since childhood. Now somewhere in his 20s, James shows no sign of moving on. He doesn‰Ûªt merely love the plucky, heroic bear ‰ÛÓ as well as Brigsby‰Ûªs adorable helpers, the Smiles Sisters, and his villainous foe, the Sun Snatcher; James has absorbed the show, its stories and ethos into his being. His walls are lined with images from it; his shelves are crammed with recordings of each episode and related paraphernalia. He can mouth old dialogue verbatim. He even sleeps on ‰ÛÏBrigsby‰Ûù sheets, as if tucking into his own fanboy nest.

A full accounting of the silliness of ‰ÛÏFrom the Land of the Moon‰Ûù requires revealing a surprise near the end. Few viewers are likely to make it that far, so let‰Ûªs start where many will stop: the English-language title, whose meaning is never clarified.

Instead of a land of the moon, Nicole Garcia‰Ûªs mostly turgid, occasionally risible period piece, largely set in the 1950s, initially takes us to Lyon, France. Gabrielle (Marion Cotillard) spots a familiar address on a building that prompts flashbacks to a lost love.

But when Gabrielle receives a diagnosis of kidney stones ‰ÛÓ the subtitles translate the French term ‰ÛÏmal de pierres‰Ûù as ‰ÛÏstones sickness‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ she travels to the Alps. There, the film offers ‰ÛÏA Cure for Wellness‰Ûù unexpected competition for the most ludicrous 2017 release set in a Swiss spa.

Ms. Cotillard can be magnetic even when playing an unplayable character, but when Gabrielle falls for a veteran (Louis Garrel, who has perfected the facial expression of someone looking for another conversation), the chasm between her abilities and her co-star‰Ûªs is mountainous.

In her youth, she chases after a teacher with an almost feral abandon, privately licking his copy of ‰ÛÏWuthering Heights.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs not clear whether she‰Ûªs mad, as some think, or whether her longings result from a repressive upbringing. The movie barely seems to decide.

Gabrielle‰Ûªs mother (Brigitte RoÌ_an) arranges for her to marry a Catalan laborer (Alex BrendemÌ_hl), who is bizarrely nonchalant about the deal. (At Gabrielle‰Ûªs request, he agrees never to have sex with her.)

Directed by Ernesto Contreras from a script by his brother Carlos, the movie opens as a young linguist, MartÌ_n (Fernando ÌÅlvarez Rebeil), enters a remote Mexican hamlet to record the last speakers of a dying language. As it happens, they are two old men who have been enemies for 50 years.

This is one of those movies in which every shot is beautiful. Conventionally beautiful, that is. ‰ÛÏI Dream in Another Language‰Ûù features lush tropical landscapes and attractive, compelling people, always lit ‰ÛÓ not quite just so (the filmmakers clearly know better) ‰ÛÓ with exemplary attention to the most eye-catching detail. It‰Ûªs delectably watchable.

One, Isauro (JosÌ© Manuel Poncelis), is a hermit who speaks only the dying language. The other, Evaristo (Eligio MelÌ©ndez), is a well-respected village elder who also speaks Spanish. Their falling-out decades before involved the woman Evaristo married. That woman is long dead, but Evaristo has an attractive granddaughter, Lluvia (FÌÁtima Molina), of whom, he says to MartÌ_n, ‰ÛÏYou lay a hand on her, I‰Ûªll kill you.‰Ûù In the next scene, MartÌ_n and Lluvia are shown together in bed.

So ‰ÛÏI Dream in Another Language‰Ûù is that kind of movie, too. The story is not without interest, and it touches on a couple of worthwhile themes: cultural erasure and the way religious and provincial prejudices can suppress love. But its treatment of these subjects is perhaps undercut by its conventionality, which even extends to the movie‰Ûªs left turn into a kind of magic realism late in the story.

There, Cassidy (Virginia Kull), an aspiring actress with no real prospects, takes a job as a courier for Barry (Ed Begley Jr.), a diamond importer who is seeing Cassidy‰Ûªs mother (Marilu Henner). The job requires Cassidy to carry diamonds to nearby stores. The theory is that security firms get robbed; an ordinary woman on the street will not. And if she does get robbed, Alex (Ashton Holmes), Barry‰Ûªs son, tells her, the business has insurance. Since they are both broke, the temptations are obvious.

Mr. Singer, who wrote, directed and scored the film, mines a fair amount of comedy from Cassidy‰Ûªs attempts to recruit an accomplice, Ray (Zach McGowan), her ex and a former drug dealer who, unfortunately for her and Alex, has embarked on a period of self-improvement.

The title ‰ÛÏImperfections‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt lie: Viewers of David Singer‰Ûªs microbudgeted directorial debut will have to endure plenty of baggy scenes and awkward exchanges to enjoy the upside of this modest con movie, which has the charming, almost anachronistic noir setting of Chicago‰Ûªs Jewelers Row district. (As a former Chicagoan, I‰Ûªll confess to some affection for the location, around the corner from the city‰Ûªs main screening room for movie critics.)

The characters‰Ûª musings about regrets ‰ÛÓ life is imperfect, you see ‰ÛÓ seem superfluous, the byproducts of an overwritten screenplay. Most of the movie‰Ûªs pleasures come from Ms. Kull, a better actress than the one she plays, and the convolutions of the plot, which has a few good feints and dodges.

Over the week, the two bond, argue and work, all of it shown with a naturalism that can be clumsy or graceful, but it always feels authentic. One mostly silent scene, showing them simply spending time with each other, is moving in its affection. Another scene, when Menashe is on a date arranged by a matchmaker, generates both winces and laughs.

My heart broke a little near the end of ‰ÛÏMenashe,‰Ûù a sweet comedy that‰Ûªs not without a bit of sadness. For sure, this funny and tender film prompts cheerful smiles, but sometimes they turn melancholy.

The film is worth praising for what it is and admiring for what it‰Ûªs not ‰ÛÓ there‰Ûªs no sappiness or false emotion, and none of the clichÌ©d, quirky misfits who populate so many commercial comedies. (It‰Ûªs a fine addition to several recent indie features, including ‰ÛÏMan Push Cart‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏStand Clear of the Closing Doors,‰Ûù that examine pockets of overlooked city dwellers.) ‰ÛÏMenashe‰Ûù also gently raises a few questions about faith, change and conformity.

Menashe himself is not always easy to like. He can be clever and friendly yet foolish and wrong: In other words, he‰Ûªs awfully real. At times you‰Ûªll feel like shaking him in frustration for his actions. But minutes later, you‰Ûªll want to put an arm around this big man‰Ûªs shoulder and, together with him, hope that things will be all right.

Outside of his job, he has a bigger worry: regaining custody of his son. Menashe is a widower, and his orthodox Jewish faith requires him to raise his child, Rieven (Ruben Niborski), in a home with a mother. A rabbi has decreed that until Menashe remarries, Rieven must live with an aunt and uncle. That same rabbi, however, has allowed father and son to spend a week together before Rieven returns to those relatives.

The script, which he wrote with Alex Lipschultz and Musa Syeed, was inspired by Mr. Lustig‰Ûªs experiences, and the actors are nonprofessionals whose performances ring true. Mr. Lustig is wonderfully empathetic, still more so when he‰Ûªs paired with the splendid young Mr. Niborski.
