Joshua Z. Weinstein, the director, shot the film in Yiddish and often in secret in Hasidic neighborhoods. His images are unaffected and candid, with wordless close-ups that speak for themselves. Mr. Weinstein made documentaries before this, his first fiction feature, and it shows.

Set in a Hasidic neighborhood in Borough Park, Brooklyn, the story finds the title character (played by Menashe Lustig) working in a small supermarket. He‰Ûªs constantly berated by his boss and others, and their criticisms aren‰Ûªt always without cause: Menashe is often late and prone to blunders, and is usually short of money.

In expanding his 2014 short film, the writer and director Dustin Guy Defa re-enlisted his friend Bene Coopersmith, a Red Hook record shop owner with limited acting experience, for this low-budget indie feature unfolding over the course of a day and divided into several separate story lines. Mr. Coopersmith‰Ûªs, though, is one of the more watchable and entertaining. He‰Ûªs a real character. When he sets out to buy a rare Charlie Parker record, the camera, shooting in grainy 16 millimeter, follows him on a journey around Brooklyn, which includes a funny sequence involving a bike chase, and a recurring bit in which Mr. Coopersmith frets about his new shirt. (Is it too sharp?)

Among the other ensemble members are Michael Cera, as a reporter desperate to connect, and Abbi Jacobson, as an awkward newbie reporter, afraid of failure; Tavi Gevinson, who plays an angsty teenager questioning her sexuality and other weighty issues; a spot-on Philip Baker Hall, as a withdrawn watchmaker who may hold the key to a mysterious death; and George Sample III, convincing as an anguished man facing the consequences of an act of vengeance.

Despite some notable names in ‰ÛÏPerson to Person,‰Ûù it‰Ûªs the lesser-known actors who leave an impression. But maybe that‰Ûªs not entirely surprising for a movie loosely about authenticity and the little absurdities that abound in New York City.

While Mr. Defa‰Ûªs dialogue mostly flows naturally from Mr. Coopersmith, it can seem too self-aware and precious in the other characters‰Ûª mouths. And the soundtrack ‰ÛÓ an infectious blend of retro gospel, R&B and funk ‰ÛÓ often feels too breezy and soulful for this mundane affair, especially when it precedes scenes with pouty teenagers, even if they‰Ûªre world-weary sorts.

These dogs are portrayed as elite athletes, born to run, but the film points out that they are asked to, in effect, run a marathon day after day for the course of the Iditarod. There are disturbing scenes from the trail of dogs who cannot go farther and must be carried to the veterinarians at the next checkpoint.

The filmmaker Fern Levitt says that her research began with no agenda but that as she saw more abuse, her film took shape, along with a desire to shut down the industry and find homes for the dogs. She makes a moving argument, introducing us to animals who start training as puppies and often end up tethered to a short chain ‰ÛÓ when they aren‰Ûªt pulling tourists or racing. Sadder still are the cases of dogs who are killed when they are no longer useful, like the 100 animals shot by a recreational sledding company near Whistler, British Columbia.

It‰Ûªs easy to fall in love with the animals in ‰ÛÏSled Dogs.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs thornier to sift through the words of the handlers and mushers ‰ÛÓ many of whom seem to genuinely care for the dogs ‰ÛÓ and determine how pervasive abuse is in dog-sledding ventures.
Ms. Levitt went on a sled ride once, and after a look behind the scenes, took a dog home with her. She will make you want to do the same.

In Alaska, the 1,000-mile Iditarod, from Anchorage to Nome, is the pinnacle of the sport. According to lore, the inspiration for the race was an emergency run to deliver serum to Nome, which was on the brink of a diphtheria epidemic. But that was a relay, taking on fresh mushers and dogs periodically, whereas Iditarod racers use a single team.

A case of excellent actors‰Ûª straining to elevate a contrived screenplay, ‰ÛÏStrange Weather,‰Ûù directed by Katherine Dieckmann (the atmospheric ‰ÛÏDiggers‰Ûù), casts Holly Hunter as Darcy, an academic administrator, at a university in Georgia. Darcy is at a crossroads: Applying for a belated bachelor‰Ûªs degree, she may soon lose her job to budget cuts. Her son, Walker, committed suicide seven years earlier.

The journey is a pretext for healing, as Darcy visits an old friend (Glenne Headly, who died in June) and Walker‰Ûªs father (Ted Ferguson), who abused her but is now ailing and mute. This gives Darcy a chance to unburden her thoughts to him while allowing Ms. Dieckmann, who wrote the screenplay, to avoid the complications of constructing a conversation.
That‰Ûªs the movie in a nutshell: A catharsis more meaningful for the character than for her audience.

Darcy soon learns that Mark (Shane Jacobsen), a friend of Walker‰Ûªs, has grown wealthy after founding a chain of hot dog restaurants ‰ÛÓ Walker‰Ûªs idea. Conspiring to confront Mark in New Orleans, she brings along her friend Byrd (Carrie Coon) and the gun Walker used to kill himself, probably more for symbolism than for proving Chekhov‰Ûªs axiom.

It may be time to retire the type of road movie in which the protagonist, ostensibly on an urgent journey, insists on taking back roads ‰ÛÓ partly because she doesn‰Ûªt like trucks, she says, but really because a quick drive on the Interstate wouldn‰Ûªt sustain a feature.

The rationalization this movie uses for the anthropomorphization of the emoji is weak, to put it mildly. But once that has been taken care of, Gene goes on his hero‰Ûªs quest in search of the cloud, where he seeks to be reprogrammed so he can do the job he takes so much pride in. He of course has a bumbling sidekick (a high-five emoji) in tow. They enlist the help of the hacker Jailbreak and move through the corridors of their phone. Much labored app humor follows.

In late 2014, the hack of Sony resulted in the publishing of private emails that much of the internet had a great time laughing at. One item considered particularly risible in certain corners was a pitch to the co-chairwoman of Sony Pictures Entertainment from a sort of youth consultant, averring that ‰ÛÏNBD,‰Ûù shorthand for no big deal, was popular text speak among millennials and that it should be used as dialogue in a new ‰ÛÏSpider-Man‰Ûù movie.

This film is exactly what its posters would lead you to believe it is: an animated narrative film about emoji. It tells the story of Gene (voiced by T. J. Miller), who is a ‰ÛÏmeh‰Ûù emoji but who is capable of making more expressions than the blasÌ© one he has been assigned. His versatility is considered a malfunction, even, to some extent, by Gene himself. This leads the effusively smiling leader of the emoji to lobby for Gene‰Ûªs deletion from the phone on which he lives.

Sony‰Ûªs latest release, ‰ÛÏThe Emoji Movie,‰Ûù features among its heroes a female computer hacker who at one point shrugs off a crisis by saying ‰ÛÏNBD.‰Ûù I‰Ûªm not sure if this is an indication of abject cluelessness, or if it represents what I believe some millennials call a self-own.

For a long time, Hollywood has been propagating the idea that the panderingly, trendily idiotic can be made to seem less so, by polishing it up with bright shiny gloss and enlisting engaging talented performers and writers. I can‰Ûªt be entirely certain of this, but I would say ‰ÛÏThe Emoji Movie‰Ûù takes this notion to the outer limits of credibility. The voice cast is full of name actors, some of whom have genuine appeal. One of the screenwriters is the very astute Mike White. This movie‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏbelieve in yourself‰Ûù message is borne out, in a perverse way, by the very fact that it even exists. And yet the whole thing remains nakedly idiotic. To add to the pain and despair of the experience, ‰ÛÏThe Emoji Movie‰Ûù is preceded by a short, ‰ÛÏPuppy,‰Ûù featuring the characters from the ‰ÛÏHotel Transylvania‰Ûù animated movies. It is also idiotic.

‰ÛÏThe Last Dalai Lama?‰Ûù spends a lot of time looking back. A collection of moments rather than a linear story, this film is at its best when it‰Ûªs suffused with the presence of the Dalai Lama, whether he is watching schoolchildren in Canada practice gratitude or meditating on separating his consciousness from his body in preparation for death.

Another shows Philip Glass at the organ at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in New York, playing music he composed for the Dalai Lama‰Ûªs 1979 visit there and discussing how his own practice of Buddhism helped him as a composer.

No film about this holy man would be complete without a recap of the escape from Tibet to Dharamsala, India, after the Chinese takeover of the country. The movie notes that the Chinese government has declared it will control the selection and development of the next Dalai Lama, an absurd idea to those who believe succession is a matter of reincarnation. The specter of two competing lamas, one controlled by the Chinese, also arises. In response, the ever-smiling Dalai Lama says he won‰Ûªt reincarnate as a 15th Dalai Lama, but aides explain that statement doesn‰Ûªt mean he won‰Ûªt be reborn in exile, and the film is unlikely to settle the question definitively.

A surplus of wisdom and benevolence radiates from ‰ÛÏThe Last Dalai Lama?,‰Ûù written and directed by Mickey Lemle, the filmmaker of ‰ÛÏCompassion in Exile‰Ûù (1993), another documentary about this Buddhist leader, who is 82.

One fascinating segment introduces the Atlas of Emotions, commissioned by the Dalai Lama and developed by Paul and Eve Ekman, a father and daughter who used behavioral science to map human feelings and their consequences.

‰ÛÏThe Last Face‰Ûù uses crises in the war-torn regions of Liberia and South Sudan to frame a knotty love story between Charlize Theron‰Ûªs Wren, the daughter of a founder of an organization like Doctors Without Borders, and Javier Bardem‰Ûªs Miguel, a dedicated surgeon. At one point Ms. Theron‰Ûªs character asks, in voice-over, ‰ÛÏIn this place of so much war, had I found peace?‰Ûù The script, by Erin Dignam, doesn‰Ûªt get much deeper than that. The romantic chemistry between Ms. Theron and Mr. Bardem feels forced throughout, never more so than in a scene of mutual seduction in a cutesy context of brushing teeth. Mr. Penn is more than competent in recreating the noise, gore and panic of war zones, but far less so in simulating the atmosphere of alienated romance common in 1960s European art films.

And then there‰Ûªs the unusual text in the movie‰Ûªs opening credits: ‰ÛÏVocal Artists: Eddie Vedder, Mary J. Blige, Suki Waterhouse.‰Ûù It appears while a simple and haunting song of African provenance plays. More than two hours later, the end credits inform you that the song is ‰ÛÏMakambo,‰Ûù by the Ugandan musician Geoffrey Oryema. This seems an accurate indication of where the movie‰Ûªs head is at.

Sean Penn has some significant experience as a human-rights activist. He has shown commendable stalwartness in walking the walk, so to speak, not just starting a foundation to help victims of  Haiti‰Ûªs 2010 earthquake but traveling there to help on the ground. We can read Mr. Penn‰Ûªs latest directorial effort, ‰ÛÏThe Last Face,‰Ûù as a kind of tribute to the aid workers he has met. As well meaning as this movie is, it is also a turgid, muddled one.

Punk history is full of lurid misadventures, and Corbett Redford‰Ûªs thorough documentary, ‰ÛÏTurn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk,‰Ûù collects many of those ‰ÛÏyou had to be there‰Ûù stories for a lively ‰ÛÓ if lengthy ‰ÛÓ chronicle of the Northern California punk scene, beginning in the late 1970s.

Mr. Redford, who wrote the movie with Anthony Marchitiello, shows enthusiasm for his subject but offers little context for newcomers to West Coast punk music. Interviewees remember names fondly but don‰Ûªt illuminate why those people were crucial to the scene or what happened to them, leaving everyone behind but die-hard fans who are already in the know.

Provoked by hellish suburbs and rural moonscapes outside San Francisco, a group of outsiders cobbled together loud, angry music that was also a reaction against the hippie generation before it. The movie follows this winding time line until its focus shifts to a famous hub, the 924 Gilman Street music collective in Berkeley, Calif., that nurtured bands like Green Day (an executive producer of the movie), Rancid, Operation Ivy, the Offspring and even the filmmaker Miranda July.

Via voice-over narration, the punk elder statesman Iggy Pop presides over the nearly 160-minute parade of musician cameos and archival footage, but his scraggly-voiced guidance returns only intermittently to connect the dots between the years. While zine-style animated sequences and VHS taped interviews enliven the pace, the documentary is burdened by too much minutiae. Not every scar earned at a concert deserves to be immortalized in a documentary.

If the movie were reliant on only the rosy recollections of Di Palma‰Ûªs professional connections, the man himself might slip out of view like the last light at dusk. Testimonials about his sensitivity pale in comparison with seeing scenes like Di Palma‰Ûªs illuminated dance hall, empty but for one couple, who dance under the glow of a thousand lights in ‰ÛÏTeresa the Thief.‰Ûù As one memorable anecdote from the set of ‰ÛÏBlow-Up‰Ûù illustrates, he was a man to paint the grass if reality wasn‰Ûªt green enough. In the end, ‰ÛÏWater and Sugar‰Ûù proves the best view of Di Palma is still the gaze from his own eyes.

The director, Fariborz Kamkari, lingers on the golden touch that Di Palma, who died in 2004, brought to films with Michelangelo Antonioni, and he enlists collaborators like Woody Allen to explain Di Palma‰Ûªs influence on their work. Though brief service is paid to this filmmaker‰Ûªs personal life, viewers seeking a juicy backstage glimpse of his famous friends should look elsewhere. Under the careful eye of Mr. Kamkari and Di Palma‰Ûªs widow, Adriana Chiesa, a producer on the movie, ‰ÛÏWater and Sugar‰Ûù presents an official history, focused more on work than pleasure or even personality.

When the Italian cinematographer Carlo Di Palma started out, he was a 15-year-old camera assistant on ‰ÛÏOssessione,‰Ûù the 1943 Luchino Visconti movie that is widely considered the first Italian neorealist film. The new documentary ‰ÛÏWater and Sugar: Carlo Di Palma, the Colours of Life‰Ûù explores Di Palma‰Ûªs long career, from that auspicious beginning to his work on ‰ÛÏRed Desert,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏRadio Days‰Ûù and some of the other best films of the 20th century.

But this is Ms. Williams‰Ûªs movie, and she owns it. (Though, with its strong ensemble ‰ÛÓ Lakeith Stanfield plays her ex ‰ÛÓ I kept thinking it could make for a smart series.) She‰Ûªs a radiant, tall glass of dopeness and isn‰Ûªt afraid to tell you so. And in New York City, isn‰Ûªt that how the strong survive?

The director Jim Strouse wrote this movie, which began streaming Friday on Netflix, for Ms. Williams after she appeared in his 2015 film, ‰ÛÏPeople Places Things.‰Ûù The camera lovingly follows her on her adventures in the city, and it‰Ûªs easy to see why he was inspired to give her this breakout role.

And yet the struggle is real for her character. Jessica James is a Brooklyn playwright going through a ‰ÛÏweird transitional phase,‰Ûù not really coping well with a recent breakup (her ex-boyfriend keeps coming to an untimely end in her dreams) and trying to remain optimistic as rejection letters from theater companies pile up. Those notices share a wall in her Bushwick apartment with Playbill covers, posters for old school productions and inspirational quotes from Lillian Hellman.

Her character‰Ûªs forthrightness draws in friends and intrigues potential suitors, including the recently divorced Boone (played by a scruffy and slightly goofy Chris O‰ÛªDowd). They are complete opposites but find themselves in bed after an awkward first date. Their courtship involves an elaborate plan to break free of the obsessive cycle of stalking their exes on social media. The solution: Each will follow the other‰Ûªs ex.

One of the best scenes in ‰ÛÏThe Incredible Jessica James‰Ûù comes two-thirds of the way through the movie. Jessica, arguing with a guy she‰Ûªs sort of been seeing, delivers a kiss-off: ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm freakin‰Ûª dope.‰Ûù That bold declaration not only represents a strong young woman but is also a gift for fans of the actress who plays her, Jessica Williams, the former ‰ÛÏDaily Show‰Ûù correspondent and current co-host of the ‰ÛÏ2 Dope Queens‰Ûù podcast.

Her love of theater is deep, as witnessed in scenes with young students in a playwriting class she teaches. She bonds with one, Shandra (a delightful Taliyah Whitaker), who shows promise but is also processing the recent divorce of her parents. The snappy dialogue makes Jessica‰Ûªs silly moments with the kids as well as heart-to-hearts with her friend Tasha (NoÌÇl Wells, just as charming as she was in ‰ÛÏMaster of None‰Ûù) feel most lived-in and natural, even when she is asked to recommend a show for a friend of her mother‰Ûªs back home in Ohio who‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏheard good things about ‰Û÷Jersey Boys.‰Ûª‰Ûù Jessica prefers ‰ÛÏdialogue-driven dramas that explore the human condition.‰Ûù

Mr. Gubler and Ms. McCord‰Ûªs characters are matched to maximum effect ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs nervous, she‰Ûªs violent ‰ÛÓ and Trent Haaga, the writer and director, races through scenes as if there were no time to waste, adding to the energy. Though his script is only half as clever as it should be, that‰Ûªs enough to give the movie a daffy charm. Alisha Boe and Sheila Vand, in supporting roles, are by turns sexy and strange.

Nuttier than a bakery full of fruitcakes and sleazier than a cheap strip club, ‰ÛÏ68 Kill‰Ûù is a proudly morbid heist movie that wallows in bad taste and still comes off as absurdly funny. It‰Ûªs a little amazing how a story so guilty of gross-out violence can retain a share of comic innocence.

Some twists and double-crosses follow the theft, none of them too complex or entirely logical. But this movie is determined not to take itself seriously, and that makes it easy for you to do the same and cackle, even as the bloodshed turns ridiculously foul and cheesiness is played as a virtue.

We‰Ûªll be ‰ÛÏin and out like it‰Ûªs nothing ‰ÛÓ nobody gets hurt,‰Ûù Liza tells Chip as she plans the crime. It‰Ûªs a ludicrous moment ‰ÛÓ there should be a neon sign above her head blinking, ‰ÛÏFat Chance.‰Ûù In that scene and others, however, you find yourself laughing out loud, and minutes later, covering your eyes.

That innocence begins and ends with Chip (Matthew Gray Gubler), whose batty girlfriend, Liza (AnnaLynne McCord), plans to rob her sugar daddy (David Maldonado) of the cash in his safe. The bumbling Chip is reluctant to help, but Liza is persuasive ‰ÛÓ she punches hard ‰ÛÓ and before you can say ‰ÛÏThey shouldn‰Ûªt be bringing weapons to this supposedly nonviolent robbery,‰Ûù everything hits the fan.

A former penitentiary now used for interrogating terrorists and war criminals has been attacked by an unknown force, and all its support personnel wiped out. Now a Special Forces squad leader (a musclebound but curiously muted Wesley Snipes) reunites his old crew to enter the compound and crack the mystery. Among his team members are a hothead (the wrestling superstar Seth Rollins); a meek software expert (Morgan Roberts); another computer wizard, with a troubled past (Dave Annable); and a squandered Anne Heche.

The director John Stockwell displayed a light comic touch at times in ‰ÛÏKickboxer: Vengeance‰Ûù that almost surmounted that 2016 movie‰Ûªs wheezy martial-arts genre conventions. Regrettably, his ‰ÛÏArmed Response,‰Ûù a low-budget, high-tech action film with supernatural overtones, is devoid of such a sense of play.

The possibilities are intriguing, but the characters are underdrawn, and the pacing lags. (Endless time is spent looking at monitors.) There is a ‰ÛÏfinal girl‰Ûù of sorts ‰ÛÓ in horror movies, the perennial remaining woman confronting the antagonist ‰ÛÓ but we hardly know her. Most egregiously, ‰ÛÏArmed Response,‰Ûù whose producers include Mr. Snipes and Gene Simmons of Kiss, offers underwhelming gunplay and fisticuffs. And that prompts an indifferent response.

Off they wander through the complex, with flashlights in dark corridors, checking cells and sensory-deprivation tanks, finding corpses and discovering that this antiseptic labyrinth ‰ÛÓ called the Temple ‰ÛÓ is itself a sentient entity with murder on its mind. As they discover the fate of the Temple‰Ûªs previous occupants, they in turn are, of course, picked off one by one. The squad‰Ûªs history in Afghanistan, and complicity in abuses there, plays a part.

Mr. Lambert, who wrote the screenplay with Michael Dowling, aims for a modest, old-fashioned yarn about a time when people believed in the news media. Even when word gets out that the Martian invasion announcement was just part of a radio show, not everyone listens as intently as they did to the original radio program and gossip. The film‰Ûªs narrative simplicity can be charming or frustrating, depending on your feelings about awkward dialogue and overreacting actors.

In Jody Lambert‰Ûªs lighthearted comedy ‰ÛÏBrave New Jersey‰Ûù panic is positive, pushing people to say or do things they may have never done under ordinary circumstances. Out of the ensuing chaos, the town‰Ûªs bashful mayor (Tony Hale, from ‰ÛÏVeep‰Ûù) is forced to assert himself, and a pastor‰Ûªs faith is challenged, as is the relationship between a schoolteacher and her new fiancÌ©.

Fake news travels fast, even in the fictitious New Jersey town of Lullaby in the 1930s. That rural town was light-years away from the Manhattan home of the CBS studio, where Orson Welles was retelling H. G. Wells‰Ûªs novel ‰ÛÏThe War of the Worlds‰Ûù in an infamous radio production on Oct. 30, 1938. Those unaware that the broadcast was a work of fiction fell for Wells‰Ûªs story of an alien invasion. Fear that it was real quickly set off a panic.

Through its many cheerful characters, ‰ÛÏBrave New Jersey‰Ûù emanates an upbeat attitude of a James Stewart kind. With its warm filters and costumes, the movie emulates a period film, but its sharp digital cinematography is at odds with its softer, vintage aesthetic.

Directed by Xavier Manrique from a script by Nicholas Schutt, the tale centers on Fenton (Shiloh Fernandez), a writer returning home to his parents (Mary-Louise Parker and Chris Noth) in Manhattan after a self-imposed exile on the West Coast. A fictional story he once wrote for The New Yorker, ostensibly about his girlfriend at the time, Jessie (Ashley Benson), and her family, wasn‰Ûªt veiled enough, and they were greatly embarrassed.

It‰Ûªs often an uphill battle for films about fiction writers ‰ÛÓ cerebral sorts who practice a static profession ‰ÛÓ and too frequently we see Fenton merely sitting and gazing at his open laptop, cursor blinking on a blank page. The premise here is already implausible: The days when a short piece of literary fiction could devastate a wide social circle are very likely gone. Worse yet, the stakes are always low for these high-income characters.
In the year or so since Fenton slunk away, Jessie met a new beau whom she is about to marry. By moping around her a few times and boozing a little, Fenton apparently seeks to win her back.

Several times in ‰ÛÏChronically Metropolitan,‰Ûù a man stares at a screen as nothing happens. You‰Ûªll know just how he feels. However inadvertently, those are the most relatable moments in this movie, and the closest its makers come to connecting with whoever‰Ûªs still watching.

Nobody seems to get genuinely sad or elated or ‰ÛÓ pick any emotion ‰ÛÓ in ‰ÛÏChronically Metropolitan,‰Ûù making it tough for a viewer to do the same. One longs to praise Mr. Manrique for attempting a serious-minded story in this, his first feature. But there needs to be a real reason to embrace it, rather than what‰Ûªs on this screen.

‰ÛÏColumbus‰Ûù can be slyly mysterious from a structural standpoint, both with respect to the plot‰Ûªs elisions and several cuts that demand that viewers fill in the blanks. The movie leaves quite a bit to the eye of the beholder, but it‰Ûªs always worth looking at.

The existence of a debut as confident and allusive as ‰ÛÏColumbus‰Ûù is almost as improbable as the existence of Columbus, Ind., where the movie is set. Columbus‰Ûªs claim to fame ‰ÛÓ other than being Vice President Mike Pence‰Ûªs hometown ‰ÛÓ is that it‰Ûªs an unlikely haven for modernist architecture. Through a combination of patronage and civic courtship, this southern Indiana city became a home to structures by Eliel Saarinen, I. M. Pei, Robert A. M. Stern, Richard Meier and many others.

The acknowledged influence of the great Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu looms over the proceedings. Kogonada draws not only on Ozu‰Ûªs frequent theme of generational conflict but also on his shooting style. (Like Ozu, he often ‰ÛÏcrosses the line,‰Ûù violating the conventions of how the camera is positioned relative to the characters in a scene.) The found backgrounds are as suggestive as the dialogue, with the director often observing his actors through doorways and mirrors.

Jin (John Cho), an English-to-Korean book translator in Seoul, travels to Columbus after his father, an architecture historian, collapses while in town for a talk. As Jin waits to find out whether his semi-estranged father will ever regain consciousness, he strikes up a friendship with Casey (Haley Lu Richardson), a tour guide and lifelong Columbus resident. A year out of high school, she is tempted to leave to study architecture, but she fears for the well-being of her unpredictable blue-collar mother (Michelle Forbes), for whom she cooks and essentially looks after.

Against this backdrop, Kogonada, a video essayist who has made artful film-analysis shorts for the Criterion Collection and Sight & Sound magazine, has shot a modest two-hander, using the architecture as a springboard for larger questions, much as his shorts are meta-riffs on the movies of Alfred Hitchcock and Richard Linklater. To his characters, a church and a bank by Eero Saarinen (Eliel Saarinen‰Ûªs son) are everything and nothing.

Over several days, as Casey and Jin wander the sites, they debate such heady ideas as the healing power of buildings, modernism‰Ûªs relationship to religion, and why ‰ÛÓ or whether ‰ÛÓ architecture means something to them. (‰ÛÏYou grow up around something and it feels like nothing,‰Ûù Jin says.) Kogonada also introduces parallel not-quite love interests: for Casey, a librarian (Rory Culkin) whose disquisition on the relative interest of video games and books may be intended as advice on how to watch this film; for Jin, a colleague of his father‰Ûªs (Parker Posey) on whom he had a crush as a teenager.

Some of this story is mildly whimsical, and there are ramps into some kind of magical realism (a blizzard at the French-Italian border is a little far-fetched). There are a lot of shots from behind a car windshield. These are more allied with Vincent Gallo‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Brown Bunny‰Ûù than with Monte Hellman‰Ûªs more lyrical ‰ÛÏTwo-Lane Blacktop.‰Ûù While Mr. Reybaud has exemplary artistic confidence and an interesting vision, this is a movie that in many ways defines or justifies the ‰ÛÏnot for everybody‰Ûù critical hedge.

Pierre is also looking to quench a thirst. He regularly checks his Grindr app, and at a roadside restroom, scans the stall graffiti and calls a number advertising sex services. He also picks up people along the roadside, not for cruising purposes, but to be of help. The first is a middle-age woman who is booked to sing at a senior home. The characters encountered are a bit more colorful than the ones you are likely to come across in real life, but not so much that they seem overtly allegorical. As Pierre roams, Paul embarks on a quest of his own, traveling to the center of the country to look for his lover via concentric Grindr circles.

There‰Ûªs a peculiarly spellbinding quality to ‰ÛÏ4 Days in France‰Ûù that is partly attributable to its premise. This feature debut of the writer and director JÌ©rÌ«me Reybaud opens with a baby-faced 30-something, Pierre (Pascal Cervo), training a phone flashlight on his lover Paul (Arthur Igual). He then leaves Paul‰Ûªs Paris apartment and drives an Alfa Romeo into rural France. The fantasy of walking out on your life and aimlessly wandering around can beguile even the most contentedly domesticated among us.

All four actresses have a natural chemistry and manage to give some inner dimensions to these otherwise archetypal characters. Though Ms. Aselton‰Ûªs Emily is only marginally more realized than the others, it‰Ûªs Ms. Everett who delivers the most memorable lines (‰ÛÏOprah and Gayle, care to open up the friendship circle?‰Ûù) ‰ÛÓ not at all surprising for those familiar with Ms. Everett‰Ûªs, um, less-than-wholesome wine-soaked cabaret stage work.

These gals don‰Ûªt start out as reunited pals, though ‰ÛÓ they only know one another through their children‰Ûªs school. There‰Ûªs bad blood between Kate (Toni Collette), who‰Ûªs too cool for the dreaded Mom circle, and Melanie (Bridget Everett), a brash taskmaster with strong feelings about traffic safety. They stand down after a few puffs of a peace pipe in the form of a marijuana vaporizer pen and some encouragement from the recently divorced Jamie (Molly Shannon), a social media oversharer, and the new-to-the-school Emily (Katie Aselton), whose marriage is in a rut.

Psst. Have you heard? On big screens across the nation women are behaving badly, really badly. And now, bringing up the rear of this summer raunch parade led by ‰ÛÏSnatched,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏRough Night‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏGirls Trip,‰Ûù comes the rather tame ‰ÛÏFun Mom Dinner.‰Ûù These mothers just want a night off for boozy shenanigans and some smoking in the girls‰Ûª room, which, of course, leads to harmless karaoke antics, mild flirtations, an Instagram faux pas and pot-induced paranoia.

The director Alethea Jones, working from Julie Rudd‰Ûªs thin script, opens with a dutiful montage of the women‰Ûªs morning routines. (Cue the requisite baby poop disaster and the Go-Go‰Ûªs singing ‰ÛÏHead Over Heels.‰Ûù) The continuous intercutting, however ‰ÛÓ must we keep checking in with the dads and kids? ‰ÛÓ eventually grows tiresome and distracting.

Those revelations were first made public months before the 2016 Olympics, when Dr. Rodchenkov‰Ûªs detailed confession about state-sponsored cheating at the 2014 Sochi Games appeared in The New York Times. In fleeing Moscow, Dr. Rodchenkov feared Russian reprisals, and the anxiety shown here is palpable; the doctor was eventually put into protective custody by the American government.

Mr. Fogel could be considered either daring or foolhardy for his initial plan. But his work with Dr. Rodchenkov is levelheaded, and his documentary illuminating. There‰Ûªs a lot not covered here ‰ÛÓ the ethical and moral questions of such drugs, their health effects and their use in professional sports are just a few. Those will have to wait for another film. This one found its timely topic, and smartly followed along.
Early scenes show Mr. Fogel injecting himself (needle-phobics, beware) with substances, then charting his performance as he meets with specialists and makes video calls with Dr. Rodchenkov.
What started as a wild idea turned into something more dangerous in ‰ÛÏIcarus,‰Ûù a documentary that had the good fortune to be filming when bad news broke.

Bryan Fogel, the director and an amateur bike racer, planned to investigate the use of performance-enhancing drugs by taking them himself and then trying to evade detection. The idea, a sort of ‰ÛÏSuper Size Me‰Ûù with steroids instead of Big Macs, brought him into contact with Dr. Grigory Rodchenkov, who led Russia‰Ûªs antidoping laboratory for Olympic athletes.

Months into the plan, Dr. Rodchenkov and Russia came under investigation for widespread doping at the Olympic Games. Mr. Fogel stops his own story and puts the focus entirely on Dr. Rodchenkov, who leaves Moscow for the United States. In interviews the doctor outlines Russia‰Ûªs widespread steroid program and the clandestine steps taken to cover it up.

By the time shooting begins on that film, Mr. Fitzmaurice is using a ventilator to breathe. He directs the actors through his only means of communication: eye-gaze technology. His computer decodes his gaze and speaks for him in a robotic voice, which his wife charmingly refers to as ‰ÛÏAmerican.‰Ûù

Painful to watch and uncomfortably intimate at times, perhaps by design, ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs Not Yet Dark‰Ûù could have been very dark indeed. This documentary takes us into the mind and body of a young Irish filmmaker, Simon Fitzmaurice, who wakes each morning closer to total paralysis.

He displays a powerful will to live, and he and his wife make the most of it so every day is memorable for the children, who number five by the film‰Ûªs end. They steer the film, and their lives, from what might be unrelenting sadness toward inspiration.

Speaking in the first person, the actor Colin Farrell narrates Mr. Fitzmaurice‰Ûªs story as he struggles to pursue his career while losing his body to the neurodegenerative disease A.L.S., or amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Frankie Fenton directed this film, which borrows from Mr. Fitzmaurice‰Ûªs memoir of the same title and makes liberal use of boisterous and tender home videos of his family that also document the last time Mr. Fitzmaurice danced or walked.

Perhaps the most striking aspect of the film is the shocking rapidity of his decline. Once his diagnosis becomes clear, when he is 34, doctors predict Mr. Fitzmaurice will live three to four years, but he soars past that (he is now 42) and remains amazingly productive, working painstakingly on his first feature film, ‰ÛÏMy Name Is Emily,‰Ûù released this year.

The director, Luis Prieto, doesn‰Ûªt waste time trying to build an arc to Karla‰Ûªs desperation. Her adrenaline kicks in the moment she sees Frankie being shoved into the back seat of an unfamiliar Mustang, and it doesn‰Ûªt dip until the credits roll. Cars crash, Karla rises. Guns fire, Karla slashes. The greatest strength of ‰ÛÏKidnap‰Ûù is that it casts the maternal instinct as a primordial will to enact violence, to drag a man from a moving van, to beat a kidnapper with a shovel. We see Karla find her best weapons in blunt objects, and to its credit, ‰ÛÏKidnap‰Ûù is a blunt movie.

It‰Ûªs sometimes funny to watch Ms. Berry act out scenes of Karla‰Ûªs frenzy ‰ÛÓ running at full speed with a limp, gingerly approaching a kidnapper‰Ûªs lair with a gun she‰Ûªs never used. But as a producer of the movie as well as its star, she approaches the task of playing this unhinged mother on the run with sincerity.

When we meet Karla Dyson (Halle Berry), the heroine of the new thriller ‰ÛÏKidnap,‰Ûù she is already trapped in a legal battle for custody of her 6-year-old son, Frankie (Sage Correa). Karla panics during a call to her lawyer ‰ÛÓ her ex has a girlfriend and a business, and she‰Ûªs only a waitress. But when Frankie is kidnapped while playing at a park, the meek Karla is unleashed as the vigilante Valkyrie of the Interstate highways, promising herself and Frankie‰Ûªs backwoods abductors through car accidents and police interference: ‰ÛÏAs long as my son is in that car, I will not stop. Wherever you go, I will be right behind you.‰Ûù

The film‰Ûªs success is directly dependent on the personalities ‰ÛÓ and achievements ‰ÛÓ of the young women highlighted. Despite the narrative gaps, Ms. Lipitz excels at putting across those personalities. Blessin, Cori, and Tayla make you smile, make you worry and make you root for them.

Cori, the valedictorian, is hoping to receive a ‰ÛÏfull ride‰Ûù to Johns Hopkins University. She‰Ûªs the oldest of six children, and while her home life is anchored by a loving and supportive mother and stepfather, money is always tight. That‰Ûªs also the case for Blessin, a hair and makeup maven ‰ÛÓ she seems to have a different hair style in every other shot. Blessin has trouble maintaining her grades, however, and in getting her mother, who suffers from depression, from partaking fully in weighing her post-high-school options. Tayla also has wobbly grades, and her mother, a police officer, sometimes embarrasses her because of her enthusiasm for the step team.

The Baltimore Leadership School for Young Women was founded in 2009 to help underserved girls, predominately African-Americans, prepare for college. As this public charter school geared up to graduate its first class last year, the filmmakers of ‰ÛÏStep‰Ûù were there to observe three seniors, all members of its step dance team.

On the other hand, the polished optimistic tenor of the movie arguably makes their triumphs seem like a foregone conclusion. Beyond the quibbles I might have, though, this is a highly pertinent story told in an entertaining way.

In trying to deliver messages of inspiration and empowerment, the director, Amanda Lipitz, deliberately swerves around the delivery of a comprehensive narrative. (In one section Blessin misses a day of school because of, according to a family discussion, conflict with some girls on the step team, but this issue is never otherwise addressed.)

This documentary has a classic twinned narrative: The girls must get into college (that‰Ûªs the school‰Ûªs main goal), and there‰Ûªs a big step competition coming up. ‰ÛÏStep‰Ûù manages to tell both stories in under 90 minutes, with a city rived by the death of Freddie Gray while in police custody as its fraught backdrop. The film uses such crowd-pleasing devices as scoring a ‰ÛÏRocky‰Ûù-training-style montage to Fifth Harmony‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWorth It.‰Ûù The action in this sequence is mostly Cori, Blessin and Tayla filling out application forms on computers, but one has to work with what one has.

Five characters constitute the backbone of the story, which concerns an escape planned by Hashima‰Ûªs captive laborers: a jazz musician (Hwang Jung-min) and his young daughter (Kim Su-an); a Seoul mobster (So Ji-sub) and one of the Korean ‰ÛÏcomfort women‰Ûù forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese (Lee Jung-hyun); and a ruthlessly efficient operative (Song Joong-ki) sent by the Office of Strategic Services to rescue a high-ranking official. Their narratives entwine as the film advances to a bloody confrontation between the Japanese and the Koreans after an Allied bombing of the island.

Subtlety is not Mr. Ryoo‰Ûªs forte here: The Japanese are, to a man, caricatures of evil. The musician‰Ûªs daughter is at one point tarted up in lipstick, makeup and silk, when she isn‰Ûªt tearfully crying out for her father, while Mr. Song‰Ûªs operative character is an indestructible force of moral rectitude. But Mr. Ryoo adroitly moves his camera through vast, crowded settings, and the climax sweeps you up in its ineluctable intensity. Its aftermath vividly conveys the pain of a national wartime trauma whose scars clearly have not healed.

Battle spectacle and Korean national pride are the order of the day in Ryoo Seung-wan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Battleship Island,‰Ûù a heated account of the mining operation on Hashima Island off the coast of Nagasaki in Japan that forcibly conscripted thousands of Koreans (and Chinese) in World War II. Though Mr. Ryoo‰Ûªs taste for heightened theatricality threatens his story‰Ûªs credibility at times, there is no denying his skill with a large-scale action set piece.

The title refers to a mysteriously woo-woo, sky-piercingly tall spire that somehow holds both the universe‰Ûªs various worlds and its monstrous threats in check. Walter wants to destroy the dark tower; Roland intends to protect it. Jake, who tends to look as confused as the audience may feel, doesn‰Ûªt yet have a mission, though giving this twerp a purpose ‰ÛÓ a kind of wee hero‰Ûªs journey (‰ÛÏSurrender, Jake‰Ûù!) ‰ÛÓ seems to be the endgame. It‰Ûªs a default solution, and reads like a cop-out. After all, if Stephen King hands you a complex fiction that turns pulpy tropes into a dense mythology with its own language and heavyweight heroes like Roland, wouldn‰Ûªt you run with at least some of it?

Every so often in ‰ÛÏThe Dark Tower,‰Ûù you catch a glimpse of what might have been: the might-have-been narrative ambition, the might-have-been pop mythology, the might-have-been genre assemblage. Based ‰ÛÓ loosely seems altogether too generous a word ‰ÛÓ on the Stephen King series, the movie is an unappealing hash of moviemaking clichÌ©s that, after much scurrying and blathering, devolves into a generic shoot‰Ûªem-up. About the only thing holding it together is Idris Elba, whose irrepressible magnetism and man-of-stone solidity anchors this mess but can‰Ûªt redeem it.

Mr. Elba plays the otherworldly Roland, whose name suggests the Arthurian legend with knights and so forth. Onscreen, though, Roland basically points, shoots and serves as an overqualified babysitter for Jake (Tom Taylor), a 14-year-old with psychic powers (he ‰ÛÏshines‰Ûù ÌÊ la ‰ÛÏThe Shining‰Ûù) who lives here and now on what Roland calls Keystone Earth. Roland, by contrast, lives in Mid-World, an incoherent realm of foggy woods, digital boogeymen, cinematic allusions, slavering nods to Mr. King‰Ûªs voluminous oeuvre and some geological formations that may cause you to uselessly flash on images from John Ford westerns. (The movie was partly shot in the Cederberg Mountains in South Africa.)

For reasons that emerge in expository blurts, Jake and Roland travel between Mid-World and the considerably less interesting Keystone Earth. Also on the move is Walter, a.k.a. the man in black (Matthew McConaughey), an amusingly dissolute supervillain who, with weary hand waves and insinuating whispers, oozes about like a Vegas lounge lizard ‰ÛÓ with a hint of the Wicked Witch of the West snap ‰ÛÒ lording over heavily armed, face-changing, blood-lusting snarlers (Jackie Earle Haley, et. al). Mr. McConaughey, topped by an artfully arranged shock of black hair and flashing some tanned chest that makes you want to whip out the gold chains, has truly developed into a Zen master of sleaze.

The ‰ÛÏDark Tower‰Ûù series can be traced to Mr. King‰Ûªs love of, among other inspirations, J. R. R. Tolkien‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Lord of the Rings‰Ûù novels as well as Sergio Leone‰Ûªs masterly 1966 film ‰ÛÏThe Good, the Bad and the Ugly,‰Ûù which I suppose explains the duster Roland wears and an empty nod to spaghetti westerns. So, there‰Ûªs that. Mostly, there are clotted action scenes, gun fetishism, bad writing and stop-and-go rhythms that suggest a longer version may once have existed. The director, Nikolaj Arcel, shares screenwriting credit and blame with Akiva Goldsman, Jeff Pinkner and Anders Thomas Jensen; whatever they thought they were doing here remains as mysterious as Walter‰Ûªs hair product.

Although Ms. Rodriguez includes a certain amount of foreshadowing, both in the title and in dialogue, few films are so rigorous in trying to evoke a structuring absence. But the withholding of details necessary to engineer the initial lull backfires in the second half, when the lack of specificity leaves the characters ill defined.

The key to the film may lie in its second shot, of a father, Francisco (Francisco Zaldua), and his teenage daughter, Adelaida (Laura Osma), watching television. Adelaida lazily calls to her mother, Lena (Maruia Shelton), who is out of frame in the next room. Lena is variously shown as Adelaida‰Ûªs comforter, advice-giver on boyfriends and occasional object of pique.

For the first half of ‰ÛÏThis Time Tomorrow,‰Ûù nothing much seems to happen. The Colombian-Canadian director Lina Rodriguez, who lives in Toronto, observes the daily lives of a family of three in BogotÌÁ. But after a midfilm rupture, the movie reveals that the seemingly uneventful first section was more consequential than it appeared. As such, ‰ÛÏThis Time Tomorrow‰Ûù poses a hazard for any spoiler-conscious reviewer. It‰Ûªs also more admirable in theory than it is illuminating in practice.

But after Lena‰Ûªs birthday, the screen fades to black. When the movie returns, Ms. Rodriguez cuts among a succession of downcast faces. It‰Ûªs probably not saying too much to reveal that ‰ÛÏThis Time Tomorrow‰Ûù concerns the shock of an unexpected death, and how the sudden absence changes the lives of the family members who remain.

The performances Mr. Sheridan draws from his cast are all excellent. Mr. Renner, who‰Ûªs been spending too much of his career imparting convincing humanity to a second-tier Marvel superhero, is in excellent form as Cory. Ms. Olsen, who has been co-starring in those Marvel films with Mr. Renner, is sympathetic as Jane. Graham Greene brings his customary quiet power and dry wit to the role of the police chief.

‰ÛÏSee what they send us,‰Ûù one resident says mournfully, shaking his head. In a different movie, the introduction of Jane and Cory would be a meet-cute. But Mr. Sheridan, who also avoided injecting a romantic theme into his script for ‰ÛÏSicario,‰Ûù in which Emily Blunt played an F.B.I. operative, has different, more serious reasons for making this character a woman. Jane acts partly as an audience surrogate, a well-intentioned outsider whose empathy and sincere desire to act on behalf of the female murder victim only gets her so far.

Homicide on an Indian reservation, as it happens, is a federal crime. The F.B.I. ‰ÛÓ which, going by the attitude of the reservation‰Ûªs quiet police chief, is consistently less helpful than it should be ‰ÛÓ dispatches Jane Banner (Elizabeth Olsen), a seemingly very green agent, to head the investigation. She shows up wearing an F.B.I. windbreaker, and Cory calmly informs her that she‰Ûªll be dead within five minutes if she goes up the mountain dressed like that.

Here, Jeremy Renner plays Cory Lambert, a federal wildlife officer who hunts predatory animals at the Wind River Indian Reservation in Wyoming. He seems on intimate terms with the residents there; his ex-wife, with whom he has a young son and had a daughter, is a Native American with family on the reservation. While searching for a mountain lion that has been attacking livestock, he finds a corpse frozen in the mountain snow. The dead young woman, who suffered a head injury and was also raped, was the best friend of Cory‰Ûªs daughter, who died three years earlier under similar circumstances.

Under David Mackenzie‰Ûªs direction, ‰ÛÏHell or High Water‰Ûù tended to overstate its hard-times-in-the-United-States theme; it seemed that every fifth shot or so showed a house foreclosure sale sign or a bankruptcy lawyer‰Ûªs billboard. As a director, Mr. Sheridan is a little more subtle than Mr. Mackenzie. This is kind of surprising; frequently, writers turned directors really like to bring the hammer down on their subtexts. But Mr. Sheridan limits himself to one shot of an American flag being flown upside down. Other than that, he lets the terrible situation on the reservation speak for itself. An actor before he was a screenwriter, Mr. Sheridan clearly spent a lot of his time learning about filmmaking on movie sets; his direction is assured throughout. A standoff scene near the movie‰Ûªs finale would not be shamed if put next to one of Michael Mann‰Ûªs better set pieces.

The movie builds to a shocking climax, even though the revelation of the bad guys makes immediate, sickening sense. The film‰Ûªs ultimate statement sinks in later, with an expanded awareness that the justice done by the good guys in this film is not nearly sufficient with respect to the larger injustice done to Native Americans.

The case lights up a cold fury in Cory. He reassures the victim‰Ûªs father, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm a hunter.‰Ûù He demonstrates to Jane that in this terrain, it‰Ûªs the landscape that will yield the most important answers, not the frequently recalcitrant Indians whom Jane wants to interview. He‰Ûªs right, of course, and his wisdom is borne out in some gut-wrenching ways.

Taylor Sheridan, the screenwriter of last year‰Ûªs socially conscious crime drama ‰ÛÏHell or High Water,‰Ûù proves an undeniably strong director with his second effort in that job, ‰ÛÏWind River.‰Ûù The movie opens on a breathtaking night sky and snow-capped mountains, with a young woman running over a long stretch of open land. ‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs a meadow in my perfect world,‰Ûù a female voice says. The juxtaposition of the imagery and the poetics make for a peculiar opening. Eventually it all makes tragic sense.

Not unlike an expensively tattooed panhandler, the couple elicit only a skeptical kind of sympathy. The American filmmaker John Cassavetes was able to make this kind of hate-love-hate scenario compulsively watchable (in movies like ‰ÛÏA Woman Under the Influence‰Ûù), partly because he made his characters operatically brash, their actions relentlessly emotionally combustible. ‰ÛÏAfter Love,‰Ûù written by Mazarine Pingeot, Fanny Burdino and Mr. Lafosse, and originally titled the less evocative but frankly more apt ‰ÛÏL‰ÛªÌ©conomie du couple,‰Ûù is too polite by half ever to generate any such sparks.

Marie, a narrowly conceived character nevertheless played well by BÌ©rÌ©nice Bejo, is uptight and withholding; Boris, by turns warmly bearish and broadly truculent as played by CÌ©dric Kahn, is controlling and manipulative, not to mention aggressively self-pitying. When he responds sympathetically to Marie‰Ûªs vulnerability, it‰Ûªs hard to tell if he is being sincere in his affection, or just exploiting a weakness. (Marthe Keller makes a welcome contribution as Marie‰Ûªs mother, whose voice-of-experience advice to her daughter falls on willfully deaf ears.)

The Belgian director Joachim Lafosse‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏAfter Love‰Ûù is an irritating movie about irritating people. The married Boris and Marie are breaking up but for economic reasons are still sharing the same living space (to which the entire movie is confined; good thing there‰Ûªs an outdoor patio). They have lovely twin daughters in front of whom they mostly argue ‰ÛÓ vehemently and with little regard for how these displays will affect the girls. Money is an issue; Marie comes from affluence, while Boris, a contractor who refers to himself as an architect, rarely has any. He incessantly confronts Marie over the labor he‰Ûªs put into their apartment.

The film ‰ÛÓ Mr. Jain‰Ûªs first feature ‰ÛÓ seems to argue that the workers, facing few or no other options, have succumbed to a form of Stockholm syndrome, and points to unionization as a potential corrective. ‰ÛÏIf the workers unite, they can get the bosses to yield,‰Ûù one worker says. ‰ÛÏBut the laborers are not united.‰Ûù

As the movie begins, lengthy Steadicam shots survey the layout of a textile factory in Sachin, India, and introduce its workers. The scenery is so gray that fabrics, embers and dyes are just about all that pops against the background. The ideological charge leveled for decades at this strain of filmmaking is that such eye-catching tableaus romanticize poverty, but prettified squalor has become sadly familiar in global documentary filmmaking. In ‰ÛÏMachines,‰Ûù even at barely more than an hour, the style leads to diminishing returns.

Following in the footsteps of other documentaries from the last decade and a half ‰ÛÓ including ‰ÛÏBehemoth,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏDarwin‰Ûªs Nightmare‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏWorkingman‰Ûªs Death‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ Rahul Jain‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMachines‰Ûù casts an unflinching eye on dire poverty, trafficking in the disjunction between surreal, aesthetically striking images and sounds and the squalor those images depict.
If they are parts in a machine, maybe they can form a whole. And even then, success is not guaranteed.
The imperious bosses openly disdain their employees. One dismisses his workers as careless with money and, in many cases, uninterested in their families (although we‰Ûªve already heard otherwise).

‰ÛÏMachines‰Ûù is at its strongest when interviewing the workers, who aren‰Ûªt named and who, the film not so subtly implies, have become cogs in the machinery themselves. One man says he has taken loans to travel for work and rides a standing-room-only train on his 1,000-mile journey to the factory. In his view, this situation would only be exploitation if he were forced to work there. Another worker asks, ‰ÛÏWhy would I get angry if I am being paid for the work I do?‰Ûù The shifts pay next to nothing and last 12 hours.

Kim (Song Kang-ho) is a garrulous if gruff widowed father to an 11-year-old girl, impatient with traffic jams resulting from protests in Seoul. If it weren‰Ûªt for the back rent he owes, he wouldn‰Ûªt need to take Hinzpeter (Thomas Kretschmann) to the besieged Gwangju. But when he does, they witness a huge street demonstration that is met with tear gas and military brutality. The soft-spoken Hinzpeter is determined to smuggle footage of the dictatorship‰Ûªs abuses to a German news organization, while the heretofore neutral Kim comes to realize the urgency of Hinzpeter‰Ûªs mission.

The film climaxes with a breathless escape from Gwangju, as Kim and Hinzpeter elude government vehicles with the aid of other cabdrivers. But most impressive is Mr. Song, who persuasively conveys a working stiff‰Ûªs political awakening.

With ‰ÛÏA Taxi Driver,‰Ûù the director Jang Hun (‰ÛÏThe Front Line‰Ûù) takes historical events in South Korea ‰ÛÓ the imposition of martial law in 1980 by the dictator Chun Doo-hwan ‰ÛÓ to construct an affecting what-if tale. The plot has a factual basis: the relationship between a German TV journalist, JÌ_rgen Hinzpeter, and the cabdriver who drove him from Seoul to the locked-down city of Gwangju, at the time a hotbed of pro-democracy student rebellion and violent repression. While the real-life name of the cabby and his ultimate fate are unclear (his name may have been Kim Sa-bok), the film calls him Kim Man-seob and gives him a poignant back story and destiny.

‰ÛÏAnnabelle: Creation‰Ûù is the third cinematic outing for the demon-hosting doll of the title, after a guest spot on ‰ÛÏThe Conjuring‰Ûù in 2013 and a star turn the next year in ‰ÛÏAnnabelle.‰Ûù The narratives lurch backward, with each film acting as a prequel to its predecessor. Should this trend continue, we could very well see one of Annabelle‰Ûªs ancestors causing catastrophic delays in the building of the pyramids.

For now, though, we‰Ûªre in the 1940s as a doll maker and his wife (Anthony LaPaglia and Miranda Otto) suffer the loss of their beloved daughter. A dozen years later, he‰Ûªs a shuffling shell and she‰Ûªs a disfigured recluse; so they open their rambling California farmhouse to a young nun and a clutch of orphaned girls. Wake up, Annabelle, your victims are here! Might I suggest you begin with the little one with the leg brace?

As with last year‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLights Out,‰Ûù he proves a master of the flash-scare, a nifty choreographer of precipitous timing and striptease visuals. But he‰Ûªs also adroit with more leisurely horrors, like the snap-crackle-pop of the murderous shade flexing for the kill, or the slow animation of a sacklike scarecrow into a toothy obscenity.
In this kind of horror movie, no one ever seems to hear you scream.

And so she does, terrorizing the youngsters in cheekily effective scenes while their host hovers ineffectually on the fringes and his wife cowers behind her bed curtains. Gary Dauberman‰Ûªs script is lamentably light on mythological details (can the demon survive indefinitely outside the doll, or does it have a curfew?), but its vacuousness allows the director, David F. Sandberg, to string together jolts any way he pleases.

But the distinction doesn‰Ûªt really matter, since the movie‰Ûªs chief investment is not in the fates of any of its characters, nor in anything like realism, but rather in its own cool. Sometimes it flaunts its clichÌ©s ‰ÛÓ Nick‰Ûªs disability, and Benny Safdie‰Ûªs slack-jawed portrayal of it, is a big one ‰ÛÓ and other times it cloaks them in rough visual textures and jumpy, bumpy camera movements, so that a rickety genre thrill ride feels like something daring and new. It isn‰Ûªt. It‰Ûªs stale, empty and cold.

This pair is not exactly Butch and Sundance, even in their own addled, delusional minds. And while Ray is hapless and almost heroically stupid, Connie is a more complicated, less clownish figure. He has a hint of heart, as well as a cruel, predatory streak that the Safdies‰Ûª expose for shocks and laughs, daring you to either take offense or take the joke, and banking on your queasiness in either case.

Nick and Connie Nikas are brothers, like Josh and Benny Safdie, the directors of ‰ÛÏGood Time.‰Ûù Nick ‰ÛÓ played by Benny Safdie ‰ÛÓ is mentally disabled, while Connie (Robert Pattinson) might charitably be described as an idiot. Motivated by a volatile mix of desperation and bravado, he involves Nick in a poorly planned, haphazardly executed bank robbery. You can bet money on a disastrous outcome, though you might not foresee the precise sequence of mayhem and farce that unfolds on the streets of Queens over a single freezing night. The caper includes an after-hours visit to an amusement park, a soda bottle full of LSD, a case of mistaken identity and plenty of chases, beatings and narrow escapes.

And yet, partly because Mr. Pattinson‰Ûªs movie-star incandescence can‰Ûªt quite be obscured by facial hair and bad lighting, and partly because of the immutable laws of genre and spectacle, you sort of have no choice but to root for him. You‰Ûªre stuck with him, and you might as well make the best of it. The Safdies have explored this kind of ambiguity before. In ‰ÛÏDaddy Longlegs,‰Ûù the wayward father, played by Ronald Bronstein (a character based on their own father), was appalling and charming in almost equal measure; his charisma both enabled and camouflaged his wanton irresponsibility. You might have recoiled in horror at his recklessness, but you couldn‰Ûªt deny that he loved his kids.

It doesn‰Ûªt take much looking to notice an ugly racial dimension in Connie‰Ûªs behavior, though most critics overlooked it when the film was shown in Cannes this spring. When the Nikas brothers carry out the bank job, they wear hard hats, reflective vests and dark latex masks that function as crude, criminal blackface. Later, Connie takes advantage of a Caribbean immigrant (Gladys Mathon) and her granddaughter (Taliah Lennice Webster), sweet-talking and bullying them into aiding and abetting him. A black security guard (Barkhad Abdi) becomes another brutally abused pawn in Connie‰Ûªs senseless game.

The Safdies are as clever and crafty as Connie is inept and impulsive. ‰ÛÏGood Time,‰Ûù their third co-directed fictional feature ‰ÛÓ after the autobiographical ‰ÛÏDaddy Longlegs‰Ûù and the addiction romance ‰ÛÏHeaven Knows What‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ moves smartly and propulsively to the stressed-out strains of Daniel Lopatin‰Ûªs edge-of-a-heart-attack score. The smudgy, grimy urban landscape ‰ÛÓ emergency rooms, fast-food restaurants, blocks of modest, over-mortgaged, squeezed-together houses ‰ÛÓ is shot (by Sean Price Williams) with a fastidious avoidance of prettiness. The story doesn‰Ûªt twist and turn so much as squirm and jump like an eel in the bottom of a rowboat. The biggest surprises confirm what an unbelievable slimeball Connie is. He‰Ûªs about as hard to root for as any movie outlaw you can think of.

Connie, for his part, adores his brother and has a way with dogs. While these traits don‰Ûªt exactly make him likable, they grant him a minimal benefit of the doubt. His manipulation of his girlfriend (Jennifer Jason Leigh) isn‰Ûªt nice, but on the other hand she is so whiny and needy that you can‰Ûªt feel too bad. Connie also has the good luck (at least as far as the audience‰Ûªs good graces are concerned) of falling in with the one guy in Queens who could make him look like a criminal genius ‰ÛÓ a gangly doofus named Ray (Buddy Duress), who has been spending his first days out of jail aggressively pursuing the opposite of rehabilitation.

This pattern does not seem accidental. The question is what it means ‰ÛÓ what degree of self-consciousness or critical distance ‰ÛÏGood Time‰Ûù brings to its depiction of bottom-of-the-barrel white privilege. You could infer a satirical dimension if you wanted to, or even a righteous indictment of what a lowlife can get away with if he has Mr. Pattinson‰Ûªs complexion. Or you could look at the film‰Ûªs riot of racial signifiers ‰ÛÓ the musical and pop-cultural references as well as the demographics of the setting ‰ÛÓ as a form of trolling, a coy, self-disavowing provocation.

In his adaptation of Fumiyo Kouno‰Ûªs 2007 manga, the director, Sunao Katabuchi, has recreated the Japanese home front with historical accuracy, and ‰ÛÏIn This Corner of the World‰Ûù thrives when it lingers on incidental observations of life in wartime. Suzu transforms a kimono into a jumpsuit; she makes the most of her family‰Ûªs meager rations. ‰ÛÏMoonlight Serenade‰Ûù plays on the radio at the military hospital where Suzu visits her father-in-law, and her niece Harumi asks, ‰ÛÏIs this the enemy‰Ûªs music?‰Ûù

When a movie begins in the streets of 1930s Hiroshima, the city‰Ûªs eventual devastation can seem like a foregone conclusion. But despite its setting in Hiroshima and the nearby port city, Kure, the new anime film ‰ÛÏIn This Corner of the World‰Ûù is as soft as its brown-and-green palette, as romantic as its perpetually blushing protagonist, Suzu, a young wife coming of age during World War II. As war rages, Suzu‰Ûªs endurance becomes the personification of hope for postwar Japan.

Compared with the fine detail of her home, though, Suzu is drawn with broad strokes. She has the artistic eye to see bombs burst like flashes of colored paint, and the emotional depth to recognize death as a crude scrawl of white pencil on black, yet Suzu asks fewer questions of war than she does a marriage proposal. Bombs drop and cities fall, but Suzu never wonders why Kure needs its navy, or why she should support the war effort. As our window into a world lost to violence, Suzu gives us the chance to see rabbits in rivers, though her rosy view obscures history‰Ûªs shadows with a preponderance of golden light.

Matt Spicer‰Ûªs debut feature introduces Ingrid (Aubrey Plaza) as an obsessive, dangerous app addict who crashes a wedding and pepper-sprays the bride, ostensibly for not inviting her. It turns out the bride wasn‰Ûªt a friend, but merely encouraged Ingrid by commenting on one of her posts.

Ms. Plaza is a whiz with timing and does a deft job of shifting viewers‰Ûª sympathy; her character can be loathsome or pathetic depending on the scene. O‰ÛªShea Jackson Jr., as her Batman-obsessed landlord, is every bit as funny and nearly walks away with the movie. Still, Mr. Spicer cops out by going with the obvious ending. Admittedly, he has tough competition. Real life already gave social media ‰ÛÏinfluencers‰Ûù a far more cutting sendup. It was called Fyre Fest.

Ingrid‰Ûªs next fixation is Taylor Sloane (Elizabeth Olsen), a social media gadfly. To get close to her, Ingrid moves to Los Angeles, visits a restaurant that Taylor has praised (repeating her order) and abducts Taylor‰Ûªs dog as a pretext for returning it. As the two become besties, the movie makes the not-revelatory point that Taylor‰Ûªs stage-managed life ‰ÛÓ including her dream of opening a boutique (‰ÛÏmy Instagram, but in real life‰Ûù) ‰ÛÓ is barely less fraudulent than Ingrid‰Ûªs.

‰ÛÏIngrid Goes West‰Ûù comes close to saying something sharp about how social media promotes envy and the illusion of connectivity, but when a comedy chooses such an obvious target, it should have the courtesy to aim from an oblique angle.

Really, though, all he advertises is the vacuity of his imagination, which he mistakes for the moral emptiness of his characters and the society that spawned them. They are not ‰ÛÓ or not all ‰ÛÓ drawn from its margins or its oppressed groups. A few of the conspirators (there are eight in all, plus an inside man at the store) seem to be children of immigrants from suburban housing projects. The others come from France‰Ûªs middle and upper classes. One of the leaders is a student at an elite university, with family connections to the minister of the interior, whose office is among the group‰Ûªs targets.

‰ÛÏNocturama‰Ûù might be an interesting movie about terrorism if there were no such thing as terrorism. If, that is, politically motivated shootings and bombings in big cities were fantastical tropes or metaphorical conceits, like zombie epidemics or extraterrestrial invasions. But perhaps ‰ÛÏinteresting‰Ûù is too strong a word. Without a real-world correlative for the actions it depicts, Bertrand Bonello‰Ûªs new film would merely be tedious and pretentious rather than repellent.

Her fatalism mirrors the nihilism behind the act, and also the chilly abstraction that characterizes Mr. Bonello‰Ûªs approach to a potentially volatile subject. As they try on fancy clothes and fiddle with wide-screen televisions and top-of-the-line sound equipment, the young rebels prove themselves to be perfect citizens of the system they supposedly hate. They don‰Ûªt really want to overthrow it or force it to change, but rather to make some noise, to feel as if they‰Ûªve done something.

Part 1 is fast-moving and suspenseful, Part 2 languorous and luxuriant. The young terrorists are brisk and businesslike until the plastic explosives detonate. Then they act out a parody of jaded consumerist hedonism, browsing among the brand names. Nike, Fendi, Issey Miyake ‰ÛÓ Mr. Bonello places the products so lovingly in the frame that you might think he was being paid to do it.

He treats them with a mixture of solicitude and detachment that reveals its cruelty by degrees. The closer they come to their inevitable bloody end, the more human these mixed-up kids appear. We learn their names, and see evidence of tenderness and folly as well as steely heartlessness. They‰Ûªre so normal! But that revelation is really just confirmation of Mr. Bonello‰Ûªs shallow cynicism, his facile conviction that he has built a trap for the audience‰Ûªs conscience rather than a useless, self-consuming artifact. When the ruthless, faceless power of the state finally asserts itself, what is meant to be a shocking climax merits little more than a nod and a shrug. What took so long? There‰Ûªs nothing political about that response: Like ‰ÛÏNocturama,‰Ûù it‰Ûªs nothing but an expression of aesthetic ennui.

An older generation of French radicals used to speak of the ‰ÛÏpropaganda of the deed‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the idea that violent or disruptive action can function as a vehicle of political meaning. Today‰Ûªs terrorists are partly the inheritors of this notion, sending dramatic, lethal messages to enemies and sympathizers alike. For Mr. Bonello‰Ûªs cadre of good-looking militants, deeds are more like marketing slogans, expressions of a free-floating aesthetic of tedium and mild stimulation.

There is no denying that Mr. Bonello, whose previous films include ‰ÛÏHouse of Pleasures‰Ûù (a prurient peek behind the scenes at an early-20th-century bordello) and ‰ÛÏSaint Laurent‰Ûù (a salacious tour of ‰Ûª70s couture), possesses cinematic skill and suavity to spare. The story told in ‰ÛÏNocturama‰Ûù splits neatly into before and after, with a few flashbacks thrown in for clarity and variety. The first half follows a collection of young French people as they prepare to carry out a series of attacks in Paris; the second stays with them in the immediate aftermath, as they kill time in a high-end department store.

Other targets include the chief executive of a bank, a row of parked cars, a gilded equestrian statue and a skyscraper with the word ‰ÛÏglobal‰Ûù conveniently displayed near its crown. The cause that motivates this violence is never specified. One member of the gang is a Muslim who doesn‰Ûªt drink alcohol and believes he will be welcomed in paradise as a martyr, but religious extremism doesn‰Ûªt seem to be part of the overall agenda. Nor does any recognizable political ideology or economic grievance. ‰ÛÏIt was bound to happen,‰Ûù a bored-sounding young woman says to a perpetrator who has wandered out for a cigarette.
‰ÛÏPilgrimage‰Ûù is a gutsy movie, and not just because a character gets his entrails ripped out. Here the filmmakers take a chance and turn a strange-seeming premise into a fast-moving tale.

The youngest monk, Diarmuid (Tom Holland, in a robe instead of the tights he wears as the new Spider-Man), is reliably good-hearted, the better to contrast with Raymond (Richard Armitage), one of the brutal bad guys. John Lynch, Ruaidhri Conroy and Hugh O‰ÛªConor, all convincing, play the other three monks.

This Ireland isn‰Ûªt the land of Guinness, and green is in short supply; most scenes here are steeped in shades of gray, matching the film‰Ûªs forbidding mood. Enemies soon arrive to steal the relic, and the chases begin.

The bulk of the story is set in Ireland in 1209, where a group of monks safeguards a holy relic. A visitor, Geraldus (Stanley Weber), arrives with papal orders to bring this MacGuffin to Rome. Four of the monks and a secretive mute (Jon Bernthal, sullen and entrancing) are assigned to shepherd Geraldus and the relic across the country.

Amid that gore (including a harsh stoning ‰ÛÓ not that there‰Ûªs any other kind ‰ÛÓ and an exciting yet vicious conclusion), ‰ÛÏPilgrimage‰Ûù raises a question or two about unexamined beliefs and religious zeal. Those questions, as well as all that blood, won‰Ûªt appeal to everyone. But those who can stomach them will receive some dark rewards.

Brendan Muldowney, the director, and Jamie Hannigan, the screenwriter, keep something happening in each scene; the pace is swift, except for shots of misty hills and shadowy forests that are lingered over as the ominous score moans. The main battle is an exercise in Grand Guignol, with swords, arrows and axes impaling faces and severing limbs.

Written by the director, Rebecca Zlotowski, and Robin Campillo ‰ÛÓ of ‰ÛÏThe Class‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏBPM (Beats Per Minute),‰Ûù a recent Cannes prizewinner ‰ÛÓ this film, mostly set in the 1930s, stars Natalie Portman and Lily-Rose Depp as Laura and Kate Barlow, a spiritualist sister act from the United States. On the Paris stop of their European tour, they give a private sÌ©ance to a film producer, AndrÌ© Korben (Emmanuel Salinger). As Laura notices, his accent suggests he isn‰Ûªt from France originally. (Ms. Portman speaks many of her lines in what sounds like credible French.)

‰ÛÏPlanetarium‰Ûù is at least three features in one ‰ÛÓ a supernatural story, a Holocaust drama and a snapshot of the French film industry in the years leading up to World War II ‰ÛÓ yet it‰Ûªs missing some of the connective tissue that would make those movies fit together. It‰Ûªs unusual to see such excellence in costumes, sets and cinematography lavished on this degree of narrative muddle.

AndrÌ© becomes eager to film the mediums at work, with the hope of recording evidence of a spectral presence. (And to paraphrase a professor in the film, cinema ‰ÛÓ even without actual wraiths ‰ÛÓ is an invention that captures the ghosts of the future.) AndrÌ© also offers the sisters residence in his home, in an arrangement fraught with class tension.

But much of what happens next ‰ÛÓ romance, illness ‰ÛÓ seems arbitrary, as characters come and go without proper introductions. Tidiness isn‰Ûªt crucial, but watching ‰ÛÏPlanetarium‰Ûù often feels like making contact with fragments of a great three-hour movie.

And there is catnip for dreamers, in the form of the so-called golden record enclosed on both vessels. ‰ÛÏA message in a bottle into the ocean,‰Ûù says Jim Bell, author of ‰ÛÏThe Interstellar Age‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and to alien life-forms that might find it. Each disc (complete with instructions) includes, among other things, photos; diagrams; greetings in 53 languages; 27 pieces of music from different cultures, including ‰ÛÏJohnny B. Goode‰Ûù; and the song of a humpback whale.

The accounts of scientists, whose enthusiasm still glows, is as wondrous as the technology seen here. Linda Morabito, a navigation engineer, recalls discovering gas plumes on Jupiter‰Ûªs moon Io. ‰ÛÏI had the first evidence of active volcanism beyond Earth,‰Ûù she says, beaming. Time-lapse Voyager-eye views of planets as they get nearer convey a sense of the epiphanies experienced in mission control.

Consider: In 1977, the pair were launched (two, to increase the odds of success); in 1979 Voyager 1 began relaying information from Jupiter, and in 1980 approached Saturn and its moon Titan, nearly a billion miles from Earth. In 1986, Voyager 2 reached Uranus, and three years later Neptune. In 2012, Voyager 1 became the first man-made object to exit our solar system and enter interstellar space, from which it still sends signals. (Voyager 2 is en route.)
‰ÛÏWe did something really, really great,‰Ûù Brad Smith, an imaging specialist, says of the 40-year adventure. Yes, and NASA, and Ms. Reynolds, deserve to take a very deep bow.

For any believer in humankind‰Ûªs instinct to transcend boundaries, the Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 space probes, and the NASA team that produced them, inspire awe. ‰ÛÏThe Farthest,‰Ûù a dazzling documentary written and directed by Emer Reynolds, illustrates why.

Lacking the book‰Ûªs episodic sprawl and psychological nuance, their movie clings to its essential tension. Jeannette, her father‰Ûªs favorite ‰ÛÓ his nickname for her is Mountain Goat ‰ÛÓ admires her parents‰Ûª free-spirited individualism even as she suffers amid the chaos of their chosen way of life. Money is always short, and the family often picks up and moves, one step ahead of bill collectors or law enforcement. Rose Mary paints landscapes, still lifes and portraits, while Rex, bouncing from job to job, conjures fantastical, almost-practical projects, like the solar-powered mansion that gives the movie its title.

Jeannette, played in middle childhood by a wonderfully shrewd and watchful young actress named Ella Anderson, will grow up to be played by Brie Larson and to grapple with adulthood in late-‰Ûª80s New York, where she writes a gossip column. Eventually, she‰Ûªll also write a best-selling memoir of her hectic childhood, which has now been adapted into this uneven, conscientious film, directed by Destin Daniel Cretton and written by Mr. Cretton and Andrew Lanham.

While Jeannette‰Ûªs attempt to deal with the men in her life provides ‰ÛÏThe Glass Castle‰Ûù with a bit of drama (and some comic scenes as well), it‰Ûªs frustrating to see the resourceful Ms. Larson pinioned between two showy male performers. Jeannette, the central voice and consciousness in the book, is an oddly blurred character on screen. And the film itself loses focus as it drifts toward the conventions of the coming-of-age story and the family-dysfunction melodrama.

Meanwhile, in the film‰Ûªs back-and-forth time scheme, adult Jeannette tries to find a place for her past (and her parents, who are now squatting on Manhattan‰Ûªs pre-gentrified Lower East Side) in her polished, professional existence. What this mostly means is trying to reconcile her attachment to Rex with her engagement to David, a sacrificial yuppie played by Max Greenfield. He‰Ûªs not a bad guy, he just cares about money, material possessions and what other people think. All of that makes him, somewhat too obviously, Rex‰Ûªs opposite.

‰ÛÏThe Glass Castle‰Ûù wrestles with two conflicting impulses: the longing for order and the desire for wildness. The main object of that ambivalence is Rex Walls, a big-talking, big-dreaming ne‰Ûªer-do-well played with the usual guile and gusto by Woody Harrelson.

Rex would qualify as a helicopter parent if that phrase referred to someone who encouraged his kid to pilot a chopper without proper training or safety equipment. If he and his wife, Rose Mary (Naomi Watts), don‰Ûªt go quite that far, it may only be for lack of available aircraft. Their four children are, to use another slightly anachronistic idiom in reference to a story set mostly in the ‰Ûª60s and ‰Ûª70s, decidedly free range. At a swimming pool, Rex throws Jeannette, his second-oldest daughter, into deep water to teach her to swim. That‰Ûªs hardly the craziest thing he does, but it‰Ûªs a convenient metaphor for his approach to parenting.

The clan‰Ûªs nomadic period, which takes up roughly the first half of Ms. Walls‰Ûªs memoir, is truncated on screen, and the audience never gets a full dose of the paternal wanderlust that provides Jeannette‰Ûªs childhood with its thrills and terrors. We spend more time in Welch, W.Va., Rex‰Ûªs Appalachian hometown, to which he had vowed never to return. Once there, in the shadow of his sinister mother, Erma (Robin Bartlett), Rex starts drinking more and dreaming less. As his charm dissolves, he devolves from a mischievous daredevil into a ranting, tyrannical drunk.

Conformity wins out in the end. Not that Rex ‰ÛÓ or the indefatigable Mr. Harrelson ‰ÛÓ is ever really tamed. But Mr. Lanham and Mr. Cretton, who proved himself a sensitive, risk-taking filmmaker with ‰ÛÏShort Term 12‰Ûù (also starring Ms. Larson), couldn‰Ûªt find a way to contain both the father‰Ûªs anarchy and the daughter‰Ûªs skeptical affection for him. The movie bogs down in dialogue-heavy obvious scenes, some of which refer to events in the book that didn‰Ûªt make it onto the screen. It‰Ûªs both too tidy and too messy, and at the same time neither quite wild nor quite sensible enough.

Washing up in Thomas‰Ûªs Lower East Side apartment building, W. F. quickly becomes the young man‰Ûªs literary life coach. Heaven knows he needs one: An aspiring writer who equates rebellion with a downscale ZIP code and a whining contempt for the financial success of his father, Ethan (Pierce Brosnan), Thomas moons over a gorgeous young woman (Kiersey Clemons) and frets over his emotionally fragile mother (a warm Cynthia Nixon). He probably also needs a therapist, preferably a Freudian, to unravel why he‰Ûªs obsessively stalking his father‰Ûªs mistress, Johanna (Kate Beckinsale).

A wide-open goal post for accusations of triteness and affectation, Marc Webb‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Only Living Boy in New York‰Ûù dares us to score the second we hear Jeff Bridges‰Ûªs cynical, omniscient voice-over. As W. F., an alcoholic author with a mysterious connection to the movie‰Ûªs nebbishy hero, Thomas (Callum Turner), Mr. Bridges slips delightedly into the kind of arrogant-artist role he perfected in ‰ÛÏThe Door in the Floor‰Ûù (2004). Here, his character is more grimy and less lustful, but no less certain of his own rectitude.
Everyone, in fact, works hard to transcend the artifice, and they deserve better. So, for that matter, do Simon & Garfunkel.

Burdened by thuddingly obvious musical choices (including Simon & Garfunkel‰Ûªs gorgeous title song and, for crying out loud, Dylan‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏVisions of Johanna‰Ûù), Allan Loeb‰Ûªs script is glib and grating. The way is cleared for W. F., with his aura of slovenly glamour and precise knowledge of the cooking temperature of heroin, to steal the show. But Mr. Turner holds his own, gamely countering his strong resemblance to the young Richard Gere with a performance of perplexed immaturity.

Anger seethes throughout the story, set days before the 2011 Egyptian Revolution. Tarik Saleh, the writer and director, constantly eyeballs the crowded city, its chaotic masses and its crumbling buildings.
