Cigarettes are smoked by the carton, exhaust chokes the air and everything is falling apart. It‰Ûªs horribly fascinating to watch.

Noredin gets the case of a murdered woman, a crime that higher-ups are eager to label a suicide. But Salwa (Mari Malek), a hotel maid, saw something, and Noredin develops a shred of conscience that leads him to investigate. Perhaps he‰Ûªs spurred by his father, who looks upon him and his ill-gotten gains with disappointment and says, ‰ÛÏYou can‰Ûªt buy dignity, son.‰Ûù

Noredin (Fares Fares), a police detective, trolls the city, demanding payoffs from whoever is unlucky enough to cross his path. To call him corrupt is not to say that the rest of the force is clean. Everyone here is on the take, all the time, from cops to clerks to politicians.
‰ÛÏForget it, Noredin. It‰Ûªs Cairo.‰Ûù

The trouble with the movie ‰ÛÓ and it‰Ûªs significant ‰ÛÓ is that Mr. Saleh is so keen to survey Egypt‰Ûªs dysfunction that his pacing wanes. It‰Ûªs possible to admire each scene and still see this film, in its entirety, as in need of some serious sharpening.

Had a similar line not been made famous in another noir, that one might serve as an apt ending for ‰ÛÏThe Nile Hilton Incident,‰Ûù a film that owes debts to ‰ÛÏChinatown,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Long Goodbye‰Ûù and other crime mysteries that are marinated in cynicism.

Mr. Fares, playing against his sidekick role in the superb ‰ÛÏDepartment Q‰Ûù films, is captivating as he takes the lead. He goes down those mean streets as a man must go, but here he‰Ûªs got an added worry ‰ÛÓ those streets are set to explode.

This comes almost entirely from Steve, whose midlife anxieties ‰ÛÓ including an elusive, married lover and a neglectful agent ‰ÛÓ are the burr under the movie‰Ûªs saddle. Plagued by disturbing dreams and career frustrations, he becomes increasingly distracted and crabby, until every comic utterance feels like a shot across the bow of mortality. This poignancy makes the picture less humorous but potentially more substantive than its predecessors. And as the men imagine themselves Don Quixote and Sancho Panza (daftly abetted by Noel Harrison‰Ûªs 1960s hit ‰ÛÏThe Windmills of Your Mind‰Ûù), the film‰Ûªs failure to engage with these discomforts feels like a missed opportunity.

Yet even artists as gifted as these two can only hitchhike so long on the charisma of household names like Mick Jagger and Michael Caine, and the dueling impressions that fuel the franchise have become effortful and repetitive. (One extended bit on Roger Moore is tortured to the point of desperation.) And though the spaces between the funny voices are filled with verdant hillsides and vanilla beaches that stretch the length of the frame, there‰Ûªs an occasional sour edge to the comedic sparring.
Instead, Mr. Winterbottom and his team ‰ÛÓ by means of an extremely strange ending ‰ÛÓ appear to be setting us up for a Trip to Morocco. Sorry, guys, but that one‰Ûªs already been done.

One way to enjoy ‰ÛÏThe Trip to Spain,‰Ûù the third entry in Michael Winterbottom‰Ûªs gags-and-gastronomy franchise, would be to periodically mute the sound. That way, the therapeutic calm instilled by the glorious Iberian scenery (photographed by James Clarke in shimmering, almost edible pastels) could be savored uninterrupted by the performative patter of the two stars, Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon. I imagine that the diners seated near them in the restaurants where much of this movie takes place would have been grateful for mute buttons of their own.

Like ‰ÛÏThe Trip‰Ûù in 2011 and ‰ÛÏThe Trip to Italy‰Ûù three years later, this latest cushy assignment sends the lads ‰ÛÓ once again playing Steve and Rob, mildly fictionalized versions of themselves ‰ÛÓ tootling around a randomly chosen region, sampling menus and trading banter. I hesitate to say jokes, because, unlike the bounce and zing of the first movie, the tone here is more sober and the humor more strained. Barely squeaking by on a familiar formula and flimsy narrative (Steve is writing a book; Rob is scribbling restaurant reviews for The New York Times), the actors convey a sense of going through the motions. Eating sumptuous meals without apparent relish, jogging separately through impossibly gorgeous towns, and firing off celebrity impersonations with wearying one-upmanship, they perform with the competitive reflexivity of the longtime double act.

‰ÛÏWhose Streets?‰Ûù takes off from the night Mr. Brown was shot. One of the movie‰Ûªs subjects is David Whitt, a resident of the apartment complex on the street where the shooting took place, who is moved to take his video camera onto the streets to record police action as rioting started. Another thread follows Brittany Ferrell and Alexis Templeton, a couple navigating parenthood and school, and putting themselves at considerable risk as they lead and participate in demonstrations like one in which they formed a human chain to block traffic on a highway.

‰ÛÏWhose Streets?,‰Ûù a documentary about the unrest and activism in Ferguson, Mo., in the wake of the 2014 police shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, is choppy, sometimes unfocused, and in every respect the opposite of slick. Its directors, Sabaah Folayan and Damon Davis, are novice filmmakers, true; but I also suspect this movie‰Ûªs form is deliberate, part of its message. This is direct and frequently powerful filmmaking that doesn‰Ûªt much care about meeting my aesthetic standards.

The movie is punctuated with quotes by black historical figures ‰ÛÓ Martin Luther King Jr.‰Ûªs observation that ‰ÛÏa riot is the language of the unheard‰Ûù is particularly resonant. Much of the footage is from low-resolution video cameras and cellphones; the most professional-looking material here is from a television interview with Officer Darren Wilson, who shot Mr. Brown, in which he says, ‰ÛÏYou can‰Ûªt perform the duties of a police officer and have racism in you.‰Ûù This is shown in the same section that features on-the-fly shots of off-duty St. Louis police officers puffing their chests at activists at a town hall meeting. Another wrenching scene shows a protester trying to address a black female officer, the only person of color in a defensive line of cops; she holds her position even as tears fill her eyes.

You don‰Ûªt need to see the first ‰ÛÏNut Job‰Ûù movie to follow the sequel‰Ûªs nonsensical plot and the script‰Ûªs preference for bottom-shelf puns. The film‰Ûªs meanspirited tone picks on both creatures and humans, like construction workers for being illiterate, animals almost too dumb to survive and the wicked rich.

The director Cal Brunker, previously a storyboard artist for ‰ÛÏDespicable Me,‰Ûù does not bring the warmth of that movie to this effort. Mr. Brunker, who wrote the script with five other people, fashions ‰ÛÏNut Job 2‰Ûù as its own dull amusement park ride, where slapdash animation, a dismal story and a score by Heitor Pereira repeated ad infinitum makes for few thrills.

The critters, led by a dour squirrel named Surly (Will Arnett), are in danger of losing their city park home thanks to an egomaniacal mayor (Bobby Moynihan) with a Texan accent who plans to build a shoddy amusement park over the sanctioned greenscape.

Apart from Mr. Arnett‰Ûªs Surly, no other animal gets more than a few scraps of screen time, including Jackie Chan as the leader of a Chinatown mice gang and Bobby Cannavale as a dimwitted pup. Surly‰Ûªs relationship with his love interest, Andie (Katherine Heigl), plays out like a Goofus and Gallant comic strip in which he does things the easy way while she moralizes about the importance of hard work and coddles Surly through his tantrums.

The animated film ‰ÛÏThe Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature‰Ûù features fluffy creatures and not much else. The jokes are thin, the computer animation is wanting and the inane plot is a series of set pieces strung together.

Young men and their elders together experiencing the rigors of the wilderness is a kind of rite all over the world. It can be a time of self-discovery and liberation. In ‰ÛÏThe Wound,‰Ûù a group of South African teenagers and their adult caretakers gather in a camp near mountains to observe a Xhosa ritual. The young men, called novitiates, are circumcised, and spend multiple weeks in the camp healing under supervision of the adults, who themselves underwent the procedure years before.

In this austere and unsettling film, directed by John Trengove and inspired by a novel by Thando Mgqolozana (who worked on the screenplay with Malusi Bengu and Mr. Trengove), the camp, which is the movie‰Ûªs only setting, becomes a kind of prison. The taciturn Xolani (Nakhane TourÌ©) is charged with looking after a sullen boy named Kwanda (Niza Jay Ncoyini). He‰Ûªs also hooking up on the sly with Vija (Bongile Mantsai), another male caretaker with a wife and children back home. The campfire conversations of blustery teenagers and chest-puffing elders contrast with the shame and rage of Xolani, who is not out, and Vija, who is leading a double life. As it happens, Kwanda isn‰Ûªt having it. He‰Ûªs relatively comfortable with his sexuality and disgusted by Xolani, whom he sees as a hypocrite for having an affair with a married man.

Mr. Trengove shoots the film in intimate wide-screen, getting in close to the characters as they tamp down explosive feelings, often letting the spectacular landscapes break down into soft-focus abstractions. His direction is perfectly judged up to and including the shudder-inducing ending.

The film‰Ûªs writer, director, producer and editor, Terry Sanders, is best known for winning an Oscar with the director Freida Lee Mock for the documentary ‰ÛÏMaya Lin: A Strong Clear Vision‰Ûù (itself best known for winning the year that ‰ÛÏHoop Dreams‰Ûù wasn‰Ûªt nominated). He has said that this script sat dormant for 45 years. Realizing such a long-deferred passion project would be an accomplishment for anyone. Still, it‰Ûªs hard to ignore that the harshly lit digital cinematography and the acting styles seem wildly out of step with the period, or that Mr. Sanders often clumsily frames his shots ‰ÛÓ with his lens in his performers‰Ûª faces ‰ÛÓ to hide contemporary backdrops.

‰ÛÏLiza, Liza‰Ûù is mostly so familiar ‰ÛÓ a standard teenage-lovers-on-the-lam tale ‰ÛÓ that it could have been set anywhere. With her boyfriend, Brett (Sean H. Scully), about to move East, Liza (Mikey Madison) runs away with him on a motorcycle trip up Big Sur. There are some signs of the times, including a druggy love-in, references to the draft, a roving gang of vaguely Mansonish thugs and a repeated Buffy Sainte-Marie song. But the question of whether the couple will consummate their relationship isn‰Ûªt a sufficient source of tension.

Ultra-low-budget features deserve leeway on verisimilitude, but you have to shut your eyes and plug your ears to maintain the illusion that ‰ÛÏLiza, Liza, Skies Are Grey‰Ûù is set in 1966, an impression that an opening title card, the occasional glimpsed appliance and a surprisingly small number of the costumes strain to convey.

Not that the plot is anything earth-shakingly original. ‰ÛÏLogan Lucky‰Ûù sticks to the ‰ÛÏOceans‰Ûù template so faithfully that someone makes a joke about it. Who cares? The pleasures of the heist genre are always procedural and specific. These movies are all the same, but also always different because of the particular mix of personalities and circumstances. What they celebrate, above all, is the combination of craft, planning and problem-solving ingenuity that can turn a job of work into a work of art. They are, in other words, the quintessential movie movies, reflecting the collaborative challenges and logistical triumphs of the production cycle.

Of the three movies released this summer that self-consciously reactivate an old-school outlaw mythology ‰ÛÓ the others are Edgar Wright‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBaby Driver‰Ûù and Josh and Benny Safdie‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGood Time‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ this one has the most to say and the least to prove. Whereas the other directors aggressively promote their own coolness, flaunting borrowed attitudes and showy retrofitted styles, Mr. Soderbergh revels in squareness, and in a loose self-confidence that disguises its mastery. ‰ÛÏLogan Lucky‰Ûù is a terrific movie. That‰Ûªs a matter of skill, and maybe also of luck. But mostly it‰Ûªs a matter of generosity.

Mr. Soderbergh never speeds through the twists and bumps. He downshifts and pulls onto the shoulder, letting the story take care of itself while the audience enjoys the sometimes funny, sometimes fractious, sometimes wistful pleasure of the characters‰Ûª company. By the time you encounter Hilary Swank‰Ûªs F.B.I. agent, or figure out that the obnoxious British energy-drink mogul who is the only truly villainous character is Seth MacFarlane, you feel like you‰Ûªre a family-reunion crasher who stuck around long enough to get promoted to second cousin.

Jimmy Logan (Channing Tatum), who plays the song for his young daughter, Sadie (Farrah Mackenzie), while they work on his pickup truck, knows that its authenticity is questionable. Two of the credited writers, he says, had probably never even been to West Virginia when they hymned the beauty of its valleys and rivers. (‰ÛÏLogan Lucky,‰Ûù it should probably be pointed out, was shot mostly in Georgia.) But Jimmy also knows that even pop-culture artifice can carry a spore of genuine sentiment, and Mr. Soderbergh shows a similar faith in the impure products of America. A student of movie traditions high and low, he draws his inspiration here less from the gritty, downbeat realism of ‰Ûª70s New Hollywood than from that decade‰Ûªs good-time populist genre hybrids. If the ‰ÛÏOceans‰Ûù series represented his updating of Kennedy-era Rat Pack swagger, ‰ÛÏLogan Lucky‰Ûù revives the irreverent, hell-raising outlaw vibe of ‰ÛÏSmokey and the Bandit.‰Ûù

In American movies ‰ÛÓ and maybe not only there ‰ÛÓ the idea of luck often functions as a euphemism for, and an antidote to, the effects of class. In a land of winners and losers, where life is acknowledged to be unfair and positive thinking is all-powerful, we often find fault (or solace) not in our social structures but in our stars.

Not that this movie feels in any way like a throwback. Mr. Tatum is about 10 times sexier than Burt Reynolds ever was, and about one-tenth as vain. Since his early screen appearances (in ‰ÛÏStep Up‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏA Guide to Recognizing Your Saints‰Ûù), it‰Ûªs been evident that he is a singularly charismatic performer, but by now it should be clear that he‰Ûªs also a great actor. I think his appeal has less to do with any supposed Everyman quality (though every man can dream, of course) than with an uncanny ability to convey irony and sincerity in the same gesture, to balance his effortless magnetism with unforced modesty.

‰ÛÏLogan Lucky,‰Ûù Steven Soderbergh‰Ûªs gravity-defying, ridiculously entertaining new film ‰ÛÓ one that ends a blessedly brief retirement from big-screen directing ‰ÛÓ concerns itself with a desperate attempt to even the odds. It‰Ûªs a caper movie, a modern-day Robin Hood tale organized around an elaborate, improbable but curiously plausible heist. A gang that includes a wounded veteran, an unemployed former coal miner, a hairdresser and other motley members of the noncoastal nonelite conspires to knock over a Nascar race sponsored by Coca-Cola. The event sucks a lot of cash from people like them, and the thieves quite literally set out to suck it right back up.

That description might make the movie sound more pointed than it is. But Mr. Soderbergh‰Ûªs class consciousness ‰ÛÓ something that has popped up often in his career, in ‰ÛÏErin Brockovich‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Girlfriend Experience,‰Ûù in ‰ÛÏBubble‰Ûù and, of course, in ‰ÛÏMagic Mike‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is atmospheric rather than programmatic. Nobody in ‰ÛÏLogan Lucky‰Ûù utters a political word, but the setting carries a heavy, obvious charge of political significance all the same. The Logans in question are proud, hard-pressed residents of West Virginia, a state that, in the real world, punches far above its demographic weight in partisan and symbolic importance. Their land is beautiful and their water is contaminated. The film‰Ûªs anthem is John Denver‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏTake Me Home, Country Roads,‰Ûù a hillbilly elegy if ever there was one.

For that reason, a good heist movie can settle into a sweet spot where reality and fantasy converge. This one‰Ûªs narrative engine hums along nicely, occasionally accelerating into farce, usually when Mr. Craig shows up, sporting neck tattoos, spiky bleached hair and an accent that sounds like the cause or the result of a badly sprained tongue. (The dialects are all over the map, but let‰Ûªs not get too hung up on authenticity.)

Jimmy, once a high school football star, has not quite resigned himself to life on the short end of the stick. Laid off from a construction job in North Carolina, he returns home to discover that his ex-wife (Katie Holmes) and her car-dealer husband (David Denman) are planning to move out of West Virginia with Sadie. Jimmy‰Ûªs brother, Clyde (Adam Driver), a bartender who lost a hand in Iraq, thinks the family is cursed. Jimmy doesn‰Ûªt share this superstition, and in any case he has a plan, or at least a how-to list for bank robbers that he decides to adapt for new circumstances.

Like George Clooney‰Ûªs Danny Ocean, he needs, first of all, to put together a crew. Starting with Clyde and their sister, Mellie (Riley Keough), Jimmy taps into another kinship network, recruiting an explosives expert named Joe Bang (Daniel Craig) and his two brothers (Jack Quaid and Brian Gleeson). That‰Ûªs not quite everyone, but there are some dandy little surprises in store that I‰Ûªm not inclined to spoil.

Michael, however, does object to Darius‰Ûªs reliance on a certain 12-letter expletive. ‰ÛÏYou ruined it,‰Ûù he whines, supplying this otherwise blunt, none-too-clever movie with a morsel of meta-humor. Every movie fan knows that Mr. Jackson didn‰Ûªt exactly invent that multifaceted word, but in its modern phraseology, he is nonetheless something of a mythic figure.

Darius, despite a rÌ©sumÌ© piled high with dead and maimed bodies, is more righteous avenger than sociopath. This, too, is no surprise. A least since ‰ÛÏPulp Fiction,‰Ûù Mr. Jackson has made a specialty of playing murderers touched by a curious sense of moral grace. Mr. Reynolds, for his part, is comfortable and credible as a smart, suave young punk in need of a bit of schooling. Mr. Jackson lays claim to most of the good lines and the big scenes, but no one can complain about that.

These range from tedious to wildly overblown to kind of fun. A hot pursuit in and along the canals of Amsterdam ‰ÛÓ with Mr. Jackson in a speedboat, Mr. Reynolds on a motorbike and the bad guys in black cars ‰ÛÓ brings a few jolts and gasps, even if the digital seams in the sequence peek out intermittently. A bout of tool-assisted hand-to-hand combat in a hardware store makes up in efficiency for what it lacks in originality. The final blowup and showdown destroy whatever sense of proportion the movie might have had, along with a lot of Dutch infrastructure.

Samuel L. Jackson is the hit man. Ryan Reynolds is the bodyguard. What more do you want me to say? These two sometime residents of different branches of the greater Marvel cosmos ‰ÛÓ Nick Fury and Deadpool, if you need reminding ‰ÛÓ join up, with ostentatious reluctance, on a European jaunt, leaving a trail of dead minions and flummoxed law enforcement officers from Manchester to The Hague. Their common nemesis is an Eastern European despot, a genocidal maniac with a scholarly mien and personal touch played, it seems almost redundant to point out, by Gary Oldman.

Mr. Jackson plays Darius Kincaid, a fearsome contract killer cooperating with the authorities to free his wife (Ms. Hayek) from prison. Mr. Reynolds is Michael Bryce, a formerly ‰ÛÏtriple-A‰Ûù-rated security specialist whose career and relationship (with Ms. Yung‰Ûªs Interpol agent) went south after he lost a client. One of these fellows is an uptight, cautious, detail-oriented professional, while the other has a looser, more improvisational style. No points for guessing which is which, or for predicting who learns what from whom.

‰ÛÏThe Hitman‰Ûªs Bodyguard,‰Ûù directed by Patrick Hughes (‰ÛÏThe Expendables 3‰Ûù) and written by Tom O‰ÛªConnor, is not a good movie, but, in fairness, it doesn‰Ûªt try to be. It occupies its genre niche ‰ÛÓ the exuberantly violent Euro-action movie-star-paycheck action comedy ‰ÛÓ without excessive cynicism or annoying pretension. The stars banter and bicker and wax sentimental about the badass women in their lives (Salma Hayek and Ìälodie Yung) until the time arrives for the next shootout or car chase or suite of explosions.

PenÌ©lope Cruz, who also starred in ‰ÛÏThe Girl of Your Dreams,‰Ûù is back as Macarena Granada, now a Hollywood superstar who, having acquired American citizenship, returns to her native Spain for a lavish American-Spanish coproduction about Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand. Blas Fontiveros (Antonio Resines), a former director exiled in France (and an ex-paramour of Macarena‰Ûªs), has sneaked back into the Spanish industry, working second-unit. After he is discovered by the authorities, Blas is banished to a labor camp, and a group that includes Macarena, her assistant (Loles LÌ©on), married crew hands (Santiago Segura and Neus Asensi) and a bumbling actor (Jorge Sanz) must smuggle him back to France.

Mr. Trueba skillfully blends genuine and mock period footage to conjure the era, while Mandy Patinkin, as a blacklisted screenwriter; Cary Elwes, as a loutish American leading man; and Clive Revill, sending up John Ford, ably help represent the Hollywood contingent. As for Ms. Cruz, she luminously revisits the role of a screen diva who, when the country‰Ûªs dictator visits the set, is not above telling him off in the most delightfully coarse of terms.

‰ÛÏThe Queen of Spain,‰Ûù a light ensemble romp from the veteran director Fernando Trueba, has fun with movie lore even as it pillories Hollywood‰Ûªs deal-making with the Francisco Franco regime in the 1950s. (The film is a sequel to Mr. Trueba‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Girl of Your Dreams,‰Ûù from 1998, about a Third Reich engagement with Spanish showbiz.) In ‰ÛÏQueen,‰Ûù an opening montage evoking newsreels describes Franco‰Ûªs invitation to American studios to shoot in Spain.

With a barrage of title-card identifications, ‰ÛÏ6 Days‰Ûù can feel closer to a re-enactment than a thriller. To the extent that the movie has a political angle, it‰Ûªs perhaps gratuitously jingoistic. A closing note that the captors ‰ÛÏlie in unmarked graves in East London‰Ûù seems out of step with what precedes it.

‰ÛÏ6 Days‰Ûù is drawn from a real event in 1980 when gunmen who identified themselves as members of Iran‰Ûªs Arabic-speaking minority took 26 hostages at the Iranian Embassy in London. (The unrelated Iran hostage crisis was unfolding in Tehran at the time.)

From a structural standpoint, what is interesting about this dramatization of events is that it only occasionally strays from the vantage points of those on the outside. That puts the viewer in the shoes of the government officials and other onlookers as they weigh various options ‰ÛÓ loading the hostage-takers onto a bus to Heathrow Airport and raiding the bus, entering the embassy through a skylight ‰ÛÓ for ending the situation.

The factions are accorded one major actor apiece: Mark Strong is an inspector with a police negotiations team, Abbie Cornish is a BBC News reporter, Jamie Bell is a member of Britain‰Ûªs Special Air Service and Tim Pigott-Smith (who died in April) is William Whitelaw, Britain‰Ûªs home secretary. Over the phone, Mr. Strong‰Ûªs character builds trust with the gunmen‰Ûªs leader (Ben Turner). The last thread most compels the director, Toa Fraser, to violate the strictures on perspective.

Sinking into a dedicated ‰ÛÓ and overwhelmingly male ‰ÛÓ subculture of enthusiasts, the director Doug Nichol unearths a trove of reasons for loving the clicketyclacking machine. The playwright and actor Sam Shepard (who died last month) confesses an addiction to the percussive sound of thoughts striking paper. Tom Hanks, an avid collector who owns around 250 machines and types almost daily, declares that he hates emailed thank-you notes and simply deletes them. Take note, sycophants and star-stalkers.

Overlong and poorly annotated (interviewees are not identified until the end, and even then without photographs), ‰ÛÏCalifornia Typewriter‰Ûù fields plenty of thinkers, but it‰Ûªs the fringe folks who entertain. Like the sculptor Jeremy Mayer, who ‰ÛÓ inspired by multiple viewings of ‰ÛÏMetropolis‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ transforms irreparable machines into fantastic beasts and life-size figures. Or the self-described typewriter poet, Silvi Alcivar, who composes impromptu stanzas for any occasion and for people who just need cheering up.
As an alternative, those clients could slip into a performance by the delightful members of the Boston Typewriter Orchestra. They‰Ûªre currently working on a cover of Slayer‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRaining Blood.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏCalifornia Typewriter‰Ûù might center on a small, beleaguered typewriter repair shop in Berkeley, Calif., but this quirky, obsessive documentary is about so much more than broken keys and busted type wheels. It‰Ûªs really about how we create art.

More substantively, the musician John Mayer and the historian David McCullough speak eloquently of the need for tangible proof of creation versus the ephemeral nature of digital data. Denied diaries, letters or first drafts ‰ÛÓ whether of songs or presidential speeches ‰ÛÓ future historians will find it much harder to plumb the minds of the famous.

On the day of the murder, as Colin and CK (Nnamdi Asomugha) go about their routines, ‰ÛÏCrown Heights‰Ûù quietly registers the texture of New York life in 1980. The crime and violence that were much more prevalent then than now, but also the daily rituals of love, family and work that never really change. Colin steals a car (for the chop shop where he works), flirts with a neighbor, Antoinette (Natalie Paul), and runs an errand for his grandmother. Then all of a sudden he‰Ûªs in custody, and ensnared in a bureaucratic and penal nightmare. Months stretch into years, and while CK raises money, hires lawyers and pursues appeals, Colin, incarcerated at the New York state penitentiary in Dannemora, fights to stay sane, safe and hopeful.

This story inspired a gripping, enraging episode of ‰ÛÏThis American Life,‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏCrown Heights,‰Ûù written and directed by Matt Ruskin, tries to adhere both to the factual record and a careful, detail-focused documentary ethos. Like its protagonist, sensitively and shrewdly played by Lakeith Stanfield, the film is soft-spoken and thoughtful, with sweet, lyrical touches that alleviate some of the grimness without blunting the cruelty and injustice of what happened.

‰ÛÏCrown Heights‰Ûù begins with, and periodically circles back to, a real-life shooting that took place on a Brooklyn street in the spring of 1980. A jury convicted two young men of the murder, one of whom, Colin Warner, had nothing to do with it. Nonetheless, Mr. Warner spent more than 20 years in prison until, thanks in large part to the tireless efforts of his friend Carl King (known as CK), his conviction was overturned and he was released.

Like countless other black men, he is ensnared in a system that seems rigged against him in every way. The police, the prosecutors, the prison guards and some of his own lawyers cut corners, rush to judgment and ignore the clear evidence of his innocence. You get the sense that they are part of a vast, shadowy, brutal machine, the illumination of which feels urgently necessary even as it lies outside the film‰Ûªs scope.

But ‰ÛÏCrown Heights‰Ûù nonetheless makes a powerful argument that Colin‰Ûªs imprisonment was hardly an anomaly. Mr. Ruskin cuts in news clips of several generations of politicians from both parties ‰ÛÓ including Presidents Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton and former New York Gov. George E. Pataki ‰ÛÓ making tough-on-crime speeches promising longer sentences, more executions and less parole. In the meantime, the kinds of policies they promote take their toll on Colin.

But the choice to focus on Colin rather than on his persecutors is an honorable and ethical one, and ‰ÛÏCrown Heights‰Ûù is a moving tribute to his resilience and the steadfastness of the people who love him.

Our attention shifts back and forth between the two men, which provides narrative momentum at the cost of dramatic and psychological depth. CK‰Ûªs devotion to the cause of his friend‰Ûªs exoneration strains his marriage, and the long sequence of stalls and setbacks in court and in parole hearings erodes Colin‰Ûªs morale. These developments are conveyed in scenes that feel a bit too pointed and familiar ‰ÛÓ effective in the moment but not quite as powerful as they might have been.

In his early interactions with Marjorie, Walter, a holographic-generated ‰ÛÏprime‰Ûù whose personality software is constructed both from what he left behind and from memories of the people close to him, is kind, solicitous and a little wide-eyed. Whenever Marjorie ‰ÛÏreminds‰Ûù him of a trait the actual Walter had, or a shared experience, his prime obediently says, ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªll remember that now.‰Ûù (The movie is set in an unspecified point in the future, though if you do the math around the video release of a movie that looms large in Walter and Marjorie‰Ûªs early story, it would seem to be around 2050.)

Most fictions about artificial intelligence are not, of course, about artificial intelligence. They use the topic as a metaphor, a scale on which to weigh and measure the assets and liabilities of humanity itself. ‰ÛÏMarjorie Prime,‰Ûù a new film written and directed by Michael Almereyda, adapted from Jordan Harrison‰Ûªs acclaimed play, is an alternately stately and brisk story in which the metaphor poses questions about mortality, loss and who our imagined ‰ÛÏbest selves‰Ûù might turn out to actually be once they‰Ûªre released from our own assessment.

Marjorie‰Ûªs daughter, Tess, has prickly feelings about having this Walter in the house, while her husband, Jon, is more optimistic about the digital ghost‰Ûªs potential for service. As you might infer from the title, household roles subsequently shift, and then shift some more. The characters‰Ûª quiet desperation to hold on to the ones they‰Ûªve loved becomes a sort of trap.

The movie has certain affinities with other recent critical favorites, but is less knotty than ‰ÛÏEx Machina‰Ûù (2014) and less sentiment driven than ‰ÛÏHer‰Ûù (2013). It is not particularly concerned with gender roles or even tender feelings as such. Tim Robbins and Geena Davis, as Jon and Tess, play their characters with close-to-the-vest discipline, and Ms. Smith tempers Marjorie‰Ûªs physical vulnerability with a wry skepticism.

The great Lois Smith reprises the role she played in both the 2014 Los Angeles and 2015 New York productions of the play, an old woman named Marjorie with an unspecified disease who has been given a new companion. ‰ÛÏHe‰Ûù is Walter, her dead husband, reincarnated in an in-his-prime version played by Jon Hamm.

Mr. Almereyda (whose 2015 film, ‰ÛÏExperimenter,‰Ûù was an underseen beauty) is a seasoned cinematic spellbinder. He doesn‰Ûªt do much to open up Mr. Harrison‰Ûªs theatrical work, confining it for the most part to an elegant, mysterious beach house, one that, paradoxically enough, contains no visible high-tech devices. When you try to break down how he achieves his seductive magic with respect to this narrative, it all looks, initially, like nothing more than good cinematic common sense. The key is what he does on the sly: the way his subtle shifts of focus within a shot don‰Ûªt just change the emphasis of the scene, but mirror quirks of consciousness. There‰Ûªs more going on in this movie‰Ûªs 90-plus minutes than in many summer blockbusters nearly twice its length.

At one point, a character points out that whenever humans revisit a memory, they are not recollecting the actual event: rather they are remembering what they remember. In that respect, the extent to which our memories make up our selves is changing without us even realizing. The ‰ÛÏprimes‰Ûù here don‰Ûªt work that way. Or do they? And what difference does that make to their interaction with humans, and vice versa?

Mr. Jasper at once finds a new variation on a central hip-hop theme and gives a hip-hop inflection to a durable show-business-movie convention. As long as there are underdogs and misunderstood kids fighting to be noticed (and paid), there will be stories like this one, walking the line between clichÌ© and classic with grit, conviction and just enough cynicism to keep things from getting too corny.

The older generation comes in for harsher treatment. Wayward parents are a staple of the genre, and Barb wouldn‰Ûªt place high in a mother-of-the-year contest, but Ms. Everett, a popular cabaret performer and a brilliant actress, endows her with dignity even at her worst. Patti‰Ûªs grandmother (Cathy Moriarty) gives her more support and earns more sympathy, and also serves as a kind of guarantor of her granddaughter‰Ûªs decency and ultimate safety. There will be tears, embarrassment and disappointment, but we‰Ûªre not here to be miserable.

Mother and daughter could easily have been figures of mockery. It‰Ûªs silly of Patti to imagine that she could be the next Nicki Minaj, and pathetic that Barb belts out old radio hits at karaoke. A lot of people in the movie make fun of the Dombrowski women, Patti in particular. Since middle school, she‰Ûªs been known as Dumbo, and when she enters into an impromptu rap battle with a guy who works at the local pizza place, his rhymes are full of fat-shaming and sexual humiliation. She gives back as good as she gets, and the film, rather than join in the ridicule, registers its cruelty.

But we‰Ûªre not invited to feel sorry for her either. In structure and attitude, ‰ÛÏPatti Cake$‰Ûù adheres to a template familiar to readers of young adult fiction, blending realism with gentle but unmistakable messages of encouragement. It tells the story of a band of young misfits asserting themselves in a world that refuses to see their value. Jheri and Patti find a beat wizard (and Patti finds a romantic interest) in the person of a taciturn African-American punk rocker (Mamoudou Athie) who lives in a shack near the cemetery and goes by the name of Basterd. The three of them, now called PBNJ, start cutting tracks and planning their assault on the big time. It‰Ûªs impossible not to root for them.

For Patricia Dombrowski, a young New Jersey woman whose many aliases include Killa P and White Trish (and who is played by Danielle Macdonald), hip-hop is not just a musical genre or a cultural style. It‰Ûªs a universal religion, bringing the promise of grace and salvation into an otherwise drab existence. With a head full of bling-spangled reveries and a notebook full of rhymes, Patti (to use her most common nickname) hones her skills and indulges her dreams with her friend Hareesh (Siddharth Dhananjay), a pharmacist whose nom de mike is Jheri.

‰ÛÏPatti Cake$,‰Ûù Geremy Jasper‰Ûªs big-hearted and astute debut film ‰ÛÓ he wrote, directed and composed the songs that make Patti and Jheri‰Ûªs aspirations plausible ‰ÛÓ could have gone wrong in a dozen different ways. The story of a white suburban redhead chasing hip-hop glory may set off alarms about cultural appropriation, but the film mostly disarms them, or mixes them into the soundtrack. ‰ÛÏWhy don‰Ûªt you act your age?‰Ûù Patti asks her mother, Barb (Bridget Everett), an almost-was wannabe stuck in her own rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll fantasies. ‰ÛÏWhy don‰Ûªt you act your race?‰Ûù is Barb‰Ûªs barbed retort.

And Ms. Macdonald is quite simply a revelation, capturing the reflexive self-confidence and defensive diffidence of the millennial generation with sneaky sincerity and offhand wit. Though it is expressively shot and crisply edited, the credibility of ‰ÛÏPatti Cake$‰Ûù ultimately rests on her shoulders. We have to believe that Patti is talented, and also that the odds are not in her favor. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs a cold world out there,‰Ûù she‰Ûªs told by her favorite D.J. (played by MC Lyte), and for us to savor the sweetness of Patti‰Ûªs creativity we need to feel that chill.

Before incarceration, Jacob Harlon (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau, from ‰ÛÏGame of Thrones‰Ûù) is a stockbroker from Pasadena. When he‰Ûªs arrested after a fatal drunken-driving accident, concomitant charges and sentencing guidelines leave him in a bind that sends him to prison for far longer than he and his wife (Lake Bell) anticipated. Once there, he falls under the protection of a white-power gang; proves his cred by murdering a snitch; and meets the Beast (Holt McCallany), a prison leader who spouts aphorisms (‰ÛÏa warrior‰Ûªs deadliest weapon is his mind‰Ûù) and who supposedly runs California from his open-air cage.

To prove that thesis, ‰ÛÏShot Caller‰Ûù stretches ‰ÛÏanything‰Ûù well beyond credulity. Involving yet trivializing, the movie unfolds as a would-be ‰ÛÏBreaking Bad‰Ûù of the prison genre, following an inadvertent criminal who is hardened by a gangland behind bars and eventually becomes one of its cleverest members.

‰ÛÏShot Caller‰Ûù interweaves before-and-after timelines, toggling between Jacob‰Ûªs initiation and his life after release, a decade later, as a tattooed, muscular ex-con plotting an arms deal. Both the prison and the gangs have rules, Jacob says, but the gangs‰Ûª rules matter. ‰ÛÏShot Caller‰Ûù effectively conveys the vise grip of Jacob‰Ûªs options, but that doesn‰Ûªt make it less ludicrous from scene to scene.

‰ÛÏShot Caller‰Ûù is the third feature from Ric Roman Waugh (‰ÛÏSnitch,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏFelon‰Ûù) to illustrate the notion that prisons make criminals instead of reforming them. Once a man is institutionalized, a character in ‰ÛÏShot Caller‰Ûù says, ‰ÛÏanything is possible.‰Ûù

Their stories are inseparable from that of the blues itself, which the filmmakers illustrate with a wealth of clips and concert footage reaching back more than half a century. The kids who thrilled to the Rolling Stones performing ‰ÛÏLittle Red Rooster‰Ûù (the first blues song to reach No. 1 on the British charts), or watched Jimi Hendrix kill ‰ÛÏKilling Floor,‰Ûù probably knew nothing of Wolf and Waters. They just knew what they liked.

All rock ‰Ûªn‰Ûª roll roads lead back to the blues. And if ‰ÛÏSidemen: Long Road to Glory‰Ûù is to be believed, most of those highways converge on three bluesmen in particular: the drummer Willie Smith, the guitarist Hubert Sumlin and the pianist Joe Willie Perkins, known as Pinetop.

But ‰ÛÏSidemen‰Ûù is about more than just legacy. Blessed with extensive interviews with their buoyant subjects (all three of whom died in 2011 within months of one another), Mr. Rosenbaum and his producer Jasin Cadic shape a narrative of professional insecurity and personal resilience. From playing brothels and juke joints in the Jim Crow South to decades-long collaborations with the Chicago blues pioneers Muddy Waters and Howlin‰Ûª Wolf, the three weathered careers of astonishing flux.

Germinating and shape-shifting for almost a decade, Scott Rosenbaum‰Ûªs loving tribute (originally conceived in 2008 as a ‰ÛÏLast Waltz‰Ûù-style concert film) pulls back the big-name curtain to celebrate these often overlooked backing musicians whose riffs and runs are revered to this day. As proof, a slew of sunken-eyed rock legends ‰ÛÓ including Johnny Winter, Gregg Allman, Keith Richards and Joe Perry ‰ÛÓ is on hand to share memories of the men and attest to their lasting influence.

Cooling to the mind and soothing to the spirit, the documentary ‰ÛÏWalk With Me‰Ûù offers a tiny oasis of relief to anyone overheated by current events. When you feel like freaking out, the movie‰Ûªs commitment to slowing down and drawing inward doesn‰Ûªt seem like such a bad idea.

Sometimes dreamy but mostly dissatisfying, ‰ÛÏWalk With Me‰Ûù offers no clarity for the curious. We can enjoy the meditative mood, but understanding its underpinnings would require more than this idyll of silence and stillness provides.

Maintaining a respectful, purely observational approach, the directors Max Pugh and Marc J. Francis introduce us to Plum Village, a community of Zen Buddhists in rural France. Here, life moves at a snail‰Ûªs pace: Walking or eating, cooking or contemplating the words of their Vietnamese teacher, Thich Nhat Hanh ‰ÛÓ many of which are supplied in voice-over by the seductive, milk-and-honey baritone of Benedict Cumberbatch ‰ÛÓ the nuns and monks dawdle contentedly. A fleeting admission of boredom is met with beatific smiles, and the most lively debate occurs over which stick might best be used to beat a drum.

Forced into exile in 1966 over his opposition to the Vietnam War, Thich Nhat Hanh, now 90, is credited with introducing the practice of mindfulness to welcoming Westerners. Yet the film supplies little in the way of background or history, either of the serene, anonymous faces that float across the frame or of the achievements of their celebrated Zen master. Instead, we‰Ûªre dipped in and out of random rituals and events (including a 2011 teaching tour) without benefit of dates, locations or explanations.

For better or worse, Mr. Broomfield‰Ûªs sleazy style gives his documentaries personality. Thus, viewers of his conspiracy-minded films about the deaths of other stars (‰ÛÏKurt and Courtney,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏBiggie and Tupac‰Ûù) may feel duped by ‰ÛÏWhitney: Can I Be Me,‰Ûù a surprisingly conventional, dutifully respectful behind-the-scenes portrait of Whitney Houston‰Ûªs rise and struggles with fame and drugs before her death at 48. (A competing Houston documentary has been announced.)

Skillful editing of old interviews makes it difficult to keep track of who agreed to participate (and some songs, such as ‰ÛÏI Wanna Dance With Somebody (Who Loves Me),‰Ûù are noticeable by their absence). The most charged assertions come from Ms. Houston‰Ûªs former bodyguard David Roberts, who says his warnings about the singer‰Ûªs need for help went unheeded. In music documentaries, sadly, that sentiment is hardly unique.

As the movie intercuts testimonials from Ms. Houston‰Ûªs friends, family and collaborators with footage from her 1999 tour ‰ÛÓ shot by Rudi Dolezal, who shares directing credit ‰ÛÓ Mr. Broomfield is heard only occasionally and never shown. We learn about the forces that weighed on the superstar singer, including the criticism she faced for embracing pop instead of rhythm and blues; speculation about her sexuality; and, in the movie‰Ûªs telling, the feud between her husband, Bobby Brown, and Robyn Crawford, her friend and possible lover.

The British investigative documentarian Nick Broomfield is a natural sensationalist, drawn to bit players in tabloid dramas. His prying questions and incessant voice-overs suggest a cross between a Fleet Street reporter and the Energizer Bunny.

The truck fills up with detainees of all ages, mostly men. Some side with the Muslim Brotherhood, others support the military that deposed Mr. Morsi. They all seem to hate the journalist. ‰ÛÏAn activist should die for a cause, not a photo,‰Ûù one man sneers at Adam.

There isn‰Ûªt much time for such ‰ÛÏ12 Angry Men‰Ûù style exchanges as the movie goes on, though. The 20 or so occupants attempt to ‰ÛÏstrategize‰Ûù; members of the Muslim Brotherhood try to segregate themselves from the others. One man suffers a head wound. A young woman tries to help him, only to be told that he can‰Ûªt be touched by a woman. When the truck stops, a column of soldiers stands in front of the back door. Every time a detainee needs to relieve him or herself, an argument breaks out.

Sitting through ‰ÛÏClash‰Ûù is largely a miserable experience, and that‰Ûªs deliberate. The movie is set in the aftermath of the 2013 overthrow of Egypt‰Ûªs first democratically elected president, Mohamed Morsi, of the Muslim Brotherhood movement. Directed by Mohamed Diab from a script he wrote with his brother Khaled Diab, ‰ÛÏClash‰Ûù begins in the back of an empty police truck. Soon a couple of men are put inside, and they try to reach the outside world via an Apple watch. The watch belongs to Adam (Hany Adel), an Egyptian-born journalist who lives in America and is back in the country covering the unrest.

Whatever affinities these characters have, they are practically obliterated as soon as they are established. Devotion to dogma and sheer perversity erodes their fellowship as day turns into night ‰ÛÓ after which ‰ÛÏClash‰Ûù turns into a full-fledged horror movie, albeit one without the fake comfort of a supernatural or science-fiction pretext. It‰Ûªs just man‰Ûªs inhumanity to man, in full sway.
He responds, ‰ÛÏA photo can be a cause.‰Ûù

One of the most affecting songs in the musical ‰ÛÏA Chorus Line‰Ûù observes, ‰ÛÏeverything was beautiful at the ballet.‰Ûù The amount of sweat, strain and pain that goes into creating that beauty has had its cinematic moments. In the 1948 classic ‰ÛÏThe Red Shoes‰Ûù even the most unpretty parts of the process were made beautiful. In ‰ÛÏBlack Swan‰Ûù (2010) they were made ‰ÛÓ perhaps more accurately ‰ÛÓ mind-bendingly horrific.

Enduring bruises, torn toenails and hard falls is only one part of a dancer‰Ûªs day-to-day life. If this film‰Ûªs directors, ValÌ©rie MÌ_ller and the French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj, don‰Ûªt offer much overt material on Polina‰Ûªs inner life, it‰Ûªs because they don‰Ûªt have to: the point of Polina, and this movie, is that her dancing is her being.

Adapted from Bastien VivÌ¬s‰Ûªs graphic novel, ‰ÛÏPolina‰Ûù takes a largely straightforward and sometimes documentary-style approach in its depiction of a dancer‰Ûªs life. The title character is first seen as a young girl in a Russian ballet school, dancing to her own beat on the way home from class. The teenage Polina, played in a confident, winning, lived-in performance by Anastasia Shevtsova (a real-life ballerina who trained with the Mariinsky Ballet), gets a shot at the Bolshoi, but breaks away from that to follow her artistic instincts. After leaving Russia for France, however, she fails to find her groove while working with a romantic partner under the guidance of a compassionate but stern contemporary dance choreographer (Juliette Binoche). Unmoored in Europe, she later regains some exuberance in Belgium with an improvisational troupe that takes inspiration from street life and electronic dance music.

Beginning at a French orphanage sometime around the 1880s, this good-natured tale finds 11-year-old FÌ©licie (voiced by Elle Fanning) and her friend Victor (Nat Wolff) ready to run away to Paris, where she hopes to become a ballerina and he an inventor. After this generic pair is chased by the orphanage overseer (Mel Brooks, criminally underused) they arrive in the big city.

Those messages are delivered often, and emphasized, to inspire young viewers. Fair enough. Less justifiable is the hit-or-miss humor and a well-worn plotline. Panoramic images of Paris, dance sequences and montages of FÌ©licie in training add some energy.

Nit-picking will get you nowhere with the target audience of ‰ÛÏLeap!,‰Ûù an animated movie for tweens ‰ÛÓ they‰Ûªre unlikely to care about critical quibbles. As for the adults who‰Ûªll get dragged to the theater: You‰Ûªve seen it all before, though it‰Ûªs pleasant enough to watch again.

FÌ©licie is the focus here, and soon she‰Ûªs befriending Odette (Carly Rae Jepsen), a former dancer turned cleaning woman, and trying out for a prestigious ballet school as various villains conspire to quash her hopes. Along the way she is told to follow her dreams, to never give up and to take big risks.

Directed by Ìäric Summer and Ìäric Warin (and first released in Europe as ‰ÛÏBallerina,‰Ûù sans that wanton exclamation point), ‰ÛÏLeap!‰Ûù remains peppy as it sets its bar at a low-to-medium height then cheerfully clears it. Sure, the movie could have heeded its own advice and taken a few risks. But the filmmakers know just what their younger audience wants ‰ÛÓ a sunny story and plenty of dancing ‰ÛÓ and they‰Ûªre not taking any chances.

Reviewing ‰ÛÏLemon‰Ûù feels like taking a sucker‰Ûªs bet, treating the film with a reverence it never even asks for. Janicza Bravo‰Ûªs feature debut, written with her husband and its star, Brett Gelman, traffics in the same anti-humor as Rick Alverson‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Comedy‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏEntertainment,‰Ûù knowingly titled movies that offer nothing of the sort. Give ‰ÛÏLemon‰Ûù credit, then: It‰Ûªs a case of truth in advertising.

Isaac is also in a floundering relationship with a blind woman (Judy Greer), who respects him almost as little as he does her. In a centerpiece of sorts, Isaac attends a Passover Seder at which his brother (Martin Starr) questions the Jewishness of their sister (Shiri Appleby) and her black son (Blake Anthony Crawford). You could cry anti-Semitism, but you‰Ûªd be taking the bait; the movie calculates its ethnic stereotypes to offend and dares you not to be in on the gag.

The movie opens with a woman on television recounting horrors in Africa, it seems, only to pivot to the viewer on the couch, something of a tragic case himself. Isaac (Mr. Gelman) is a failure in every respect: career, grooming and ‰ÛÓ we eventually discover ‰ÛÓ pet-sitting and bathroom hygiene. He appears in embarrassing ads. While working as an acting teacher, he pits two students (Gillian Jacobs and Michael Cera, sporting what looks like a rodent-chewed Art Garfunkel hairdo) against each other, perhaps for his amusement. Though he‰Ûªs not laughing. After Mr. Cera‰Ûªs character finds success, Isaac tags his car with a slur.

The protagonist eventually tiptoes toward functionality while wooing a woman (Nia Long) who, like Ms. Bravo, is black. At this point ‰ÛÏLemon‰Ûù apparently becomes an inside joke about the filmmakers. (Mr. Gelman is Jewish.) The rampant self-loathing was just a ruse for narcissism.

‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt really know what I like,‰Ûù Frankie (Harris Dickinson) says to a man he meets on a gay hookup site in ‰ÛÏBeach Rats.‰Ûù He repeats variations on that phrase throughout the film, and part of what‰Ûªs refreshing about Eliza Hittman‰Ûªs sophomore feature is that the character‰Ûªs confusion isn‰Ûªt limited to coming out.

Frankie‰Ûªs drug intake, his ailing father, his relationships with his mother (Kate Hodge) and younger sister (Nicole Flyus) and perhaps even his reluctance to leave familiar surroundings all contribute to a powerful sense of limbo. The back-and-forths of the character‰Ûªs decisions feel real, and Mr. Dickinson‰Ûªs laconic blankness (you would never guess the actor was British) helps to give Frankie‰Ûªs existential crisis a charge. Ms. Hittman is also assured enough to know it can‰Ûªt be easily resolved.

When not cruising the web with a cap on and shadows hiding his face, Frankie hangs out with macho, aimless potheads in and around the Coney Island boardwalk. (Like Ms. Hittman‰Ûªs first feature, ‰ÛÏIt Felt Like Love,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏBeach Rats‰Ûù doubles as a portrait of Brooklyn‰Ûªs southern-shore neighborhoods, lyrically photographed by HÌ©lÌ¬ne Louvart.)

During a fireworks show, Frankie effortlessly ‰ÛÓ in the sense of exerting no effort ‰ÛÓ catches the eye of Simone (Madeline Weinstein), who flirts with him oblivious to his uncertain sexuality. After initially taking her home only to rebuff her, he spends much of the movie waffling on the relationship, trying to make it work and even defensively confessing to a man he accompanies to a motel for sex that he has a girlfriend.

The filmmakers feign boldness in tackling national politics, but revert to coyness and caricature when it comes to local matters, gesturing toward a multiculturalism that isn‰Ûªt even skin deep and sweeping gentrification under the rug. The civil war ‰ÛÏBushwick‰Ûù imagines is mostly about white people, which kind of makes the movie a piece of historical revisionism about something that hasn‰Ûªt even happened yet.

Fleeing black-uniformed snipers and storm troopers, as well as opportunistic street criminals, Lucy teams up with a burly janitor named Stupe (Dave Bautista), and they zigzag through the neighborhood that gives the movie its title. The name once signified a working-class black and Latino part of New York, but lately it has become synonymous with the artisanal, post-collegiate culture of 21st-century Brooklyn.

‰ÛÏBushwick‰Ûù opens with a beautiful aerial shot of New York ‰ÛÓ moving north over Brooklyn from Coney Island ‰ÛÓ that turns out to be the view from a helicopter gunship. The city is under attack, invaded not by a foreign or extraterrestrial army but by forces of secession from the southern United States. A young woman named Lucy (Brittany Snow), on her way to visit her grandmother, finds herself caught up in a new civil war.

This is not a bad premise. The idea that regional and ideological divisions might erupt into violent conflict doesn‰Ûªt seem entirely far-fetched these days, and low-budget genre movies can often generate more political insight than their prestige-minded Hollywood cousins. But while ‰ÛÏBushwick,‰Ûù directed by Cary Murnion and Jonathan Milott from a script by Nick Damici and Graham Reznick, offers reasonable technical competence ‰ÛÓ following shots that are as fluid and kinetic as expert video-game play ‰ÛÓ its storytelling is dimwitted and amateurish.

When one artist adapts the work of another, fans of the original stand ready to pounce on any and all infidelities. So tackling ‰ÛÏDeath Note,‰Ûù the sprawling, gobsmackingly detailed Japanese manga series by Tsugumi Ohba and Takeshi Obata, is a ballsy move ‰ÛÓ even if you‰Ûªre backed by Netflix. And for the director Adam Wingard, who needs a win after last year‰Ûªs disappointing ‰ÛÏBlair Witch‰Ûù sequel, the prospect of riling those fans must have been especially daunting.

Devotees of Mr. Wingard, on the other hand, will immediately recognize a sensibility ‰ÛÓ rare among horror-movie directors ‰ÛÓ that prioritizes mood over mayhem. From the dreamy opening to the flashback-heavy finale, the movie has a tone and temperament that are consistently his own. The sharply executed violence, jabs of humor and, in particular, a fascination with the seductiveness of evil (most pronounced in his 2014 feature, ‰ÛÏThe Guest‰Ûù) are all here, albeit in a compressed package.

Lurking in Light‰Ûªs bedroom, however, is the actual killer: A mischievous Japanese death spirit named Ryuk (voiced with cackling relish by Willem Dafoe), who resembles a rotting tree trunk and behaves like an annoying goad. Yet this malevolent house pest is far less worrisome than L, a ninja-styled Ì_ber-detective who is obsessively investigating the murders. As played by a mesmerizing Lakeith Stanfield, L is a twitchy oddity with an attentive handler (Paul Nakauchi) and a back story that deserves its own spinoff. Face half hidden beneath a black turtleneck, L crouches on chairs like an anime arachnid, sucking up candies and sniffing out clues.

By far the more entertaining of the two mythically entwined antagonists, L zeros in on Light with eccentric speed. And that‰Ûªs the problem: Perhaps stifled by the cultural and commercial clout of its source material (a multimedia juggernaut of books, movies, television shows and a stage musical), ‰ÛÏDeath Note‰Ûù feels rushed and constricted. As a result, what should have been Light‰Ûªs incremental surrender to godlike power becomes an instantaneous embrace, and what ought to have played out as an extended manhunt is resolved with embarrassing ease.

Set in Seattle (played by Vancouver, British Columbia), the story centers on Light (Nat Wolff), a smart, isolated high schooler whose world is upended when an ancient, leather-bound notebook drops from the heavens. Inside are instructions: Picture the face and write the name of whomever you would like to kill, and that soul‰Ûªs expiration is assured. A test run to eliminate a troublesome bully is spectacularly successful, and soon Light and his girlfriend, Mia (an underserved Margaret Qualley), are wiping out evildoers worldwide.

Cramming several tons of plot into a one-pound screenplay, the three writers (one of whom, Jeremy Slater, created Fox television‰Ûªs thoughtful adaptation of ‰ÛÏThe Exorcist‰Ûù) have little option but to condense. That said, Mr. Wingard‰Ûªs eye for a stylish image hasn‰Ûªt dimmed. Working with the cinematographer David Tattersall, he concocts sequences that tilt and drift, awash in neon and a soundtrack that evokes a woozy, winking romanticism. At certain moments, we can almost feel his desire to shrug off the straitjacket of fidelity and make this tale of false gods and flawed superheroes completely his own.

‰ÛÏHeaven knows I‰Ûªm miserable now,‰Ûù goes a 1984 ode to alienation by the British band the Smiths. The lyric could also serve as an alternate title for ‰ÛÏEngland Is Mine,‰Ûù Mark Gill‰Ûªs unauthorized and unrelentingly dour biopic of the early years of the group‰Ûªs frontman, Steven Patrick Morrissey.

Unfolding mainly in dingy rooms, whose cheap curtains barely obscure the miserable Manchester streets beyond, this doggedly unilluminating portrait opens in 1976 with the 17-year-old Morrissey (a game Jack Lowden) immersed in Oscar Wilde and the New York Dolls. Fulminating with contempt for England and disdain for the daily grind, he bangs out vitriolic screeds on an old typewriter, the confrontational prose at odds with his diffident manner. There is also a great deal of moping.

With its bleak, yearning tone and defiantly cloudy color palette, ‰ÛÏEngland Is Mine‰Ûù has a pleasingly granular feel for its era and location. But its imagining of Morrissey as a self-pitying narcissist, a curiously passive intellectual who can‰Ûªt get out of his own way, soaks the movie in a wearying inertia. While we‰Ûªre all waiting for greatness to find him, though, three hardy women are around to nudge things along: A punkish artist (Jessica Brown Findlay), a hectoring best mate (Katherine Pearce) and his empathetic Mum (Simone Kirby), whose support for her sulky son never wavers.

Skirting sexuality and absent Morrissey‰Ûªs music (the movie ends in 1982 as he and Johnny Marr are on the brink of forming the band), ‰ÛÏEngland Is Mine‰Ûù is a soggy schlep. But if you‰Ûªre among those who believe that great art rarely foments in the cheerfully well-adjusted, then this one‰Ûªs for you.

Shot in black and white, the movie centers on two Korean-American brothers, Eli (Mr. Chon) and Daniel (David So), who run their dead father‰Ûªs shoe store. Daniel dreams of becoming a rhythm-and-blues singer; Eli just wants to hold down the fort, although Daniel‰Ûªs habit of giving discounts isn‰Ûªt exactly helping them cover the rent. They spend the day goofing around with Kamilla (Simone Baker), an 11-year-old who, like them, has lost a parent.

The movie owes a sizable debt to ‰ÛÏDo the Right Thing,‰Ûù both in its portrait of a community on the verge of violence and its use of music as a motif. (The opening, which appears to be foreshadowing, shows Kamilla dancing before a burning building; a lighthearted sequence depicts Kamilla, Eli and Daniel dancing to ‰ÛÏManeater.‰Ûù)

Set on the first day of the 1992 Los Angeles riots, Justin Chon‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏGook‰Ûù takes place in Paramount, Calif., southeast of what was then called South Central Los Angeles. The rundown neighborhood is just far enough from the first sparks of the uprising that the characters can believe the flames and looting won‰Ûªt reach them. The verdict of the Rodney King trial is on everyone‰Ûªs minds, of course, but it exists, initially, in the background, on TV and radio broadcasts.
The film isn‰Ûªt perfect ‰ÛÓ Mr. Chon‰Ûªs wild camera motions seem more undisciplined than electric ‰ÛÓ but it does find an angle on the riots that hasn‰Ûªt been seen much onscreen.

Though the characters don‰Ûªt seem preoccupied with the day‰Ûªs news, ‰ÛÏGook‰Ûù captures the area‰Ûªs racial tensions. The liquor store across from the shoe shop has a South Korean immigrant owner (Sang Chon, the director‰Ûªs father) who makes a point of not speaking English, and fears that Kamilla will steal from him. Kamilla‰Ûªs brother (Curtiss Cook Jr.) doesn‰Ûªt trust Eli and Daniel.

As teenagers, Martina (Ximena Romo) and Lucio (SebastiÌÁn Aguirre) quickly went from friends to a passionate and experimental couple before they were torn apart by their scandalous expulsion from a Catholic school. When, after 25 years with no contact, Martina and Lucio (now played by Cecilia SuÌÁrez and Manuel GarcÌ_a-Rulfo) run into each other on the streets of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, they swap elaborate stories of made-up families to prove that they hadn‰Ûªt waited like fools to reconnect. Realizing they are both going to the same exhibition that night, each must find someone to pose as a spouse to pull off the ruse.

Though the film successfully evokes feelings of first love, ‰ÛÏTales of an Immoral Couple‰Ûù relies on a familiar formula: the story line of friends turning into lovers. Only, the movie isn‰Ûªt concerned with that awkward dance toward a relationship. Instead, it delightfully bounces between the young students falling in love ‰ÛÓ then from grace ‰ÛÓ and the reluctance of their adult counterparts to express their feelings.

Young love can be both fleeting and unforgettable. A reminder of puppy love can bring back wistful memories of a more innocent time before heartbreak. And that‰Ûªs the feeling Manolo Caro‰Ûªs latest movie, ‰ÛÏTales of an Immoral Couple,‰Ûù tries to summon in its audience.

Mr. Caro, who also wrote the script, favors the comedic potential of this couple‰Ûªs situation and plays up the good humor with visual jokes, frivolous misadventures and upbeat pop rock music. The result is a sweet and affecting story, one that forgoes the awkward moments of teenage romance and offers the possibility of reliving a bit of our youthful amor ‰ÛÓ if just for the film‰Ûªs 90-minute running time.

Such is the plight of Sook-hee (Kim Ok-bin), a trained assassin who is the focus of this convoluted thriller. After executing the movie‰Ûªs opening slaughter, she is caught by the police and recruited as a sleeper agent by an intelligence agency, which promises her freedom following 10 years of service. As ‰ÛÏThe Villainess‰Ûù jumps between Sook-hee‰Ûªs past and present, it becomes clear that she is trapped in a dizzying world of violence, where neither law nor outlaws can be trusted. Yet despite her despair, every action scene is as queasily pristine as the first, leaving ‰ÛÏThe Villainess‰Ûù caught in paradox. It‰Ûªs hard to enjoy the action when you witness its emotional cost, but once Sook-hee starts slashing goons from atop motorcycles, it‰Ûªs equally impossible to root for the violence to stop.

As directed by Jung Byung-gil, a former stuntman, the film mirrors the experience of playing a video game. The camera whips to each new target with the assurance of someone who knows all the combinations, and has instinctive, practiced access to every code and cheat. The only sign of conscious, unautomated humanity is the sound of the protagonist‰Ûªs ragged breathing ‰ÛÓ an acknowledgment of the exhaustion that comes when a human being is pushed to become an action avatar.

When the South Korean action drama ‰ÛÏThe Villainess‰Ûù begins, we are immediately enlisted as the perpetrators of a slaughter. With arms outstretched from the sides of the screen, and our eyes taking in the perspective of the killer, we shoot, hack and beat our way through a sea of assailants.

The movie‰Ûªs linchpin is a real-life battle between Lee (Philip Ng) and a Shaolin monk, Wong Jack Man (Yu Xia), which an opening title says was reputed to have been spurred by Wong‰Ûªs objection to Lee‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏkung fu for all‰Ûù ethos. In the movie‰Ûªs view, Lee‰Ûªs real problem is his bluff arrogance. Wong‰Ûªs approach is more spiritual, less egocentric. This attracts one of Lee‰Ûªs white students, the overly aggressive Steve (Billy Magnussen), who happens to be in love with a young Asian immigrant who‰Ûªs being groomed for a concubine‰Ûªs life by a female boss. Steve can‰Ûªt fight for her, but the boss is interested in staging an event that can generate some gambling profits. You see where this is going. For the sake of their pal, Wong and Lee agree to test each other in battle. It‰Ûªs clear that Wong is right about Lee‰Ûªs egotism being a limitation, but the question is whether Lee will get it.

The milieu from which Bruce Lee emerged to become the world‰Ûªs first martial-arts superstar ‰ÛÓ both as a film performer and a proponent-teacher ‰ÛÓ was probably as fascinating as the man himself. The screenwriters Stephen J. Rivele and Christopher Wilkinson and the director George Nolfi only intermittently manage to breathe credible cinematic life into that milieu in ‰ÛÏBirth of the Dragon,‰Ûù which is set in late ‰Ûª60s San Francisco, where, the movie tells us, Lee taught kung fu. (It was actually Oakland.)

The ‰ÛÏWest Side Story‰Ûù romance angle is the least interesting part of the movie, so it‰Ûªs frustrating that so much time is spent on it. ‰ÛÏBirth of the Dragon‰Ûù is ambitious: It wants to be a character study, an explication of martial arts philosophy and an action picture. (The battle scenes are presented in a mix of slow motion with super-clear fast-shutter shots and they‰Ûªre not always enhanced by this approach.) But the film never really gets fully juiced until the climax, when rivalries are put aside and the two very charismatic leads get on the same side to kick some righteous butt.

Like Mr. Hrebejk‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDivided We Fall‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a story of a sheepish Czech gentile who locates a vein of courage and generosity during the Nazi occupation ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏThe Teacher‰Ûù is polished, engaging and somewhat risk-averse. True, there‰Ûªs nothing lighthearted about the plot, which finds one student driven toward suicide and an astrophysicist father (Peter Bebjak), whose wife has left him, reduced to washing windows.

Set in Bratislava in 1983, when Czechoslovakia was under Communist rule, the movie centers on a new teacher, Maria Drazdechova (Zuzana Maurery), who, upon meeting her students, asks for their parents‰Ûª lines of work.

There are shades of ‰ÛÏ12 Angry Men‰Ûù in the scenes of the parents trying to convince one another to sign it. Contrary to the idea that strength comes in numbers, ‰ÛÏThe Teacher‰Ûù illustrates that some of the parents, while individually upset, are afraid to speak up as a group. They‰Ûªve already bought into a corrupt system, acceding to the teacher‰Ûªs demands, and signing the petition is tantamount to an admission of guilt.

While somewhat on the nose as allegory, the movie deftly illustrates that a culture of collaboration ‰ÛÓ whether in Bratislava in the 1980s or, indeed, any political or workplace context ‰ÛÓ requires active participation, even if subconscious. When Maria backs down on the cake-smuggling request, Marek (Csongor Kassai), the airport accountant, is so relieved that he offers to drive her to her country cottage, seemingly oblivious that he‰Ûªs being pressed into a different kind of service.

‰ÛÏThe Teacher‰Ûù is a foray into Slovak-language filmmaking by the industrious Czech director Jan Hrebejk, and for the occasion, he and his regular screenwriter, Petr Jarchovsky, have chosen a premise that sets up a dark satire about governance and human nature.

Using the children‰Ûªs grades as leverage, Maria plans to blackmail the parents into favors. These range from the menial (fixing her washing machine) to the potentially ruinous (smuggling a cake to Moscow by plane, which could cost a father who works at the airport his job). Ms. Maurery has great fun with the character, a tricky part because Maria nearly always maintains a kindhearted veneer, even at her most venal. It‰Ûªs clear she has no regard for her class‰Ûªs well-being or education.

Most of what we see of Maria comes in flashbacks during a parents‰Ûª conference the school‰Ûªs head teacher (Ina Gogalova) has convened, risking her own job because Maria is the chair of the Communist Party at the school. But if enough parents sign a formal complaint, they may be able to oust her.

But ‰ÛÏThe Teacher‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt dare take its premise to darker places by having Maria prod the parents too far beyond the bounds of their own moral compasses ‰ÛÓ a logical conclusion of this story. As the psychologist Stanley Milgram‰Ûªs experiments on obedience showed ‰ÛÓ and some governments have learned ‰ÛÓ a flock in thrall to an authority figure may follow that person anywhere.

You can judge Dolores Huerta by what others say about her. Just choose a side: Bobby Kennedy, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton have sung her praises, while Richard Nixon, Rush Limbaugh and Bill O‰ÛªReilly have disparaged her ideas. Better yet, judge her by her accomplishments, which are outlined in ‰ÛÏDolores,‰Ûù a documentary that extols her lifelong, and seemingly unlimited, fighting spirit in the service of workers‰Ûª rights.

Born in the United States and of Latin American heritage, Ms. Huerta took up community organizing at a young age before meeting Cesar Chavez and helping found what would become the United Farm Workers. For decades she led unionizing efforts, lobbied politicians and coordinated events (including a widespread grape boycott and workers strike in the 1960s). Throughout the film we see her campaigning for civil rights and protesting unsafe labor conditions, sometimes putting herself in harm‰Ûªs way.

Peter Bratt, the director, uses an immense amount of historical footage and interviews, arranged with clarity. Although his film is intended to applaud Ms. Huerta, he doesn‰Ûªt shy away from the toll her travels and choices took on her family. Several of her 11 children are interviewed, and they express pride in their mother, yet recall the deep unhappiness they felt when growing up, often without her around. The sexism that hindered her, too, isn‰Ûªt glossed over.
Ms. Huerta, now 87, continues her efforts. As a girl, she says, she had wanted to be a dancer. In some way you can see that in her work: She has made activism an art form.

God‰Ûªs grace seems cruelly missing in ‰ÛÏFree in Deed,‰Ûù a quiet, unsettling story of faith found and tragically lost. Set in present-day Memphis, it focuses on two people who are just barely clinging to the margins. Abe (David Harewood) works as a janitor, pushing brooms and cleaning up other people‰Ûªs waste; he spends much of the rest of his time in church. Melva (Edwina Findley Dickerson), a single mother, has a desk job but pours much of her energy into the care of her two children, particularly a son she can scarcely control and whose outbursts slip into frightening violence.

Mr. Mahaffy‰Ûªs oblique approach, which owes more to the classic art film than to the commercial mainstream, can be frustrating. At times, his visual style announces itself too overtly; and he tends to be too withholding, as if he were concerned about being obvious or falling into melodrama. He parses out information about his characters incrementally in scenes that come across less like moments from fully realized lives and more like flashcards: a man walking amid debris to imply alienation and abjection. The results occasionally feel coy, but each time the movie edges into mannerism Mr. Harewood and Ms. Dickerson pull you close enough to make it hurt.

The writer-director Jake Mahaffy‰Ûªs elliptical storytelling conveys meaning largely in visual and auditory bits, in shots of hands raised in prayer, in images of men and women isolated in the frame. The movie‰Ûªs realism owes much to the lived-in locations and its two excellent leads, who fill in the gaps with nuanced emotional texture; the script doesn‰Ûªt tell you much about who these people are, but the actors do. Such is the case with Mr. Harewood, whose rigorously restrained physical performance ‰ÛÓ a heavily bowed head, arms tightly crossed over his chest ‰ÛÓ conveys a desperate attempt at self-control and an unspoken burden that seems as if it should break a man.

Unlike Abe, Melva is still open to the world ‰ÛÓ her children, it‰Ûªs suggested, are one reason ‰ÛÓ which makes her especially poignant. She‰Ûªs a single mother and struggling, but she isn‰Ûªt a casualty or a case file: She goes out with girlfriends, tends to her children. Yet if she isn‰Ûªt broken when the movie opens, she has begun to buckle. Ms. Dickerson draws you to her slowly and inevitably with hopeful smiles, glints of panic and fear; her tears dribble and then cascade but are always earned. Like Mr. Harewood (from TV‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHomeland‰Ûù), Ms. Dickerson (‰ÛÏThe Wire‰Ûù) is one of a legion of very fine performers working in television who deserve to be in more movies.

Abe and Melva meet through church. A tentative bond takes shape amid the humble pews and reverberant call and response, as the Pentecostal worshipers echo the resounding ministering. Soon, along with a few other congregants, Abe forms a prayer circle with the intention of healing Melva‰Ûªs son, Benny (RaJay Chandler). Together, the congregants pray over Benny, who‰Ûªs lain supine on the altar on a simple cloth. As he moans and sometimes thrashes, they praise and they plead, begging for help from above while pledging their love. They‰Ûªre seeking a miracle for the child who increasingly looks like a sacrifice.
The movie flouts its intolerance in an attempt at provocative humor. Unless you laugh at fossils, I have no idea why you should buy a ticket to gawk at this dinosaur.

Of course, there are intolerant people everywhere, but NicolÌÁs LÌ_pez‰Ûªs movie isn‰Ûªt clever enough to make its lead character sympathetic or multidimensional, only more insufferable. The movie asphyxiates on tired jokes about anal sex, dropping the soap in the shower and a transgender prostitute. Aside from references to hookup apps and hipsters, there's little in Mr. LÌ_pez and Guillermo Amoedo‰Ûªs outdated script that doesn‰Ûªt seem like it was written 20 years ago.

Can a movie about gay panic make people laugh in 2017? The filmmakers behind ‰ÛÏHazlo Como Hombre‰Ûù are counting on it. Otherwise, there's little appeal to this romantic comedy‰Ûªs protagonist, a man so unlikable the movie opens with an M.P.A.A.-style warning for the character‰Ûªs sexism, homophobia and machismo.

RaÌ_l (Mauricio Ochmann) is a walking prehistoric machista ‰ÛÓ a man who thinks he has the right to cheat on his pregnant wife and act disgusted at the slightest homoerotic gesture. But after his best friend (Alfonso Dosal) breaks off his engagement to RaÌ_l‰Ûªs sister (Aislinn Derbez) and comes out to his friends, RaÌ_l is at a loss for words. Fortunately, everyone else in the movie seems unmoved by the news. Unfortunately, we‰Ûªre stuck with RaÌ_l.

Rather, the massage-parlor treat promised here is an anniversary gift from Cybil (Mary Steenburgen) to her longtime husband, Harvey (Paul Reiser). But the giving is itself an act of such passive-aggressive loathing that it all but destroys any comedic potential in their relationship, never mind any desire we might have to see their union endure.

In that we‰Ûªre joined by Vivian (Dolly Wells), a bitter British filmmaker who believes marriage to be unsustainable. To prove her thesis, she has enlisted Cybil and Harvey plus two more fractured Florida couples for what she is pleased to call a documentary. Ms. Bell (who also wrote the preposterous script) and Ed Helms play an unhappily childless twosome who practice ‰ÛÏresults-based‰Ûù sex by means of a phone app that tracks ovarian cycles. And Amber Heard and Wyatt Cenac are hippie-dippie caricatures whose free-love philosophy is as much a sham as Vivian‰Ûªs filmmaking ethics.

Painted in the broadest possible strokes, these ropy relationships agitate a movie that has neither a coherent point nor an authentic character. There‰Ûªs little evidence here of the talent that made Ms. Bell‰Ûªs 2013 filmmaking debut, ‰ÛÏIn a World ...‰Ûù (about struggling voice-over artists), as gentle and genuine as this one is abrasive and cartoonish. Hanging out with these folks is no fun; being married to some of them is unimaginable.

The most valuable takeaway from ‰ÛÏI Do ... Until I Don‰Ûªt,‰Ûù Lake Bell‰Ûªs pained sex comedy, is that there‰Ûªs a lot of money in happy endings. And not the kind that are typically tacked onto movies like this one.

One such group of fellows is depicted in ‰ÛÏJesÌ_s,‰Ûù a Chilean film written and directed by Fernando Guzzoni. The antisocial demeanors and antics of these men eventually result in grave harm to an innocent.

Teenage boys are all idiots. Some are harmless idiots, and some are brutish ones. Eventually most of them grow out of it. Some of the brutish ones don‰Ûªt, and if they happen to do something particularly heinous during their idiot period, their chance to reform may be cut short.

This movie has a lot of the stylistic and content hallmarks of what passes for committed realism in contemporary world cinema. A hand-held camera is often following the lead character from behind. There are explicit, seemingly unsimulated sex scenes. The filmmakers were inspired by a recent real-life event in Santiago. One feels the filmmaker trying hard to work out the inner struggles of his sad but largely unsympathetic characters. But his movie is as miserable and ultimately confounding as it is earnest.

JesÌ_s (NicolÌÁs DurÌÁn) and his crew smoke dope, drink 40-ounces, watch drug-cartel execution videos on the internet, inveigle sex from girls they later insult behind their backs, and so on. And one night they brutally beat a young man in the park who is too drunk to walk, because they think he‰Ûªs gay. This is followed almost immediately by a scene of JesÌ_s having sex with one of his male friends, because, you know, of course. The beating makes national news, and JesÌ_s turns to his father, from whom he has long been alienated.

Sharing selfies and urban legends, the four friends are an unselfconscious sorority, flirting with the camera and making out with abandon. The corruption of innocent flesh ‰ÛÓ by hickeys and herpes and worse ‰ÛÓ might be a heavy-handed metaphor, but when it‰Ûªs rendered this gorgeously, who can complain?

Clinging unswervingly to the girls‰Ûª viewpoints, ‰ÛÏKill Me Please‰Ûù is at once brash and subtle, blissed out and razor sharp. Long, stalking shots of deserted roads and darkening landscapes alternate with the flares of garish color in a kaleidoscopic birthday party, and the rainbow fluorescence of a bus shelter at night. (The stunning cinematography is by JoÌ£o Atala.) And as Bia becomes increasingly obsessed with one of the victims, the director surrounds her with zombie-movie signifiers ‰ÛÓ like a herd of silent students, viewed from above, slowly exiting a school ‰ÛÓ that underscore the dazed sensuality of her actions.

Especially for Bia (Valentina Herszage, 15 at the time of filming) and her three friends, whose upscale Rio de Janeiro neighborhood is suffering a rash of violent rapes and murders. Glistening apartment blocks gird a desolate construction site where the bodies are found and where Bia ‰ÛÓ in a scene that encapsulates the picture‰Ûªs silly-chilly mood ‰ÛÓ gently kisses the bloodied lips of one near-dead girl. The killer might still be at large, but his identity is beside the point, his victims simply the aphrodisiac that ignites the movie‰Ûªs atmosphere of sinister arousal.
