In spite of Mr. Stiller‰Ûªs displays of doubt and discomfort, the movie protects him from humiliation and finds a safe space for Brad‰Ûªs bruised ego. There is something a little disappointing about this, but also something honest, since the movie‰Ûªs message is that what looks like disappointment should be embraced as the only real happiness there is.

What do they have that Brad lacks? Where did he go wrong? Why does he only rate a worthless silver airline rewards card, instead of gold or platinum? He ruminates on these and related matters in long passages of voice-over narration, brought back to reality by the ringing of his cellphone or the needs of his son.

She has a point. So does he. His angst is real, as are the gradations of social hierarchy that cause it. But in the bigger picture, his misery is trivial. Mr. White could easily have loaded the satiric dice, emphasizing Brad‰Ûªs Gen-X self-absorption or Ananya‰Ûªs millennial self-righteousness, but he suspends judgment, leaving the viewer hanging in an exquisitely uncomfortable limbo. What are we supposed to think? We‰Ûªre supposed to think for ourselves.

Fellini used nostalgia to point out something about ourselves; Mr. Lexton uses it to remind us of Fellini‰Ûªs films. The movie can shift unevenly from effusive love letter to travel lust to sentimental moment, but that doesn‰Ûªt break the fantasy.

In the movie, Lucy (Ksenia Solo) is a sheltered 20-year-old who inherited her mother‰Ûªs idealistic view of romance and appreciation of feel-good movies. After her mother (Maria Bello) falls ill, Lucy finds solace at a festival of Fellini films and discovers movies with dark endings and sexual scenes that she had never seen before. She resolves to find the man of her cinematic dreams in Italy.

Nancy Cartwright, the voice of Bart Simpson on the long-running animated television series, has made her first movie as a screenwriter and producer, a charming drama about the love of movies and youthful passion. ‰ÛÏIn Search of Fellini‰Ûù reimagines a whirlwind adventure Ms. Cartwright once had to try to meet the Italian director Federico Fellini. With the help of her longtime collaborator and co-writer, Peter Kjenaas, and the first-time director Taron Lexton, Ms. Cartwright creates a Felliniesque fantasy of her own.

Lucy, whose wide-eyed naÌøvetÌ© is modeled after Giulietta Masina‰Ûªs character in ‰ÛÏLa Strada,‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt the only reference to Fellini‰Ûªs movies. ‰ÛÏIn Search of Fellini‰Ûù is overflowing with characters, locations and visual cues to the director‰Ûªs classics, like ‰ÛÏLa Dolce Vita,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏ8 å_‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏNights of Cabiria.‰Ûù Fans who refer to Fellini as Il Maestro may delight in these references, but several cues and cameos are followed by a scene or poster of the cited movie, so as not to exclude the rest of the audience.

Mr. Blahnik inspires this warmth by dint of his shoes and also his character, which is eccentrically patrician, starry eyed, elegant. (He wears the hell out of a lilac suit.) He‰Ûªs a man who describes wisteria ‰ÛÓ the word, but presumably also the plant ‰ÛÓ as ‰ÛÏso Olympic, it‰Ûªs so hedonistic in a way.‰Ûù
The most potent, and poignant, tribute in the sweet back-scratch of a documentary ‰ÛÏManolo: The Boy Who Made Shoes for Lizards‰Ûù is that Anna Wintour lets you see her eyes.

But this film, directed by the fashion writer and editor Michael Roberts, doesn‰Ûªt aspire beyond embrace. It rushes through Mr. Blahnik‰Ûªs biography, dwelling on pop-culture moments and blandly ecstatic celebrity testimonials (not counting the uproarious AndrÌ© Leon Talley, who insists Mr. Blahnik is ‰ÛÏup there with Baudelaire‰Ûù). It also leans heavily at times on recreated footage of Mr. Blahnik‰Ûªs childhood, as well as on a bizarre scene imagining a 1930s African society party in which a white woman emerges from a gorilla costume.

Normally, that fearsome Vogue editor wears sunglasses ‰ÛÓ in the front row of fashion shows; when she was made a dame earlier this year. But for Manolo Blahnik, maker of some of the most sublime women‰Ûªs footwear of the past four decades, she drops the lenses and lets her eyes, and feelings, show.

There is little accounting of his inner life, or for that matter of his creative gifts, which are quite exquisite. And though there are some cleverly conceived but blindingly lighted scenes of Blahnik shoes in nature, or nestled amid sculpture or architecture, there is nothing systematic to the way the shoes are discussed or filmed. In a scene puzzlingly late in the film, Mr. Blahnik, who apparently still makes samples by hand, walks through his factory and finesses a sensuous heel out of a stump of wood. More of that would have made this confection about a radiant man into something sturdier.

From within a variety of environments ‰ÛÓ including Frances Glessner Lee‰Ûªs meticulously constructed miniature dioramas of unexplained deaths ‰ÛÓ Mr. Anthony shines as much light on racist urban planning as on ratty behavior. Lessons on residential segregation slip in quietly among oddball portraits of city residents who harbor, hunt or otherwise relate to the creatures. A young couple laboriously rat-proofs a living room so their pets can play, and two men go ‰ÛÏrat-fishing‰Ûù using lines baited with turkey meat and peanut butter. With a side helping of Louisville Slugger.

Equal parts disturbing and humorous, informative and bizarre, ‰ÛÏRat Film‰Ûù is a brilliantly imaginative and formally experimental essay on how Baltimore has dealt with its rat problem and manipulated its black population.

‰ÛÏIt ain‰Ûªt never been a rat problem in Baltimore; it‰Ûªs always been a people problem,‰Ûù says Harold Edmond, a wry exterminator and philosopher-poet. And as successive layers of street maps are projected onscreen, the relationship between infestation and economic inequity is clear: Rats thrive, according to Mr. Edmond, where people have no dreams. Unspoken is the suggestion that those aspirations have been more effectively eradicated than any vermin.

Paralleling pest control and racial oppression, this first documentary feature from Theo Anthony presents a collage of ideas that rock gently between the real and the surreal, the benign and the batty. Past, present and future share visual and narrative space as the histories of poisons, eugenics, home-loan guidelines and forensic science coalesce like iron filings around a magnet. The aesthetic audacity alone is intriguing; combined with Maureen Jones‰Ûªs icily robotic narration and Dan Deacon‰Ûªs eerie electronic score, the effect is somewhere between confounding and mesmerizing.

Though questions of race and justice are raised, Yance Ford more often examines how he and the rest of his middle-class family dealt, or refused to deal, with the tragedy. He keeps the camera closely trained on the faces of those who‰Ûªve suffered emotional wounds that won‰Ûªt heal, and who live with regrets that are devastating. That includes himself.

Were ‰ÛÏStrong Island‰Ûù a strict procedural, that exclusion would be more glaring. Yet this potent film gives equal weight to complex emotions as well as bare facts. In the same way, it‰Ûªs not just the story of a man‰Ûªs death, but also a study of the aftermath.

William Ford Jr. was shot and killed on April 7, 1992, an incident at the center of the documentary ‰ÛÏStrong Island.‰Ûù Something deep inside his family also died that night, and Yance Ford, one of William‰Ûªs siblings and the film‰Ûªs director, explores that loss, exposing a grief that is profound and agonizing.

The effect is intense and elegiac, even as the pace veers toward the overly deliberate, and as Mr. Reilly and some essential witnesses aren‰Ûªt interviewed or approached by the filmmaker; no explanation for this omission is given.

William, an unarmed, black 24-year-old teacher, was slain by Mark Reilly, a 19-year-old white man who was working at an auto body shop on Long Island. Mr. Ford had gone there after a dispute over a repair and confronted Mr. Reilly about an insult that was said to have been made earlier to Mr. Ford‰Ûªs mother. A grand jury declined to indict Mr. Reilly, a decision that staggered Mr. Ford‰Ûªs loved ones.

The wedding in question is the fifth try for Eve Wilde (Glenn Close, looking bored to the point of embalmed), an over-the-hill film star and Laurence‰Ûªs ex-wife. Her latest intended is a writer named Harold (Patrick Stewart, mugging beneath a horrendously permed wig), and he and several generations of the couple‰Ûªs families and hangers-on have convened at Eve‰Ûªs lavish New York estate for the nuptials. Sex and drugs and formulaic frolicking ensue.

‰ÛÏI‰Ûªve done some stupid things in my life,‰Ûù says Laurence Darling (John Malkovich), a stage actor, at one point in ‰ÛÏThe Wilde Wedding.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs a line that Mr. Malkovich might easily filch to excuse his participation in this execrable remarriage comedy, one that‰Ûªs mystifyingly seeded with acting heavyweights. Maybe the writer and director, Damian Harris, has a dossier.

With too many characters to keep track of, never mind care about, the viewer is reduced to counting the movie‰Ûªs many irritants. There‰Ûªs the virtually nonstop, banal music; the bleating narration of a family member (Grace Van Patten), who‰Ûªs making a documentary; the inane dialogue (‰ÛÏLove is in the air!‰Ûù). While Harold gets it on with a woman seemingly young enough to have missed the fall of the Berlin Wall (in one of the film‰Ûªs more distasteful digressions), Laurence ‰ÛÓ all head-to-toe cream and fey wrist-flicking ‰ÛÓ is such a parody he belongs in a mockumentary about classical actors.

The soullessness of the enterprise is staggering. Making clichÌ©d, cynical gestures toward romance, Mr. Harris (whose last feature was almost a decade ago) tortured me for a full 96 minutes. You‰Ûªre welcome.

Babel Johnson (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje), called Babs, is a former Philadelphia cop who had a drug problem. Now clean, he is living in New Jersey, dealing with corrupt police brass and getting a new partner, Paddy Sheehan (Christopher McDonald), an affable gambling addict whose wife (Jennifer Ehle), a TV news anchor, strikes sexual sparks with Babs.

As the haunted Babs, Mr. Akinnuoye-Agbaje has an imposing physicality and understated nobility, while Ms. Graham fleshes out the resolute if underwritten Savannah. (Ms. Graham keeps improving, and her role lends a welcome grit to her fresh-scrubbed image.) And Barry Markowitz‰Ûªs cinematography nicely captures a desolate outpost of sea and sin. But as cinematic excursions go, ‰ÛÏWetlands,‰Ûù the feature debut of its writer-director, Emanuele Della Valle, is more deserving of a day trip than a long-term stay.

But Babs is mainly on a mission to regain the trust of his ex, Savannah (Heather Graham), and daughter, Amy (Celeste O‰ÛªConnor), who want no part of him. Savannah cavorts in seedy bars with Surfer Girl (Reyna de Courcy), a drug runner skimming goods that she hopes will buy her a new life in Hawaii. When Surfer Girl runs afoul of her suppliers, events take a homicidal turn as a coastal hurricane brews.

The moody ambience of the beachside noir ‰ÛÏWetlands‰Ûù is almost enough to make you want to plan an off-season visit to Atlantic City, near where it is set, or to believe the film‰Ûªs dramatic devices and occasionally arch dialogue. And yet, for some, its atmosphere and intriguing performances will prove worthy of the outing.

JuliÌÁn (the Haitian-Dominican actor and filmmaker Jean Jean), who has been convicted of theft, is shorn of his resplendent dreadlocks when he is sent to Najayo, where he quickly learns the sign language ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏwoodpecking‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ that the inmates employ to communicate and flirt from afar with the female inmates at an adjacent penitentiary. (An elevated fenced enclosure looks out at their athletic area.)

JuliÌÁn also serves as a proxy for Manaury (RamÌ_n Emilio Candelario), a hotheaded drug dealer, who has been barred from communicating directly with his incarcerated ‰ÛÏgirlfriend,‰Ûù Yanelly (Judith RodrÌ_guez). When JuliÌÁn himself catches Yanelly‰Ûªs eye, and she his, tensions escalate between JuliÌÁn and Manaury, and the men are relocated to the even more oppressive La Victoria. There, a newly freed Yanelly visits as passions and a prison riot erupt.

The lean handsomeness and quiet authority of Mr. Jean is a perfect complement to Ms. RodrÌ_guez‰Ûªs passionate Yanelly, while the locations ‰ÛÓ and the presence of actual inmates ‰ÛÓ underscore the harsh boundaries the lovers struggle against. Their efforts to transcend their station leads to a stark climax that is a silent, anguished and haunting cri de coeur.

JosÌ© MarÌ_a Cabral‰Ûªs arresting drama ‰ÛÏWoodpeckers (Carpinteros)‰Ûù could be called love in a pressure cooker, but that would be understating its vivid textures and palpable vitality. The film was shot on location in the Dominican Republic‰Ûªs Najayo and La Victoria prisons, where the stifling claustrophobia of those settings infuses every frame.

Mr. HabrÌ© was arrested in 2013 in Senegal, where he was living in exile, and the movie was first shown at the Cannes Film Festival in May 2016, shortly before Mr. HabrÌ© was convicted of war crimes. That foreknowledge provides some context for the interviews, most of which are conducted by ClÌ©ment AbaÌøfouta, the leader of a group that pressed for Mr. HabrÌ©‰Ûªs prosecution.

Documentarians have long struggled with how to depict the aftermaths of atrocities. Claude Lanzmann‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏShoah‰Ûù spreads its interviews out over more than nine hours, implicitly acknowledging the limitations of making a Holocaust film even as it serves as a record of survivors‰Ûª memories. Joshua Oppenheimer‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Act of Killing‰Ûù goes for the throat: The director shows the former members of Indonesian death squads re-enacting their crimes.

In considering the case of HissÌ¬ne HabrÌ© (also known as Hissein), who as president of Chad from 1982 to 1990 led a murderous, dictatorial government, ‰ÛÏHissein HabrÌ©, a Chadian Tragedy‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt go to any extremes. It‰Ûªs more of a document than a documentary; calling it cinema seems like an error of categorization.

Although the director, Mahamat-Saleh Haroun (‰ÛÏA Screaming Man‰Ûù), who was raised in Chad but left during Mr. HabrÌ©‰Ûªs rule and now lives in France, provides a voice-over, his authorial presence is minimal. The bulk of the film consists of survivors of Mr. HabrÌ©‰Ûªs reign recounting their arrests and what happened to them afterward. The interviews can be dry and formal (names, ages and dates of arrest). Many victims are still suffering the physical tolls of torture.

The tensest scene involves an effort by Mr. AbaÌøfouta to broker a reconciliation. Mr. AbaÌøfouta sits with a man who was arrested by Mr. HabrÌ©‰Ûªs political police force, and with the policeman the former prisoner says arrested and tortured him. Then Mr. AbaÌøfouta asks the victim if it‰Ûªs possible to offer forgiveness. The former HabrÌ© police force member attempts to play down his actions (‰ÛÏI was a subordinate,‰Ûù he says), and likens himself to a dog who was trained to attack.
In response, the victim urges him to ‰ÛÏbe a man‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ not a dog ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏat all times.‰Ûù

Unlike their spring 2018 fashion collection, Kate and Laura Mulleavy‰Ûªs first foray into moviemaking, ‰ÛÏWoodshock,‰Ûù is depressingly dull and terminally inarticulate. Oh, it‰Ûªs pretty enough, in the superficially embellished style of a perfume ad or fashion video ‰ÛÓ the gifted Finnish cinematographer Peter Flinckenberg virtually empties his bag of tricks. But it‰Ûªs more lacking in substance than a yard of silk chiffon.

The title refers to the psychological panic engendered by being lost in a forest (here played by the giant redwoods in Humboldt County, California), but Theresa (Kirsten Dunst) isn‰Ûªt physically disoriented, just mentally unmoored. Having helped her sick mother die using a spiked spliff, Theresa, who works in a medical-marijuana dispensary, descends into a detached reverie of hallucinatory grief. Neither her boyfriend (Joe Cole, underemployed to the point of effacement) nor her boss (a miscast Pilou Asbaek) can reach her.

Filmmaking might be a natural sidestep for fashion designers ‰ÛÓ as Tom Ford has twice proven, though he had the foresight to use strong novels as building blocks ‰ÛÓ but ‰ÛÏWoodshock‰Ûù is a painterly bore. At their most basic level, movies are supposed to actually move; this one is as becalmed as its perpetually high heroine.

What follows is less a consideration of the fallout from an act of euthanasia than a succession of disjointed, dreamlike scenes of Theresa listlessly caressing tree trunks and her mother‰Ûªs shabby-chic furnishings. More than one person will die as she continues to mope and medicate, attired in a succession of lace-trimmed chemises. Yet no substantive conversation or hint of greater meaning pierces this gauzy void, which the Mulleavy sisters, whose fashion label is Rodarte, decorate by slapping butterflies or flowers on virtually every available surface.

Following this drolly mordant prologue, ‰ÛÏThirst Street‰Ûù becomes the story of Gina‰Ûªs fanatical rebound from her lover‰Ûªs suicide. We watch as Gina fixates with rose-colored glasses on a new partner, this time a skeezy Parisian bartender, JÌ©rÌ«me (also played by Mr. Bonnard), whose acquiescence to a one-night stand in no way prepares him for the onslaught of Gina‰Ûªs obsession.

But even as Gina‰Ûªs behavior dips past manic pixie dream girl to merely manic, the director never deviates from the detached tone of his prologue. Though both Ms. Burdge and Mr. Bonnard offer vulnerably world-weary performances, Mr. Silver has made a movie about obsession that never delves deeper than infatuation.

The director, Nathan Silver, frames Gina (Lindsay Burdge) in the lime, magenta and lapis light of Gina‰Ûªs Technicolor fantasies, even as a wry voice-over by the narrator, Anjelica Huston, observes the beloved Paul transitioning from honeymoon period to suicidal depression, without Gina‰Ûªs notice.

Thematically shallow but stylistically rich, ‰ÛÏThirst Street‰Ûù is best enjoyed with a hint of its heroine‰Ûªs willfully superficial vision. For an audience with an eye for their own pleasure, ‰ÛÏThirst Street‰Ûù offers a parade of beautiful light, beautiful (women‰Ûªs) bodies, and beautiful surfaces ‰ÛÓ no need to worry about what‰Ûªs inside.

The preamble of the new black comedy ‰ÛÏThirst Street‰Ûù finds Gina, an American flight attendant, in a period of stability, happily partnered with her doting boyfriend, Paul (Damien Bonnard), as she jetsets from Berlin to Chicago to Rome.

‰ÛÏKill Elton John!‰Ûù is a line you‰Ûªre unlikely to hear in the average spy caper, but ‰ÛÏKingsman: The Golden Circle‰Ûù aims far above average. Like its 2015 predecessor, this latest visit with the British agents-cum-Savile Row tailors swings for the fences without caring whose head ‰ÛÓ or torso, or dignity ‰ÛÓ is shredded en route. Even if it belongs to Sir Elton.

Yet in a movie as happy to resurrect characters as rub them out, nothing is of consequence, and the glibness grows numbing. As does the cocky masculinity: This is, after all, a man‰Ûªs world, and women had better get behind or beneath them if they want to survive. Sir Elton will make it just fine on his own.

Bigger, longer and ‰ÛÓ at an interminable 141 minutes ‰ÛÓ apparently uncut, ‰ÛÏCircle‰Ûù is an emotionally sterile lark, its wounds inflicted with brolly and bullwhip, a smirk and a shrug. Obliterating all but two Kingsmen in the opening reel, the story (by the director, Matthew Vaughn, and Jane Goldman) forces the leftovers into the protective arms of their American counterparts, cowboy spies with rolling hips and code names like Tequila and Champagne. Their presence, led by a strutting Channing Tatum, lends the action a homoerotic glaze that I choose to believe is intentional.

In a plot as sloppy and extended as over-washed elastic, the singer‰Ûªs cameo as the feathered-and-sequined pet of a drug-dealing villain named Poppy (Julianne Moore) is a ludicrous highlight. A homesick sociopath, Poppy has styled her Cambodian lair to resemble Eisenhower-era America, including a diner where those who displease her are churned into Hamburger Helper. (So that‰Ûªs what the first film was lacking: cannibalism.)

A dollop of mawkish sentiment is to be expected in this kind of movie. ‰ÛÏThe Lego Ninjago Movie‰Ûù applies it in gluey globs, freezing the action so that Lloyd and Garmadon can work out their issues. For whose benefit? Children are unlikely to be captivated by this unconvincing melodrama of abandonment and reconciliation, and adults will be moved by it only because we‰Ûªre hopeless crybabies.

‰ÛÏWhen are the Wegos coming on?‰Ûù the young boy sitting next to me asked his father. His impatience was reasonable enough. Here we were, five minutes into ‰ÛÏThe Lego Ninjago Movie,‰Ûù gazing at a live-action prologue with Jackie Chan, a kid and a cat in a store full of exotic knickknacks.

We‰Ûªre also, at least in the eyes of the committee that issued this strategy memo disguised as a movie, eager to hear the voices of cool people we watch on television. Abbi Jacobson of ‰ÛÏBroad City,‰Ûù Fred Armisen of ‰ÛÏPortlandia‰Ûù and Kumail Nanjiani of ‰ÛÏSilicon Valley‰Ûù (and also ‰ÛÏThe Big Sick‰Ûù) are on sidekick duty here, to no memorable effect. Ms. Jacobson‰Ûªs character, the only girl in the six-ninja squad, barely rises to the level of tokenism.

Not as much as we‰Ûªd like to. The Lego figures are rendered with playful rigor; their limited movements and expressions generate some amusing sight gags. But the physical world they inhabit is more of a generic digital-cartoon space than a snapped-together environment. And the themes they explore are tired, cynical, sub-Disney bromides about family reconciliation and self-discovery.

‰ÛÏShe‰Ûªs a girl and a ninja! Can she have it all?‰Ûù a voice-over asks sardonically, trying to make a self-conscious joke at the expense of the movie‰Ûªs own imaginative limitations. ‰ÛÏYou fellas need to inform yourselves on where we‰Ûªre at culturally,‰Ûù the lady ninja retorts. It‰Ûªs a good line, but also one that the writers and directors ‰ÛÓ fellas to a man ‰ÛÓ might have taken a bit more to heart. Or maybe they did, and this is just where we‰Ûªre at culturally.

Garmadon, who wants to be a mayor, is a megalomaniac whose regular assaults on peace and normalcy are breathlessly covered by the news media and whose favorite pastime is firing his underlings. His estranged teenage son, Lloyd (Dave Franco), is ostracized and mocked for being the child of such a monster. But Lloyd, whose alter ego is the Green Ninja, works behind the scenes to check his father‰Ûªs worst tendencies. Does every movie have to be a political allegory now? Can‰Ûªt we just have fun?

Soon enough, the Wegos awwived, and the latest installment in a nearly foolproof franchise was underway, a fast-moving mÌ©lange of brazen corporate promotion, winking pop-culture cleverness and earnest lesson-learning. I realize that makes this movie sound indistinguishable from nearly every other piece of family-targeted animated big-screen entertainment out there, and I‰Ûªm sorry to report that the Lego movie enterprise has lapsed into intentional mediocrity.

This is especially disappointing given the conceptual wit, visual flair and bonkers imagination of ‰ÛÏThe Lego Movie‰Ûù and the sweet silliness of ‰ÛÏThe Lego Batman Movie.‰Ûù ‰ÛÏThe Lego Ninjago Movie,‰Ûù directed by Charlie Bean, Paul Fisher and Bob Logan from a script with an army of credited authors, attaches itself to some of the tropes and images of Asian action cinema with sloppy affection. Mr. Chan, who voices a wise and venerable teacher in addition to playing the wise and venerable shopkeeper, doesn‰Ûªt really belong to the ninja genre. But neither do the young fighters who protect the city of Ninjago from an evil four-armed warlord named Garmadon, voiced by Justin Theroux. They prefer big, noisy machines to stealth, guile and swordsmanship.

Bobbi Jene Smith had performed with the Batsheva Dance Company in Israel for a decade before deciding to return home to the United States. Early on we watch her informing Ohad Naharin, the troupe‰Ûªs artistic director, of her plan. Other scenes monitor her resulting long-distance relationship with Or Schraiber, her Israeli boyfriend, who‰Ûªd stayed behind.

Though we‰Ûªre told Ms. Smith was a star, her years with the company aren‰Ûªt recapped, and there‰Ûªs scant information on her intriguing back story ‰ÛÓ she grew up in Iowa before making her way to Juilliard, only to leave to follow Mr. Naharin; for a time they were lovers. No colleagues or critics are interviewed to give insights or memories or opinions. Ms. Smith reveals little about her theories or hopes or ideas.

Late in ‰ÛÏBobbi Jene,‰Ûù Ms. Smith is back in Israel, performing a piece in the nude that requires her to bring herself to orgasm in front of an audience. What could seem pornographic is instead an entrancing meditation on shame and desire. Yet here again, no effort is made by Ms. Lind to engage the unacquainted. Afterward, Ms. Smith laments that in contemporary dance, a performer can create a great work but few people will see it. Documentaries like this won‰Ûªt gain the art form many new followers.

Those exclusions are apparently deliberate. The film‰Ûªs director, Elvira Lind, chooses to slowly observe Ms. Smith rather than rush to understand or challenge her. That formless approach is risky, and for viewers unfamiliar with Mr. Naharin‰Ûªs technique, gaga (which is the subject of another recent documentary), it‰Ûªs bound to lead to confusion.
Enigmatic to an extreme, the documentary ‰ÛÏBobbi Jene‰Ûù may interest viewers who are well versed in contemporary dance. All others are on their own.

She does not inhabit the best of all possible worlds, though, for all her privilege. Because Madonna is such an obvious antecedent (and she is mentioned here, specifically with respect to the tsoris surrounding Gaga‰Ûªs reputedly Madonna-derived song ‰ÛÏBorn This Way‰Ûù), this movie is bound to be compared to 1991‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏTruth or Dare.‰Ûù But these are very different movies, because their subjects are very different people. While Madonna was shown as the happy ringleader of a media circus, ‰ÛÏFive Foot Two‰Ûù depicts an artist and idol in a peculiar isolation. Even when other people are in the frame, Gaga often seems sadly but necessarily alone.

That would be her album ‰ÛÏJoanne,‰Ûù which, she tells the writer Darryl Pinckney in a disarming scene here, was inspired by an aunt who died before this artist was born as Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta. (As Mr. Pinckney noted in his piece, for The Times‰Ûªs T Magazine, Gaga was named in part for her.) Besides baring a heretofore-unseen part of her artistic soul, the movie finds her coping with heartache and physical ailments. While it‰Ûªs possible that the director and cinematographer Chris Moukarbel is good at withholding unflattering material, Gaga comes off well, and credibly so: intelligent, an accomplished craftswoman, a well-mannered collaborator and boss.

Even when the pop music provocateur known as Lady Gaga seemed to be changing personae by the hour, one eyebrow-raising costume or public gesture after another, those paying proper attention could discern a disciplined, focused performer/musician behind the choreographed madness. While the movie climaxes with preparations for Gaga‰Ûªs strangely spectacular 2017 Super Bowl halftime show, it mostly chronicles the artist at work in 2016 on a project that would ostensibly present her ‰ÛÏunplugged,‰Ûù so to speak.

Structurally, the movie is as loose as some of the features that Mr. Doyle has made as a cinematographer for Wong Kar-wai (‰ÛÏ2046‰Ûù). Although ‰ÛÏHong Kong Trilogy‰Ûù is divided into three segments, each ostensibly focusing on a different generation, the sections bleed into one another. Some characters float throughout the film.

The most cohesive section is the middle, between ‰ÛÏPreschooled,‰Ûù which focuses on the very young, and ‰ÛÏPreposterous,‰Ûù a non sequitur of a finale that deals, partly, with speed-dating seniors. ‰ÛÏPreoccupied,‰Ûù however, centers on young activists and depicts a snapshot of the Umbrella Movement, the 2014 pro-democracy uprising against Beijing‰Ûªs political influence. Mr. Doyle films the tents that sprouted in the city and visits demonstration sites ‰ÛÓ including an organic farm and a wall inspired by John Lennon ‰ÛÓ that were also designed, the movie suggests, as spaces for thought.

Despite plentiful onscreen text, the film doesn‰Ûªt clarify details. (You may wonder about the fate of Vodka, a child the police haul in for littering.) The free-form assembly is consistent with this movie‰Ûªs utopian worldview, but the lack of narrative discipline can be trying.

Directed by the cinematographer Christopher Doyle, ‰ÛÏHong Kong Trilogy: Preschooled, Preoccupied, Preposterous‰Ûù is drawn from the real voices of contemporary Hong Kong residents, a title card says. More of a poem or a city symphony than a documentary, it drifts freely, sometimes frustratingly between captured and fictionalized moments.

‰ÛÏLoving Vincent‰Ûù addresses its subject, the Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh, with two what-ifs ‰ÛÓ one marvelous and fantastical, the other empirical and pedestrian. What if his paintings, with their wild colors and vibrant brush strokes, had been able to move? And what if the bullet that killed him had been fired by someone else?

That legend has been sustained by earlier movies, notably Vincente Minnelli‰Ûªs rumbustious ‰ÛÏLust for Life‰Ûù (with Kirk Douglas as van Gogh) and Robert Altman‰Ûªs more cerebral ‰ÛÏVincent & Theo‰Ûù (starring Tim Roth and Paul Rhys as the brothers).

Vincent himself (Robert Gulaczyk) is a more elusive presence in ‰ÛÏLoving Vincent,‰Ûù since most of its action is posthumous and self-portraits make up a relatively small part of his oeuvre. There are flashbacks, but the painter is evoked mainly through the dialogue of the other characters, as if he were the Maltese Falcon.

A long and arduous labor of love by Dorota Kobiela and Hugh Welchman, the film turns van Gogh‰Ûªs work into an unusual kind of biopic. Using tens of thousands of oil paintings commissioned from scores of artists, the filmmakers transform famous works of modern art into a hypnotic and beguiling cartoon. The people van Gogh rendered on canvas ‰ÛÓ the provincial French functionaries, doctors, barmaids and farmers immortalized on museum walls ‰ÛÓ are brought to uncanny life, with the voices of professional actors, some of them well known.

They participate in a meandering detective story. Armand Roulin (Douglas Booth), the layabout son of a village postmaster (Chris O‰ÛªDowd), is instructed by his father to deliver a letter to Vincent‰Ûªs brother Theo. Armand travels to Paris and then to Auvers-sur-Oise, the northern French town where Vincent died, leaving behind contradictory memories among the people he painted in his final years. They recall a passionate, hard-working artist, but not always the tormented, suicidal genius of legend.

The questions are interesting, but not quite sufficiently dramatized to sustain ‰ÛÏLoving Vincent‰Ûù for its full length. As the story limps and drags, the viewer also becomes accustomed to the images, and astonishment at the film‰Ûªs innovative, painstaking technique begins to fade. But its charm never quite wears off, for reasons summed up in the title.

The principal mystery is the stuff of police procedural, as Armand doggedly tries to reconstruct van Gogh‰Ûªs final weeks and shed light on the circumstances of his death. How miserable was he, and why? What secrets did he harbor? What enemies had he made?

Ms. Faris and Mr. Dayton handle the many moving parts in Simon Beaufoy‰Ûªs busy script smoothly as they toggle between intimate moments and public events, and set Billie Jean‰Ûªs bedroom sighs off against Bobby‰Ûªs heat-seeking braggadocio. There‰Ûªs a lot to follow and a great deal to look at, including an atmospherically embellished past that turns the movie into a veritable wayback machine of amusing and amusingly unfortunate colors and choices. (The director of photography is Linus Sandgren; the production designer is Judy Becker.) There are plaid jackets and flirty minis, sideburns and shags, harvest-gold drapes and rooms perilously fogged in by cigarette smoke.

Billie Jean faces down Kramer at one point, speaking feminist truth to power: ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs when we want a little bit of what you‰Ûªve got,‰Ûù she says, ‰ÛÏthat‰Ûªs what you can‰Ûªt stand.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs a solid gotcha moment, but the reason it works as well as it does is its low-key realism, which underscores the absolute ordinariness of the sexism she‰Ûªs calling out. Ms. Stone handles the scene exactly right, letting you see the tremor of indignation while keeping righteousness in view yet also in check. She‰Ûªs unsurprisingly good and often moving, although the best thing about the performance is that Ms. Stone hasn‰Ûªt been asked to play the girl who seduces us with big eyes and a smile. Billie Jean is a woman, and that‰Ûªs a win.

The directors Valerie Faris and Jonathan Dayton make these early scenes pop, cramming characters and information into Billie Jean and Bobby‰Ûªs separate realities. Billie Jean‰Ûªs is livelier, more engaging, partly because there‰Ûªs more at stake and because she‰Ûªs surrounded by chummy, pleasurably prickly women like Rosie Casals (Natalie Morales) and Gladys Heldman (a tangy Sarah Silverman), the founder of Tennis World magazine. Together with seven other top female players, these three form a feminist revolt called the Virginia Slims tour, a women‰Ûªs pro circuit that sets out to combat the gross inequalities that defined professional (open) tennis since its advent in 1968.

Every so often an exceptionally capable woman has to prove her worth by competing against a clown. That‰Ûªs one of the durable truisms of ‰ÛÏBattle of the Sexes,‰Ûù a glib, enjoyable fictionalization of the 1973 exhibition tennis match between Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs. She was 29 and one of the top female tennis players in the world. He was 55 and had been a world champion before she was born. She was a feminist symbol and the first female athlete to win more than $100,000 in a single year; he was a self-avowed male chauvinist pig who liked to gamble big. It was a man vs. woman match made for maximum public-relations gimmickry but also a deadly serious referendum on equality on and off the court.

As the sunny, sporty feminists stake their rightful claim ‰ÛÓ holding press conferences, drumming up support, winning and winning some more ‰ÛÓ a rather dark, clubbier male world comes into view. A gambler, Bobby watches Billie Jean on TV but hangs with masters of the universe, male cigar chompers and scotch swirlers who think nothing of betting away a Rolls-Royce. It looks like a lethal bore, as does Bobby‰Ûªs home, where he plays with his young son under a conspicuously large and looming portrait of his wife. By the time Bobby is challenging Billie Jean to play it almost seems as if he were willing himself into the arms ‰ÛÓ or at least company ‰ÛÓ of this other woman.

A revolution can be tough to squeeze into two hours, but ‰ÛÏBattle of the Sexes‰Ûù manages it mostly by skipping along its handsome surfaces. The film repeatedly announces that there‰Ûªs a lot at stake here, but without much urgency or sting. Bobby‰Ûªs sexist pronouncements are outrageous, but his stunts are so absurd and self-serving that they‰Ûªre hard to take seriously. And while Mr. Carell bounces and sags persuasively, the characterization is finally so soft that Bobby comes off as more needy and pathetic than threatening. The better foil and villain is a tennis promoter, Jack Kramer (Bill Pullman), one of those men who never bothers to hide his contempt for women.

So it was personal and it was political, which ‰ÛÏBattle of the Sexes‰Ûù gets. It was also entertainment, which is where the movie really excels. Nice and easy, it sets the players and early 1970s scene, with Billie Jean (Emma Stone) already making history and Bobby (Steve Carell) largely sidelined. She‰Ûªs making waves as a player and as a champion of women‰Ûªs rights, including equal pay, and earning plaudits from the likes of President Nixon. Bobby seems to be living off his indulgent wealthy wife (Elisabeth Shue), a frozen smiler right out of Stepford, and spending time on idle in a fancy office. Mostly, Billie Jean is winning while Bobby is keeping boredom at bay.

It takes a while for them to meet on the court, partly because Billie Jean initially turns Bobby down. So instead, he takes on Margaret Court (Jessica McNamee), the Australian champion who becomes the movie‰Ûªs female heavy. (The real Ms. Court has played that role off screen for her views on same-sex marriage and homosexuality, which she‰Ûªs branded ‰ÛÏa lust for the flesh.‰Ûù) In a well-publicized faceoff soon called the Mother‰Ûªs Day Massacre, Bobby defeats Margaret, a loss that Billie Jean feels she needs to correct. It‰Ûªs game on, though with complications, including Billie Jean‰Ûªs revelatory attraction to another woman, a hairdresser, Marilyn Barnett (Andrea Riseborough).

For Mr. Bauman and his milieu, Mr. Green forgoes the standard Hollywood clichÌ©s about boisterous, hard-drinking, ‰ÛÏpolitically incorrect‰Ûù working-class Bostonians in favor of characters who are far, far, far more boisterous, hard-drinking and ‰ÛÏpolitically incorrect.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs kind of terrifying. For instance, Jeff‰Ûªs mother, Patty, in an astounding turn by Miranda Richardson, is a slovenly, resentful, egocentric drunk who frequently prioritizes her hangovers over Jeff‰Ûªs physical rehabilitation appointments. For all that, the movie itself never judges its people.

‰ÛÏStronger‰Ûù takes more artistic risks than any other American-made ‰ÛÏinspired by true events‰Ûù picture I can recall. The emotions and situations depicted, as Jeff struggles with PTSD, his immobility, his relationship with Erin and his hometown-hero status (which he believes to be completely unearned), are raw, sometimes desperate. A scene late in the film in which Jeff begs not to be abandoned is played at such a high pitch that it flirts with, then transcends, bathos.

‰ÛÏStronger,‰Ûù the new movie directed by David Gordon Green, harks back to his work in the first decade of this century. His ‰ÛÏAll the Real Girls‰Ûù (2003) and ‰ÛÏSnow Angels‰Ûù (2007) brought acute, cleareyed, compassionate consideration to trauma and tragedy as they affect intimate relationships. Unlike those pictures, though, ‰ÛÏStronger‰Ûù carries a separate weight. It‰Ûªs also about an actual galvanic event in recent American history.

But as it approaches the two-hour mark, the movie seems to wake to the fact that it has to live up to its title. Then ‰ÛÏStronger‰Ûù rushes through what screenwriting gurus call the ‰ÛÏredemptive arc,‰Ûù with little concern for just how its lead character makes the life changes that enable him to face his responsibilities. And in that respect, it brings the viewer up short.
‰ÛÏStronger‰Ûù is the story of Jeff Bauman, a resident of Chelmsford, Mass., who lost both his legs above the knee in the terrorist bombings of the Boston Marathon in 2013.

The movie, based on Mr. Bauman‰Ûªs autobiography, begins with a depiction of him as a relatively amiable screw-up. Played by Jake Gyllenhaal, who‰Ûªs almost a decade older than Mr. Bauman was at the time of the events shown, the character is nevertheless a convincing man-child. After making a grisly mess of a chicken-roasting task at the Costco where he works, Jeff repairs to his local, where he drinks and curses and makes moon-eyes at his ex-girlfriend Erin (Tatiana Maslany), a rather more directed soul who‰Ûªs popped in to collect donations for her marathon run. Seizing on a notion to win her back, Jeff hand-letters a sign to brandish near the race‰Ûªs finish line. He sees one of the bombers moments before the explosion that costs him his legs.

As its title suggests, ‰ÛÏThe Force‰Ûù offers a look at a police department, explicitly as it is embodied by individuals and operates as an institution. There are times, especially when the other meanings of ‰ÛÏforce‰Ûù emerge ‰ÛÓ and power, compulsion and violence become nakedly present ‰ÛÓ that you wish that Mr. Nicks would have stayed longer so he could dig deeper into related issues, including segregation and racism. He tends to cycle through historical markers fairly fast, as when he shows archival images of the group originally and pointedly called the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense, which started in Oakland in 1966, partly in response to police brutality.

In the potent documentary ‰ÛÏThe Force,‰Ûù there‰Ûªs a moment when Sean Whent, the Oakland chief of police, faces a tough critic: the public. It‰Ûªs 2015, and he‰Ûªs talking about the police response to calls. He admits the police are not providing the level of service they should but adds that they‰Ûªre trying their best. When a robbery victim says their best isn‰Ûªt good enough, he apologizes. ‰ÛÏWe need to do a better job, no doubt, and we are trying to do a better job.‰Ûù By the end of the movie it seems clear that he didn‰Ûªt apologize enough.

‰ÛÏThe Force‰Ûù doesn‰Ûªt offer much on the history of the settlement, though the director, Peter Nicks, does periodically pull back to look at the bigger messy picture. For the most part, he keeps his focus trained on events as they transpire during the two often turbulent years that he roots around the department. He rides with officers, follows them onto the streets and straight into assorted testy conflagrations. He sits in on meetings, some with officers and others with politicians, recording silences and outbursts, moments of frustration and complaint. Repeatedly, he sets the efforts of individual cops against larger departmental issues.

Yet while ‰ÛÏThe Force‰Ûù aims for political even-handedness, the fact that Mr. Nicks embedded with the Oakland police (rather than, say, with activists) means it emphasizes reform as a goal and a possibility. The movie may offer an incriminatory catalog of organizational failure, but it also repeatedly shows people trying to make the system work. A sobering alternative view surfaces late when Cat Brooks, with the Anti Police-Terror Group, says ‰ÛÏWe do not believe that police departments can actually be reformed.‰Ûù For these activists, a triage solution like a civilian review board makes sense, even as other questions ‰ÛÓ is a police force necessary? ‰ÛÓ linger.

Blunt and sobering, ‰ÛÏThe Force‰Ûù is an account of a big-city police department in crisis. In some ways, it is a bleakly familiar story of a troubled department struggling ‰ÛÓ and failing and struggling ‰ÛÓ to right its wrongs. In 2003, Oakland and its police settled a civil-rights lawsuit and began trying to implement reforms (like improved officer training) and adhere to fundamentals, or what the city attorney called the department‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏcommitment to constitutional policing.‰Ûù By 2014, the year the documentary opens, the department was into its second decade of federal oversight and these basic goals remained stubbornly elusive.

If Mr. Nicks intended to advance an overt political agenda or partisan point of view going into his documentary, it isn‰Ûªt all that evident onscreen. Certainly the documentary doesn‰Ûªt come off as either for or against the police in general terms or in respect to the Oakland force. And while personalities emerge, Mr. Nicks doesn‰Ûªt elevate heroes or call out villains. Instead, he makes room for various voices, from community organizers to protesters with Black Lives Matter signs to a sober young officer whose experiences underscore how tough and at times harrowing being a street cop can be. These voices are fractious, cacophonous and rarely in sync.

Serving as his own cinematographer, Mr. Nicks largely takes an observational approach to ‰ÛÏThe Force,‰Ûù the kind that turns the camera into a persistent bystander. This particular bystander tends to have a fairly short attention span and rarely stays in one place for long, perhaps because Mr. Nicks crams years of material into a 93-minute film. He also incorporates a bit of found material, including old news reports, as well as a few extremely disturbing lethal encounters taken from police body cams. Every so often, he identifies a speaker with onscreen text or adds a time stamp; occasionally, he slides in some propulsive electronic beats.

A saga of Norway‰Ûªs entry into World War II that probably plays more stirringly in the nation where it is set, ‰ÛÏThe King‰Ûªs Choice‰Ûù dramatizes a celebrated moment in the country‰Ûªs constitutional monarchy, when King Haakon VII (Jesper Christensen) refused to surrender to the Nazis‰Ûª invasion.

‰ÛÏThe King‰Ûªs Choice‰Ûù maintains a sense of intrigue when it sticks to the king‰Ûªs dealings with the government, but the movie drags when it moves outside of back rooms and deviates from setting up the BrÌ_uer-Haakon showdown.

Braíöuer is alone among the German characters in his affection for neutral Norway and recognizes that Norwegians aren‰Ûªt sympathetic to Germany‰Ûªs desire for iron ore and a strategic coastline, or its violently proffered promise of protection from a hypothetical British invasion.

Apart from a great deal of hand-held, wide-screen camera work that might be thought of as Lars von Trier-o-Vision, the movie, directed by Erik Poppe, proceeds in the manner of any number of war epics of the 1960s, sluggishly charting how the ostensibly ceremonial king acquired real negotiating power during a crisis ‰ÛÓ and had the resolve to lead his country into war.

Checking off dates and locations onscreen, and filling its dialogue with undigested exposition, the movie traces the parallel journeys of the king, who evacuates Oslo with the royal family in the face of the attack, and the German envoy, Curt Braíöuer (Karl Markovics), who, in the film‰Ûªs telling, is authorized by Hitler to bypass the cabinet and negotiate directly with the king.

The year is 1979, the fashions are horrendous and Sami has but two ambitions: To win the love of his childhood sweetheart and achieve the social status of his father, a celebrated tiger hunter who died when Sami was a child. Problems arise immediately when an expected engineering position disappears in a downsizing company, leaving Sami with a temporary job as a draftsman and a visa that‰Ûªs set to expire in 30 days.

With a likable cast and a wholesome message about the true meaning of success, ‰ÛÏThe Tiger Hunter‰Ûù might balk at the harsher details of immigrant life, but it has a generosity of spirit that lifts everyone up. Surrounding Sami with a strong support group of fellow South Asian professionals working menial jobs, the director, Lena Khan (who wrote the script with Sameer Gardezi, and whose own grandfather was a tiger hunter), knows exactly the story she wants to tell.

A gentle, warmhearted immigrant comedy that‰Ûªs rarely more than mildly amusing, ‰ÛÏThe Tiger Hunter‰Ûù follows Sami (Danny Pudi), an aspiring engineer, from his rural Indian village to a job opportunity in Chicago.

She is helped immensely by Mr. Pudi, whose quirky performance as a television-obsessed student on the NBC comedy ‰ÛÏCommunity‰Ûù was a consistent delight. It also gave him an ease with ensemble work that allows him to blend with other actors instead of sucking attention. The result is an endearingly old-fashioned comedy, not just in its style and the sweetness of its plot, but also in its bright-eyed optimism about immigrant opportunities. These days, it can be hard to remember that for those who dreamed large, America once seemed like a soft place to fall.

Nearly 30 years after chronic fatigue syndrome was given its unfortunate name, it‰Ûªs still not understood or even completely accepted by the medical world: No definitive cause has been identified, nor any consensus treatment. And while it affects an estimated 1 million Americans and 17 million globally, those with the condition are often dismissed as suffering from psychosomatic disorders.

Mainly, though, ‰ÛÏUnrest‰Ûù is a video diary and, as such, is not always easy to watch. Ms. Brea bravely spares very little in showing how the disease literally leveled her life ‰ÛÓ at times leaving her crawling the floor ‰ÛÓ and strained her marriage. The film is also not vested in an upbeat ending. Rather, it powerfully insists on giving a voice to victims whose greatest challenge, apart from their symptoms, is surmounting a world of indifference.

In trying to understand chronic fatigue syndrome, Ms. Brea found other sufferers online and includes some of their stories here ‰ÛÓ a young Englishwoman bedridden for eight years, a Danish girl kept against her will in a psychiatric hospital for three years. Other interviews lightly sketch the history of the medical response to the syndrome, and how utterly insufficient it seems to be. Research money is only a small fraction, the film says, of that for multiple sclerosis, a condition afflicting roughly half as many Americans.

If nothing else, ‰ÛÏUnrest,‰Ûù by Jennifer Brea, demonstrates just how debilitating chronic fatigue syndrome, also known as myalgic encephalomyelitis, can be. Ms. Brea, herself a victim, was a well-traveled Ph.D. student at Harvard who fell ill after a high fever in 2011. Along with exhaustion, she experienced loss of muscle control, the inability to speak coherently, pain, and extreme sensitivity to light and noise. Specialists at first concluded that she was dehydrated or stressed; one even suggested a delayed reaction to some childhood trauma that she might not recall.

This is the second movie in 20 years in which Judi Dench plays Queen Victoria. And this is the second movie in 20 years in which Queen Victoria, played by Judi Dench, has a life-enhancing relationship with a man not of her station. This movie, ‰ÛÏVictoria and Abdul,‰Ûù directed by Stephen Frears from a script by Lee Hall, goes 1997‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏMrs. Brown‰Ûù one better in the Relevant to Contemporary Concerns department by depicting a friendship between the second-longest-reigning monarch of England and an Indian Muslim.

‰ÛÏBased on real events ‰Û_ mostly,‰Ûù reads a text at the movie‰Ûªs opening. Queen Victoria‰Ûªs first encounters with Abdul Karim (Ali Fazal), an Indian functionary sent to Britain to present her with a ceremonial coin, are in comedic scenes that lampoon the pomp of her court. The material is broad, and funny. The Queen is struck by Abdul‰Ûªs bearing and handsomeness, and soon enough is receiving him in private audiences and having him tutor her in Urdu. He becomes her ‰ÛÏmunshi‰Ûù (teacher) and his presence in her life invigorates her. Much to the displeasure of her actual court, including her son and heir ‰ÛÏBertie‰Ûù (a.k.a. Edward VII), played with a beard and fiercely indignant eyebrows by Eddie Izzard.

In the shift from comedy to drama the movie goes wobbly. The narrative of cross-cultural understanding by way of individual affinity is a comforting but ultimately dubious one. The notion of Queen Victoria as the most progressive figure of the Victorian age is also peculiar. But this is a handsomely packaged collection of such notions, and will provide genteel entertainment to those of a mind to swallow them.

Despite their largely successful experiments, Mr. Reade and Mr. Evans express skepticism that the delicacies they‰Ûªve tried could ‰ÛÓ or should ‰ÛÓ be produced on a commercial scale. That issue isn‰Ûªt satisfactorily resolved in 73 minutes, which is just enough time to make you hungry.

The movie follows Ben Reade, a chef, and Josh Evans, a researcher, then both of the Nordic Food Lab in Denmark, as they travel the world to visit cultures where insects are prepared as food. (Roberto Flore, another chef, joins the trip later.) The Nordic lab, a project initiated by Claus Meyer and RenÌ© Redzepi, founders of the foodie polestar Noma, has a mission to explore ‰ÛÏfood diversity and deliciousness.‰Ûù The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has reported that the use of insects as food may have long-term benefits for the global food supply. It also offers cooks new possibilities for tastes and textures. (If you thought using whole animals was trendy, just wait until you try dishes that use multiple developmental stages.)

If an enterprising restaurateur is eager to grill up some insects and make a mint in the West Village, the time has never been riper. ‰ÛÏBugs,‰Ûù an entertaining and eye-opening documentary from Andreas Johnsen, will send moviegoers out with a feeling of culinary adventurousness, eager to sample well-prepared escamoles (ant larvae) or termite queen with mango. (The maggot mousse might be pushing it.)

As they pay visits to Australia, Kenya, Uganda, Mexico and Japan, Mr. Reade and Mr. Evans are effectively M.C.s on the world‰Ûªs weirdest episode of ‰ÛÏIron Chef.‰Ûù (‰ÛÏTo be honest, I would rather a normal Camembert,‰Ûù Mr. Reade confesses after sampling casu marzu, a maggot-infested cheese from Italy.)

Later discoveries included Barry Manilow, whose debut album, Mr. Davis felt, needed a hit; he recommended the song that became ‰ÛÏMandy,‰Ûù which exploded on radio. It was Mr. Davis who masterminded ‰ÛÏSmooth,‰Ûù Carlos Santana‰Ûªs 1990 smash collaboration with Rob Thomas; its album, ‰ÛÏSupernatural,‰Ûù reinvigorated Mr. Santana‰Ûªs career and earned a Grammy.

On camera, Mr. Davis describes how the deaths of his parents while he studied at New York University devastated him. The losses also helped shape his determination. After graduating from Harvard Law, he was working at Columbia Records, at that time largely a bastion of middle-of-the-road acts, when he experienced an epiphany seeing Janis Joplin at the Monterey International Pop Music Festival in 1967. (After he signed her, he says, she offered to sleep with him, but he declined to mix business and pleasure.)

The film‰Ûªs tragic figure is Whitney Houston, whom Mr. Davis had mentored since her adolescence. He adored her, and yet all his formidable power could not save the self-destructive singer, after years of drug use, from herself. She died hours before she was to attend a pre-Grammy party hosted by Mr. Davis.

Chris Perkel‰Ûªs reverent documentary ‰ÛÏClive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives‰Ûù is a valedictory for Mr. Davis, the music executive whose Midas touch with radio hits across genres ‰ÛÓ especially at Arista Records, from 1975-2000 ‰ÛÓ is industry legend. The career of Mr. Davis, now 85, covering the 1960s to the present, is remarkable when you consider his longevity and resilience given pop music‰Ûªs core audience of young listeners. Entertainment luminaries ‰ÛÓ Aretha Franklin, Puff Daddy, Bruce Springsteen, Patti Smith, Alicia Keys and many others ‰ÛÓ attest to his golden ear and marketplace savvy.

For Ms. Wang, who was raised in China, left that country in 2011 and now lives in New York, Dylan‰Ûªs lifestyle represents a distinctly American form of freedom. (He calls it the ‰ÛÏeasiest life you can imagine.‰Ûù) To her family in China, she narrates, ‰ÛÏthe idea that someone would choose to be homeless would be inconceivable.‰Ûù And with a camera in tow, or sometimes in Dylan‰Ûªs hands, she begins to live life his way. (‰ÛÏThis was the first time I ate food from a garbage can,‰Ûù she says in the film.) Dylan has a gift for making friends but seems to begrudge generosity, giving away money or selling food he has received.

His habit of shrugging off good-will changes Ms. Wang‰Ûªs attitude, a boon for anyone wondering whether her methods constitute willful naÌøvetÌ©, particularly with regard to Dylan‰Ûªs acknowledged past substance abuse and present drinking. Is this freedom or addiction? Initially, the film‰Ûªs conceit appears to rest on not acknowledging the difference.

It‰Ûªs unfair to reveal precisely where ‰ÛÏI Am Another You‰Ûù goes, but Ms. Wang delves further into Dylan‰Ûªs past. If by the end she probably still puts too much trust in Dylan‰Ûªs aphorisms, give her credit for recognizing the shortcomings of her footage and correcting course.

The documentary ‰ÛÏI Am Another You‰Ûù poses tricky questions about the relationship between filmmaker and subject, and maybe between filmmaker and audience. It begins when the director, Nanfu Wang (‰ÛÏHooligan Sparrow‰Ûù), meets a young, itinerant homeless man named Dylan in Florida and decides to tag along with him.

Addie‰Ûªs companionship awakens other urges, but ‰ÛÏOur Souls at Night‰Ûù is in no hurry to confirm the hunches of the audience or the suspicions of the town‰Ûªs nosier citizens. (One of these, a blowhard friend of Louis‰Ûªs, is played by Bruce Dern, who once upon a time was Tom Buchanan to Mr. Redford‰Ûªs Jay Gatsby). Since Addie and Louis are already sleeping together, there‰Ûªs no need to rush into anything.

He and Addie are solid, respectable people of a kind who usually show up in movies to be mocked or sentimentalized. The disappointments and satisfactions they have lived through are etched on their faces, which are also the faces of two very famous movie stars ‰ÛÓ Jane Fonda and Robert Redford. Viewers with long memories or heavy TCM habits will recall that 50 years ago they starred as New York newlyweds in ‰ÛÏBarefoot in the Park.‰Ûù In 1979, they reunited, with a touch more denim, in ‰ÛÏThe Electric Horseman.‰Ûù The intervening decades have hardly diminished their charm or their skill, and part of the pleasure of this film, directed by Ritesh Batra (‰ÛÏThe Lunchbox‰Ûù), lies in the rediscovery of what wonderful actors they can be, and how good they are together.

As gentle as a moth‰Ûªs wing, as soft and sweet as the flesh of a marshmallow, ‰ÛÏOur Souls at Night‰Ûù chronicles the blossoming of a December-December romance between two neighbors in the fictional prairie town of Holt, Colo. It begins not with a spark of passion but with a sensible, if unusual, proposal. Addie Moore shows up at Louis Waters‰Ûªs house and asks if he will sleep with her. Addie doesn‰Ûªt mean she wants to have sex with Louis. She wants to slide under the covers next to him, turn off the bedside lamp and chat quietly until slumber arrives, simulating the easy marital intimacy that the two of them, both long widowed, have learned to live without. Louis, startled by the idea, agrees to think about it.

Louis, for his part, doesn‰Ûªt mind his solitude. Mr. Redford, who barely uttered a word in ‰ÛÏAll Is Lost,‰Ûù at first seems prepared to match that feat here, interrupting what seem like monthlong pauses to mutter, sigh and occasionally deliver a complete sentence. He is one of the great minimalists of American cinema, an actor who can dazzle you by opening the tiniest window onto a character‰Ûªs inner life. When Louis meets Addie‰Ûªs young grandson, Jamie (the remarkable Iain Armitage, seen on television in ‰ÛÏBig Little Lies‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏYoung Sheldon‰Ûù), the encounter awakens a long-dormant paternal instinct, and also a streak of boyishness.

‰ÛÏOur Souls at Night,‰Ûù adapted (by Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber) from Kent Haruf‰Ûªs final, posthumously published novel, is too cautious and cozy to be a great movie, or even a very interesting one. The music (by Elliot Goldenthal) telegraphs the emotions too precisely, and Mr. Haruf‰Ûªs wry and subtle plot is mishandled, so that there is both too much dramatic conflict and not quite enough. When Addie and Louis‰Ûªs grown-up children show up ‰ÛÓ played by Matthias Schoenaerts and Judy Greer ‰ÛÓ they drag in some bulky baggage. Each family has a painful event in its past, and each child represents a textbook drawing of the consequences of that pain, rather than a fully embodied, credibly suffering human being.

Luckily, the stars have humanity to spare, and very little left to prove. With her careful diction and a bearing that conveys starchiness and sensuality in perfect, improbable balance, Ms. Fonda turns middle-class maturity into a bewitching form of charisma. Addie‰Ûªs approach to Louis, a man she has never known that well, is driven less by neediness than by a rational understanding of what she needs. She needs to be less alone.

There‰Ûªs something mildly sinister about the interlopers, with their ingratiating smiles, aw-shucks mannerisms and continued refusal to leave. Yet the director elects not to follow that vibration, choosing instead to back away from the story‰Ûªs edgier, more unnerving possibilities in favor of something altogether more soggy and formless.

Consequently, what some may see as an examination of loss and legacy, others will view as a portrait of psychological coercion: overbearing men riding roughshod over the wishes of a grieving woman. That two of those men are dying makes the behavior no less repugnant.

The second feature written and directed by Angus MacLachlan (after  ‰ÛÏGoodbye to All That‰Ûù in 2014), this hermetic tale takes place entirely on a family-owned tobacco farm in North Carolina. Not that we ever feel the sense of expansiveness one might expect from a movie whose plot revolves around the land. Instead, Mr. MacLachlan and his cinematographer, Andrew Reed, frame a majority of scenes ‰ÛÓ even those that take place outdoors ‰ÛÓ in contained, virtually static shots that are of no help in selling the story.
The title is quite the mouthful, but it‰Ûªs not the only thing about ‰ÛÏAbundant Acreage Available‰Ûù that‰Ûªs hard to swallow.

What we do see of the scenery isn‰Ûªt exactly breathtaking as Tracy (Amy Ryan, wonderful) and her Bible-thumping brother, Jesse (Terry Kinney), bury their father‰Ûªs ashes. Jesse‰Ûªs bullying tendencies are clear from their first disagreement; and when the siblings come upon three older adults camped in a field ‰ÛÓ brothers who believe they have a claim to the property ‰ÛÓ the gender dynamics soon overwhelm any other consideration.

Mr. Liman also likes stories about people with secret selves. Maybe it‰Ûªs an interest he picked up from his father, Arthur L. Liman, who was the chief counsel to the Senate committee during its 1987 Iran-contra investigation. The real Mr. Seal may have played a jaw-droppingly outlandish role in that notorious affair, which, among many other byzantine turns, involved the National Security Council funneling aid to the Nicaraguan contras. The scandal encompassed a vast cast of characters that included President Ronald Reagan and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North. A few show up in ‰ÛÏAmerican Made‰Ûù either as fictionalized supporting characters or as themselves, smiling and slinking in archival images.

There are moments when it feels as if Mr. Liman‰Ûªs breakneck pacing is partly an attempt to distract us, to keep us from looking or thinking too hard about the grotesquely corrupt circus parading onscreen. Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs performance often seems similarly calculated. Barry likes to leap before he thinks: ‰ÛÏAll this is legal?‰Ûù he asks, scarcely pausing before plunging into the fray ‰ÛÓ and Mr. Cruise regularly widens his eyes in what seems to be an effort to convey Barry‰Ûªs incredulity. It‰Ûªs dissembling that is about as convincing as the Wolf leering in granny‰Ûªs nightie. In truth, this Barry is just another ugly American, a happy hustler with a what-me-worry smile and a foot planted on another man‰Ûªs throat.

The tagline for ‰ÛÏAmerican Made,‰Ûù a breezily, at times woozily rollicking Tom Cruise vehicle, announces that it is ‰ÛÏbased on a true lie‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ though the movie also asserts that it is based on a true story. But who‰Ûªs quibbling? This is, after all, a Hollywood fantasy starring Mr. Cruise as Barry Seal, a real-life smuggler. An enigma with multiple chins, Mr. Seal was apparently known as El Gordo (the Fat Man), a name he may have picked up while working for a drug cartel, the C.I.A. or the Drug Enforcement Administration.

There‰Ûªs a lot going for ‰ÛÏAmerican Made,‰Ûù which spins like a top and has the visually beguiling, somewhat jaundiced look of a faded old Polaroid. So it‰Ûªs too bad that Mr. Liman himself didn‰Ûªt burrow in here as a filmmaker. The real Mr. Seal has been both the main and side attraction in many articles, books, documentaries and hard-core propaganda flicks, including some hinged on the Conspiratorial Industrial Complex which emerged during the Clinton presidency. Mr. Seal was also the subject of ‰ÛÏDoublecrossed,‰Ûù a 1991 HBO docudrama starring Dennis Hopper (which is vaguely amusing if only because Mr. Hopper played a very different coke smuggler in ‰ÛÏEasy Rider‰Ûù).

It can be hard to keep tabs on the movie‰Ûªs Barry, a pilot who racks up lots of miles while serving different masters. When the story opens, he is flying for T.W.A. and bored out of his evidently simple, rather dangerously restless mind. On the job, he amuses himself by flipping a few switches, jerking the controls and abruptly awakening sleeping passengers. His life takes a wild turn when a shady C.I.A. smiler, Schafer (Domhnall Gleeson), makes Barry an offer to help his country or something. Before long, Barry is cozying up to Pablo Escobar and smuggling cocaine and AK-47s across the Americas. Every so often, he drops into Panama to swap packages with that country‰Ûªs strongman, Manuel Noriega.

This kind of secret world is familiar terrain for the director Doug Liman, who kick-started the ‰ÛÏBourne‰Ûù spy franchise and directed ‰ÛÏFair Game,‰Ûù a fictional take on some real-world intrigue involving Valerie Plame Wilson, a former C.I.A. officer, and her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, a onetime diplomat. ‰ÛÏAmerican Made,‰Ûù in its self-amused tone and skittering rhythms, though, is closer to the thriller ‰ÛÏEdge of Tomorrow,‰Ûù Mr. Liman and Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs movie about a man ‰ÛÓ a wrong-guy, wrong-place type ‰ÛÓ who dies to live another day only to die (repeat). Mr. Liman likes playing with Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs persona, say, by messing up that famous smile, and he clearly likes letting his star strut and glide.

‰ÛÏAmerican Made‰Ûù encourages and earns your laughter, although it also provokes skepticism, particularly in its attempt to portray Barry as a picaresque hero, one of those rogues tumbling and swaggering from adventure to adventure in a world that‰Ûªs more corrupt than they are. After all, it asks, how bad can Barry really be, especially given the company he keeps? He doesn‰Ûªt kill anyone, not exactly, and he‰Ûªs nice to his wife, Lucy (Sarah Wright Olsen), and their kids. A slightly downscale version of Margot Robbie‰Ûªs character in ‰ÛÏThe Wolf of Wall Street,‰Ûù Lucy has a few tangy moments, but she and the kids mostly enhance the visual design, much like the period cars and costumes.

Written by Gary Spinelli, ‰ÛÏAmerican Made‰Ûù goes down easily, especially if you don‰Ûªt let the historical record with its real-world stakes bother you. Mr. Cruise‰Ûªs brisk, ingratiating performance ‰ÛÓ all smiles, hard-charging physicality and beads of sweat ‰ÛÓ does a lot to soften the edges. But Mr. Liman doesn‰Ûªt press Mr. Cruise to dig into the character, and the actor mostly hurdles forward in a movie that never gets around to asking what makes Barry run and why. So Barry just runs and he flies and he flies some more, delivering coke and accumulating suitcases of cash that he buries and stashes in closets. (It‰Ûªs hard not to think that Mr. Cruise signed on to the movie so he could do all his own flying.)

Swaying repeatedly from vibrant seasonal tones to a pearlescent, misty gray, ‰ÛÏAutumn, Autumn‰Ûù has a low-key fretfulness that suggests a darker reading of its ambiguous dual endings. Yet though disappointment and loneliness guide its conversations, the movie isn‰Ûªt bleak; it‰Ûªs a touching and tender commentary on the need to be seen and the desire to be heard.

‰ÛÏAutumn, Autumn,‰Ûù the moving new film from the South Korean writer and director Jang Woo-jin, contains two rather remarkable scenes. In the first, a young man (Woo Ji-hyeon), a little drunk, calls an old friend on the phone and asks him to sing for him. The friend complies with a mournful love song, and the movie seems to hold its breath until the final notes rise into the night air.

Both scenes unfold in the same geographical location ‰ÛÓ Chuncheon, a resort town on the banks of a man-made lake ‰ÛÓ but that‰Ûªs their only obvious commonality. Using a bisected structure and extraordinary patience, Mr. Jang presents two distinct narrative arcs, following the young man for the first half and the couple for the second. Yet the ghosts of the past, of lost connections and missed opportunities, haunt both sections, binding the characters with a single, sorrowful skein.

The second shows an older couple (Yang Heung-ju and Lee Se-rang) enjoying a late-afternoon meal in a modest restaurant. For more than 10 minutes, we listen to them hesitantly converse while the camera barely moves. The natural light around them, however, shifts back and forth from golden to gloomy in seeming accord with their waxing and waning intimacy.

One of many recent works to study post-traumatic stress (including the documentary ‰ÛÏThank You for Your Service‰Ûù and the novel ‰ÛÏPreparation for the Next Life,‰Ûù which both focused almost exclusively on men), ‰ÛÏBlood Stripe‰Ûù refuses to moralize or explain itself. That could seem like either a cryptic decision or an admirable stance. More than likely, it‰Ûªs a good bit of both.

Those words, uttered by a former Marine known as Sarge, are enough to generate a gasp in ‰ÛÏBlood Stripe.‰Ûù Sarge is talking about how long she‰Ûªll have to wait to get mental health treatment at a V.A. hospital. Based on what we‰Ûªve seen, she may not make it another week, let alone four months.

There‰Ûªs not much more plot. This drama, written by Ms. Nowlin and her husband, Remy Auberjonois, who also directed, centers on Sarge‰Ûªs inner struggles. Other than a few references to her combat service and to a physical injury she sustained, the script relies on subtext and Ms. Nowlin‰Ûªs expressions to convey her condition. She‰Ûªs up to the task; even in the many silent moments, she‰Ûªs compelling.

Still, while this worthy film sidesteps clichÌ©s ‰ÛÓ there are no horrid flashbacks or emotional speeches ‰ÛÓ its spareness occasionally feels planned rather than spontaneous. After a powerful first half, later scenes offer diminishing returns.

Since returning from tours in Iraq and Afghanistan, Sarge (Kate Nowlin) swings between confusion and rage. After losing control at her coming-home party (a scene no less tense for being inevitable), she leaves her husband to stay at a secluded campground by a Minnesota lake. There she works nearly nonstop, or exercises to exhaustion, or drinks herself into a stupor to keep her demons at bay.
‰ÛÏA hundred twenty-nine days.‰Ûù

The pair seem close, but their relationship is tumultuous. Millie and Emma get on each other‰Ûªs nerves and in each other‰Ûªs business. Their relationship is so believable, and feels so personal, that at the end, when their grandmother (Shelley Long) waxes on about sisterly love, it feels too sentimental.

As with many siblings, the sisters at the center of Morgan Dameron‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDifferent Flowers‰Ûù fit together like a pair of mismatched socks. Millie (Emma Bell) is the seemingly put-together grown-up about to marry her longtime sweetheart (Sterling Knight). Her sister, Emma (Hope Lauren), is more of a wild child. But when Millie decides to become a runaway bride on her wedding day, Emma is the perfect match to sneak her out of the church.

In her directing and screenwriting debut, Ms. Dameron steps far away from the ‰ÛÏStar Wars‰Ûù universe, where she worked as an assistant to J.J. Abrams and lent her surname to the character Oscar Isaac plays in ‰ÛÏThe Force Awakens.‰Ûù For her Midwestern-set story, Ms. Dameron uses direct shots to give the cinematography a plain-spoken feel. Several scenes have a warm, rosy tinge to them, even during the sisters‰Ûª meanest blowups, as if to assure the audience that, for these two, there will always be a reconciliation.

The film‰Ûªs last third toggles, somewhat awkwardly, between the shows and clips from the postseason. The music‰Ûªs great, the baseball ‰Û_ well, we know the outcome; what will the Cubs do for an encore? With the team again back in the playoffs, the cry is now ‰ÛÏLet‰Ûªs win two.‰Ûù

Among the team‰Ûªs most exultant fans was Eddie Vedder, the frontman for Pearl Jam. The band may be synonymous with Seattle and the grunge-rock scene there that spawned it, but Mr. Vedder was born and raised in suburban Chicago, and is devoted to the Cubs. In 2008, he even wrote ‰ÛÏAll the Way‰Ûù for the club.

Directed by Danny Clinch, ‰ÛÏLet‰Ûªs Play Two‰Ûù provides neither as complete a Pearl Jam concert as ‰ÛÏTouring Band 2000‰Ûù nor as illuminating a band history as Cameron Crowe‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPearl Jam Twenty.‰Ûù But it shares a side of Mr. Vedder his fans will enjoy: the baseball aficionado who fills out a scorecard and treats Wrigley sod as holy ground. A rehearsal with other band members ‰ÛÓ the guitarists Stone Gossard and Mike McCready, the bassist Jeff Ament and the drummer Matt Cameron ‰ÛÓ atop Murphy‰Ûªs Bleachers, across from the ballpark, recalls the Beatles‰Ûª rooftop concert, and their Wrigley performances of hits like ‰ÛÏCorduroy,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏJeremy‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏAlive‰Ûù demonstrate Pearl Jam remains as potent as ever.

‰ÛÏLet‰Ûªs Play Two: Pearl Jam Live at Wrigley Field‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ the title was a favorite expression of the beloved Cubs shortstop Ernie Banks ‰ÛÓ is a blend of concert film and sports diary, chronicling Pearl Jam‰Ûªs two August shows at Wrigley during the 2016 season, then capturing highlights of the team‰Ûªs championship run.
After a 108-year drought, the Chicago Cubs finally won the World Series last year. Maybe you heard.

Justin Long is no stranger to the rom-com trenches: In ‰ÛÏA Case of You,‰Ûù he wooed Evan Rachel Wood, and in ‰ÛÏGoing the Distance,‰Ûù he courted Drew Barrymore. Now in the disjointed ‰ÛÏLiterally, Right Before Aaron,‰Ûù Mr. Long romances, or tries to re-romance, Cobie Smulders. Ms. Smulders plays Allison, who went out with Adam (Mr. Long) for years before they broke up. Now she has invited him to her wedding to Aaron (Ryan Hansen), and Adam is ambivalent about it at best, unhinged at worst. He decides to attend and win her back.

The problem here is Mr. Long‰Ûªs Adam, a twitchy knot of tics and self-pity. He invites our sympathy ‰ÛÓ especially when contrasted with the smarmy Aaron ‰ÛÓ but doesn‰Ûªt really deserve it. We never quite discover why Allison and Adam separated, though there is a fleeting reference to Adam‰Ûªs past Vicodin use. And by the time he spectacularly disrupts the reception, any emotional capital the viewer has invested is forfeit. Even a seeming twist on ‰ÛÏThe Graduate‰Ûù at the climax can‰Ûªt salvage the movie.

This movie ‰ÛÓ written, directed and edited by the actor Ryan Eggold (‰ÛÏThe Blacklist‰Ûù) and expanding on his 2011 short film of the same name ‰ÛÓ attempts to subvert genre expectations. To its credit, it offers top-notch supporting talent: John Cho plays Adam‰Ûªs best friend; Kristen Schaal portrays Adam‰Ûªs nervous date; and Luis GuzmÌÁn is a blue-collar worker from whom Adam receives advice and swigs of Champagne. Lea Thompson and Dana Delany are wise and luminous representatives of an older generation. And Ms. Smulders conveys notes of grace, which is no small feat given her underwritten character.

Then, one day, he falls down, and the film subtly shifts from a quietly comical character study to a delicate reflection on loneliness and mortality. As Lucky bonds with a fellow World War II veteran and, in one lovely scene, slides into an impromptu song at a child‰Ûªs birthday party, the movie is more intent on measuring the weight of a life than contemplating death. So when our cranky hero, a lifelong atheist, declares that there is no soul, it seems an extraordinary line to give an actor who spent his entire career proving otherwise.

Nothing much happens in ‰ÛÏLucky,‰Ûù and then everything does. That doesn‰Ûªt mean this leisurely portrait of its title character, a cantankerous old coot (Harry Dean Stanton, in one of his last roles), is any more eventful at the end than at the beginning. Rather, the accumulation of spot-on performances and long-familiar faces, small-town routines and dusty-worn locations, finally coalesces into a picture that‰Ûªs greater than the sum of its oft-clichÌ©d parts.

Maudlin and meandering, this first feature by the actor John Carroll Lynch could have sprouted organically from the compost of its star‰Ûªs back catalog. (The script, by Logan Sparks and Drago Sumonja, was written as an almost biographical celebration of Mr. Stanton‰Ûªs life.) We‰Ûªve seen him stride through arid desert towns like this before, though now, as Lucky, his gait is more fragile if no less purposeful. Following the same daily routine ‰ÛÓ an unvarying trek from home to diner to bodega to bar ‰ÛÓ Lucky would rather watch game shows than engage in small talk. The townsfolk (warmly played by David Lynch and Ed Begley, Jr., among others) don‰Ûªt seem to mind, and are even quite fond of him, in the way of longtime owners of a rather surly pet.

The movie is ‰ÛÏMark Felt ‰ÛÓ the Man Who Brought Down the White House,‰Ûù and the headlines from which it was ripped are more than four decades old. The title sounds like a category error, since the White House, as of this writing, is still standing. But Mark Felt, though almost nobody knew back in the ‰Ûª70s, was undoubtedly instrumental in ending the presidency of Richard M. Nixon. The associate director of the F.B.I. at the time of the Watergate burglary, Felt entered the annals of Nixon-era scandal as Deep Throat, a pseudonym bestowed by the Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward.

Felt, who didn‰Ûªt much like the name, identified himself as Mr. Woodward‰Ûªs source in 2005. The memoir he published before his death in 2008 has been turned, by the writer and director Peter Landesman, a former journalist, into a hectic, intermittently intriguing and accidentally timely procedural thriller, with Mr. Neeson in the title role. His face as sharp as the blade of a hatchet, his brow creased with his weariness and his eyes ablaze with indignation, Mr. Neeson is a mighty presence on a small, cramped stage.

‰ÛÏMark Felt‰Ûù is a sharp portrait set against a blurry background, a history lesson that won‰Ûªt help you on the test. It is possible to savor the crags and shadows of Mr. Neeson‰Ûªs performance without quite grasping why Mr. Landesman thinks the story is worthy of such somber, serious and sustained attention. Both the internal politics of the F.B.I. in the aftermath of J. Edgar Hoover‰Ûªs death and the larger political and social dramas of the late ‰Ûª60s and early ‰Ûª70s are invoked, but neither the national nor the institutional stakes are illuminated with sufficient clarity or force.

Even for die-hard Watergate nerds, the movie can be a tough slog. The main conflict is between Felt and his new boss, L. Patrick Gray (Marton Csokas), who Felt comes to believe is functioning as Nixon‰Ûªs mole in the F.B.I., and who also wants to limit the bureau‰Ûªs Watergate inquiries. (Gray is also the man who took the job Felt thought should have been his, and wounded pride may be among his motives.) Meanwhile, on the home front, Felt and his long-suffering, heavy-drinking wife, Audrey (Diane Lane), worry about their daughter, who has vanished into the mists of the counterculture.
