She casually rattles off the names of dead friends (‰ÛÏtoo many to count‰Ûù). Boonie also has a boyfriend, which leads to complications that shouldn‰Ûªt be spoiled.

The filming period coincided with the shooting death of the unarmed black teenager Michael Brown in nearby Ferguson, Mo., in 2014, and a grand jury‰Ûªs decision not to indict Darren Wilson, the officer who shot him. The protests are mainly a backdrop to Boonie‰Ûªs story, though. While the film ends at a logical stopping point, it feels incomplete. It probably could have used a few more years of filming.

The movie begins with Daje Shelton, known as Boonie, then 17, visiting a courtroom after a school fight. The judge, Jimmie M. Edwards, who opened the academy, tells her that he will decide whether to lock her up. The alternative school is her last option for getting a high school diploma, he says. She won‰Ûªt be able to attend other public schools in Missouri.

‰ÛÏFor Ahkeem,‰Ûù a documentary directed by Jeremy S. Levine and Landon Van Soest, grew out of a People magazine article from 2011 about the Innovative Concept Academy, an alternative school in St. Louis designed to rehabilitate teenagers who might otherwise be incarcerated. The film follows one such student over about two years.

Born in 1895, the Chickasaw performer Te Ata came of age at a time when the United States prohibited public displays of Native American culture. Yet despite laws dictating that her indigenous performances remain private, Te Ata eventually acted and danced on Broadway and for President Franklin D. Roosevelt‰Ûªs White House. She became an advocate, through her own artistic excellence, for the inherent dignity that the federal government denied American Indians ‰ÛÓ fittingly, her stage name means ‰ÛÏbearer of the morning.‰Ûù Te Ata‰Ûªs life story is now the subject of Nathan Frankowski‰Ûªs film ‰ÛÏTe Ata,‰Ûù which goes for the sweep of an epic despite a tight budget.

Produced by Chickasaw Nation Productions, ‰ÛÏTe Ata‰Ûù valorizes this little-known hero, introducing elements of myth like a wandering white wolf to mark Te Ata‰Ûªs life as its own Chickasaw legend. The film sprawls from the Oklahoma plains to old New York, murkily conveying the passage of time and her rising social status. But the movie‰Ûªs driving force is its mythic performance scenes, which are choreographed, sung and acted with clear, balletic conviction by the film‰Ûªs star, Q‰Ûªorianka Kilcher, who collaborated with Chickasaw researchers and advisers. In the film‰Ûªs most compelling parallel, just as Te Ata grew to be a voice for American Indians who lacked representation, Ms. Kilcher offers her star power on behalf of the Chickasaw.

As depicted, Te Ata, who died in 1995 at the age of 99, grew up as Mary Frances Thompson in the Indian Territory that later became Oklahoma. She devoted her life to relaying the Chickasaw legends she had learned in childhood, in addition to the stories that were shared with her by the diverse American Indian audiences she met on tour.
Sad, tender and quietly moving, ‰ÛÏThe Departure‰Ûù never says more than it needs to, much like its subject, a Buddhist priest who counsels those contemplating suicide.

The men and women here convey deep torment and helplessness. Mr. Nemoto occasionally asks questions, gives advice or offers reasons to live. But more often he listens, and his face registers both empathy for them and sometimes despair at his own shortcomings. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm sorry,‰Ûù he says softly to one troubled woman as he looks away. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm not being much help, am I?‰Ûù

His nearness to their pain takes a toll. Mr. Nemoto‰Ûªs health declines as the unceasing calls and emails he receives wear on him. ‰ÛÏI take on so much of their suffering when I‰Ûªm counseling,‰Ûù he says. ‰ÛÏI can never show them how draining is it.‰Ûù

The documentary, directed by Lana Wilson, follows Ittetsu Nemoto, who after a troubled adolescence became a monk, then a priest, in Japan. He settled with his wife, child and mother at a temple in Gifu prefecture where he spends nearly all his time trying to dissuade those in danger of taking their own lives.

Ms. Wilson resists any urge to overexplain the priest‰Ûªs work or the people he encounters. Instead, she captures their forlorn expressions and records their searching questions. (Viewers seeking additional background on Mr. Nemoto can find it in an excellent article from The New Yorker by Larissa MacFarquhar, which inspired this film.) Nathan Michel‰Ûªs score is haunting.

Like a haiku, ‰ÛÏThe Departure‰Ûù weighs its words carefully. But silences, too, play a vital role here. During its quiet moments, we can only watch this priest comfort the despaired and hope that he succeeds.
Jackie Chan built a career on playing cheerful martial-arts warriors. In his new movie, ‰ÛÏThe Foreigner,‰Ûù which he also helped produce, he loses his joie de vivre soon after the opening credits.

What‰Ûªs that, you ask? ‰ÛÏAuthentic I.R.A.?‰Ûù Why, yes, apparently. In this film‰Ûªs convoluted scenario, jam-packed with morally bankrupt people doing ugly things to one another, a Northern Irish faction is making an aggressive comeback. The movie, directed by Martin Campbell, is based on a novel called ‰ÛÏThe Chinaman,‰Ûù by Stephen Leather, whose I.R.A.-heavy plot may have made sense when it was written in 1992. This boneheaded update practically defines the term scab picking.

But back to the action: Cryptically, and implacably, demanding names of the perpetrators, Quon pursues Hennessy to his country home and makes like a senior-citizen Rambo in the woods. Mr. Chan is in his early 60s, and he doesn‰Ûªt deliver the action pizazz here that he used to. Nor, frankly, does he summon enough gravitas to be persuasive in the role of a grief-maddened father. For what it‰Ûªs worth, Mr. Brosnan, as Quon‰Ûªs nemesis, sells the angry-all-the-time requirement for his character.

Here he plays a single father named Quon, who, as the movie opens, is seen dropping off his daughter at a boutique in London so she can buy a dress for a dance. Then a terrorist bombing blows the block to smithereens and turns Quon into an aspiring avenger. After facing roadblocks with the local authorities, he trains his sights on Liam Hennessy (Pierce Brosnan), an Irish political operative who, Quon is convinced, knows something about the ‰ÛÏauthentic I.R.A.‰Ûù that is claiming responsibility for the bombing.

If you‰Ûªve ever watched an episode of the A&E television show ‰ÛÏHoarders,‰Ûù you‰Ûªve probably seen a residence more nightmarish in its squalor than the Brooklyn home of Avraham and Shraga, twin brothers forced by the squawking of an enraged tenant, among other things, to clean house, in the documentary ‰ÛÏThy Father‰Ûªs Chair.‰Ûù
‰ÛÏIt has to be done,‰Ûù sighs the shamed resident, taking solace in a glass of wine. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm addicted to the alcohol,‰Ûù he explains.

When a company called Home Clean Home comes in and takes action, the head of the crew begins to work not just as a sanitation manager but as a therapist to the brothers. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm sad to see you like this,‰Ûù the Home Clean Home man (he‰Ûªs never named) says to one twin after a particularly brutal sweep has been executed in one section of the house.

Nevertheless, their home is an unholy mess, in several senses of the term. Avraham and Shraga inherited the building from their parents. Despite the fact that they look to be of a pretty advanced age themselves, the fellows still seem in need of a parent of sorts.

The movie, directed by Antonio Tibaldi and Alex Lora, is quiet and quietly moving and quite different from ‰ÛÏHoarders‰Ûù in its steady pace and poetic vÌ©ritÌ© style. It‰Ûªs a story of unlikely friendship ‰ÛÓ not to mention a potentially very good promotional tool for Home Clean Home, which does a thorough and, more to the point, exquisitely sensitive job.

Tom‰Ûªs eureka moment comes when he visits California. Police officers raid a party, appearing as if they‰Ûªre about to arrest the gay revelers. False alarm: ‰ÛÏWe‰Ûªre looking for a suspect who just robbed a mini mart down on Sunset,‰Ûù one officer says.

A biopic can take any life, no matter how transgressive or interesting, and reduce it to check marks on a list. In ‰ÛÏTom of Finland,‰Ûù a primarily Finnish-language feature from Dome Karukoski, the biography is that of Touko Laaksonen (Pekka Strang), the Finnish advertising designer who, under the name Tom of Finland, published drawings of hyper-muscular, well-endowed men and became famous for expanding perceptions on the portrayal of gay life in art.

While Mr. Laaksonen devoted his life (1920-91) to challenging conventions, the film is committed to honoring them. The movie traces Mr. Laaksonen‰Ûªs service in World War II, his experience with public-park cruising and discrimination, and his early illustrations of aggrandized masculinity. (He says the pictures would be easier to publish in the Vatican than in Finland, where homosexuality was outlawed at the time.) His sister (Jessica Grabowsky), a fellow artist, suspicious of his sexuality, dares him to kiss a woman in a game of truth-or-dare.

If the film emphasizes the power that Mr. Laaksonen‰Ûªs drawings held for the gay community, it‰Ûªs less interested in his reception as a boundary-breaking artist, a kindred spirit to the filmmaker Kenneth Anger, among others. For those seeking more information, the closing credits actually direct viewers to a website.

Mr. Garrel‰Ûªs work has a unique aesthetic that today‰Ûªs American cinephiles seem to be hungry for; this movie‰Ûªs long-overdue release here is part of a longer retrospective at the Metrograph. One reason Mr. Garrel‰Ûªs earlier work has been hard to see in this country is that his early career was more or less as an underground filmmaker ‰ÛÓ one of the inspirations he cited during a recent New York appearance is Andy Warhol, whom he met through Nico. ‰ÛÏL‰ÛªEnfant Secret‰Ûù forms a kind of bridge between his more abstract pictures and the narratives of the ‰Ûª80s and beyond, extending to his latest movie, ‰ÛÏLover for a Day,‰Ûù which was seen at the New York Film Festival and will have a theatrical run here next year.

The peculiar dark magic of ‰ÛÏL‰ÛªEnfant Secret,‰Ûù a 1979 film by Philippe Garrel only now seeing theatrical release in the United States, begins with its models. ‰ÛÏModels‰Ûù was the term the monumental French filmmaker Robert Bresson used for the men and women he cast in his films; he believed acting was an art best reserved for the theater, so he recruited faces and bodies he felt could carry his intents, and instructed them to enact precise physical movements, but not to emote.

Most sad stories of love in our culture express disappointed romanticism. In the world of Mr. Garrel, whose whole work can be seen as an inquiry into the nature of love, romanticism is crushed, slowly and inexorably, yet refuses to die fully. The movie‰Ûªs few moments of respite from this process are provided through brief shots of the couple walking hand in hand with Swann. Far longer are the shots of them on a park bench in the pouring rain, or sitting on a mattress on an apartment floor, framed by dingy off-white walls.

Mr. Garrel, a filmmaker since his teens, is looser and more expansive in his approach. Nevertheless, in this film he cast two former Bresson ‰ÛÏmodels,‰Ûù Anne Wiazemsky and Henri de Maublanc, as the lovers Elie and Jean Baptiste. The secret child of the title is, in a sense, the film itself, one in which, according to Mr. Garrel, he ‰ÛÏreturned to autobiography‰Ûù after a series of experimental features.

But the movie does feature a little boy named Swann who belongs to Elie. The adorable blond moppet, she tells Jean-Baptiste, is the son of a film actor who refuses to acknowledge paternity, even though his mother is raising the child. It reflects Mr. Garrel‰Ûªs own long love affair with the musical artist Nico, who had a child she said was the son of the French film star Alain Delon. He never acknowledged the boy, but his parents largely raised the child in his early years.

Ms. Wiazemsky and Mr. de Maublanc maintain a kind of Bressonian passivity in enacting the dank, entropic spiral that sucks their characters ever downward. They alternately try to maintain, or violently break away from, their intimacy. Mr. Garrel‰Ûªs approach to narrative here is deliberately provisional; he presents a number of story modules which fragmentedly depict Jean-Baptiste‰Ûªs mental breakdown, Elie‰Ûªs mourning over the death of her mother and the couple‰Ûªs flirtations with potential new lovers and dangerous drugs.

‰ÛÏL‰ÛªEnfant Secret‰Ûù is shot in a black and white that is frequently out of focus, by a camera that‰Ûªs intentionally not entirely steady. Some shots are reiterated in the ultra-grainy form in which they might have been viewed as rushes, or through a Moviola. Part of Mr. Garrel‰Ûªs mastery is his ability to make expressive use of what would constitute dire technical flaws in other people‰Ûªs films. The loose ends, the ragged edges, the awkward cuts: Here they‰Ûªre like the angry low-fi communication of a postpunk song, desperate in its constricted ability to evoke the ineffable.

At its most fun, ‰ÛÏThe Paris Opera‰Ûù functions as a stealth backstage chronicle, notably when the man singing the part of Hans Sachs in Wagner‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDie Meistersinger von NÌ_rnberg‰Ûù calls in sick, setting off a scramble to find a last-minute understudy somewhere in Europe. The baritone Michael Kupfer-Radecky assumes the task with humor as bountiful as his voice.

Covering a wider swatch of the institution more swiftly, ‰ÛÏThe Paris Opera‰Ûù feels at once sprawling and insufficiently patient. Even so, it spans a pivotal stretch: The filmmaker, Jean-StÌ©phane Bron, captured the Paris Opera while it adjusted to the leadership of a new director, StÌ©phane Lissner, who took over in 2014 and is shown presiding over a period that included the November 2015 terrorist attacks in Paris.

The film primarily deals with the institution‰Ûªs daily challenges, from labor issues to the appropriate cost of a ticket. Mr. Lissner expresses frustration as Benjamin Millepied decides whether to resign as the director of dance after a little more than a year in that position. (Mr. Millepied ultimately left, although the causes of his departure receive superficial treatment.)

The documentary ‰ÛÏThe Paris Opera‰Ûù risks redundancy. After all, Frederick Wiseman, one of nonfiction cinema‰Ûªs masters, already explored the institution‰Ûªs ballet company in ‰ÛÏLa Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet‰Ûù (2009). ‰ÛÏThe Paris Opera,‰Ûù which employs similar observational methods, demonstrates the invisibility of Mr. Wiseman‰Ûªs technique ‰ÛÓ his genius for drawing out his themes from long scenes of meetings and performances.

Jane Goodall‰Ûªs observations of chimpanzees in the wild challenged conventional wisdom about what made humans exceptional. Brett Morgen‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏJane,‰Ûù which tells Ms. Goodall‰Ûªs story largely through footage of her expeditions, is such an absorbing account of her experiences at a reserve in what is now Tanzania that you may not pause to think about how its imagery was captured.
‰ÛÏJane‰Ûù will delight those familiar with Ms. Goodall and provide a vibrant introduction for newcomers.

His footage has appeared before, notably in the 1965 National Geographic documentary ‰ÛÏMiss Goodall and the Wild Chimpanzees,‰Ûù narrated by Orson Welles. But Mr. Morgen‰Ûªs film draws on more than 100 rediscovered hours from National Geographic‰Ûªs archives. The abundant raw material allows Mr. Morgen to construct the impression of a complete narrative arc, and to show the tedious work of gaining the trust of the chimps and collecting data in fast forward, conveying the excitement of scientific discovery with adventure-movie momentum.

As an opening title card explains, most of ‰ÛÏJane‰Ûù comes from 16-millimeter film shot by Hugo van Lawick, the renowned wildlife photographer who joined Ms. Goodall on her travels and eventually became her first husband.

If Ms. Goodall ‰ÛÓ who was 26 and had no scientific degree when she first ventured into the forest, hoping to gain acceptance from chimpanzees inclined to run from her ‰ÛÓ was mostly exploring on her own, who set up the camera for that incredible shot of her climbing? How is it that the animals are so calm in the presence of moviemaking tools?

Such editing-suite sleights of hand may displease purists, and so will an insistent score by Philip Glass, whose melodious montage glue has become something of a documentary clichÌ©. But the flip side of such freehandedness is that ‰ÛÏJane,‰Ûù like Mr. Morgen‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏChicago 10‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Kid Stays in the Picture‰Ûù (which he directed with Nanette Burstein), is involving and immediate. He fashions a firsthand account of what Ms. Goodall learned about the chimps‰Ûª capacity for toolmaking, nurturing and cruelty, and what they taught her when she became a parent herself.

Ms. Goodall, who is seen in a fresh interview with Mr. Morgen and heard in excerpts from an audio version of one of her books, narrates her efforts to make contact with the chimps. The footage has been edited in a way that is not strictly faithful to chronology but complements the storytelling. (Even the visuals accompanying the tale of her initial months were filmed later, once Mr. van Lawick had arrived.) Because the archival footage lacked sound, the natural noises ‰ÛÓ chimp grunts and bird chirps ‰ÛÓ have been created, seamlessly, from separate recordings made in the Gombe forest that Ms. Goodall once explored.

The Slovenian band Laibach is best appreciated not as a music group but as a deliberately confounding aesthetic construct. Its publicity photos, the personas of band members and their music videos have, since the group‰Ûªs 1980s beginnings, borrowed from the imagery and style of 20th-century totalitarian regimes. But their music never matched the provocation of their presentation. The critic Robert Christgau once commented: ‰ÛÏNot fascists ‰ÛÓ in fact, probably antifascists. That‰Ûªs something.‰Ûù

The Norwegian filmmaker Morten Traavik, who has directed a number of Laibach videos, arranged for the group to perform in Pyongyang, North Korea, in 2015 as part of wide-ranging official commemorations of the anniversary of Korean liberation from Japanese colonial rule in 1945. Mr. Traavik has extensive experience dealing with the country‰Ûªs bureaucracy. Still, ‰ÛÏLiberation Day,‰Ûù a documentary of preparations for the concert directed by Mr. Traavik and Ugis Olte, is a consistently understated chronicle of Westerners who are very carefully playing with fire. In one scene, some of the band‰Ûªs technicians complain about the lack of a sound check, as a half-dozen North Korean censors mill about the empty hall. ‰ÛÏIt is a sound check,‰Ûù another crew member insists. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs not; it‰Ûªs an exam,‰Ûù an exasperated roadie grumbles back.

Laibach‰Ûªs music these days is kitschy Europop with Count-Draculaesque vocal croaks up front, courtesy of the singer Milan Fras. The movie is very careful not to reveal the inner workings of the band, but several breadcrumblike clues are dropped by Ivan Novak, a member from early days who now works behind the scenes. But this withholding, intended to maintain Laibach‰Ûªs mystique, contravenes the ostensible documentary function of the movie.

At 3, Izak Szewelewicz was sent by his mother, Aida, to Israel from Bergen-Belsen to be raised by foster parents. ‰ÛÏIt was the best I could do,‰Ûù she says simply when interviewed. Aida herself immigrated to Canada and would visit Izak on rare occasions. But she never told him that he had a younger brother, or that his father had taken the brother but that she didn‰Ûªt know where. Izak learned of this when he was 67, in 2013. The Schwarzes, Izak‰Ûªs nephews, assisted him while filming this unfolding account.

With the help of investigators and archives in Europe, Canada and Israel, Izak meets his brother, Shepsel, who is blind and living in Winnipeg. But the teary reunion and Shepsel‰Ûªs first nervous meeting with Aida are just the start. As Izak and Shepsel try to assemble their family history, questions abound. Friends of Aida recount bits of background she had shared. At 89, though, Aida remains evasive: She doesn‰Ûªt recall that man with her and the boys in that Bergen-Belsen photo; she‰Ûªs fuzzy on why she moved to Canada without Shepsel and his father. The film is called ‰ÛÏAida‰Ûªs Secrets‰Ûù for good reason.

Directed by Alon and Shaul Schwarz, ‰ÛÏAida‰Ûªs Secrets‰Ûù chronicles one man‰Ûªs late-in-life search for his brother, from whom he was separated as a toddler at the Bergen-Belsen displaced persons camp after World War II. But the remarkable tale it tells ‰ÛÓ of a family split up and dispersed to different continents, and the detective work required to figure out what had happened ‰ÛÓ turns this documentary into a fascinating mystery of reshuffled identities. In this time of mass displacement across the globe, it is a stark reminder of how traumatic the refugee experience often is.

You could say that their relationship is the film‰Ûªs main extra-political concern, since Sean and Nathan are the characters whose intimate lives it follows in most detail. But of course the point of ‰ÛÏBPM,‰Ûù and of the movement and moment it reconstructs, is that the personal and political passions can‰Ûªt be easily disentangled. This is not so much argued as felt. The erotic scenes are dialectical as well as hot; the meetings have a wanton, feverish energy. The air is heady with abstraction and carnality. It‰Ûªs not a French movie for nothing. (Though it does serve as a fitting fictional companion piece to ‰ÛÏHow to Survive a Plague,‰Ûù David France‰Ûªs magnificent documentary history of Act Up in America.)

In the long planning sessions that constitute most of the film‰Ûªs action, the participants are not much nicer to one another. An early scene sets out rules and procedure ‰ÛÓ finger snaps instead of applause; no debating in the designated smoking area ‰ÛÓ which are subsequently tested and flouted. Though everyone is committed to the same cause, ferocious quarrels about theoretical and practical issues lead to shouting matches and episodes of lacerating humiliation.

The young French AIDS activists ‰ÛÓ members of the Paris chapter of Act Up ‰ÛÓ whose meetings, tactics and love affairs fill the dense, absorbing 140 minutes of ‰ÛÏBPM‰Ûù are outspoken in their advocacy of the marginalized. They confront their adversaries with a litany of stigmatized populations ‰ÛÓ gays, drug users, prostitutes ‰ÛÓ whose dignity they are pledged to defend. The group‰Ûªs language is confrontational and its tactics uncompromising, in ways that anyone aware of Act Up in its fierce heyday will remember. Balloons full of fake blood are hurled at government officials and pharmaceutical executives. Meetings and conferences are disrupted. Demonstrators lie down in the street like corpses.

‰ÛÏBPM‰Ûù takes a similar approach. When the group is together working through the items on its agenda, the camera is more participant than observer, and it turns a gathering of individuals into a complex collective organism. You see how people with different ideas and temperaments ‰ÛÓ as well as different experiences with the disease that brings them together ‰ÛÓ coalesce into something with a will of its own, expressive of but distinct from theirs. And you also observe the way members of that composite self regain their particularity, changed by their encounter with one another but still very much themselves.

The passion in the after-hours classroom where strategy is discussed and actions orchestrated can hardly be contained within its walls. Friendships form and fracture; rivalries percolate. Sex happens, too. In the case of Sean (Nahuel PÌ©rez Biscayart) and Nathan (Arnaud Valois), political solidarity, personal sympathy and sexual attraction deepen into love.

In the first decade of this century, Mr. Campillo worked as a screenwriter on three films with Laurent Cantet: ‰ÛÏTime Out,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏHeading South‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Class.‰Ûù (He also worked on Mr. Cantet‰Ûªs latest film, ‰ÛÏThe Workshop.‰Ûù) ‰ÛÏThe Class‰Ûù in particular, which chronicled the life of a teacher in a working-class French public school (and won a surprising Palme d‰ÛªOr in Cannes), was exquisitely attuned to the emotional nuances of institutional procedure. It felt like a documentary in its attention to routine and like a melodrama in the way it galvanized currents of feeling.

All of this happened a long time ago, of course, but in spite of its historical specificity, ‰ÛÏBPM‰Ûù never feels like a bulletin from the past. Its immediacy comes in part from the brisk naturalism of the performances and the nimbleness and fluidity of the editing. The characters are so vivid, so real, so familiar that it‰Ûªs impossible to think of their struggles ‰ÛÓ and in some cases their deaths ‰ÛÓ as unfolding in anything but the present tense. And even though some of the battles their real-life counterparts fought have been at least partly won, their anger feels urgent and unassuaged. They were fighting for their lives, and also forging a template of resistance.

It is said of one of the characters in Robin Campillo‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBPM (Beats Per Minute)‰Ûù that ‰ÛÏhe lived his politics in the first person.‰Ûù Even in translation and even in a movie set a quarter-century in the past, this suggestive phrase, which is part of a eulogy, cannot fail to resonate. The words, and the passionate, uncompromising sentiment behind them, offer an implicit rebuttal to the currently fashionable critique of ‰ÛÏidentity politics,‰Ûù a phrase that seeks to trivialize struggles that are, for the people who practice such politics, a matter of life and death.

Mr. Korem keeps a reverent distance from his subject, as if not to spoil the magic. The director is either too polite or too timid to push Mr. Turner to reveal more details than he‰Ûªs comfortable sharing. Such a dynamic personality as Mr. Turner‰Ûªs could use a more dynamic documentary to illuminate it. As it is, ‰ÛÏDealt‰Ûù remains a pleasing ‰ÛÓ if inoffensive ‰ÛÓ portrait.

The card magician Richard Turner reveals that he has more than just a few tricks up his sleeve in Luke Korem‰Ûªs captivating documentary ‰ÛÏDealt.‰Ûù Mr. Turner‰Ûªs magic prowess lies in his nimble hands that manipulate any deck of cards. But behind the facade of a self-assured showman is the secret Mr. Turner tries to keep to himself: He‰Ûªs blind.

As confident as he appears when shuffling a deck of cards, Mr. Turner remains at odds with his blindness. In a few TV appearances, awkward moments arise when the host clumsily refers to Mr. Turner‰Ûªs disability before he can illustrate his strength as an illusionist. In candid interviews, he‰Ûªs open about his discomfort around strangers showering him with sympathy and his attempts to hide his blindness in public by refusing to use a cane or a guide dog.

Mr. Turner, 63, had rebelled in his youth against the grim prognosis that he would one day lose his eyesight. From his love of TV westerns, he learned the sleights of hand used by cardsharps. Then with an obsessive ‰ÛÓ and sometimes reckless ‰ÛÓ energy, he made a career as one of the foremost card magicians in his field, performing at the Magic Castle nightclub in Hollywood, at magic conventions and on TV talk shows.

To play the Israeli adventurer Yossi Ghinsberg, Mr. Radcliffe dives into water and quicksand, slathers himself in fire ants, tangles with a snake and excavates a parasite from his forehead. Given that these torments are very much in his director‰Ûªs wheelhouse, it‰Ûªs no surprise that they have an energy the rest of the movie (based on Mr. Ghinsberg‰Ûªs 2005 memoir) lacks.

Slow to get moving and dramatically slack, ‰ÛÏJungle‰Ûù cares only about Yossi, whose solo suffering and speed-enhanced hallucinations dominate the narrative. Despite Mr. Radcliffe‰Ûªs all-too-obvious dedication (his increasingly emaciated body, astonishingly, was not digitally enhanced), he can‰Ûªt rescue a screenplay (by Justin Monjo) that cares more about the condition of his flesh than the contents of his head.

Yet the look is polished and the setup promising as Yossi heads into the Bolivian jungle with two backpacking pals, an American photographer (Alex Russell) and a Swiss teacher (Joel Jackson). Their guide is Karl (Thomas Kretschmann), a sketchy stranger whose possibly menacing motives cry out for an investigation ‰ÛÓ fictionalized, if necessary ‰ÛÓ that never comes. Similarly, Yossi‰Ûªs friends remain essentially enigmas, generic sidekicks without much to distinguish them beyond degrees of daring and propensity for bickering.

You have to hand it to Daniel Radcliffe: Instead of luxuriating in all that Harry Potter cash ‰ÛÓ maybe accepting the occasional cushy acting gig to keep his hand in ‰ÛÓ he seems to be going out of his way to suffer. In last year‰Ûªs magical ‰ÛÏSwiss Army Man,‰Ûù he played a gassy, much-manhandled corpse; now he‰Ûªs embracing the muck and mortifications of ‰ÛÏJungle,‰Ûù a real-life survival tale from the Australian horror specialist Greg McLean.

Not that a solution even seems possible. Apparently aiming for an open-ended psychological thriller, Ms. Thoman focuses so fiercely on atmosphere that her narrative isn‰Ûªt just opaque, it‰Ûªs a confounding collision of signifiers and symbols. At their center is Miranda (Mireille Enos), an unraveling New York City artist whose work involves invading the privacy of strangers.

If only we cared. Ms. Enos is a credibly fraying voyeur, all anxious looks and nervous starts, but ‰ÛÏNever Here‰Ûù is too emotionally antiseptic to engage. That leaves all the heavy lifting to Sebastian Wintero‰Ûªs moody, nocturnal cinematography, perfectly paired with James Lavino‰Ûªs dissonant original score. As Miranda prowls the indigo city streets, bathed in ominous whispers and sharp jabs of neon, you might momentarily forget that the movie around her is a tiny bit bananas.

‰ÛÏYou did a bad thing,‰Ûù her latest victim complains when she builds an exhibit from information purloined from his cellphone. Bad things are something of a habit: When her married lover (Mr. Shepard) sees a violent assault on the street beneath her window, she tells the police ‰ÛÓ echoing the plot of Curtis Hanson‰Ûªs 1987 thriller, ‰ÛÏThe Bedroom Window‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ that she was the witness. Stalking a man she recognizes from a police lineup (Goran Visnjic), her behavior grows increasingly paranoid and unhinged. Is she preparing a new art installation, or is someone trying to kill her?

More experimental art project than fully-formed movie, ‰ÛÏNever Here‰Ûù might snag some attention for providing Sam Shepard with his final, all-too-brief screen role. Otherwise, this narrative feature debut from Camille Thoman is mostly a frustrating jumble of surreal puzzle pieces that audiences will likely be uninterested in solving.

A thread emerges early in ‰ÛÏOne of Us,‰Ûù a documentary about three Hasidic Jews who have left that community, and it‰Ûªs that leaving doesn‰Ûªt only mean severing a spiritual connection; the toll is complete. ‰ÛÏNobody leaves unless they‰Ûªre willing to pay the price,‰Ûù says Chani Getter of Footsteps, a support group for former ultra-Orthodox Jews as well as those considering straying from the fold.

But the most wrenching journey is that of Etty, in her early 30s, who seeks a divorce from a husband who, a title card says, was removed by the police from their home for alleged abuse. (At the start of the film, we hear audio from a 911 call that Etty placed after he was escorted out.) The movie makes the case that the Hasidic community has effectively exploited legal loopholes and financial muscle to win custody battles. Ms. Grady and Ms. Ewing don‰Ûªt show Etty‰Ûªs face until a powerful moment midway through the film.

In the film, directed by Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady (‰ÛÏJesus Camp,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏDetropia‰Ûù), the three have left for different reasons. One, a teenager, Ari, left as his thirst for knowledge came into conflict with religious restrictions. ‰ÛÏWikipedia,‰Ûù he says, ‰ÛÏwas a gift from God.‰Ûù He attends a Christian gathering simply out of curiosity. He also says he has been abused in his past.

Another of the three, Luzer, initially seems like the cutup of the bunch, an aspiring actor who lives part-time in Los Angeles and says he had forged his impression of the outside world from furtive movie viewings. We learn later that leaving meant effectively walking away from his family and children.
As a documentary, ‰ÛÏOne of Us‰Ûù is a small act of portraiture, but each portrait captures the pain of having a life upended.

The more aspirational narrative concerns Eric Marsh (Josh Brolin, whose craggy face has never better blended with a parched setting). Marsh is determined to whip the Hotshots into an efficient unit, despite challenges from his forthright wife (a vivid Jennifer Connelly, whose impassioned arguments with Mr. Brolin‰Ûªs character have their own kind of spark). Marsh, a bespectacled Buddhist in recovery from substance abuse, is a fascinating variation on your typical taciturn hero. (As his avuncular mentor, a veteran fire chief, Jeff Bridges embodies a more conventional template.)

This is a movie about Southwestern working-class men who drink beer, carry heavy tools, train in quasi-military fashion, banter in a weight room, attend a group family picnic and drive pickup trucks to a soundtrack loaded with AC/DC and ZZ Top. The women in their lives raise children (or train horses) when they‰Ûªre not scolding their men about neglecting family or the risks of their profession. Amid the familiar milieu, however, there are subtle, inventive touches.

Mr. Kosinski ‰ÛÓ and the screenwriters, Ken Nolan (‰ÛÏBlack Hawk Down‰Ûù) and Eric Warren Singer ‰ÛÓ let the characters grow in complexity before they face their greatest trial. Wisely, they do not overly sentimentalize the conclusion. This may not be a story of triumph, but it‰Ûªs inspiring nevertheless.

Given what Northern California has endured recently with wildfires, perhaps it‰Ûªs high time to honor those risking life and limb to contain such conflagrations. If only Joseph Kosinski‰Ûªs action-drama ‰ÛÏOnly the Brave‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ based on the exploits of the real-life Granite Mountain Hotshots, a troop of elite firefighters near Prescott, Ariz. ‰ÛÓ had a less generic title and fewer formulaic beats. But under its slick, schematic surface, this tale of aspiration and redemption at least offers moments of genuine feeling.

The redemption concerns a feckless pothead (Miles Teller) whose pregnant girlfriend has left him because of his indigence and dissolution. He must win her back and prove himself a responsible, loving father. The Hotshots help, though he must contend with a ne‰Ûªer-do-well (Taylor Kitsch) with his own immaturity issues.

Adela, the film‰Ûªs other subject, speaks of her daughter Monica, a college student who disappeared and is suspected of being kidnapped by human traffickers with the help of the local authorities. Adela continues her search for Monica, even as she is threatened with death by criminal groups who demand that she stop.

It‰Ûªs an artful and lyrical assembly; by splitting the audio from the visuals, and filming random strangers rather than the speaker, Ms. Huezo seeks to create a sense that ‰ÛÏwhat happened to Miriam could happen to anybody living in Mexico today,‰Ûù she writes in her director‰Ûªs statement.

The documentary, directed by Tatiana Huezo, spotlights two women tormented by Mexico‰Ûªs Kafkaesque justice system. The first is Miriam, a young mother working at an airport in Cancun who was accused, apparently without evidence, of human trafficking. ‰ÛÏWe call you payers,‰Ûù she recalls her court-appointed lawyer saying. ‰ÛÏPeople who pay for other people‰Ûªs crimes.‰Ûù She was taken to and held at a ‰ÛÏself-governing‰Ûù prison run by gangs, where her family was forced to send money each week for her protection.
It works.
Nightmarish stories intertwine with dreamy visuals to create an unsettling, and strangely entrancing, film in ‰ÛÏTempestad.‰Ûù

Miriam and Adela tell their tales while Ms. Huezo and her cinematographer, Ernesto Pardo, deliver images that are often only vaguely related to the stories. As the women recount the horrors, we see footage of dark rooms, bus rides or crumbling buildings. Long, languid views of Mexican landscapes, city streets and shipyards are woven with voice-overs that recount tortures, emotional agony and murders.

Mr. Keoghan, recently seen in ‰ÛÏDunkirk,‰Ûù has the ability to at once solicit and repel sympathy and a face that suggests both absolute innocence and terrible cunning. Martin is an abstraction, the embodiment of an occult principle of cosmic vengeance, and Mr. Keoghan makes him appropriately menacing and also pitiable, since he‰Ûªs also a grieving, needy child. This incongruity is the key to the movie, but it‰Ûªs the key to an empty box. You will suffer in vain.

The premise might remind you of any version of ‰ÛÏCape Fear‰Ûù (except maybe the one from ‰ÛÏThe Simpsons‰Ûù) or countless horror movies. Mr. Lanthimos‰Ûªs techniques ‰ÛÓ a hovering, prying camera, an atmosphere of chilly, cerebral detachment ‰ÛÓ owe a debt to the films of Michael Haneke, in particular those like ‰ÛÏCache‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏFunny Games‰Ûù that subject the guilty conscience of the bourgeoisie to painful deep-tissue massage. But Mr. Lanthimos is less interested in moral shock therapy or social criticism than in aesthetic estrangement. ‰ÛÏSacred Deer‰Ûù feels like a dark, opaque bit of folklore transplanted into an off-kilter modern setting.

Steven Murphy (Colin Farrell) is a respected heart surgeon. His wife, Anna (Nicole Kidman), is an equally successful eye doctor. They live with their two children ‰ÛÓ Kim (Raffey Cassidy), a wide-eyed teenage girl, and her younger brother, Bob (Sunny Suljic) ‰ÛÓ in a big house in an unspecified, apparently American city. (The film was shot in Ireland and Cincinnati.) Steven also has a curious friendship with an odd, earnest young man named Martin (Barry Keoghan). The two of them have lunch and take walks together and exchange gifts, and the opening scenes invite the audience to guess at the nature of their relationship.

I‰Ûªll stop now. It isn‰Ûªt quite fair to say, with respect to Yorgos Lanthimos‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Killing of a Sacred Deer,‰Ûù that you‰Ûªve seen it all before. His methods and sensibility are very much his own. But if you were intrigued, unnerved and tickled by ‰ÛÏThe Lobster‰Ûù or by Mr. Lanthimos‰Ûªs earlier films ‰ÛÏAlps‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏDogtooth‰Ûù (I was), you might be surprised and a little disappointed to find him traipsing over such familiar territory. His previous work ‰ÛÓ allegorical, satirical, anti-realist and metapsychological ‰ÛÓ defies genre labels and can seem scrubbed clean of any trace of influence. ‰ÛÏSacred Deer,‰Ûù in contrast, rings all kinds of frequently-heard bells.

Is this a curse? A superpower? As in Mr. Lanthimos‰Ûªs other movies, no explanation is offered. No boundary is marked between the normal and the supernatural. The normal, in this filmmaker‰Ûªs world, is pretty weird to begin with. All the characters speak in the same droning, matter-of-fact tone until they are provoked to violent rage. They ask puzzling questions and produce overelaborate answers, not so much like machines but like people doing their best to fail a Turing test.

It‰Ûªs made clear soon enough. Martin, who seems both a little slow and spookily intuitive, turns out to be the evil force who will torment the Murphys. Some years earlier, Steven had performed an operation on the boy‰Ûªs father, who subsequently died. In lieu of filing a malpractice claim, Martin has chosen a more archaic ‰ÛÓ and, in the film‰Ûªs modern setting, a far scarier and more preposterous ‰ÛÓ form of score settling. He demands that Steven kill Anna or one of their kids. If he doesn‰Ûªt, the whole family will sicken and die. Martin describes the process in exacting detail, and then it begins.

Stop me if you‰Ûªve heard this one. The members of an upstanding, upper-middle-class nuclear family are terrorized by a malign force. Their suffering is not entirely arbitrary, because not all of them are completely innocent. (Usually it‰Ûªs Daddy‰Ûªs fault.) Their tormentor metes out a cruel and disproportionate kind of justice, and revels in the punishment. Meanwhile, the audience squirms in complicity, taking both masochistic and sadistic pleasure at a game of cat and mouse in which the roles keep shifting.

Sometimes this is funny, and sometimes effectively scary. The auditory migraine of the sound design and the visual paranoia of the drone-mounted cameras help create an ambience of perpetual panic. You laugh to break the tension, and also you can‰Ûªt help but intuit a comic intention under the cast‰Ûªs deadpan. Mr. Farrell, half-hidden behind an absurdly self-important salt-and-pepper beard, extinguishes nearly all of his natural impishness but keeps the tiniest ember burning. Ms. Kidman has a gift for seeming utterly natural in the most artificial of settings, and here, as in ‰ÛÏThe Beguiled‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏDogville,‰Ûù she brings fresh air to the hothouse of a director‰Ûªs imagination.

Certainly ‰ÛÏThe Snowman‰Ûù might have been better if someone at some point had learned from Hawks (always a good idea) and let the characters handle the plot. That might have helped, at least a little. The movie is based on a novel by the popular Norwegian writer Jo Nesbo, whose intricately involved, atmospheric tales are far more complex ‰ÛÓ they have politics, themes and worldviews ‰ÛÓ than anything in this movie. Shot to shot, Mr. Alfredson and his estimable team give you plenty to look at, including acres of blinding white snow, noirish nights, desaturated pooling red, a sleekly generic Euro-scape and Mr. Fassbender‰Ûªs expressionless mug. Yet there‰Ûªs no glue ‰ÛÓ not a whiff of life or a single substantial, grounding directorial idea ‰ÛÓ that makes this pottage work scene to scene.

Mr. Fassbender plays Harry Hole, a dissipated, alcoholic detective living in Oslo, which presumably means he‰Ûªs Norwegian even if he (and most everyone else) speaks in English. With his red-rimmed eyes and a cigarette drooping from his lips, Harry comes across as one of those classically shabby gumshoe types, the existential inside-outsider who chafes against the rules even as he saves the day. He has an ex (Charlotte Gainsbourg) and a new colleague (Rebecca Ferguson), and soon he has a mess of trouble that he navigates amid a great deal of snow, byzantine developments, dead-end detours and a grab bag of random characters. (Val Kilmer, ChloÌÇ Sevigny and Toby Jones all breeze by.)

There are a couple of mysteries swirling through ‰ÛÏThe Snowman,‰Ûù a leaden, clotted, exasperating mess. This ostensible whodunit involves a serial killer who‰Ûªs preying on women, leaving behind carefully arranged body parts and a childlike snowman as a kind of elaborate signature. The greater puzzle, though, is how an enterprise studded with so much talent ‰ÛÓ starting with the director Tomas Alfredson (‰ÛÏTinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy‰Ûù) and including the star Michael Fassbender ‰ÛÓ has led to such a grim, thrill-free thriller, one without a twitch of real feeling and next to no elementary story sense.

The problem isn‰Ûªt the narrative complications, even if the movie soon becomes mired in them. Raymond Chandler tied his novel ‰ÛÏThe Big Sleep‰Ûù into so many knots that apparently he couldn‰Ûªt tell who killed one of its characters. As Leigh Brackett, who helped turn the novel into the 1946 film, said, ‰ÛÏWhen you read it from page to page it moves so beautifully that you don‰Ûªt care.‰Ûù The problem, Brackett said, was ‰ÛÏif you start tearing it apart to see what makes it tick, it comes unglued.‰Ûù The trick was to hold on to Chandler‰Ûªs language and go with his flow, mood and milieu, letting ‰ÛÓ as the film‰Ûªs director, Howard Hawks, said later ‰ÛÓ the characters ‰ÛÏhandle the plot, rather than let the plot move them.‰Ûù

But although ‰ÛÏTragedy Girls‰Ûù is up-to-date on tweets and technology, its high school dynamics conform to familiar tropes. Sadie and McKayla are catty, prone to jealousy, and quick to swoon before their male victims. ‰ÛÏTragedy Girls‰Ûù might add group texts to its instruments of death alongside marauding table saws and falling barbells, but the movie‰Ûªs gender stereotypes keep it chained to the past.

Midway through the horror comedy ‰ÛÏTragedy Girls,‰Ûù the director Tyler MacIntyre delivers this slasher movie‰Ûªs first real scare. Two high school social media stars and secretly budding serial killers, Sadie and McKayla, are holding a school assembly for one of their victims, a fellow cheerleader who got fresh about McKayla‰Ûªs choice of sneakers. As their sanctimonious In Memoriam slide show plays, the dates of the fallen cheer captain‰Ûªs birth and death flash onscreen, bringing a sickly realization more frightening than any kill: These teenagers were all born in the year 2000.

‰ÛÏTragedy Girls‰Ûù updates the slasher genre by identifying personal branding as the horror that trends with the millennial teen. Played with acidic irony by Brianna Hildebrand and Alexandra Shipp, Sadie and McKayla exhibit all the textbook signs of narcissism, and their bloodthirstiness is really a thirst for the followers that murder is able to drum up for their online horror brand. After rehearsing for their own killing spree by tracking and kidnapping the town‰Ûªs local madman, Sadie and McKayla exhibit a talent for terror to match their social media savvy.

Although the film follows the novel fairly closely ‰ÛÓ Mr. Selznick wrote the script ‰ÛÓ it nevertheless is very much a Todd Haynes production. Its ideas feel pitched to an older audience, for one, and its emotional temperature is cooler than that of Mr. Selznick‰Ûªs book, which is soon splashed in tears as Ben‰Ûªs terror gives way to anguish about his mother. Mr. Haynes is happy to set a wolf after Ben in the woods, a jaggedly shot chase bathed in midnight blue, but he refrains from easy sentimentalism. (The director of photography is Ed Lachman.) As a filmmaker, Mr. Haynes prefers appealing to our heads over tugging at our hearts, and so for a while he keeps you at an intellectual remove.

Stars glitter and worlds collide in Todd Haynes‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWonderstruck,‰Ûù a lovely ode to imagination and to the stories that make us who we are. A cleverly bifurcated tale of two children, it starts in 1977 with Ben (Oakes Fegley), a boy of about 10 in rural Minnesota. He‰Ûªs in mourning for his mother (Michelle Williams in flashback) and has a question mark ‰ÛÓ an absent father ‰ÛÓ that needs solving. First, though, there‰Ûªs David Bowie on the turntable (‰ÛÏground control to Major Tom‰Ûù) and a lightning strike that leaves Ben deaf. Fearless and resourceful, Ben splits for New York to find his father.

Mr. Selznick‰Ûªs emphasis on wonder ‰ÛÓ represented by the story‰Ûªs surfeit of enchantments and the near-miraculously fitted parts ‰ÛÓ can feel bullying, as if he were demanding delight instead of earning it. Yet even as he follows Mr. Selznick‰Ûªs narrative lead, Mr. Haynes quietly and touchingly makes ‰ÛÏWonderstruck‰Ûù his own because the wonder of the film isn‰Ûªt in its story but in its telling. It‰Ûªs in the expressive beauty of his images, the expansiveness of his ideas and the way he naturally, generously brings a once-upon-a-time girl and boy to life, allowing them to find themselves ‰ÛÓ in their willfulness, their heartbreaks and their imaginings ‰ÛÓ so that eventually they can find someone else.

Both Rose and Ben fantasize about escaping their lives, but they need a little push, inspiration. Storytelling lies at the heart of ‰ÛÏWonderstruck‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ its two children are effectively writing their way out of one reality and into another ‰ÛÓ and the film is chockablock with those boxed worlds, with imitations of life like dioramas, doll-size figurines, stuffed animals, illustrations and an ingenious paper city. Much like the cabinet of curiosities that Rose and Ben each discover, these representations point to new worlds and alternative realities. And, as they pile up, Mr. Haynes joins the story‰Ûªs halves with craft and wit. Rose‰Ûªs half isn‰Ûªt just in black and white, it also emotionally and gesturally recalls a late-period silent film; Ben‰Ûªs, by contrast, has the rough textures and bleeding colors that summon 1970s big-screen New York.

‰ÛÏWonderstruck‰Ûù is based on a hefty, generously illustrated children‰Ûªs book by Brian Selznick, best known for ‰ÛÏThe Invention of Hugo Cabret.‰Ûù Martin Scorsese turned that book into ‰ÛÏHugo,‰Ûù a reverie about movie love that also features dead parents, a grave if pluckily resourceful child, many whirring yet connected parts and a preoccupation with the cinematic. The film version of ‰ÛÏWonderstruck‰Ûù draws from much the same overflowing treasure-trove of ideas, although Mr. Haynes (like Mr. Scorsese) often feels most energized by the many different ways human beings ‰ÛÓ with cinematic sights and sounds, through wall shadows and painstaking miniatures ‰ÛÓ put the world in a box.

Part of the pleasure of Mr. Haynes‰Ûªs films ‰ÛÓ which include ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm Not There‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏCarol‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ is how he deploys intellectual distance as he plays with cinematic form, considers identity and upends clichÌ©s. Elsewhere, this can come across as dreary, even programmatic. Yet because Mr. Haynes also leads with his characters rather than his ideas, his films gather force until, at times with near-violent suddenness, they become devastatingly, skin-prickingly alive. In Mr. Haynes‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏFar From Heaven,‰Ûù his combination of playfulness and seriousness translates into a homage to Sirkian melodrama that turns into a thrilling example of the very same. And, in ‰ÛÏWonderstruck,‰Ûù a children‰Ûªs story about finding your place in the world, in time becomes a Haynesian exploration of identity, desire and imagination.

Despite the distinct periods and palettes ‰ÛÓ Ben‰Ûªs story unfolds in color, Rose‰Ûªs in black and white ‰ÛÓ the story, the editing and the children‰Ûªs deafness underscore that these two are deeply connected. The film‰Ûªs mysteries include how and why they fit, and its satisfactions involve seeing where the scattered bread crumbs lead. How, for instance, an Oscar Wilde line in Ben‰Ûªs room ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏWe are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ fits into the larger puzzle. And why, after Ben asks his mother about his father, the film shifts to a plaintive Rose, who‰Ûªs looking at a movie-magazine ad trumpeting ‰ÛÏOur Brightest Stars.‰Ûù Both that  Wilde epigram and Rose‰Ûªs film fandom are hints, clues in a story that eventually dovetails with Mr. Haynes‰Ûªs interest in images and identity.

Ben‰Ûªs story-twin, whose life and adventures curiously mirror his own, is Rose (Millicent Simmonds, a discovery), a 12-year-old deaf girl in 1927 who yearns to escape her lonely, cosseted life in Hoboken, N.J. To that end, following in the footsteps of countless other dreamers, she, too, flees to New York. There, she seeks out her absent mother, but instead finds a cipher (Julianne Moore), a screen star who clutches fictional babes to her breast but has no time for life‰Ûªs real lost children. As undaunted and determined as Ben, Rose sets off again, entering a world thrumming with coincidences and complications.

‰ÛÏWonderstruck‰Ûù takes a while to find its groove, but it gets there. Mr. Haynes‰Ûªs oscillation between the story‰Ûªs two halves is gracefully handled (the editor is Affonso GonÌ_alves), but it can create a frustrating sense of narrative interruptus. That‰Ûªs particularly true because it‰Ûªs hard not to miss Rose when Ben is onscreen. Part of this has to do with the charming exoticism of her old-time world with its winking artifice and cinematic allusions. Ben‰Ûªs half has its attractions, including his new pal (Jaden Michael) and the sun-blasted vision of a broiling New York summer. But it‰Ûªs also the section in which the machinery of Mr. Selznick‰Ûªs storytelling, with its mysticism and coincidences, creaks the loudest.

Directed by Dean Devlin from a script he wrote with Paul Guyot and discreetly installed in theaters without advance screenings, ‰ÛÏGeostorm‰Ûù uses digital technology to lay waste to a bunch of cities and hacky screenwriting to assault the dignity of several fine actors. Andy Garcia and Ed Harris are the president and secretary of state, while Abbie Cornish is a Secret Service agent secretly keeping company with a deputy secretary named Max Lawson (Jim Sturgess) who happens to be Jake‰Ûªs younger brother. The siblings have their differences, but they share an unplaceable American accent, an aversion to regular shaving and a desire not to see the world destroyed by ice, fire, hail or heavy rain.

If I had to spend a global meteorological catastrophe with anyone, I don‰Ûªt think Gerard Butler would be my first choice. But of course I don‰Ûªt have a choice. Mr. Butler‰Ûªs character, Jake Lawson, has a job to do, and so do I. Jake‰Ûªs is to fix the space-based weather-control system he designed and built, racing against a digital clock that counts down the minutes until ‰ÛÏgeostorm.‰Ûù Mine involves counting the minutes until ‰ÛÏGeostorm‰Ûù is over and then offering a comprehensive damage assessment. To quote something Jake says to a grandstanding senator (Richard Schiff) who dares to question his expertise: you‰Ûªre welcome.

The movie does what it can to replicate those elemental forces. I happened to see it in the 4DX format ‰ÛÓ a first for me ‰ÛÓ which combines the thrill of a Mad Tea Party ride with the sensory challenges of a cab ride across the Manhattan Bridge on a rainy night. Your seat rocks and rumbles during chase scenes, lists gently from side to side during zero-gravity interludes and abuses your lumbar spine when space junk starts flying. You sometimes catch a whiff of burning skyscraper, a spray of monsoon mist, a whoosh of gale-force wind and the gentle caress of Mr. Butler‰Ûªs stubble on your cheek.

Not that last thing, actually, but I‰Ûªm sure they‰Ûªre working on it. And I look forward to future 4DX adventures, or at least to installing one of those chairs in my office. I wouldn‰Ûªt say the experience improved ‰ÛÏGeostorm,‰Ûù but it certainly didn‰Ûªt make it any worse. As for Mr. Butler, he is no more or less credible as a renegade scientific genius than in any other role he‰Ûªs attempted; consistency is his chief and perhaps his only virtue as an actor. He does his job. I do mine. The world is safe. The weather is fine.

The prospect of Mr. Perry‰Ûªs rambunctious Madea possibly taking on a Jason Voorhees-type killer has an amusement value that is not even vaguely realized here. This movie finds Mr. Perry, never the most deft at the technical aspect of filmmaking, drastically off whatever his best game is. Every camera setup is a study in inertia; every other cut is a beat or two behind where a punch line needs to land. To call this movie unwatchable would be inaccurate, though the scenes featuring Mike Tornabene and Yousef Erakat, portraying frat brothers who act as if they are dying to reassemble a group of Dead End Kids for Sidney Kingsley‰Ûªs play, are pretty painful. On the other hand, the lighting is so weak, ‰ÛÏBoo 2!‰Ûù is quite often close to unseeable.

About a year ago, Tyler Perry‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBoo! A Madea Halloween‰Ûù arrived in theaters. It was hardly distinguished, but it had its moments, largely because of the comic interactions between the outrageous, finely aged characters Madea and Joe (both played by Mr. Perry) and their fellow dyspeptic senior citizens, Hattie (Patrice Lovely) and Aunt Bam (Cassi Davis).

Once again Tiffany is determined to attend a frat party. And, yes, it‰Ûªs the same inhabited-by-30-year-olds frat from the first film. The twist this time is the fellas aren‰Ûªt allowed to have a party in the house, so instead they‰Ûªre having it at Derrick Lake, which was (cue scary music) the scene of a still-apparently-shrouded-in-mystery (with this shoddy script it‰Ûªs hard to really tell) mass murder back in the 1970s. Rumor has it some kind of massacre-seeking entity haunts the premises.

‰ÛÏTyler Perry‰Ûªs Boo 2! A Madea Halloween,‰Ûù which, as usual with Mr. Perry‰Ûªs pictures, wasn‰Ûªt screened in advance for critics, frequently feels more like a remake than a sequel. The movie revisits Brian Simmons (Mr. Perry), a single dad, and his rebellious teenage daughter, Tiffany (Diamond White). The respect-your-parents and don‰Ûªt-even-think-about-having-sex lessons of the previous film have long been forgotten by the characters; if anything, Tiffany, now turning 18, is snottier, and Brian more passive. (The movie introduces an ex-wife, played by Taja V. Simpson, who walks all over him and is too permissive with Tiffany.)

Trapped between skies like beaten tin and earth scrubbed raw by wind and rain, the characters in ‰ÛÏGod‰Ûªs Own Country‰Ûù are well used to harshness. Like Johnny (Josh O‰ÛªConnor), who labors on his struggling family farm in Yorkshire under the critical eyes of his sick father (Ian Hart) and stolid grandmother (Gemma Jones). For relief, he vents his frustrations in binge-drinking and furtive, feral sex with random young men.

Both are about to be loosened. The arrival of Gheorghe (Alec Secareanu), a gentle, darkly handsome Romanian migrant worker, softens Johnny‰Ûªs heart and the movie‰Ûªs tone. Their passion isn‰Ûªt pretty, but awkward and pasty and explicit: two frantic strangers grappling in the muck of the moors. Yet Gheorghe is skilled at handling more than newborn lambs; and as the men grow closer, the glowering light grows warmer and the whole picture seems to briefly exhale.

These taciturn encounters, unfolding as unsentimentally as the internal exam he gives a pregnant heifer, suggest someone disgusted by his own sorry self. But this bracing, sometimes brutal movie ‰ÛÓ the feature debut of the writer and director Francis Lee ‰ÛÓ doesn‰Ûªt present Johnny‰Ûªs sexuality as the cause of his self-loathing. Rather, it‰Ûªs his imprisonment by a legacy he‰Ûªs not sure he wants that ties his tongue and clots his emotions.

Filmed with a naturalism that recalls Andrea Arnold‰Ûªs 2012 dive into ‰ÛÏWuthering Heights,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏGod‰Ûªs Own Country‰Ûù weaves a rough magic from Joshua James Richards‰Ûªs biting cinematography and the story‰Ûªs slow, unsteady arc from bitter to hopeful. Bodily fluids ‰ÛÓ bestial and human ‰ÛÓ stain the screen, punctuating a story that‰Ûªs as much about rediscovering place as finding love. So when Gheorghe looks out at the brooding countryside and murmurs ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs beautiful here,‰Ûù we sense that Johnny really doesn‰Ûªt need persuading.
Joan Didion‰Ûªs meticulously calibrated prose has the effect of placing her at a particular remove from the reader. The persona she creates on the page is always frank but never ingratiating.

The exchanges between Mr. Dunne and Ms. Didion are at once fond and candid. When Mr. Dunne suggests that his uncle, Ms. Didion‰Ûªs husband, was a ‰ÛÏprotector,‰Ûù Ms. Didion nods animatedly before adding, ‰ÛÏAnd a hothead.‰Ûù

While the movie covers the whole of Ms. Didion‰Ûªs life (and even the period before it, offering a fun fact that at one point the pioneer Didions traveled with the Donner party), those expecting a thorough examination of Ms. Didion‰Ûªs work may be disappointed. Which is not to say that Mr. Dunne, a very canny filmmaker, doesn‰Ûªt accomplish a lot via implication. The movie is subtly bracketed by readings of Ms. Didion‰Ûªs appreciation of John Wayne, in an early essay, and her excoriation of Vice President Dick Cheney, in a later one. Unlike a great many more facile thinkers, Ms. Didion clearly does not consider them equivalent figures. But the citation of both works illuminates the changes in Ms. Didion‰Ûªs thinking over the years.

The relationship between Mr. Dunne and Ms. Didion limits the movie in certain ways, but opens it up in others. Mr. Dunne‰Ûªs longtime family connections and his own prestige as a filmmaker no doubt helped him snag interviews that other documentarians would be hard-pressed to schedule. Ms. Didion‰Ûªs friend Calvin Trillin is among the interviewees, and while I‰Ûªd never dare suggest that great writer is not a big get, I was impressed in a different way when Harrison Ford showed up.

Her early writing reveals the instincts of a conservative. As she witnessed the tectonic shifts in American life wrought by, among other things, the counterculture, she admittedly lost faith in ‰ÛÏthe social contract,‰Ûù but did not turn left for solutions; rather, she staked a claim as a kind of ideological outsider. (Two words that are never uttered in this movie are ‰ÛÏfeminism‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏfeminist.‰Ûù) Mr. Dunne‰Ûªs movie gets you thinking about all this with extremely well-chosen archival footage and evocative music choices.

The movie‰Ûªs title, like that of Ms. Didion‰Ûªs collection ‰ÛÏSlouching Towards Bethlehem,‰Ûù is derived from the W.B. Yeats poem ‰ÛÏThe Second Coming.‰Ûù Mr. Dunne‰Ûªs portrait and tribute to his aunt, now 82, also reminded me of an observation by D.H. Lawrence: ‰ÛÏOurs is essentially a tragic age, so we refuse to take it tragically.‰Ûù Ms. Didion‰Ûªs triumph, as a writer and a human being, has been to take the age for what it is, to pinpoint how she saw it, and to stick it out.

So it‰Ûªs disarming to see a relatively cozy Joan Didion in the documentary ‰ÛÏJoan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold,‰Ûù but it should not be surprising. The movie is directed by Griffin Dunne, one of Ms. Didion‰Ûªs nephews, who also appears as an onscreen interviewer. The Dunne-Didions are a storied family whose members are, and have been, significant cultural forces. They are also a clan rived by tragedy. Two of Ms. Didion‰Ûªs most celebrated recent works concern the deaths of her husband, the writer John Gregory Dunne, and her daughter, Quintana Roo.

‰ÛÏAll I See Is You‰Ûù is halfway through before something resembling a plot kicks in, and even then this limp, shape-shifting psychodrama proves unable to sell it with anything approaching coherence.

Nor is she. New erotic interests surface during a trip to Spain, where the hypersexualized marriage of her sister and brother-in-law nudges the film into seamier territory and prompts a change in Gina‰Ûªs appearance. As James becomes increasingly destabilized by his wife‰Ûªs transformation, the movie seems keen to linger over what can happen to a relationship when a previously dependent partner gains agency.

Instead, we‰Ûªre hastened toward a nonsensical, almost illegible ending that lays waste to all this careful mood-setting. Ms. Lively is well cast, gracefully patrolling the boundary of her limited range, with Mr. Clarke less steady in the more amorphous role of someone who seems a bit off from the outset. And though the milky visual disruptions that signal Gina‰Ûªs initially blurry view of the world are overdone, there‰Ûªs something seductive about her journey that cries out for a filmmaker like Nicolas Roeg. In his hands, the haze of sex and danger that surrounds these two might have been revealed as more than just a tease.

Yet the director, Marc Forster (who wrote the script with Sean Conway), fashions such a languid, tipsy aesthetic around the seemingly happy marriage of Gina and James (Blake Lively and Jason Clarke) that it‰Ûªs easy to keep watching. Legally blind since childhood, Gina rarely leaves their home in Bangkok, relying almost entirely on the attentive James. But when a cornea transplant restores vision to one eye, Gina discovers that her life is not quite as she imagined.

Mr. Nye, who left his Emmy-winning series after around 100 episodes, has embraced a new mission: educating an older generation as he champions space exploration and challenges creationists and climate-change deniers.

In the film ‰ÛÏBill Nye: Science Guy,‰Ûù Mr. Nye, the 1990s children‰Ûªs-television personality with the signature bow tie, warns of ‰ÛÏan anti-science movement‰Ûù afoot in this country. And this delightful, revealing documentary, directed by David Alvarado and Jason Sussberg, offers evidence supporting that assessment.

‰ÛÏHere is anti-science,‰Ûù he adds, gesturing in the direction of the Kentucky tourist attractions the Creation Museum and Ark Encounter, whose exhibits present such sights as prehistoric humans cohabiting, Flintstone-like, with dinosaurs, and a sauropod (a dinosaur species) dwelling on Noah‰Ûªs ark. Mr. Nye debates the museum‰Ûªs chief executive, Ken Ham, on a stage, though his efforts only galvanize Mr. Ham‰Ûªs supporters.
Most inspiring, it finds him at a conference of adoring science teachers, who applaud him as a defender of all they hold dear.
‰ÛÏAs we stand here, the Juno spacecraft just went into orbit around Jupiter,‰Ûù Mr. Nye says. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs an extraordinary accomplishment of engineering and rocket science.‰Ûù

In TV clips, Sarah Palin impugns Mr. Nye‰Ûªs credentials, and an Obama-era Donald J. Trump declares, ‰ÛÏOur president is worried about global warming ‰ÛÓ what a ridiculous situation.‰Ûù Joe Bastardi, the former chief long-range forecaster at AccuWeather and a frequent Fox News guest, insists that extreme weather is merely meteorological variation, not the result of human-caused global warming. (Mr. Nye is polite but resolute as he argues with Mr. Bastardi during a visit to his home.)

The documentary also follows Mr. Nye‰Ûªs work as chief executive of the Planetary Society, as he collaborates with the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson and spearheads the LightSail project (a small spacecraft powered by photons from the sun), a tribute to Mr. Nye‰Ûªs mentor Carl Sagan. And it accompanies Mr. Nye to Greenland, where he witnesses melting ice caps and ice-core studies revealing climate temperatures of centuries past and our fossil-fuel-poisoned present.

Stensland and Grady‰Ûªs romantic plight might have earned more sympathy if their characters weren‰Ûªt so insufferable. While Mr. Tent‰Ûªs direction is serviceable, it‰Ûªs safe. His movie lacks any stylish risks that would make this trio‰Ûªs bad romance memorable, leaving ‰ÛÏCrash Pad‰Ûù to feel like a warm-up act.

The sin of poor comedic timing is almost an unpardonable one. Kevin Tent, Alexander Payne‰Ûªs longtime editor, has worked on some of that director‰Ûªs funniest movies, including ‰ÛÏSideways‰Ûù and the forthcoming ‰ÛÏDownsizing.‰Ûù Yet Mr. Tent‰Ûªs directorial debut, ‰ÛÏCrash Pad,‰Ûù indicates this artist has more to learn about his new craft.

‰ÛÏCrash Pad‰Ûù follows a millennial slacker and self-professed romantic, Stensland (Domhnall Gleeson), in the depths of heartbreak after the end of his fling with a married woman, Morgan (Christina Applegate). After binge-watching episodes of ‰ÛÏDawson‰Ûªs Creek‰Ûù and trying to blackmail his former flame, Stensland receives an unusual proposal from Morgan‰Ûªs husband, Grady (Thomas Haden Church from ‰ÛÏSideways‰Ûù). The two men become roommates in a bid to make Morgan jealous while they mend their bruised feelings with women and cheap tequila.

The movie‰Ûªs premise isn‰Ûªt as bad as the forced, unnatural dialogue. Even the reliable Ms. Applegate and Mr. Church can‰Ûªt salvage the screenwriter Jeremy Catalino‰Ûªs clumsy lines. ‰ÛÏMorgan‰Ûªs faithlessness has emboldened me to take a vacation,‰Ûù Grady declares when moving into Stensland‰Ûªs apartment. Saddled with the wordiest scenes in the movie, Mr. Gleeson comes across like a college freshman fumbling through his first Shakespeare play.

The red-blooded vivacity of Ms. Olin‰Ûªs performance, however, pierces through the muck. She chews feeble lines like meat, spitting out the masticated remains. For all of Maya‰Ûªs talk of finding the youthful Actaeon to her Artemis, the only time Ms. Olin appears matched is in her brief scenes with her neighbor, Leonora, played by the equally strong Rosanna Arquette.

The first time we hear Maya Dardel (Lena Olin, and her inimitable rasp), she is declaring her intention to commit suicide. Maya, a renowned poet living in isolation, believes her work has begun to decline. Her only concern now is with finding a worthy heir to manage her estate. Women need not apply ‰ÛÓ Maya wants to play with power and toy with the young male poets who offer themselves as her potential successors.

The passions that drive ‰ÛÏMaya Dardel,‰Ûù written and directed by Magdalena Zyzak and Zachary Cotler, are more literary than cinematic. Maya circles her legacy-minded suitors, dropping references to Sylvia Plath and discussing the merits of rhyme schemes and suicide. But for all the linguistic gymnastics, the film is hamstrung by its directors‰Ûª lack of visual imagination. Maya challenges her boyish applicants poetically, sexually and finally with offers of intimacy, but the editing all too often settles into a submissive back and forth. During Maya‰Ûªs tÌ»te-ÌÊ-tÌ»tes, we get a glimpse of her home, but every room in her mountainside hideaway has the same sickly hues of blue and green. What little light makes it through appears weak and suffocated, and though the claustrophobia abates when she walks through the California brambles, even nature isn‰Ûªt immune to the enervating pallor of Ms. Zyzak and Mr. Cotler‰Ûªs compositions.

Scott Haze, the director, is eager to inspire. Interviews show Mr. Mully to be resolute, and his family kindhearted. Yet the film‰Ûªs tone sometimes turns repetitive. In one short section, a few orphans tell of their lives before meeting Mr. Mully. Their brutal recollections are essential to hear, but Mr. Haze hurriedly retreats from those and other harsh topics. Just as vexing, redundant voice-overs describe what is being shown; while Mr. Mully speaks of events, scripted scenes re-enact them.

‰ÛÏMully‰Ûù nods toward its subject‰Ûªs religious faith but refrains from preachiness. Mr. Mully‰Ûªs actions speak for themselves, and his robust personality makes him a pleasure to listen to. If the film doesn‰Ûªt always dig deeply into this man‰Ûªs life, we still see the results of his efforts. Those are enough to admire.

Charles Mully was born in Kenya and abandoned by his family at 6; he later stole and begged on the streets. Through the generosity of strangers, hard work and some prayer, he not only found a job but became wealthy by running several companies, including a bus service and oil and gas ventures.

To the surprise of his wife and eight children, Mr. Mully one day decided to give up business and devote his resources to Nairobi‰Ûªs orphans. He turned his residence into a shelter, moving in dozens of homeless Kenyans (while sending some of his own children away to boarding schools). Later he built an orphanage that has housed and fed thousands; a farm there is dedicated to environmentally friendly agriculture.
‰ÛÏMully‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt much in the way of cinema. But its courageous subject makes this documentary‰Ûªs shortcomings easier to overlook.

Their reasons for joining the order are as various as their temperaments. One cites Audrey Hepburn in ‰ÛÏThe Nun‰Ûªs Story‰Ûù as a primary inspiration. ‰ÛÏNovitiate‰Ûù avoids both the laundered piety of that movie and the sensationalism that hovers around the subject of women and religion. At least since the 18th century, the depiction of nuns and convents in literature has often tended toward the Gothic or the pornographic, fed by anticlerical and anti-Catholic ideology as well as by fantasies about female sexuality.

Ms. Betts refrains from easy, uplifting answers and facile condemnations of organized religion. Aided by Kat Westergaard‰Ûªs warm, restrained cinematography, she takes the viewer close to an understanding of Cathleen‰Ûªs evolving sense of her relationship with God.

‰ÛÏWhat do you seek? What do you desire?‰Ûù a young woman named Cathleen is asked as she prepares to take religious vows. Even though the questions are part of a centuries-old ritual, ‰ÛÏNovitiate,‰Ûù written and directed by Maggie Betts, takes their content seriously and understands that they are not synonymous. What Sister Cathleen (Margaret Qualley) and her fellow novices aspire to become does not always align with what they want in their hearts. Though they feel themselves called to a life of sacrifice, seclusion and austerity, that vocation often expresses itself with a passion that can be unsettling. It is not just about loving God, but about being in love with him. Eros and Agape, the worldly and spiritual manifestations of love, are not always easily separated.

There is certainly cruelty in ‰ÛÏNovitiate,‰Ûù and lust as well. In her desk drawer, the reverend mother keeps a small whip made of knotted rope, called ‰ÛÏthe discipline,‰Ûù that the sisters may borrow to use on themselves. Cathleen‰Ûªs spiritual hunger ‰ÛÓ her need to be loved and worthy of love, her longing for comfort as well as sacrifice ‰ÛÓ brings its share of anguish, shame and confusion. Ms. Qualley‰Ûªs performance, and those of some of the supporting cast, notably Morgan Saylor and Rebecca Dayan, convey the difficulties these women face.

Cathleen Harris arrives at the Sisters of Blessed Rose monastery in 1964, when she is 17. Even though the Vatican II reforms initiated by Pope John XXIII are bringing radical changes to the Roman Catholic Church, they have yet to reach the quiet hillside where the sisters live, almost entirely cut off from the rest of the world. Cathleen, educated in a Catholic girls‰Ûª school in Tennessee, is leaving a family situation sketched in a few baldly over-dramatized scenes. Her tomcatting father (Chris Zylka) comes home drunk and angry and then leaves altogether. Cathleen‰Ûªs mother, Nora (Julianne Nicholson), an occasional churchgoer, smokes and swears and sleeps around and is utterly mystified by the intensity of her daughter‰Ûªs faith.

‰ÛÏNovitiate‰Ûù veers between subtlety and its opposite, which is personified mainly by Melissa Leo‰Ûªs abbess. An autocrat with a sadistic streak, the reverend mother enforces harsh discipline and seems to enjoy humiliating her young charges. She brooks no dissent and finds herself in conflict both with an independent-minded underling (Dianna Agron) and with the modernizing archbishop (Denis O‰ÛªHare). Another side of the reverend mother‰Ûªs personality ‰ÛÓ an intense religious devotion entwined with a quasi-feminist, anti-authoritarian streak ‰ÛÓ emerges late in the film, but rather than reveal the character‰Ûªs complexity it undermines the story‰Ûªs coherence.

The movie is on surer, more interesting ground when it explores Cathleen‰Ûªs inner life, her daily routines, and the camaraderie and rivalry that emerge among the novices. Discouraged from forming close friendships that might distract from their primary devotion, the young women, mostly still teenagers, behave in some of the usual ways for girls of their age. They gossip and share confidences and break rules carelessly or brazenly, all the while grappling, as most adolescents do, with deep and murky questions of identity.

In an ordinary movie this would set off a race-against-the-clock scenario. But ‰ÛÏFÌ©licitÌ©,‰Ûù written and directed by the Franco-Senegalese filmmaker Alain Gomis, is an unconventional treatment of an emergency.

Expressive, almost dreamlike dissolves figure in a particularly fraught homecoming scene. There are shots of an orchestra and a choir in Kinshasa rehearsing, and eventually performing, works by Arvo PÌ_rt. There are scenes in which FÌ©licitÌ© wanders a night forest alone. None of these tendrils feel affected, though. And Mr. Gomis has a sharp ear for the alarming way in which romantic transactions are negotiated between men and women in this milieu.

In ‰ÛÏFÌ©licitÌ©,‰Ûù VÌ©ro Tshanda Beya Mputu plays the title character, a singer and single mother in Kinshasa, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The movie opens in a lively bar, full of gyrating, intoxicated folk, whom FÌ©licitÌ© and the band entertain all night with infectious songs filled with blue notes. (The music is provided by the well-regarded Kasai Allstars.)

At crucial junctures in FÌ©licitÌ©‰Ûªs desperate scramble to raise funds for her son‰Ûªs medical care, Mr. Gomis, who wrote the screenplay with Olivier Loustau and Delphine Zingg, expands time instead of compressing it. FÌ©licitÌ© still has her job to do, after all. This movie aspires to depict real life, not life as cinema is often inclined to idealize it; by the same token, it is hardly a work of naturalism.

Mr. Gomis‰Ûªs cinematic style is spectacularly multifaceted. The camerawork and cutting often have the fleetness of a documentary, but there‰Ûªs nothing sloppy about them. (The cinematography is by CÌ©line Bozon, the editing by Fabrice Rouaud and the director.)

There is one sequence near the middle of the film, in which FÌ©licitÌ©, standing against a blue wall, hears more bad news about her son. She collapses, her back sliding down the wall, and the camera, staying near her head, follows her. There‰Ûªs a palpable immediacy to the scene; it resolves in a close-up of FÌ©licitÌ© that is as exquisitely framed as any shot from Carl Dreyer‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Passion of Joan of Arc.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏMarry me, mama; your life will improve,‰Ûù the handyman, Tabu (Papi Mpaka), says while working on the refrigerator. No sooner has he gotten that out then he adds, ‰ÛÏIf you forget me, I‰Ûªll strangle your little neck.‰Ûù They become lovers, and stable ones at that. This is one of the several illuminating and often moving surprises ‰ÛÏFÌ©licitÌ©‰Ûù delivers.

The next day, she‰Ûªs got troubles with her refrigerator and negotiations with a local handyman. Then, some bad news: Her teenage son has been grievously injured in a motorbike accident. He needs an immediate ‰ÛÓ and immediately paid-for ‰ÛÓ operation.

The story opens just as the Mayerses, Suburbicon‰Ûªs first black family, move into the area, an event the neighborhood treats as a collective home invasion. Women whisper and stare, men sputter and rage, and soon all their white faces have gone red. Before long, unneighborly clusters begin gathering around the family‰Ûªs home, edging around the perimeter and transforming it into a kind of stage. And then the fences go up, and the clusters develop into a pack. The whispers morph into jeers, and the progressively, dangerously impatient crowd howls for the show to begin. Any resemblance to the audience watching ‰ÛÏSuburbicon‰Ûù is as intentional as it is obvious.

The title refers to the ticky-tacky Potemkin suburb where it all goes down. You know the place: It‰Ûªs as American as apple pie and quiet desperation. It‰Ûªs the post-World War II wasteland with the identical homes, lawns and faces that has been grist for critique and caricature, novels and movies, ever since suburbs were invented. In ‰ÛÏLittle Boxes,‰Ûù a 1960s lament about conformity, Pete Seeger warbles about that sprawling wasteland, where all the ‰ÛÏboys go into business and marry and raise a family.‰Ûù That these little boxes look a lot like coffins gives his song the tenor of a dirge, one that ‰ÛÏSuburbicon‰Ûù delivers anew with cruel laughter, violent enthusiasm and acres of dark-wood paneling.

The greater, graver flaw, though, the one that empties ‰ÛÏSuburbicon‰Ûù out and turns it into a mannerist exercise, is that the movie reproduces the inequality it‰Ûªs ostensibly outraged by. This has less to do with star power and everything to do with emphasis and interest.
