It‰Ûªs an alluring milieu ‰ÛÓ charming, civilized and perfectly, if a shade too flawlessly, arranged. Here, even a busy breakfast table and the fruit on a tree can seem art directed. Mr. Guadagnino almost can‰Ûªt help making everything look intoxicating, yet he also makes you believe in this family‰Ûªs reality. The grand piano isn‰Ûªt for show and neither are the books or the open affection and respect with which Elio and his parents treat one another. (The movie reminds you how rarely characters read for pleasure, much less listen to classical music.) ‰ÛÏCall Me by Your Name‰Ûù is set in 1983, so no one is staring into a smartphone. And the time frame means that AIDS doesn‰Ûªt figure in the story, though there‰Ûªs a suggestion that the closet does.

Written by James Ivory (the director of films like ‰ÛÏMaurice‰Ûù), ‰ÛÏCall Me by Your Name‰Ûù progresses through evasions and encounters, with Elio advancing, Oliver receding and their circling narrowing. The two don‰Ûªt (can‰Ûªt, won‰Ûªt) always say what they mean. So Mr. Guadagnino speaks for them by eroticizing their world, making desire visible in the luxuriousness of the setting, in the green enveloping the villa, the gushing waters of a pool and the graceful lines of male statues. When Oliver hungrily eats a soft-boiled egg, cracking the shell and causing the yolk to messily spurt, Mr. Guadagnino‰Ûªs lyricism slides into comedy; it‰Ûªs hard to know just how self-mocking the moment is meant to be.

The story primarily unfolds through Elio‰Ûªs point of view. The restless camera tags alongside him, showing you what he sees, his erotic reveries and yearning. And it‰Ûªs Elio who initiates the affair, at least overtly, though Oliver later admits to playing his part in what the story frames as a mutual seduction. Mr. Guadagnino avoids directly engaging the difference in Elio and Oliver‰Ûªs ages, which might have forced him to explore the underside of his sumptuous surfaces to greater, messier effect. Instead, Mr. Guadagnino leans on beauty, as when Elio‰Ûªs father poetically speaks to an increasingly agitated Oliver about the ‰ÛÏageless ambiguity‰Ûù of some male statues (‰ÛÏas if they‰Ûªre daring you to desire them‰Ûù).

Mr. Guadagnino is very good at catching the indolent drift of long summer days, with their sleepiness and bared limbs. Everyone seems to move in slow motion at the villa, except perhaps the family‰Ûªs hard-working maid. This languor fits the tempo of Elio and Oliver‰Ûªs relationship, which evolves over meals, drowsy idylls, a little work and a spontaneous piano recital that becomes an overture to seduction. A gifted musician, Elio easily moves from piano to guitar (much as his family shifts from speaking Italian to French to English), talent that makes him seem at one with the villa‰Ûªs miles of bookshelves, its velvet sofas, scattered Oriental rugs and tastefully arranged antiques.

You don‰Ûªt just watch Luca Guadagnino‰Ûªs movies, you swoon into them. His best-known titles, ‰ÛÏI Am Love‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏA Bigger Splash,‰Ûù feature beautiful people with impeccable taste experiencing haute-bourgeois life intensely. Passion and drama upend those lives, but what‰Ûªs most striking about these movies is their extraordinary palpable quality. In Mr. Guadagnino‰Ûªs work, passion and drama are expressed in words, deeds and surging music but also in the vibrant, visceral textures that envelop his characters ‰ÛÓ the cool marble, succulent fruit, shadow and light, sheens of sweat. These are movies that turn your gaze into near-touch, inviting you to see and almost caress their sun-warmed bodies.

Mr. Guadagnino‰Ûªs latest, ‰ÛÏCall Me by Your Name,‰Ûù is another ravishment of the senses, though this time there‰Ûªs a strong narrative tethering all the churning feelings and sensuous surfaces. Like the 2007 novel by AndrÌ© Aciman on which it‰Ûªs based, the story turns on an affair between Elio Perlman (TimothÌ©e Chalamet), a coltish 17-year-old American-Italian, and Oliver (Armie Hammer), an American in his 20s. Elio lives with his father (a tremendous Michael Stuhlbarg) and mother (Amira Casar) in a villa in northern Italy. Each summer the father, a professor of Greco-Roman culture, invites a student to work with him and stay with his family; this year it‰Ûªs Oliver who moves in.

Elio and Oliver‰Ûªs affair begins slowly with each circling the other at a distance, conveying the kind of nonchalance that‰Ûªs a shield for interest. Oliver proves far better at this part of the game; he knows more than to look too long and too hard. Elio‰Ûªs furtive, ducking glances, by contrast, tend to linger, hovering in the air like questions. He‰Ûªs increasingly curious about this new guest, but soon inexplicably (to Elio, at least) irked by him as well, leading Elio to complain to his parents about Oliver‰Ûªs standard signoff (‰ÛÏlater‰Ûù). But when Elio scribbles a private rebuke in a notebook, chastising himself for responding harshly toward Oliver, it‰Ûªs as if he were writing an apologetic love letter.

‰ÛÏAny girl can be glamorous,‰Ûù the actress Hedy Lamarr once said. ‰ÛÏAll you have to do is stand still and look stupid.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs a withering observation, especially for a Hollywood star once known as ‰ÛÏthe most beautiful woman in the world.‰Ûù Beauty brought Lamarr fame, at least until everything fell spectacularly apart; as with too many actresses, beauty was also her gilded cage. The new documentary ‰ÛÏBombshell: The Hedy Lamarr Story‰Ûù shows how hard and how long she struggled to escape it ‰ÛÓ including through her invention in the 1940s of a groundbreaking communication system that underlies modern encryption.

Lamarr‰Ûªs subsequent tenure in Hollywood comes across as tame by comparison. There were tasty and dreary roles, missed opportunities and heartbreak. She married again (and then four more times) and raised a few children, one of whom she treated unspeakably. She also tinkered and she invented. At home, Lamarr had what her biographer Richard Rhodes, one of the movie‰Ûªs on-camera experts, describes as an inventing table. Howard Hughes gave her a small version of this setup, Mr. Rhodes explains, that was kept in the trailer she used while shooting films. Hughes also lent her a few of his chemists for one of her projects; for her part, Lamarr counseled him on a plane design.

Over Lamarr‰Ûªs lifetime, the brilliance of her discovery was overshadowed by the spectacle of failure as her stardom gave way to forgettable roles, misfires, catastrophes and more scandal. ‰ÛÏBombshell‰Ûù sympathetically tracks her downward spiral without reducing her to the sum of her misfortunes. That‰Ûªs a relief and seems right given how tough and proud Lamarr can sound in the interviews. Back in 1942, in that breathless story about her invention, Lamarr insisted that she hadn‰Ûªt changed. ‰ÛÏI‰Ûªve always been as I am today,‰Ûù she said. ‰ÛÏIf I am a ‰Û÷new Hedy‰Ûª as some say, it is because they are seeing me as I really am, not looking at the outside of me.‰Ûù History finally figured out that she was right.

By the time Mr. Meeks wrote about Lamarr, she was in her 70s and no longer of use to Hollywood. That part of her story is bleakly familiar; it‰Ûªs a sad, maddening movie-industry refrain, especially for older actresses. Another hurdle, as ‰ÛÏBombshell‰Ûù makes clear, is that a female performer who subverted expectations ‰ÛÓ who was smart and not just lovely ‰ÛÓ wasn‰Ûªt welcome in the world. Some of the period coverage of Lamarr‰Ûªs invention attests to this. ‰ÛÏIt does seem incredible that anyone as beautiful and as fragile-looking as the luscious Hedy could be mechanically minded,‰Ûù one 1942 magazine story trumpeted, adding that ‰ÛÏshe can sing, has a flare for designing and interior decorating.‰Ûù

Ms. Dean relates Lamarr‰Ûªs ventures, those onscreen and off, with savvy and narrative snap, fluidly marshaling a mix of original interviews and archival material that includes film clips, home movies and other footage. Ms. Dean‰Ûªs most valuable resource, though, are Lamarr‰Ûªs taped interviews with Fleming Meeks, a journalist. In a 1990 Forbes article, he helped refurbish her legend by recounting how some 50 years earlier Lamarr ‰ÛÓ who wanted to contribute to the war effort ‰ÛÓ created a communication system with her friend, the composer George Antheil. What she was after was a radio-controlled torpedo that couldn‰Ûªt be jammed. Her solution: randomly switched frequencies.

By 1938, Hedy Kiesler had been renamed Hedy Lamarr, and she was under contract to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and starring alongside Charles Boyer in the romantic thriller ‰ÛÏAlgiers.‰Ûù It was Boyer‰Ûªs show; Lamarr was a side dish. In his review of the film, the critic Otis Ferguson all but shrugged her off as ‰ÛÏthe girl,‰Ûù while movie magazine writers slobbered over her looks. ‰ÛÏNo more beautiful woman,‰Ûù one columnist gushed, ‰ÛÏhas ever stormed the doors of moviedom than Hedy, grey-eyed, raven-haired Viennese known as the ‰Û÷Ecstasy Girl.‰Ûª‰Ûù Four years later, Lamarr was still battling such typecasting blather, despite having patented a secret communications system called frequency hopping.

Directed by Alexandra Dean, ‰ÛÏBombshell‰Ûù is a very enjoyable addition to what has become a minor Hedy Lamarr industry that includes documentaries, books and stage productions. Like some of these other accounts, this documentary traces the arcs of Lamarr‰Ûªs personal and professional lives, which by turns harmoniously converged and wildly veered in opposite directions. Whatever happened, it was rarely dull. The daughter of assimilated Jews, she married a munitions magnate who came with a castle and did business with Mussolini. When she decided to ditch her husband, she staged (or so she claimed) an escape that turned her into the heroine of her own thrilling adventure.

The story of that invention has been told before though it‰Ûªs curiously missing from Lamarr‰Ûªs contribution to a dubious 1966 memoir, ‰ÛÏEcstasy and Me: My Life as a Woman,‰Ûù which, bizarrely, includes an introduction by a shrink. (She unsuccessfully tried to stop its publication.) The title refers to the 1933 film that set her on the path toward scandal and stardom. Directed by Gustav Machaty, ‰ÛÏEcstasy‰Ûù involves a young woman‰Ûªs sexual desire and disappointment, and remains best known for the sight of its teenage Viennese star ‰ÛÓ then called Hedy Kiesler ‰ÛÓ frolicking naked and, more notoriously, feigning orgasm. (Machaty apparently jabbed her with a pin to achieve the desired writhing.)

Among them is a little girl who Mr. Alpert tracks down decades after first photographing her, discovering a single mother of two trying to leave the island. Once she does, Mr. Alpert follows the children she left behind. There‰Ûªs also Luis, an amiable slum resident who Mr. Alpert misses on one visit because he‰Ûªs doing prison time for working the black market ‰ÛÓ an activity he cheerfully returns to on his release. Most memorable are Angel, Gregorio and Cristobal, three farming brothers who are able to beat Mr. Alpert at arm wrestling well into old age.

In part because of its political blind spots, ‰ÛÏCuba and the Cameraman‰Ûù is captivating. (Whatever you think of Mr. Alpert‰Ûªs perspective, it‰Ûªs interesting.) But it‰Ûªs mostly worth watching because of human stories like these.

The cameraman in ‰ÛÏCuba and the Cameraman‰Ûù is the indefatigable documentary filmmaker Jon Alpert, the director of the movie. Which begins inside a car, in Havana in 2016, as the death of Fidel Castro is announced on state radio. The streets are nearly empty and have a haunted quality. Havana has seen a lot of change, but in some ways it still earns its reputation for being frozen in time.

Mr. Alpert‰Ûªs friendliness toward Castro and many of his policies will no doubt infuriate some viewers (the authoritarian regime‰Ûªs human rights abuses are not addressed). But even those frustrated by Mr. Alpert‰Ûªs politics will appreciate the ordinary Cuban lives he captured on his visits.

Mr. Alpert‰Ûªs movie is a personal examination of the ways Cuba changed and did not change over the course of the 45 years he has been visiting and filming there, shooting over 1,000 hours of footage in the country and even accompanying Castro on one memorable trip to the United States.

The director‰Ûªs story begins with cofounding the Downtown Community Television Center, where he used scrappy video equipment to expose sweatshops and chronicle labor struggles in New York. His interest in Cuba grew out of his activism: ‰ÛÏWe heard that Fidel Castro was implementing the social programs that we were fighting for here in New York,‰Ûù Mr. Alpert states plainly.

He doesn‰Ûªt explain how he, an American, was able to enter Cuba for his first visits, when he toured schools and hospitals set up by what he calls ‰ÛÏthe revolution.‰Ûù Later on, he was on the plane with Castro when he flew to New York to address the United Nations in 1979. In these and other scenes, Castro demonstrates his much bruited charisma, playing to Mr. Alpert‰Ûªs camera in a slyly ingratiating way.

‰ÛÏI was becoming chauvinistic and fascist, too,‰Ûù he admits of his behavior. At the end of that tunnel was a sobriety that was, some might say, cruelly tested by the death of Conor. As a musical biography, this comes up short; it plays substantially better as a story of recovery and recovered integrity.

As the title, ‰ÛÏEric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars,‰Ûù implies, it begins with the blues. In narration, Mr. Clapton talks of being practically mesmerized by music by African-American musicians he heard on the radio as a child. Obsessed, he picked up a guitar and started imitating the players he loved, including B.B. King and Little Walter, whose harmonica sounds he wanted to adapt to guitar. Music helped him cope with, or at least mentally escape, a confusing home life, one in which he initially believed his mother was an older sister.

The first half of the movie is largely a 1960s ‰ÛÏand then I wrote/played‰Ûù story that is more interested in Mr. Clapton‰Ûªs romantic obsession with Pattie Boyd, the then-wife of his then-best-friend George Harrison, than with Mr. Clapton‰Ûªs seemingly constitutional inability to stick with one band for any length of time ‰ÛÓ although the two things may not be entirely unrelated, in terms of temperament at least. The pursuit of Ms. Boyd did yield one of the most notable classic rock albums ever, ‰ÛÏLayla,‰Ûù and its making is given a considered treatment here. But Mr. Clapton‰Ûªs work with the American roots rockers Delaney & Bonnie, and his first solo album, both stage-setters for ‰ÛÏLayla,‰Ûù are completely ignored.

The second half of the film, though, shows exemplary frankness in revealing how drugs and alcohol brought out the very worst in Mr. Clapton in the 1970s. His reprehensible racist remarks, his abuse of friends and band mates, and more, is laid out in practically unsparing detail.

Ms. Zanuck takes an unusual approach to the music documentary. She has no talking-head interviews; the visual component is entirely composed of archival footage, of either the still or moving-picture variety. Interviewees are tagged with onscreen titles. (Roger Waters is erroneously presented as the guitarist for Pink Floyd; he was its bass player.)

The producer and director Lili Fini Zanuck used Eric Clapton‰Ûªs recording ‰ÛÏTears in Heaven‰Ûù in a scene of mourning for her 1991 movie ‰ÛÏRush.‰Ûù The song‰Ûªs origins are heartbreaking: Mr. Clapton wrote it after his 4-year-old son, Conor, died in a fall from a building in the spring of that year. Now Ms. Zanuck has made, in her second feature film as director, a documentary on Mr. Clapton‰Ûªs life that takes into consideration the many turning points in the classic rock legend‰Ûªs career.

In between interviews, ‰ÛÏAl Di Qua,‰Ûù written and directed by Corrado Franco, offers a narrative line of sorts, as the cast members gather at a hospital to pay tribute to Rodolfo, a dead comrade. In the strangest of many strange aesthetic decisions, the voices have been slowed down to give the dialogue a baritone sound, as if a combination of (mostly) black-and-white shooting, a fragmented structure, sporadic slow motion, quotations from Rainer Maria Rilke, Godardian title cards and absurdly gratuitous overlays of Bach weren‰Ûªt portentous enough.

The film‰Ûªs official materials cite Vittorio De Sica and Pier Paolo Pasolini as inspirations. ‰ÛÏAl Di Qua‰Ûù has other antecedents, too, from Lionel Rogosin‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏOn the Bowery‰Ûù (1957) to the Fontainhas films of Pedro Costa ‰ÛÓ all movies about poverty that combine fiction and documentary elements.

Freely departing from documentary conventions, ‰ÛÏAl Di Qua‰Ûù casts the homeless of Turin as themselves (or close approximations). Identified by their first names, they tell their stories to the camera: We hear how they came to Turin, how they became homeless, what they dream of and how they feel about ‰ÛÏal di qua‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a phrase translated in the subtitles as ‰ÛÏlife/here‰Ûù that, in this context, seems understood more simply as ‰ÛÏlife as they see it.‰Ûù

But Mr. Rogosin was a gifted filmmaker, as is Mr. Costa. ‰ÛÏAl Di Qua‰Ûù is so showy in its stylistic choices and glacial in its pace ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs tempting to applaud every time the camera finally rounds a corner ‰ÛÓ that it comes across as amateurish. The film seems pitched at an audience that has never heard of homelessness: Every shot is composed to evoke acknowledgment of the subjects‰Ûª dignity, even while individual personalities are subsumed into the blur of Mr. Franco‰Ûªs operatic ambitions. However worthy or political its intent, ‰ÛÏAl Di Qua‰Ûù is too overwrought to seem anything but trivializing.

It‰Ûªs also a story of camaraderie; among Mr. Lewis‰Ûªs Neapolitan friends was a man who made money posing as a fancy uncle from Rome at funerals. But colorful details like that don‰Ûªt change the sense that ‰ÛÏNaples ‰Ûª44‰Ûù is essentially an abridged version of a much more detailed work. It seems less a full-fledged movie than a trailer for a book.

A feat of editing and research, ‰ÛÏNaples ‰Ûª44,‰Ûù directed by Francesco Patierno, is taken from a 1978 memoir by Norman Lewis. As a British intelligence officer during World War II, Mr. Lewis was stationed in Naples after the Allied Forces‰Ûª invasion of nearby Salerno in September 1943. An able translator, he helped the military communicate with the civilian population.

This aesthetic choice ‰ÛÓ along with useless snippets of an actor, not clearly identified as such, playing Mr. Lewis as an old man returning to the city ‰ÛÓ doesn‰Ûªt always seem fitting. You may at times wonder if Mr. Lewis, who died in 2003, would have chosen some of these clips. But the selection does lend an effective visual dimension to Mr. Lewis‰Ûªs tales of wartime strife in the city. We hear of a lack of food and clean water; how Neapolitans resorted to prostitution and to buying goods on the black market; and how disease ran rampant through the city, taking it back to an almost medieval state. Mr. Lewis remembers the devastation of delayed-action explosive devices left by the Germans and the ‰ÛÏslag heap‰Ûù from the eruption of Vesuvius, just southeast of Naples, in March 1944.

On the evidence of the film, he also served as a remarkable chronicler of life in the occupied city. His plain-spoken yet poetic sentences (‰ÛÏNow the statues are disappearing from the public squares, and one cemetery has lost most of its tombstones‰Ûù) are read in voice-over by Benedict Cumberbatch, and the fluid editing skillfully illustrates his words with disparate material ‰ÛÓ a mix that includes archival footage and movies like Roberto Rossellini‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏPaisan,‰Ûù Mike Nichols‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏCatch-22‰Ûù and Liliana Cavani‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Skin.‰Ûù

Still, ‰ÛÏ32 Pills‰Ûù makes clear how Ruth‰Ûªs personality, coupled with her seemingly endless photographs, writings and drawings, created the temptation. The film explores the notion that the sisters were troubled in different ways. And as the excavation continues, predictably ‰ÛÓ maybe even subconsciously ‰ÛÓ Hope‰Ûªs own health issues resurface.

The exchange sums up what‰Ûªs queasily fascinating about ‰ÛÏ32 Pills.‰Ûù Without Hope‰Ûªs relapse, the movie would be too personal: something for family, friends and a therapist. But the more Hope‰Ûªs own obsession grows, the more involving the movie gets, even as it raises ethical questions about its making ‰ÛÓ and about those who continue to watch.

Ms. Litoff, a film editor, begins by investigating the storage space filled with the belongings of her sister, Ruth, an artist who committed suicide in 2008. Hope wants to find something illuminating, though the prospect that Ruth, who had a long history of mental illness, left some sort of Rosebud is a dubious proposition.

Pivoting on the exceptionally fine line that separates TMI from brave self-revelation, ‰ÛÏ32 Pills: My Sister‰Ûªs Suicide‰Ûù is tough viewing. Even by the end, it hasn‰Ûªt made a good case for its existence. Still, Hope Litoff‰Ûªs documentary becomes more voyeuristically gripping as it progresses.

A recovered alcoholic, Hope shoots chilling video-diary footage of her first drink in 16 years. She pops two pills from a table covered with her sister‰Ûªs leftover prescription medication bottles. ‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs something about the fact that they‰Ûªre Ruth‰Ûªs pills that make them feel more special to me,‰Ûù she says. Her producer, Beth Levison, who is present, expresses alarm about becoming an enabler.

We meet Mr. Ingels‰Ûªs parents in Denmark, where the architect recalls his early aspirations as a cartoonist, then watch the Maritime Museum‰Ûªs unveiling in 2013, and BIG‰Ûªs opening in Manhattan in 2015. Major New York real estate players testify to his brilliance, and we see the buff Mr. Ingels bicycling around Manhattan wearing sunglasses and headphones. A party for his employees, presented in slow motion, evokes nightclub glamour.

Tension is minimal. After Mr. Ingels has received a concussion from a baseball bat (an incident not elaborated upon), he frets about an M.R.I. and the circumstances behind the deaths of the architectural giants Le Corbusier, Louis Kahn and Eero Saarinen. But his fears prove unwarranted. We see little of his personal life besides his spacious loft and, briefly, his doting girlfriend, another architect. Unmentioned is Mr. Schroder‰Ûªs 2009 documentary about parkour, ‰ÛÏMy Playground,‰Ûù in which Mr. Ingels and his structures play a part. Clearly, the architect and the filmmaker are tight, which does not entirely benefit ‰ÛÏBig Time.‰Ûù

Cool and competent, Kaspar Astrup Schroder‰Ûªs documentary ‰ÛÏBig Time,‰Ûù an adoring profile of the Danish ‰ÛÏstarchitect‰Ûù Bjarke Ingels, merely glances at human drama. The aesthetic of Mr. Ingels ‰ÛÓ whose firm, BIG (for Bjarke Ingels Group), has triumphed with designs like that for the M/S Maritime Museum of Denmark in Helsingor; the Via 57 West complex in Manhattan; and the in-progress Two World Trade Center ‰ÛÓ has a youthful, playful audacity (he is only in his 40s). Mr. Schroder‰Ûªs film seems expressly designed to further burnish Mr. Ingels‰Ûªs reputation.

The rap artist Azealia Banks plays Coco, an aspiring hip-hop musician whose crew, the self-dubbed ‰ÛÏStaten Island‰Ûªs Finest,‰Ûù is stalled with no record label interest. Her bandmate Malik (John David Washington) proves a faithless boyfriend, and Coco doesn‰Ûªt split from the group, but does distance herself from it. ‰ÛÏYou want to rap? That‰Ûªs fine with me,‰Ûù Coco‰Ûªs no-nonsense mother advises. ‰ÛÏBut from now on you‰Ûªre going to have to do it between classes.‰Ûù

At the small college where Coco studies accounting, she is led by her friend Julie (Hana Mae Lee) to a poetry class headed by the imperious, glamorous Professor Dixon (Jill Scott) and her handsome, young British-accented teaching assistant Derek (Lucien Laviscount). Both insist to Coco that rap and poetry are different things. She defiantly sets to prove them wrong, only to discover that in a way they‰Ûªre right.

The script by Nicole Jefferson Asher toggles between sharp observations about wordcraft and some ‰ÛÏDynasty‰Ûù- or Tyler Perry-level soap operatics. RZA‰Ûªs direction lacks visual personality, but he keeps the narrative moving and elicits strong performances from his cast. The rap battle and poetry slams take place in settings that are brightly lit and ‰ÛÓ a few tetchy spats between rivals romantic and artistic notwithstanding ‰ÛÓ relaxed. The dangerous, poverty- and drug-plagued Staten Island from which RZA‰Ûªs own music sprang feels very far away. But the director‰Ûªs comfortable approach to his material and its milieu seems unforced, and yields a frequently enjoyable movie.

Anyone coming into ‰ÛÏLove Beats Rhymes‰Ûù expecting to find some continuity with 2012‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Man With the Iron Fists,‰Ûù the prior and first feature film directed by the hip-hop luminary RZA, may well be confounded. ‰ÛÏIron Fists,‰Ûù in which the founding member of Wu-Tang Clan also starred, was a not entirely successful meta-martial arts picture buoyed by some imaginative idiosyncrasy. ‰ÛÏLove Beats Rhymes‰Ûù is a contemporary romantic drama that‰Ûªs very grounded in a conventional personal-growth narrative.

Scarcely more welcoming is the dimly lighted, coldly luxurious apartment where Zhenya and her boyfriend sedately fornicate, or the barricaded dwelling of her estranged, viperish mother. A tone of fraught pessimism accumulates, swelling into sociopolitical allegory as, in the background, the country‰Ûªs deteriorating relationship with Ukraine plays out on the evening news and journalists are vilified for inciting end-of-days hysteria. It‰Ûªs a grimly cynical view of modern Russia that‰Ûªs inarguably blunt (especially in an extended shot of Zhenya, running on a treadmill to nowhere, the word ‰ÛÏRussia‰Ûù emblazoned on her sweatsuit) but no less chilling for that.

With its fastidious framing and angry-tough temperament, ‰ÛÏLoveless‰Ûù (a title distilled in a single image of a child‰Ûªs violated, unclaimed corpse) earns its air of careful foreboding. Again and again, Mikhail Krichman‰Ûªs camera creeps forward as if about to reveal something frightful while we stare, hearts in mouths. The trick is shamelessly manipulative, but it lends the movie an ominousness that‰Ûªs powerfully magnetic. Boris and Zhenya may have behaved despicably, but their spiritual rot doesn‰Ûªt exist in a vacuum. When the state loses its humanity, Mr. Zvyagintsev seems to be asking, how long can its citizens hold on to theirs?

Unfolding beneath skies the color and density of damp concrete, ‰ÛÏLoveless,‰Ûù the fifth feature from the Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev (after his notable 2014 drama, ‰ÛÏLeviathan‰Ûù), uses a toxic marriage to paint a larger portrait of decay, dereliction and moral detachment.

Initially, no one notices. Distracted by new lovers ‰ÛÓ and, in Boris‰Ûªs case, a religious boss who will probably fire him if he learns of the divorce ‰ÛÓ the couple is slow to contact the police. A lugubrious detective laments official ineptitude in missing-child cases, and a volunteer search group is contacted. The hunt transforms the movie into a wintry document of decline, as the orange-vested team tramps through echoing buildings, a frozen forest and a dank and dripping ruin ‰ÛÓ spaces at best inhospitable, and at worst deadly, to a distraught boy.

And oh, his gaze is pitiless. Set in Moscow in the autumn of 2012, the picture sits on the screen with an almost physical weight, its heaviness as much to do with the bleakly beautiful visuals and painstaking pacing as the bitter divorce at its center. Boris and Zhenya (Alexey Rozin and Maryana Spivak) loathe each other, their vitriol pouring over their 12-year-old son (Matvey Novikov) like lava. Sobbing silently out of sight, the boy listens to his parents argue over who will be saddled with the child that neither wants. Then he disappears.

Complicating the claustrophobic arrangement is the fact that Hassan has married Ali‰Ûªs old flame, Fatma (Nahed El Sebai). She still longs for Ali, a strapping, handsome contrast to her kind but ineffectual husband, while the oblivious Hassan tries to arrange a marriage for his cousin.

What follows combines a bit of James M. Cain and a bit of ‰ÛÏMacbeth‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and more than a bit of topicality, since the events in the film, though they unfold away from Cairo, overlap with the Tahrir Square demonstrations of 2011. (The revolution weighs heavily on the wealthy Mourad and divides him politically from his children.)

‰ÛÏSins of the Flesh,‰Ûù an Egyptian feature from Khaled El Hagar, opens with Ali (Ahmed Abdala Mahomud) on the run, having escaped prison seven years into a 25-year sentence for a murder that may have involved extenuating circumstances. Hiding out, he takes a job alongside a cousin, a farmworker named Hassan (Mahmoud El Bezawi). Hassan‰Ûªs boss, Mourad (Zaki Faten), a respected landowner, seems decent enough at first: He allows Ali to stay. But he also counts on total subservience.

But the movie is somewhat labored and repetitive as a piece of screenwriting, spelling out motivations when the power of suggestion might go further, and its purported allegorical dimensions don‰Ûªt come across clearly. No doubt subtleties have been lost in translation, but the film is best viewed as an overripe, noir-tinged tragedy.

Reading or hearing about the life of LoÌøe Fuller, the American-born actor, inventor and dancer whose performances entranced belle epoque Paris of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, one is apt to think, ‰ÛÏThis could be a spectacular movie.‰Ûù One hopes that future filmmakers are not dissuaded from making that movie on account of the existence of this glum biopic directed by StÌ©phanie Di Giusto, who wrote the screenplay with Sarah Thibau.

In Fuller‰Ûªs signature piece, termed the ‰ÛÏSerpentine Dance,‰Ûù she transformed her body into a moving, three-dimensional work of op art by means of choreography, elaborate costuming and lighting effects that Fuller herself patented.

This movie, which stars StÌ©phanie Sokolinski, the French musician known as Soko, in the role of Fuller, only comes alive during the dance sequences. Ms. Di Giusto takes considerable liberties with the facts of Fuller‰Ûªs life, giving her an entirely fictional male patron whose decadent ether addiction is out of a bad ‰ÛÏDorian Gray‰Ûù parody. (It‰Ûªs not much of a role, and Gaspard Ulliel, who was very good in 2014‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSaint Laurent,‰Ûù makes very little of it.) In Ms. Di Giusto‰Ûªs vision, Fuller is outshined by Isadora Duncan, portrayed by Lily-Rose Depp as a shallow arriviste. Ms. Depp‰Ûªs flat line readings are, in this respect, appropriate.

Rather than depicting the milieu in which Fuller thrived, Ms. Di Giusto mainly confines the action to a villa where Fuller endures sickness and a series of self-fulfilling romantic humiliations. She then watches as Duncan goes on to eclipse her. In commemorating the work of a female artist by largely refracting it through an imagined professional rivalry with another female artist, ‰ÛÏThe Dancer‰Ûù seems genuinely hostile to its subject, whose real-life accomplishments deserve better.

Jonatan Relayze‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏRosa Chumbe‰Ûù can feel too hopeless to watch. It‰Ûªs the story of a police officer, Rosa (Liliana Trujillo), who‰Ûªs struggling with alcoholism and a gambling addiction while living with her daughter and grandson in Lima, Peru. Things are clearly not going well. Rosa falls into drunken stupors almost daily while watching late-night TV. Those hazy moments are among the few times she laughs. One night, after a fight with Rosa, her daughter Sheyla leaves her baby in her mother‰Ûªs obviously unreliable care.

The movie, messily constructed, seems more fascinated with the tragedy of these two women‰Ûªs parallel struggles than it does with the characters themselves. They become walking metaphors in search of a story arc. Then there‰Ûªs a deus ex machina that throws into question everything we‰Ûªve seen in the movie up to that point. It‰Ûªs a radically upbeat note that‰Ûªs too contrived in an otherwise desolate situation.

Although ‰ÛÏRosa Chumbe‰Ûù is Peru‰Ûªs foreign language film entry for the Oscars this year, the movie doesn‰Ûªt feel like it warrants that distinction. The women‰Ûªs missteps seem to come straight out of a cautionary tale. And the movie‰Ûªs dismal outlook even extends to the dimly-lit cinematography. It doesn‰Ûªt need a miracle to see the light. It needs a full pardon.

A little after the ascendance of Julian Schnabel set the tone for the boom years of the New York art world of the 1980s, the three people making the most noise were Jean-Michel Basquiat, Keith Haring and Richard Hambleton.

In later years, we see him scurrying through his studio‰Ûªs corridors, practically hunchbacked, a Band-Aid seeming to hold his nose to his face. This intense documentary shows a driven creator walking the walk, so to speak, in the most perverse fashion possible. The story is both repellent and strangely inspiring.

But he never stopped painting, even making works with his own blood on paper during a heroin-driven period when he was living in a single room with two women. Friends and patrons, most of them interviewed here, interceded. Mr. Hambleton got skin cancer and had scoliosis.
One interviewee posits that death turned out to be a good career move for Basquiat and Haring. Mr. Hambleton, by dint of staying alive, never sold at extravagant prices.

Basquiat died in 1988 of a heroin overdose. This year, a painting of his sold for $110.5 million. Haring died in 1990 of AIDS; his works regularly sell in the low millions. As for Mr. Hambleton, who for years had cancer that he declined to treat, he died recently, in a cheap residence in Chinatown. According to ‰ÛÏShadowman,‰Ûù a fascinating, harrowing film about his life, he was still painting until he died.

The movie, directed by Oren Jacoby, begins with black-and-white, night-shot video of Mr. Hambleton stalking the Lower East Side, paint can and brush in hand, and making instant silhouettes on building walls. These shadow paintings were different from graffiti, he insisted. They created a sensation, and Mr. Hambleton, who had begun in Vancouver, British Columbia, doing sidewalk ‰ÛÏmurder paintings‰Ûù in which chalk outlines of bodies were spattered with blood-red paint, got caught up in the underground arts scene‰Ûªs attendant vices.

Written by Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber, ‰ÛÏThe Disaster Artist‰Ûù is a straighter, more obviously commercial-minded project than some of the other movies that Mr. Franco has directed. It‰Ûªs a divertingly funny movie, but its breeziness can also feel overstated, at times glib and a bit of a dodge. In ‰ÛÏThe Room,‰Ûù Mr. Wiseau comes across as somewhat menacing, with an underlying intensity that can‰Ûªt be entirely laughed away. (That‰Ûªs part of what makes the unwatchable almost watchable.) Mr. Franco‰Ûªs performance keeps you hooked, in large degree because of its entertaining visual spectacle. Tommy‰Ûªs wardrobe, for one, suggests a commitment to the 1980s and a familiarity with the defunct catalog International Male, a source for padded briefs and Jack Sparrow frippery.

An ode to bad taste and dubious intentions, the ha-ha comedy ‰ÛÏThe Disaster Artist‰Ûù involves one of the favorite topics of the movies: itself. It‰Ûªs another story of crushed Hollywood dreams, one that unfolds through the eyes of Greg Sestero (Dave Franco), an aspiring actor who hitched himself to a phenomenon when he met Tommy Wiseau (James Franco, Dave‰Ûªs brother). A would-be auteur, the real Mr. Wiseau became a minor cult figure after he released a 2003 specialty item, ‰ÛÏThe Room,‰Ûù that some anointed the worst movie ever made. In time, its notoriety started to pay off; in 2013, Mr. Sestero wrote a tell-all book.

Mr. Wiseau has made the most of his 15 minutes, which have already been generously extended by ‰ÛÏThe Disaster Artist.‰Ûù His website for ‰ÛÏThe Room‰Ûù suggests that he‰Ûªs a busy man. It lists where and how you can see the film, sometimes with him in attendance. In the synergistic spirit of Disney (but with lavish misspellings), the website also features a line of tie-in products like ‰ÛÏRoom‰Ûù-themed watches, backpacks, jackets and men‰Ûªs briefs emblazoned with Mr. Wiseau‰Ûªs name on the waistband. It‰Ûªs funny and somewhat depressing, which also pretty much sums up the ‰ÛÏThe Room,‰Ûù one of those cultish attractions that is so terrible it makes you wonder if the laugh finally is on us.

Yet if Mr. Wiseau is a bona fide eccentric, he proves to be not an especially interesting one in this incarnation. The filmmakers try to complicate Tommy, including with some self-referential layering that never meaningfully develops. At one point early on, Greg and Tommy visit the site where James Dean died, a pilgrimage that at once nods to Mr. Franco‰Ûªs breakthrough role as Dean and telegraphs one of the more ludicrous scenes in ‰ÛÏThe Room.‰Ûù Dean becomes Greg and Tommy‰Ûªs inspiration, a success story that they invoke while struggling to make it. But there‰Ûªs no sense that either remotely grasps Dean‰Ûªs art, which might have made their failure and ‰ÛÏThe Disaster Artist‰Ûù more resonant.

An odd, inexplicable friendship begins, and before long Greg and Tommy are driving from San Francisco to Los Angeles, where much of the story takes place. Shacked up in Tommy‰Ûªs apartment, the two men try and fail to break into the entertainment business, though Greg manages to sign with a talent agency. Hope fades, as it does, amid the sunshine and smiles, and this movie slips into idle. Tommy continues to prove his lack of talent in a very funny and terrible audition; Greg finds romance with a bartender, Amber (Alison Brie). At last, inspired by Greg, Tommy ‰ÛÓ who has mysteriously deep pockets that never seem to empty ‰ÛÓ decides to direct and star in his own movie, with Greg as backup. It‰Ûªs a personal vision that eventually spirals into a mutual hallucination.

Based on that tell-all (which Mr. Sestero wrote with Tom Bissell), ‰ÛÏThe Disaster Artist‰Ûù recounts both the making of a friendship and the absurdly inept movie it produced. Greg meets Tommy in acting class, where they‰Ûªre both bombing out. Greg comes off as simply incompetent as he flatly fumbles through a scene from ‰ÛÏWaiting for Godot,‰Ûù one of the movie‰Ûªs first jokey meta-moments. (‰ÛÏLet us do something, while we have the chance!,‰Ûù Vladimir exclaims in ‰ÛÏGodot,‰Ûù much as Tommy soon urges Greg.) Tommy, by vivid contrast, captivates the agape class ‰ÛÓ particularly the inhibited Greg ‰ÛÓ by turning up the volume on Stanley Kowalski while thrashing about as if demonically possessed.

James Franco, who also directed ‰ÛÏThe Disaster Artist,‰Ûù swoops through the movie like a star, one who has no idea that he never achieved liftoff. His face framed by a dramatic curtain of inky black hair and noticeably if discreetly modified by prosthetics, Mr. Franco certainly looks the part and sounds it too, having perfectly captured Mr. Wiseau‰Ûªs puzzling accent and arrhythmic intonation. Yet even at its most convincing, Mr. Franco‰Ûªs performance retains an interior lightness, a playfulness, including when Tommy goes emotionally dark. Mr. Franco isn‰Ûªt making fun of his character, at least not entirely; rather, he‰Ûªs put distance into the mix, as if to point out that Tommy is very much a self-made man, a construction.

The making of ‰ÛÏThe Room‰Ûù gives ‰ÛÏThe Disaster Artist‰Ûù its point and much of its broad comedy. Filmmakers love making movies about movies, and Mr. Franco is no exception. (He mined similarly reflexive terrain in the very dissimilar ‰ÛÏInterior. Leather Bar.,‰Ûù an experimental feature that he directed with Travis Mathews about the making and remaking of ‰ÛÏCruising.‰Ûù) Mr. Franco recreates the production of ‰ÛÏThe Room‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ and the escalating behind-the-scenes nuttiness ‰ÛÓ with an assured, energetic touch, some fitting burlesque and an appealing cast that includes Jacki Weaver and Seth Rogen, who gives his deadpan a workout to play Tommy‰Ûªs put-upon script supervisor.

Cody Wilson, a self-described techno-anarchist, found himself in trouble with the American government after publishing designs online that could be used to create a gun with a 3-D printer. Stopping him raises thorny questions involving the First and Second Amendments, and introduces broad arguments over liberty and innovation.

Those ideas have been around for centuries. But technologies can now turn them into something frightening. Though it would have been valuable to see Mr. Wilson and Mr. Taaki challenged on their opinions, Adam Bhala Lough, the director, allows the men to make uncontested cases for their extremist and sometimes militant stances. Interviews with Julian Assange and mentions of George Orwell are sprinkled throughout, sowing a sense of paranoia.
For such a cerebral documentary, ‰ÛÏThe New Radical‰Ûù packs a wicked punch.

Interviews with Mr. Wilson show him to be both astute and confounding, sometimes sounding like a cautious bookworm, other times like an undergrad drunk on Ayn Rand novels; he disdains corporate influence in politics, yet admires the alt-right movement.

Mr. Wilson‰Ûªs interests don‰Ûªt end with guns. He has since joined with Amir Taaki, an anarchist from England, to create Dark Wallet, an internet application that allows for clandestine financial transactions using bitcoin. Like Mr. Wilson, Mr. Taaki has brazen ideas about revolution.
It‰Ûªs possible to fully, and vehemently, disagree with Mr. Wilson and Mr. Taaki yet still see their points. That can make ‰ÛÏThe New Radical‰Ûù unsettling. It also makes it a film worth watching.

The Golden Pint looks like a terrible place to eat ‰ÛÓ especially when Wikstrom decides to refashion it as a sushi place ‰ÛÓ but it is nonetheless a kind of utopian spot, a republic of misfits and oddballs among whom solidarity is automatic. The deadpan style of the acting functions as a vaccine against sentimentality, but there is no doubting the sincerity of this movie‰Ûªs motives or the effectiveness of its methods.

That‰Ûªs a deep, subtle joke, one of many in ‰ÛÏThe Other Side of Hope,‰Ûù the Finnish director Aki Kaurismaki‰Ûªs humane and gravely funny new film. The national temperament, at least as Mr. Kaurismaki sketches it, is decidedly saturnine. Smiles are as rare as trips to the gym or the plastic surgeon. Finland is a country of weary, stoical sad sacks, with sagging faces, who sit behind desks, eat bland food and play in rockabilly bands. Maybe Mazdak is right, and the government hopes that admitting upbeat migrants will provide a needed infusion of joy.

Viewers familiar with Mr. Kaurismaki‰Ûªs other work (which includes ‰ÛÏThe Man Without a Past,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏJuha‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏLeningrad Cowboys Go America‰Ûù) will instantly recognize the hallmarks of his style. Those new to the filmmaker may need a few scenes to adjust to the look, feel and rhythm of his world. His approach is old-fashioned. ‰ÛÏThe Other Side of Hope‰Ûù has the stately pace and graceful precision of a movie from the 1930s, and democratic, anti-authoritarian politics that also evoke that era. This is less a matter of nostalgia than of aesthetic commitment. You could list filmmakers from the past ‰ÛÓ Victor Sjostrom, Frank Borzage and Jean Vigo, for example ‰ÛÓ among Mr. Kaurismaki‰Ûªs influences, but it would be more accurate to describe them as his contemporaries.

Khaled, fleeing civil war in Syria, has wound up in Helsinki, where he lives in a dormitory with other refugees. One, Mazdak, who is from Iraq, coaches Khaled (Sherwan Haji) before his asylum hearing. Mazdak (Simon Hussein Al-Bazoon) tells his friend to be cheerful, since the Finns will deport ‰ÛÏmelancholics.‰Ûù

Khaled‰Ûªs fortunes are entwined with those of Wikstrom, played by Sakari Kuosmanen, a familiar face in the Kaurismaki cosmos. A grumpy businessman whose apparent midlife crisis coincides with Khaled‰Ûªs arrival, Wikstrom abruptly, but not quickly ‰ÛÓ Mr. Kaurismaki has a principled aversion to haste ‰ÛÓ leaves his wife, quits his job, wins a lot of money in a poker game and buys a restaurant called the Golden Pint. He discovers Khaled sleeping near the garbage bins, and the two bloody each other‰Ûªs noses, commencing a beautiful friendship. Khaled joins the restaurant staff, which includes a dubiously competent chef (Janne Hyytiainen), a bored-looking waitress (Nuppu Koivu) and a spectral maÌ¨tre d‰Ûª (Ilkka Koivula).

In an earlier time, ‰ÛÏThe Other Side of Hope‰Ûù might have been cited as an example of realism, by virtue of its subject matter. It addresses an urgent social problem ‰ÛÓ the European refugee crisis ‰ÛÓ and sets its story among what used to be called the common people. But Mr. Kaurismaki does not traffic in the harsh, immersive naturalism that has recently flourished on the international festival circuit, and his movies feel more like fables than like bulletins.

But Mr. Kaurismaki, a fixture of world cinema, returning to form after a period of relative inactivity ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏOther Side‰Ûù is his first feature since 2011, and only his fourth in this century ‰ÛÓ is a profoundly patriotic filmmaker. He is less a satirical observer of his nation‰Ûªs foibles than an excavator of its mopey, mordant, steadfast conscience. Helsinki, as Khaled experiences it, has its dangers. He is menaced by racist skinheads and thwarted by literal-minded bureaucrats. Yet he also encounters the unsentimental, occasionally grudging kindness of ordinary Finns, and when he tells Mazdak that he has fallen in love with his new home, you can understand why.

Which is not to suggest that there is anything naÌøve or fantastical about this tale of struggle and resilience. On the contrary, it‰Ûªs at once honest and artful, a touching and clearsighted declaration of faith in people and in movies.

‰ÛÏThe Shape of Water‰Ûù is partly a code-scrambled fairy tale, partly a genetically modified monster movie, and altogether wonderful. Guillermo del Toro, the writer and director, is a passionate genre geek. Sometimes his enthusiasm can get the better of his discipline, producing misshapen (but never completely uninteresting) movies like ‰ÛÏPacific Rim‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏCrimson Peak.‰Ûù At his best, though ‰ÛÓ in ‰ÛÏThe Devil‰Ûªs Backbone,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏPan‰Ûªs Labyrinth‰Ûù and now, at last, again ‰ÛÓ he fuses a fan‰Ûªs ardor with a romantic sensibility that is startling in its sincerity. He draws on old movies, comic books, mythic archetypes and his own restless visual imagination to create movies that seem less made than discovered, as if he had plucked them from the cultural ether and given them color, voice and form.

Mr. del Toro, though he has dabbled in large-scale, franchise-ready filmmaking, has never succumbed to the authoritarian aesthetic of the Hollywood blockbuster. He is a reflexive democrat whose underdog sympathies haven‰Ûªt curdled into glum superhero self-pity. The most welcome and notable thing about ‰ÛÏThe Shape of Water‰Ûù is its generosity of spirit, which extends beyond the central couple. Zelda and Giles, an artist whose advertising career has been derailed, are not just supporting players. They have miniature movies of their own, as does Mr. Stuhlbarg‰Ûªs scientist-cum-spook. And so, for that matter, does Strickland, though it isn‰Ûªt a movie anyone else would want to be in, not least because it feels the closest to reality.

Ms. Hawkins and Doug Jones, soulful and gorgeous beneath his shimmering carapace of blue-green scales, supply most of those. Since neither Elisa nor the Asset possesses the power of speech, they communicate through gestures and, since both can hear, through music. Ms. Hawkins, giving a silent performance in a sound film, will perhaps inevitably evoke Charlie Chaplin, and she moves her body and her facial features with Chaplinesque elegance, narrowing the distance between acting and dancing, turning physical comedy into corporeal poetry.

You may marvel at just how far Mr. del Toro takes this interspecies romance ‰ÛÓ all the way, basically ‰ÛÓ and also at how natural, how un-creepy, how pure and right he makes it seem. And why not? Folklore is full of frog princes, beauties and beasts. Classical mythology has its satyrs and centaurs, its shape-shifting gods and metamorphosing nymphs, whose commingling and canoodling is part of the human heritage.

The most obvious reference point for ‰ÛÏThe Shape of Water‰Ûù is ‰ÛÏCreature From the Black Lagoon,‰Ûù a Cold War-era camp-horror classic about a strange beast, quasi-fish and sort-of human, discovered in the rain forests of the Amazon. In Mr. del Toro‰Ûªs update, such a creature is brought to Baltimore in the early 1960s and kept in a tank at a government research lab, where he is subjected to brutal torture in the name of science and national security.

Bigotry and meanness flow through every moment like an underground stream, but kindness is always possible, and so is beauty. ‰ÛÏThe Shape of Water‰Ûù is made of vivid colors and deep shadows; it‰Ûªs as gaudy as a musical (and briefly turns into one), bright as a cartoon and murky as a film noir. (The cinematographer is Dan Laustsen. The score is by Alexandre Desplat.) Its busy plot moves swiftly ‰ÛÓ the presence of Russian spies never hurts, especially when one is played by Michael Stuhlbarg ‰ÛÓ except when Mr. del Toro lingers over a moment of tenderness, a delicate joke or an eruption of grace.

In Mr. del Toro‰Ûªs world, though, reality is the domain of rules and responsibilities, and realism is a crabbed, literal-minded view of things that can be opposed only by the forces of imagination. This will never be a fair or symmetrical fight, and the most important reason to make movies like this one ‰ÛÓ or, for that matter, to watch them ‰ÛÓ is to even the odds.

‰ÛÏThe Asset,‰Ûù as his minders call him, poses no threat to anyone. He is, as wild things tend to be in movies nowadays, an innocent at the mercy of a ruthlessly predatory species, which is to say us. His particular nemesis is Richard Strickland, a government-issue, square-jawed square played with reliable menace by Michael Shannon. Strickland lives in a suburban split-level with his wife and two kids, drives a Cadillac, reads ‰ÛÏThe Power of Positive Thinking‰Ûù and is into mechanical missionary sex (and workplace sexual harassment). His favorite accessory is an electric cattle prod, a detail that links him to the Southern sheriffs occasionally shown terrorizing civil rights demonstrators on television.

Elisa‰Ûªs interest is stirred less by curiosity than by recognition. Because of her muteness, she is looked at by others ‰ÛÓ and sometimes regards herself ‰ÛÓ as ‰ÛÏincomplete,‰Ûù something less than fully human. Her two best friends are Zelda (Octavia Spencer), an African-American woman who works with her, and Giles (Richard Jenkins), a gay man who lives next door. The understated, intuitive sympathy among these outcasts gives this fable some political bite.

A caricature? Maybe. But also a perfectly plausible villain, and in his diabolical all-American normalcy a necessary foil for the film‰Ûªs loose rebel coalition, a band of misfits who come to the Asset‰Ûªs defense. The most important of these is Elisa (Sally Hawkins), a member of the laboratory‰Ûªs nighttime cleaning staff, who plays jazz records for the piscine captive, feeds him hard-boiled eggs and before long falls in love with him.

Directed by the brothers Brendan and Emmett Malloy, ‰ÛÏThe Tribes of Palos Verdes‰Ûù portrays the cultish fixations that can arise within volatile families. As the mother forces the weight of her sadness onto her son, the father pushes his daughter to be his advocate with his estranged wife, and the son projects his anxiety onto his sister. As Medina‰Ûªs world churns, she takes up surfing, which gives her the only head cool enough to narrate this tale of family dysfunction.

When Medina Mason (Maika Monroe) begins to tell her family‰Ûªs story in ‰ÛÏThe Tribes of Palos Verdes,‰Ûù they have just made a fresh start in paradise ‰ÛÓ Palos Verdes, an affluent suburb of Los Angeles. While her mother, Sandy (Jennifer Garner), struggles to adjust to their new neighbors‰Ûª plastic smiles, Medina‰Ûªs father, Phil (Justin Kirk), decides to moves on, leaving Medina and her twin brother, Jim (the newcomer Cody Fern), in their mother‰Ûªs increasingly unstable care.

It is the film‰Ûªs great fortune that the Masons are portrayed by an exceptional team of actors, starting with Ms. Monroe, who is the calm eye at the center of the storm. The bellows of this tempest come from Ms. Garner, who ably depicts the demanding neediness of the vulnerable matriarch. Yet the Malloys‰Ûª filmmaking never rises to the level of the actors‰Ûª nuanced performances. The actors are energized, but the camera enervates. The colors have been bled from the California sunshine, and the camera alternates wanly between shaky close-ups and indifferent establishing shots. In ‰ÛÏThe Tribes of Palos Verdes,‰Ûù even the sea seems stifled.

Had you done so in the Colorado establishment owned by Gerald Foos some time between 1966 and 1990, your host might have been peering through a ceiling vent, taking copious notes on your ablutions. An obsessive peeper who enjoyed decades of onanistic pleasure at his oblivious guests‰Ûª expense, Mr. Foos shared his prurient interests and diaries with Mr. Talese, who documented them for The New Yorker in 2016. A poorly reviewed book followed, only to be briefly disavowed by Mr. Talese after The Washington Post unearthed serious discrepancies in Mr. Foos‰Ûªs recollections.

The second wife to collude with her husband‰Ûªs clandestine adventures (the first, Donna, even brought him the occasional snack), Ms. Foos remains a placid enigma. Now, her primary purpose seems to be soothing and cajoling the husband who once viewed himself as a superior being. In one especially memorable moment, he threatens a meltdown over book reviews that he feels present him as ‰ÛÏnothing but a creep.‰Ûù

‰ÛÏI‰Ûªm the guy!‰Ûù Mr. Foos rails, infuriated when media attention over the book focuses on Mr. Talese. And when one of the filmmakers tentatively asks Mr. Foos to explain an inaccuracy in his story, Mr. Talese vociferously objects, deriding the directors as mere ‰ÛÏcameramen‰Ûù and unfit to act as journalists. The humor of these outbursts is not lost on the directors, who add little jabs of their own with repeated shots of Mr. Foos and his wife, Anita, peeking through their window shades in nervous agitation.

Filled with unasked questions and unverified assertions, ‰ÛÏVoyeur‰Ûù is a sad, strange tale of two men whose similarities of taste and temperament ‰ÛÓ including extreme ego, unbridled nosiness and a penchant for the lurid ‰ÛÓ are its real subject. Chronicling the literary debacle and the decades-long relationship that preceded it, the directors Myles Kane and Josh Koury dance from the memorabilia-crammed basement in Mr. Talese‰Ûªs Manhattan brownstone to the cluttered living-room in a Denver suburb where Mr. Foos holds court.

Choosing not to delve too deeply into the mind of either man ‰ÛÓ or to question Mr. Talese‰Ûªs journalistic ethics and less-than-scrupulous fact-checking ‰ÛÓ the directors are content to mostly watch as each vies for control of the movie, and his legacy. It‰Ûªs an entertainingly desperate joust, playing out beneath defiantly unattractive lighting.

Peppered with sleazy re-enactments and unflattering close-ups, ‰ÛÏVoyeur‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a squirmy documentary about the celebrated journalist Gay Talese‰Ûªs infamous investigation of a perverted motel owner ‰ÛÓ leaves you with an urgent need to take a shower.
‰ÛÏWell,‰Ûù his wife says, smiling, ‰ÛÏyou are.‰Ûù

So, when Mickey (Justin Timberlake, too modern a presence), a lifeguard and self-described romantic, gives Ginny the once over, she gratefully falls into his arms. ‰ÛÏWonder Wheel‰Ûù more or less becomes Ginny‰Ûªs story, but she doesn‰Ûªt get to own it. The movie is narrated by Mickey, who pops in and out and looks directly into the camera. He has literary ambitions, as he likes to remind us, as well as a pad in Greenwich Village. For a while, Mickey offers Ginny a respite from her everyday grind, at least until the arrival of Carolina (a fine Juno Temple), Humpty‰Ûªs daughter from an earlier marriage. She‰Ûªs on the run from her gangster husband. ‰ÛÏI know where all the bodies are buried,‰Ûù Carolina says.

Ginny isn‰Ûªt all used up, despite the insistently unflattering way she is often presented. She winces and frowns a lot, and the camera conspires with the lighting and makeup to catch every twitch of distress, and the sweaty, oily sheen she never seems able to blot away. It‰Ûªs no surprise that she‰Ûªs worried. She works in a clam house on the boardwalk, scrambling for hoi polloi, while back at home she has to juggle her loud, loutish husband, Humpty (Jim Belushi), and her son, Richie (Jack Gore). Like the young Alvy in ‰ÛÏAnnie Hall,‰Ûù Richie is a redhead. But while Alvy is depressed about the universe, Richie seems largely troubled by his home life, specifically his demonstrably miserable mother.

Somewhat of a cultural magpie, Mr. Allen has often folded bits and pieces ‰ÛÓ and at times entire conceits ‰ÛÓ from other work into his movies. Mickey mentions Eugene O‰ÛªNeill, a reference that suggests we‰Ûªre meant to see something of that playwright in Ginny and Humpty at their most raw and boozily fraught. Mr. Allen‰Ûªs often blunt, overwrought dialogue, however, also alternately brings to mind Budd Schulberg (‰ÛÏI coulda been a contender‰Ûù) and imitation Clifford Odets. In some scenes, you almost expect Mr. Belushi, who‰Ûªs playing his heart out, to start bellowing about someone named Lefty. Much like its gaudy title attraction, ‰ÛÏWonder Wheel‰Ûù keeps on turning, even while going nowhere.

Mr. Allen certainly keeps you busy with all these colors, tones, influences, complications, stereotypes and histrionics, but to little end. As has always been the case with his movies, the actors seem to have delivered the performances they came to the set with, so the strong ‰ÛÓ in this case, the invaluable Ms. Winslet ‰ÛÓ are strong while the rest of the cast members do what they can with varying degrees of success. Ginny, who yearns for something better than clam houses and brutality ‰ÛÓ and who is mercilessly punished for her yearning ‰ÛÓ could easily have become a monstrous, one-note clichÌ©. But Ms. Winslet fills this shabby character with feverish life. She conveys far more with a single, quietly stunned look than any of Mr. Allen‰Ûªs speeches or Mr. Storaro‰Ûªs color changes.

This is Mr. Allen‰Ûªs second movie with the cinematographer Vittorio Storaro, who seems to have enjoyed taking the color wheel and camera out for a spin. He gives the story visual flow, even when the characters are in claustrophobic lockdown. And Mr. Storaro keeps your pupils dancing with the light and dark hues. Some of the establishing shots of Coney Island recall the softer side of Technicolor, whereas the violently saturated scenes suggest the vibrancy of the Blue Rider palette. The more extreme colors ‰ÛÓ including an unlovely orange light that floods Ginny ‰ÛÓ pushes the whole thing into expressionism even as the movie fluctuates between kitchen-sink realism and hothouse melodrama.

At one point, after Ginny has turned into Blanche DuBois, she announces, ‰ÛÏWhen it comes to love we often turn out to be our own worst enemy.‰Ûù And not for the first time you wonder what Mr. Allen, who has long blurred fact and fiction, thinks he‰Ûªs doing here. He couldn‰Ûªt have anticipated that his name would be in the news because of the allegations of sexual abuse upending the entertainment industry. Yet how could we not think of him? In 1993, he was accused of molesting his daughter, Dylan Farrow. He maintained his innocence and was never prosecuted, yet the allegations as well as discomfort about his marriage to Soon-Yi have hovered over him like a malignant cloud. Critics have often uneasily ignored his history, but he himself seems perversely intent on invoking it.

‰ÛÏWonder Wheel‰Ûù returns Mr. Allen to Coney Island, the childhood home of his alter ego Alvy Singer, the narrator of ‰ÛÏAnnie Hall‰Ûù who claims to have grown up under the amusement park‰Ûªs roller coaster. (‰ÛÏI have some trouble between fantasy and reality,‰Ûù Alvy says.) In ‰ÛÏWonder Wheel,‰Ûù the sad wife, Ginny (Kate Winslet), lives in an apartment that looks directly onto the park‰Ûªs looming Ferris wheel. The attraction obscures her view of the ocean, literalizing already narrow horizons, and casts deep, expressionistic blue and red light on the apartment‰Ûªs dilapidated interior and its equally worn inhabitants.

‰ÛÏWonder Wheel,‰Ûù Woody Allen‰Ûªs latest movie, is one of his more unfortunate contributions to cinema. It tells the story of a desperately, unhappily married woman whose affair with a local Romeo is derailed when he takes notice of her stepdaughter, whose breasts have been lit to glow like Vermeer peaches. The heart wants what it wants, as Mr. Allen once said by way of explaining his affair with his now wife, Soon-Yi, the daughter of his longtime ex, Mia Farrow. I tend to think it‰Ûªs a bad idea to put a movie on the couch, but what if it climbs on the couch and then starts winking?

I am a fervent fan of Mr. Frisell‰Ûªs. I‰Ûªve been following his work since the mid-1980s; I‰Ûªve seen him perform live twice this year, and might try to catch one of his shows this weekend at Jazz Standard.

Directed by Emma Franz, this project has clearly been in the works for a long time. Three of its interviewees, all music greats, have died in recent years: the jazz guitarist Jim Hall, also a teacher of Mr. Frisell‰Ûªs; the remarkable drummer Paul Motian, with whom Mr. Frisell played in a groundbreaking jazz trio with Joe Lovano; and the wonderful, albeit widely misunderstood, guitarist John Abercrombie, who provides an interesting technical analysis of Mr. Frisell‰Ûªs style and tone, among the most distinctive and recognizable in contemporary music.
But the movie is at its liveliest when it depicts Mr. Frisell making his distinctive sound with a variety of colleagues. And, fortunately, Ms. Franz includes a lot of such footage.

Bill Frisell, the genre-spanning guitarist, is such a busy musician these days that a new documentary about him doesn‰Ûªt feature any archival footage from his long career until about an hour and 20 minutes into its nearly two-hour running time. Early on in  ‰ÛÏBill Frisell: A Portrait,‰Ûù Mr. Frisell, a quiet, diffident man, tells an off-camera interviewer that when he gets up in the morning, he picks up a guitar, starts playing ‰ÛÏand then ‰Û_‰Ûù he drifts off. The suggestion is that he never stops.

These qualities, however, don‰Ûªt always make entirely compelling cinema. A cab ride through London with Mr. Frisell‰Ûªs former teacher, the composer and conductor Michael Gibbs, is frankly a little drowsy. Once the duo, who are working on a collaborative concert, reach their destination, a radio station, they are directed to a studio called ‰ÛÏthe Barbarella Room.‰Ûù

On the way there, Mr. Frisell recalls what he remembers as ‰ÛÏthe only illegal thing‰Ûù he has ever done: as a 15-year-old, gaining entry to a theatrical screening of ‰ÛÏBarbarella,‰Ûù the very tame, sex-in-outer-space ‰Ûª60s film starring Jane Fonda, when the movie was restricted to viewers over 16. Which is funny.

Nevertheless, there are several points in this movie ‰ÛÓ which I‰Ûªm still recommending ‰ÛÓ that I found, if not boring, a little dry. In a sense, Mr. Frisell, 66, is an entirely atypical contemporary musician. As the impresario and record producer Hal Willner notes early in the documentary, despite Mr. Frisell‰Ûªs having performed or recorded with literally hundreds of other top-flight players and troubadours, ‰ÛÏthere‰Ûªs no one who has a bad word to say about him.‰Ûù Being a ‰ÛÏno drama‰Ûù person is lovely, and it‰Ûªs particularly salutary that Mr. Frisell upends the myth that the great artist needs to be full of anger, or to behave badly, to be inspired.

Energetically directed by Craig Gillespie, ‰ÛÏI, Tonya‰Ûù charts the hard-won rise and calamitous fall of its title character (Margot Robbie). Taking the form of a mock, mocking documentary, one that disjointedly swings between heehaw comedy and wincing agony, the movie establishes its raised-eyebrow tone with a title card stating it‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBased on irony-free, wildly contradictory and totally true interviews with Tonya Harding and Jeff Gillooly,‰Ûù her former husband. (The screenwriter, Steven Rogers, has said that he spoke with both.) From their separate corners, the middle-aged, long-divorced Tonya and Jeff (Sebastian Stan), provide linked, at times vividly contradictory accounts of what happened.

In ‰ÛÏI, Tonya,‰Ûù she is also an unreliable narrator, just like Jeff. ‰ÛÏThere‰Ûªs no such thing as truth,‰Ûù Tonya announces. ‰ÛÏEveryone has their own truth.‰Ûù The film takes up this statement as its guiding narrative principle, toggling between the she-said and he-said as it hurdles toward its nadir. The older Tonya makes an assertion, and the older Jeff does likewise. The young Tonya ‰ÛÓ in flashback ‰ÛÓ says one thing, the young Jeff says something else, and every so often LaVona chimes in. Characters periodically break the fourth wall by looking into the camera and directly addressing the viewer, as if to assert ownership on the unwinding story. Listen to me, each seems to say in these moments.

As ‰ÛÏI, Tonya‰Ûù skips here and there and thickens the plot, it becomes increasingly baffling why the filmmakers decided to put a comic spin on this pathetic, dispiriting story. No matter how hard the movie tries to coax out laughs, there‰Ûªs little about Ms. Harding, her circumstances or her choices that skews as funny. She was poor, grew up in trailers, had a temper, liked loud colors, dropped out of school, traded in one abuser for another and maintained some stupid acquaintances ‰ÛÓ a clown posse the filmmakers lavish too much time on. She might have played a role in the attack on Ms. Kerrigan, but in many ways Ms. Harding had already been found guilty for just being who she was. The same feels true here.

As Tonya and Jeff offer up alternating stories, her past, her abuse and her triumphs come into view. The only daughter of an unhappily married couple, the young Tonya is a daddy‰Ûªs girl. Her father takes her hunting, teaching her how to shoot rabbit. Her awful mother, LaVona (Allison Janney, chilled and excellent), is the one who arranges for Tonya to take lessons with a skating coach (Julianne Nicholson). Tonya turns out to be a prodigy and is soon powering her way into the top echelon of the sport, despite the snobbery and visible discomfort of the judges who favor froufrou femininity over aggressive competition. They want gliding princesses, not grunting athletes like Tonya.

The story of Tonya Harding has been told before in mainstream journalism and in scholarly accounts, documentaries and a quickie made-for-TV movie that lathered the soap. Before and after the incident, as it‰Ûªs often called, she was grist for thumb-sucking takes on women, femininity, sports and social class. Before the attack, writers liked to point out that Ms. Harding played pool and drove a truck. In a sympathetic 1992 profile, Sports Illustrated described her as a ‰ÛÏhardscrabble, dispossessed kid‰Ûù who had become ‰ÛÏan interloper in the realm of pixies and queens who‰Ûªs as at home doing a brake job as she is performing an arabesque.‰Ûù She was Cinderella with edge and muscles.

The real Tonya Harding went from fame to infamy in 1994, after she was implicated in an attack on Nancy Kerrigan, a rival. On Jan. 6, after practicing for the United States Figure Skating Championships in Detroit, Ms. Kerrigan was attacked by a man who thwacked her leg with a collapsible police baton. (He seems to have been going for her knee.) A camera captured Ms. Kerrigan on the ground as she repeatedly wailed ‰ÛÏWhy?‰Ûù Ms. Harding went on to win the championship; it was a short-lived victory. The F.B.I. was soon questioning her, her ex-husband and their dumb-and-dumber associates. By June, Ms. Harding had been barred from competing for her role in the attack.

Ms. Robbie takes on the role with vigor and strained toothy smiles, giving an outsize performance that suits the film‰Ûªs broadness and showy surfaces. (She does much of her own skating, though the trickier moves were completed with stunt doubles and digital effects.) Despite the makeup and a few tragic haircuts, Ms. Robbie remains an unpersuasive fit for the tiny Ms. Harding, who could bench press more than her weight and whose sculptured muscles freaked some out. You could write a treatise on female bodies pegged to the contempt that journalists unloaded on her, especially after the attack, when they called her ‰ÛÏwhite trash‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏold Thunder Thighs.‰Ûù She was 23.

The subject of ‰ÛÏI, Tonya‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a winking, eager-to-please, fictionalized gloss on the disgraced ice skater Tonya Harding ‰ÛÓ gets roughed up a lot. As a child, she is degraded and smacked around by her mother, who kicks little Tonya‰Ûªs chair so violently the kid flies off it. When the teenage Tonya gets involved with the man she will marry, her life as a punching bag continues. Her husband smashes her head onto a glass surface so hard that shards scatter; he bloodies her nose a few times. He also points a gun at Tonya, threatening to kill her. Despite all the beatings and blood, ‰ÛÏI, Tonya‰Ûù insists it‰Ûªs a comedy.

‰ÛÏI, Tonya‰Ûù asserts that the truth is elusive. Yet some facts are known. Ms. Harding ‰ÛÓ as was widely reported ‰ÛÓ took out restraining orders against Mr. Gillooly, telling the police that he had hit her and she was afraid of him. Back then, her abuse was often played down; here, it is countered by scenes in which the tough Tonya fights back, at times with a comedic spin, as if to suggest that she can give as good as she gets. That makes this film and the brutality more breezily watchable, I suppose. Still, it‰Ûªs instructive that at one point Tonya lectures the audience on its complicity in how she was treated. It‰Ûªs an impressively disingenuous wag of the finger from a film that has encouraged our laughter right from the start.

In one location, Jeff sits facing the camera in front of a large window framed by photo-covered walls. There‰Ûªs a lot more visual coding going on with Tonya, who‰Ûªs plunked down at a table in a modest kitchen wearing a pale jeans jacket and cowboy boots. Lank blond hair and bangs border her face; her neck has gone puffy. Looking into the camera, she occasionally draws on a cigarette and crosses her legs, one big, down-home, country-gal ankle resting on a knee. The real eye-catchers are the dirty dishes stacked in the sink behind her. They stay put and stay dirty, which seems curiously sloppy given that Tonya, a media veteran, is here to tell her truth. If you didn‰Ûªt know she had a reputation as down-and-dirty, here‰Ûªs a hint.

The dog, who gets his own point-of-view shots and flashbacks, has been made violent by a crime boss, Blue (Antonio Banderas). Blue has just cleaned up at a dogfight on the premises and will soon return. (The ring is evidently run by cinephiles; the dogs are named after actors like Clint Eastwood and Robert Mitchum.)

‰ÛÏBullet Head‰Ûù provides an answer to one of contemporary cinema‰Ûªs enduring mysteries: What if ‰ÛÏReservoir Dogs‰Ûù had an actual dog? In the director Paul Solet‰Ûªs endearingly lunkheaded thriller, three thieves, reeling from a partly botched heist, hide in a warehouse whose only other living occupant is a vicious, implacable Canary mastiff.

Is ‰ÛÏBullet Head‰Ûù good? In truth, it‰Ûªs drab, derivative and more than slightly silly, but it‰Ûªs tough to dislike a movie that proceeds as if the 1990s cycle of Quentin Tarantino knockoffs never ended and that uses the prospect of gory canine violence in service of loud and persistent pro-dog cheerleading. The closing credits say that a portion of the movie‰Ûªs proceeds will go toward eliminating dogfighting.

All three robbers ‰ÛÓ Stacy (Adrien Brody), Walker (John Malkovich) and Gage (Rory Culkin) ‰ÛÓ have histories with pets. This leads to dialogue in which Walker and Stacy discuss the qualities of cat people and dog people (‰ÛÏBeing a cat person doesn‰Ûªt necessarily make you less of a man,‰Ûù Walker says); how a standard poodle once saved Stacy from being arrested; and the unfortunate incident in which a young Walker intermingled stolen freshwater and saltwater fish.

It‰Ûªs no surprise when violence fully erupts at the checkpoint. It‰Ûªs been hanging over this movie much as those carefully doting soldiers hovered over Michael and Dafna, telling them, wrongly of course, that their only son had died serving his country. Those soldiers are so good at what they do, Mr. Maoz suggests, because they have so much experience. There‰Ûªs even a sense, conveyed through their practiced calm and soothing voices, that violence and grief are somehow inevitable, maybe normal. Image by image, and with invocations of history and the Holocaust, Mr. Moaz also suggests that normalizing catastrophic violence ‰ÛÓ and routinizing mourning ‰ÛÓ is finally little else than nihilism.

If that sounds like a metaphor, it most likely is. Mr. Maoz doesn‰Ûªt say, at least through the dialogue. Avoiding speeches and exegesis, he writes characters that talk like ordinary people in everyday life, even as he focuses your attention on their faces, their interactions with others, how they carry themselves, how they withdraw and advance. (You learn more about Michael from how he treats the family dog than from what he says.) Visually, though, Mr. Maoz leans into Expressionism. Michael and Dafna‰Ûªs apartment, for instance, creates a powerful sense of a purposefully ordered world that is upended by grief; the abject decay surrounding Jonathan says something else entirely.

It‰Ûªs a grabber of an opening in a movie that builds into a devastating indictment of a nation, shock by shock, brutal moment by brutal moment. (The movie is Israel‰Ûªs Oscar entry in the foreign-language category.) Meaning surfaces slowly here in details, flashes of cruelty, glimmers of apathy and a mounting sense of helplessness. First, though, there are parental tears and Dafna and Michael‰Ûªs handsome, sparsely furnished apartment with its tidy bookshelves and modernist furniture. The biggest room, where Michael lingers while watching Dafna collapse, has a geometrically patterned floor and is so large and precisely arranged that it suggests a showroom. At times, it also evokes a stage.

The violence in the Israeli movie ‰ÛÏFoxtrot‰Ûù starts with a tremor. The shudders begin soon after the movie does when a woman opens a door, stares into the camera and falls to the ground. Just one look, and Dafna (Sarah Adler) knows the worst: The soldiers on her doorstep have come bringing death. Her son, Jonathan (Yonatan Shiray), who‰Ûªs in the army, has been killed. In a whir of motion and fatigue green, they stoop over Dafna, soothing and sedating her, then tucking her in bed. Her husband, Michael (a fantastic Lior Ashkenazi), mutely stares at this scene as if he were a bystander in his own life.

With Dafna asleep in the bedroom, Michael initially suffers and mourns alone. His red eyes watering yet not quite spilling over, he understandably seems to be in shock. The soldiers have tended to him, too, fussing and hovering over him; in one shot, he looks up at them as if he were a child. His brother (Yehuda Almagor), comes by and begins busily arranging a memorial notice. Two women rush in as well, including Michael and Dafna‰Ûªs daughter (Shira Haas). Everyone plays his or her part. The soldiers re-enter, and one comfortably settles into a chair and rather too blithely proposes funeral arrangements to Michael, sketching in every detail with the fastidious attention of a wedding planner.

The writer and director Samuel Maoz (‰ÛÏLebanon‰Ûù) has an exacting eye. The framing is meticulous; soon it‰Ûªs also very purposefully working your nerves. Although Michael briefly leaves to tell his mother about Jonathan, much of the movie‰Ûªs first section unfolds inside the apartment. It‰Ûªs a cloistered space, made more confining by the tight close-ups of Michael‰Ûªs face (Mr. Ashkenazi makes mourning palpable in each twitch), his ponderous, near-somnolent movements and several overhead shots of him. These dramatically isolate him in the frame while creating an ambiguous, narratively untethered point of view, as if we were peering at him from a catwalk. Filmmakers call this a God‰Ûªs-eye view.

After the intense emotions and physical limitations of the apartment, the checkpoint with its wide-open vistas provides relief. For a moment, if seems as if you can breathe. The soldiers are cute, amusing and very young. They‰Ûªve settled into dull, monotonous work ‰ÛÓ raising the barrier for a camel ‰ÛÓ that can seem absurd. (What could go wrong?) But they also dance, draw, listen to music, tell stories and entertain one another. The looseness and humor of their interactions are welcome, but there are also new shivers of unease: The soldiers bunk in what looks like a repurposed, derelict shipping container. Everything is falling apart, decaying, and the container is rapidly sinking into the mud.

By the time the first section is over, a near-miracle has occurred. Jonathan turns out to be alive, and after his parents process the news, the story shifts to him. He‰Ûªs in a remote outpost fulfilling the compulsory military service demanded of most Israelis when they turn 18. Along with three other young men, Jonathan guards a checkpoint, lowering and raising a barrier for the occasional passing car or slow-loping camel. At night, the soldiers train a harsh spotlight on passers-by and check IDs. It‰Ûªs a dramatically beautiful, seemingly depopulated area, framed by distant mountains and bisected by a single lonely road that seems to stretch on forever yet also to go nowhere.

Alison closely resembles Jennifer Lawrence‰Ûªs character in ‰ÛÏWinter‰Ûªs Bone,‰Ûù another self-sufficient young woman whose family and community turn against her. This movie is not as tense, but it gets close thanks to Ms. Agron‰Ûªs resolute performance and the movie‰Ûªs hostile small town setting. The world may not always be just ‰ÛÓ those who break things don‰Ûªt always pick up the pieces ‰ÛÓ but headstrong women like Alison still survive.
Soon this gloomy family drama, directed and written by Scooter Corkle, transforms into a backwoods thriller littered with bodies and conspiracies.

Set in a remote small town in Canada, ‰ÛÏHollow in the Land‰Ûù follows Alison (Dianna Agron) as she struggles to look after her troublesome brother, Brandon (Jared Abrahamson). Their mother is long gone, and their jailbird father is still locked up. When Brandon is accused of murder, he disappears, leaving Alison alone to exonerate him.

Under the film‰Ûªs color-drained cinematography, Alison looks tired and pallid as she‰Ûªs harassed and chased away by locals who despise her family. She looks ready to snap from the first scene on, yet her resolve to find her brother keeps her going. The movie mirrors Alison‰Ûªs desperation through dimly lit dead-end clues and hectic chase sequences through town.
