Filled with desolate vistas, a feathered and furred menagerie, and multiple aperture-like windows, these fragments quickly establish a moody tone and over time become dolorous refrains. Each section is divided by fades to black and individual titles (Frame 2, Frame 15) that create a kind of countdown effect.

A fine-art photographer as well as a filmmaker, Kiarostami could set your heart to leaping with cinematic landscapes that sometimes linger longer than his stories: a rough, dusty hill delineated by a zigzagging path in ‰ÛÏWhere Is My Friend‰Ûªs House?‰Ûù; two travelers motoring through a swaying field in ‰ÛÏThe Wind Will Carry Us.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs no surprise then that the images in ‰ÛÏ24 Frames‰Ûù are consistently pretty and at times striking, harmoniously composed and filled with visual tension that make the shots vibrate even before something ‰ÛÓ birds, horses, an unfortunate deer or an opportunistically placed cat ‰ÛÓ starts moving in them. Many of the views are organized around an obvious center point, a leafless tree or bush, for instance, roughly set in a brilliantly white wintry expanse.

Images become cinema in ‰ÛÏ24 Frames,‰Ûù the last movie from the Iranian filmmaker Abbas Kiarostami (1940-2016). ‰ÛÏI always wonder to what extent the artist aims to depict the reality of a scene,‰Ûù he reveals in the opening text. ‰ÛÏPainters capture only one frame of reality and nothing before or after it.‰Ûù This wondering led him to digitally transform 24 still images into short, visually and thematically linked sequences that make up this alternately charming and frustrating labor of love, which he worked on during the final three years of his life. (It was completed under the supervision of one of his sons.)

‰ÛÏ24 Frames‰Ûù can‰Ûªt help but be affecting because it is Kiarostami‰Ûªs final movie. But it‰Ûªs intellectually uninvolving, and its technical limitations prove frustrating. In a few shots, snow or rain falls, for instance, on the same left-to-right diagonal, creating a distracting pattern that suggests the software wasn‰Ûªt altered for each photograph. This synthetic quality may be an intentional imitation of life; certainly it‰Ûªs obvious that Kiarostami was thinking a great deal about cinema. Intriguingly, while winter and all it implies loom large here, they are gently offset by a glimpse of the film ‰ÛÏThe Best Years of Our Lives‰Ûù playing on a computer as the sounds of a deeply unexpected love song fill a lonely room.

At other times, Kiarostami flattens the picture, turning it into a stack of horizontal wedges. In one frame, a slab of darkly brooding sky seems to loom down on a skeletal railing that runs across the shot, cleaving it in half. Beyond the railing, water (ocean, sea or lake) surges and, with a bird, gives the image a frisson of drama. Repeatedly, a movement ‰ÛÓ a bird raising its head, a horse its hooves ‰ÛÓ turns an image into a tidy narrative fragment. Every so often (a watery panorama with a balustrade, tall poles and complaining gulls), the compositions seem to nod at Yasujiro Ozu, the Japanese filmmaker to whom Kiarostami dedicated ‰ÛÏFive‰Ûù (2003), another experimental work.

Their music here, largely downbeat but relentlessly anodyne, is not to my taste. During the song ‰ÛÏOn My Way to Heaven,‰Ûù Cobi, a vocalist for the touring band, looks to his right and proudly says ‰ÛÏLadies and gentlemen, Jono on the Rhodes,‰Ûù and Jono Grant, a member of the core trio, plays an electric piano solo that I think I first heard in the lounge of the Las Vegas Hilton in 1989. Still, Above & Beyond‰Ûªs audience, a not insubstantial one, seems unfailingly moved by its work.

The trio Above & Beyond originated as an electronic dance music group, and became popular in that iteration. In 2014 the group made an album called ‰ÛÏAcoustic,‰Ûù which featured them playing conventional instruments rather than samplers and decks. In this film, the group tours in support of that and similar work with a large retinue of singers and instrumentalists, culminating in a gig at the Hollywood Bowl.

Everyone in the group gets along with each other, and with everybody else. The movie, directed by Myles Desenberg and Paul Dugdale, frequently counts down to the Hollywood Bowl show as it chronicles rehearsals and other tour stops, but there‰Ûªs no real suspense, because the footage from that show is interspersed throughout the movie from the very beginning, and the show seems to have gone off without a hitch. The movie is slightly prone to such fallacies, starting with the title. If you‰Ûªre making your living creating music and you adjust your instrumentation, that‰Ûªs not really giving up your day job. But this will not likely bother the movie‰Ûªs intended audience: Above & Beyond fans for whom this film can serve as a kind of cinematic Snuggie.

When will they ever learn? The aliens, I mean, who can‰Ûªt seem to resist the impulse to invade Earth and wipe out humanity. ‰ÛÏBefore We Vanish,‰Ûù Kiyoshi Kurosawa‰Ûªs witty science-fiction chin-scratcher ‰ÛÓ less a horror movie than a series of musings on potentially horrifying ideas ‰ÛÓ addresses the question literally. It concerns a reconnaissance squad of space travelers sent to do fieldwork in our ways and habits, with particular emphasis on our mental concepts.

It‰Ûªs not always easy to know whom to root for. The first invader we encounter (Yuri Tsunematsu) has taken the form of a uniformed schoolgirl, whose bloody introduction evokes, teasingly and somewhat misleadingly, the iconography of classic Japanese horror. She is joined by a young man (also an alien, played by Mahiro Takasugi) who has latched onto a cynical journalist (not an alien, played by Hiroki Hasegawa) who serves as a guide. Alien etiquette apparently discourages harvesting your guide‰Ûªs concepts, and the two are refreshingly forthright about their identities and intentions. Not that anyone believes them, at least at first.

So the real question, as it tends to be in dystopian science fiction, is whether we will learn, or whether it‰Ûªs too late for us to recover the value of the concepts that define us. Mr. Kurosawa, a prolific and skilled genre master, spins this parable with a light, nimble touch, punctuating heavy passages of exposition with punchy, modest action sequences and snatches of incongruously bouncy music. There is a decided air of pastiche ‰ÛÓ a predigital, low-budget, ‰Ûª80s feel ‰ÛÓ and the right measure of sincerity to remind you why the concept of the alien-invasion movie is one that matters to the species.

There is a long and rich tradition of debate in philosophy and cognitive science about the nature of those entities, which the three main aliens resolve with impressive practical acumen. For them, to acquire a concept is to steal it from the person who explained it, a theft that is consummated by a brisk tap on the forehead. The victim crumples to the ground (there are some variations on this procedure) and then resumes life missing a key piece of mental furniture.

The result is not always terrifying. A manipulative, sexually-harassing boss, robbed of ‰ÛÏwork,‰Ûù capers across the desktops of his office, laughing and tossing paper airplanes. A young man who has lived for a long time as an anxious shut-in loses ‰ÛÏhome‰Ûù and finds himself free to explore the world and embrace political causes. It almost seems as if the aliens do their unwitting hosts a favor. The catch is that they plan to exterminate us and take over the planet.

Meanwhile, Narumi (Masami Nagasawa) is dealing with a mysterious change in her husband, Shinji (Ryuhei Matsuda), whose body has been taken over by one of the extraterrestrials. Their marriage was unhappy before, and now it passes through an even rougher patch on the way to a charming and not altogether surprising transformation. Once he learns enough to stop stumbling around in a semi-stupor, Shinji turns out to be an improvement over his earlier self. He‰Ûªs open-minded. He pays attention. He listens to his wife.

Filled with lovely natural landscapes that have been meticulously framed and photographed, ‰ÛÏLegend of the Mountain‰Ûù is often a visual ravishment. (It was shot in the South Korean countryside.) There‰Ûªs a mesmerizing appeal to many of its panoramas, with their variegated colors, dense vegetation and drifting, swirling white mist. And while King Hu certainly likes to move the camera ‰ÛÓ it sweeps, swoops and sometime breaks into a near-run ‰ÛÓ he also likes to linger on images as if encouraging you to admire their compositional harmony. You can get lost in these pictorial reveries as you trace the rays of light piercing the trees, brightening the dark waters and the reality-softening haze.

Despite being warned away by a stranger, Ho at last makes it to the outpost, where a story of sorts emerges, along with allies and other figures who prove more sinister. Mysterious women (the equally charismatic Hsu Feng and Sylvia Chang) come and go, as does an enigmatic lama (Ng Ming-choi) with an open, cherubic face and splendid yellow vestments. There are digressions and some wonderful visual fillips ‰ÛÓ beautifully curved trees and noble stone statues lined up like soldiers. All these attractions are a necessary balm given that Ho turns out to be a deeply uninvolving character (Mr. Shih mostly smiles, grimaces or looks amazed), a wan placeholder for a character in a narratively thin film that runs over three very leisurely hours.

A magical mystery marathon, King Hu‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏLegend of the Mountain‰Ûù takes place (maybe, as the narrator waggishly says) in the 11th century during the Song dynasty. It tells of a cheerful, underemployed scholar, Ho Yunqing (Shih Chun), who makes a meager living as a copyist. Soon after the movie opens, he is entrusted to copy a Buddhist sutra (a dialogue or sermon) that can liberate souls stuck in limbo. Ho isn‰Ûªt a believer, but he needs the money and so enthusiastically heads out on a seemingly simple mission, one that eventually leads to an isolated outpost where curious and curiouser things occur.

A giant of Chinese cinema, King Hu (1932-1997) is best known for his wuxia films (‰ÛÏA Touch of Zen‰Ûù), martial arts stories involving heroic deeds, quests, swordplay and the supernatural. ‰ÛÏLegend of the Mountain,‰Ûù a 1979 film that has been restored to the director‰Ûªs cut, is more wuxia-adjacent though it does feature some fight sequences in which characters go fantastically airborne, defying gravity with bounce and somersaults. Amusingly, the main choice of weapons isn‰Ûªt swords but drums that opponents beat ‰ÛÓ with insistent, galloping fingers ‰ÛÓ to create a powerful, mystical sonic force. The drumming is wonderful and suitably hypnotic even if it doesn‰Ûªt necessarily pull you under the film‰Ûªs own spell.

Mr. Unay often shoots Mr. Carman in wide screen at close range, emphasizing the physical strain of his routines, whether he‰Ûªs running, training or doing mechanical work for a ferry system. Part of the secret of the movie‰Ûªs interest is that Mr. Carman is not invincible or a former superstar. We‰Ûªre told that he doesn‰Ûªt even make money off cage matches.

The straightforward, elemental documentary ‰ÛÏThe Cage Fighter‰Ûù suggests that many of the clichÌ©s of boxing and wrestling movies ‰ÛÓ about not being able to resist a last fight, about the ring‰Ûªs lure being a force more powerful than love ‰ÛÓ aren‰Ûªt clichÌ©s at all, but simply true to life.

‰ÛÏThe Cage Fighter‰Ûù is hardly epic in scope or originality, but it is uncommon to watch this degree of open self-flagellation on screen. Mr. Carman insists to one of his daughters that having a black eye doesn‰Ûªt count as being ‰ÛÏhurt‰Ûù and visits a doctor who wonders whether his symptoms indicate post-concussion syndrome. He appears in court when an ex-wife wants to relocate and sits stoically when the judge implies that he is the less dependable parent.

Yet the damage they do to his home life is real. ‰ÛÏIt‰Ûªs the only time in my life when I feel proud of myself,‰Ûù he tells dismayed family members who have just learned that he is fighting again, despite having promised his ill wife never to get back in the ring. Fighting, he says, allows him to feel that he likes himself. Mr. Carman is shown throughout the film as a loving parent (we see him dancing with his daughters and making them pancakes), but he can‰Ûªt check his pride. Fighting means being in a cage in more than one sense.

‰ÛÏThe Cage Fighter‰Ûù is not riveting from moment to moment, but Mr. Unay allows the movie‰Ûªs themes to click into place beautifully toward the end, when Mr. Carman shares a moment of rapport at a bar with a competitor ‰ÛÓ and learns, to his surprise, that his younger rival is every bit as mortal.

With a bare-bones, direct-cinema style and only scant context, the movie ‰ÛÓ the first directorial feature from Jeff Unay, who has worked in visual effects ‰ÛÓ plunges viewers into the world of Joe Carman, a mixed martial arts fighter in Washington State. In the first scene, Mr. Carman is 39, hardly a prime age for grappling. The question that emerges is whether he knows it‰Ûªs time to call it quits.

Directed by Michael Radford (no stranger to corny, middle-of-the-road snoozers) with more attention to chronology than creativity, the story dallies so long in its hero‰Ûªs leafy Tuscan childhood that we‰Ûªre more than halfway through before anything resembling a singing career materializes. Before then, we learn about the glaucoma that rendered him virtually blind, the soccer accident that exacerbated the condition and the love of music set aside in favor of a law degree.

The filmmakers have no such excuse. Not until Antonio Banderas arrives to play Maestro, the crucial voice coach who knocks Amos into shape, does this metronomic slog to stardom muster a pulse. He‰Ûªs too late to save the movie, but he‰Ûªs just in time to stop us from nodding off altogether.

How much of ‰ÛÏThe Music of Silence‰Ûù is true and how much fiction, only its inspiration, the singer Andrea Bocelli, knows for sure. Adapted from Mr. Bocelli‰Ûªs 1999 novel of the same name (a story he has described as ‰ÛÏsimilar to‰Ûù his own life), this blah trudge from cradle to stage will be catnip to his fans and Ambien to everyone else.

Around him, primarily Italian actors gamely wrestle with thickly accented English dialogue, most of it hagiographic and all of it dull. The object of their admiration, meanwhile ‰ÛÓ here called Amos Bardi and played as an adult by Toby Sebastian ‰ÛÓ is a singularly bland talent, a mopey presence in cardigans and corduroy. Yet my sympathies are all with Mr. Sebastian: It can‰Ûªt be easy to create a dynamic character when you‰Ûªre unable to fully open your eyes.

Released without fanfare or publicity screenings, the haunted-house movie ‰ÛÏWinchester‰Ûù would seem to lack the confidence of its makers. One soon sees why: Despite the typically elevating presence of Helen Mirren, this super-silly feature (the fifth from the Australian brothers Peter and Michael Spierig) stubbornly resists being classed up.

Enter Dr. Price (Jason Clarke), a psychologist hired by the Winchester company‰Ûªs board to count Sarah‰Ûªs marbles and report back. Conveniently addicted to laudanum, Dr. Price is soon staggering around the labyrinthine structure, besieged by generic scares: a creepy butler, a rattling armoire, a child in the grip of milky-eyed possession. The Hogwarts-like domicile might be swarming with staff and construction workers, but not until Price arrives do the spirits hit the fan.

Set in 1906 and inspired by actual events (liberally sauced with myth and legend), the story centers on the eccentric Sarah Winchester (Ms. Mirren, grimly determined), heiress to the rifle fortune and eager dabbler in architecture and spiritualism. Believing that she has flourished on the deaths caused by her late husband‰Ûªs invention, Sarah atones by constructing a vast and ever-changing mansion, whose hundreds of rooms are intended to imprison evil spirits or encourage benign ones to move on.

Written by the Spierigs and Tom Vaughan, the script is as batty and clichÌ©d as its heroine. The house (you can take a tour of the real one in San Jose, Calif.) never feels like a single space, as ho-hum apparitions appear and disappear without a trace. Ms. Mirren and her representatives are probably hoping the movie will do likewise.

Part of the movie‰Ûªs pleasure and its ethos ‰ÛÓ which wends through its visuals ‰ÛÓ is how it dispenses with familiar either/or divides, including the binary opposition that tends to shape our discourse on race. Life in Wakanda is at once urban and rural, futuristic and traditional, technological and mystical. Spaceships zoom over soaring buildings with thatched tops; a hover train zips over a market with hanging woven baskets. In one of the most striking locales, an open-air throne room is horizontally lined with suspended tree limbs, creating a loose pattern that pointedly blurs the divide between the interior and exterior worlds and is echoed by the fretwork in costumes and other sets.

Buoyed by its groovy women and Afrofuturist flourishes, Wakanda itself is finally the movie‰Ûªs strength, its rallying cry and state of mind. Early on, a white character carelessly describes it as ‰ÛÏa third world country ‰ÛÓ textiles, shepherds, cool outfits.‰Ûù Part of the joke, which the movie wittily engages, is that Wakanda certainly fits that profile except that its shepherds patrol the border with techno-wizardry, and its textiles and costumes dazzle because of the country‰Ûªs secret vibranium sauce. More critically, having never been conquered, Wakanda has evaded the historical traumas endured by much of the rest of Africa, freeing it from the ravages of both colonialism and postcolonialism.

A jolt of a movie, ‰ÛÏBlack Panther‰Ûù creates wonder with great flair and feeling partly through something Hollywood rarely dreams of anymore: myth. Most big studio fantasies take you out for a joy ride only to hit the same exhausted story and franchise-expanding beats. Not this one. Its axis point is the fantastical nation of Wakanda, an African Eden where verdant-green landscapes meet blue-sky science fiction. There, spaceships with undercarriages resembling tribal masks soar over majestic waterfalls, touching down in a story that has far more going for it than branding.

The story initially involves a satisfying if obvious cartoonish villain, Ulysses Klaue (Andy Serkis, having a conspicuously very good time), an underworld arms dealer with a weaponized arm, an Afrikaans sneer and a rampaging cohort that includes Erik Killmonger (Mr. Jordan). As his name announces, Killmonger has, well, issues to go with his striking body ornamentation. The band‰Ûªs evildoing ways attract the attention of the Black Panther and an international lawman in the person of a friendly C.I.A. agent (the customarily cuddly Martin Freeman), whose good-guy status is just one reminder that ‰ÛÏBlack Panther‰Ûù adheres to at least some dubious Hollywood conventions.

Race matters in ‰ÛÏBlack Panther‰Ûù and it matters deeply, not in terms of Manichaean good guys and bad but as a means to explore larger human concerns about the past, the present and the uses and abuses of power. That alone makes it more thoughtful about how the world works than a lot of mainstream movies, even if those ideas are interspersed with plenty of comic-book posturing. It wouldn‰Ûªt be a Marvel production without manly skirmishes and digital avatars. Yet in its emphasis on black imagination, creation and liberation, the movie becomes an emblem of a past that was denied and a future that feels very present. And in doing so opens up its world, and yours, beautifully.

As with all Marvel screen ventures, the story has a lot of moving parts, but in general the results don‰Ûªt register as the same-old superhero busywork, the kind that makes for forgettable stories and strenuously overinflated running times. Written by Mr. Coogler and Joe Robert Cole, ‰ÛÏBlack Panther‰Ûù brings T‰ÛªChalla‰Ûªs story up to the present, sketches in his past and looks to his future, all while clearing room for the Marvel Cinematic Universe and its other unitard-wearing warriors. (Black Panther was first wedged into the forgettable ‰ÛÏCaptain America: Civil War.‰Ûù) The movie also rather too breezily establishes Wakanda as a militaristic monarchy that is nevertheless fair and democratic.

Wakanda is home to Black Panther, a.k.a. T‰ÛªChalla (Chadwick Boseman), the latest Marvel hero to leap off the comic-book page and into his own movie. Created in 1966 by Stan Lee (script) and Jack Kirby (art), the original Black Panther ‰ÛÓ a hepcat in a slinky suit with claws and ears ‰ÛÓ debuted alongside the Fantastic Four in an adventure in Wakanda, which is powered by a mystery metal, vibranium. It was a splashy, timely entrance (the revolutionary group that shares his name officially formed that same year), and by the end of his first escapade, the Four had assured T‰ÛªChalla ‰ÛÏthere‰Ûªs no reason for the Black Panther‰Ûªs career to come to an end!‰Ûù

For a while, as the story and the Black Panther veer here and there, jumping from Wakanda to Busan, South Korea, the filmmakers seem as if they‰Ûªre simply going to deliver a remix of James Bond with a touch of Spidey shenanigans. The Black Panther even slinks into a swank casino with some backup and before long the place has erupted with the kind of choreographed mayhem that ‰ÛÓ as legs and gowns twirl ‰ÛÓ achieves liftoff. There‰Ûªs also the inevitable chaotic car chase that turns Busan into a video game and, dispiritingly, a car commercial, an egregious tie-in that is somewhat alleviated by the amusing image of a woman warrior‰Ûªs bare foot putting pedal to the metal.

Flourishes like this (along with an amusingly airborne wig and, later, rampaging rhinos) and the Wakandan backdrop give the action scenes kick and actual personality, but Mr. Coogler‰Ûªs directing strengths are more intimate. There are sequences in ‰ÛÏBlack Panther‰Ûù that may make you cry because of where they go and what they say, but also because of the sensitivity he brings to them. He makes some savvy story choices too. And so, before Mr. Serkis can steal too many scenes, Mr. Coogler turns his attention to Killmonger and pushes the movie in another direction, away from a white villain wronging black people to black people living their lives.

Mr. Jordan is a terrifically charismatic presence and there are times when you wonder if he might have made a better Black Panther. Mr. Boseman‰Ûªs magnetism is more slow-burning and his performance is more physically restrained than Mr. Jordan, even deliberate, though he has his splashier, freewheeling moments, including some hand-to-hand grappling. (Wrestling is big in Wakanda, hence a few sexy smackdowns featuring acres of bare skin and jumping muscle.) Like many other Wakandans, he speaks in English with a South African lilt, an accent that vividly summons up Nelson Mandela and suggests that T‰ÛªChalla will soon be assuming the role of international diplomat.

It‰Ûªs important to the movie‰Ûªs politics and myth-building that he is surrounded by a phalanx of women, among them a battalion of women warriors called the Dora Milaje. These aren‰Ûªt moviedom‰Ûªs irritatingly token strong chicks, the tough babes with sizable biceps and skills but no real roles. For all his father issues, T‰ÛªChalla is enveloped by women who cushion him in maternal, military, sisterly and scientific support. A female general (Danai Gurira) stands by his side; his baby sister (a vivacious Letitia Wright) provides gadgets and withering asides ÌÊ la Bond‰Ûªs gadget guy. Angela Bassett swans in as the royal mother, while Lupita Nyong‰Ûªo, as a spy, makes the case for her own spinoff.

In the decades since, Black Panther has undergone a variety of costume alterations and adventures in the comics, some under the direction of the filmmaker Reginald Hudlin and, more recently, the author Ta-Nehisi Coates. To direct the first Panther movie, Marvel tapped Ryan Coogler, who with his last outing, ‰ÛÏCreed,‰Ûù shook the dust off the Rocky series by giving it an African-American champion played by Michael B. Jordan. For ‰ÛÏBlack Panther,‰Ûù Mr. Coogler brought back both Mr. Jordan and some former crew members ‰ÛÓ including Rachel Morrison, the director of photography on his first feature ‰ÛÏFruitvale Station‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ continuity that may help account for this movie‰Ûªs intimacy and fluidity.

The rejection of the either/or divide extends to Killmonger, whose emotional, fraught back story gives the movie more heft and real-world friction than any of Marvel‰Ûªs other superhero blowouts. Like a lot of adventures, ‰ÛÏBlack Panther‰Ûù turns on a familiar father-and-son drama ‰ÛÓ there‰Ûªs an assassination, a power vacuum and a somewhat reluctant heir ‰ÛÓ a patrilineal intrigue that is filled in here with intense face-offs involving questions of ancestry, identity, the African diaspora, the new world and the old. One particularly moving narrative thread features Sterling K. Brown, a tremulous, vibrantly sensitive actor who conveys entire chapters of grief. (He could out-weep Juliette Binoche.)

The movie follows three women combating the proliferation of drugs in the heavily affected city of Huntington, W.Va. The filmmakers trail Jan Rader, who becomes the city‰Ûªs fire chief, on tense overdose calls, and sit in the courtroom of Judge Patricia Keller, who speaks to the recovering addicts before her with the patience of a parent. Necia Freeman hands out food to addicted prostitutes.

The front-runner is probably Elaine McMillion Sheldon‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏHeroin(e),‰Ûù which bears the imprimatur of Netflix, the company that took this statuette last year with ‰ÛÏThe White Helmets.‰Ûù The most visceral of the nominees, it addresses an issue in the news ‰ÛÓ the opioid epidemic ‰ÛÓ with present-tense reportage and an eye toward putting human faces on the crisis.

‰ÛÏHeaven Is a Traffic Jam on the 405‰Ûù tells the story of Mindy Alper, who spent her life grappling with mental illness, and emerged as a successful artist. The director, Frank Stiefel, draws on Ms. Alper‰Ûªs artwork for visual flair, but the film is a bit of a slog.

‰ÛÏEdith+Eddie,‰Ûù from the Chicago documentary house Kartemquin Films, simply offers a moving portrait. The director Laura Checkoway watches compassionately as the title characters ‰ÛÓ a Virginia couple who met when splitting a lottery ticket and married in their mid-90s ‰ÛÓ are separated because of squabbling family members and an indifferent bureaucracy. It‰Ûªs the most intimate movie in the lineup, and all the better for it.
In some years, watching the Oscar-nominated documentary shorts is the easiest way to spot the winner. This year there are plausible rationalizations for all five.

Police brutality is front and center in Kate Davis‰Ûªs powerful ‰ÛÏTraffic Stop,‰Ûù which revisits the violent arrest of Breaion King, an African-American teacher in Austin, Tex., flagged by an officer for a traffic violation. The movie combines the dashcam footage of the arrest with Ms. King‰Ûªs reflections on the incident. The biographical details, meant to warm the heart and stoke outrage, feel superfluous. (A violent arrest would be a violent arrest even if Ms. King weren‰Ûªt a model citizen.)

At 39 minutes, ‰ÛÏHeroin(e)‰Ûù sprawls; each thread could sustain longer-term treatment. In sheer scope, the movie is likely to overshadow Thomas Lennon‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏKnife Skills,‰Ûù though Mr. Lennon‰Ûªs film will attract anyone eager to gawk at mouthwatering food. It follows the first class of trainee workers at Edwins, a Cleveland haute cuisine restaurant committed to hiring the formerly incarcerated, with the hope of preventing their returns to prison.

Bigotry of a different kind powers the German filmmaker Katja Benrath‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏWatu Wote/All of Us,‰Ûù as Muslim bus passengers in Kenya rally to protect a terrified Christian woman from an attack by Al-Shabaab terrorists. My personal favorite, though, is ‰ÛÏThe Silent Child,‰Ûù Chris Overton‰Ûªs heartbreaking story (written by one of its stars, Rachel Shenton) about a profoundly isolated deaf 5-year-old (a wonderful Maisie Sly) and the social worker who tries to help her. Gorgeously shot and perfectly performed, the movie delivers an emotional wallop that many features six times its length never achieve.

Churning with gun violence, racism, prejudice and religious conflict, four of the five live-action short films nominated for Oscars this year feel so weighty that the lone comedy comes as something of a relief.

That would be ‰ÛÏThe Eleven O‰ÛªClock,‰Ûù Derin Seale‰Ûªs whip-smart standoff between a psychiatrist and a delusional patient that resembles your worst psychoanalytic nightmare. Hinging on a showdown between objective reality and individual fantasy, this brisk Australian entry is as painfully relevant to our unstable political moment as most of its fellow nominees.

Three are based on actual incidents, including both American entries, Reed Van Dyk's ‰ÛÏDeKalb Elementary‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ a throat-tightening duet between a disturbed school shooter and an empathetic administrator ‰ÛÓ and the quietly potent ‰ÛÏMy Nephew Emmett.‰Ûù Unfolding during the hours preceding the 1955 murder of the black teenager Emmett Till, Kevin Wilson, Jr.‰Ûªs fraught drama, richly photographed in glowing gold and mahogany, coaxes tension from little more than a simple shack and a marvelous performance from L.B. Williams as Till‰Ûªs uncle, a man who has seen too much and knows what‰Ûªs coming.

Three of the other shorts are not without their pleasures. ‰ÛÏLou,‰Ûù a Pixar short directed by Dave Mullins, sees the anthropomorphized contents of a schoolyard lost-and-found box teaching a lesson to a bully. The premise is a stretch, but Pixar‰Ûªs tech mastery and imaginative chops were made to render such stretches into good cartoons, and this is one. ‰ÛÏNegative Space,‰Ûù directed by Max Porter and Ru Kuwahata, is realized in exquisite stop-motion animation. An adult reminisces about how his father taught him to efficiently pack a suitcase; the childhood memories yield to a chilly present-day and a road trip to a farewell. ‰ÛÏRevolting Rhymes‰Ûù is a BBC adaptation of Roald Dahl‰Ûªs cheeky revisionist fairy-tale poetry book. A wolf (superbly voiced by Dominic West) regales a baby sitter with the real lowdown on Red Riding Hood and Snow White, with couplets including ‰ÛÏThen this is the disgusting part/the Queen sat down and ate the heart.‰Ûù The computer animation here yields a fun variety of facial caricatures for the beloved figures being deconstructed.

The animated shorts nominated for Oscars are rarely the subjects of controversy. But this year, ‰ÛÏDear Basketball,‰Ûù which the retired N.B.A. star Kobe Bryant conceived, executive-produced and narrated, drew some #MeToo movement disapprobation when it was announced as one of the five nominees for the 90th Academy Awards. On social media and elsewhere, a 2003 sexual assault case against Mr. Bryant (which was later dismissed) was cited as a reason not to honor the movie. But the content of this short is unobjectionable on the surface. Directed by Glen Keane, the movie is an autobiographical sketch in which Mr. Bryant thanks basketball ‰ÛÓ both the object and the game ‰ÛÓ for the life he devoted to it. The animation, rendered in modes of pencils and pastels, has a gorgeous fluency to be sure. The score is by none other than John Williams, American cinema‰Ûªs king of the Heroic Theme. Ultimately, ‰ÛÏDear Basketball‰Ûù is substance-free, an advertisement for itself. It deserves to not receive an Oscar for that reason alone.

The really outstanding nominee is ‰ÛÏGarden Party,‰Ûù directed by a French collective of six that calls itself Illogic. It‰Ûªs a simple narrative in which a few animals, mostly amphibious ‰ÛÓ a tree frog and a bullfrog among them ‰ÛÓ trudge out of water and down from branches into a mysteriously deserted mansion. The mastery of computer animation here is staggering. The rotting food in the kitchen that the animals snack on is a vivid metaphor for human overconsumption, and the reason for the house‰Ûªs desolate state is both horror-movie grim and mordantly funny. Watch out for Illogic ‰ÛÓ these artists are sure to be heard from more decisively in the future.

Their heroism is at the center of Clint Eastwood‰Ûªs new movie, ‰ÛÏThe 15:17 to Paris,‰Ûù a dramatic reconstruction as unassuming and effective as the action it depicts. Based on a book written (along with Jeffrey E. Stern) by Mr. Sadler, Mr. Skarlatos and Mr. Stone, the film stars them, too.

And on a normal day, they would have been ‰ÛÓ part of the mass of tourists, commuters and other travelers taking a quick ride from one European capital to another. At times, Spencer, the most restless of the three and the one whose life choices receive the most attention, talks about the feeling of being ‰ÛÏcatapulted‰Ûù toward some obscure destiny. But ‰ÛÏThe 15:17 to Paris‰Ûù isn‰Ûªt a meditation on fate any more than it is an exploration of the politics of global terrorism. Rather, it is concerned with locating the precise boundary between the banal and the extraordinary, between routine and violence, between complacency and courage.

On Aug. 21, 2015, Ayoub El Khazzani boarded a high-speed train en route to Paris, armed with a knife, a pistol, an assault rifle and nearly 300 rounds of ammunition. His attack, apparently inspired by ISIS, was thwarted by the bravery and quick thinking of several passengers, notably three young American tourists: Alek Skarlatos, Anthony Sadler and Spencer Stone.

Frustrated by the educational demands of both church and state, the boys indulge in minor acts of rebellion: toilet-papering a neighbor‰Ûªs house, swearing in gym class, playing war in the woods. They are separated when Alek moves to Oregon to live with his father and Anthony changes schools, but the three stay in touch as Anthony attends college and Alek and Spencer enlist in the military. Spencer, stationed in Portugal, meets up with Anthony in Rome, and Alek, who is serving in Afghanistan, visits a girlfriend in Germany before joining his pals in Berlin. They go clubbing in Amsterdam, wake up hung over and, after some debate, head for Paris.

To call what happens before the confrontation with the gunman a plot, in the conventional sense, does not seem quite accurate. Nor do Spencer, Anthony and Alek seem quite like movie characters. But they aren‰Ûªt documentary subjects, either. Mr. Eastwood, famous for avoiding extensive rehearsals and retakes, doesn‰Ûªt demand too much acting. Throughout the film, the principal performers behave with the mix of affability and reserve they might display when meeting a group of people for the first time. They are polite, direct and unfailingly good-natured, even when a given scene might call for more emotional intensity. In a normal movie, they would be extras.

But the thing to admire about ‰ÛÏThe 15:17 to Paris‰Ûù is precisely its artlessness. Mr. Eastwood, who has long favored a lean, functional directing style, practices an economy here that makes some of his earlier movies look positively baroque. He almost seems to be testing the limits of minimalism, seeing how much artifice he can strip away and still achieve some kind of dramatic impact. There is not a lot of suspense, and not much psychological exploration, either. A certain blunt power is guaranteed by the facts of the story, and Mr. Eastwood doesn‰Ûªt obviously try for anything more than that. But his workmanlike absorption in the task at hand is precisely what makes this movie fascinating as well as moving. Its radical plainness is tinged with mystery.

Producing the illusion of intimacy is not among Mr. Eastwood‰Ûªs priorities. He has always been a natural existentialist, devoted to the idea that meaning and character emerge through action. At the end of ‰ÛÏThe 15:17 to Paris,‰Ûù a speech by former President FranÌ_ois Hollande of France provides a touch of eloquence and a welcome flood of feeling. But the mood of the film is better captured by Mr. Skarlatos‰Ûªs account of it, published in news reports after the attack: ‰ÛÏWe chose to fight and got lucky and didn‰Ûªt die.‰Ûù

The practice of casting nonprofessionals in stories that closely mirror their own experiences has a long history ‰ÛÓ it‰Ûªs a staple of Italian neorealism, the films of Robert Bresson and the Iranian cinema of the 1990s ‰ÛÓ but it remains a rarity in Hollywood. Usually the most we can expect is a poignant end-credits glimpse of the real people our favorite movie stars have pretended to be for the previous two hours. After all, part of the appeal of movies ‰ÛÏinspired by true events‰Ûù is the chance to admire the artistry of actors (like Tom Hanks‰Ûªs, say, in Mr. Eastwood‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏSully‰Ûù) as they communicate the grit and gumption of ordinary Americans in tough circumstances.

Who exactly are these guys? They first met as boys in Sacramento, which is where we meet them, played by Cole Eichenberger (Spencer Stone), Paul-Mikel Williams (Anthony Sadler) and Bryce Gheisar (Alek Skarlatos). Alek and Spencer, whose mothers (Judy Greer and Jenna Fischer) are friends, pull their sons out of public school and enroll them in a Christian academy, where they meet Anthony, a regular visitor to the principal‰Ûªs office.

The personalities of the main characters remain opaque, their inner lives the subject of speculation. You can wonder about the sorrow in Alek‰Ûªs eyes, about the hint of a temper underneath Spencer‰Ûªs jovial energy, about Anthony‰Ûªs skeptical detachment. But at the end of the movie, you don‰Ûªt really know them all that well. (You barely know Chris, a British passenger who helped subdue Mr. Khazzani, at all. He is seen but not named.)

Becks goes to live with her mother, Ann (Christine Lahti), a former nun, in the St. Louis area. Ann is still working on embracing her daughter‰Ûªs sexual orientation, and it‰Ûªs a measure of the movie‰Ûªs nuance that they never quite reach an accord. Unsure of what‰Ûªs next, Becks performs in a bar run by a friend (Dan Fogler) and offers guitar lessons ‰ÛÓ though her only pupil is Elyse (Mena Suvari), the wife of a man Becks knew in high school as a bully.

A description of ‰ÛÏBecks,‰Ûù about a lesbian musician who returns to the more conservative environment in which she grew up, makes it sound like an earnest, shopworn indie drama. But the movie exemplifies how small judgments in pace, performance and soundtrack can transcend modest trappings.

That Becks and Elyse will become more than friends is a predictable development, but the movie makes it persuasive by taking its time. Perhaps recognizing their biggest asset, the directors, Elizabeth Rohrbaugh and Daniel Powell, allow Ms. Hall‰Ûªs numbers to play out at length. (The songs are by Alyssa Robbins, the movie‰Ûªs real-life inspiration, and Steve Salett.) If the screenplay perhaps backs itself into a corner, its irresolution feels true to life.

Much of the credit is due to the film‰Ûªs charismatic, tone-perfect lead, Lena Hall, who won a Tony in 2014 for ‰ÛÏHedwig and the Angry Inch.‰Ûù She plays Becks, a Brooklyn guitarist and singer who follows her girlfriend (Hayley Kiyoko) to Los Angeles ‰ÛÓ only to catch her with another woman.

Let‰Ûªs go with that, then. ‰ÛÏHe‰Ûªs not good in a crisis,‰Ûù Ben‰Ûªs father informs us, though a montage of botched suicide attempts has already established Ben‰Ûªs misery bona fides and general ineptness. His wife has skedaddled, but his nosy neighbor (the delightful Diana Bang) is eager to clean his house and enable his quest to track down the woman who was once almost his adoptive sister. Like the wiring in Ben‰Ûªs brain, it‰Ûªs complicated.

Indie romantic comedies are swarming with aimless, emotionally damaged men seeking meaning in the arms of confident young women. Sometimes, like Ben (Thomas Middleditch) in ‰ÛÏEntanglement,‰Ûù these sad specimens are permitted clinical passes for their weird behavior; but whether in need of restraints, medication or simply a decent barber, they are almost always presented as desirable romantic partners.

Impressively photographed and perkily paced, Jason Filiatrault‰Ûªs story never droops quite as much as its lead character, injecting a welcome poignancy that tempers the cuteness. And Mr. Middleditch (star of the smart HBO comedy ‰ÛÏSilicon Valley‰Ûù and those grating Verizon commercials) is blessedly low-key, dialing down the neuroses and allowing his director, Jason James, to control the increasingly sanguine mood.

Yet the job of rescuing the movie from a well of cartoonish whimsy falls on the gifted Jess Weixler as Hanna, the mystery woman who gives Ben the eye and a reason to live. Pert and pretty and smart-mouthed, Hanna is intriguing and a little dangerous ‰ÛÓ the splash of vinegar that counters the sugar. That she would give Ben the time of day is more than enough notice that all may not be as it seems.

As popular as this window-fogging franchise has become, its flaccid finale is likely critic proof. But if I can persuade just one of you to bypass its milquetoast masochism and watch the stratospherically superior ‰ÛÏ9 1/2 Weeks‰Ûù instead, then I will have done my job.

Layering a damp-squib thriller subplot beneath what appears to be an ad campaign for the one-percent lifestyle, the returning director and screenwriter (James Foley and Niall Leonard) test the newly married couple with an inconvenient pregnancy and an unconvincing car chase. There‰Ûªs an out-of-left-field abduction and a marital tiff over email addresses; but these narrative fragments, lazily tossed together alongside a neglected supporting cast, are no more than a flimsy causeway connecting bonking sessions.

Invariably accompanied by wailing makeout music and sometimes a dairy product, these function simultaneously as the movie‰Ûªs raison d‰ÛªÌ»tre and its creamy topping. Yet with the couple‰Ûªs power dynamic seemingly settled ‰ÛÓ he‰Ûªs a controlling chauvinist, she‰Ûªs mostly fine with that ‰ÛÓ the rods and restraints are no longer necessary negotiating tools. Now, it‰Ûªs just married sex, albeit more rippling and racy than most.

Previously on ‰ÛÏOne Bruise at a Time‰Ûù (a.k.a. the first two ‰ÛÏFifty Shades‰Ûù outings): Ana and Christian (Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan), our slap-and-tickle surrogates, bonded through bondage and a shared affection for flattering lighting. Now, with ‰ÛÏFifty Shades Freed,‰Ûù we‰Ûªve reached what the publicity notes are pleased to call ‰ÛÏthe climactic chapter‰Ûù of this titillation trilogy based on the heavy-breathing novels of E.L. James. If another sequel shows up, though, I‰Ûªm going to have to use my safe word.

Ms. Hall, though, is the standout, selling Anna‰Ûªs indecision even through some of the script‰Ûªs dubious patches. (It‰Ûªs bad enough that Dane is such a thinly conceived Prince Charming; Will‰Ûªs epiphanic drug trip with Lydia is an even worse clichÌ©.) And it should be said that ‰ÛÏPermission‰Ûù really shows its teeth in the homestretch. If unwise remarks at a dinner can cast a pall over a longstanding relationship, then a great ending can redeem and even force reconsideration of an otherwise middling film.

Despite Reece‰Ûªs apology the next day, the idea sticks, and once agreed to, the swinging experiment pays off with astonishing speed. The roulette wheel of New York City dating is no problem for Will and Anna, even with a lack of practice. On the couple‰Ûªs first night out, Anna, a music historian whose thesis draft has the mind-melting title ‰ÛÏFemale Composers + Feminism ‰ÛÒ Matriarchal Pedagogy = Feminist Composers‰Ûù meets the composer-rocker of her dreams, Dane (FranÌ_ois Arnaud). Soon after, Will responds to the flirtations of a divorcÌ©e, Lydia (Gina Gershon), who walks into his store, where he sells, in what one hopes is unintentional Freudianism, wood furniture.

Important safety tip: While drinking, do not propose a drastic relationship overhaul to your friends, especially if your advice sounds suspiciously like a screenplay pitch. In ‰ÛÏPermission,‰Ûù a birthday celebration turns awkward when Reece (Morgan Spector) mentions an elephant in the room: Anna (Rebecca Hall), who is turning 30, and Will (Dan Stevens) have only ever gone out with each other. They‰Ûªre likely to marry, and they‰Ûªre clearly a perfect, consistent couple ‰ÛÓ but aren‰Ûªt they the least bit curious about what sex with other people is like?

‰ÛÏPermission‰Ûù actually offers a double dose of couples therapy, according nearly equal screen time to Reece and his relationship with Hale (David Joseph Craig), Anna‰Ûªs brother, who desperately wants a baby. The movie raises questions about how the pairs choose to talk or not talk to each other, even while inviting inadvertent musing on how all the characters can afford such nice apartments. There‰Ûªs also an intriguing musical-chairs aspect to the casting: Ms. Hall is in fact married to Mr. Spector, while Mr. Craig is married to the film‰Ûªs writer and director, Brian Crano. It‰Ûªs easy to envision ‰ÛÏPermission‰Ûù reconceived as a gimmick-driven Off Broadway play in which the generally very good leads swap roles every week.

Indeed, despite the fact that the film‰Ûªs director is Will Gluck (an American whose prior film was the 2014 ‰ÛÏAnnie‰Ûù remake), the mode of cheeky humor here is reasonably British. There are at least a handful of inflections of Aardman, the renowned British stop-motion animation studio, in this picture. The scene in which Peter, his sisters Flopsy, Mopsy and Cottontail, and his neurotic sidekick Benjamin Bunny travel to London on a mission to find a crucial human character recalls Aardman‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏShaun the Sheep Movie,‰Ûù from 2015. Let me be clear, though: ‰ÛÏShaun the Sheep Movie‰Ûù is an animation masterpiece, while this film is ‰Û_ not. For one thing, it leans pretty heavily on the convention of ‰ÛÏcomedic scenes scored to jumpy ‰Û÷classic‰Ûª rock songs.‰Ûù But its story line is clean; the live-action actors, particularly Rose Byrne (as Bea, an artist who paints portraits of the bunnies), bring their onscreen-appeal A game; and the computer-generated animals are charming, albeit lacking in the particular gentle winsomeness of Potter‰Ûªs originals.

With movies such as these, the most pertinent immediate question is, ‰ÛÏWill the kids like it?‰Ûù I don‰Ûªt have any myself, but for the press screening I was able (with an actual parent, mind you) to host three, between the ages of 5 and 7. These were pretty sophisticated kids, as you tend to find in the tristate area. One of the 7-year-olds, on learning that I had a fear of heights, asked me if I‰Ûªd ever seen ‰ÛÏVertigo.‰Ûù They enjoyed the movie pretty quietly, and over pizza afterward, enthusiastically compared notes on their favorite scenes. Your results may vary.

If you follow trends in children‰Ûªs animated films, you might have figured out quite some time ago that a cheekily self-reflexive, C.G.I.-heavy treatment of the beloved character Peter Rabbit was inevitable. Over in Britain, at least, this development has been met with great trepidation. ‰ÛÏAnother kids‰Ûª classic wrecked forever,‰Ûù read a headline of one U.K. article last fall, a review of this film‰Ûªs trailer. (I still can‰Ûªt get over the fact that reviewing trailers is now a thing.)

The film in its entirety, I found, was not as bad as the trailer looked to many. Yes, right away the movie dispenses with the sweetness and light and lyricism of the books by Beatrix Potter. A chorus of birds flying over the British countryside, singing an air that sounds as if it may turn into the title song of ‰ÛÏThe Sound of Music,‰Ûù is swept out of frame to make way for blue-jacketed Peter, whose wisecracks and egocentricity rather recall that of an American cartoon bunny, Bugs. But given that the wisecracks are voiced by the London-born James Corden, this Peter hasn‰Ûªt been too Yankee-fied.

Sam is talking about leaving her job as ‰ÛÏa glorified personal assistant‰Ûù for an older woman. Sam compares herself both to her boss, who is contentedly single, and to Jess, who seems happily married. ‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt want to feel adrift in some nebulous middle ground,‰Ûù Sam says. ‰ÛÏWhere am I?‰Ûù she wonders, repeating the question twice. She answers it herself: ‰ÛÏWasteland.‰Ûù To which Jess gently responds: ‰ÛÏHeavy handed and dramatic, minus five points.‰Ûù It‰Ûªs a small, recognizably true and complex moment as Sam‰Ûªs self-absorption is met by a sisterly reality check. Each smiles ‰ÛÓ one weakly yet warmly, the other almost fitfully ‰ÛÓ and then Sam abruptly asks if Buddy is seeing another woman.

‰ÛÏLove, jealousy and deficiency‰Ûù would make a fitting alternate title for ‰ÛÏGolden Exits,‰Ûù the latest from the writer-director Alex Ross Perry. These words are spoken fairly late in the movie, which traces the emotional and psychological architecture of two intersecting groups of men and women. For the most part, they make an absurdly comic, at times pitifully narcissistic assembly ‰ÛÓ you laugh at them and then you cringe. White and mostly comfortably middle-class or bourgeois adjacent, they have nice homes, jobs and people they love and some they scarcely tolerate. They also have a lot of time to talk about themselves and their discontent, which eats at some and all but consumes others.

Naomi ‰ÛÓ her beauty, youth and novelty ‰ÛÓ disturbs the fragile geometry created by Nick, Alyssa and Alyssa‰Ûªs supremely thorny, self-satisfied sister, Gwen (a peerless Mary-Louise Parker). Together, these three mirror a younger trio that enters when Naomi meets up Buddy (Jason Schwartzman), a childhood acquaintance who runs a recording studio with his wife, Jess (Analeigh Tipton). Buddy seems charmed by Naomi but he too is discomforted, almost destabilized by her. When Buddy first tells Jess about his plans to meet up with an old acquaintance, he agitatedly paces the room, eliding specifics only to blurt ‰ÛÏit‰Ûªs a her,‰Ûù as if he were confessing a sin. ‰ÛÏSorry if that was unclear.‰Ûù

Over the next months, a period marked by time stamps (‰ÛÏApril 12‰Ûù), the triangulated relationships among these disparate characters shift, overlap and almost collapse with near-mathematical precision. Much of the movie takes place in rooms that are either modestly sized (Nick‰Ûªs broom closet of an office) or are framed and shot to convey constriction and limitation. Working with a low budget that never becomes a hindrance, Mr. Perry uses exterior space to convey interiority, as when Alyssa speaks to Nick ‰ÛÓ who keeps his back to her ‰ÛÓ from across a room that feels like a vast, unpassable chasm. (The director of photography is Sean Price Williams; the editor is Robert Greene.)

This intimation of marital disloyalty ‰ÛÓ a suggestion that is itself a betrayal ‰ÛÓ is a moment of casual cruelty in a movie filled with cuts and wounds, some Oedipal. ‰ÛÏGolden Exits‰Ûù is partly indebted to Woody Allen and Eric Rohmer, cinematic patriarchs with long shadows. Mr. Perry has a thing for celebrated fathers: the dead painter in ‰ÛÏQueen of Earth,‰Ûù the monstrous literary legend in ‰ÛÏListen Up Philip.‰Ûù In ‰ÛÏGolden Exits,‰Ûù the legacy of Alyssa and Gwen‰Ûªs father hangs over their lives and can feel like a rebuke to their pettiness and navel gazing. It‰Ûªs difficult to imagine these self-involved sisters having a legacy that‰Ûªs worth archiving, which also seems to be part of their father‰Ûªs endowment.

Which brings me back to ‰ÛÏlove, jealousy and deficiency,‰Ûù a phrase that the determinedly unhappy Sam unloads on Naomi. Sam is holding forth on relationships, but as is often true of most everyone in ‰ÛÏGolden Exits,‰Ûù she is also talking about herself. ‰ÛÏMy problem is that personal dynamics ebb and flow,‰Ûù she says, though it‰Ûªs obvious she has no idea what her problem is. Sam wants to leave her job ‰ÛÏon a high note, a perfect final moment‰Ûù (a phrase that seems to nod at the film‰Ûªs title). She adds that ‰ÛÏfamily doesn‰Ûªt afford that endless optimism for happy endings.‰Ûù There‰Ûªs something in her pessimism, but as Sam keeps talking ‰ÛÓ and talking ‰ÛÓ about herself, both Naomi and the world slip away.

‰ÛÏGolden Exits‰Ûù takes place in a lonely, prettily tree-lined corner of Brooklyn where even the most populated streets feel empty. The story‰Ûªs hub is a newly arrived young Australian, Naomi (Emily Browning), who has taken a temporary job with an archivist, Nick (Adam Horovitz). He‰Ûªs married to Alyssa (ChloÌÇ Sevigny), a therapist, and is organizing his dead father-in-law‰Ûªs papers or ‰ÛÏmaterials,‰Ûù as he testily puts it. Nick and Alyssa‰Ûªs marriage seems locked in a slow-moving death spiral. ‰ÛÏDo I need to be worried about Naomi?‰Ûù Alyssa asks. Nick, who has a habit of fidgeting with his wedding ring, answers no (more or less).

There‰Ûªs poignancy to these characters and how they keep reaching and fumbling for one another across the divide. In one scene, Gwen sits in Alyssa‰Ûªs living room, the two sisters talking, mostly and awkwardly about Nick. They inelegantly hold glasses of wine while sitting at a distance from each other ‰ÛÓ an off-kilter, uncomfortable arrangement that adds to the disquiet. Here, as throughout, the framing remains steady, a visual choice that can feel like a long, hard, pitiless stare. The scene that follows directly echoes this one, but takes place in Jess‰Ûªs apartment where she‰Ûªs hanging out with her sister, Sam (Lily Rabe). Except that these two are intimately seated right across from each other.

A virtuoso of unease, the 33-year-old Mr. Perry makes films that seem almost calculated to go against the grain of contemporary American independent cinema. He isn‰Ûªt interested in tidy or nice stories and feelings, much less lessons, uplift, closure or relatability. His movies are talky, intimate to the point of claustrophobia, and populated by characters that can be charitably described as prickly. You wouldn‰Ûªt necessarily want to spend time with them in real life; among other things, their foibles can feel squirmingly familiar. But Mr. Perry is such a good filmmaker that he can make the embarrassing and the unbearable insistently, fascinatingly engrossing (and often funny).

‰ÛÏThe Female Brain‰Ûù is a fictionalized adaptation of a nonfiction book of the same title by the neuropsychiatrist Louann Brizendine. Armed with scientific conviction, the movie pits men‰Ûªs minds against women‰Ûªs with no room for overlap, and no room for those identities that exist outside the male and female categories. With tender performances and dubious conclusions, this story is best appreciated as an explanation for why people seek out the false comfort of gendered pseudoscience. But by fitting characters into formulas, ‰ÛÏThe Female Brain‰Ûù fails to observe the flexibility of human experience.

As the couples stumble through their daily frustrations, the film occasionally pauses to overlay a brain chart on the action, lighting up the glands and lobes Julia deems responsible for their behaviors. According to Julia‰Ûªs funny phrenology, Lexi criticizes Adam‰Ûªs hair and skin because her pituitary gland releases endorphins when she grooms, and Lisa adjusts a dangling bedroom mirror because her amygdala registers fear faster than Steven‰Ûªs.

Romantic comedy conventions get a brain scan in this new movie directed by the comedian Whitney Cummings. Ms. Cummings also stars as Dr. Julia Brizendine, a newly divorced neuroscientist who observes brain activity as a way to study gender. While Julia uses work to dodge dating, her long-married study subjects, Lisa (SofÌ_a Vergara) and Steven (Deon Cole) have become more platonic than romantic. In Julia‰Ûªs other case studies, Lexi (Lucy Punch) can‰Ûªt stop nit-picking her boyfriend, Adam (James Marsden), and Zoe (Cecily Strong) has let professional stress seep into her marriage to a basketball player, Greg ( Blake Griffin of the Detroit Pistons.)

Such images have given her a reputation as a grandstander and media manipulator. She counters that her methods hold powerful figures accountable and provide their often-silenced victims with a voice, ‰ÛÏeven if they can‰Ûªt have justice in the conventional setting of a court of law.‰Ûù

Ms. Allred, who specializes in women‰Ûªs rights cases, has represented many of those who have accused influential men (including Bill Cosby, Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski) of sexual assault, discrimination or other crimes. Though she also handles lower-profile cases, she‰Ûªs best known for sitting with clients behind banks of microphones, or standing in front of cameras at protests and marches.

This energetic film unabashedly supports that view as the directors, Sophie Sartain and Roberta Grossman, trace Ms. Allred‰Ûªs long history of activism. The first scene shows her speaking on Dinah Shore‰Ûªs talk show in 1977, and an excellent and well edited (Chris Callister) collection of news footage charts her legal fights and victories. Her early stands on gay rights and women‰Ûªs issues, frequently unpopular when she made them, seem prescient today.

If you haven‰Ûªt seen the lawyer Gloria Allred on television ‰ÛÓ a distinct impossibility ‰ÛÓ she now appears on movie screens in ‰ÛÏSeeing Allred,‰Ûù a documentary that‰Ûªs remarkably engaging despite treating its rough-and-tumble hero with kid gloves.

Few of Ms. Allred‰Ûªs detractors are heard from, and the directors don‰Ûªt press her to divulge too much about her personal life or to refute criticisms. (When she says she doesn‰Ûªt care what others think of her, you believe it.) Still, the filmmakers capture some revealing stories, particularly when Ms. Allred recalls her own ordeals, including a rape and her subsequent abortion. Although other scenes show us what Ms. Allred does, those moments hint at why she does it.

A good part of the picture relies on Mr. O‰ÛªMalley‰Ûªs account of his life with and without the bottle ‰ÛÓ members call it a ‰ÛÏqualification‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ during this A.A. gathering. He tells how he started in conflict mediation when, in the early ‰Ûª70s, he bought a Cambridge bar and funneled its revenue into hosting a negotiation between warring factions of Northern Ireland ‰ÛÓ a first for these groups.

Padraig O‰ÛªMalley is a scholar and what one might call an amateur diplomat. He is the peacemaker of this film‰Ûªs title. The documentary, directed by James Demo, is not a portrait of an idealist. The Irish-born Mr. O‰ÛªMalley is an often dour man, and when he speaks of his work, there are no stars in his eyes. One of his recent books, about Israel and Palestine, is called ‰ÛÏThe Two State Delusion.‰Ûù In negotiation, as the movie shows, he is pragmatic, focused and often steely.

His story is an unusual one, which the director unspools by showing Mr. O‰ÛªMalley first in a war-torn Iraq, then in the streets of Cambridge, Mass., where he teaches. (He travels so frequently he calls no place ‰ÛÏhome‰Ûù). He enters a church, and we soon understand he‰Ûªs in an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting. Filming an A.A. meeting isn‰Ûªt exactly kosher, but Mr. Demo doesn‰Ûªt show the faces of the other attendees. (It‰Ûªs not quite clear that this session hasn‰Ûªt been staged specifically for the movie.)

‰ÛÏI don‰Ûªt love anybody,‰Ûù the lanky, white-haired Mr. O‰ÛªMalley admits during one interview segment. It‰Ûªs his peculiar detachment, perhaps, that makes him good at what he does, even when the summits he hosts ‰ÛÓ he spent years in Iraq and in South Africa ‰ÛÓ yield nothing more than agreements on bilingual street signs. The movie is a fascinating portrait that is if anything too brief.

In the opening scene of ‰ÛÏDouble Lover,‰Ûù its protagonist, ChloÌ© (Marine Vacth), is seen getting her hair cut. Her wet hair, pale face and the gray background impart a simple elegance to the sequence. The following scene takes place in the bleaker confines of a gynecologist‰Ûªs office. In one shot, the screen fills with the colors pink and silver. Viewers may wonder exactly what they are seeing at first, but as the camera zooms out it becomes clear: a speculum seen from the point of view of a doctor conducting a vaginal examination. The shot dissolves into a geometrically corresponding close-up of ChloÌ©‰Ûªs eye.

Mr. Renier is clearly having a blast as the twins, but Ms. Vacth, who worked with Mr. Ozon on the 2014 film ‰ÛÏYoung and Beautiful,‰Ûù does more than hold her own opposite him. She modulates ChloÌ©‰Ûªs mood from slumping vulnerability to hip-swinging confidence, from a whirlpool of self-doubt and near despair to defiance. ‰ÛÏDouble Lover‰Ûù is as much, if not more, Ms. Vacth‰Ûªs movie as it is the director‰Ûªs.

What‰Ûªs going on here? The doubling imagery, the recurring spiral staircases, and so much else engulfing ChloÌ© make this thriller unusually engrossing. ‰ÛÏDouble Lover‰Ûù nods a bit to David Cronenberg‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏDead Ringers‰Ûù (1988) and Roman Polanski‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Tenant‰Ûù (1976), two arguably classic thrillers on doppelgÌ_ngers and madness, and Mr. Ozon‰Ûªs stylistic gymnastics sometimes bring to mind Brian De Palma, who made a film about good/bad twins early in his career. But ‰ÛÏDouble Lover,‰Ûù which Mr. Ozon ‰ÛÏfreely adapted‰Ûù from the Joyce Carol Oates book ‰ÛÏLives of the Twins,‰Ûù spins its influences into a frenzy that ultimately reveals the story to be very much its own thing. And a crazy, and eventually strangely moving, thing it is. As elaborate as its visuals are, the movie is also intimate. There aren‰Ûªt many characters besides ChloÌ© and the twins, which adds to the frisson late in the movie when the great Jacqueline Bisset makes her entrance.

The straightforward explicitness of the imagery is a hallmark of FranÌ_ois Ozon, the film‰Ûªs director (his best known films include the thrillers ‰ÛÏSee the Sea‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏSwimming Pool‰Ûù); the juxtaposition is very Georges Bataille (he wrote a piece of outrÌ© eroticism titled ‰ÛÏStory of the Eye‰Ûù). Some might say it‰Ûªs all very French, and perhaps it is. But it does make one sit up and take notice. The clever thing about it is that it‰Ûªs not until the movie is almost over that the viewer can fully understand this imagery as something more than an effective, but perhaps idle provocation.

ChloÌ©, looking underweight, has complained about chronic stomach pains to her gynecologist. And on that doctor‰Ûªs advice, she starts seeing a psychoanalyst, Paul (JÌ©rÌ©mie Renier). He‰Ûªs handsome, gentle, compassionate. He ‰ÛÏcures‰Ûù her, they confess romantic feelings for each other, and they move in together. One small glitch is that he does not much care for her cat Milo. A bigger glitch comes soon after that: ChloÌ© meets another psychoanalyst, Paul‰Ûªs double, who claims to be his twin brother. He‰Ûªs a rougher character who likes his own cat, a specimen of a rare breed. He thinks he can cure ChloÌ© of a new complaint, and there‰Ûªs lots of athletic sex involved in the treatment.

Pari (Elmira Rafizadeh), the prostitute, needs a judge (Hasan Ali Mete) to sign her divorce papers. She lives in an apartment he owns and trades sex for his influence, which later helps ensure her son‰Ûªs enrollment at school.

‰ÛÏTehran Taboo‰Ûù gains much of its power from its use of rotoscoping, a form of animation (familiar to viewers of ‰ÛÏWaking Life‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏTower‰Ûù) in which the drawing is done over filmed actors. What is provocative about the technique here is that it‰Ûªs a sort of workaround ‰ÛÓ a way for the director, Ali Soozandeh, who grew up in Iran and now lives in Germany, to tell a story that he says would have been impossible to film in Tehran.

Subtlety and aesthetic elegance ‰ÛÓ the jerky animation complements the blunt tone ‰ÛÓ are not among the film‰Ûªs virtues. ‰ÛÏTehran Taboo‰Ûù aims to expose systemic hypocrisy; in that respect, it is brisk and bracing.

One of Pari‰Ûªs neighbors is Sara (Zar Amir Ebrahimi), who is uneasy about her latest pregnancy and also wants to take a job, which she can‰Ûªt do without her husband‰Ûªs permission. The other principal thread concerns a musician, Babak (Arash Marandi), who, after a nightclub tryst with Donya (Negar Mona Alizadeh), has a week to pay for an unsanitary quack doctor with a hacking cough to restore the appearance of her virginity.

An ensemble piece (and European production, despite the Persian dialogue), the movie lays bare the double standards that surround sex in Iran. Its confrontational quality is established in the opening scene: A driver picks up a prostitute who is turning tricks with her young son in tow ‰ÛÓ and moments later expresses horror when he spots a man holding hands with his daughter.

But I would not go so far as to say that ‰ÛÏEarly Man‰Ûù is entirely devoid of historical interest. Its structuring myth is the loss of Arcadia. A peaceful and authentic way of life is threatened with destruction by the forces of modernity, and the threat is resisted in a stirring and potentially tragic show of courage. The encounter between the simple, primitive folk and their more sophisticated would-be conquerors may remind you of the films of Mel Gibson. Mr. Park has essentially remade ‰ÛÏApocalypto‰Ûù but with soccer instead of human sacrifice, ‰ÛÏBraveheart‰Ûù with a giant stop-motion duck.

Just like us! Humanity, I mean, in our primal, primitive state, to which ‰ÛÏEarly Man‰Ûù pays paradoxically sophisticated tribute. You remember how it was, before we got all snooty and fancy and mean: One of us fell down, the rest of us doubled over in mirth, and someone else made a picture so we could laugh at the thing all over again as many times as we wanted.

It would be pedantic in the extreme to fault this movie for its inaccurate rendering of the past. Did mammoths‰Ûª feet in ancient times walk upon England‰Ûªs green and pleasant land? Does the fossil record contain evidence of a mallard the size of a 727? You might as well ask if there are La Brea Tar Pits in Scotland. As Bugs Bunny will tell you, there are no La Brea Tar Pits in Scotland.

My feelings about ‰ÛÏEarly Man‰Ûù can be summed up as better late than never. I‰Ûªm a little sorry that this utterly silly feature from Nick Park and Aardman Animations was not around when I was 7 or 8 years old, or when my children were wearing out the Wallace and Gromit videocassettes that someone had given them for Christmas. Not that anyone could outgrow this kind of movie, which manages to be fresh and delightful even as some of its jokes are so old ‰ÛÓ how old? So old that the last time I heard them, I fell off my dinosaur I was laughing so hard.

First, though, they must face the villainy of the Bronze Agers, soccer-mad imperialists led by a classic Aardman baddie named Lord Nooth (Tom Hiddleston). He has what sounds suspiciously like a French accent, though he answers ‰ÛÓ mostly via bird-enabled instant messaging ‰ÛÓ to a very British queen (Miriam Margolyes). His footballers are cosmopolitan superstars whose skills are as formidable as their egos. For reasons too ridiculous to summarize (and yet also absolutely persuasive), Dug and his mates must master the beautiful game and face off against Lord Nooth‰Ûªs squad.

Another way to look at this movie might be as an artisanal cartoon exploration of the story told by the Yale political scientist James Scott in his recent book ‰ÛÏAgainst the Grain.‰Ûù According to Mr. Scott (no relation to the present writer), the rise of states ‰ÛÓ of political authority, organized violence, accumulated wealth and everything else we associate with the advance of civilization ‰ÛÓ was a disaster for our species: a blow to our autonomy, our solidarity, our moral and physical health. Or, to put the argument in ‰ÛÏEarly Man‰Ûù terms, we were happier when we were chasing rabbits instead of building monuments, fighting wars and paying taxes. The rabbits, all things considered, were probably happier, too.

You might believe that you are too refined to giggle at even one not-too-naughty double-entendre about the fact that soccer is played with balls, let alone a dozen or so. You are so wrong. If you‰Ûªre a Premier League fan, you might beat the script to a joke about ‰ÛÏEarly Man United‰Ûù by a good hour and still laugh like an idiot when it arrives. I could write 500 more words explaining the semiotics of the big duck routine, and you would still be amazed by how brilliant and how dumb it is at the same time.

Does this ragtag band of misfits, coached by a renegade named Goona (Maisie Williams), stand a chance against a bunch of hot shots with flowing locks, fancy uniforms, and all the talent and training that Nooth‰Ûªs lucre can buy? You tell me. The genius of ‰ÛÏEarly Man‰Ûù is that it cannot possibly be spoiled. The animation is foolproof in its combination of ingenuity and obviousness, and the script obliterates the difference between a laugher and a groaner.

The movie swears allegiance to that halcyon, carefree world, where humor is a matter of laughing with rather than at. The laws of gravity and the innate clumsiness of the human body are always good for a chuckle, and nobody really gets hurt. Dug (Eddie Redmayne), a friendly nincompoop with the usual Aardman features ‰ÛÓ a wide rubbery mouth holding a few blunt teeth; a narrow brow; wide, placid eyes ‰ÛÓ lives happily in an easygoing society with minimal hierarchy and ample leisure time. (The chief, voiced by Timothy Spall, is more camp counselor than warlord.) Dug and his pals are oblivious to the future and dimly aware of the past. Ancient drawings point to a vaguely recollected moment of origin, a creation story that the audience already knows (it‰Ûªs the opening scene) and will eventually be rediscovered.

About that: In prehistoric times, according to Mr. Park and the screenwriters (Mark Burton and James Higginson), cave men and giant lizards shared the planet for a while. A bit later, descendants of those same cave-dwellers ‰ÛÓ a band of genial, not-too-bright hunter-gatherers in a verdant valley near what is now Manchester, England ‰ÛÓ coexisted uneasily with a more aggressive and arrogant breed of humans, who mastered metallurgy, stadium-building and sports commentary. ‰ÛÏThe age of stone is over. The age of bronze is here,‰Ûù they proclaim as they drive the Stone Agers into the wasteland.

The hip-hop entrepreneur Damon Dash has been producing and directing motion pictures since the late 1990s. You‰Ûªd never know it from looking at ‰ÛÏHonor Up,‰Ûù a new movie he directed from a script he wrote with Kevin Bennett.

The filmmaking is point-and-shoot rudimentary (when it wants to get fancy, it resorts to split-screen effects that bring to mind the 1980s production software called Video Toaster). The acting is awkward (Mr. Dash himself has a leading role), and the characters themselves indifferently delineated. ClichÌ©s are rife, both in dialogue (‰ÛÏSometimes good guys have to do bad things‰Ûù) and construction (shootout scenes are frequently scored to arias and fake-arias sung by Radmila Lolly).

Nicholas Turturro as a relentless and racist cop, and Eishia Brightwell as the ostensibly ‰ÛÏoff limits‰Ûù sister of a dealer who tries to get herself a piece of gang action, make particularly vivid impressions. For all of its failings, the movie sometimes manages to bring a scary whiff of the street into its sounds and images.

And yet this anecdotal movie about drug dealers and their internecine troubles, and their further troubles with the justice system, can be oddly persuasive. Narrated by Mr. Dash‰Ûªs character, named O.G., the movie begins by laying out the meaning of the title phrase. Which is pretty much what you‰Ûªd infer: that you don‰Ûªt rat out your partners in the criminal enterprise that players call ‰ÛÏthe game.‰Ûù The movie then shows various gang members and rivals facing each other down, wiping each other out, and eventually giving each other up.

Mark Pellington‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏNostalgia‰Ûù is the kind of heartfelt wallow that you feel like a heel for attacking. A soggy string of Hallmark moments designed to interrogate the value of the objects we cherish, the movie is front-loaded with major stars and squelching with sentiment. To say it‰Ûªs depressing, then, is to state the obvious; less evident is why Mr. Pellington, previously known for suspenseful thrillers like ‰ÛÏArlington Road‰Ûù and ‰ÛÏThe Mothman Prophecies,‰Ûù would dive down this rabbit hole at all.

Beset by a moony piano and maudlin musings about the stuff we carry (‰ÛÏCan what we hold in our hands be the same as what we hold in our hearts?‰Ûù), the film follows for a time an eye-rollingly empathetic insurance assessor (John Ortiz) as he helps bereaved clients answer that question. A lonely octogenarian (Bruce Dern) prepares for death by taking inventory of his possessions; a distraught widow (Ellen Burstyn) salvages keepsakes from her burned-out home.
Fascinated by the Portuguese word ‰ÛÏsaudade,‰Ûù Kathleen defines it as ‰ÛÏa pleasure you suffer, a pain you enjoy.‰Ûù If that‰Ûªs what Mr. Pellington was going for, he was half successful.

Picking up the narrative baton, Jon Hamm takes over as the most softhearted collectibles expert ever. But it‰Ûªs here, in the movie‰Ûªs longest section, that this repetitive dirge ‰ÛÓ inspired by a 2013 article in The New York Times ‰ÛÓ gains thematic heft from exceptionally strong performances. Catherine Keener and James LeGros excel as a grieving couple, and Mikey Madison (riveting as the eldest daughter in FX‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏBetter Things,‰Ûù) is so moving as Kathleen, a mourning teenager, that we want to give her her own movie.

In ‰ÛÏThe Boy Downstairs,‰Ûù a debut feature from the writer and director Sophie Brooks, not only do Diana and Ben live in the same brownstone, but Ben is also dating Meg, the real estate agent who showed Diana the apartment. Meg (Sarah Ramos) is a former good friend of Diana‰Ûªs bestie, Gabby (Diana Irvine). And Brooklyn has a fourth resident, Amy (Deirdre O‰ÛªConnell), a kind landlord who is always there to provide wise counsel to Diana ‰ÛÓ an aspiring writer, of course.

‰ÛÏThere are eight million stories in the naked city,‰Ûù the narrator of that classic crime movie said. But there are, apparently, so few apartments in contemporary Brooklyn that Diana (Zosia Mamet) can unwittingly move into the same building as Ben (Matthew Shear), the former boyfriend she dumped three years earlier before she moved to London.

How, and in whose apartment, Diana and Ben will confess their emotions is the subject of Ms. Brooks‰Ûªs pallid dramedy, which leaves its actors looking somewhat stranded, as if waiting for Neil Simon zingers that were never written. It doesn‰Ûªt matter that there‰Ûªs little suspense to the central romance (Ben and Diana still obviously have feelings for each other); people don‰Ûªt always resolve their confusion in real time. That‰Ûªs roughly the speed, however, at which ‰ÛÏThe Boy Downstairs‰Ûù seems to play.

Shot in Vietnam (where it was released in 2016), ‰ÛÏThe Housemaid‰Ûù is an ambitious, atmospheric first feature that ‰ÛÓ notwithstanding a rather nifty twist at the end ‰ÛÓ would have benefited from a more rigorous editor. It‰Ûªs a setting so fertile with real-life horrors that any narrative embellishment can only feel like too much of a bad thing.

Drawing equally from Hitchcock and the clammy scares of Japanese horror movies like ‰ÛÏJu-on: The Grudge‰Ûù (2002), Mr. Nguyen whips up a spectral stew of past atrocities and present-day hanky-panky. Lush, verdant exteriors ‰ÛÓ vibrantly photographed by Sam Chase ‰ÛÓ define a plantation where, according to Sebastien‰Ûªs garrulous cook, hundreds of Vietnamese workers were brutalized. Bleeding foliage and a mass grave back her up, but the movie‰Ûªs invocation of slavery and Holocaust-like imagery feels overshadowed and muted by its soapy center.

Mixing a lathered-up love triangle with a ghostly murder-mystery, Derek Nguyen‰Ûªs ‰ÛÏThe Housemaid‰Ûù wraps a painful chapter in Vietnamese history in Gothic-melodrama trappings. The result is a good-looking but overstuffed genre pileup that confuses as often as it compels.

Set in 1953 when Vietnam was under French colonial rule, the story ‰ÛÓ inspired by the recollections of Mr. Nguyen‰Ûªs grandmother, a former housemaid ‰ÛÓ takes place on a sprawling rubber plantation belonging to Sebastien (Jean-Michel Richaud), a handsome French officer. When an orphan named Linh (Nhung Kate) joins his small house staff, she enters a terrifying world where creaks and whispers and vibrating strings follow her from room to room. Everyone, it seems, harbors shameful secrets, not least the house itself, where Sebastien‰Ûªs wife and baby died and a wraithlike apparition flits and hovers.

These secrets also slowly leak out over the course of a 71-minute black-and-white movie that mostly comes off like a futile filmmaking exercise in how to move bodies inside a (largely) confined space. It‰Ûªs a familiar conceit: Place a group of actors inside a box and go! (Hitchcock was a master of this: ‰ÛÏLifeboat,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏRope,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏRear Window‰Ûù and most of ‰ÛÏDial M for Murder.‰Ûù) You get to know this part of Janet and Bill‰Ûªs home ‰ÛÓ the kitchen, bathroom and a living room that lets out onto a courtyard ‰ÛÓ fairly intimately because Ms. Potter gives the characters plenty of reasons to move from one space to another. One snorts drugs in the bathroom, another takes weeping refuge in it, a third hurls in the toilet, while others meander here and there.

Bill‰Ûªs bearing is matched by his bleak story, which leaks out over the course of this grindingly unhappy affair. Written and directed by Sally Potter, who has made other movies worth seeing ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏThriller,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏOrlando,‰Ûù ‰ÛÏGinger & Rosa‰Ûù ‰ÛÓ ‰ÛÏThe Party‰Ûù is a brittle, unfunny attempt at comedy that features some very fine actors and a lot of empty chatter. It takes place inside a few rooms on the ground-level floor of Bill and Janet‰Ûªs comfortable London digs. There, they are giving a party to celebrate Janet‰Ûªs recent appointment as a government functionary of the unnamed opposition party. From the way she furtively coos into her cellphone, it is clear that Janet has some secrets.

Timothy Spall looks so defeated in ‰ÛÏThe Party‰Ûù it‰Ûªs a wonder he isn‰Ûªt waving a white flag. His body droops and his face sags, jowls draping under a thatch of beard. He‰Ûªs playing Bill, who‰Ûªs somewhat of a mystery man. For a long while, all that you really know about Bill is that he‰Ûªs married to Janet (Kristin Scott Thomas), the woman cheerfully bustling in the kitchen. Also: He likes vinyl. Every so often, Bill miraculously manages to gather together his flaccid bits so he can put on a record. Then, with a bottle of wine by his side, he collapses back into his chair, resuming his man-of-sorrows pose.

As to what happens, well, there are shards of drama and melodrama, many meant to cut and hurt. Janet‰Ûªs triumph is soon dampened and eventually spoiled by her friends, most of whom prove a convenient, presumably emblematic collection of narcissists. It‰Ûªs all about them, their lives and needs, which they readily share, turning the festivities into a group-therapy session. The funniest and meanest of Janet‰Ûªs pals is played by Patricia Clarkson, and while you don‰Ûªt believe her character for a second, the performance ‰ÛÓ Ms. Clarkson‰Ûªs supple nonchalance suggests years of practiced cruelty ‰ÛÓ is enjoyable. Cherry Jones, Emily Mortimer, Bruno Ganz and Cillian Murphy also enter and deliver lines.

Ms. Potter stirs things up, though to no identifiable end. Characters talk and talk, mostly at one another, and they bitch, argue and fight.
